Through the experimentation it observed that the impact of adding NMOS, PMOS, and a combination of both is a significant reduction in leakage power in the majority of setups, along with a noticeable increase in speed during read and write operations. The work concludes that the sleeper cell composed of NMOS and PMOS appeared to balance speed and power savings the best during the sleeper cell analysis process in comparison with sleeper cell designed exclusively by PMOS and NMOS. With the introduction of sleeper cells made up of both NMOS and PMOS, a 90% reduction in power leakage is achieved. The obtained results clearly show that the deployment of sleeper transistors in SRAM designs can result in a memory unit that is more energy-efficient for modern SoCs and portable electronics.

title: Intelligent Three-Phase Imbalance Optimization Considering Participation Willingness of Flexible Resources: A Deep Learning Approach
authors: Xin Chen, Zheling Zhou, Weisheng Xu, Hongshi Chen, Xiang Zheng, Yingmou Chen
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Smart Grid and Clean Energy Technologies (ICSGCE)
abstract: With the rapid penetration of distributed energy resources and single-phase loads in distribution networks, three-phase imbalance has emerged as a critical power quality issue affecting system efficiency and equipment lifespan. Traditional imbalance mitigation approaches often overlook user participation willingness and the heterogeneous characteristics of different flexible resources, leading to suboptimal performance and low user satisfaction. This paper proposes an intelligent three-phase imbalance optimization method that considers the participation willingness of various flexible resources including residential air conditioners, commercial air conditioners, electric vehicles, water heaters, and distributed energy storage systems. A Long Short-Term Memory neural network is employed to predict user participation willingness based on historical behavior patterns, economic incentives, and temporal characteristics. A multi-objective optimization framework is developed to balance imbalance mitigation and user comfort through coordinated control strategies. The proposed elastic willingness guidance mechanism dynamically adjusts incentive strategies based on three-phase imbalance severity levels. Simulation results on a typical distribution network demonstrate that the proposed method reduces three-phase imbalance violations while maintaining user comfort levels above acceptable thresholds, achieving improvements in power quality and user satisfaction compared to conventional approaches.

title: AI-Driven Cybersecurity: Predictive Insights Into Attack Patterns and Effective Preventive Strategies
authors: Suhas Chavan, Rajneeshkaur Sachdeo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: The tremendous growth of digital technology transformed several domains, making them increasingly susceptible to a growing spectrum of cyber-attacks. This paper investigates the multifacted picture of cyberattacks, and specifically of the adversarial threats, which leverage vulnerabilities within AI systems. As cyber attackers become more and more sophisticated with their attacks, the old cybersecurity defenses become less effective, thus highlighting an increased need for implementation of more defensive strategies. This paper provides a survey about different types of cyberattacks such as phishing, ransomware and adversarial attacks, that affect Aidriven systems and shows their impacts on such systems. Furthermore, the paper investigates advanced AI approaches for threat detection and response such as ML and deep learning which are used for fast discovery and suppression of new cyber threats. The article also stresses that a defense-in-depth approach combining AI capabilities and conventional security policies is required to mitigate the attack surface. Finally, this research attempts to advance the broader discussion on computer security by shedding light on the perils from adversarial attacks and by offering practical prevention strategies.

title: Comparative Analysis of Fault Detection Techniques for Edge Enabled Smart Power Grids
authors: Jayashree Kulkarni
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: The increasing complexity of modern power grids and utilization of renewable sources of energy necessitate faster and more reliable methods of fault detection. Conventional centralized monitoring tends to be delayed, suffers from bandwidth constraints, and is not scalable. Edge computing presents a convincing alternative due to data analysis near the source. This research explores how edge computing can enhance power grid fault detection, with an emphasis on how rapid fault detections are avoided. There is a comparison with conventional cloud-based systems with improved response times, energy consumption, and system reliability. Various fault detection methods, such as Wavelet Transform-based thresholding, Zscore anomaly detection, and Isolation Forest algorithm are compared. The performance indicates that although the Z-score did not detect transient disturbances and the Isolation Forest detected more anomalies (with more false advantages), the Wavelet Transform approach was the best performing and computationally most efficient for edge nodes and thus suitable for real-time fault detection in power networks.

title: Anomaly-Oriented Multi-Class Intrusion Detection Using Machine Learning and Ensemble Methods
authors: Arya Jadhav, Aadi Parkhi, Manas Bhise, Shrey Bhandari, Amar Buchade, Santosh Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: This study evaluates six intrusion detection models using the UNSW-NB15 dataset, which serves as a modern benchmark encompassing diverse attack types and authentic traffic conditions. We analyze four traditional classifiers (Random Forest, XGBoost, SVM, and Logistic Regression), one deep learning approach (MLP + Autoencoder), and a stacking ensemble featuring RF, XGB, and SVM as base models with XGBoost as the meta model. Surprisingly, although ensemble and deep models are highly complex, Random Forest attained top macro-F1 and accuracy, especially performing well on minority classes. Preprocessing methods such as SMOTE and one-hot encoding played a significant role in feature balancing and encoding. Results point to RF as a robust, interpretable baseline. Future directions are diverse ensembles, hybrid DLML frameworks, and explainable AI.

title: A Lightweight Real-Time Dual-Metric System for Bicep Curl Form Correction
authors: Pradyumna Wagholikar, Ravindra B. Murumkar
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: Correct execution of strength-training exercises is critical for maximizing performance and minimizing injury risk. Automated systems that can monitor posture and provide immediate feedback are therefore of increasing importance in fitness applications. This research presents a real-time, vision-based system for the analysis and correction of bicep curl form, utilizing the MediaPipe Pose framework for landmark detection. The primary contribution is a dualmetric evaluation method that concurrently assesses the elbow flexion angle and the spatial stability of the elbow joint. This method enables the real-time identification of biomechanical errors, such as excessive joint displacement, while tracking repetitions based on adherence to a target angular range. The efficacy of this approach is validated through a quantitative analysis of captured motion data, which demonstrates a clear correlation between decreased joint stability and the terminal phases of flexion and extension. The framework operates in real time on standard consumer hardware, demonstrating the potential of lightweight vision-based systems for accessible fitness training.

title: Face Clustering Based on Local Identity Relation Estimation and Conservative Edge Expansion
authors: Jong-Hyeon Baek, Yeong Jun Koh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: Face clustering aims to group unlabeled face images into identity-consistent clusters and is essential for large-scale face retrieval and dataset construction. However, existing graph-based methods often suffer from false positive connections and limited recall in complex feature spaces. This paper introduces a robust face clustering framework that addresses these challenges through two key components. First, the proposed local identity relation estimation network (LIRENet) verifies edge reliability by modeling both local context and identity-level interactions. Second, a neighborhood edge extension module adaptively expands the graph using shared neighbor constraints and similarity thresholds. The combination of these components enhances connectivity prediction while preserving cluster quality. Experimental results on MS-Celeb-1M, IJB-B, and DeepFashion demonstrate consistent improvements over previous state-of-the-art methods on both closed- and open-set benchmarks.

title: Unlocked Learning: How Educators Navigate AI in Open Education Spaces
authors: Abdelhak Senadjki, Hui-Nee Au Yong, Iddrisu Mohammed Awal, Samuel Ogbeibu
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: With the changing face of open learning because of the involvement of artificial intelligence (AI), the education sector is presented with new possibilities and intricate ambiguities. Although most of the existing discussions focus on technological innovation, the opinions of educators, who are the ones who are experiencing the influence of AI in pedagogy and access, have not been voiced yet. The proposed research seeks to address the question of how teachers of various backgrounds view and experience the use of AI in the open learning setting. A qualitative research design was used to gather data using in-depth interviews and focus group discussions with 30 educators selected in terms of disciplines, institutions, and regions. Five major themes have been uncovered: (1) AI tools are perceived as a means to improve administrative efficiency but not to substitute pedagogical judgment; (2) there are concerns about algorithmic bias, learner data privacy, and cultural neutrality; (3) AI-driven platforms can create digital divides unless equitably deployed; (4) educators want to have more agency and training in the adoption of AI; and (5) attitudes and preparedness toward AI depend heavily on disciplinary and regional contexts. The results indicate that inclusive AI policies should put a lot of emphasis on the voice of educators, contextual awareness, and lifelong learning. To make AI truly useful in open learning, systems should shift away from automation to supporting educators as co-designers of equitable, AI-enhanced learning.

title: Intelligent Route Optimization Framework with IoT Integration for Efficient Waste Collection Trucks
authors: Nivethitha T, Abinav G, Dhanushwaran S, Gowshik M, Hanshan Kumar B, Hariharan S
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Inefficient collection of the traditional waste is based on fixed routes and schedules with overflowing bins, fuel wastage and higher costs. In this paper, a proposal will be provided regarding an Internet of Things (IoT) intelligent route optimization framework that utilizes real-time sensor data, machine learning predictions, and dynamically planned routes. The system utilizes the ultrasonic and MQ-135 gas sensors to measure the fill and odor levels on waste containers that are connected to ESP32 microcontrollers. A real-time dashboard is available on a Flask basis and offers administration. A nearest-neighbor greedy algorithm is used to perform route optimization with a Haversine distance calculation and bin fill-time prediction is done with a Random Forest Regressor model using various environmental and temporal features. The finding of simulation shows that efficiency of routes can improve by 15-30 percent, using resources can be saved, and functioning can improve, which opens the way towards sustainable smart city waste management.

title: Location-Supported Lesions Representation with Potato Leaf Blight Disease Detection Using Dual-Head Convolutional Neural Network
authors: Y. V. Bhaskar Reddy, Imad Shalout, K. Latha, Rajkumar Bhookya, Swathi B, R. Premkumar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: A deep learning framework designed for classifying potato leaf blight diseases using the Plant Village Dataset, we developed the Location-Supported Lesions Representation with Potato Leaf Blight Disease Detection Using Dual-Head Convolutional Neural Network (LLPLDC) model which consists of 2,152 processed images. To improve model generalization and tackle data imbalance, the dataset undergoes noise removal and augmentation. A Diffusion-based IGN-Net generates synthetic images of diseased leaves from healthy ones, the DH-CNN features dual outputs: one for identifying healthy versus diseased leaves and another for differentiating between early and late blight. Training utilizes stochastic gradient descent with learning rate adjustments and ReLU activations, enhancing classification accuracy. The confusion matrix, training and validation loss and accuracy of DHCNN and ROC curve are used to calculate the performance of LLPLDC.

title: Cognitive Cyber Armor: AI-Driven Resilience against Intelligent Threat Actors
authors: Mohammad Majharul Islam Jabed, Muntaha Islam, Lamia Akter, Sharmin Ferdous, Sakera Begum, Amit Banwari Gupta
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Substantial advancement of cyberattacks necessitates smart defense systems that have the ability to adjust to changing threat horizons. The following paper is about Cognitive Cyber Armor, an AI-based resilience model that uses sophisticated learning methods to neutralize intelligent threat agents. The suggested algorithm combines the Robust PCA to pre-process the data to remove noise and improve the signal quality, mRMR to select the features and maximize the relevant characteristics, and a Graph Attention Network classifier to detect the malicious actions. The system is implemented in Python with PyTorch and PyTorch Geometric and is associated with high accuracy in detection and low false-positives but better interpretability with regard to attention-based graph modeling. The results of the experiments point to its effectiveness in eliminating redundancy, achieving processing speed, and maintaining a strong performance even in adversarial situations. Cognitive Cyber Armor can be used to develop a scalable defense paradigm by integrating resilience, adaptability, and explainability, further developing proactive approaches to cybersecurity to secure against intelligent and adaptable cyber threats against major infrastructures.

title: Analysis of Kannada Tweets for Depression using Machine Learning Models
authors: V D Praveen, K Soorya Krishna, Smeely Mary Picardo, Aishwarya, Prashanth Kannadaguli
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Computing, Semiconductor, Mechatronics, Intelligent Systems and Communications (COSMIC)
abstract: The expanding role of social media has positioned platforms like X, Facebook, and WhatsApp as critical spaces for individuals to convey their thoughts and emotions instantaneously. This study focuses on the classifying users as depressive or non-depressive based on their social media posts in Kannada using machine learning techniques. Kannada’s distinct linguistic characteristics and scarcity of language resources create specific challenges for Natural Language Processing. In the present work, Machine Learning algorithms are used to find the indications of depressive thoughts of the user based on the tweets. This can then be used further for providing necessary aid and counselling to the depressed persons. A labelled dataset of Kannada tweets, adapted from the Sentiment140 corpus, was utilized in this study. Pre-processing techniques including tokenization, stop-word removal, vectorization and lemmatization using Word2Vec were applied. Logistic Regression, Extreme Gradient Boost, Ridge Classifier, Linear Discriminant Analysis and Stochastic Gradient Descent Classifier were trained using the vectorized dataset with their performance being evaluated using metrics accuracy and the Area Under the Curve score. The Linear Discriminant Analysis outperformed the chosen models with $79.95 \%$ accuracy.

title: Speed Control of DC Motor with Microcontroller Using Hand Gestures
authors: T.D. Sudhakar, R Nitish, H Aqeel, M Mohamed Askar, R R Prajesh, K Boopathy
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: This paper explores an innovative approach to adjusting the DC motor speed by hand gestures detected through a laptop camera, integrating image processing and microcontroller technology. Traditional methods of motor speed control often rely on physical interfaces like knobs, switches, or keypads. However, the proposed system leverages computer vision to interpret real-time hand movements, which are processed through software to generate appropriate signals. These indications are transmitted to a microcontroller (such as an Arduino), which adjusts the motor's speed via a motor driver. The goal is to generate a touch-free, intuitive control mechanism which enhances user interaction and reduces mechanical wear from physical components.

title: “CryptoKalp”: A Tool for Cryptocurrency Investigation
authors: Sanjita Jain, Rupprashik Khare, Samyak Lahire, Chaitali Patil
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: There are more than over 23,000 cryptocurrencies” in existence which represent one of the biggest unregulated markets across the globe. Currently, each cryptocurrency utilises distinct public-private key and public address formats. This diversity complicates the investigator's task of tracing and verifying a suspect's involvement in cryptocurrency-related crimes. Moreover, law enforcement agencies such as the police frequently seize digital devices, generating digital disk images for investigation which is a time consuming process. Thus, the investigation of cryptocurrencies has emerged as a major challenge. for law enforcement agencies across the world. Our proposed solution “CryptoKalp” aims to combat cybercrimes involving cryptocurrencies. The essence of our proposed tool is encapsulated in its name: “CryptoKalp.” The name is a fusion of two significant terms - “crypto,” signifying cryptocurrency, and “kalp,” a Sanskrit word representing investigation [1]. Our proposed tool makes the investigation process quicker by taking digital images, strings, various formats of files and folders as input and utilising a comprehensive database of regular expressions covering various cryptocurrency public-private key and address formats. Currently, our tool successfully identifies Bitcoin public-private keys and addresses from text files, with future plans outlined expanding its capabilities for Ether, Tether, Monero, Dash and Dogecoin. Investigating officers can access the system's user-friendly interface and the database containing login credentials, cryptocurrency formats, and history of searched strings, which enables officers to track a specific criminal associated with a series of crypto transactions. Police can confirm whether a suspect is involved in cryptocurrency transactions and take necessary actions. Our solution will aid law enforcement authorities in combating cybercrime.

title: AI based Assistive Device For Aphasia Elderly Patients
authors: N.N. Baalakumar, S. Prabakar, K.Mythili, N.Naveen, M.Sabharigirivasan, S.Mathan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Communication is a very crucial part of human interaction, and it enables people to express their ideas, wants, and feelings. Aphasia is a language disorder that is commonly caused by stroke or brain damages, which impairs speech comprehension and production, but cognitive and motor skills are generally unaffected. As a result, there are extreme communication barriers among the affected individuals in their everyday lives. This paper introduces an AI-supported communication system that combines the real-time hand gesture recognition with the text-to-speech features to support aphasic people. The Python based system which is implemented using OpenCV library uses a web camera to record and read the hand gestures, depending on the number of extended fingers. Every gesture is associated with a prepared verbal communication, e.g. one finger means I need water and two fingers I am hungry. The identified gestures are translated into audio both with the offline (pyttsx3) and online (Google Text-to-Speech) engines to provide the flexibility when different network conditions occur. The device is affordable, portable, and very easy to use and it only needs a normal computer and a webcam. It has a modular design whereby one can easily customize gestures and message mappings to suit personal requirements. The future products are to introduce machine learning based on dynamic gesture recognition, speech support in multiple languages and the implementation of the product on the mobile platform to increase its accessibility. The suggested system demonstrates the possibilities of computer and AI. mission to create all-inclusive, low-cost technologies that will contribute much to the quality of life of people with speech and language impairments.

title: SIGNAL: Stereo Image Neural Learner for Continuous Super-Resolution
authors: Xu Liu, Yang Zhao, Yuan Chen, Xinjie Li, Zhao Zhang, Wei Jia
publish: IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics
abstract: Stereo images are widely used in many scenarios such as autonomous driving and stereoscopic display. Stereo image super-resolution is a common technique to obtain high-definition stereo images. However, existing methods are mainly designed for fixed scales and cannot smoothly support arbitrary upscaling. To address these problems, this paper proposes a Stereo ImaGe NeurAl Learner (SIGNAL) based on implicit neural representation, which consists of three parts. First, a feature extraction module leveraging the iPASSR architecture to robustly extract hierarchical features from low-resolution stereo images. Second, a novel stereo implicit representation module that explicitly models the inherent geometric consistency and contextual relationships between the two views, enhancing the latent features through view-specific and cross-view interactions. Third, a cross-view decoding module designed to fully exploit the complementary information across views during the image reconstruction process. Extensive experiments across diverse datasets demonstrate that the proposed SIGNAL framework achieves superior performance. The results underscore the effectiveness of our approach in handling arbitrary scaling factors while preserving visual fidelity in stereo image restoration.

title: Enabling “see-and-Point” Communication Between Robots
authors: Huangwei Wu, Weiguo Wang, Meng Jin, Zhuxuan He, Qi Cao, Xinbing Wang, Chenghu Zhou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: This paper proposes a novel address mapping mechanism for multi-robot communication and collaboration systems, named SPing. SPing addresses each robot with a dynamic physical-world address - an encoding of the robot's physical location - rather than a pre-assigned digital-world ID (e.g., the IP address). This enables a “see-and-point” communication mode for robots: a robot can establish an immediate connection pointing to any other robot it intends to collaborate with in its visual field, without relying on a pre-existing multi-robot network. This on one hand improves the robustness and usefulness of multi-robot systems in uncertain and unstructured environments where network infrastructures are unavailable. On the other hand, it makes the robots' communication behavior tightly coupled with and more supportive of the collaboration tasks in the physical world. We build an end-to-end prototype of SPing and evaluate its performance in both static and mobile scenarios. The results show that SPing can always establish a connection precisely pointing to the target receiver with an average matching rate of 99.58%, and a spatial resolution of 0.3 m$\sim$ 0.5m.

title: Enhancing UAV Intrusion Detection Against Adversarial Samples Based on AdvGAN and Decision Boundary Reconstruction
authors: Mengyang Li, Yongze Jin, Wenjiang Ji, Junqi Liu, Jing Xin, Yichuan Wang, Xinhong Hei
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: With the widespread application of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), intrusion detection based on wireless communication traffic has become increasingly critical. While deep learning (DL) models have significantly enhanced anomaly detection accuracy, recent research indicates that they remain vulnerable to adversarial sample attacks, which poses severe threats to the open communication networks used by UAV systems. To address this challenge, an enhanced UAV intrusion detection framework is proposed for defending against adversarial samples, integrating generating adversarial samples with adversarial networks (AdvGAN) and decision boundary reconstruction. Specifically, a convolutional neural network (CNN) is first developed as the baseline intrusion detection model to detect anomalous traffic in UAV wireless communication. Subsequently, to overcome the gradient-dependent perturbation limitations of traditional adversarial attack methods, AdvGAN is employed to analyze real monitored traffic data and generate semantically consistent adversarial samples that retain the intrinsic characteristics of authentic network flow. Finally, a hybrid adversarial-real data training strategy is proposed to dynamically reconstruct the model’s intrusion decision boundaries. This strategy augments the training dataset with AdvGAN-generated adversarial samples, enabling the model to adaptively adjust decision thresholds through iterative backpropagation. On a real-world dataset, the superior performance of proposed method is verified: it maintains high detection accuracy for legitimate traffic while substantially reducing the success rate of adversarial attacks. Experimental results confirm the stealthiness of generated adversarial samples and the robustness of the enhanced detection model, validating the effectiveness of the proposed framework.

authors: Cong Yang
publish: N/A
abstract: The recent advancement of Bird’s Eye View (BEV) perception algorithms requires extensive, high-quality annotated map data for effective training and deployment in real-world scenarios. However, existing HD map-based auto-labeling methods, like those found in public datasets, face significant issues related to efficiency and accuracy. For instance, the nuScenes dataset reveals considerable misalignment and inconsistency between images and their annotations, with an average reprojection error of approximately 8.03 pixels. Additionally, the dependence on HD maps limits the applicability of these methods for large-scale, real-world auto-labeling. To tackle these challenges, we introduce CAMAv2: a vision-centric approach for Consistent and Accurate Map Annotation. This pipeline primarily utilizes camera inputs to generate precise 3D annotations of static map elements, achieving high reprojection accuracy across all surrounding cameras and maintaining spatiotemporal consistency throughout the entire sequence. Importantly, CAMAv2 annotations show lower reprojection errors compared to the original nuScenes map elements, with errors of 4.96 pixels versus 8.03 pixels. Comprehensive evaluations across various public datasets confirm the feasibility and generalizability of our pipeline in diverse environments, as well as under different weather and lighting conditions.

title: Physics-Guided Deep Learning for Battery Future Capacity and Remaining Useful Life Predictions
authors: Tianjing Wang, Jiangong Zhu, Weihan Li, Yan Xu, Zhao Yang Dong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Transportation Electrification
abstract: Accurate predictions of future capacity and remaining useful life (RUL) are critical for ensuring battery safety and prolonging lifespan. However, existing studies struggle to achieve high-accuracy long-term predictions from early cycles of battery operation. To address this limitation, this study proposes a physics-informed deep learning framework called physics-controlled differential equation (CDE) for forecasting battery capacity and RUL. The proposed approach integrates a Query-Key-Value neural CDE structure to extract attention-weighted features, effectively capturing essential battery dynamics. Furthermore, a long short-term memory-embedded neural CDE models differential relationships over time, while an empirical model periodically updates physical constraints to refine degradation trends. Experimental validation across multiple datasets demonstrates that the proposed method outperforms existing approaches by accurately reconstructing the entire capacity degradation curve from only a small number of early-cycle measurements, without requiring full-lifecycle capacity labels, while also providing reliable RUL predictions from early cycles. Even when forecasting capacity degradation over the full lifecycle on various datasets, the prediction error remains below 0.04, confirming the method’s robustness and precision.

title: Path Planning for End-Effector-Guided Motion of Tapered Cable-Driven Hyper-Redundant Manipulators_supp1-3658150.pdf
authors: Jianwen Huo
publish: N/A
abstract: This article presents an improved maximum deflection angle rapidly-exploring random tree Star (IMDA-RRT*) algorithm for path planning in the end-effector-guided motion (EGM) of tapered cable-driven hyper-redundant manipulators (TCDHMs). First, the relationship between the boundaries of additional collision regions arising from the manipulator's EGM and path parameters—such as corner angle, step size, and link length—is analyzed. On this basis, the existing path collision detection algorithm is enhanced to improve path reliability and expand the feasible search space. Furthermore, based on the MDA-RRT* algorithm, improvements are made in terms of constant step size and directional guidance, addressing the issues of inconsistent step sizes caused by the algorithm's pruning process and the inability to constrain the terminal orientation. Finally, simulation and physical experiments are conducted under three distinct scenarios to validate the algorithm's performance. The results demonstrate that the IMDA-RRT* effectively addresses the EGM path planning problem for TCDHMs, showing excellent adaptability in narrow and constrained environments. Compared to existing algorithms, it achieves a higher success rate and faster solving efficiency.

title: Controller Reliability Assessment Model (CRAM): A Novel Framework for Reliability Evaluation of Attitude Control Subsystems in LEO Space Missions
authors: M. Damircheli, M. Fakoor, P. Nikpey
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This study presents the Controller Reliability Assessment Model (CRAM), a new framework for evaluating the reliability of the controller and the attitude control subsystem (ACS) of Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellites. CRAM integrates Software-in-the-Loop (SIL) simulations to construct a performance-based database that captures the operational behavior of the ACS under both internal and external disturbances. Data-driven analysis is then applied to derive a detailed understanding of controller performance and to determine the failure rates of controller components. In addition, a Reliability Block Diagram (RBD) is developed to quantify the contribution of each controller and to estimate system-level reliability over a three-year mission duration. The proposed model identifies the most robust, accurate, and responsive controller with the highest reliability. The ACS design incorporates solar radiation pressure, gravity-gradient torque, and aerodynamic drag as external disturbances, while actuator loss of effectiveness is modeled as an internal disturbance. A tetrahedral reaction wheel configuration is employed, where three wheels provide three-axis control and a fourth wheel serves as redundancy. The evaluated control schemes include a proportional–derivative (PD) controller, an H∞ controller, and two variants of sliding-mode control.

title: Addressing Data Imbalance in the Prediction of Protein Binding Pocket Similarity
authors: Yihang Huang, Jin Li
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Protein pocket matching plays a pivotal role in drug discovery. However, in the promising field of human-plant protein comparison, the scarcity of similar protein pairs results in severely imbalanced datasets, causing models to be highly prone to overfitting and exhibiting a bias towards negative samples. Crucially, conventional computational models primarily focus on extracting features from individual proteins in isolation, lacking explicit modeling of the relational mechanisms between protein pairs, and thus fail to capture the functional synergy between paired proteins. To address these dual challenges, this study proposes a dual-pronged framework: (i) the introduction of a Cross-Attention Network (CrossNet) to learn and fuse paired feature representations, thereby enabling explicit modeling of inter-protein relationships; and (ii) the adoption of a hybrid strategy combining Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) with popularity-based dynamic negative sampling to mitigate the issue of extreme positive-negative sample imbalance.

title: Modeling of a Three-Winding Transformer for Resonance Prediction in Flyback Converters
authors: Ashritha Manjunath, Venkadeshkumar Anbalagan, Soundarrajan Karuppusamy
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Electromagnetic Interference and Compatibility (INCEMIC)
abstract: A comprehensive analysis of resonant ringing phenomena in a flyback converter utilizing a three-winding transformer model is presented. The transformer model incorporates detailed parasitic elements, allowing for the extraction of both interwinding and layer-to-layer parasitic capacitances in three winding transformer. These parasitic components are integrated into a high-frequency equivalent circuit, which serves as the basis for estimating the resonant frequency observed at the MOSFET switching node. The proposed modeling and resonance prediction framework supports accurate system-level Electro Magnetic Interference study.

title: TrueSightQ: A Multimodal Framework for Detecting AI-Generated Content Using Quantum Techniques and Web3 Integration
authors: Vivekrabinson K, C Yogesh, Indra Kumar M, Hari Suriya K, Reeshebaala S, Bharath Singh J
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: The rapid progress of generative AI has already seen the rise of highly realistic artificial and deepfake content that has created a problems related to trust on information, privacy, issues related to cyber security loss of general trust. This research introduces TrueSightQ, a unified full stack web application framework through with multimodal detection of AI generated content through use of Quatnum enhancement and Web3 Integration. This system is a hybrid between heuristic and deep learning methods with the added feature of GPU accelerated training combined with quantum advantage classifiers. The trustworthiness and transparency of blockchain technology, as well as IPFS storage and Ethereum Smart contract to improve verification process. The model is further enhanced with modality wise fusion and, decentralized trust based mechanisms for the defense mechanism to adversarial attack. Results show that in general TrueSightQ significantly outperforms standard unimodal detectors overall, with additional gains to verifiability, precision and interpretability demonstrating how the multimodal and decentralized methodology within the model mitigates the issues of AI generated content very efficiently.

title: Applications of Artificial and Computational Intelligence in Women’s Healthcare
authors: A. Nagalaxmi, Syed Akram Pasha, P. Gurusamy, L. Lakshmanan, N. Srimathi, S. Manikandan
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: Breast cancer is the most prevalent health problem affecting women globally, and it has detrimental effects on their personal and professional life in addition to their physical health. Early illness detection can boost recovery and survival rates, reduce complexity, and enhance the efficacy of healthcare. Initial detection of breast cancer, which is the most deadly and common form of the illness, is an excellent example of the benefits of early diagnosis. The initial phase of breast cancer, which is asymptomatic and goes unreported by patients, cannot be identified by conventional analytical methods. Therefore, the adoption of advanced computational techniques and intelligent learning systems is crucial for the prompt detection of illnesses. These models can detect disease before symptoms manifest, avoiding the difficulties encountered by conventional medical diagnostic techniques. This research work creates a new model Multi-Layer Genomic Recognition System (MLGRS) that diagnoses breast cancer more effectively and with less complexity. To enhance the current model, the present study unites advanced preprocessing techniques with hybrid classification methods for gene expression data to predict breast cancer. The performance of the proposed MLGRS is found to be greater than that of the existing approaches such as Support Vector Machine, Logistic Regression and Decision Tree.

title: Graph Convolutional Networks for Individual and Group Activity Recognition in Sports Videos
authors: Ishrat Zahra, Ahmad Jalal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Engineering &amp; Computing Technologies (ICECT)
abstract: Group activity recognition in sports videos is challenging due to complex player interactions. This paper presents a robust framework for volleyball activity recognition using a multimodal approach. The proposed pipeline begins with refined preprocessing, utilizing median and edgepreserving filters to reduce visual noise and emphasize key motion boundaries. Subsequently, YOLOv11 is employed for efficient player localization and tracking, followed by a hybrid feature extraction module. This module integrates handcrafted visual descriptors (HOG, LBP, and SIFT) with motion and posebased cues obtained from MediaPipe and MOCON to capture both appearance and dynamics of athletes. Spatial and temporal dependencies among players are modeled using a Graph Convolutional Network (GCN), which effectively learns team coordination patterns. Furthermore, a Genetic Algorithm (GA) is employed to compress redundant features, resulting in an $80 \%$ reduction in dimensionality and a notable improvement in recognition performance. Evaluations on a benchmark volleyball dataset demonstrate that our framework achieves a recognition accuracy of $91.8 \%$, surpassing prior methods while maintaining a fast inference speed of 0.15 s per frame. The system offers a practical balance between computational efficiency and predictive accuracy, making it suitable for realtime sports analytics and coaching applications.

title: From Cyberbullying to Doxing: Privacy, Law, and Challenges in Online Harms
authors: Pinal Hansora, Maitri Shah, Monali Parikh, Jayshree Ranoliya, Mayur Chauhan, Bhargav Bharvad
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: This paper examines the increasing prevalence of online harms such as cyberbullying and doxing within digital environments, with a particular emphasis on their social and legal implications. While cyberbullying has been widely studied, the phenomenon of doxing remains underexplored, despite its significant impact on individual privacy, security, and psychological well-being. The review critically highlights research gaps, notably the limited availability of observed and empirical studies addressing doxing practices and their societal outcomes. Furthermore, it investigates the role of data privacy regulations in prohibiting and mitigating doxing, considering the adequacy of existing legal frameworks across jurisdictions. A systematic tabular analysis of current literature is presented to consolidate existing knowledge, followed by a discussion of challenges such as regulatory inconsistencies, enforcement limitations, and emerging technological risks. Future directions are identified, emphasizing the need for cross-disciplinary research, stronger policy interventions, and the integration of technical safeguards within online platforms to counter doxing and its related harms.

title: Knee osteoporosis detection from Deep learning stacking ensemble model on Preprocessed X rays Images
authors: Ankit Singh Patel, Aishwarya Mishra, Anjum, Rahul Katarya
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: Osteoporosis is a progressive skeletal disease characterized by a steady decline in bone mineral density (BMD) and deterioration of bone microarchitecture, ultimately resulting in fragile bones, higher fracture risk, and impaired quality of life. The current clinical gold standard for diagnosis, dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA), provides accurate BMD measurements but remains limited by high cost, restricted accessibility, and impracticality for population-level screening. These limitations have encouraged increasing interest in computer-aided diagnostic approaches based on plain radiographs, which are inexpensive, widely available, and non-invasive. In this study, we propose a deep learning framework for stage-wise classification of osteoporosis from knee radiographs, focusing on the clinically significant distinction between Normal, Osteopenia, and Osteoporosis. The framework integrates a robust preprocessing pipeline, transfer learning across multiple state-of-the-art convolutional neural networks, and a novel ensemble strategy that fuses predictions through weighted averaging and a static deep meta-learner. Experimental evaluations on publicly available datasets demonstrate that the ensemble outperforms individual models, achieving higher accuracy and balanced precision-recall scores across all classes. Beyond performance gains, the framework presents a scalable and clinically relevant solution to the limitations of existing diagnostic methods. These findings underscore the potential of ensemble deep learning to strengthen automated osteoporosis detection and enhance clinical decision-making.

title: Design of a 24-Bit High Precision SAR ADC with Random Forest-based Error Correction for IoT Edge Devices
authors: Gowrishankar V, Parimala Devi M, Abinaya S, Charuvi P, Dinesh K, Harishaa R
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: The need for high accuracy, High precision Analog to Digital Converters for IoT devices is gradually growing, particularly for devices at the edge. This paper introduces the design of a 24-bit Successive Approximation Register (SAR) ADC in submicron 45nm process using the Cadence virtuoso tool with high precision and low power consumption. This paper proposes a Random Forest-based error correction machine learning algorithm to improve accuracy by filling in nonlinearities and mismatches in the SAR ADC. In comparison to traditional 24 bit SAR ADC design, our proposed method enhances energy efficiency with better Effective Number of Bits (ENOB) and Signal-to-Noise and Distortion Ratio (SNDR). Simulation results validate that the demonstrated 24 bit SAR ADC attains 20.1 ENOB and 122.7 dB SNDR with a power consumption of less than 50 mW, making it a top candidate for IoT edge applications demanding high precision and accurate signal acquisition.

title: Layer 2 Trade-Offs: Evaluating Privacy, Security, and Decentralization in Ethereum Scaling
authors: Varun Pareek, Karan Kumawat, Anunay Tiwari, Taruna Sunil
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: Blockchain technology, particularly Ethereum, has enabled a wide range of decentralized applications but continues to face significant scalability challenges, including high gas fees, limited transaction throughput, and frequent network congestion. This review provides a comprehensive analysis of Ethereum's scalability constraints and critically evaluates current Layer 2 scaling solutions such as Rollups, Plasma, the Lightning Network, and other emerging alternatives. The study conducts a comparative assessment of these mechanisms with respect to decentralization, privacy, and security-core dimensions of the blockchain scalability trilemma. Recent academic contributions, including stochastic models of gas fee behavior and protocolspecific analyses, are examined to provide both theoretical and empirical insights. Emphasis is placed on understanding the architectural advantages of zk-Rollups and their positioning as a leading Layer 2 solution. Quantitative metrics such as transaction throughput benchmarks, privacy, and security capability comparisons are presented to support the evaluation. The findings are intended to inform the design of more scalable, secure, and privacy-preserving Ethereum-compatible architectures.

title: Unified Collaboration: Leveraging AI-Augmented Teams and Voice Platforms
authors: Sunil Kumar Gingade Krishnamurthy
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: AI is set to transform business activity across teams. AI assistants and speech platforms are driving this transformation. So, they are enhancing telehealth services. Also, they are helping with patient experience, care coordination and communication within departments across healthcare, finance, retail, manufacturing and other sectors. Although these systems have strong potential for increasing productivity or enhancing decision-making, they will only succeed if a number of important conditions are met: integration; low latency; transcriptions; and more. The goal of this research is to look at these things and find out what challenges and opportunities AI has to enhance the workflow and work performance of the team. And analyze the impact of artificial intelligence systems on operational outcomes through quantitative data, performance metrics, case studies, and other tools. Artificial intelligence technology has amazing potential but multiple limitations as well. It is suggested to improve integration, lower latency and transcription. The objective is to help organizations effectively use A.I. tools for enhanced cross-functional collaboration and decision-making through performance.

title: AI-Powered Voice Assistants for Accessible E-Commerce: A Review of ASR, RAG, LLMs and TTS
authors: Kshama N, Prajwal Andanur, Pranava Udupa E P, Suraj S Airani, Dattathreya
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Online Shopping today is a daily necessity for the most, but the visually impaired still face challenges using the con ventional e-commerce sites. This paper discusses recent advances in AI—namely Speech-to-Text (STT), Large Language Models (LLMs), and Text-to-Speech (TTS)—that empower voice-first as sistants to allow users to search, compare, and buy products using natural speech. Combined with Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), these models provide more accurate, context-sensitive, and health-aware recommendations, such as diet-specific grocery plans and medication suggestions. We integrate prior work on accessibility, personalization, multilingualism, and advancements in natural language understanding, with a focus on methods that improve conversational quality and recommendation salience. Despite these encouraging results, major challenges still remain in handling diverse user inputs, sustaining real-time performance, and adapting to individual preferences. We propose scalable RAG pipelines to improve factuality and responsiveness, testing with visually impaired consumers, and robust dialogue management as future research priorities. A focus on these areas will open the door for dependable, efficient voice assistants that make online shopping a reality

title: Optimizing Renewable Energy Forecasting Using Heterogeneity-Aware Federated Learning
authors: Yang Li, Bin Sun, Tao Shen, Liyao Ma
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Renewable energy forecasting, especially wind power prediction in distributed environments faces challenges from device heterogeneity and resource constraints. Traditional federated learning approaches assume uniform computational capabilities across participating devices, which rarely holds in practice. We propose HA-FedASMU, an extension of the FedASMU algorithm that incorporates computational power assessment and adaptive workload distribution. Our method introduces two key mechanisms: a computational power factor (CPF) for quantifying device capabilities, and a workload adjustment factor (WAF) for dynamic weight allocation during model aggregation. Experimental validation on real world data (UK Power Networks photovoltaic) shows improvements of 33.3% in prediction error, 5.1% in accuracy, and 58.8% in convergence speed compared to baseline methods. The results demonstrate the practical viability of heterogeneity-aware federated learning for renewable energy applications.

title: A Fair Review of Legal AI Applications and Challenges
authors: Aman Kumar, Rita Chhikara, Tamalika Chaira
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is making great strides to transform various domains of life. Presently, through various machine learning (ML) - supervised, semi-supervised and unsupervised algorithms, there is automation of work. Moreover, algorithms are predicting the possible outcomes based on historical data. Application of such algorithms in law is not behind. The use of Natural language Processing (NLP) and recently Large Language Models (LLMs) are redefining the legal knowledge landscape. Legal research and data retrieval, preparation of petitions, writing of judgements and case outcome predictions are tasks which are the focal point of legal AI. This heralds the substantial rise of efficiency and productivity of law firms, lawyers and judges. The algorithms augment the existing capabilities to reduce the legal cases pendency. Nonetheless, the positive outcomes are not elusive from serious legal and ethical issues. The obscure decision making of algorithms (Black box problem), ethical and privacy concerns, accessibility and equity must be addressed before larger implementation.

title: Estimation of a Prolonged Release NPK Fertilizer with Humic Acid and Zeolite for Optimizing Nutrient Retention for Yield in Vegetative Crops
authors: Adithya R, Harsha A, Deepa R
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: The existing agricultural model depends on high application of chemical fertilizers in order to sustain productivity but in the process traditional fertilizers composed of three major character NPK (nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium) usually lead to poor use of nutrients and high cost of inputs and environmental pollution. The research aims at designing and testing a prolonged release, NPK fertiliser with the use of zeolite and humic acid to increase nutrient availability rate, minimise losses, increase the yields of short-cycle vegetable crops (spinach and cabbage). The natural Aluminosilicate, High-grade zeolite was used in this because cation exchange capacity which liberates ammonium and potassium ions gradually. Humic acid also makes the soil structure more soil and promotes the activity of microorganisms beneficial to the soil, and promotes plant nutrient uptake by plant roots. Experimental analysis indicates an ensemble ML model that has 95.8 percent accuracy when used to perform crop rec- ommendation and 92.4 percent of accuracy when used to perform fertilizer dosage prediction. The suggested framework is efficient in nutrient recycling, optimization of yields, and sustainability of the environment and is flexible to both smallholder farmers and large-scale agricultural systems.

title: Instance Segmentation Approach for Detecting NonHypertrophic Synovium Knee Osteoarthritis
authors: Dite Geovani, Siti Nurmaini, Anita Desiani, Ade Iriani Sapitri, Putri Muthia
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Technological Solutions (ICAITech)
abstract: Detection of knee osteoarthritis conditions in ultrasound images requires extensive skill and experience from rheumatologists. One of the conditions of damage that occurs in patients with knee $\mathbf{O A}$ is non-hypertrophic synovium. This study aims to perform deep learning-based instance segmentation using YOLOv8 to detect knee OA conditions. Specifically, it focuses on detecting non-hypertrophic synovium osteoarthritis conditions in ultrasound images. The YOLOv8 model was trained using a dataset of knee ultrasound images. The performance evaluation yielded a mean Average Precision (mAP) of 0.85 and an Intersection over Union (IoU) score of 0.83. These results indicate that the deep learning-based instance segmentation approach using YOLOv8 can detect non-hypertrophic synovium osteoarthritis conditions with precision and accuracy. Based on the predicted image instance segmentation results, the YOLOv8 method provides detailed visualizations of areas showing non-hypertrophic synovium osteoarthritis in ultrasound images. This study has the potential to enhance diagnostic efficiency and support treatment planning for patients with knee osteoarthritis.

title: Bayesian Network-Based Anomaly Detection for SQL Injection Attacks in HTTP Payloads
authors: Nurul Afifah, Deni Danuarta, Deris Stiawan, Dendi Renaldo Permana, Tri Wanda Septian, Ika Putri Aprilia
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Technological Solutions (ICAITech)
abstract: SQL Injection (SQLi) is one of the most critical cyberattacks that exploits vulnerabilities in the web application layer, particularly through database query manipulation. Preventing these attacks is crucial for resilient digital infrastructure, a key target in the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), particularly SDG 9. This attack can result in data theft, authentication bypass, and even system takeover. SQLi attack techniques continue to evolve, requiring accurate and adaptive detection methods. One promising approach is the use of Bayesian Networks, which can model probabilistic relationships between attack patterns and normal traffic. SQL Injection attack patterns are analyzed through HTTP payloads at the application layer, resulting in two main categories: query character-based patterns and percent encoding patterns. Bayesian Networks are implemented by calculating the probability of URI character occurrence using the Python programming language. Test results demonstrate high detection performance, with a True Positive Rate (TPR) of 99.3% in optimal testing and a False Positive Rate (FPR) of $0 \%$. The confusion matrix reveals system accuracy ranging from $82.7 \%$ to $99.7 \%$, with precision at $100 \%$. However, variations in TPR occur due to differences in query complexity, such as in the seventh test ($64.4 \%$) which included all types of attacks. This finding demonstrates the effectiveness of Bayesian Networks in detecting SQL Injection by leveraging dependencies between variables, although challenges remain with certain queries that resemble normal traffic.

title: GANs for Pandemic Preparedness: A Systematic Review and Performance Benchmark for Pandemic Detection and Data Augmentation
authors: Dipti Theng, Sofia Singh, Madhuri Hiwale
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: The complexity and inherent scarcity of labeled, high-dimensional clinical data pose a significant challenge to conventional deep learning models used for COVID-19 detection and diagnosis. This paper presents a systematic review of Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) and their variants as a potent methodology to overcome these pandemic-related data deficiencies. We meticulously analyze and compare the implementation and performance of major GAN architectures-specifically Conditional GANs (cGANs), Cycle-Consistent GANs (CycleGANs), and Style-based GANs (StyleGANs)-across diverse healthcare applications. Our analysis maps the direct utility of GANs in solving critical data challenges, including scarcity, imbalance, and privacy constraints in clinical and epidemiological datasets. We evaluate the efficacy of these models in three core areas: generating high-quality synthetic medical images (X-rays/CT) for data augmentation; creating novel molecular structures for accelerated drug discovery; and enhancing epidemiological prediction models. Furthermore, the review explores crucial optimization techniques like WGAN-GP used to stabilize training and improve data fidelity. Finally, we synthesize reported performance metrics (e.g., FID, PSNR, diagnostic accuracy) to establish a comprehensive benchmark for current GAN-based COVID-19 solutions, detailing their strengths, limitations, and charting essential future research directions for infectious disease preparedness.

title: Adaptive Improvements and Experimental Analysis of YOLOv8 in Dynamic Digital Recognition on a Comprehensive Test Bench
authors: Shuxi Guo, Zhijun Xu, Ting Xue, Hui Wang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: This paper proposes an adaptive improvement scheme based on YOLOv8 algorithm to address the problems of variable target scale and motion blur interference faced by dynamic digital recognition in industrial test bench scenarios, in order to enhance its detection accuracy and inference efficiency. Firstly, the Retentive Block module is introduced into the backbone network to enhance the model's prior modeling ability for the spatial structure of digital sequences through its spatial attenuation mechanism, effectively suppressing background noise; Secondly, in the neck network, an attention based intra scale feature interaction module (AIFI) is used to replace the original SPPF structure and enhance global contextual information fusion; Finally, a lightweight VoVGSCSP module is employed to construct an efficient feature fusion path, thereby enhancing its accuracy. Experiments on a self-made test bench dynamic digital dataset show that the improved model maintains high inference speed while achieving an average accuracy of 89.4%, which is 4.6 percentage points higher than the original YOLOv8; In motion blur and occlusion scenes, the recall rate increased by 3.3%, significantly better than compared models such as YOLOv7, effectively verifying the robustness and practicality of the proposed improvement strategy in complex industrial scenes.

title: Multi-Objective Optimization for QoS-Aware Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: Anjali Dhamiwal, Shilpa Mahajan, Yogita Gigras
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) are expanding to become a powerful technology for a wide variety of applications, including environmental monitoring, healthcare, and smart cities. However, the low energy resources in sensor nodes pose a behemoth challenge to network lifetime and sustainability. This paper presents an optimization model to enhance energy efficiency in WSNs based on the existing optimization methods, such as Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), Genetic Algorithm (GA), and Ant Colony Optimization (ACO). This paper presents a framework based on these optimization methods to optimize node deployment, routing protocols, and data aggregation protocols. By exploiting the sensor nodes’ energy in an efficient manner, we minimize energy consumption without compromising maximum connectivity and coverage. Routing protocols are also optimized to further promote effective data transmission and conserve power usage to help extend network lifetime. Our simulation results show that our proposed optimization methods improve energy efficiency much better than traditional methods. Findings indicate that the application of optimization algorithms enhances network performance and data reliability. And the operational lifetime of WSNs. The study is part of existing research works that have been intended to design sustainable WSNs, opening up opportunities for the advancement of more robust and efficient wireless communication systems. <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">[9] [10] [17]</sup>

title: Innovative Embedded System Architecture for Secure Voting Machines Built on the Blockchain: Capabilities for Real-Time Verification and Difficulty Detection
authors: Anand Raj I, Dhandapani Samiappan, D. Kalaiyarasi, Riham Alkabbji, G. John Samuel Babu, G. Karthikeyan
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: - In a time of increased focus on the integrity of elections, the intersection of embedded technology and blockchain algorithms provides a powerful new means of implementing transparent, secure and resilient voting systems. This paper is dedicated towards the design of a novel embedded system structure for the secure EVM (Electronic Voting Machine) system, using a blockchain for non-repudiation of data and distributed entity verification. The design approach includes a multi-tiered security posture from hardware level tamper suppression, on the fly vote verification, and dynamic anomaly detection with embedded intelligence. At the heart of the system, a light-weight high-performance embedded controller combined with a secure element and cryptographical co-processor guarantees secure data processing, identity authentication and system integrity. Votes are tokenized and represented as transactions on a blockchain, which preserves end-to-end verification while preserving individual voter secrecy. Its underlying architecture leverages a hybrid consensus mechanism especially adjusted for private or consortium blockchain network to scale out the trustful voting recording and counting. Instant verification is secured with smart contracts and Merkle proof verification and every validated vote is consistently recorded and immutable. Moreover, the machine learning module is contained in the firmware for detecting hardness. This module observes and learns user behavior pattern, user reviewing behavior pattern and packet processing performance over time in order to raise alerts about potential threats such as hardware breakdowns, unauthorized entry attempts or nonconforming voting behaviors, etc., and take actions in order to prevent it. The in-built AI also learns and evolves with regional/ jurisdictional voting patterns, to reduce false positives and increase sensitivity to electoral irregularities. It was experimentally validated in a prototype deployed in an ARM Cortex-M7 embedded board connected with Hyperledger Fabric, displaying real-time transaction throughput fit out for medium-sized election scale.

title: Deep Learning-Based LIS Reflection Matrix Design: Impact of Optimizer Selection
authors: Sherif Sayed, Amr A. Nagy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Telecommunications and Artificial Intelligence (IC-FTAI)
abstract: Large Intelligent Surfaces (LIS) are emerging as a key technology in future wireless communication systems. This work investigates a practical LIS architecture where a small subset of elements is activated and linked to the baseband for sensing purposes. In contrast, most elements remain passive. A multilayer perceptron (MLP), a deep learning-based framework trained on the DeepMIMO dataset, is employed to estimate the optimal reflection beamforming vector from partial channel state information (CSI) obtained through the active elements. To analyze the impact of different optimization strategies, the performance of six optimizers—Lion, Adam, AdamW, NAdam, SGDM, and RMSprop—is examined. The overall system performance is evaluated based on the achievable rate, outage probability, and training time. The findings show that while the Lion optimizer delivers performance that nearly matches an ideal genie-aided system, it requires a longer training period. Conversely, RMSprop requires the least training time but yields the poorest results. Consequently, selecting an appropriate optimizer is crucial for enhancing system performance in wireless networks supported by LIS.

title: A Novel Hybrid Ensemble Machine Learning Framework for Inference Score Prediction in Rheumatoid Arthritis
authors: C.Vimala Josphine, R. Renugadevi, J. Jayalakshmi, E. Nimmy Magarin Sophia, M.Theodore Kingslin
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) is a chronic autoimmune disease that is faced by about 1 % of the world populationwhich involves progressive inflammation in the joints and systemic complications. The research introduces a new hybrid ensemble framework of predicting inference scores of gene-disease associations on RA. It involved a systematic analysis of a large dataset of 29,540 gene-disease associationswhich are gene identifiers and compound interactions. The methods of analysis were tested on 6 different methods to identify the most suitable. These were XGBoost, LightGBM, Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, Support Vector Regression and Multi-layer Perceptron. The best results were obtained with the weighted averaging ensemble technique. It had an R2 value of 0.9642, RMSE of 1.6758 and MAE of 0.9682. A laying group was constructed as well. It uses various learning methods with Ridge regression in order to refine predictions. This procedure almost worked equally well with an R 2 of 0.9640. These methods were found to be reliable after repeated testing with cross validation. They are stable with dissimilar data sets. It revealed the factors that are the most important. Complexity of interactions between genes was the highest. The final predictors were the number of interactions of compounds. The results have potential of personalized treatment of patients. They can also accelerate the new medicines search.

title: Harnessing Ensemble Learning with Stacking to Enhance Diabetes Risk Prediction Using PIMA Indian Dataset
authors: Vaishnave, Vincy D Rose, Anitha G.
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Accurate diabetes prediction is essential for early intervention and preventative care. This work suggests a unique architecture for the Pima Indian Diabetes Dataset that combines advanced preprocessing, class balancing, and multilevel ensemble learning. Support Vector Machine (SVM), Logistic Regression (LR), K-Nearest Neighbours (KNN), Decision Tree (DT), and Random Forest (RF) were five classifiers evaluated separately; Random Forest obtained 77.9 % accuracy. With 75.9 % accuracy, F1-score 0.615, recall 0.552, and precision 0.696, a stacking ensemble that combined all base learners with Logistic Regression as the meta-learner surpassed Bagging (71.0%) and Boosting (69.8%). These findings show how well ensemble approaches work for early diabetes prediction.

title: Multilingual and Severity-Aware Cyberbullying Detection with Emotion Fusion and Transformer Models
authors: Nishikant Vetal, Bharati Vasgi
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Cyberbullying has become a pervasive challenge in the digital era, significantly impacting the mental health and social well-being of individuals, particularly among adolescents and young adults. While several approaches have been proposed for cyberbullying detection, existing systems are often limited by their reliance on single-language datasets, binary classification schemes, and lack of interpretability. Moreover, traditional models fail to capture the severity levels of bullying and the emotional context of abusive language. In this paper, we propose a comprehensive cyberbullying detection framework that integrates GloVe embeddings with PCA dimensionality reduction and Logistic Regression as a baseline, further enhanced with transformer-based architectures such as RoBERTa and XLMRoBERTa for multilingual detection. The framework introduces two novel components: severity scoring, which classifies abusive content into mild, moderate, and severe categories, and emotion fusion, which incorporates emotional context (e.g., anger, sadness, joy, fear) into the detection pipeline. To enhance transparency, we employ explainable AI techniques (LIME and SHAP) to highlight word-level contributions to predictions, thereby improving interpretability for end-users and moderators. A real-time Streamlit-based dashboard application is developed, supporting both single-text and bulk CSV analysis, along with visualization tools for sentiment distribution, severity levels, and emotional trends. Experimental evaluation on publicly available cyberbullying datasets demonstrates that our proposed approach achieves significant improvements in accuracy, precision, recall, and F1score compared to traditional machine learning baselines. The results indicate that combining severity analysis, emotion fusion, and explainability not only improves classification performance but also enhances the practical applicability of cyberbullying detection systems in real-world educational and social media environments

title: Single-Shot Transient Imaging Via Compressed Time-Of-Flight Imaging And Dictionary Learning
authors: Peyman F. Shahandashti, P. López, V.M. Brea, D. García-Lesta, Miguel Heredia Conde
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: In this work, we propose a single-shot transient imaging framework that combines sparsity-based signal modeling with compressive frequency-domain sampling. The temporal response function of a scene encodes rich information about depth and light transport, and its accurate reconstruction is critical for various imaging applications. To enable transient recovery from a limited number of measurements, we exploit learned sparse representations in an optimized dictionary basis. We compare multiple sampling strategies in the frequency domain and show that both transient profiles and depth maps can be reconstructed under highly compressed acquisition. Notably, we achieve full transient reconstruction using only 16 modulation frequencies, based on real correlation functions, enabling practical singleshot acquisition through spatial frequency multiplexing.

title: Rapid and Automated Flood Segmentation through Landsat with Google Earth Engine Using Deep Learning Architecture
authors: T P Ramachandran, SK. Sheema, Maram Y. Al-Safarlnr, R. Manasa, J Shubangi, Rakesh Chandrashekar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: To enhance flood mapping, a crucial need during natural disasters, the research introduces an AFSGDL model. Traditional mapping methods are often slow and can be biased due to their reliance on thresholds and manual input, leading to challenges like false readings caused by vegetation and active urban environments. The Rapid and Automated Flood Segmentation Through Landsat with Google Earth Engine Using Deep Learning Architecture (AFSGDL) model integrates various sources of remote sensing data, specifically utilising Sentinel-1 synthetic aperture radar (SAR) imagery and historical flood vectors from UNOSAT. Pre-processing steps employed radiometric calibration and cloud masking for improved dataset reliability and the Digital Elevation model (DEM). A hybrid deep learning model has been developed that integrates Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) for enhanced data analysis and feature extraction performance, and a Residual Swin Transformer Block (RSTB) architecture was developed to capture both local details and broader contextual data. Specialised loss functions were created to mitigate class imbalances in flood and non- flood areas, enhancing overall segmentation accuracy. The following parameters are calculated with existing models MLRFM, INFLOS, and IOERD, compared with the AFSGDL model. Where the parameters are loss and dice, ROC curves analysis, RMSE curves analysis, water depth analysis, and velocity. The loss and dice of the AFSGDL model is 0.12 - 0.95, ROC curves analysis of 0.991, RMSE curves analysis of 0.078, water depth analysis of 13.0, and velocity analysis of 2.7.

title: Cognitive Load-Aware AI Model for Optimizing English Reading Comprehension in Adaptive Learning Platforms
authors: S Theporal, B R Lakshmi, Nashwan Adnan Othman, V. Saranya, Telugu Neelima, B Sreela
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: Reading comprehension is a foundation of academic achievement, but students demonstrate vast individual differences in cognitive processing and capacity during text encounters. Most adaptive learning systems are based on fixed heuristics or achievement measures (e.g., quiz performance, reading speed) that do not account for the dynamic process of cognitive load. This work proposes a hybrid deep learning framework integrating Convolutional Neural Networks, Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory, and Attention to overcome these shortcomings. Preprocessing of EEG signals is done by bandpass filtering, removal of artifacts using ICA, and segmentation through a sliding window method. FFT and PSD are utilized for feature extraction, followed by end-to-end learning by the hybrid model. The DEAP dataset, with EEG activity of 32 subjects over 40 trials, is utilized for cognitive classification based on emotions. The designed model is accurate to 92.3% and has a low inference latency, which suits deployment at the edge using TensorFlow Lite. Python-based libraries such as NumPy, SciPy, and MNE are utilized throughout the pipeline. This method extends spatial-temporal feature learning, makes the model easier to interpret, and provides a scalable solution for real-time cognitive monitoring in embedded systems.

title: Explaining BiLSTM-based Fiber Optic Prediction Based on Integrated Gradients
authors: Shubo Qi, Xin Li, Chenyu Zhao, Dongrou Wang, Ruoting Liu, Shanguo Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: With the increasing complexity of optical fiber transmission systems, ensuring reliable and high-performance data transmission has become critically important. In this paper, we employ Integrated Gradients to interpret the predictions of a BiLSTM model used in optical fiber transmission analysis, revealing the contribution of the input features to the model’s decisions. The explanation results are further validated through model evaluation metrics under different feature configurations.

title: A Visual Composer for Quantum Circuits
authors: Anas Tamer Osman, Milad Ghantous, Hassan Soubra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Telecommunications and Artificial Intelligence (IC-FTAI)
abstract: Designing and prototyping quantum circuits remains challenging for beginners and intermediate users due to steep learning curves in text-based frameworks and limited features in existing visual tools. This paper introduces QuantumFlow, a web-based platform that addresses these challenges through an accessible drag-and-drop interface for constructing and simulating quantum circuits. The platform provides realtime validation, state visualization, and interactive Bloch-sphere rendering to enable both conceptual exploration and rapid prototyping. Key features include modular subcircuit design, mid-circuit measurements, export to Qiskit, Cirq, and JSON, and hardware-aware transpilation for processors such as IBM's Falcon and Google's Sycamore. Implemented with React and Redux, the platform runs entirely client-side without installation. A structured evaluation with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 4}$</tex> participants found that QuantumFlow users completed circuit construction tasks <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 5 \%}$</tex> faster and scored 38 % higher on comprehension assessments than peers relying on textbook workflows. Exported code aligns with framework standards and incorporates optimizations including gate fusion, commutation, and device-specific mapping. Current limitations involve scalability constraints and the absence of direct backend connectivity. Overall, QuantumFlow enhances accessibility to quantum computing education, supports interactive learning, and accelerates early-stage development, effectively bridging instructional platforms with advanced frameworks.

title: A Hierarchical Address Decomposition Method for Multidimensional Array Access Optimization
authors: Jingming Gou, Xianbo He
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Multidimensional array access is a primary performance bottleneck in High-Performance Computing (HPC). Modern compilers typically flatten multi-dimensional index computations into a single offset expression, thereby obscuring the hierarchical invariance inherent in the address calculation that corresponds to the loop nesting structure. This flattening prevents standard optimizations like Loop-Invariant Code Motion (LICM) from being effective. This paper proposes a Hierarchical Address Decomposition (HAD) method, which reconstructs address computations in LLVM into a chained intermediate representation that is isomorphic to the loop nest. This transformation explicitly exposes pointer-level invariants, enabling them to be automatically hoisted by the standard LICM pass. Furthermore, this paper introduces a model-guided promotion strategy that leverages a cost model to balance the benefits of optimization against the overhead of the transformation.
