Experimental results on SPEC CPU bench-marks (481.wrf and 621.wrf_s) demonstrate that HAD achieves up to a 1.08x speedup, validating its effectiveness and portability for multidimensional array access optimization.

title: Two-Wheeler Safety and Theft Prevention System using Facial Recognition, Helmet Detection, and Motion-based Alerts
authors: Nishanthi R, Neil Raj M, Nanditha G, Abinaya N S
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Two-Wheelers are best economic option for daily transport. However, they are involved in a lot of traffic accidents and car thefts. Riders who fail to wear their helmets are responsible for a significant portion of injuries. Meanwhile, large cities continue to see an increase in thefts. A clever system for preventing theft and ensuring the safety of two-wheelers is presented in this work. It uses integrated sensors and computer vision to improve rider safety in advance. Facial recognition feature is integrated by a hybrid algorithm MTCNN, ArcFace, and DeepSORT. That module has a 97.5 percent accuracy rate. It also attains 95.5 percent F1-score, 96.0 percent precision, and 95.0 percent recall. These results surpass those of models that only use ArcFace, which only attain 93.2% accuracy. To identify helmets, the system uses YOLOv8. That approach yields a mean average precision of 96.4 percent at 0.5. It remains strong even when helmets are partially blocked. Rider fatigue is detected using the Eye Aspect Ratio method. This can identify drowsiness in real time with a sensitivity of 94.8%. A touch-based authentication feature provides backup verification. It gives riders safe feedback through vibrations. Vibration sensors can detect any movement without permission. They then use GPS to track the location and turn on theft alerts. Compared to standard systems that need mobile applications, this design is different. Rather, it uses computer vision, onboard controls, and smart sensors to function independently. The prevention of theft and total safety coverage are the objectives of all of this.

title: Impact of Poor PCB Layout on EMC Performance and Proposed Solutions using 3D Simulation
authors: Surendra Domal, Suresh Kumar Yenumula, Aravind Kamath
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Electromagnetic Interference and Compatibility (INCEMIC)
abstract: Electromagnetic Compatibility (EMC) challenges in electronic products are often attributed to poor printed circuit board (PCB) design. Inadequate component placement and improper ground routing contribute significantly to Radiated Emissions (RE) and Radiated Immunity (RI) susceptibility test failures. This paper investigates the root causes of EMC degradation arising from sub-optimal PCB layout and presents design improvements that enhance compliance. By optimizing component placement, ground return paths, and routing strategies, notable improvements in EMC performance are demonstrated across RE and RI tests. In this paper we have used 3D simulation for the purpose of troubleshooting. We have provided a step by step approach to use 3D simulation to validate the test results and to predict further improvement after modification.

title: Avya: The Smart Echo of Plant Wellness
authors: Krishna Prasad K, Dhanya Nagaraj Balekai, Dhanyashree, Esha V Shetty, Vaishali U
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: Agricultural productivity is very much dependent on time identification and treatment of crop diseases. Small-scale farmers, especially those living in rural regions, often come across challenges such as limited access to agricultural experts, language barriers, and unstable or no internet connectivity. This paper presents AVYA: The Smart Echo of Plant Wellness, an AI-powered multilingual mobile application designed to provide real-time crop disease diagnosis and treatment guidance. AVYA implements TensorFlow Lite an optimized convolutional neural network model trained on selected datasets of common field crops to detect the type of plant diseases using leaf images. The system supports offline inference for image-based disease detection while enabling online multilingual voice-based interactions through integration with natural language processing services. Expert-verified treatments, including both organic and chemical solutions, are stored in a structured database and dynamically translated into the farmer's preferred regional language. By combining image analysis, AI-based voice-enabled communication, and language localization, AVYA improves accessibility, accuracy, and timeliness of agricultural decision-making. Field testing demonstrates its potential to improve early disease management and reduce crop loss, thereby contributing to sustainable farming practices.

title: Impact of Optimization Algorithms and Regularization Techniques on Neural Network Performance for Binary Classification
authors: Mostafa A. Ebied, Walid Hamdy, Amr I. Shehta, M. S. Elborlsy, Mohamed Refaat Abdellah
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Telecommunications and Artificial Intelligence (IC-FTAI)
abstract: Optimization and regularization are two critical components influencing the convergence behavior and generalization ability of neural networks. This paper presents a comprehensive comparative evaluation of how different optimization algorithms-Adam, RMSprop, Gradient Descent (GD), and Gradient Descent with Momentum- interact with L1 and L2 regularization in a binary classification setting. Using the Fetal Health dataset from Kaggle, the models were trained over 25 epochs with a batch size of 32, and evaluated through accuracy, precision, recall, and Fl-score metrics. The results prove that the Adam optimizer with L1 regularization achieved the highest performance, reaching 94% accuracy, 0.94 weighted precision, 0.94 recall, and 0.94 Fl-score, closely followed by Adam with L2 and RMSprop with L1, both supporting accuracies above 93%. Conversely, pure gradient descent without momentum underperformed, achieving only 58% accuracy with L1 and 77% with L2, highlighting its inefficiency in handling non-convex error landscapes. Incorporating momentum significantly improved GD's stability and performance, achieving accuracies around 89-90%. These results emphasize the constructive collaboration between adaptive optimizers and proper regularization in improving model robustness and convergence speed. Future research will extend these findings to hybrid optimizers, adaptive regularization methods, and transfer learning-based binary classifiers.

title: An Enhanced Approach of Empowering Social Interaction Among Students with ASD
authors: S. Meena, P. Ramani, D. Sangeetha, S. Ponlatha, Premalatha
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Students with ASD often find it difficult to express their emotions in a social environment. Sometimes even the caregivers, teachers are not able to get connected with the kid. This eventually leads to many challenges in social interactions. To overcome this, multimodal emotional identification system has been adapted here with the procedure of articulation based analysis. The articulation is then converted as words by means of DistilBERT and LSTM based model. The model also takes the input from the caregiver or teachers or anyone who is interacting with the kid. Through the combined analysis of input queries and the responses to them, the analysis has been strengthened. The proposed approach outshined the other traditional ML algorithms in the shorter inference latency and in improvised real time adaptability. Along with the analysis model efficiency has been calculated for the benchmark analysis

title: IoT-Integrated Real-Time Cargo Monitoring and Security System for Logistic Management
authors: K. Naga Tejaswi, D. Rajeswara Rao, B. Karthik, Y. Sanjana
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: Over the years, as global supply chains have become more intricate and seamless, the safety and security of cargo transportation require more attention than ever. Real-time monitoring poses a challenge for many logistics tracking systems currently in use, as they often lack environmental control and alerting mechanisms. To overcome such obstacles, we suggest implementing a multi-sensor-based Arduino microcontroller system that offers integrated real-time monitoring and security for the cargo IoT. It utilizes advanced IoT sensors like DHT-11 to track temperature and humidity, SH-420 for detecting vibrations, BH-1750 for light intensity, and a NEO-6M GPS for real-time location tracking of goods. When predefined shielding thresholds are surpassed, immediate notification is pushed through to the logistics managers via GSM messaging, which ensures quick decision making. This smart IoT-based approach will be in logistics and will enhance timely management, needlessly improving the security of the cargo and the efficiency of its transportation.

title: Federated Learning and Blockchain Integrated Frame-work for Energy Management
authors: Seema Gupta Bhol, Srutipragyan Swain, Prasant Kumar Pattnaik, Suneeta Mohanty
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: Energy saving is need of hour and effective energy management for Smart grids is no exception. Efficient management of Smart grids is complex task and thus needs state-of-the-art technologies for efficient management and ensuring data privacy. For secured and efficient management the emerging technologies like Federated Learning and Blockchains can be deployed. The integration of Federated learning and Blockchain offers a promising solution for these advanced and decentralized energy management systems. Federated Learning is distributed machine learning approach where the model is trained over multiple decentralized devices. data centralization. Blockchain technology offers, immutable,secured distributed ledger system that complement the Federated Learning framework. The integration of Federated learning and Blockchain facilitates secure tamper proof data analytics, which can transform energy management systems. The present research paper proposes a model for Smart grids which is based on integration of FL and BC technologies. The study discusses System Architecture for FL-BC framework. Study also proposes the possible simulation for real-world smart grid scenario consisting of smart energy devices like smart meters, solar panels, industrial IoT sensors, and Home Energy Management Systems (HEMS). It can be simulated using Python with the help of machine learning libraries like TensorFlow, PyTorch.

title: Progressive Dual Branches Guidance Network for Single Image Deraining
authors: Miao Qi, Wei Liu, Hangyu Nie, Ziqiang Huang
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotic Systems and Applications (ICRSA)
abstract: Existing single image deraining methods predominantly focus on eliminating rain streaks and can effectively mitigate rain interference. However, as light refracts through rain streaks, background information is prone to being damaged. It makes texture restoration harder. To overcome these problems, we propose a Progressive Dual Branches Guidance Network for Single Image Deraining The network consists of a dynamic texture reconstruction module and a progressive cross-guidance module. The dynamic texture reconstruction network is based on dynamic convolution and Transformer. It adopts a U-Net architecture, with dynamic convolution modules equipped in both the encoder and the decoder. This setup avoids detail loss that may occur when using fixed convolution kernels to process complex backgrounds. Meanwhile, it can adaptively adjust the shape and weights of convolution kernels according to the input image features to obtain superior feature representations. The progressive guidance network extracts background texture features from an auxiliary network to guide the backbone network in forming rich feature representations, thereby restoring more authentic background information. Extensive experiments show that our method outperforms state-of-the-art techniques.

title: Graph Convolutional Networks for Spatiotemporal Activity Recognition in Smart City
authors: C. Nithyaprabha, P Nithish Kumar, B Pavithra, U K Ragavvan, A Ramyakrishna
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: The rapid expansion of intelligent city infrastructures has resulted in the generation of big spatiotemporal streams of data from various sources, from surveillance networks and IoT sensors to transport systems and social media sites. Conventional deep learning approaches often have difficulty in embracing the non-Euclidean structural relations and temporal dynamics inherent in this data and therefore become ineffective in dealing with large-scale activity recognition tasks. To overcome this barrier, we propose a new spatiotemporal model based on Graph Convolutional Network (GCN) to particularly support big data analysis in smart cities. Compared to conventional hybrid models, our approach has a dual-layer dynamic graph building mechanism that naturally embeds the temporal dynamics of activities and spatial interactions among urban objects at the same time. Moreover, we design an adaptive attention mechanism inside the GCN to give more importance to key spatiotemporal interactions, thus enhancing the accuracy and robustness of recognition in complex urban environments. Compared with state-of-the-art approaches, experimental results over real-world smart city datasets prove better throughput, scalability, and accuracy. As such, this establishes an efficient route towards intelligent urban management and real-time decision-making for smart city systems.

title: A Privacy Preserving Federated Learning Framework for Skin Disease Prediction
authors: Sunny Karmakar, Girisha G S, Reshma J
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: The use of artificial intelligence in the diagnostic sphere is changing the medical sphere as today there is high rate and accuracy in detecting the disease that is in the early stages by scaling them.. With increasing prevalence of skin diseases as well as lack of dermatological services in rural settings, intelligent diagnostic device is in high demand. This study presents a privacy-sensitive distributed learning structure that could be used to categorize the skin diseases using dermoscopic photographs. A deep convolutional neural network using EfficientNet-B2 is fine-tuned on HAM10000 dataset to identify seven different skin conditions. Model training is done locally on simulated statuses of decentralized clients, raw data is not shared among any parties, and updates on client are grouped together on a centralized server to form a global model. The resulting model achieves over 95 percent performance on previously unexplored data. In a few cases (such as remote and resource limited locations and a low latency web based graphical interface which provides an escalation mechanism to display images live and a human readable forecast can be bore).

title: Vision Transformers-Based Structural Health Monitoring System for Bridge Safety
authors: Sudheer Choudari, Shrikrishna Gosavi, B Ramu, J Hemalatha, Saish Pawar, Nidal Al Nidal Al Said
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: In this paper, a Vision Transformers-Based Structural Health Monitoring System to Bridge Safety, a Hybrid Vision Transformer (ViT) + CNN architecture, multi-sensor fusion, and Reinforcement Learning (RL) are used to improve the accuracy, efficiency, and scalability of bridges monitoring. The proposed system combines ViTs, used to extract global features, and CNNs, used to detect local anomalies, up to 95 % accuracy in identifying damage. The multi-sensor fusion adds strength to the model as it is less sensitive to the weather and lighting conditions. Moreover, a Reinforcement Learning agent will self-optimize maintenance schedules, minimizing unnecessary maintenance and increasing bridge lifespan. The system demonstrates the use of PyTorch, Hugging Face Transformers and OpenAI Baselines to provide fast processing and real time performance using edge cloud hybrid architecture. This paper has shown that such a system results in an improvement of the detection accuracy, as well as the efficiency of the operations, which are capable of providing a holistic solution to the long-term management of bridges safety.

title: Impact of AI and Machine Learning on Regulatory Compliance in Financial Services
authors: Nidhi Mahajan
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: This paper discusses the effect of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) on regulatory compliance in the financial services industry. One major technique used is Natural Language Processing (NLP), which is used to analyze regulatory documents, compliance reports, and updates in the law. With the financial industry one of the most regulated industries, and with ever-growing complex and shifting regulations, the traditional manual methods of compliance are no longer efficient nor scalable. By using NLP, financial institutions can automate the process of scanning and understanding large amounts of regulatory texts, which can help them to adapt to new laws and regulations faster and more accurately. The application of NLP enables relevant insights to be extracted from regulatory materials to help ensure compliance for regulatory firms whilst reducing the risk of human error. This paper explains how AI-powered NLP tools greatly increase the efficiency and reliability of compliance frameworks, eventually resulting in the more secure and well-regulated financial services operations.

title: Exploration of Individualized Learning Models and Their Implementation in Vocational Colleges: Adapting to the Challenges of the Digital Intelligence Era
authors: Yang Zhang
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: The focus of this research is on how effective the strategy of providing individual learning models in vocational colleges in the digital intelligence era. Drawing from an explorative research approach and following a phenomenology research, six participants comprising educators and students were interviewed on their perceptions, experiences and challenges. A positive sentiment was observed regarding personalised learning as well as the role of technology, including AI, in the teaching and learning process, while considerable constraints including insufficient funding, support infrastructures and lack of professional development of teachers were reported. As applied and implemented approaches, thus, both integration of technology and industry partnerships were perceived as enablers.

title: Generative AI-Enhanced Deep Learning for Glaucoma: A Framework for Early Detection and Progression Forecasting
authors: Deepa D, R Pugalenthi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Glaucoma is still a leading cause of permanent blindness, and artificial intelligence (AI) has the potential to be used to detect the disease at an early stage. Nevertheless, the current constraints of ophthalmic datasets in the development of deep learning (DL) models are devastating because they are small, unheterogeneous, and cross-sectional in nature. To address these data-centric bottlenecks, this paper suggests a new framework to be implemented with the help of generative AI. We present a procedure by which large-scale, high-fidelity syn- thetic data of color fundus photographs and optical coherence tomography (OCT) scans might be produced using Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs). This is not only a way of overcoming data scarcity and bias in representation, but also allows the synthesis of longitudinal data to model the progression of a disease. Such enhanced datasets will be trained on the models of advanced DLs: a Vision Transformer (ViT) to detect the early signs and a spatiotemporal Convolutional Long Short-Term Memory (ConvLSTM) network to predict the progression. Such models should perform much better than models trained using real data alone especially with respect to their extrapolation to a wide range of real-world clinical environments. This framework will generate credible, precise, and fair AI tools by incorporating explainable AI (XAI) methods, which will lead to customized and predictive glaucoma care.

title: AI Powered Honeypots for Advanced Threat Detection and Analysis
authors: K Malarvizhi, Ravivarman M, Chandru R, Dharshan S, Ranjith M, Nagaraj S
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Cyber attacks are becoming more sophisticated and happening more often. Traditional honeypot systems like rule-based methods depend on manually defined patterns requiring significant human effort for analysis and struggle to detect novel attacks thus frequently falling short in identifying sophisticated intrusion patterns and ensuring timely responses. To address these limitations, An Al-powered honeypot system is proposed to proactively detect, classify, and analyze cyber-attacks using machine learning techniques and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network algorithms. By simulating common attack vectors such as DDoS, brute-force login attempts, and malware probes, the system collects real-time data which is then analyzed using autoencoder-based feature extraction and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) for multi-class classification of intrusion types. Furthermore, the system automatically sends email notifications in real time to alert relevant cybersecurity personnel upon the detection of malicious activity. All captured attack data is securely stored in a computer database for further analysis and forensic investigation. The Al-driven approach significantly enhances early threat detection, enables faster and more accurate incident response, and provides a valuable repository of attack information for modern network environments.

title: Smart Sensor Network for Privacy Preserving Surveillance System
authors: Sakthimohan M, Devadharshini.G, Naveenkanth. S, Sanjai M
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: The real-time privacy-preserving human presence detection system is the design for large indoor environments like malls and warehouses. The proposed system is the integration of camera-based face recognition with IoT sensor-based human presence detection while ensure continuous monitoring while maintaining privacy in restricted areas like trial rooms and restrooms. During Functioning hours, the system captures and identifies individuals using existing CCTV cameras through a Python-based recognition module. While in privacy zones, non-visual sensors such as PIR, ultrasonic, temperature, and sound sensors detect occupancy without visual intrusion. An LED indicator notifies on-site staff when human presence is detected, and alerts are triggered automatically during after-hours activity. To ensure the surveillance accuracy, this hybrid architecture is proposed to minimise false alarms and also by preserving personal privacy of each individual by combining real-time data processing with sensing method. The system demonstrates scalable, and privacy-conscious approach towards the modern smart surveillance applications.

title: Icing State Identification for Wind Turbines Based on Wind Speed-Temperature Coupling Features and Ensemble Learning
authors: Dai Wen, Huai Xiaowei, Li Bo, Xie Linjin, Kang Wenjun, Yang Boyuan
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Smart Grid and Clean Energy Technologies (ICSGCE)
abstract: With the transformation of the global energy structure, wind power—an important component of clean energy—has seen increasingly widespread development and application, particularly in cold climate regions. However, harsh winter meteorological conditions such as low temperatures and high humidity frequently lead to wind turbine icing, which severely affects wind power generation efficiency and threatens the safe and stable operation of the power grids. To address the challenge of icing state identification in mountainous wind farms, this paper proposes an innovative method based on a wind speed– temperature coupling (STC) feature and multi-model stacking ensemble learning. By constructing the STC feature in accordance with physical mechanisms, the synergistic effects of temperature and wind speed across different temperature ranges are effectively quantified. Four heterogeneous models—Random Forest, XGBoost, LSTM, and Transformer—are integrated to significantly improve identification accuracy. Validation was conducted using three winters of monitoring data from a high-altitude, cold-region wind farm in central China, and the results show that the proposed method achieved an accuracy of 90.8% and demonstrated strong generalization capability. This method not only improves the accuracy of wind turbine icing detection, but also provides effective technical support for the intelligent operation and maintenance of wind farms and the safe operation of power grids.

title: NLP and Reinforcement Learning-Based Chatbots for Efficient Public Service Delivery in Smart Cities
authors: Sowmya V, Syed Fakruddin Albeez, Venkadeshan Ramallngam, G. Nagappan, G. Manikandan, Saranya R
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI)-powered chatbots are revolutionizing public service delivery in Indian municipalities by increasing operational efficiency and citizen engagement. Physical visits and phone calls were instances of conventional approaches that were costly, time-consuming, and had little penetration. The AI-based chatbot system can automatically respond in real-time to citizens' questions, complaints, and service status checks because it is based on natural language processing (NLP) and machine learning (ML). Among its attributes are its round-the-clock accessibility, simple backend integration, and reinforcement learning for continuous learning. Performance evaluation shows reaction times have decreased from 5 to 20 minutes to 1 to 5 seconds, resolution rates have improved by 10 to 20%, and average user satisfaction has increased from 3.2 to 4.7 out of 5. With the extra benefit of being cost-effective, the proposed method improves productivity, scalability, and service quality significantly, starting a greater degree of confidence between the former citizens and the local authorities.

title: DRL-FedProto: Adaptive Hyperparameter Tuning for Federated Prototype Learning Using Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Wenjin Liang, Min Tang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Federated learning (FL) is a distributed learning setting that can handle the privacy data challenge. However, FL encounters two main bottlenecks: communication cost and Non Independent and Identically Distributed (Non-IID) data. FedProto can mitigate the communication cost by exchanging the class prototypes and works very well. Conventional FedProto however uses a static hyperparameter set and pays fixed local training parameters on all clients, hence it cannot adapt to client data distributions or the states of model training, leading to the potential degradation of the global model.To cope with this bottleneck, we propose a DRL-FedProto: a Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) algorithm to adaptively tune FedProto hyperparameters. In federated training, we consider the multi-client hyperparameter configuration as a Markov Decision Process (MDP). To this end, we designed a Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) agent that, observing the global state, receives personalized local hyperparameters for each client in each round of communications: local batch size, local epoch and loss weight. The agent's objective is to learn a valid policy that maximizes the last converged performance accuracy of the global model trained on the Non-IID dataset. We simulated the Non-IID scenario on several public datasets: Australian, Breast-Cancer and Diabetes. Experimental results show that our DRL-FedProto algorithm outperforms the FedProto baseline and achieves the largest performance improvement of up to 8.5%. However, by an in-depth ablation study, we also highlight that the elements of the reward themselves, most importantly the stability penalty, are very sensitive to dataset statistics and can only be relatively well parameterized, which is a key insight for future work.

title: OSPP-RT-YOLO:A Multi-Scale Detector for Aluminum Surface Defects
authors: Zhiwei Xuan, Jianlin Mao, Jinbao Zhang, Kaixin Tong, Chang Liu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: To address the high missed detection rate for small targets, insufficient accuracy for multi-scale defects, and high computational costs of traditional methods in aluminum surface defect detection, this paper proposes the Omni-Scale Perception Pyramid (OSPP) algorithm. In the neck structure, our method uses SNI and GSConvE to dynamically fuse multi-scale features and employs a SPDConv module to enhance small target feature extraction. To eliminate the NMS post-processing overhead, we replace the conventional detection head with RT-DETR’s Transformer decoder, which uses self-attention mechanisms to improve contextual modeling and generates bounding boxes directly via query vectors. Experimental results show our algorithm achieves an AP@0.5 of 84.7%. Compared to the baseline model YOLOv8n, the AP@0.5 is improved by 13%, with a significant performance boost for small defects. The algorithm demonstrates strong robustness to complex background interference while maintaining high real-time capability.

title: Frequency Stability and System Resilience of Grid Forming and Grid Following Inverters with a Partial Power Boost Converter under Grid Strength Variation in Distribution Networks
authors: Gordon Everah Max, Ramon Zamora, Babar Ejaz
publish: 2025 IEEE PES 17th Asia-Pacific Power and Energy Engineering Conference (APPEEC)
abstract: Modern distribution networks face the challenge of frequency instability as inverter-based resources (IBRs) replace synchronous generators. This paper investigates frequency stability and system resilience in a photovoltaic (PV)-integrated 22 kV distribution system in Papua New Guinea (PNG), focusing on droop-based grid-forming inverter (GFMI) and enhanced grid-following inverter (EGFLI) control strategies. A 2.50 MW PV farm with a partial power converter (PPC) and perturb-and-observe maximum power point tracking (MPPT) was modeled in MATLAB/Simulink. Grid strength variation was introduced by tuning feeder resistance and reactance to emulate short-circuit ratios (SCRs) of a strong grid (SCR=15), a weak grid (SCR=5), and a very weak grid (SCR=2), including islanded scenarios. The simulation results show that droop-based GFMI consistently maintained frequency deviations within ±0.03 Hz and rapidly resynchronized under severe disturbances, while phase-locked loop (PLL)-based EGFLI exhibited oscillations and longer settling times. The PPC enhanced DC-link stability and ensured robust PV output under real irradiance and temperature data. The findings confirm that GFMI control provides superior frequency stability and system resilience for low-inertia grids, making it a promising replacement for synchronous generators in very weak and unstable distribution networks.

title: Mineuron: Minimal Neuron Realization For Fast Fpga Snn Inference Using Logic Optimization
authors: Daniel Windhager, Lothar Ratschbacher, Bernhard A. Moser, Michael Lunglmayr
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: We introduce MiNeuron as a solution for achieving efficient inference of Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) on FPGA platforms. Built upon the Leaky Integrate-and-Fire neuron model and incorporating sparse optimization during training, MiNeuron enables efficient use of an FPGA’s on-board lookup tables. An SNN is implemented in Python using the PyTorch library, with custom modifications designed to support sparse learning. The learned weights are mapped to logic tables by using logic optimization at synthesis time. Our findings show that this approach enables the FPGAs used in the “Digit Recognition Low Power and Speed Challenge” of this conference to achieve approximately 3.9 million inferences per second per Watt, all while satisfying the required accuracy target of 97.5%.

title: Case Study: Optimizing Energy Consumption in Robotics Using Linear Regression for Control Parameter Prediction
authors: George Read
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Telecommunications and Artificial Intelligence (IC-FTAI)
abstract: This research addresses the growing concern related to energy consumption in robotic systems. The increasing diversity of robots and their applications across various industries requires new energy-efficient strategies to decrease operational costs and reduce environmental impact. This paper presents a linear regression-based approach to reduce energy consumption in robotics. The method is to use linear regression in the prediction of appropriate control parameters and to investigate the possibility of integrating simulation into the system to further reduce energy consumption. The challenge is the uncertain and dynamic nature of energy consumption during robotic systems operations, which limits the efficiency of standard control measures. This paper presents a linear regression model that was trained on large sets of data that contain operational parameters in robotic systems and associated energy consumption measures. This linear regression model predicts those operational parameters that would minimize energy consumption while meeting the desired performance. The primary contribution was that the linear regression generated predictive controls that could greatly reduce energy consumption compared to standard operational controls. Through our investigation, we affirm that linear regression is a practical and implementable machine learning approach for real energy optimization in robotics. Through the operational changes resulting from intelligence in altered control parameters, the potential for savings in energy consumption and improving operational efficiency is significant.

title: Optimization Scheduling Strategy for Microgrid Based on Credit Score Demand Response
authors: Ming Yu
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Smart Grid and Clean Energy Technologies (ICSGCE)
abstract: Demand response is a means to achieve balance between electricity supply and demand on the user side through adjusting the electricity consumption behavior based on incentive signals. An optimization scheduling problem of a microgrid is addressed by utilizing the proposed credit score demand response in this paper. Based on price incentives and user credit, demand response is regulated, and the optimization is performed using a greedy algorithm that dispatches the power among the renewable energy, micro gas turbines, the energy storage and users. By comparing and analyzing the operation results under three typical working conditions which are summer sunny days, winter overcast days and island operation, the system operation and demand response reliability are evaluated. By updating user credit through a differentiated incentive mechanism, the participation of high-credit users can be effectively enhanced and benefited, while constraints on low-credit users are formed and default risks are accordingly reduced, thus enhancing the reliability of microgrid demand response and providing more economic benefits for high-credit.

title: Detection Of Generated Obscured Images Protecting Confidential Image Content
authors: Valentin Noyé, Norman Hutte, Pauline Puteaux, William Puech
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: More and more multimedia data, such as images and videos, is transmitted over digital networks and stored or shared in the Cloud. For reasons of confidentiality or secret information, it is increasingly necessary to protect multimedia content directly. Although many image obscuration methods have been developed to protect the semantic content of images, few of them are both reversible and non-visible, and therefore detectable visually or by trained classifiers. In this paper, we propose a new image obscuration method based on variational autoencoders and a secret key, that transforms images from their source class into a target class, in a non-visible and reversible way, allowing the original image content to be recovered. In the experimental results we present whether the obscured images generated by our method are detectable.

title: Image segmentation Method based on the Improved Falcon Optimization
authors: Jianheng Yin, Ying Guo
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: Image segmentation is a critical step in image processing and analysis, with the aim of dividing images into mutually exclusive regions in order to extract objects of interest. Conventional thresholding, region-based, and edge-driven methodologies are inherently vulnerable to noise, lighting variations, and texture complexity, resulting in suboptimal robustness. Whilst the incorporation of swarm intelligence algorithms into segmentation can enhance accuracy, such approaches frequently encounter challenges such as slow convergence and susceptibility to local optima.To address these issues, this paper proposes an image segmentation method based on the Improved Falcon Optimization (IFO)-2D Otsu algorithm. Specifically, in the exploration phase, IFO introduces random solutions to improve the global search ability and avoid falling into local optimum. During the exploitation phase, a variable-step mutation operator based on population entropy is designed to enhance the local search capabilities of IFO. The experimental findings demonstrate that, in comparison with conventional swarm intelligence methodologies such as the Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) and Aquila Optimization (AO), this approach leads to substantial enhancements in convergence speed, accuracy, and robustness in the context of multi-threshold grayscale image segmentation.

title: Dual-Attention GAN for Multi-Disease Detection in Noisy Chest X-ray Images
authors: S.Rajalakshmi, Bediga Sharan, A. Sumaiya Begum, S.Sesha Vidhya, Ashwini Pravin Navghane, B.Jegajothi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Noise artifacts and superposition of the pathological characteristics of the pathological entities are common to impair the accurate diagnosis of the thoracic diseases by means of a chest X-ray. The study proposes DAGNet-X, a generative adversarial network with dual attention together with a cross-modality transformer classifier that fulfils these requirements in cross-disease detection using noisy chest radiographs. Proposed architecture takes an initial step in using the Dual-Attention GAN to parallel reduce noise in the images and enhance features related to the disease by using channel attention and spatial attention. The denoised representations are subsequently passed into residual CNN encoder and a transformer-based classification head which allows the contextual comprehension of fine-grained lesion patterns across image patches. The model has been tested on the NIH ChestX-ray14 radiography and has performed outstandingly well, its overall accuracy is 95.1 percent, F1-score 93.5 percent, and ROC-AUC 98.1 percent. Due to the contrast of certain traditional CNN and DenseNet-based models, disease-wise, the AUC scores were better with DAGNet-X being overall better in AUC scores with values of 0.968 and 0.944 being disease-wise and cardiomegaly and atelectasis, respectively. The explainability score of the suggested model was also quite high (0.91) due to the incorporation of SHAP and Grad-CAM visualization techniques. In spite of that, DAGNet-X was only 3.3ms per image and thus has the potential to be deployed on a real-time device. This indicates that the performance of the DAGNet-X can be recommended as an effective and clear-cut approach to automated diagnosis of chest diseases. Its clean up capacity with the denoising improvement of clinically significant patterns presents an excellent progression in smart medical imaging systems.

title: A Sparse algorithm of Intelligent Reflecting Surface for Physical Layer Secure Communication
authors: Linhan Wang, Wei Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: Intelligent Reflecting Surfaces (IRS) enhance wireless communication security by dynamically adjusting channel properties through destructive interference at eavesdropping points, improving physical layer security. paper proposes an IRS sparse design scheme using a simplified clouded leopard algorithm to optimize reflective unit placement. Compared to existing methods, the sparse configuration achieves higher security rates under identical array size and power constraints. To address multi-objective optimization challenges, a penalty-based fitness function is designed, converting the problem into a constrained single-objective framework. This approach effectively balances security performance and resource efficiency.

title: Lightweight YOLOv7 Architecture for Obstacle Recognition and Depth Mapping in Assistive Walking Systems
authors: V. Saroja, A. Muthukumaravel
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Obstacle detection and reliable depth estimation are key abilities in assistive walking devices that aim to help the visually impaired navigate. A lightweight two-branch architecture using a YOLOv7-tiny network is proposed with modifications to avoid these limitations. This design can process monocular depth estimation and obstacle detection simultaneously using shared feature representations. With the addition of semantic detection components to the depth regression process, the developed method uses a novel cross-attention fusion scheme to enhance the geometric reasoning process. The outcome of the experiment shows that the system performs beyond expectations, with a 95.3% mAP@0.5 detection rate and an RMSE of 0.129 meters in the depth estimation. With a model size of just 12.8 MB, the NVIDIA Jetson Nano makes it possible to carry out real-time inference at a rate of over 28 FPS. The proposed approach can improve intelligent guided navigation in a range of applications based on its high level of generalizability as well as low processing delay.

title: YOLO-CFD: An Enhanced Deep Learning Framework with Bi-Level Routing Attention and Spatial Pyramid Pooling for Precise Brain Tumor Detection in MRI Images
authors: Xianyu Hu, Chaoyue Ouyang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Early diagnosis and accurate localization of brain tumors are crucial for improving patient survival rates. Among these, automated detection methods based on deep learning have become a research hotspot. However, tumor detection, especially for complex shapes and small targets, remains challenging. To address this, this study proposes an improved YOLO model— YOLO-CFD—aimed at enhancing the detection accuracy for complex and small targets in brain tumor MRI images. The model builds upon YOLO by incorporating the BRASPPF module (a combination of bi-level routing attention mechanism and spatial pyramid pooling), dilated convolution, and small object detection layers. Experimental results show that the YOLOv8-CFD model achieves a good balance between precision and recall, with an overall mAP@0.5 of 0.929 and an F1 score reaching 0.90, demonstrating excellent detection performance. When detecting tumors, the model’s precision values are 0.974, 0.964, and 0.851, respectively. Validation results show that the model can provide accurate predictions at both high and low confidence levels, with strong detection capabilities and good generalization ability, making a significant contribution to the identification of brain tumors.

title: Deep Learning for Stock Market Prediction: A Comparative Study of LSTM and Transformer-Based Models
authors: S. Venkatesan, Kabirdoss Devi, T.V. Ambuli, Sampath K., V. Ramu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: Stock market prediction involves complicated and dynamic tasks because financial data shows stochastic behavior. The research details an evaluation of the predictive abilities between the Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and Transformer-based deep learning models in stock market analysis. Stock market data from the past was employed to test both models for their capability to extract pattern information and generate trustworthy predictive estimations. When applied to stock market predictions the Transformer achieved better results than LSTM since it attained 97.9% accuracy while LSTM only achieved a prediction accuracy of 94.2%. The Transformer-based approach demonstrated superior performance, achieving a lower Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of 8.97, highlighting its capability to better model long-range dependencies in financial data. The research results demonstrate that Transformer models exceed LSTM models in their capacity to handle complex market dependencies and market trend patterns. The study adds value to present-day attempts that use state-of-the-art deep learning strategies to enhance algorithmic trading systems as well as financial business decision systems.

title: Attention-Augmented Generative AdversarialNetworks (GANs) for Synthetic Data Augmentationin Prostate Cancer MRI-Bases Segmentation Tasks
authors: Kavitha A, Mayilan Y, Naveen Kumar S
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Prostate cancer remains to be one of the most common cancers in men. Detection and segmentation of this cancer from MRI images are very important for patient outcomes. The work in this project introduces a novel method utilizing attention-augmented GANs in generating synthetic data for the specific application of prostate cancer MRI segmentation. By integrating multi-scale U-Net models with channel-attention and spatial-attention mechanisms, the system generates high-fidelity mpMRI images representing patterns of interest for prostate cancer. A two-attention discriminator and Wasserstein adversarial training ensure anatomical fidelity and diversity of the synthesized data, addressing data scarcity and enhancing segmentation model strength. In reality, a segmentation network that integrates synthetic data and attention-based subnetworks demonstrates remarkable gains in correctly delineating tumors, particularly in challenging and complex cases. Quality assurance entails detailed quantitative evaluations, radiologist-led assessments, and statistical reviews to ensure the clinical significance and reliability of the synthetic data set. The methodology involves curriculum learning, uncertainty estimations, and interpretability tools that enable reliable model predictions and expert reviews efficiently. Overall, this project establishes a technique for synthetic data augmentation based on advances in adversarial and attention learning in recent times, resulting in improved prostate MRI segmentation and offering a useful resource to improve prostate cancer screening and diagnosis.

title: E-Commerce IP Shield: A CNN-RNN Ensemble Framework for Predicting Trademark Infringements on Online Platforms
authors: T Logapriya, Frederick Ruby Helen, B. Lavaraju
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: In online trademark infringements a fundamental challenge is the heterogeneous modality of the data, involving semi-structured textual claims as well as unstructured visual features. It is challenging to treat the multimodal data in a unified way, and there is a need for methods which address and combine different kinds of data cohesively. Most of the conventional models are restricted to one-to-one pair-wise matching, which is not desirable in some real-word tasks (e.g., trademark infringement), where a single product may have multiple variations. In this study, to design a novel lightweight ensemble-framework, E-Commerce IP Shield, that incorporates RNN architecture to leverage image-based features and textual claim information for the detection of trademark-infringement pertaining to online platforms. The motivation of this work is to improve the vector representation of the utilized annotation algorithm by exploiting the complementary advantages between CNNs and RNNs (sequential text). Our suggested model obtained the total average accuracy of 99.24%, this result shows our model achieve better accuracy from other traditional Models.

title: Intelligent IoT Framework for Real-Time BLDC Drive Fault notification using PID and Neural Network Optimization
authors: J Dhanaselvam, S Madumitha, J Justin, I Libin Jebel, Ajith B Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: A neural network-based controller to control the speed of a Brushless DC (BLDC) motor accurately and reliably in real-time has been proposed in this research. The controller generates the Pulse-Width Modulation (PWM) signals used by the electronic speed controller by processing the reference speed input and providing constant voltage and current feedback. The proposed system provides improved steady-state accuracy, an improved response, and better disturbance rejection compared to the traditional methods by learning the nonlinear aspects of the motor and adapting to load, supply voltage, and other external disturbances. The inference mechanism used is lightweight and executed near the motor to minimize response time, and hybrid fallback logic helps maintain stability and safety by utilizing conventional methods as fallback in case of anomalous outputs.

title: Design of the UNet and Spatial-Time Augmentation Method with Feature Fusion for Soybean Diseases and Yield Prediction
authors: Jenila Rani D, M. Manideepika, Mohammad Omar Sabri, R. Koteswara Rao, Rajkumar Bhookya, Swathi B
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: To improve predictions of soybean yields and disease detection by employing multimodal data processing and augmentation techniques, we developed the UNet and Spatial-Time Augmentation Method with Feature Fusion for Soybean Diseases and Yield Prediction (USAFSY) model. Based on 164 high-resolution images of soybean diseases from controlled labs, the study tackled overfitting in small datasets through various offline augmentation methods and introduced SpatialTime Augmentation (STA) for dynamic spatiotemporal variations. The model include a multi-head attention mechanism for feature integration using feedforward neural networks, a custom UNet architecture for extracting features from satellite and meteorological data, and the application of Heterogeneous Graph Neural Networks (HGNN) to represent complex agricultural relationships. The USAFSY model used these parameters to calculate STA Analysis, Confusion Matrix, Accuracy Calculation, RMSE Calculation, and F1-Score Calculation.

title: Large Parallax Image Stitching Based on Spatial Distance-Residual Constrained Warping
authors: Tengfei Zhang, Huanhuan Xie, Xiaohang Ma, Dong Sun
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Large parallax images with depth variations remain a persistent challenge in image stitching. Despite numerous attempts by warping-based methods, the results often fall short of expectations. This paper presents a novel large parallax image stitching algorithm based on spatial distance-residual constrained warping. The approach begins by dividing the target image into superpixel grids and determining the optimal homography for each grid by evaluating the contribution of feature points based on their spatial distance to the grid center and homography residual consistency. Additionally, spatial gradient complexity and homography residual consistency confidence are introduced to adaptively adjust the contribution weights of local geometric distance and homography residual consistency using the softmax function. Finally, a strategy based on Random Sample Consensus (RANSAC) for outlier removal is proposed. This approach refines the selection of inliers through an improved bidirectional projection error criterion, thereby enhancing the accuracy of feature matching. Experimental results demonstrate that the algorithm accurately aligns large parallax images with depth, outperforming state-of-the-art stitching methods.

title: AI-Driven Transparent Trend Analysis of Inflation and its Macroeconomic Implications
authors: Smrutirekha Mohanty, Ananya Mitra, Shradhanjali Panda, Leena Priyadarshini Singh, Bhumika Das
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: The paper uses Explainable Boosting Machines (EBMs) to examine inflation dynamics and macroeconomics implications and focuses on the predictive performance as well as transparency. The EBMs, which are a type of generalized additive models that automatically identify interactions, are most appropriate to represent non-linear relationships between monetary supply, interest rates, unemployment, and commodity prices as the independent variables and inflation as the dependent variable. The analysis also quantifies the contribution of each variable to the trends on inflation by incorporating SHAP (SHapley Additive Explanations), which makes the analysis interpretable to policy-makers and economists. These findings indicate that the EBMs perform as well as the developed black-box models in relation to forecasting; therefore, they are suitable in economic policy settings. The model emphasizes the prevalence of the impact of energy price shocks and the state of the labor market in recent increases in inflation, and finds the lagged impact of monetary tightening. This transparent method based on AI provides a strong paradigm of monitoring inflation, allowing making macroeconomic decisions based on evidence and enhancing trust in the application of machine learning to economic analysis.

title: Next-Gen Battery Management Systems for Optimized Electric Vehicle Performance
authors: Sonu Kumar, Radhika Dora, Desham Sai Nivas
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: The rapid evolution of electric vehicles (EVs) has underscored the critical importance of advanced Battery Management Systems (BMS) in enhancing battery performance, safety, and longevity. This paper explores recent advancements in BMS design and optimization, focusing on key areas such as enhanced state estimation algorithms, improved thermal management techniques, wireless communication systems, and fault diagnosis through predictive maintenance. Enhanced state estimation methods, including Kalman filters and neural networks, significantly improve the accuracy of State of Charge (SoC) and State of Health (SoH) predictions, thereby optimizing battery usage. Innovative thermal management strategies, such as phase change materials and dynamic cooling systems, ensure that batteries operate within safe temperature ranges, enhancing their lifespan. The adoption of Wireless Battery Management Systems (WBMS) reduces wiring complexity, leading to lighter battery packs and increased reliability through advanced communication protocols. Furthermore, the integration of artificial intelligence enables early fault detection and predictive maintenance, allowing for proactive management of battery health. As these technologies continue to evolve, they promise to play a pivotal role in the broader adoption of electric vehicles and the transition towards sustainable transportation solutions. This paper provides a comprehensive overview of these advancements and their implications for future EV designs.

title: Optimal V2G Scheduling of Electric Buses to Mitigate Grid Constraints and Absorb PV Surplus Power
authors: Minato Umetsu, Yutaka Iino, Tsunayoshi Ishii, Yasuhiro Hayashi, Takashi Hada, Ryo Maeda, Shingo Uchiyama
publish: 2025 IEEE PES 17th Asia-Pacific Power and Energy Engineering Conference (APPEEC)
abstract: This study proposes a vehicle-to-grid (V2G) scheduling method for battery electric buses (BEBs) that optimizes the charge/discharge schedule to simultaneously absorb surplus photovoltaic (PV) power in the distribution grid during the day and avoid grid-constraint violations caused by the evening peak load. The proposed model is formulated using mixed-integer secondorder cone programming, which relaxes the AC optimal power flow (ACOPF) problem considering a 24-h scheduling horizon with 5-min intervals and the operational constraints of both the distribution network and the BEBs. Numerical simulation results indicate that BEBs absorb surplus PV-generated power during the day to meet their transportation requirements and discharge the minimum amount required in the evening, which is sufficient to alleviate voltage violations and line congestion. This suggests the feasibility of an operational strategy that ensures responsiveness to grid conditions, as well as the minimization of energy losses from discharging and guaranteeing scheduled bus services.

title: Prompt-Based Jailbreaking of Leading LLM Chatbots: A Survey of Attacks and Defenses
authors: Brynn Knowlton, Jovani Campa, David Solis Gallo, Khalil Dajani, Nabeel Alzahrani
publish: IEEE Transactions on Artificial Intelligence
abstract: Generative AI systems—particularly large language models (LLMs)—remain vulnerable to jailbreak attacks: adversarial prompts that bypass safeguards and elicit unsafe or restricted outputs. This survey synthesizes jailbreak research from 2023–2025, covering attack methods, defense strategies, and evaluation frameworks. Jailbreak techniques are grouped into five main categories: prompt-based injections, role-play conditioning, multi-turn dialogue, multilingual or multimodal exploits, and optimization-driven pipelines. We also examine discovery methods such as human red teaming and automated attacker systems (e.g., AutoJailbreak, LLMStinger), and review defense mechanisms including supervised fine-tuning (SFT), reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF), adversarial fine-tuning, and output or pipeline filtering. Standardized benchmarks—such as PromptBench, JailbreakBench, and multimodal evaluation suites—are analyzed in terms of reproducibility, coverage, and robustness testing. Persistent issues of generalization, reproducibility, and scalability are discussed, along with tradeoffs between safety alignment and model utility. This paper provides an up-to-date reference clarifying the evolving landscape of jailbreak attacks and defenses in LLMs.

title: Handover Optimization Using a Dynamic $\epsilon$-Greedy Based Q-Learning and a Hybrid MCDM Approach in Heterogeneous Networks
authors: Pratyashi Satapathy, Judhistir Mahapatro, Maheswar Rajagopal
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Heterogeneous network is a dedicated approach to leveraging the potential benefits of all existing wireless networks by integrating diverse radio access technologies with varying specifications to fulfill the demands of mobile users. Two primary factors that influence a mobile user to switch network connections are their mobility and changing network conditions. An efficient vertical handover solution can enable the seamless transfer of an ongoing user's connection to a better-suited network. This paper proposes an intelligent, optimized vertical handover decision algorithm with a two-phase approach. First, a feasible network category (i.e., small cell or macro cell) is determined based on user speed. This phase ensures fast-moving users do not experience handover abnormalities during communication. Then, an optimal target node is selected from this feasible set using a hybrid multi-criteria decision-making approach. Second, a dynamic <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\epsilon$</tex-math></inline-formula>-greedy-based Q-learning technique is employed to learn the near-optimal handover triggering point, ensuring timely and successful handover execution. Crucially, the <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\epsilon$</tex-math></inline-formula> value is not rigidly fixed; instead, it adapts dynamically, driven by rewards from the environment. The conclusions drawn from network simulations illustrate that the proposed algorithm outperforms other existing algorithms by minimizing handover delays, ping-pong effects, failure rates, and packet loss rates.

title: Stable and Durable BTOnws&#x2013;PVDF Triboelectric Nanogenerator for Self-Powered energy supply and Real-Time Impact Monitoring_supp3-3663008.mp4
authors: Xiong Dien
publish: N/A
abstract: Triboelectric nanogenerator (TENG) has emerged as promising candidates for self-powered systems due to their ability to harvest mechanical energy and serve as active sensors. In this work, we report the fabrication of a barium titanate nanowire (BTOnws)-doped poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) composite TENG, designed to enhance mechanical robustness and electrical output. The optimized TENG exhibits stable and superior output performance including open-circuit voltage (VOC) of 280 V, short-circuit current (ISC) of 12 μA, and power density of 1.45 W/m2. The effects of device structural on output performance are systematically investigated. Environmental stability tests reveal that the TENG maintained stable voltage and current outputs across a wide temperature/humidity range and over 10,000 contact–separation cycles and that the output attenuation of this TENG is superior to that of the previously reported PVDF-based TENG. Furthermore, we verify its power supply capability by lighting up 52 LEDs and fabricated a new TENG-integrated table tennis bat for wireless position detection. The sensing system utilize a two-stage amplification circuit to overcome the high output impedance of TENGs, achieving accurate localization of ball impacts with only nine sensing units. This study not only provides insights into optimizing TENG structural and environmental resilience but also highlights their potential in electronic devices, sports analytics, and intelligent sensing networks.

title: Design of Three-Stage Twisted and Folded Clos Network Based on Necessary and Sufficient Condition for Strict-Sense Non-Blocking
authors: Takuto Kubo, Ryotaro Taniguchi, Kazuya Anazawa, Eiji Oki
publish: IEEE Transactions on Networking
abstract: Optical circuit switching provides high-capacity and low-latency data transmission capabilities. A Clos network is well known as a class of non-blocking switching networks. A prior study addressed designing a three-stage twisted and folded Clos network (3TF), which has a larger switching network size, i.e., the number of terminals connected to the network, than its two-stage variants. That study used a sufficient condition for strict-sense non-blocking (SNB) in 3TF to solve an optimization design problem. However, this condition may be stricter than necessary to guarantee strict-sense non-blocking, suggesting that by using the necessary and sufficient condition, the constraints can likely be relaxed, allowing for configurations with a larger switching network size. No study has addressed the necessary and sufficient condition for SNB in the whole 3TF. A past study derived the SNB condition for the three-stage folded Clos (3F), the basis of 3TF, assuming that connections within the same first- and second-stage group loop back no further than the second stage. Its necessary and sufficient condition in the general case, however, remains unexamined, despite an initial study on the SNB condition for 3F. This paper proposes a design model of 3TF based on the necessary and sufficient condition for strict-sense non-blocking. We derive and prove the necessary and sufficient condition for strict-sense non-blocking in the whole 3TF. The proposed design model considers two cases: one where no blocking is allowed and another where the blocking probability does not exceed a given admissible threshold, based on our derived necessary and sufficient condition for strict-sense non-blocking in 3TF. We formulate the problem based on the necessary and sufficient condition to obtain the configuration of the proposed model that maximizes the switching network size. We theoretically show that the maximum switching network size obtained by solving the proposed model is always larger than or equal to that obtained by solving the existing 3TF design model. Numerical results show that the proposed model achieves a larger switching network size than the existing 3TF design model.

title: Rethinking Graph Contrastive Learning for Heterophilic Graphs: An Effective Method for Heterophilic GCL Methods With Regularization and Stabilization Techniques Enhanced High-Pass Filter
authors: Han Chen, Yuhua Li, Yixiong Zou, Keke Huang, Rui Zhang, Ruixuan Li, Philip S.Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering
abstract: Graph contrastive learning (GCL) is a powerful self-supervised learning approach. However, existing GCL methods are designed for homophilic graphs, using low-pass filters that struggle to capture high-frequency components in heterophilic graphs. We propose <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">G</u>raph <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">C</u>ontrastive <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">L</u>earning with <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">R</u>egularization and stabilization techniques enhanced high-pass <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">F</u>ilter (GCLRF). <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">RE</u>gularization and <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">S</u>tabilization techniques enhanced <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">H</u>igh-pass filter (RESH) can serve as a mutually promoting plug-in, significantly improving the performance of various homophilic GCL training strategies on heterophilic graphs. We also investigate four component orderings in RESH and identify the optimal fusion mechanism, demonstrating its critical impact on performance. Experiments show GCLRF achieves state-of-the-art (SOTA) performance across six benchmark datasets in node classification and clustering. Notably, on the Cornell dataset, GCLRF outperformers classification accuracy by 6.76% and achieves a 23.64%relative improvement in clustering normalized mutual information (NMI).

title: Refining Clear-sky AI Radiative Transfer Model Forward Predictions and Jacobian Accuracy for ATMS Using a ResNet and Physical Constraints
authors: Xingming Liang, Quanhua Liu, Christopher Grassotti
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Radiative Transfer Models (RTMs) are pivotal in remote sensing and data assimilation, providing simulations of satellite-measured radiances and corresponding Jacobians—matrices that quantify how radiative quantities change in response to variations in atmospheric or surface parameters. These Jacobians lie at the heart of variational data assimilation and drive a wide range of inverse modeling applications. Although traditional RTMs yield high-fidelity results, they are computationally intensive, which is increasingly problematic given the high spatial, temporal, and spectral resolutions measured by modern sensors. Recent advances in artificial intelligence (AI) have led to AI-derived “fast” RTMs that substantially accelerate forward predictions, (e.g., brightness temperatures). However, accurately estimating and stabilizing AI-derived Jacobians remains a key challenge. In this paper, we present a new AI-CRTM framework based on a Residual Neural Network (ResNet), augmented by physical constraints using the reference Jacobians from the traditional Community Radiative Transfer Model (CRTM). By leveraging residual connections, the proposed approach mitigates vanishing gradients and captures complex, multi-scale dependencies in radiative transfer physics. Physical constraints are applied during training to align the learned partial derivatives with trusted RTM references, thus ensuring physically consistent Jacobians. The AI_CRTM was initially trained and tested for simulated measurements from the Advanced Technology Microwave Sounder (ATMS) in global clear-sky conditions. Forward-model accuracy is accessed through comparisons with both CRTM-simulated radiances and high-spectral-resolution line-by-line simulations from the MonoRTM model. The results demonstrate that incorporating these constraints, alongside ResNet’s residual structure, significantly improves both forward prediction accuracy and Jacobian fidelity. This hybrid strategy addresses ill-posed issues in AI Jacobian inference, broadens applicability to different atmospheric scenarios, and paves the way for rapid and robust data assimilation.

title: Sub-connected Active RIS Assisted Secrecy Communications
authors: Xiaoyu Song, Liang Wu, Zaichen Zhang
publish: IEEE Communications Letters
abstract: This letter proposes a sub-connected active reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS)-aided downlink wireless communication scheme for the physical layer security (PLS). In the proposed scheme, the statistics CSI error is considered and the secrecy rate (SR) of the system is maximized by jointly designing the beamforming vectors of the base station and the reflecting coefficients of the sub-connected active RIS. Besides, fractional programming (FP) and successive convex approximation (SCA) methods are applied to convert the original optimization problem into three subproblems. A penalty-based alternating optimization (AO) framework is employed to solve the optimization problem. Simulation results verify the efficiency and robustness of the proposed sub-connected active RIS-assisted PLS scheme.

title: LCTNet: Lightweight Convolution-Transformer Network for Hyperspectral Image Classification
authors: Zaoping Zhong, Chengbin Liang, Ming Yang, Deguang Wang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Deep learning models, especially hybrid models combining convolutional neural networks (CNN) and Transformer, introduce new ideas for hyperspectral image (HSI) classification. However, the complex structure and high spectral dimension of HSI data often affects classification accuracy and computational complexity. Therefore, a novel lightweight CNN-Transformer network (LCTNet) model is proposed. LCTNet consists of three core modules designed to improve HSI classification performance while maintaining a lightweight structure. The spectral extraction-dimension reduction module extracts essential spectral features from the hyperspectral data, simultaneously reducing data dimensions to decrease the computational load for subsequent processing. The spatial-spectral feature marking module then enhances crucial spatial and spectral features, facilitating the efficient fusion and utilization of spatial-spectral information. Meanwhile, the dynamic sparse transformer module dynamically adjusts the proportion of attention sparsity, which reduces redundant computation but also preserves critical spectral-spatial global dependencies. These three modules enable LCTNet to effectively improve the classification accuracy and reduce the complexity. Experiments demonstrate that LCTNet achieves overall accuracy of 99.31%±0.26, 99.42%±0.13, 98.13%±0.15, and 98.90%±0.05 on four public datasets, respectively. Compared with nine other methods, LCTNet attains almost all the highest accuracy with relatively low computational complexity. Additionally, the ablation experiment also further verified the function of each module of LCTNet.

title: Design and Control of a Compact Series Elastic Actuator Module for Robots in MRI Scanners
authors: Binghan He, Naichen Zhao, David Y. Guo, Charles H. Paxson, Alfredo De Goyeneche, Michael Lustig, Chunlei Liu, Ronald S. Fearing
publish: IEEE/ASME Transactions on Mechatronics
abstract: Robotic assistance has broadened the capabilities of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)-guided medical interventions, yet force-controlled actuators tailored for MRI environments remain limited. In this study, we present a novel MRI-compatible rotary series elastic actuator (SEA) module that employs velocity-sourced ultrasonic motors for force-controlled operation within MRI scanners. Unlike prior MRI-compatible SEA designs, our module uses a transmission force sensing SEA architecture, with four off-the-shelf compression springs placed between the gearbox and motor housings. To enable precise torque control, we develop a controller based on a disturbance observer, specifically designed for velocity-sourced motors. This controller improves torque regulation, even under varying external impedance, enhancing the actuator’s suitability for MRI-guided medical interventions. Experimental validation confirms effective torque control in both 3 Tesla MRI and non-MRI settings, achieving a 5% settling time of 0.05 s and steady-state error within 2.5% of the actuator’s maximum output torque. Notably, the controller maintains consistent performance across both low- and high-impedance conditions.

title: A Damage Prevention Device for Suspension Towers Subjected to Conductor Breakage
authors: Hironmoy Kakoty, Chinmoy Kolay
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Delivery
abstract: Suspension towers in high-voltage transmission lines are generally designed to sustain some damage during a sudden conductor breakage due to economic constraints. This study presents a novel device to be installed between an insulator and its supporting tower cross-arm to prevent such damage. The device is designed to act as a rigid link under normal operations and undergo large inelastic deformations during a conductor breakage, thereby dissipating energy and limiting the transferred force below the design lateral load capacity of the tower. Laboratory tests are conducted to experimentally characterize the device behavior and develop detailed continuum finite element models. A trilinear model of the device is then developed using basic principles of mechanics and dimensional analysis and the results of a comprehensive parametric FE simulation. The trilinear model is used to perform conductor breakage simulation of an existing 132 kV transmission line system. The results show that the proposed device can prevent damage to suspension towers and is well-suited to enhance the reliability of new and existing transmission line systems.

title: DSVA: An Iterative Refinement Multi-Agent Framework for NL-to-MTL Translation
authors: Jinhui Lyu, Ye Wu, Yong Cai
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Safety-critical cyber-physical systems require rigorously verifiable specifications, yet natural language (NL) requirements introduce ambiguity and defects. While Metric Temporal Logic (MTL) expresses complex real-time constraints, manual NL-to-MTL translation is labor-intensive and error-prone. Existing single-agent LLM approaches like TR2MTL struggle with semantic ambiguity and lack automated refinement mechanisms. This paper proposes DSVA (Deconstruct-Synthesize-Verify-Analyze), a multi-agent framework with diagnostic-driven iterative refinement. DSVA deploys specialized agents: Deconstruct parses NL into semantic sketches; Synthesize generates MTL formulae; Verify controls iteration via back-translation and similarity checking; and Analyze diagnoses failures to guide refinement. A phase-specific Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) mechanism enhances contextual understanding. Evaluation on the TR2MTL dataset across four LLMs shows DSVA achieves 85.6% mean accuracy, with GPT-4 reaching 90.9%, a 17.99 percentage point improvement over the TR2MTL baseline (72.91%). Comprehensive ablation studies reveal synergistic component interactions: RAG contributes +15.1% when combined with iteration, iterative refinement contributes +14.4% when combined with RAG, yielding a +7.6pp synergy bonus beyond additive effects (14.3pp→21.9pp). Even the weakest full DSVA configuration (Gemini-2.5-flash: 75.8%) surpasses the baseline. The framework’s consistent cross-model performance gains validate its architectural benefits: specialized agent division of labor, automated iteration control, and diagnostic refinement, providing a potentially more reliable solution for automated requirements formalization in safety-critical systems.

title: An LCC-LCC Compensated Simultaneous Wireless Power and Data Transfer System With Flexible Regulation and Load-Independent Constant Voltage Output
authors: Jing Feng, Jin Tian, Yanyan Shi, Meng Wang, Lin Yang, Yapeng Men, Yuhan Dou, Qi Luo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: In this paper, an LCC-LCC compensated simultaneous wireless power and data transfer (SWPDT) system is proposed to realize load-independent constant voltage (CV) output and suppress the power carrier frequency and high-frequency interference of the data transfer channel. Power is transferred via a pair of DD coils while data is directly injected into and extracted from one single D-coil, and the additional trap inductor is omitted. Combined with the characteristics of conventional LCC compensation network, a specially designed LCC compensation topology is utilized on the receiving side, both for CV output regulation and high-frequency interference suppression.
