The single D-coil is fully compensated by the compensation capacitors at the power carrier frequency, inhibiting the power carrier interference significantly. The performance of the power is analyzed, and the condition of the CV output regulation is provided. The mechanism of the interference suppression is explored, and the influence of the circuit parameters on the noise suppression is also discussed. It is proven that the CV output with high-quality data transfer can be obtained in the proposed system. Finally, an experimental prototype with 104.5 V output voltage and 200 kbps data rate is designed to verify the feasibility of the proposed system.

title: Blockchain Based Medical History Management System
authors: Surendra Kumar Shukla, Pradeep Kumar, Rahul Shrivastava, Paras Jain, Vishan Kumar Gupta, Ayush Choukse
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: Safe and efficient management of patient information is of primary importance in the contemporary healthcare setting. Information intrusion, inefficiency, and interoperability are typically issues with traditional centralized systems. To address these problems, this article proposes a decentralized digital health passport system based on blockchain technology. The system enables patients to save their healthcare history safely on a blockchain that is accessible to the authorized healthcare providers in the country. The patients are given unique identifiers such as the passport numbers that are associated with their mobile numbers to access control through OTP. The system uses the decentralized and immutable character of blockchain in place of unauthorized access, tampering, or data leakage, as well as, guarantee data availability throughout the country. It also uses enhanced encryption technology to prevent sensitive information and multi-factor authentication to enhance security. The following paper will outline the system architecture, present the processes of its functioning, and explain how it is likely to influence healthcare data management. The suggested solution is a safe, scalable, and easy-to-use system of managing patient data within a digital healthcare environment.

title: Metamaterial-Based Four-Port Polarized MIMO Antenna for SWIPT Applications
authors: M. Odiamenhi, H. J. Basherlou, C. H. See, N.O. Patchin, K. Goh, H. Yu, A. S. I. Amar, Y. M. Madany
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Telecommunications and Artificial Intelligence (IC-FTAI)
abstract: This paper presents a low-profile, single-layer wideband metamaterial-inspired linear polarized multiple-input multiple-output antenna array with an integrated rectifier for simultaneous wireless information and power transfer applications. The antenna consists of eight elements fabricated on Rogers 4350 substrate with a defected ground structure, where four ports are dedicated to wireless information transfer and four ports are directly connected to a rectifier for wireless power transfer. The rectifier employs four SMS7630 diodes and is directly matched to the antenna with input impedances of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$34-\mathrm{j}57\Omega$</tex> and rectifier impedance of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$34+\mathrm{j}57\Omega$</tex>, delivering 0.9 V output voltage with 75% efficiency into a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1000 \Omega$</tex> load. The total array occupies <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.599 \times 0.33\lambda$</tex>, operating over 3.2-4.3 GHz, with a peak gain of 5.5 dBi and isolation below -20 dB between all ports. Metamaterial-inspired elements enhance impedance and bandwidth, providing stable polarization. MIMO performance is evaluated via envelope correlation coefficient, diversity gain, and mean effective gain, confirming suitability for SWIPT-enabled sensors, IoT devices, and other low-power wireless systems.

title: Modelling of Electrostatic Discharge: A Fuzzy Logic Approach
authors: Rishabh Deo Pandey, Ankita Oraon, Shivani Kumari, Itu Snigdh, Nisha Gupta
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Electromagnetic Interference and Compatibility (INCEMIC)
abstract: Electrostatic discharge (ESD) poses a significant threat to electronic components, often leading to costly damage and system failures. Traditional ESD protection methods may not effectively address the dynamic nature of ESD events. This paper introduces a fuzzy logic-based model designed to predict electrostatic discharge by analyzing two critical input parameters: resistance and humidity. The proposed fuzzy logic model improves prediction accuracy by leveraging real-time processing. It dynamically adjusts predictions based on continuous monitoring of discharge resistance and humidity levels. Simulation results demonstrate that the fuzzy logic approach significantly improves the reliability of ESD predictions. The model’s ability to handle uncertainty and variability in input parameters offers a substantial advancement over traditional methods. The proposed work contributes to the field of electronic safety by providing a robust framework for ESD prediction

title: Adaptive Energy-Efficient Communication Architecture for Large-Scale IoT Systems in 5G Environments
authors: D Ananda Babu, A Swathi, Mahmoud Odeh, M. Swarna, T Mrudula, S. Kaliappan
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: The scalable and energy-saving communication frameworks in 5G contexts are required by the exponential increase in Internet of Things (10 T) application in smart cities, healthcare, and industrial automation, but the current architectures used, based on resource allocation that is static and relies on the use of traditional MAC mechanisms, have high energy consumption, congestion, and latency when deployed at high densities. To address these issues, this study develops Adaptive Energy-Efficient Communication Architecture (AE2CA) that combines 5G network slicing, edge computing, energy-aware routing, and reinforcement learning-based resource allocation and Non-Orthogonal Multiple Access (NOMA) and LPW A optimal planning to dynamically trade off energy efficiency and Quality of Service (QoS). The designed framework allows the IoT nodes to selectively switch to both an active and inactive state and intelligently utilize the spectrum control and reduce signalling overhead to provide a reduction in overall power consumption without compromising connectivity and throughput. The datasets that will be used to evaluate the system include the CityPulse Smart City 10 T dataset with anticipated outcomes being minimized energy use -up to 30–40 percent, increased network life and enhanced scalability of massive IoT systems in 5G and above.

title: Multilingual Video to Text Summarizer Framework for Cross-Lingual Content Accessibility
authors: K Vignesh, B Baranitharan, Shaik Sajid, T Sai Sree Hari Gokul, D Gnana Vardhini, M Chaitanya
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: The surging growth of video content in education, companies and media has created the necessity of powerful instruments that can be used to analyze and gain insight into long-length video. In many cases, users lack time and/or cannot access the most important materials of video lectures, meetings, or interviews due to language barriers. Although automated transcription tools do exist in the market, they are in many cases restricted to a single language, lack the option of summarization as an option, and lack quality recordings, which means that a user uses a combination of applications. In this paper, a new integrated video-to-text multilingual summarization system is discussed. The end-to-end model involves the use of an effective pipeline to translate, summarize, and transcribe video into text. It is designed in the system to transcribe video through the Whisper automatic speech recognition model, which gives users accurate and robust transcriptions irrespective of different accents and acoustic characteristics. The BART-Large-CNN transformer model will be used to summarize the transcription into an abstract, and its definition objective was to produce an abstract that is coherent and contextually relevant. The combination of these sophisticated features in one user-friendly application is a major solution to the scalability of the system as it facilitates global usability by creating end state summaries in more than 100 languages. A web-based interface is also included in the application and provides the user with the ability to set the length of the summaries, compare the summarized output with the source text and save the output in a variety of different formats. The outcomes of the experiment demonstrate the ability of our proposed system to retrieve significant information using video data much more quickly with reduced language barrier. In general, our study confirms the combination of transformer-based models, which are efficient, scalable, inclusive, and offer a productivity increase to a global audience, and have potential opportunities to be applied in real-time meeting summaries and processing vast volumes of content.

title: Experimental Characterization of an RF Power Dependent Immunity Model for an RC Timer IC
authors: Rakesh Kichouliya, Dipanjan Gope
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Electromagnetic Interference and Compatibility (INCEMIC)
abstract: Achieving electromagnetic compatibility (EMC) is a persistent challenge for designers, where implementing EMC principles during the design phase is crucial for compliance. Verification is further required to confirm compliance and evaluate EMC margins. Software-based EMC verification, utilizing detailed PCB layouts and component electromagnetic models, offers a transformative solution. This paper presents an experimental characterization of immunity behavior and impedance of an RC timer integrated circuit (IC) ICM7555 with and without DC bias and with variable RF power at its +V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">cc</inf> pin. Such an IC model is useful to determine pass/fail criterion in a simulation-based conducted susceptibility testing.

title: Designing systemic interventions for a Just Transition to Net Zero: Case of the JUST-Systems Programme
authors: Tavis Potts, Jennifer Dickie, John Bone
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Environment Friendly Energies and Applications (EFEA)
abstract: Delivering a just transition to achieve Net Zero in the UK is a critically important and difficult challenge and high on the policy agenda. Presently in the UK, deep social, economic, and regional inequalities intersect with the decarbonisation agenda. Achieving Net Zero requires not only technological innovation but also the transformation of social and economic systems that govern energy, housing, health, and local economies. In rising to the challenge, JUST-Systems programme applies transdisciplinary and whole-systems approaches to understand and intervene in these interconnected challenges, drawing on Critical Systems Heuristics (CSH) and participatory modelling through the MHORES platform. Working across five diverse UK case studies, the project co-develops actionable pathways with local stakeholders that link decarbonisation with social justice, fuel poverty reduction, and community wellbeing. By situating research in real-world contexts—from housing retrofit to local energy systems to social care—the project is developing evidence and methods for integrating fairness, inclusion, and capacity building into national Net Zero policy. JUST-Systems ultimately seeks to support a people-centred, place-based transition in the UK.

title: Graph Partitioning via Genetic Algorithm: A Maximum Spanning Tree Sparsification Approach
authors: Ali Chaouche, Menouar Boulif, Mohammed Haddad, Youcef Yahiatene
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Innovative Applications (AIIA)
abstract: This papers presents a graph-theory-based approach for solving the unsupervised graph partitioning problem using genetic algorithms. These bio-inspired methods are known for their efficiency and robustness. However, their performance heavily depends on the characteristics of the encoding scheme used to represent candidate solutions, such as alphabet cardinality and chromosome length. In this paper, a maximum spanning tree is leveraged to get an edge based encoding scheme that yields short chromosomes with reduced alphabets. The results are very promising when compared to the literature.

title: AI-Based Text Extraction from Images and PDF Documents
authors: Kiran Yesugade, Anuradha Kiran Yesugade, Sonali Kadam, Akshada Bombe, Eshani Ghanwat, Shweta Gogawale
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Optical Character Recognition (OCR) plays a vital role in converting physical text into machine-readable formats for digital archiving, information retrieval, and intelligent automation. While conventional OCR systems provide reliable results for printed documents, they often struggle with handwritten scripts, degraded scans, and complex layouts. Recent advances in deep learning and hybrid recognition frameworks have addressed these challenges by integrating multiple recognition engines and contextual postprocessing. This paper proposes a dual-framework OCR system that leverages PaddleOCR for structured printed text and a hybrid EasyOCR-Tesseract pipeline for handwritten recognition. To further enhance interpretability, the extracted text is semantically processed using the Gemini 2.5 Flash API, enabling context-aware querying and interaction. The framework was evaluated using printed contracts, receipts, and handwritten samples, with accuracy assessed via Word Error Rate (WER) and Character Error Rate (CER). Results demonstrate a 10-15% improvement in handwritten recognition accuracy compared to baseline OCR systems, highlighting the effectiveness of combining OCR engines with semantic models for real-world applications.

title: Minimizing Risk: An Integrated System for Earthquake and Landslide Early Warning
authors: Kaavya S, Rajalakshmi M, Melwin Joanna P, Mohana Sri C, Sadeesh Kumar A
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Natural disasters such as earthquakes and landslides continue to pose severe threats to human lives and critical infrastructure. This study introduces a unified early warning framework that combines smartphone sensors, including accelerometers and vibration detectors, with an external IoT-based hardware module equipped with additional environmental sensors. The external unit continuously captures real-time ground motion and soil moisture data, transmitting it to a dedicated smartphone application. Historical disaster data are used in conjunction with machine learning algorithms to improve prediction accuracy. The system disseminates warnings via in-app notifications, SMS, and automated phone calls through GSM and API integration. Designed with a focus on accessibility, scalability, and cost efficiency, the proposed model enhances disaster preparedness and response, especially in rural and high-risk areas.

title: Simulation Model for Several Blockchain Systems using Queueing Theory
authors: Shivani Agarwal, Paras Jain, Garima Sharma, Tanveen Kaur Bhatia, Meenakshi Kandpal, Vishan Kumar Gupta
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: In recent years, blockchain technology has attracted the attention of researchers, engineers, and institutions. Several industries, including social security, logistics, smart homes, e-healthcare, e-finance, and the Internet of Things, have seen an upsurge in interest because of its use. Chain management, digital identity verification, voting systems, and cryptocurrency are just a few of the many ways that blockchain technology can be used. It offers a secure and transparent method of transaction recording, making data manipulation and falsification challenges. To validate our proposed model, I run simulations for a week's worth of transactions using actual data from three popular cryptocurrencies: Bitcoin, Ethereum, and Binance Smart Chain. Variables such as the memory pool's queue time, memory pool's response time, mining pool's response time, system throughput, and arrival rate are all part of the measured performance. Real statistics are contrasted with these values. The simulation used in this study only simulates cryptocurrencies that are based on blockchains. However, the model that was suggested could be used for many other blockchain-based uses as well.

title: A Vision-Language Model-Based Scene Graph Generation Method With Directional Relationship Reasoning
authors: Jinyeong Oh, Eunbeen Kim, Jonghwa Shim, Eenjun Hwang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: Scene Graph Generation (SGG) generates graphs from visual scenes in the form of {subject-predicate-object} triplets. Traditional SGG methods rely on fully supervised training, requiring annotated datasets for new objects and predicates. They also ignore subject-object directionality, generating inappropriate predicates for the subject. In this paper, we propose a novel SGG method that combines a pretrained vision-language object detector with a lightweight relationship inference module. The detector performs object detection by leveraging knowledge from extensive image-text pairs. The inference module projects the object representations into distinct subject and object embeddings and selects relevant object candidates per subject. It then generates directional relationship representations and predicts predicates by selecting appropriate subject-object pairs and comparing them with predicate embeddings. The proposed method improves mR@20 by about 14% over the state-of-the-art methods on the Visual Genome dataset and shows qualitative results that better distinguish subject and object roles.

title: Course-Specific AI TA: Implementation and Impact on Student Learning
authors: Joon S. Park
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: This paper presents the design and evaluation of a course-specific AI Teaching Assistant (AI TA) developed to support student learning in higher education. Trained on tailored instructional materials, the AI TA provided personalized academic support, improving student engagement, comprehension, and research skills. We implemented a structured evaluation framework including experimental comparisons, survey-based feedback, and correlation analysis. Results show that students perceived the AI TA as accurate, responsive, and aligned with instructor content. Strong correlations were observed between AI TA usage and increased academic motivation and interest in future AI integration. Findings highlight the potential of human-centered, ethically designed AI tools to enrich educational experiences and long-term academic outcomes.

title: Context-Aware Secure Multi-User Cloud File Sharing Framework Using Federated Learning and Attribute-Based Encryption
authors: Arshin A S, Dinesh Kumar A S, Niresh Kumar S
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: File sharing systems in the cloud need to have a strong security layer to ensure sensitive data is kept safe and at the same time provide fine-grained access control. This paper presents a practical application of an encrypted cloud file sharing method that fuses Waters11 CP-ABE based encryption and Federated Learning based anomaly detection. Our system is based on the hybrid AES-256-GCM and CP-ABE encryption, in which only symmetric keys are encrypted using the attribute-based encryption, minimizing computational costs while maintaining fine-grained access control. We use a federated learning architecture operated by logistic regression with trimmed mean aggregation to identify abnormal access patterns according to location, device, temporal and departmental factors. The system's encryption throughput scales from 101 MB/sec to 325 MB/sec for larger files. It supports federated learning anomaly detection, processing 1.45 million requests per second with a latency of 0.69 microseconds, achieving 96.7% accuracy with a 6.1% false positive rate, and supports 20 concurrent users. We test the system with a synthetic dataset of 10,000 events and 25 simulated clients with 15 percent anomalous patterns. The implementation illustrates the practice of secure cloud sharing of files with context-aware access control and intelligent anomaly detection.

title: Colorectal Cancer Tumor Grade Segmentation in Digital Histopathology Images: from GIGA to Mini Challenge
authors: Alper Bahcekapili, Duygu Arslan, Umut Ozdemir, Berkay Ozkirli, Emre Akbas, Ahmet Acar, Gozde B. Akar, Bingdou He, Shuoyu Xu, Ümit Mert Çağlar, Alptekin Temizel, Guillaume Picaud, Marc Chaumont, Gérard Subsol, Luc Téot, Fahad Alsharekh, Shahad Alghannam, Hexiang Mao, Wenhua Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the third most diagnosed cancer and the second leading cause of cancer-related death worldwide. Accurate histopathological grading of CRC is essential for prognosis and treatment planning but remains a subjective process prone to observer variability and limited by global shortages of trained pathologists. To promote automated and standardized solutions, we organized the ICIP Grand Challenge on Colorectal Cancer Tumor Grading and Segmentation using the publicly available METU CCTGS dataset. The dataset comprises 103 whole-slide images with expert pixellevel annotations for five tissue classes. Participants submitted segmentation masks via Codalab, evaluated using metrics such as macro F-score and mIoU. Among 39 participating teams, six outperformed the Swin Transformer baseline (62.92 F-score). This paper presents an overview of the challenge, dataset, and the top-performing methods.

title: Blockchain-Based Security Mechanism for Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) Communication
authors: Vaishali G Waghmode, Madhuri J Siddharapu, Amruta R Patil, Madhav J Salunkhe
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) communication plays a pivotal role in enabling intelligent transportation systems and autonomous driving. However, it is vulnerable to various security threats such as message tampering, spoofing, and denial-of-service attacks. This paper proposes a blockchainbased security framework for V2X communication that leverages decentralized trust, immutability, and smart contracts to enhance data integrity, authentication, and trust management. A detailed literature review with 15 recent studies is conducted, followed by a proposed architecture and implementation methodology. The results demonstrate that blockchain integration significantly improves security, though certain challenges remain in terms of scalability and latency. The paper concludes with future directions for optimizing blockchain applications in vehicular networks.

title: Predictive Analytics for Supply Chain Optimization using ML Models
authors: k Akila, M Vinothini, N Priyanka, S Nandhini, M Masilamani, R Jayanthi
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: The increasing complexity and internationalization of recent supply chains have made the rule-based decision-making systems of the past no longer appropriate to address efficiency and resilience. It is suggested that a supply chain predictive analytics framework based on pagewise supply chain optimisation is developed on the basis of recent paradigm-shifting machine learning models that include Temporal Fusion Transformer (TFT), Graph Neural Networks (GNNs), TabNet, and NGBoost. It uses historical sales and logistics data as well as supplier networks to dynamically predict demand, highlight risks in the supply chain, and adapt inventory levels using advanced deep learning and probabilistic modeling techniques. TFT is designed for interpretable multi-horizon demand forecasting, GNNs capture relational dependencies among supply nodes, TabNet enables trustworthy decision making over structured tabular datasets, and NGBoost enables uncertaintyaware risk assessment. The part comes with a real-time dashboard visualisation and ERP connection, which means that data-driven decisions can be made at scale. The experimental evaluation demonstrates considerable improvements in prediction quality, cost and agility over the state- of-the-art approaches. This study presents a new, understandable and scalable AIbased supply chain decision support system that ushers in a new generation of predictive logistics.

title: Blockchain-Based Smart Contracts in Insurance: Enhancing Transparency, Security, and Efficiency in Policy Management
authors: B. Jeyaprabha, Anthony Rose, Rachit Jain, Animesh Pratap Singh, Roshna Ravindran, L.S. Swasthimathi
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: The paper discusses the use of smart contracts based on blockchain in the insurance sector in terms of improving transparency, security, and efficiency in the process of policy management. In the case of the automated claims processing through the application of smart contracts, the study shows how blockchain technology can simplify the claims verification and approval procedure with the involvement of humans and mistakes minimized. The presence of smart contracts with set conditions makes smart contract transparent as everyone can be able to access unchangeable terms of the contract and the blockchain is decentralized, preventing fraud and data integrity. The study utilizes the Ethereum smart contracts, which are created with the help of Solidity program language, as the main instrument of automatizing and insuring processes. It is this example of a combination of blockchain technology and automated processes that will result in faster claims processing, reduced administrative expenses, and increased customer satisfaction. Generally, and throughout the paper, the challenges that blockchain-based solutions can address have the capacity to enhance the insurance industry in the context of enhancing the efficiency of the operations, as well as increasing trust due to transparency and security of the processes involved.

title: Multi-Task Particle Swarm Optimization Algorithm Based on Adaptive Gene Migration
authors: Yejian Cheng, Chuang Luo, Jiachen Li
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Multi-Task Optimization (MTO) algorithms exhibit higher efficiency and effectiveness in solving multiple tasks simultaneously. However, current MTO algorithms face challenges of slow convergence and a tendency to get trapped in local optimal solutions when dealing with complex tasks. To address these issues, this paper proposes an Adaptive Multi-Task Particle Swarm Optimization Algorithm based on Gene Conversion, aiming to enhance the performance of multi-task optimization. This algorithm integrates inter-task learning strategies, parameter adaptive strategies, and gene conversion strategies. By transferring search experience through difference terms, dynamically adjusting learning probabilities, and promoting positive knowledge transfer, it broadens the search scope, enhances global exploration capabilities, and effectively mitigates negative knowledge transfer. This research provides a new perspective for solving the current challenges faced by MTO algorithms and holds broad application prospects.

title: Two-stage regional reconstruction method of distribution network considering optimal operation
authors: Hao Cui, Qitong Luan, Dongsheng Yang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Power System and Energy Internet (PoSEI)
abstract: With the long-term operation of distribution network equipment and lines, equipment aging and line deterioration significantly increase the operation risk of distribution network. Therefore, this paper presents a two-stage regional reconstruction method of distribution network considering optimal operation. Firstly, based on the real-time data of distribution network equipment and lines, the index system of transformer health assessment and risk assessment is established, and the transformer operation state assessment model is constructed. Secondly, a two-stage regional reconstruction method of distribution network considering optimal operation is proposed. In the first stage, the regional reconstruction model of distribution network is constructed with the aim of the lowest risk index and the lowest line loss of each branch transformer. In the second stage, the transformer maintenance strategy based on risk index is proposed, and the regional reconstruction optimization model of distribution network under the optimal operating state is constructed. Finally, PG&E 69-node distribution lines are used for example analysis. The results show that the proposed method can effectively reduce equipment risks and line losses, and effectively improve the security and reliability of the distribution network system.

title: Adversarial Challenges in AI-based Intrusion Detection Systems for Cloud Environments: A Comprehensive Review
authors: Shajila Velliyath, D. Kalaivani
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: "Cloud Computing (CC)" has become the foundation of modern digital infrastructures, offering scalable, flexible, and cost-efficient computing and storage services across multi-tenant environments. While this paradigm enables diverse applications from e-commerce and healthcare to finance, it also exposes cloud platforms to sophisticated cyber threats, including zero-day attacks, insider threats, and adversarial manipulations. Traditional "Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS)", relying on signature-based or conventional "Machine Learning (ML)" techniques, often fail to detect dynamic and evolving attacks in distributed cloud ecosystems. This survey provides a comprehensive analysis of "Artificial Intelligence (AI)-based IDS frameworks for CC, examining the progression from traditional ML to "Deep Learning (DL)", "Federated Learning (FL)", adversarially robust models, and hybrid explainable architectures. The study evaluates each paradigm in terms of detection accuracy, interpretability, scalability, robustness against adversarial attacks, and suitability for cloud deployment. Recent advancements in federated and distributed learning demonstrate the potential for privacy-preserving, multi-tenant collaboration, while adversarially aware and hybrid approaches highlight the importance of resilience, operational trust, and transparency. The survey also identifies critical research gaps, including the need for standardized cloud-specific datasets, integrated interpretability mechanisms, and efficient deployment strategies for edge-cloud environments. By synthesizing the strengths, limitations, and emerging trends of contemporary AI-driven IDS, this study provides actionable insights for researchers and practitioners aiming to design robust, adaptive, and explainable intrusion detection frameworks for next-generation cloud infrastructures. The findings serve as a foundation for future research in developing scalable, resilient, and trustworthy AI-based IDS capable of addressing the evolving threat landscape in CC.

title: HEMP Hardening Assessment of Aircraft
authors: Venkata Ramana Botsa, Suguna Gandipilli, Mahesh Gopal
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Electromagnetic Interference and Compatibility (INCEMIC)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive analysis of the electromagnetic hardening of aircraft systems against High-altitude Electromagnetic Pulse (HEMP) threats using 3D EM modeling & simulation, and Practical measurements. Various EMP interaction mechanisms have been systematically analyzed, including coupling through wires near apertures, RF front-end penetration via antennas, and fixed-wire antenna interactions. The simulation framework replicates realistic EMP environments and evaluates the resulting transient responses specifically induced currents and voltages within internal aircraft circuitry. These responses are benchmarked against known susceptibility thresholds of onboard electronic systems to assess electromagnetic vulnerability. The interaction flow, guided by standard EMP coupling paths, enables the identification of critical exposure points, thereby supporting targeted electromagnetic shielding and mitigation strategies. This study provides valuable insights into the hardening effectiveness of aircraft systems under EMP stress, contributing to improved resilience of airborne platforms in high-threat electromagnetic environments.

title: CT-like Scanning and High-Resolution Point Cloud Generation of Digital Models Based on SDF
authors: Enkuan Du, Chongzheng Huang, Yihai Qin, Hong Chen
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: To meet high-precision point cloud needs in virtual simulation/digital twins and solve low efficiency/data gaps in traditional Web systems, this paper proposes a CT-like scanning and high-precision point cloud generation system for digital models. The system integrates Signed Distance Field (SDF) technology and mesh discretization, innovatively converts ray casting into triangular surface rendering, and designs a vertical patch renderer and SDF Z-buffer mechanism. It enables fast multi-mode scanning and CT-like perspective, supporting viewframing, custom precision, and model coloring.Tests on the ModelNet40 dataset show high-definition scanning of million-level polygon models takes 1–2 seconds. Surround perspective point cloud speed reaches 3.90M points/s, and planar perspective 14.6M points/s. This system fills the gap in Web-based digital model CT-like perspective point cloud generation, supports 100-million-level point clouds, and meets high-precision/performance needs for Web point cloud acquisition.

title: Enhanced Sentiment Classification of Mobile Phone Technical Reviews using BERT-based Models
authors: Sweety Singhal, Snehlata Ajmera, Vartika Vyas, Abhilasha Dangi, Monalisa Meena, Awanit Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: Mobile phone reviews often consist of domainspecific terminology whose sentiment is complicated to retrieve using traditional sentiment analysis methods. In such scenarios, simple models like Naïve Bayes, SVM, and Bagged Random Forests do not interpret the context well, whereas CNNs and RNNs are limited in modeling long-term dependencies. This study creates a domain-specific, technical-term-based BERT sentiment classifier, with technical terms like “heat dissipation”, “fast charging”, etc., to specify the domain. Data collection sources are the terms from reviews, after which they undergo several preprocessing steps before being assigned a positive, negative, or neutral sentiment label. Experiments have been conducted, revealing that the fine-tuned BERT model produces $91.2 \%$ accuracy and an F1-score of 0.90, while the accuracy of the baseline models Bagged Random Forests and SVM only reach $78.5 \%$ and $79.1 \%$, respectively. This suggests that the BERT is able to grasp subtle, context-based sentiment in technical domains. Future work will explore lighter transformer variants and aspect-based sentiment analysis for real-time applications.

title: Federated Intelligence for Secure Diagnosis of Rare Diseases in Clinical Imaging
authors: Krishna Pandey, Rahul Joshi, Suman Kumari, Rhythma Badola
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: This work presents a federated learning framework for the remote diagnosis of a rare disease using a given set of clinical images. The process is carried out via an isolated model training from different hospitals, without disclosing the patient's personal records, thus complying with data governance rules and benefiting from a variety of datasets needed to excel in diagnostic performance. Here, FedAvg with a ResNet-based structure was adopted to support the regular updates and stable generalizations among hospitals. This system was put to the test in remote and sometimes unfriendly locations and situations. The experiments indicate that the same accuracy levels can be achieved through federated learning training as compared to centralized training, without compromising the privacy of the patient's data. This model presents immense possibilities for AI-based, secure, scalable, and collaborative healthcare diagnostic mechanisms, especially in rare and critical conditions.

title: IoT-Integrated Hybrid Beetle–Ant Algorithm for Real-Time MPPT in Solar Photovoltaic Systems
authors: R. Sundar, Mukesh Singh, Kruthi Jayaram, Praful V. Nandankar, K. B. Venkata Brahma Rao, S.SriRagavi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Using solar panels to collect energy in changing weather patterns is still a difficult task, especially when it comes to hooking them up to the smart grid. A new IoT-guided MPPT framework with HBAO algorithm is designed in this paper to make solar PV systems work more effectively. The suggested approach joins the international discovery power of the Beetle Antennae Search (BAS) algorithm with the local accuracy of Ant Colony Optimization (ACO), guaranteeing that the maximum power point is always located steadily no matter the fluctuating illumination and temperature. With the help of IoT sensors, PV voltage, current, and irradiance are acquired in real time and promptly sent to the algorithm for feedback. The duty cycle of a boost converter is adjusted through the control signal to get the best output power. Simulations carried out with MATLAB/Simulink have proven that the HBAO approach is 98.7% efficient in tracking, and causes fewer oscillations and faster convergence than popular conventional approaches including P&O and PSO. Because the IoT is integrated, it provides constant monitoring, easy scalability, and access to controls remotely, making the proposed system well-equipped for smart solar energy technology.

title: A Comprehensive Survey on the Causes and Challenges of Network Traffic Congestion in Modern Networks
authors: J. Vijitha Ananthi, James Deva Koresh Hezekiah, G. Yamini Priya, T. Vishnu Priya, M. Bala Bhoomika
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: Network Traffic Congestion has become a major problem of facing modern communication systems, primarily due to the quick increase in data and multiple user requirements. This congestion can lead to packet loss, delayed response times, and also decreased service reliability, altering both wired and wireless networks. This study consists of an in-depth examination of congestion causes, detection approaches and relief measures. It focuses on the importance of congestion control algorithms, traffic predictive analytics, and QoS enhancement in optimizing network efficiency. Moreover, the study analyses the latest trends, like software-defined networking and machine learning-based techniques designed towards congestion prevention. By combining new research results, this survey delivers the valuable insights into effective traffic control measures and reveals key sectors for future advancements.

title: Research on Deep Learning-Based Part Detection and Recognition Methodology
authors: Ying Liu, Ming Zhang, Changqing Zou
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Measurement Control and Instrumentation (MCAI)
abstract: A deep learning based method for parts detection and recognition is proposed to address the challenges of multi-scale object recognition and distortion of edge details in industrial parts inspection. Integrating CLAHE enhancement, bilateral filtering, and Canny edge detection in the image preprocessing stage; In the feature extraction stage, ResNet50 is used as the backbone and a multi-scale fusion strategy is introduced; Improved YOLOv8 is used for object detection, which integrates ASPP module to enhance small object detection; Construct a classification network based on ResNeXt50 AGF for the recognition module. The experimental results show that the optimized model mAP@0.5 Compared to the original model, the accuracy has improved by 2.10%, precision has increased by 1.80%, and FPS has increased by 6.5%. It performs better in terms of detection accuracy and real-time performance, verifying the effectiveness of the method.

title: Weather Prediction and Classification for Citrus Farming Using Support Vector Regression (SVR) and Classification and Regression Tree (CART)
authors: Angelina Balqis Khansa, Vivi Nur Wijayaningrum, Moch Zawaruddin Abdullah
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Technological Solutions (ICAITech)
abstract: Accurate weather information is crucial for agricultural planning, yet farmers in developing regions often face limitations due to the lack of localized and reliable forecasting tools. Existing forecasts are typically broad in scale and short-term in nature, making them less effective for guiding crop management decisions at the farm level. In citrus farming, where productivity is highly dependent on microclimatic factors, the lack of precise predictive systems increases the risk of yield reduction and inefficient resource allocation. To overcome these challenges, this study developed a weather prediction and classification system that integrates machine learning techniques with historical meteorological data from the Indonesian Meteorological, Climatological, and Geophysical Agency (BMKG). Support Vector Regression (SVR) was applied to predict four essential weather parameters, including relative humidity, average temperature, rainfall, and sunshine duration, while Classification and Regression Tree (CART) was employed to classify conditions into “favorable” and “unfavorable.” The methodology involved systematic data preprocessing, including parameter selection, imputation of missing values, augmentation via smoothing, normalization, and hyperparameter optimization, followed by functional testing to ensure usability. The experimental evaluation showed that SVR achieved strong predictive performance with RMSE values of 2.06 (RH_avg), 0.27 (Tavg), 4.53 (RR), and 0.68 (ss). CART provided excellent classification results with an accuracy of 0.9854, precision of 0.9855, recall of 0.9911, and an F1-score of 0.9882. These results demonstrate that the proposed system is both accurate and reliable, offering a practical decision-support tool to help farmers optimize citrus crop management under varying weather conditions.

title: A Comprehensive Review of YOLO Object Detection Models Across Diverse Domains: Evolution, Adaptations, and Performance Benchmarks
authors: Ajaykumar Solanki, Vipul Vekariya, Warish Patel
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Object detection is a core computer vision problem that requires real-time performance as an indispensable companion of accuracy. The YOLO family (You Only Look Once) has gained popularity as it merges detection with the single-stage paradigm of detection being set side by side with speed. In this article, all developments of the YOLO model, from their seminal formulation to the current state-of-the-art in 2018–2025 publications by colleagues in areas such as aerial imagery, infrared/low illumination scenarios, underwater detection applications, agriculture and medical imaging applications, and safety/surveillance applications are critically surveyed. Instead of submitting the results in the results, performance measures such as mAP, FPS, number of parameters, and FLOPs are critically reasoned using comparative lenses. We exhibit trends such as lightweight network architecture, anchor-free detection, and preprocessing-directed variations as well as identify open challenges, including heterogeneity of the datasets, absence of reproducibility, and lack of generalization of the domain. The analysis reveals that post-2018 YOLO variants reduce computational cost by 40–70% while preserving <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\geq 85 \%$</tex> of COCO mAP, a trade-off quantified in Fig. 1. Future prospects indicate the use of the multimodal fusion, transformer-based YOLOs, federated learning for applications promoting the augmentation of privacy along with interactions using the large-scale language models.

title: Adaptive Workflow Orchestration in Large-Scale Cloud Data Pipelines using Apache Airflow
authors: Suseelkousic Gogineni, Vijayasai Madamanchi, Venkata Makineni, Pamula Udayaraju, M. Sitharam
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: Data analytics and data processing are continuously increasing in cloud applications. They should face the challenges of data scalability, smart, and stable workflow management. The existing data processing applications are not scalable and fault tolerant. Hence, this research aims to provide an adaptive workflow orchestration framework that can manage the entire workflow automatically, with improved scalability, and handle a large volume of data using a directed acyclic graph available in Apache Airflow. The proposed framework can handle multidimensional and multilevel data processing flow in any distributed environment. The framework monitors continuously in a real-time environment, and it uses effective and dynamic scheduling, dynamic prioritization, and confirms the data flow even in inconsistent workloads. To do this, a machine learning algorithm is implemented to predict the availability of requested resources, bottlenecks in resource allocation, and the execution path to ensure automatic data processing in the cloud. It also reduces the overall execution time and functional overhead problems. The machine learning algorithm learns the historical data efficiently to make accurate decisions to reduce pipeline letdowns. To demonstrate the overall process and performance of the framework, the Kubernetes, BigQuery, Amazon S3, and native services are integrated to provide improved reliability and scalability when deploying the framework processes in multi- and hybridcloud architectures. It also includes the checkpoints and recovery points that provide robust fault management in the entire architecture. From the experimental outputs, the proposed orchestration frameworks outperform the others in terms of throughput, latency reduction, scheduling, fault-tolerance, and cost. This research also highlights that the integration of automations, intelligence, and adaptability in the cloud workflow framework and its potential value can be used in the next generation of cloud data processing applications.

title: A Literature Review of Federated Learning Algorithms for Load Prediction
authors: Zu Wayne Ng, Samuel-Soma M. Ajibade, Muhammed Basheer Jasser, Ghassan Saleh ALDharhani, V. E. Sathishkumar, Anthonia Oluwatosin Adediran, Olumide Simeon Ogunnusi, Kayode A. Akintoye
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: Load prediction is an essential task for optimizing energy distribution, reducing operational costs, and maintaining grid stability. However, traditional centralized approaches to training predictive models often encounter significant challenges related to privacy, scalability, and latency. As such, federated learning has emerged as a promising alternative by enabling collaborative model training across distributed nodes without direct data sharing, thereby preserving privacy. Therefore, this study presents a comprehensive literature review of federated learning algorithms that could be applied to load prediction, covering both established and emerging strategies such as EdgeFed, FedSGD, FedNorm, FLchain, FedAvg, FedYogi, FedAdam, and FedAdagrad. In addition, this work further examines several deep learning algorithms, namely RNN, LSTM, GRU, and TCN, that could be integrated with the federated learning algorithms. Through this analysis, the study synthesizes existing contributions, underscores unresolved challenges, and outlines opportunities for future research aimed at achieving a balance between accuracy, efficiency, and privacy in energy applications

title: LRS-Chain: A Permissioned Blockchain-Enabled Framework for Secure and Transparent Land Registry Systems
authors: Prity Rani, Pritam Rani, Rohit Shorya
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: Land is a fundamental asset in any economy, and an efficient land registry system is vital for ensuring property rights, enabling real estate transactions, and fostering economic development. Conventional land registry systems face critical challenges such as limited transparency and traceability, legitimate ownership verification, and susceptibility to fraudulent activities. Traditional land registry systems are primarily centralized and lack comprehensive digitization, which increases the risk of forgery, data manipulation, and disputes over ownership. To address these challenges, this study proposes a blockchainenabled land registry system framework, named LRS-Chain. This proposed LRS-Chain employs the SHA-256 hashing algorithm for cryptographic security, utilizes the Interplanetary File System (IPFS) for decentralized storage of land transaction records, and adopts the Raft consensus algorithm to validate and authenticate transactions within the LRS-Chain. The proposed work has been implemented using Hyperledger Fabric version 2.5.4. The performance of the proposed work is evaluated using Hyperledger Caliper, a benchmarking tool that generates dummy workloads to analyze the throughput and latency of write and query operations. Transactions ranging from 50 to 2000 are considered for testing. Additionally, CPU utilization percentages of different peer nodes are analyzed as key performance indicators. This initiative aims to effectively address and mitigate the challenges faced in land registry systems.

title: HYPER-RAG: Evaluating Hyperparameter Trade-Offs in Biomedical Retrieval-Augmented Generation
authors: Ankush Sil Sarma, Pawan Kumar Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) improves the factual accuracy of large language models by combining document retrieval with text generation. In biomedical question answering, where correctness is critical, the effect of key hyperparameters has not been studied in a systematic way. This paper presents an evaluation of RAG on the COVID-QA dataset with a focus on three retrievers (dense, BM25, hybrid), two retrieval depths (top- <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{k}=1,3$</tex>), and optional reranking with a cross encoder. We use a single biomedical prompt and measure exact match (EM), F1 score, semantic similarity, groundedness, and latency. We also report a composite score that balances lexical accuracy, semantic similarity, and efficiency. Our results on a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 0}$</tex>-question subset show that reranking improves grounding at the cost of extra latency, and that increasing top-k improves recall but gives smaller gains after a point. The study highlights that multiple metrics are needed to judge biomedical RAG systems reliably and that careful tuning of retrieval and reranking settings can yield practical improvements under compute constraints.

title: Testbed Evaluation of MR-Gov: The Multi-Radio Coexistence Governor
authors: Atul Kumar, Gajendra Kant Mishra
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: The rapid adoption of CSA Matter as a unifying IoT standard has increased demand for reliable coexistence across heterogeneous wireless technologies such as Wi-Fi, Thread (802.15.4), and Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE). While our prior work introduced MR-Gov, a closed-loop coexistence governor validated via large-scale simulation, its real-world feasibility remained unexplored. In this paper, we present the first experimental testbed validation of MR-Gov on commodity tri-radio gateways. Our implementation leverages Raspberry Pi 5 platforms with Wi-Fi 7 (802.11be), BLE 5.3, and OpenThread border routers to execute multi-radio coexistence policies under Matter workloads. MR-Gov dynamically adjusts channel assignments, airtime usage, and duty-cycling based on cross-radio telemetry (RSSI, packet error rate, airtime utilization). Evaluation across 30+ devices and mixed workloads (video streaming, command/control, BLE advertisements) demonstrates that MR-Gov reduces Wi-Fi PER by 40%, lowers Matter command latency by 28%, and improves BLE advertisement delivery by 32% compared to baseline coexistence. Energy profiling of Thread sensors further shows up to 18% improvement in battery longevity. These results confirm that MR-Gov is deployable in real-world IoT environments and provides a practical foundation for robust multi-radio Matter ecosystems.

title: A Hybrid Machine and Deep Learning Framework for Student Risk Prediction in Learning Management System
authors: Bathula Hepsi, Kaligithi Rajesh Kumar, Gelli Archana
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: Learning Management Systems (LMS) generate extensive data capturing both academic performance and behavioral engagement through features such as attendance rate, login frequency, session duration, assignment submissions, and forum participation. Translating these diverse indicators into reliable academic risk predictions remains a key challenge. This research presents a hybrid machine and deep learning framework for student risk classification into Low, Medium, and High categories. Six machine learning algorithms—Logistic Regression, Decision Tree, Random Forest, Support Vector Machine, K-Nearest Neighbors, and XGBoost— are comparatively evaluated alongside a deep Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) model. The top-performing models, XGBoost and MLP, are integrated using a hybrid ensemble to improve generalization and stability. Experiments conducted on an LMS dataset containing $\mathbf{1, 5 4 5}$ student records and $\mathbf{1 5}$ academic, behavioral, and demographic features achieved a maximum accuracy of 96.84%. The results confirmed that the proposed hybrid approach enhances predictive reliability and supports the development of early-warning systems for proactive academic intervention.

title: Encrypted Traffic Classification in Software-Defined Networks Using Machine Learning: A Comparative and Design-Oriented Approach
authors: Samish.N. Kamble, Ajay. D. Jadhav
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: Software-Defined Networks (SDNs) have transformed traditional network management by offering significantly improved flexibility. This shift in network architecture introduces new security challenge in the detection of abnormal encrypted activities. Accurately identifying such anomalies in SDN environments is critical for effective mitigation of various network threats. This paper presents an in-depth investigation of malicious encrypted traffic identification in SDN networks using a variety of machine learning algorithms. We compare the efficacy of these algorithms in detecting encrypted malicious traffic, specifically for implementation within an SDN environment. The methodology involves deploying different machine learning algorithms within the SDN architecture for malicious traffic detection. We utilize two publicly available network traffic databases for testing, with Python used for programming the machine learning algorithms. This paper authenticates the usefulness of the proposed method through complete experiments conducted on real-world network traffic databases. Experimental findings specify that deep learning models, such as Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) display the best performance for different types of encrypted traffic. We conclude that CNN is highly effective for accurate network traffic classification within an SDN environment.

title: Lightweight CNN-based Malaria detection framework based on the use of MobileNetV2
authors: K Kiran, Rajkumar, Stuti Bhatt, Alankrita Joshi
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: Malaria, mainly caused by Plasmodium parasites which is transmitted by the bite of infected mosquitoes, is considered one of the most life-threatening illnesses in the tropical and sub-tropical areas. The mortality rates can be reduced through early and precise detection of malaria by facilitating timely treatment. The proposed study is an effective deep learning model that makes use of a MobileNetV2-based Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) to identify malaria using image-based microscopic blood smears. Extracted data comes in the form of 550 images in two classes; Parasitized (311 images) and Uninfected (239 images) and is sourced out of Kaggle. The series of observation is found to classify with an overall accuracy of 94% which showed a high generalization and reliability of the proposed model. The Parasitized group attained a precision of 0.93 and a recall of 0.99 whereas the Uninfected group obtained a precision of 0.97 and recall of 0.84. The convergence of the training and validation curves is good and there is no overfitting as evidenced by the confusion matrix which indicate that the prediction is correct with a limited number of misclassifications. The combination of lightweight architecture and transfer learning greatly streamlined the level of computation and is thus applicable in the resource constrained healthcare setup. This model contributes to the sustainable development by facilitating high standards of medical diagnostics, enhancing better health results, healthcare advancement, and enhancing international collaboration in combating contagious diseases.

title: Design of Wide Passband Band Stop Filter for EMC Applications
authors: Saurabh Kichouliya, K J Vinoy
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Electromagnetic Interference and Compatibility (INCEMIC)
abstract: This paper presents design methodologies for wide passband band-stop filters. A stepped stub resonator-based band-stop filter is developed using lumped-element modeling and microstrip line realization. Full-wave electromagnetic simulations are performed using CST Microwave Studio and Keysight ADS to evaluate the filter’s performance against the specified design criteria. Dimensional optimization is carried out using the CST Microwave Studio optimizer to achieve the design objectives. The prototype is fabricated on an RT/duroid 5880 substrate, and the simulation results are validated through experimental measurements.

title: Research on a Lithium Battery Health Management System Based on Big Data and Artificial Intelligence
authors: Jiatao Zhou
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: The rapid growth of electric vehicles and energy storage systems necessitates advanced lithium battery health management, as conventional BMS relying on static thresholds and single-model strategies often fail under complex dynamic conditions and multi-physics coupling effects during aging. To bridge this gap, we propose an integrated data-AI-system solution via a five-layer framework (data acquisition–feature extraction– AI modeling–multiphysics simulation–closed-loop optimization). By embedding electrochemical mechanisms into graph neural networks (GNN) combined with reinforcement learning, our system achieves precise state-of-health prediction and dynamic control. Validation results show a 1.2% MAE in SOH prediction—20% lower than traditional methods—with exceptional generalization in late aging stages, alongside <1.8% SOC deviation in multiphysics simulations and accurate thermal runaway forecasting. This work establishes a unified platform bridging AI, simulation, and control, offering a practical pathway toward full-life-cycle battery management with enhanced safety and longevity.

title: AI-Driven Brain Stroke Detection with Outcome-Optimized Triage and Alerts
authors: Sakshi Thakur, Dinesh Singh Dhakar, Ruchika Gupta
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Brain stroke is a sudden cranial vascular condition that demands quick and outcome-focused medical care. This work presents an AI-based framework that combines early stroke detection, subtype classification, and hospital selection support for use in prehospital and emergency settings. The framework uses a hybrid pipeline, XGB-CNNBi-LSTM-CMAES (DT-Lite Triage), which first identifies stroke versus non-stroke cases, then separates ischemic and hemorrhagic types, and finally recommends treatment centers by considering past hospital outcomes and travel-time estimates. Experiments on the California Hospital Inpatient Mortality and Quality Ratings dataset with geospatial data report an overall accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$99.00 \%(0.990017)$</tex> and fewer false negatives compared to existing methods, while aligning hospital referrals with outcome-based rankings. At the last stage, the system extends detection to survival-focused alerts, sending timely notifications to hospitals, ambulance services, and emergency teams; these alerts are fewer than early detections, showing selective escalation. A comparative evaluation with existing approaches highlights improved results, stronger reliability, and clear clinical value of the proposed framework for stroke decision-making across diverse scenarios in healthcare.

title: Machine Learning Approaches to Predict Employee Retention in the Textile and Apparel Industry
authors: A. Nagalaxmi, Gowtham K, Kaviyarasu M, Dineshkumar M, Dineshkumar B
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: The high rates of job insecurity and absence of career-relevant opportunities and stress criteria explain the high rates of retention in the textile and apparel industry as well, and human resource retention is a burning issue of the textile and apparel industry. Machine learning methods have been applied to forecast employee retention with better accuracy and decision-making capabilities. A hybrid model using a Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, and Neural Networks was developed and trained using a set of all demographic, performance, and workplace satisfaction features. The proposed system revealed an accuracy of 94.5, a precision of 93.2 %, a recall of 92.8 %, and an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$F 1$</tex> score of 93.0 %; much higher than the traditional models and much more stable and interpretable. In addition, it was found to be superior to earlier methods in predictive capability and was considered to be an acceptable tool to simulate in real time with MATLAB. The actionable implications of the above findings are evident with regard to textile enterprises to the extent that they actively establish a workforce strategy. The implications for intelligent human resource management and recommendations on future developments of explainable AIbased decision support.

title: Integrating AI and Immersive Technologies in Art Education: An Umbrella Review of Tools, Pedagogies, and Implications
authors: Jingwen Li, Wanqiu Meng, Rodrigo Flores-Hurtado
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: This umbrella review synthesizes evidence from 7 eligible reviews to examine how artificial intelligence (AI) and immersive technologies are being integrated into art education. Drawing from recent literature (2020-2025), the review identifies key tools, pedagogical approaches, benefits, and challenges associated with the use of AI in formal educational settings. The findings highlight that AI and VR/AR technologies support personalized learning, creative exploration, and hybrid instructional strategies, while also introducing ethical, legal, and technical complexities. Applying the Human-Centric AI-First Pedagogical Framework, the study offers a structured analysis and outlines future research directions focused on ethical AI, virtual tutoring, and cross-disciplinary applications.

title: CitrusSeg: A Lightweight High-Precision Instance Segmentation Network for Dense Citrus Detection
authors: Mengyan Wang, Binzhi Gao, Xianghui Hui
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Citrus detection faces significant challenges including severe occlusion, dramatic scale variation, and dense clustering in orchard environments. To address these issues, we propose CitrusSeg, an improved instance segmentation model based on YOLO11. CitrusSeg introduces two key innovations: (1) the Medium Object Enhancement Pyramid (MOEP) that specifically enhances medium-sized target detection through targeted P4 layer optimization, and (2) the Shared Convolution Decoupled Segmentation Head (SCD-Seg) that reduces parameters by 60% while improving accuracy through task decoupling. Experimental results demonstrate that CitrusSeg achieves 95.6% mask mAP@0.5 and 72.9% mask mAP@0.5:0.95, outperforming YOLO11n-Seg by 6.5 and 7.1 percentage points and surpassing YOLO12n-Seg (92.2%). Comprising only 3.12M parameters and 8.47 GFLOPs, CitrusSeg provides an effective lightweight solution for automated citrus harvesting and yield estimation.

title: Biometric-Controlled, Quantum-Safe ABE with Blockchain for Secure Healthcare Data
authors: Aditya, Islabudeen Mohamed Meerasha
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: Quantum computing advancements are a significant threat to Electronic Health Record (EHR) security, posing a “harvest now, decrypt later” threat that exposes patient data to being compromised for decades. Guaranteeing the integrity of this lifetime medical data is therefore essential because their unauthorized disclosure can expose patients to severe risks, from insurance discrimination to social stigma and professional reprisal. In addition, traditional access control frameworks fall short of offering actual data sovereignty and lack verifiable accountability mechanisms. In this paper, we introduce a new framework that couples quantum-safe cryptography with patient-driven control to address both concerns at hand. Our solution is based on a post-quantum Module-Learning with Errors (M-LWE) lattice-based Attribute-Based Encryption (ABE) scheme, hence, sensitive health data is securely and forever shielded. The framework has two fundamental contributions. First one is an access model controlled by biometrics where patients themselves manage and withdraw access to their information from user devices via secure off-chain authentication. This implies that no sophisticated key management systems are required and control is in the hands of the user. Second, a blockchain-audited ledger that securely stores every access event, such as grants and revocations, with an immutable trail for regulatory compliance and trust. In addition to this our architecture is also able to handle a decentralized multi-authority model for scalability across diverse healthcare institutions. The outcome is a holistic framework that ensures data confidentiality against future attack while establishing a new standard for auditable, patient-initiated health information exchange.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Data Augmentation on Cervical Pre-cancerous Lesion Segmentation Using SegFormer
authors: Errissya Rasywir, Siti Nurmaini, Muhammad Fachrurrozi, Setiawan Assegaff, Yovi Pratama, Jasmir
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Technological Solutions (ICAITech)
abstract: Data augmentation is essential for strengthening the robustness of deep learning models in medical image segmentation. This study evaluates the effectiveness of augmentation strategies on cervical pre-cancerous lesion segmentation using SegFormer, a Vision Transformer (ViT) model. The dataset comprises 645 cervical images from Visual Inspection with Acetic Acid (IVA) tests, captured via mobile phone cameras under real-world clinical conditions, split into 521 training images and 124 testing images. Augmentation techniques were selected based on previous CNN-based segmentation studies and included rotation, flipping, elastic transformation, perspective transformation, gamma contrast adjustment, shear, sharpening, shift, and brightness adjustment. Intersection over Union (IoU), Recall, and F1-Score were used as the primary evaluation metrics. Experimental results show that geometric augmentations, particularly rotation (IoU: 0.8030, F1-Score: 0.9636), significantly improved segmentation performance compared to the non-augmented baseline (IoU: 0.7627, F1-Score: 0.9184). Flip, elastic, and perspective transformations also contributed positively. In contrast, brightness adjustment reduced performance (IoU: 0.6875, F1-Score: 0.8148), indicating its unsuitability for datasets with subtle lesion features. This study confirms that augmentation strategies originally recommended for CNNs remain effective when adapted for transformer-based models. Carefully selected geometric augmentations enhance SegFormer’s ability to segment cervical lesions captured under non-standardized clinical conditions

title: Ethical and Secure AI-Driven Markov Chain Monte Carlo Framework for Cryptographic Signature Verification in Governance-Critical Systems
authors: R. Elangovan, Raj Anand Sundaramoorthy, Rahul Srinivas, G. K. Sudarshan, S. Chitravel
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: This paper presents an ethical, transparent, and secure AI-driven Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) framework for enhancing the integrity and reliability of cryptographic signature verification in governance-critical systems. Unlike imagebased handwritten signature methods, cryptographic verification requires mathematical validation of parameters such as hash values, random nonces, and private-public key relationships. The proposed model integrates an AI-guided proposer network with MCMC sampling to compute probabilistic confidence scores for signature validity. This probabilistic approach supports accountable decision-making under uncertainty and aligns with ethical requirements for explainability in security-governance workflows. Experiments using the ElGamal digital signature scheme show improved anomaly detection, higher verification accuracy, and robustness against adversarial manipulation. The framework strengthens both technical security and ethical assurance, offering a reliable, interpretable, and governance-aligned solution for future cybersecurity infrastructures.

title: BKA: A Nature-Inspired Approach for Intelligent Task Scheduling in Cloud Environment
authors: Gugulothu Devibai, Rajani Bandaru, K Anusha, C Keerthi, J Pranathi, J Ashrith
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: Efficient task scheduling plays a crucial role in enhancing the performance and reliability of cloud computing environments. This research introduces a novel scheduling approach based on the Black Kite Algorithm (BKA), inspired by the cooperative hunting and gliding behavior of black kites, to optimize resource utilization and improve overall system performance. The proposed BKA model is implemented and evaluated in CloudSim using Google Cloud workload traces, focusing on three key parameters such as VM failure rate, task success rate, and throughput. Comparative analysis with the existing algorithms such as Ant Colony Optimization (ACO), Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), and Whale Optimization Algorithm (WOA) demonstrates the superior performance of the proposed approach. Experimental results reveal that BKA achieves a 17.6 % reduction in VM failure rate, a 14.2 % increase in task success rate, and a 19.4% improvement in throughput compared to the best-performing baseline methods. These outcomes indicate that the BKA-based scheduler effectively balances task distribution, minimizes execution failures, and enhances system reliability, making it a promising solution for intelligent task scheduling in dynamic cloud computing environments.

title: Embedded Cost-Effective VLSI Structures with Low-Power Scheduling and Spiking Convolutional Neural Network Inference
authors: A Purnachandra Rao, Ahmad Abdelhafiz Ali Samhan, Pradeep Kumar D, M Sreerama Kiran, K Dharmarajan, P Yakaiah
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: The Cost-Effective VLSI Structures with Low-Power Scheduling and Spiking Convolutional Neural Network Inference (CVLPSC) process features a high-performance architecture that integrates advanced fingerprint sensing with robust cryptographic security and energy-efficient engineering for real-time applications. It includes a highly sensitive sensor structure designed to detect minute capacitive changes from fingerprints, optimized with shielding and buffering to improve performance while reducing noise. The pipelined charge integration technique facilitates rapid image capture, alongside security measures such as Kerckhoff's principle and SUCs, which enhance encryption key generation to defend against attacks. The SCNN modules provide strong processing capabilities, able to perform 100-million-pixel computations per second. The following metrics: energy consumption analysis, system energy comparison, throughput calculation, delay calculation, and routing overhead, several existing models such as EFMIL, CHVST, and ESDSB.

title: RLVPR: Process-level Supervision for Thinking with images in Multimodal Language Models
authors: Xinyang Tian, Yukun Zhang, Tao Fu, Xiaoyan Xie
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: The paradigm of "thinking with images", where Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) act as visual agents, has shown remarkable promise in tackling complex visual reasoning tasks. This approach leverages Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Rewards (RLVR), enabling models to make multi-round function calls to refine their visual input. However, current RLVR implementations only consider the correctness of the final answers, neglecting the validity of the reasoning process. This can lead to "reward hacking", where models receive high rewards for correct answers despite wrong Chain-of-Thought (CoT) reasoning processes. In this paper, Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Process-supervised Rewards (RLVPR) is proposed to mitigate reward hacking in "thinking with images" MLLMs. RLVPR incorporates a verifiable process-supervised reward system that provides process-level supervision for the model’s actions throughout multi-round rollouts. Furthermore, a "function call balance" mechanism is introduced to penalize superfluous function calls, ensuring that the model only takes actions that are instrumental in solving the task. The experimental results show that this fine-grained process supervision leads to substantial performance gains on high-resolution visual-search benchmarks, offering a more robust and reliable path for multimodal reasoning.

title: Time-Aware Hybrid Stacking Ensemble for Air Quality Prediction
authors: Neha Chatterjee, Sandhya Arora
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: The recent decline in air quality in Delhi, India's national capital, brought back the long-standing issue of air pollution and its adverse effects under the spotlight. It is about time we forsake traditional statistical and single-model machine learning methods for more recent, advanced neural models, which can cater to the issues of complexity and stochasticity of air quality data. This paper explores a stacking ensemble learning approach that utilises advanced recurrent neural networks like Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) as base learners, stacking them with a Random Forest meta-learner for forecasting PM2.5 values in Ahmedabad, India. The methodology involves multistep time series forecasting using meteorological and atmospheric features, and delves into two methods - a pure stacking model, and a refined hybrid ensemble blending in statistical temporal features, so as to improve the model's performance. The findings highlight the challenges of modelling noisy atmospheric data, and the promise of hybrid ensemble architectures for enhancing predictive accuracy in atmospheric science applications.

title: Random Forest based IDS Framework for DDoS Attack Mitigation in Cloud Computing
authors: Srikanth Indurthi, Ganesh Reddy Karri
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: Cloud computing environments are highly vulnerable to Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attacks making the development of robust and efficient Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) a critical requirement. This research proposes a Random Forest (RF)-based IDS designed to accurately detect and classify DDoS attacks using the benchmark UNSW-NB15 dataset. The system architecture incorporates preprocessing stages such as Min-Max normalization and feature selection enabling the RF model to handle high-dimensional traffic data while improving computational efficiency. Experimental evaluation is conducted through NS3 simulation under realistic cloud traffic scenarios and the performance of the proposed RF model is compared with conventional deep learning classifiers including Convolutional Neural Networks and Recurrent Neural Networks as well as traditional statistical classifiers such as Logistic Regression and Naϊve Bayes. Results demonstrate that RF achieved superior performance with 98.5 % accuracy, 99.5 % precision, 98.8% recall, 98.9% True Positive Rate, and a significantly reduced False Positive Rate of 0.32, outperforming all benchmark models.
