These improvements highlight the RF model’s effectiveness in minimizing false alarms while ensuring high detection accuracy. The findings establish RF as a scalable, reliable, and computationally efficient solution for DDoS detection in cloud environments, offering significant advancements over the existing IDS approaches.

title: Carbon-Aware AI Workload Scheduling with Renewable Energy Sources
authors: Sweta Chopdar, Yapalaparvi Sruthi, Diana George, Soumadip Mondal, Mithun Kumar, George Fernandez. I
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: The challenge of meeting infrastructure requirements for large-scale training of artificial intelligence (AI) models has created immense pressure on data centers. This, in turn, has led to increased energy usage and carbon emissions. The scheduling mechanisms in data centers are rudimentarily in place to focus on performance or save energy, without any focus on the carbon intensity of the energy powering the systems. This research tries to propose a carbon intensity-aware scheduling system that tries to schedule AI workloads in sync with renewable availability in electricity markets. The system utilizes carbon intensity signals from the power grid and adjusts the scheduling of AI training and inference tasks to reduce emissions and still meet performance goals. The rest of the systems only try to reduce total energy or operational cost, but this system tries to propose a new multi-objective optimization strategy that tries to optimize job deadlines, costs, and carbon footprint. Furthermore, the model enables geodistributed scheduling by moving workloads to other regions with better renewable energy utilization. Testing in simulated data center contexts shows that the proposed approach can reduce carbon emissions by as much as 30 % with very little impact on job completion times. To our knowledge, this paper is the first to propose a solution that offers environmental and economic benefits for future sustainable cloud infrastructures, bringing us closer to the goal of net-zero AI computing.

title: Design of a Secure Systolic Array matrix multiplication Accelerator for Neural Network Based on Merkle Tree Verification
authors: Qiuyan Xu, Xiang Wu, Xiang Li, Junyu Tang, Hao Guo, Wentao Xu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Systolic array accelerators, a key implementation platform for modern neural networks, are vulnerable to malicious attacks such as directed bit flips and fault injections. These attacks compromise model weights and computation processes, causing severe degradation in model accuracy. To address this security risk, a secure systolic array architecture is proposed, integrating a Merkle-tree-based verification mechanism. The architecture incorporates hardware-level cryptographic techniques, to ensure the real-time integrity of input data, model weights, and all intermediate and final computation results. The proposed design maintains robust security while achieving acceptable performance and hardware costs. Compared with a baseline architecture lacking security features, computational latency increases by 3.68%, while hardware area and power consumption increases remain within 62.9% and 23%, respectively. This design provides a hardware foundation for building Trustworthy Artificial Intelligence systems.

title: A Novel Index Tracking Model with the Perspective of Behavior Related Algorithm Design
authors: Dongsheng Bei, Ju Wei
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Considering the importance of behavioral finance in portfolio construction, in this paper, we propose a novel integrated index tracking model with a neural network algorithm. Specifically, Gumbel-SoftMax sampling mechanism is used to obtain sparse asset selection by via a differentiable sampling method. Second, a behaviorally adjusted quadratic programming problem in portfolio weight optimization is formulated with prospect theory to reflect investors’ asymmetric attitudes toward gains and losses. The back-testing framework includes a sparse index tracking problem with the behavior related algorithm. The empirical results indicate that the behavior adjustment model significantly reduces maximum drawdown, suppresses extreme negative returns at the left tail, and maintains low rolling tracking errors during high volatility periods while maintaining benchmark tracking accuracy, thereby enhancing the overall robustness and risk protection capability of the investment portfolio.

title: AI-Enhanced Biometric Systems for Insurance: Secure Authentication and Regulatory Compliance
authors: Rohit Laheri
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: In this paper an innovative strategy is offered to the AI-Enhanced Biometric Systems to Insurance, grounded in the idea of ensuring security in authentication and regulatory compliance by means of the combination of Federated Learning and Multi-Modal Biometric Fusion. By using TensorFlow Federated (TFF) to train models with decentralization and TensorFlowLite, which allows fast deployment on the edges, the proposed system will guarantee accuracy and low false rejection rates and guarantee user privacy since biometric data will be stored on the machine. The multi-modal fusion consists of facial recognition, voice authentication and fingerprint scanning, which enhance security and resistant to adversarial attacks. This method is less expensive than the traditional and centralized techniques in terms of computation and can scale with non-monolithic scaling, as it enables real-time authentication with 95 percent accuracy at low latency. Also, the system is in line with the international data protection laws, which makes it a safe and privacy-saving tool to the insurance sector. The findings show that it can be used in scalable, efficient, and secure applications in the industry.

title: Socio-Technical, Electrification, and Hydrogen-Driven Pathways for Residential Heating Decarbonisation in the North of Tyne
authors: Mohamed Abuella, Adib Allahham, Sara Walker
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Environment Friendly Energies and Applications (EFEA)
abstract: Decarbonising domestic heating remains a major challenge, particularly in gas-dependent and fuel-poor regions. This paper investigates hydrogen-based and alternative decarbonisation pathways for residential heating in the North of Tyne (NoT) region, UK. A multi-system perspective (MSP) framework—combining qualitative scenario analysis with quantitative energy system modelling—evaluates the effects of socio-technical interventions (STIs), technology adoption (heat pumps and hydrogen boilers), and hydrogen blending on energy demand, CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emissions, and system costs to 2050. Monte Carlo simulations capture behavioural uncertainties, while a game-theoretic investment model supports long-term planning. Results show that while STIs significantly reduce demand, they cannot alone achieve net zero. Hydrogen blending offers limited short-term benefits, whereas heat pumps deliver the lowest operational costs and emissions, representing the most efficient pathway under full electrification. Hydrogen boilers, though cost-intensive and less efficient operationally, show high long-term net present value (NPV £318–624 million), suggesting potential economic payoff over time. By 2050, with full CCS deployment and high renewable penetration, operational emissions are nearly eliminated across all scenarios. The findings highlight the importance of integrated planning, investment coordination, and social engagement to deliver a resilient and cost-effective low-carbon heating transition.

title: Hierarchical Training Improves Consistency of Pollen Classification on the Family Level
authors: Salih Numan Buyukbas, Veysel Suzerer, Mamatha Thota, Petra Bosilj, Erchan Aptoula
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: Accurate classification of pollen grains is crucial in various fields such as biology, medicine, and environmental monitoring. Even though deep learning methods have improved performance over traditional hand-crafted approaches, existing models often do not take into account the taxonomic hierarchy information of pollen species. In this paper, we propose a hierarchical training framework that jointly optimizes at the family, genus, and species levels using a shared feature extractor and parallel classifier heads. We evaluate our methods using a newly created dataset of 1,787 microscopic pollen images from 274 species, belonging to 145 genera, or 47 families. Experimental results, using two different backbones, demonstrate that the hierarchical training setup improves consistency on the family level while maintaining comparable classification performance at the species level. These findings highlight the value of incorporating biological taxonomy into model training for fine-grained image classification tasks.

title: A Multimodal Semantic Enhancement Method for Image Retrieval in Construction Project Planning
authors: Yuhao Wu, Lu Zhao, Fuqiang Chen, Weijia Liu, Jianjian Yue, Feng Tao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Control and Computing Science (ICICCS)
abstract: With the rapid development of information technologies in construction projects, image data has become increasingly essential for construction planning and documentation. However, the recall rate of image retrieval in construction plan preparation remains relatively low due to the weak semantic alignment between images and textual descriptions. To address this issue, this paper proposes a multimodal semantic enhancement image retrieval method tailored for construction project planning. The method employs a multimodal large language model to jointly encode construction images and their contextual text, leveraging a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) mechanism to achieve semantic segmentation and unified vector representation. By storing both visual and contextual embeddings in a shared semantic space, the proposed method enables high-recall, cross-modal retrieval. Experimental results on real-world construction datasets demonstrate that the proposed approach significantly outperforms traditional models in Recall@3 and Precision@3, providing a practical and intelligent solution for image retrieval in construction plan generation.

title: AI Enhanced IELTS Preparation using Custom Neural Networks
authors: P V Vasudeva Rao, Permanki Guthu Rithesh Pakkala, R Akhila Thejaswi, Bellipady Shamantha Rai, Sudheer Shetty, Madhukar Bhaktha
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Computing, Semiconductor, Mechatronics, Intelligent Systems and Communications (COSMIC)
abstract: International English language proficiency exams such as IELTS, TOEFL, and PTE assess candidates across four key skills: speaking, listening, reading, and writing. Many learners struggle to find a single platform that provides integrated, automated, and detailed feedback across all these components, particularly in real-time and without human intervention. Existing tools often address only one skill at a time or lack advanced AI-driven analytics, leading to fragmented preparation, slower improvement, and difficulty in tracking progress over time. This work presents an AI-enhanced web-based application designed to provide end-to-end training for all four IELTS modules. The system incorporates a custom Speech Recognition Neural Network for precise spoken input analysis, a Fluency Score Algorithm for real-time oral proficiency assessment, and a fine-tuned BERT model for deep grammatical and coherence evaluation in writing tasks. Listening and reading modules feature comprehension passages, adaptive difficulty, and performance-driven question sets to strengthen auditory and textual understanding. A unified feedback and reporting mechanism consolidates results from all modules, generating a single Grammar/Coherence Score and personalized improvement suggestions. The data-driven approach ensures that the difficulty and focus areas evolve with the learner’s performance, making it suitable for exam aspirants, professionals, and language enthusiasts alike.

title: Adaptive Cooperative Coverage Technology for Satellite Internet Traffic Balancing Based on Adjacent Satellites
authors: Baohai Chen, Zhu Tang
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: Addressing the load imbalance problem faced by mega low Earth orbit (LEO) constellations in burst traffic scenarios, this paper proposes a load-aware inter-satellite/satellite-ground adaptive cooperative coverage technology. This technology integrates multi-dimensional on-board load indicators to construct a dynamic overload determination model, achieving precise collaboration triggering; designs a lightweight inter-satellite collaboration interaction protocol, supporting elastic beam adjustment and dynamic coverage expansion based on geographic grid coding; introduces Lyapunov stability theory to ensure the dynamic convergence of the network-wide collaborative scheduling process. Simulation experiments show that the proposed method significantly outperforms existing schemes in core metrics such as collaboration infection rate, system stability, and resource efficiency, providing an effective technical path for building highly resilient, reliable, and efficient intelligent satellite networks.

title: AI-Driven System for Predicting Efficiency Degradation in Synchronous Generators
authors: Rampalli Shasidhar, Haripriya R, M. Krishna Kanth, T.Thamilazhagan, Jayapal Lande, Vivekanandhan V
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Determining the degradation of efficiency in synchronous generators is crucial to power system maintenance to ensure the availability of power and minimise lifecycle costs. This paper proposes an AI-based model that forecasts efficiency loss based on regularly measured operational variables in order to determine efficiency loss at an early stage and decide on maintenance scheduling. The preprocessing of a harmonized dataset that is composed of load, vibration, temperature, and operating hours are processed through imputation, outlier control, and normalization. We compare the performance of the three models (Random Forest Regressor, multilayer perceptron (MLP) and support vector regression with an RBF kernel) on an 80/20 split, 10-fold cross-validation, and hyperparameters that are grid-searched. Findings indicate that the suggested method has continuously obtained lower mean squared error and greater R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> than baseline options, with the MLP having the most suitable and consistent forecasts on test cases. The analysis also indicates how the operation variables impact on predictive performance in support of interpretable decision-making. The method allows scheduling condition-based maintenance and enhancing the utilization of assets by giving credible predictions of efficiency degradation in the short term. The model is extremely model-agnostic and can be easily expanded to larger data regimes and generators.

title: Optimizing Wireless Telecommunication Tower Placement in Libya Using the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP)
authors: Naji S. Abdelwanis, Ahmed M. Kashbur, Monaem Elmnifi
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: Developing wireless communication networks is crucial for the social and economic success of Libya. However, determining the optimal locations for tower placements is a real challenge. This study aims to demonstrate the use of the Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP) to select the best tower sites for the Libyan Telecom and Technology Company (LTT), thereby achieving optimal coverage and service reliability.Additionally, this study also aims to enhance the decision-making process for tower site selection by examining various criteria such as telecommunications, civil work, energy and electrical projects, contracting, and regulatory aspects. Therefore, it will make a significant contribution to both telecommunications practice and research.The AHP model enhanced the decision-making process significantly by providing a foundation for determining the optimal tower locations.The AHP model identified 38.24% of existing decisions as non-optimal and provided greater accuracy in 58.82% of decisions. Particularly, the model excelled in complex scenarios where decision-making was most difficult, with the ability to make decisive and forceful choices amid minor differences across numerous possibilities.This study highlights the merits of the AHP model as an efficient maximizer of decision accuracy and more information-based, better-informed outcomes in theoretical and practical applications.

title: A Novel Early Stage Lupus Disease Identification Methodology Based on Learning Enabled Structure Optimization Strategy
authors: Flemitha Mary D, G. Ramkumar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Early-stage detection of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) remains a major clinical challenge due to its heterogeneous manifestations, overlapping symptoms, and fluctuating biomarker expression. The paper presents the new early-stage Lupus detection algorithm, which is founded on the Learning Enabled Structural Optimization (LESO) approach and a combination of a hybrid CNN-MLP network. The data includes multimodal clinical inputs, such as genetic profiles, serological indicators, histories of symptoms, and demographics of patients. Premedical techniques, including anonymization, multimodal alignment, and missing values, were used to improve the integrity of the data. Dense embeddings and composite biomarker extraction were applied to achieve feature encoding, and a hybrid GWO-statistical feature selection model was used to remove noisy and redundant variables. The adaptive learning model dynamically optimized the neural architecture by using reinforcement-based topology tuning, meta-learning-based allocation of neurons, and hierarchical attention to supervision. An early-stage detection module further reduced false-negatives by using a focal loss-based sensitivity enhancement module. The proposed system had a peak classification accuracy of 96.56 with a sensitivity of 95.88, specificity of 97.11 and AUC of 0.964 during experimentation. The relative analysis to the baseline models showed that the detection performance improved by between 4 and 7 %. The findings verify that both structural optimization and selective attention processes have a significant positive contribution to diagnostic accuracy at an early stage. The methodology provides an intelligent autoimmune diseases screening framework that is scalable and interpretable.

title: Two Hardware Trojan Detection Algorithms: Based on Image Features or Erosion
authors: Chao Yu, Chen Sun, Liwei Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Measurement Control and Instrumentation (MCAI)
abstract: Hardware Trojans covertly implanted in chip supply chains pose significant security threats to critical systems. Addressing the limitations of existing methods that rely on golden chips and complex testing environments, this paper proposes two image processing-based algorithms for comparing layout and SEM images. The first method uses connected region feature extraction with Hungarian algorithm matching to identify structural anomalies. The second method applies iterative morphological erosion to difference images to expose suspicious regions. Experiments on 20,000 image pairs from the REFICS dataset (90nm node) demonstrate that both algorithms achieve high detection accuracy (96.85% and 94.2%) with strong batch processing capabilities. The feature extraction method offers superior accuracy and speed, while the erosion-based method provides better noise resistance. This work enables practical, large-scale hardware Trojan screening for engineering applications.

title: Privacy-Preserving and Explainable AI in Credit Card Fraud Detection: Balancing Accuracy, Transparency and Security
authors: Lakshya Sharma, Ayush Kaushik, Mridul Sharma, Shilpa Gupta
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: There have been around ${\$}$30 billion worth of monetary losses due to credit card fraud around the globe. This exhibits a serious problem for finance and payment companies, buyers, retailers and banks as well. Traditional fraud-detecting methods usually don’t perform well. They fail not because of a lack in their guessing ability, they do because they integrate excessive data bias, which is difficult to obtain, and principles of the data usage. Data usage principles, such as GDPR and RBI regulations, are very strict. This paper aims to present a totally innovative and extensive framework that can be utilised for fraud detection.. We propose an unified ensemble model that employs soft-voting fusion mechanism, where we take the average of predicted probabilities of each base model that features Logistic Regression, Random Forest, XGBoost, and Safe Neural Networks. We integrated important techniques like SMOTE to generate additional unusual fraud case examples. We used SHAP & LIME to provide insights into model functionality, and a reliable technique like Safe SGD. Our experiments were conducted on a comprehensive Kaggle dataset (284,807 transactions, 492 fraud cases), which displays that our model attained an F1-score of 0.68, a Recall of 0.95 and a PR AUC exceeding 0.96, along with secure, powerful privacy protections.

title: Towards Intelligent Human Resource Management: An Agentic AI Approach with Embedded Analytics
authors: Hemant Purswani, Jhalak Mishra, Rohan Jain, Sahil Dave, Shalini Wadhwa
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: This article presents a multi-agent system with AI capabilities as both a modular, multi-agent system and attempts to the end-to-end model of recruitment by automating and simplifying the process. The architecture that is designed is premised on autonomous agents, working together to process documents, draw skills, assess candidates, and offer data-informed decision support. The system is also capable of mapping unstructured job description and resume information to meaningful skills and experience and keywords using Optical Character Recognition (OCR) and Large Language Models (LLMs). Candidate-job similarity scores are computed through a Skill Matching Agent, and adaptive, skill-focused tests are produced by a generative AI-based Test Generation Agent. The answers of the candidates are collected with the help of an interactive interface and analyzed with the help of an integrated analytics module, which displays performance metrics, visual reports, and leaderboards. The technology results in an HR Decision Hub that integrates the insights in clear and effective shortlisting of candidates. It is experimentally established that the model enhances precision of recruitment, reduction of bias, and operational effectiveness in hiring talents.

title: Multivariate Time Series Generation Based on Spatiotemporal Dual-Channel Coding and LSTM-Enhanced Diffusion
authors: Qicai Ma, Shunyi Zhao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Control and Computing Science (ICICCS)
abstract: Multivariate time series data are ubiquitous across numerous domains, and generation methods are used to alleviate the problem of time series data scarcity. However, existing models have deficiencies in modeling temporal dependence and spatial correlation, while diffusion models have demonstrated unique advantages in generation tasks. Based on diffusion models, this paper designs a spatiotemporal-separated dual-channel coding structure to accurately capture long-range temporal trends and spatial correlations between features respectively; an long short-term memory (LSTM) enhanced diffusion transformer (DiT) fusion module is proposed to improve the adaptability to diffusion noise while retaining temporal continuity; and a dynamic gating fusion mechanism is adopted to adaptively balance the contributions of spatiotemporal features. Experimental verification demonstrates the capability of the proposed model to produce high-fidelity data, providing a new solution for the efficient expansion of scarce multivariate time series.

title: Ranked Pairwise Reconstruction Difference Enabled Time Series Anomaly Detection
authors: Hangcheng Cao, Cong Wu, Bin Pu, Ziyang He, Weisong Sun, Longzhi Yuan, Wenbin Huang, Jian Bai, Zhao Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: Unsupervised anomaly detection in multivariate time series, particularly reconstruction-based methods have obtained increasing attention recently. However, existing methods primarily focus on optimizing the reconstruction error of normal samples during training, neglecting the core goal of anomaly detection, namely, enhancing the reconstruction error separability between normal and anomalous samples. This limitation often results in an increased false detection rate, particularly when detecting subtle anomalies. To relieve this issue, we introduce a novel ranked pairwise reconstruction error comparison method, Ra-PIR, which begins by introducing noise at varying levels into normal samples to generate a set of samples with different levels of deviation. It then adopts a triplet structure to input paired samples into the reconstruction network for error computation. Building on this, we propose a ranking-constrained loss function minimizes reconstruction error and ensuring that the error ranking aligns with the deviation level, thereby improving the model’s sensitivity to anomalous patterns. Experimental results conducted on public datasets show that compared with four existing anomaly detection methods, Ra-PIR improves the average detection accuracy.

title: Extreme Learning Machine (ELM) Performance in Behavior-Based of Self-Esteem Level Prediction
authors: Mochammad Anshori, Wahyu Teja Kusuma, Risqy Siwi Pradini
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Technological Solutions (ICAITech)
abstract: This study is presented as a pilot investigation into the feasibility of predicting self-esteem levels among university students using behavior-based questionnaire data and Extreme Learning Machine (ELM). The dataset consisted of 47 student responses, which is acknowledged as a small sample size that limits generalizability. Preprocessing steps included categorical encoding, random oversampling to address class imbalance, and min-max normalization. The model was trained and evaluated using ten-fold cross-validation while comparing five activation functions across varying hidden neuron counts. Results showed that the model achieved its highest accuracy of $74.5 \%$ using the rectified linear unit (ReLU) function with 16 neurons, while the hyperbolic tangent ($\tanh$) function with only 2 neurons offered comparable accuracy with higher stability. However, no statistical significance tests were conducted, and thus performance differences should be interpreted cautiously. The findings suggest that ELM performance is influenced by activation function and neuron configuration. Despite dataset limitations, this pilot study highlights the potential of behaviorbased questionnaires as a scalable alternative to physiological data in psychological prediction tasks. Future work with larger and independent datasets is needed to validate these findings.

title: Learning-Based Root Cause Prediction from Multi-Modal Error Logs in AR/VR and wearable computing systems
authors: Caiwei Wu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: AR/VR and wearable computing systems have become increasingly complex, integrating diverse sensors, hardware modules, and distributed computing pipelines. As system scale grows, diagnosing root causes of anomalies becomes difficult due to high heterogeneity, multimodal data sources, and implicit inter-module dependencies.This paper presents a learning-based root cause prediction framework that leverages multimodal error logs, performance metrics, and sensor streams to automatically identify and interpret system failures. The framework integrates log parsing, temporal embedding, reliability-aware multimodal fusion, and causal graph propagation to provide interpretable predictions. Experiments on simulated and real-world AR/VR devices demonstrate substantial improvements in diagnostic accuracy and latency compared to traditional single-modality or rule-based methods. Our approach advances the frontier of autonomous fault analysis in resource-constrained intelligent systems.

title: Optimizing Solar Energy Harvesting Efficiency using Convolutional Neural Networks for Under Variable Weather Conditions
authors: Aaron Kevin Cameron Theoderaj, S Sree Southry, R. Meenakshi, G Narayana Moorthy, A. Annie Lotus, C Srinivasan
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: The creation of solar energy is significantly influenced by environmental conditions such as temperature, humidity, cloud cover, and sun irradiance, which may vary during the day. Conventional approaches to solar power optimization often depend on static models that fail to adjust to real-time environmental variations. This research investigates using Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) to enhance solar energy harvesting efficiency amid fluctuating weather conditions. CNNs, due to their capacity to learn and generalize complex patterns, can analyze multivariate meteorological data and enhance the functionality of solar panels. Training a CNN on historical and real-time meteorological data enables the model to forecast solar panel efficiency and modify system settings for maximal energy extraction. The system aims to optimize solar energy generation while reducing losses caused by erratic weather conditions. The proposed model is evaluated using a real-world solar energy dataset, which shows improvements in efficiency and flexibility compared to the traditional optimization methods. The results highlight the capability of CNNs to improve the efficacy of solar energy systems, making them more robust against the challenges presented by fluctuating weather conditions. This work uses a CNN for solar energy optimization, with 96% accuracy, to ensure efficient energy collection under diverse settings.

title: Domain-Adaptive GAN for Underwater Image Enhancement
authors: Bv Poornima, K Charith Rai, Srujan M Naik, K C Shodan, Hemanth A Naik
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Computing, Semiconductor, Mechatronics, Intelligent Systems and Communications (COSMIC)
abstract: Underwater images often suffer from severe degradation including color distortion, low visibility, and blur caused by light absorption and scattering, limiting their use in marine applications such as underwater robotics, marine biology, and environmental monitoring. This paper presents a Domain-Adaptive Generative Adversarial Network (DA-GAN) that improves the quality of underwater images by inferring domain-invariant transformations from the degraded inputs to the natural in-air-like outputs without requiring paired training data. The training strategy employs a hybrid multi-loss objective combining adversarial, perceptual, domain-consistency, contrastive, and color restoration losses, enhanced by curriculum learning, selfsupervised regularization, and meta-learning to improve generalization under diverse underwater conditions. An upgraded and detailed real-world underwater image dataset are available to show various aquatic environments and support an extensive evaluation beyond the existing benchmarks. The performance of the proposed DA-GAN model on public and in-house datasets, as measured by several metrics, including PSNR, SSIM, and UIQM, is significantly better than that of the state-of-the-art methods, both to the human eye and from the point of view of the quantitative metrics. The findings serve as evidence that the model can be used in real time as a solution to the problem of difficult underwater conditions.

title: Early Kidney Cancer Prediction using Exploratory Data Analysis
authors: K.V. Nageswari, Bhramara Bar Biswal, RVVSV Prasad
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Machine learning and AI have shown superior accuracy in predicting cancer, particularly kidney cancer, surpassing clinicians' capabilities. Despite early stages, artificial intelligence (AI) is being used in medical research for diagnosis, treatment, and analysis. Decision trees are widely used classification methods for kidney patient data, consisting of decision nodes and leaves, starting with a root tree with no inputs. EDA is crucial for comprehending kidney cancer datasets, identifying patterns in patient hypothesis data, and analyzing sympathetic data distribution, outliers, and significant features. A one-tailed test is a statistical method used to test a statical hypothesis, such as comparing the survival rate of a group of people with a specific cancer. The paper identifies the optimal points of the population and the patient's classification values using a proposed method. The study aims to estimate high blood pressure and early eGFR Stage-1 in women using least squares estimation, examining the correlation between age and B.P.Y. Kidney cancer symptoms may resemble other illnesses, leading to incorrect diagnoses. The CT scan effectively detects kidney cancer by analyzing the mean square error rate, particularly when a mass is detected, with a significant positive correlation in experiments. The use of fuzzy logic is being employed to identify cancer risk stages based on clinical trials.

title: Pneumonia Detection Using Optimized Deep Learning Technique
authors: Ahmed M. Moussa, Sandy S. Samir, Fatma M. Talaat
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Telecommunications and Artificial Intelligence (IC-FTAI)
abstract: Pneumonia remains a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, necessitating early and accurate diagnosis for effective treatment. While deep learning models, particularly Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), have shown promise in pneumonia detection from chest X-ray images, challenges such as overfitting and suboptimal model performance persist. This study proposes an optimized deep learning approach leveraging Genetic Algorithms (GA) to enhance the performance of the VGG16 model for pneumonia detection. By replacing traditional backpropagation with GA- based optimization, we aim to mitigate overfitting and improve classification metrics. The methodology involves fine-tuning the final layer of a pretrained VGG16 model using GA, where candidate models undergo crossover, mutation and selection based on fitness criteria such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. Comparative analysis with other optimizers, including Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), Ant Colony Optimization (ACO), and Bayesian Optimization, demonstrates the efficacy of GA in achieving robust performance. Experimental results on a publicly available dataset reveal that the GA-optimized model achieves competitive accuracy while maintaining generalizability, highlighting its potential for real-world clinical applications. This research underscores the significance of metaheuristic optimization in advancing deep learning models for medical image analysis. The proposed PSO-optimized VGG16 model achieved an accuracy of 97.43% on the Chest X-Ray dataset.

title: Site-Specific Pathloss Modeling Using Quadratic and Cubic Polynomial Regression for LoRa-Based WSNs in Tropical Oil Palm Estates
authors: Syahfrizal Tahcfulloh, Dwi Santoso, Etty Wahyuni, Michael Yehezkiel Rattu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Technological Solutions (ICAITech)
abstract: This study presents an empirical pathloss model for wireless sensor network (WSN) deployment in mature oil palm plantations, a challenging environment due to dense vegetation and canopy obstruction. Field measurements were conducted at $\mathbf{4 3 3 ~ M H z}$ using ESP32-LoRa transceivers in Sebatik, North Kalimantan, Indonesia, across line-of-sight (LOS), non-line-of-sight (NLOS), and partial-LOS scenarios. Received signal strength indicator (RSSI) data were collected over distances from 10 m to 800 m, with antennas mounted at 1.5 m to reflect realistic WSN node placement. A modified log-distance model and two polynomial models (quadratic and cubic) were proposed and validated against standard empirical models (ITU, Weissberger, FITU-R, COST-235). The results show high pathloss exponents of 2.45 (LOS) and 3.72 (NLOS), indicating severe signal attenuation caused by trunk and foliage blockage. Standard models exhibited poor accuracy with RMSE values ranging from 56.35 dB to 148.82 dB, while the proposed quadratic polynomial model achieved the lowest RMSE of 2.35 dB (LOS) and 1.43 dB (NLOS), with $\boldsymbol{R}^{2}\gt0.95$. The practical communication range was found to be approximately 600 m in LOS and 400 m in NLOS for reliable LoRa transmission (SF12). These findings provide a site-specific, high-accuracy pathloss model essential for optimizing WSN design, node placement, and energy efficiency in tropical plantation environments.

title: Cloud Computing-Enhanced Serverless Optimization Framework for Real-Time Workload Management
authors: Rama Krishna Mani KantaYalla, Subramanya Shashank Gollapudi Venkata, Suresh Gangula, Hari Prasad Dasari, Harish Kumar Krishnamurthy Sukumar, Aldo Francis Augustine
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: In this paper, the authors introduce a Cloud Computing-Aided Serverless Optimization Framework of Real Time Workload Management based on Reinforcement Learning (RL)-Driven Predictive Resource Scaling. To achieve improved performance and costeffectiveness, the proposed model implements TensorFlow and Tensorflow Agents to dynamically scale the resources based on the dynamically varied workloads. With RL, the system is able to learn to predict resource needs and adjust allocation to minimize resource waste and reduce latency. It has been experimentally determined to conserve as much as 30 percent of resources and 25 percent of latency over traditional methods of assigning resources in a non-dynamic manner. The framework is also more adaptable and cost effective than heuristicbased load balancing and genetic algorithm optimizations. Although slight delays were noticed under the peak demand conditions, the RL-based strategy was found to be very efficient in real-world conditions. This contribution can lead to the development of serverless computing by offering scalable and smart serverless system workload management.

title: Bridging Communication Gaps: A Comprehensive Approach to Sign Language Recognition
authors: Kavish Dhiman, Apoorva Prakash, Supraja P
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Sign language functions as an essential communication method specifically designed for deaf and hard of hearing people. Standardized recognition systems fail to include all populations because they operate with tight limitations aimed at Indian Sign Language (ISL) and similar widespread forms. A complete systematic approach introduces a real-time artificial intelligence system that learns five Indian sign language varieties and other regional variants. The system presents a monolithic architecture inside Jupyter Notebook which combines MediaPipe keypoint extraction with an LSTM-based deep learning model for temporal sequence classification. Through its operation the model transforms real-time sign language gestures directly to English text with precise accuracy thus enhancing accessibility among users. Real-time prediction and model interpretability along with feedback visualization depend on our solution which utilizes OpenCV, NumPy, TensorFlow/Keras and cvzone. We accessed publicly accessible video material which included various linguistic territory representations for our study. The article presents performance evaluations while making comparisons to existing solutions specifically designed for ISL applications. The proposed framework integrates regional sign system recognition to establish multilingual assistive technologies which can benefit educational, healthcare and public service functions.

title: GARNETT: Graph-based Fast yet Accurate Post-Placement Toggle Rate Prediction Model from RTL without Technology-dependent Logic Synthesis and Placement
authors: M B Rakesh, Anant Terkar, Pabitra Das, Amit Acharyya
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems
abstract: We propose a novel high-speed yet accurate GrAph-assisted post-placement prediction model that predicts the average Toggle rate of ASIC Design from RTL, skipping placEmenT, logic syNthesis and gate-level simulation. We present an efficient graph representation learning solution by sufficiently training the proposed GARNETT using a custom features-assisted graph neural network (GNN) architecture on the unbiased distribution of logic cells in translated technology-independent (TTI) netlist, achieved by bypassing technology-dependent logic synthesis and placement. This unbiased training ensures GARNETT’s efficient learning to propagate the toggle rates with our GNN by effectively embedding the feature values as vectors on each logic cell, unlike the biased training with post-synthesized netlist files in state-of-the-art (SoA) architectures, GRANNITE, Method, and GRIPT. The proposed GARNETT achieves a mean improvement in accuracy of 23.31%, 4.47%, 2.1% and 2.74% higher than the commercial RTL toggle rate estimation tool, GRANNITE, SoA Method, and GRIPT in predicting the average toggle rate, respectively. The proposed GARNETT is faster than the commercial placement-level toggle rate estimation tool, GRANNITE, SoA Method, and GRIPT, in inference latency, with a mean improvement of 6.08X, 4.05X, 4.09X, and 4.03X, respectively.

title: FSINet: A Robust Feature Separation and Integration Network for Multiscale SAR Object Detection
authors: An Wei, Song Liu, Congxuan Zhang, Shuaiqi Liu, Kaicheng Xu, Zhen Chen
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Deep learning has rapidly progressed in Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) image object detection. However, complex noise, intricate backgrounds, and multiscale objects impact the performance of SAR image object detection. To solve these problems, in this paper, we propose a Feature Separation and Integration Network (FSINet) to mitigate noise interference and improve the accuracy of multiscale objects for SAR images. FSINet is constructed in three steps. First, we construct the Feature Separation Module (FSM) as a preprocessing unit that decouples input images into distinct components, enabling collaboration with the downstream backbone to separate noise and enhance critical information. Subsequently, we propose an Adaptive Feature Integration Module (AFIM) designed to fuse cross-layer multiscale features, generating precise feature representations. Additionally, a new regression loss called Shape Normalized Wasserstein Distance (SNWD) is used to enhance the detection performance for multiscale objects. To validate the superiority of the proposed FSINet, a series of comparative experiments are conducted on three public SAR image object detection datasets, that is the High-Resolution SAR Image Dataset (HRSID), SAR-AIRCraft dataset, and MSAR dataset. The experimental results demonstrate the superiority of our method, revealing that our method achieves state-of-the-art performance in SAR image object detection.

title: Human-Autonomy Teaming in Robot Navigation Using Bioinspired Approach for Search and Rescue_supp1-3651248.pdf
authors: Chaomin Luo
publish: N/A
abstract: Search and rescue operations save thousands of lives yearly, and robotics can further improve survival rates in hazardous, partially observable environments. This article introduces a trustworthy human-autonomy teaming (HAT) navigation framework that fuses human situational awareness with algorithmic planning across both global and local layers. At the global level, a hybrid graph integrates generalized Voronoi diagrams (GVDs), for high-clearance, topology-preserving roadmaps interpretable to operators, with a spatiotemporal graph that dynamically updates edges and node salience as obstacles and mission priorities evolve. Human input is incorporated through a node optimization protocol that prioritizes access nodes, adjusts waypoint sequences, and invokes RRT*-informative path planning when jump-search shortcuts become unreliable, thereby aligning exploration with operator-defined areas of interest and mission constraints. At the local level, a bioinspired neural network (BNN) with an adaptive window strategy provides reactive obstacle avoidance and target tracking, ensuring smooth and safe motion in cluttered, dynamic scenes. Simulation results across indoor and urban-like environments demonstrate that the proposed framework enhances path efficiency, robustness to environmental change, and responsiveness while reducing unnecessary re-planning. By unifying GVD-based global structure, human-guided decision-making, and BNN-based local reactivity, the HAT framework advances autonomous navigation toward greater safety, adaptability, and effectiveness in real-world search and rescue operations.

title: A cost-effective real-time energy management strategy for fuel cell electric vehicles combining dynamic programming and model predictive control
authors: Rui Quan, Dazhi Liu, Yulong Zhou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: Fuel cell electric vehicles (FCEVs) encounter difficulties in minimizing running costs and prolonging fuel cell lifespan, and current energy management strategies fail to reconcile real-time performance with global optimization. This study proposed a framework integrating model predictive control (MPC) and dynamic programming (DP) to reduce the running cost of the FCEVs' powertrain system. A bidirectional long short term memory (BiLSTM) network optimized via the dung beetle optimizer (DBO) algorithm enabled high-accuracy velocity forecasting, and a multi-objective cost function incorporating equivalent hydrogen cost, lithium battery pack loss, and fuel cell loss was established. Leveraging the state of charge (SOC) of the lithium battery, the DP algorithm determined the best power distribution within the control horizon, and energy utilization was optimized through the rolling optimization of MPC. The findings indicate that the suggested DP-MPC strategy markedly diminishes fuel cell power fluctuations and loss costs, lowering the overall running cost of the FCEVs powertrain system throughout four driving cycles: the Worldwide Harmonized Light Vehicles Test Procedure (WLTP), the Supplemental Federal Test Procedure (US06), the Urban Dynamometer Driving Schedule (UDDS), and the China Light-Duty Vehicle Test Cycle (CLTC). Compared to DP, sequential quadratic programming MPC (MPC-SQP), Pontryagin's Minimum Principle minimizing equivalent hydrogen consumption (PMP-H2-min), DP minimizing equivalent hydrogen consumption (DP-H2-min), and rule-based strategies, DP-MPC achieves average fuel cell loss reductions of 26.4%, 22.0%, 67.0%, 60.5%, and 71.9%, respectively, and reduces the total running cost of the FCEV by 10.6%, 21.2%, 16.9%, and 41.7% compared to MPC-SQP, PMP H2-min, DP-H2-min, and rule-based strategies. The numerical and hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) experimental results show that the proposed strategy offers excellent direction for decreasing FCEVs' running costs and alleviating fuel cells' degradation.

title: Stable and Durable BTOnws&#x2013;PVDF Triboelectric Nanogenerator for Self-Powered energy supply and Real-Time Impact Monitoring_supp2-3663008.mp4
authors: Xiong Dien
publish: N/A
abstract: Triboelectric nanogenerator (TENG) has emerged as promising candidates for self-powered systems due to their ability to harvest mechanical energy and serve as active sensors. In this work, we report the fabrication of a barium titanate nanowire (BTOnws)-doped poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) composite TENG, designed to enhance mechanical robustness and electrical output. The optimized TENG exhibits stable and superior output performance including open-circuit voltage (VOC) of 280 V, short-circuit current (ISC) of 12 μA, and power density of 1.45 W/m2. The effects of device structural on output performance are systematically investigated. Environmental stability tests reveal that the TENG maintained stable voltage and current outputs across a wide temperature/humidity range and over 10,000 contact–separation cycles and that the output attenuation of this TENG is superior to that of the previously reported PVDF-based TENG. Furthermore, we verify its power supply capability by lighting up 52 LEDs and fabricated a new TENG-integrated table tennis bat for wireless position detection. The sensing system utilize a two-stage amplification circuit to overcome the high output impedance of TENGs, achieving accurate localization of ball impacts with only nine sensing units. This study not only provides insights into optimizing TENG structural and environmental resilience but also highlights their potential in electronic devices, sports analytics, and intelligent sensing networks.

title: Trajectory Planning for Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Formation with Attitude Coupling Based on Distributed Model Predictive Control
authors: Jinghe Hu, Bin Xian, Qingsong Li, Pengzhi Jiang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: This paper proposes a distributed model predictive control (DMPC) framework for unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) formation trajectory planning. Unlike conventional methods relying on simplified point-mass models, this approach explicitly integrates attitude dynamics to enhance tracking precision. The strategy ensures formation integrity and collision avoidance with unknown obstacles in real time. A decoupled geometric control scheme is further employed to regulate the attitude loop independently, significantly improving the planning success rate. The stability of the closed-loop system is established via Lyapunov analysis. Finally, real-time flight experiments validate the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed framework in complex environments.

title: Developing the cryogenic veto for BULLKID-DM experiment
authors: T. Lari, M. del Gallo Roccagiovine, G. Soum-Sidikov, D. Lhuillier, A. Acevedo-Rentería, L. E. Ardila-Perez, P. Azzurri, L. Bandiera, M. Calvo, M. Cappelli, R. Caravita, F. Carillo, U. Chowdhury, A. Cruciani, A. D'Addabbo, M. De Lucia, G. Del Castello, D. Delicato, F. Ferraro, M. Folcarelli, S. Fu, R. Gartmann, M. Grassi, V. Guidi, L. Malagutti, A. Mazzolari, A. Monfardini, T. Muscheid, D. Nicolò, F. Paolucci, D. Pasciuto, L. Pesce, C. Puglia, D. Quaranta, C. M. A. Roda, S. Roddaro, M. Romagnoni, G. Signorelli, F. Simon, M. Tamisari, A. Tartari, E. Vázquez-Jáuregui, M. Vignati
publish: IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity
abstract: BULLKID-DM is a cryogenic experiment that will use phonon-sensing Kinetic Inductance Detectors (KIDs) to search for <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\leq 1\ \text{GeV}/\text{c}^{2}$</tex-math></inline-formula> WIMP dark matter particles. The experiment will be conducted in the low background environment of the underground Gran Sasso National Laboratories in Italy. In the experiment's energy region of interest (200 eV - 2 keV), it is crucial to minimise background signals from muons, <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\gamma$</tex-math></inline-formula>-rays and neutrons. For this reason, the collaboration is developing a cryogenic anticoincidence detector (veto) composed of high density scintillating crystals read out by KID-based light detectors. We conducted a study to select the optimal veto material. Along with Bismuth Germanate B <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$_{4}$</tex-math></inline-formula> G<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$_{3}$</tex-math></inline-formula>O <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$_{12}$</tex-math></inline-formula> (BGO), we have identified Gadolinium Oxyorthosilicate Gd<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$_{2}$</tex-math></inline-formula> SiO<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$_{5}$</tex-math></inline-formula> (GSO) and Gadolinium Aluminum Gallium Garnet Gd <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$_{3}$</tex-math></inline-formula> Al<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$_{2}$</tex-math></inline-formula>Ga <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$_{3}$</tex-math></inline-formula> O<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$_{12}$</tex-math></inline-formula> (GAGG), which contain Gadolinium and thus are ideal for absorption of thermal neutrons. We tested the scintillating properties of the three crystals at cryogenic temperatures down to 20 K. GAGG exhibited the highest light yield and sub-microsecond scintillation times. Furthermore, we validated the effectiveness of the veto through simulation of the backgrounds originating from photon and neutron fluxes in the full BULLKID-DM experimental setup. A benchmark detector composed of a large (3x3 inch cylinder) BGO crystal coupled to a Si wafer equipped with with a KID was tested. We successfully operated this device by measuring the energy spectrum of a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$^{137}$</tex-math></inline-formula>Cs gamma source. We then estimated the light yield, energy resolution, and expected energy threshold. We interpreted the results with a simulation that takes into account crystal scintillation, optical photon transport, and KID response. Our finding allow for the optimization of the coupling between a KID and a scintillating crystal to further enhance the detection performance of the BULLKID-DM veto.

title: Research on Application of Distribution Network Fault Outage Prediction and Digital Management
authors: Xin Tang, Yangkai Liao, Peng Guo, Jianguan Li, Chunrong Chen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Power System and Energy Internet (PoSEI)
abstract: Aiming at the problem of unbalanced power failure data and low efficiency of manual management in distribution network, the research is carried out by combining quantitative scoring and digital means. K-means-GAN is used to deal with data imbalance, and RandomCost-CNN model is constructed to improve fault prediction recall rate and F1 value. Build a digital ledger of power outage events to achieve data entry, report generation and historical query; combined with global visualization technology, dynamic display of power outages and other issues. Practice shows that the model prediction is accurate, and digital management can shorten the fault processing time and provide support for lean operation and maintenance of distribution network.

title: Mind Mentor Net: Digital Mental Health Awareness and Adaptive Self-Evaluation Cybernetics
authors: Valarmathi N, Ragavan S, Ranjith K R, NandhaGokul R, Ragul M
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Pressures posed by the modern lifestyle are feeling mental health problems including stress, anxiety, and depression. In this project, a mobile-based application is given that is aimed at the promotion of mental health awareness and self-assessment based on the interactive questionnaires and education materials. The system relies on psychological scales which have been validated to examine the user inputs and give personalised feedback with stress management tips. Integrating awareness, self-assessment, and constant monitoring, the application prompts the user to know his or her mental state and take active measures towards an emotional state.

title: Personal Memory Assistant for Amnesia Patients
authors: Bharathi R, Balaji S, Ashwin Khannaa R L, Bhoovanash K R, Kishore Balaji V
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: The article concerns a Personal Memory Assistant (PMA) system that is meant to assist people with amnesia to overcome difficulties associated with memory retrieval using advanced technology of artificial intelligence (AI), natural language processing (NLP), and memory retrieval. It has a simple chat interface that is designed with React.js and background services that are written in FastAPI and use advanced AI models, including LangChain, OpenAI GPT, and Sentence-Transformers to produce embeddings that assist with effective semantic understanding. FAISS vector search technology is applied to allow effective memory retrieval, and the profiles of all the patients and chat histories are safely stored in a PostgreSQL database, with the supplementary backup of the information being stored in cloud storage systems, such as AWS S3 and the Azure Blob. The memory impairments faced by the patients of amnesia pose significant issues to both patient autonomy and the assistance of the caregiver. The latest progress in AI and NLP will provide context-specific memory support, which will address the conventional drawbacks in reactivity and flexibility. The recommended system offers real-time, context-driven dialogues that are aimed at memory retrieval, emotional assistance, and monitoring caregivers based on notifications and dashboards, and it aims to improve the quality of life of these patients and maximize the process of care coordination. The architecture combines different multimodal interfaces, high-quality NLP, and transformer models, including GPT-3.5, to produce an interesting and intelligent conversation, which is optimized by FAISS-based vector databases and enables the capability to learn dynamically. There is a harmonious functioning of all the system elements with the help of LangChain, and cloud integration that provides the safe data management and takes care of caregivers. The assessments indicate that the system is capable of producing the high-quality, individualized interactions and effective memory support, as well as promote active participation of the caregivers. This architecture advances the scalable memory support and there are chances that it can significantly enhance clinical results of individuals with memory impairments.

title: Research on a remote voltage reference transmission model for integrated circuit testing system based on quantum time
authors: Chao Ding, Yan Yang, Yang Liu, Qian Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Measurement Control and Instrumentation (MCAI)
abstract: Addressing the long-standing core challenges in the field of remote calibration for integrated circuit (IC) test systems, such as bulky calibration devices, complex linkages, and the inability to achieve remote metrology, this paper proposes a remote voltage transfer model based on quantum time benchmarking. By integrating quantum frequency standard technology with classical electronic engineering principles, a remote transfer model centered around a rubidium clock as the quantum time excitation source and an AD650 frequency-to-voltage conversion chip is constructed, achieving collaborative optimization of voltage benchmark stability, calibration efficiency, and remote operation compatibility. Experimental verification shows that within the 10-400 kHz frequency band, the model exhibits good output linearity. Compared to traditional on-site calibration methods, measurement errors are effectively reduced, and the calibration device volume is compressed to 1/100 of that of traditional systems. Through the pioneering "key-calibration board" dual-module architecture, the quantum extension of the measurement traceability chain is realized, laying the foundation for the subsequent remote intelligent upgrade of IC test systems.

title: A Unified System with Large Language Model for Hierarchical Multi-Label Text Classification
authors: Xuezhong Li, Jinhui Zhang, Yuxuan Zhao, Yuxiao Zhao, Sujie Wang, Wang Luo, Ming Li, Yun Bu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: To address the issue of taxonomy for hierarchical multi-label texts, we develop a system using prompt engineering based on the large language models(LLM) and overcome the inherent instability property of LLM that generates different answers to the same question. Compared to the existing label classification, our system offers a plug-and-play approach to utilizing the prompt words with rules and the experimental results verify that not only the single-level occasions can the system attain the high correct and stable answers, but also the multi-level occasions our system can precisely offer the answer with consistency. The key trick for system orchestration is to use the rule that decomposes the sentences by the property of words and matches the labels according to the meaning of keywords. This trick ensures that LLM generates the expected answers for the single-level label classification whenever it is called, as for the hierarchical multi-label text classification, our system extends the trick to the multi-level occasion and combines it with the dictionary for the hierarchical multi-label text classification.

title: A Comprehensive Review of Pixel Value Ordering in Reversible Data Hiding: Methodologies & Applications
authors: Aayush Jindal, Shilpa Mahajan, Pankaj Rakheja
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: Reversible Data Hiding (RDH) in information security entails the basic capability of embedding data into a host signal with the ability to retrieve it completely restore the original signal. Prediction Error Expansion (PEE)-based techniques are often the most well-known class of RDH methods, as they often boast good embedding capacity with modest distortion. One of the most well-known PEE-based methods is Pixel Value Ordering (PVO), that exploits the spatial redundancy of digital images, utilizes the spatial redundancy in digital images by ordering pixel values in local blocks to impose a predictable structure to the embedding process. This paper provides a comprehensive review of the literature related to prediction-based reversible data hiding (RDH) that follows the trajectory from early ideas to recent models. The review looks at the original PVO design and its modifications, which achieved large values of improvement in prediction and embedding. The review also includes sophisticated methods using adaptive embedding, dynamic partitioning, and multi-layered methods. The review even discusses using PVO in challenging contexts, such as in the context of encrypted images (RDH-EI), dual-image methods, video data, and 3D models. One focus; though, is the collection hybrid methods, in which PVO is incorporated with other approaches stemming from histogram shifting and machine learning. There also is a comparison of selected PVO methods in terms of capacity and fidelity.

title: Low Cost Water Filtration System: Working and Data Science Integration
authors: Mukund Kumar, Shakib Saif, Krish Sharma, Prashant Chaudhary, Supriya P. Panda
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: Access to safe drinking water remains a critical issue in developing countries despite its importance for human survival. In regions across the Philippines and India-particularly Odisha, Jharkhand, Chhattisgarh, Rajasthan, and the southern states—water scarcity has severe economic and social impacts. Saline groundwater, droughts, and poor infrastructure force reliance on contaminated sources. Similar challenges exist in Bangladesh, Indonesia, Kenya, and Ethiopia, where contamination and inadequate distribution systems worsen health and sanitation conditions. To address this, a Low-Cost Dispenser-Type Water Filtration System (LCDTWFS) was developed to provide clean water without electricity. The 10-liter system, primarily made of natural clay, was tested over six weeks, and the filtered water met national and international quality standards, confirming its portability and safety. The LCDTWFS is affordable, eco-friendly, and locally manufacturable by rural artisans, supporting both community health and livelihoods. Integrating data science enables performance optimization, predictive maintenance, and real-time monitoring, enhancing efficiency and reliability. Overall, this study presents a sustainable, community-driven, and scalable solution to improve access to potable water, particularly in rural and coastal regions of developing nations.

title: Understanding Pre-service Teachers’ Artificial Intelligence Perceptions Through Text-Mining: A Mixed-Method Analysis of Language Patterns, Themes, and Sentiment
authors: Hilary Ka Yan Ng, Lester Chi Him Chan
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: As artificial intelligence rapidly transforms educational landscapes, pre-service teachers’ perceptions and preparedness become pivotal for successful technology integration. While existing research has examined broad attitudes toward AI in education, a significant gap exists in understanding the nuanced linguistic, thematic, and emotional dimensions of how future educators conceptualize AI. This study employed textmining techniques, using topic modeling and sentiment analysis to examine pre-service teachers’ AI perceptions in Hong Kong. Participants provided five adjectives in Hong Kong Chinese to describe AI, yielding 258 responses. Data underwent frequency analysis, BERTopic modeling for thematic clustering, and AIassisted sentiment classification. Frequency analysis revealed “convenient” (13.2 %) and “expedient” (8.1 %) as dominant descriptors. Topic modeling identified 15 themes, with “Usability and Every day Convenience” (14.75%) and “Technology’s Societal Impact and Debate” (14.34 %) as the most significant clusters. Sentiment analysis showed 73.3 % positive responses, with all 10 participants reporting previous AI experiences classified as having positive perceptions, while none of the neutral/negative participants reported previous AI experiences. The findings reveal predominantly positive but potentially surface-level AI perceptions among pre-service teachers, with a strong relationship between experience and positive sentiment. These insights inform evidence-based approaches to teacher preparation programs, emphasizing hands-on AI experiences and deeper pedagogical understanding beyond convenience-focused perceptions.

title: Smart IoT-based Framework for Livestock Mobility Monitoring and Support in Livestock
authors: Shankar K, Thanujasree K, Venkatesan T
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Effective livestock management requires continuous monitoring of the health and mobility of vulnerable animals, such as downer and pregnant cattle, to prevent injuries, economic loss, and animal suffering. This paper presents a Smart IoT-Based Framework for Livestock Mobility Monitoring and Support, designed to provide real-time health tracking and automated assistance for at-risk animals. The proposed system integrates a network of physiological and behavioral sensors that capture key parameters including body temperature, posture, and activity level. These data streams are processed by an intelligent control unit equipped with decision-making algorithms capable of detecting anomalies at an early stage. Upon detection, the system automatically triggers a relay-driven actuation mechanism that initiates timely support actions, such as mobility assistance or alert notifications to farmers and veterinarians via a mobile application. The novelty of this work lies in the seamless integration of IoT-based sensing, intelligent analytics, and automated actuation into a unified platform, enabling proactive and autonomous livestock care. Experimental results demonstrate that the framework enhances mobility detection accuracy and reduces the response time compared to conventional manual monitoring systems. Overall, the proposed solution promotes animal welfare, operational efficiency, and sustainable livestock management through intelligent and data-driven intervention.

title: FCSA-YOLO: A UAV Object Detection Algorithm Integrating Frequency Dynamic Convolution and Spatial-Channel Synergistic Attention
authors: Huiru Cao, Kai Zhang, Lei Liu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: In this paper, an algorithm named FCSA-YOLO is proposed to address the limited feature extraction capability in UAV object detection. First, to preserve high-frequency details in feature maps, conventional convolutions are replaced with frequency dynamic convolutions. Second, to enhance the network’s focus on critical regions within the feature maps, the C3K2 module is improved using a spatial–channel synergistic attention mechanism, thereby reducing the influence of redundant features on detection performance. Finally, experimental results on the VisDrone2019 dataset demonstrate significant improvements in precision and recall, as well as reductions in false and missed detections, confirming the effectiveness and practical value of the proposed approach for UAV object detection.

title: Vit-Gwo: Integrating Vision Transformer with Grey Wolf Optimizer for Robust Crop Leaf Disease Detection
authors: Pramod Begur Nagaraj, Winner Pulakhandam, Swapna Narla, Sreekar Peddi, Nila Feby Puspitasari, Lalit Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: The role of detecting plant diseases is highly crucial in the preservation of crop yield and food safety. The conventional approaches to the detection of plant diseases are constrained by dependency on man, high time, and poor capacity to handle extensive use. This research proposes VIT-GWO, a hybrid approach with Vision Transformer (ViT) as a feature extractor and Grey Wolf Optimizer (GWO) as a model optimizer to eliminate the disadvantage of previous approaches. The new method encourages the accuracy of models, generalization, and effectiveness of computing based on the deep feature learning mechanism of ViT and optimization of the capabilities of GWO. The PlantVillage data has been used for model testing, and the performance has improved phenomenally over the current models in terms of the measures such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F 1 measure. The precision rate is even higher in the New VIT-GWO model at $99.21 \%$ when compared to the existing models. This model has outstanding scaling, robustness, and realtime usage in large agricultural environments compared to the traditional methods. Finally, VIT-GWO is a very efficient process of leaf disease detection on crops with the possibility of improvement through hyperparameter optimization, transfer learning, or effective monitoring capabilities with drone cameras or smartphones, which makes it applicable to real-world and large-scale usage in precision agriculture.

title: Evaluation of State Feedback and Output Feedback Control for Vehicle Path Tracking
authors: Buris Unnwongse, Nuksit Noomwongs
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotic Systems and Applications (ICRSA)
abstract: This paper presents a comparative evaluation of state feedback and output feedback control strategies for vehicle path tracking. A linearized bicycle model is employed to describe the vehicle's lateral dynamics, and control laws are developed using Linear Quadratic Regulator (LQR) and Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) methods. The LQR controller is implemented with and without a state observer to represent both full-state and estimated-state feedback approaches. Simulation results are provided to compare tracking performance, control effort, and transient behavior under identical conditions. The study highlights the trade-offs between controller complexity, performance, and state availability, offering insights into their suitability for autonomous driving applications.

title: A Factor Graph-based Phase Unwrapping Algorithm
authors: Yifan Zhang, Xianming Xie, Yunrui Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Measurement Control and Instrumentation (MCAI)
abstract: A robust phase unwrapping (PU) method based on factor-graph (FG) optimization theory is presented to tackle the challenges of unwrapping interferogram in Interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar (InSAR). This method formulates PU as a nonlinear least-squares (NLS) problem under a Maximum a Posteriori (MAP) estimation framework. By constructing an FG with observation factors, prior factors, and process factors, this method establishes constraints between the phases of unwrapped pixels and those to be unwrapped within a processing window. To enhance computational efficiency for large-scale interferograms, the implementation combines a sliding window mechanism with parallel computing, leveraging multi-threading to accelerate the iterative solution. The experimental results obtained with simulated and measured data showed that the proposed method performed better than some of the conventional PU methods, including ILS method, QGPU method, and UKFPU method, in terms of unwrapping accuracy and unwrapped phase continuity.

title: YOLOv7-CEA: An Improved YOLOv7 Model with Dual Attention Mechanisms for Fine-Grained Recognition of Forage Species within Ecological Quadrats
authors: Jing Yang, Chengyu Li, Tingxia Li, Hua Miao, Yue Pan, Zhenhang Wang, Dong Li, Ding Han
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Grassland ecosystems play a vital role in maintaining ecological balance and supporting sustainable livestock production. However, identifying forage species from quadrat images remains challenging due to dense plant distribution, scale variation, occlusion, and complex backgrounds. To address these issues, we constructed a dataset containing 14 representative forage species and proposed an improved detection model named YOLOv7-CEA.The model enhances the original YOLOv7 architecture through two attention-based improvements. The Convolutional Block Attention Module (CBAM) is embedded into the last three ELAN modules to strengthen the model’s focus on important spatial and channel features. Meanwhile, the Efficient Channel Attention (ECA) module is integrated into the SPPCSPC structure to refine multi-scale feature fusion and improve the detection of small or occluded plants. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the YOLOv7-CEA model. For detecting 14 forage species, the model achieved a precision of 98.85%, a recall of 96.65%, and a mean average precision (mAP) of 98.86%, improving over the original YOLOv7 by 5.3%, 3.4%, and 5.0%, respectively. Visualization results show that the model accurately identifies multiple species even in dense quadrats with overlapping plants and complex backgrounds, significantly reducing missed and false detections.

title: DriveSure: Predictive Analytics for Fleet Maintenance
authors: Jiya Sharma, Sarth Mane, Usman Shaikh, Aditya Parade, Anuradha Yenkikar, Pranjal Pandit
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Predictive maintenance has emerged as the very crucial solution to minimize operating downtime and cost in fleet management. This paper presents DriveSure, an innovative machine learning predictive analytics system that can be used to forecast truck failures, plan maintenance, and enhance overall fleet efficiency. Leveraging multiple datasets like transportation tracking, logistics activity, and large truck fleet data, the system integrates vehicle parameters, maintenance history, and working habits in an attempt to forecast potential failures. The proposed framework employs machine learning algorithms such as random forest, XGBoost, and LSTM networks for encoding structured and time-series relationships in fleet data. The framework addresses three prediction targets: binary classification for probabilities of breakdown in 30 days, regression-based prediction of days to next required maintenance, and multi-class prediction of specific maintenance needs. Experiment results indicate potential business value in the form of 30-50% reduction in unplanned downtime, year-end savings $100K-$500K per fleet, and 5-15% fuel efficiency improvement. Proactive maintenance also makes fleets safer through reduced mechanical failures that would otherwise result in accidents. A frontend that is easy to use is created with streamlit that allows for interactive visualization and decision-making by fleet operators. This work focuses on the integration of advanced analytics and real-world logistics data to enable scalable data-driven maintenance strategies that increase operational robustness, safety, and cost-effectiveness in modern-day transportation networks.

title: AECNN: A Dual-Stage Deep Learning Framework for Accurate and Efficient Ultrasound-Based Breast Cancer Detection
authors: S. Meenakshi, A. S. Arunachalam
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
