abstract: Ultrasound-based breast cancer detection presents unique challenges due to the inherent variability in tissue texture, image quality, and tumor boundary definitions. We introduce a new dual-stage deep learning model with autoencoder and Convolutional Neural Network, termed AECNN (AutoEncoder-Convolutional Neural Network), and investigate the potentials of the newly presented architecture in terms of accurate and consistent breast cancer diagnosis on grayscale ultrasound images. The framework utilizes a compressed latent representation achieved by a high-dimensional input through an unsupervised autoencoder into compact, informative latent information to the supervised 1D convolutional neural network to perform classification. This decoupling of feature extraction and classification can be used to enable the model to remove meaningless noise and concentrate on clinically important patterns. The ultrasound dataset used in this study contains images labeled as benign, malignant, and normal, collected from a publicly available Kaggle repository. Generalization was increased by performing such preprocessing as normalization, grayscale enhancement, and augmentation. After the classification, the AECNN model gained an outstanding result of 98.97, which exceeded several classic CNNs and pre-trained networks, such as VGG16, ResNet50, and DenseNet121. The model showed very high precision (99.10), recall (98.80), and F1-score (98.95) besides the accuracy. It is also advantageous of the framework since the inference is faster than in a deeper network and this allows deployment in real time to clinical decision-support systems. These findings reveal that the AECNN model is very effective to separate between malignant cases and benign and normal cases which makes it a probable source of contention in the use of ultrasound in the diagnosis of breast cancer.

title: Deep Learning for Web Application Security: A Comprehensive Survey on Intrusion Detection Systems
authors: Vemuri Nitin, Aarti, Venkata Nagaraju Thatha
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: An intrusion detection system (IDS) is meant for protecting web applications against a host of hostile activities such as SQL injection, Cross-Site Scripting (XSS), and Denial-of-Service (DoS/DDoS) attacks. This survey will discuss deep learning (DL) approaches for web-based IDS and analyze advanced forms of technology, including Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs), Long Short Term Memory (LSTM) networks, Transformers, Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs), and Autoencoders. Research on benchmark datasets indicates that deep learning-based IDSs (DL-based IDSs) applications exceed predictive accuracy of 95% and detection rates considerably exceed traditional machine learning methods. CNNs identify and locate attack patterns, LSTM networks identify and exploit dependencies in stream sequences and Transformer-based networks facilitate and control higher levels of stream processing for complex, multi-part attacks. GANs and Autoencoders improve robustness through anomaly detection. Hybrid frameworks, and particularly, CNN-BiLSTM-Attention models, achieve exceptional detection accuracy by exceeding 99% on standard web attack datasets. The survey is correct in stating that systems based on deep learning approaches (DL approaches) do not address challenges such as adversarial evasion and attack vectors, class imbalance, false positives and model explainability. Emerging research on federated learning, adversarial robust frameworks, and autonomous architectures, offer promising paths for the development of next-gen adaptive IDS for securing web applications.

title: Domain-Adaptive Image Inpainting for Scene Editing in 3D Virtual Environments
authors: Hyeongseok Oh, Jinmo Byeon, Joonki Paik
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: Image inpainting, the task of synthesizing visually plausible content in missing or occluded regions of an image, has seen substantial progress in the context of 2D real-world imagery. However, existing methods often struggle to generalize to 3D virtual environments due to fundamental differences in geometric structure, rendering pipelines, and the diversity of visual styles and abstraction levels inherent in virtual scenes. To address these limitations, we propose a novel inpainting framework specifically adapted for 3D virtual environments. Our approach builds upon conventional inpainting architectures but introduces domain-specific enhancements to better capture the structural and semantic characteristics of virtual scenes. We evaluate our method across multiple widely-used 3D virtual environment datasets and additional in-the-wild virtual samples to assess its generalizability. Experimental results demonstrate that our model not only achieves competitive performance in filling missing regions but also enables practical applications such as scene editing and content creation, thereby validating the effectiveness and utility of the proposed framework.

title: LINR Bridge: Vector Graphic Animation via Neural Implicits and Video Diffusion Priors
authors: Wenshuo Gao, Xicheng Lan, Luyao Zhang, Shuai Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: Vector graphics, known for their scalability and user-friendliness, provide a unique approach to visual content compared to traditional pixel-based images. Animation of these graphics, driven by the motion of their elements, offers enhanced comprehensibility and controllability but often requires substantial manual effort. To automate this process, we propose a novel method that integrates implicit neural representations with text-to-video diffusion models for vector graphic animation. Our approach employs layered implicit neural representations to reconstruct vector graphics, preserving their inherent properties such as infinite resolution and precise color and shape constraints, which effectively bridges the large domain gap between vector graphics and diffusion models. The neural representations are then optimized using video score distillation sampling, which leverages motion priors from pretrained text-to-video diffusion models. Finally, the vector graphics are warped to match the representations resulting in smooth animation. Experimental results validate the effectiveness of our method in generating vivid and natural vector graphic animations, demonstrating significant improvement over existing techniques that suffer from limitations in flexibility and animation quality.

title: Adaptive Erasure Coding based File Updates for Immutable Content-Addressable Networks
authors: Aya Abdallah Gebriel, Mahmoud El-khouly, Rowayda Abdelhamed Sadek
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Telecommunications and Artificial Intelligence (IC-FTAI)
abstract: Optimizing distributed storage, particularly with Content Addressed Storage (CAS) like InterPlanetary File System (IPFS), faces challenges with data redundancy and update efficiency. Traditional replication offers simplicity. However, this comes at the cost of high storage and bandwidth overhead. Erasures coding offers better space efficiency but incurs re-encoding and re-upload costs for update. Traditional storage systems modify data in place. In contrast, content-addressable immutable storage systems employ content identifiers (CID), such as cryptographic hashes. Consequently, any update to a file generates an entirely new and immutable object with a unique CID. This paper proposes an IPFS-based erasure coded file storage update system; EC-CID which optimizes updates by reencoding and re-uploading only modified segments. Our simulation results showed that, EC-CID offer superior storage efficiency but with higher update latency over various modification percentages. The EC-CID reduces average update cost by 64.89 % compared to replication. Simulation analysis demonstrates the efficacy of the EC-CID as a novel and efficient solution for file updates using erasure codes over CAS, balancing efficiency, resilience, and adaptability.

title: Adaptive Noise and Selective Updates for Efficient Differentially Private Federated Learning
authors: Jun Zhang, Shunshun Peng, Weicheng Li, Chengxing Hu, Hongbing Wang, Taolin Guo
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Federated learning addresses the issue of data silos by allowing clients to share only locally trained model parameters. However, studies have shown that even without directly exposing raw data, attackers can still infer sensitive private information by analyzing parameters such as the weights of deep learning models. To address this challenge, differential privacy techniques have been integrated into federated learning frameworks to enhance privacy protection. Nevertheless, the noise typically added in traditional methods often leads to significant degradation in model performance. Most existing approaches adopt uniform gradient clipping and noise injection strategies, failing to adequately account for the heterogeneity of training parameters across different clients and the dynamic characteristics of the model convergence process. To overcome these limitations, this paper proposes an adaptive gradient selection and noise injection mechanism, named ASUR-DPFL. Specifically, to avoid wasting privacy budget on ineffective gradient updates, we introduce a gradient selective update strategy during the central server aggregation process. Additionally, we employ the more compact Gaussian Differential Privacy (GDP) framework for privacy accounting to improve the precision of privacy analysis. Experimental results on multiple real-world datasets demonstrate that the proposed ASUR-DPFL method not only effectively protects data privacy but also significantly outperforms existing state-of-the-art approaches in terms of performance.

title: Video Latent State Optimization In Switching Models For Autonomous Agent Trajectory Prediction
authors: Abrham Shiferaw Alemaw, Pamela Zontone, Lucio Marcenaro, Carlo Regazzoni
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: Learning and perception in trajectory estimation involve a process of free energy minimization aimed at acquiring an optimal solution that efficiently models the environment. In most real-world scenarios, the environment is stochastic and high-dimensional. Learning and inferring in such highly dynamic situations require learning a representation mechanism capable of modeling key features that are both predictable and concise to support optimal decision-making. We examine the predictability of latent-state representations derived from video sequences for a self-driving vehicle using Coupled Markov Jump Particle Filters.

title: TDP-QIMLE: A Novel Temporal Differential Privacy with Quantum-Inspired Multi-Layer Encryption Framework for Secure EHR Data Storage in Cloud Computing
authors: K Radhika, George Fernandez I
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: EHR (Electronic Health Record) systems face a significant dilemma in maintaining utility while securing data that is uploaded to the cloud. This is because sensitive data requires strong and future-proof security EHRs require strong, future- proof security that traditional encryption methods, which do not have temporal privacy or post-quantum resilience, cannot provide. In this paper, a unified framework that protects EHR data from classical and quantum threats is proposed and named TDP-QIMLE (Temporal Differential Privacy with Quantum- Inspired Multi-Layer Encryption). It combines temporal privacy with time-decay sensitivity vectors, quantum-inspired encryption mapped to lattice transformations, lattice-based obfuscation, adaptive noise injection, partially homomorphic encryption, blockchainstyle integrity verification, and biologically evolving master keys. This multi-tiered defense enables analytics that are privacy-preserving to be conducted on longitudinal records, it ensures secure computation, and maintains auditability. Evaluation on synthetic EHR data demonstrates that TDP- QIMLE can provide strong privacy with minor utility degradation and is applicable for edge-cloud deployment. Moreover, ethical and bias considerations, and in particular the one related to adaptive noise, have been explicitly discussed, bringing the field one step closer to secure, compliant and explainable healthcare data infrastructure in the postquantum era.

title: Economic Viability of Electric Vehicles in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia: Insights from a Monte Carlo-Based TCO Model
authors: Sikandar Abdul Qadir, Amjad Ali, Md Tasbirul Islam, Muhammad Shahid
publish: 2025 IEEE PES 17th Asia-Pacific Power and Energy Engineering Conference (APPEEC)
abstract: The rapid adoption of electric vehicles (EVs) is expected to substantially reduce emissions in the transportation sector of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia (KSA). However, a large-scale transition toward EVs also introduces challenges related to vehicle ownership costs. This study develops a Monte Carlo-based techno-economic model to evaluate the total cost of ownership (TCO) for representative EVs and internal combustion engine vehicles (ICEVs) under KSA conditions. The model incorporates vehicle cost, insurance, maintenance, registration, fuel and electricity price, and Vehicle Kilometres Travelled (VKT) - based depreciation. Results show that under the Baseline scenario, EVs are marginally cheaper at low mileage (10,000 km) but lose this advantage as ICEVs become progressively more cost-efficient at higher distances. In the City scenario, EVs also record an early cost advantage up to 20,000 km, after which ICEVs surpass them. Under the Highway scenario, EVs are consistently more expensive across all mileage levels, with the disadvantage widening significantly at higher VKT. These findings highlight that EVs can be cost-competitive in baseline and city scenarios at low mileage, but ICEVs remain more economical for longer-distance use, especially under highway conditions in hot climates. The results provide evidence-based insights into the economic viability of EV adoption in KSA and the potential requirements for supporting policy interventions such as residual value guarantees, electricity price stability, and investment in charging infrastructure to ensure competitiveness with ICEVs across diverse driving conditions.

title: New Vvc Profiles Targeting Feature Coding For Machines
authors: Md Eimran Hossain Eimon, Ashan Perera, Juan Merlos, Velibor Adzic, Hari Kalva
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: Modern video codecs have been extensively optimized to preserve perceptual quality, leveraging models of the human visual system. However, in split inference systems—where intermediate features from neural network are transmitted instead of pixel data—these assumptions no longer apply. Intermediate features are abstract, sparse, and task-specific, making perceptual fidelity irrelevant. In this paper, we investigate the use of Versatile Video Coding (VVC) for compressing such features under the MPEG-AI Feature Coding for Machines (FCM) standard. We perform a tool-level analysis to understand the impact of individual coding components on compression efficiency and downstream vision task accuracy. Based on these insights, we propose three lightweight essential VVC profiles-Fast, Faster, and Fastest. The Fast profile provides 2.96% BD-Rate gain while reducing encoding time by 21.8%. Faster achieves a 1.85% BD-Rate gain with a 51.5% speedup. Fastest reduces encoding time by 95.6% with only a 1.71% loss in BD-Rate.

title: AI-Driven Gamification for Cybersecurity Literacy in Higher Education
authors: Roman Madrid De Angel, Ronel Francisco Ramos, Juan Paulo Hilario Magcuyao, Alfredo Lucion Calimbo, Ace Carpio Lagman
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: Cybersecurity literacy is increasingly vital in higher education, yet traditional teaching methods often fail to sustain student engagement. This paper introduces Aegis Academy, an AI-driven gamified learning platform that uniquely integrates adaptive feedback mechanisms with game-based elements to enhance cybersecurity awareness and skills. Unlike existing systems, Aegis Academy combines real-time personalization, rolebased analytics, and modular gamification tailored for academic settings. A pilot study involving 100 students and 20 instructors demonstrated significant improvements in phishing awareness (+22 %), overall scores (+18 %), and module completion rates (87% vs. 64%). Students rated the platform highly for engagement and learning impact, while instructors reported strong pedagogical alignment and usability. The platform supports Sustainable Development Goal 4 (SDG 4) by promoting inclusive, equitable, and engaging digital education. These findings suggest that Aegis Academy offers a scalable and effective model for cybersecurity instruction in higher education.

title: AI-Driven Lung Tumor Classification using a CNN–SVM Hybrid Model
authors: Khushdeep Kaur, Tripti Verma, Gaouri Jaiswal, Shivam Bhardwaj, Paawani Tripathi, Aryan Awasthi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: This research establishes a hybrid model of the Convolutional Neural Network with the Support Vector Machine model for the precise classification of lung cancer into the malignant categories. In total, 10,240 lung CT images for the study dataset, 5,000 samples were taken for benign and 5,240 malignant cases, with support proportions of 0.49 and 0.51 for these two subclasses, respectively. The proposed model clearly shows that it can effectively classify the dataset considered, with an overall accuracy of 98.53% for both classes. The model would show, about the benign class, precision as 98.99%, recall as 98.000%, and F1 score as 98.49% indicating the model's efficacy in identifying non-cancer cases. It has achieved a precision of 98.11%, a recall of 99.05%, and an F1 score of 98.58% for the malignant class, showing that it is very sensitive to detecting cancerous cases. These results suggest that the model is robust and reliable, proving it as a very effective computer-aided diagnosis tool for early and timely detection of lung cancer. Being artificially balanced is accessible to most real medical environments, enhancing diagnostic decision-making and patient care.

title: Real-Time Detection of DDoS in SDN Environments using Self-Attention Mechanisms
authors: Basi Reddy.A, Challa Sujitha, Enugubala Shama, Boyella Raju, Dasari Brahmeswara Rao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) are the more significant threat to Software Defined Networking (SDN) environments because of its programmable infrastructure and centralized means of control. The proposed paper introduces a new real-time DDoS detection framework to model the dynamics in traffic patterns using self-attention models and detect anomalous SDN flows. The provided system challenges and tailors the network telemetry data, executes temporal embedding, and employs transformer-based encoders as a mechanism of capturing traffic dependency without the use of recurrent architectures. Comparisons on benchmark SDN datasets reveal improved accuracy, False Positive rate and throughput over prior machine learning and deep learning approaches. The model attains a 97.2 % accuracy and inference times of less than 5ms indicating its appropriateness in demanding real-time models.

title: Edge-Intelligent Block Chain Framework for Federated Privacy-Preserving Medical Diagnostics
authors: R. Tamilamuthan, S. Shobana, K. Kotteswari, V Suresh Kumar, B.T. Geetha, M. Lakshmanan
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: The rapid proliferation of Internet of Medical Things (IoMT) devices and artificial intelligence (AI)-driven diagnostic systems has transformed healthcare delivery, yet centralized architectures still face challenges of data privacy, latency, and trust. This research proposes a novel Edge-Intelligent Blockchain Framework (EIBF) that integrates federated learning (FL) with edge computing and permissioned blockchain to enable privacy-preserving, decentralized medical diagnostics. In the proposed system, hospital edge nodes collaboratively train AI models on local electronic health records without transferring sensitive data to the cloud. Model updates are securely recorded and verified through smart contracts on a blockchain ledger, ensuring immutability, auditability, and transparent contribution tracking among participants. A dynamic trust-aware aggregation algorithm, inspired by reinforcement learning and hybrid metaheuristics, assigns adaptive weights to model updates based on data quality, accuracy, and node reliability, mitigating poisoning and inference attacks. The framework also employs an energy-optimized consensus mechanism using adaptive Practical Byzantine Fault Tolerance (PBFT) to improve transaction throughput and scalability in edge environments. Experimental evaluation using the MIMIC-III and PhysioNet clinical datasets demonstrates a 96.4% diagnostic accuracy, a 35% reduction in model convergence time, and a 40% improvement in energy efficiency compared to the conventional federated learning systems. The proposed EIBF framework ensures data sovereignty, low-latency inference, and verifiable trust across distributed healthcare ecosystems, establishing a foundation for next-generation secure and intelligent medical networks.

title: Performance Comparison of Logistic Regression and Random Forest in Predicting Customer Acquisition
authors: Elisya Aprilia, Romi Fadillah Rahmat, Rizki Muliono, Andre Hasudungan Lubis, Muhathir
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Technological Solutions (ICAITech)
abstract: Customer acquisition is a critical component of business sustainability, and predictive modeling offers a datadriven approach to identify potential customers more effectively. This study compares the performance of Logistic Regression (LR) and Random Forest (RF) in predicting customer acquisition using a publicly available consumer electronics dataset comprising product attributes, demographic profiles, purchase behavior, and satisfaction levels. To ensure robust evaluation, both models were optimized using Grid Search and Random Search hyperparameter tuning, rather than relying solely on default configurations. The results show that RF significantly outperforms LR across all metrics, achieving an accuracy of $95.4 \%$ and F1-score of 0.959 compared to LR’s $85.4 \%$ accuracy and 0.874 F1-score. The findings confirm that RF provides superior predictive power and generalization capability, while hyperparameter tuning enhances the reliability of comparative analysis. This research contributes by demonstrating the importance of hyperparameter optimization in model evaluation and provides empirical evidence that $\mathbf{R F}$ are more effective than $\mathbf{L R}$ for customer acquisition prediction.

title: Proactive Congestion Detection and Video QoE Preservation Over QUIC Using LSTM
authors: Sarika Patil, Shilpa Gaikwad
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: A data-driven framework for proactive congestion detection and video quality preservation in QUIC-based streaming networks is introduced. An SDN/Mininet hierarchy with programmable switches creates reproducible bottlenecks, while QUIC transports (NewReno, BBRv2) carry constant-frame-rate streams. The path is instrumented to build a sequence feature vector—active flows, pre-ACK transmissions, utilization, effective window, decrement events, and session wait time—and detection is formulated as supervised sequence modeling with stacked LSTMs. The model anticipates congestion from ACK timing and flow dynamics, outperforming SVM, DT, DA, and KNN (accuracy 0.96, specificity 1.00). A complementary PSNR study on standard YUV clips shows that under 1-2% loss, QUIC-BBRv2 sustains higher fidelity than QUIC-NewReno and a TCP-CUBIC reference, whereas NewReno matches BBRv2 at 0% loss. Findings support cross-layer control coupling sequence-aware prediction with QUIC pacing to stabilize queues and protect QoE. Deployment paths include MPQUIC integration, online adaptation via reinforcement learning, and evaluation across cellular, Wi-Fi, and satellite links.

title: Secure Enterprise Authentication Using Continuous Behavioral Biometrics and Adaptive AI
authors: Srushty Chavan, Gauri Surale, Gayatri Khairnar, Harshita Wasnik, Priya Karemore, Prerna Humbe
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: The threat of cyberattacks such as replay attacks, phishing, and credential theft has made classic authentication methods such as passwords and OTPs more vulnerable. Biometric authentication then became a safer alternative to these. Despite their uniqueness, physiological biometrics (e.g., fingerprint and face recognition) are static and susceptible to deepfake attacks, spoofing, and man-in-the-middle attacks. These weaknesses bring into focus the need for behavioral biometrics, including active user interaction for enhanced security. For corporate environments, our recommended method constructs a multifactor adaptive continuous authentication system through the fusion of keystroke dynamics, mouse movements, and touchpad usage. As opposed to traditional static authentication, our method is constantly monitoring user activity for inconsistencies and unauthorized access in real time. AI models such as Random Forest, One-Class SVM, Reinforcement Learning, and LSTM are applied within the system in order to improve detection precision and adapt to patterns of user behavior. In order to enhance company security without compromising ease of use, this ensures a safe, seamless, and non-intrusive authentication experience. This process is well-suited for modern company authentication because it provides robust protection against impersonation and cyberattacks.

title: Seizing the Moment: Multimodal EEG Trends and Real-Time Epilepsy Seizure Detection with Dual Deep Nets
authors: Shreyaskar Ganguly, Sagnik Chakraborty, Ayush Roy, Mukundraj V. Patil, Reena Pagare
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Epilepsy is a chronic neurological disorder marked by sudden, recurrent seizures that impact quality of life. EEG signals are key for diagnosis but manual analysis is time-consuming and error-prone. This study proposes a machine learning-based system for automated seizure detection using EEG data. After noise removal and feature enhancement, time and frequency-domain features are extracted to capture seizure-specific patterns. Multiple models were trained and tested, with an ensemble of STAR-Net and EEG-Net achieving the highest accuracy of 99.5217% on the pre-processed Kaggle Epileptic Seizure Recognition dataset. The proposed system accurately distinguishes seizure from non-seizure states, offering a fast, reliable, and consistent tool to assist neurologists, especially where expert EEG interpretation is limited.

title: AI-Driven Predictive Model for Assessing Psychological Wellbeing of Employees in the Information Technology Sector
authors: P. Kalyanakumar, Mohamed Sameer S, Arshath Ahamed A
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Mental health for employees has become increasingly important through organizational concern, especially in the technology domain, due to elements such as higher workloads, minimal peer or supervisory support, and high paced work environments. Tackling these challenges in mental health as part of a crisis management strategy is an imperative first step for improved employee quality of work life, performance and organizational stability. The study investigates the use of supervised machine learning algorithms to predict the propensity towards mental health issues among employees according to static and dynamic human resources, demographics and workplace applications. The research utilizes a dataset representing the “Mental Health in Tech Survey”, provided by Open Sourcing Mental Illness (OSMI), which holds extensive information on employee's perceived workplace experience relating to mental health. An ensemble approach combines three advanced supervised learning models (TabNet, DynaBoost, LightGBM) was developed to discover more accurate predictive model and used majority voting mechanism to improve prediction performance. The dataset was prepared by using a variety of methodologies relating to the treatment of missing values, categorical encoding, and feature reducing methodologies to improve the quality of the model. Model assessment was guided by classification's common metrics like MSE, R2 Scores. The study indicates the relatively new area of data-driven methodologies can provide a collaborative approach to enhancing employee's quality of work life through early detection and intervention strategies.

title: Image Analysis-Based Evaluation of CNN Models for Crop Disease Detection
authors: Dhruv Singh, Ginni Arora, Chirag Miglani, Dhruv Saini, Prem Massand
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: Agro-diseases are a major nightmare in global agricultural production, resulting in massive losses of production and inadequate food security. The conventional manual techniques of detection are very laborious, subjective and prone to errors, hence the need for the mechanized alternative. The proposed research has carried out an analytical assessment of convolutional neural network (CNN) approaches to crop disease diagnosis using images in a profound image analysis state. Carry out a systematically constructed CNN architecture evaluation of benchmark data of diseased and healthy leaves of crops. The structure of the methodology comprises data preprocessing and transfer learning training of the model, optimization of hyperparameters and strict validation of performance with the assistance of cross-validation and the confusion matrix analysis. Comparative analyses are done with respect to accuracy, sensitivity to change with respect to variations in lighting and occlusion, and computational efficiency on different crops. Results indicate that deeper CNNs are more effective at the extraction of complex disease patterns, and they are better than shallow models in generalization, but can be practically deployed. Primarily, this analysis finds that a well-informed choice of ready-made CNN models can allow highly efficient and scalable crop disease detection systems to be built that allow farmers with timely interventions to reduce the economic and environmental ramifications without requiring new algorithmic work.

title: Agentic AI-Driven Decision Orchestration System for Real-Time Project Coordination
authors: P. Harini, Bhavani Thota, Shamim, Banitamani Mallik, V.S. Prasad Kandi, Maddikera Kalyan Chakravarthi
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: With a recent development in the technology field for artificial intelligence (AI) speed and optimization, agentic software capable of autonomous decision, and self-determining and auto-coordinating (or at least similarly supposed) software have been made capable of being statistically possible. The scope of this research is to present project coordination Agentic AI for project management Decision Orchestration System (dynamic and complex project triangulation in real-time environment). The hybrid decision intelligence (DDI) of system includes deep reinforcement learning for the optimizer; transformer-based adaptive communication for mobile agents, knowledge graph for being aware of and mapping algorithm for centralized neural network system, prediction of sub-system of digital twins, GNNs and expert; sub-system prediction. The solution offers proactive risk management - remote control scheduling and live remote operations of distributed personnel and loT-based infrastructure. The reason depends partly on this solution being explained, and the fact that it is fully transparent and incredibly scalable thanks to its continuous learning system. Specifically, the orchestration platform creates a fundamental shift in how projects are being executed because it is built upon efficiency, agility, and intelligent automation for more mature organizations

title: Essential Technological Enablers Toward the Emergence of AI-Native 6G
authors: M. Boumalkha, A. S. I. Amar, Y. M. Madany, H. J. Basherlou, N.O. Parchin
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Telecommunications and Artificial Intelligence (IC-FTAI)
abstract: The evolution of mobile communications has progressed from basic voice-centric 1G systems to the highly connected and intelligent paradigms of 5G. However, the exponential rise in data demand, device heterogeneity, and emerging applications such as holographic communications, industrial digital twins, and immersive XR highlight the limitations of current networks. Sixth-generation (6G) wireless systems are envisioned as the first AI-native generation, embedding artificial intelligence as a core component of network architecture rather than a peripheral optimization tool. This paper explores the key enabling technologies that will underpin AI-native 6G, including Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces (RIS), Non-Terrestrial Networks (NTN), Joint Communication and Sensing (JCAS), Semantic Communications, and next-generation AI hardware accelerators. By integrating these pillars, 6G aims to deliver autonomous, adaptive, and service-oriented connectivity capable of meeting unprecedented performance and intelligence requirements. The paper provides a forward-looking perspective on how these technologies converge to establish a foundation for resilient, scalable, and intelligent wireless systems in the 2030s and beyond.

title: Development of an Integrated Digital Twin Model for Photovoltaic Facilities and Predictive Control with Spatial Dependency Modeling
authors: S. Agnes Shifani, Lingala Venkateswarlu, Ch Kiran Kumar, Jayashree N, Mary Kannidi, M. Dinesh
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: The IDTPPS has been developed to enhance the performance and efficiency of NZEB. This system incorporates DT modeling, multi-objective optimization, and photovoltaic (PV) circuit modeling consists of four main stages: data collection, model construction, simulation analysis, and validation iteration. Error metrics are employed to ensure precise calibration for improved energy management, while a comprehensive equivalent circuit model for PV subsystems is utilized to optimize power tracking. Model Predictive Control (MPC), adaptive gain scheduling, and a modified Graph Attention Network (GAN) are implemented to effectively manage the complex spatial and temporal relationships among interconnected systems. The following metrics are used to calculate the IDTPPS model of Maximum Power Analysis of IDTPPS, Predictive Power Analysis of IDTPPS, Train and Test Data Prediction, AQI Prediction, and Maximum Power Point.

title: Fine-Tuned BERT Model for Fraudulent Messages Detection in Algerian Dialect: A Lightweight Approach with Balanced Evaluation Metrics
authors: Dhiya Eddine Abid, Abdelkader Ghazli
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Innovative Applications (AIIA)
abstract: Fraudulent messages, particularly those involving phishing attempts and financial scams, pose a significant threat to online security in Arabic-speaking regions. The challenge is amplified in contexts where the Algerian dialect and Modern Standard Arabic are intermixed, as these dialectal variations remain underexplored in natural language processing research. In this study, we present a lightweight approach for fraud detection in Arabic and Algerian dialect messages by fine-tuning the DziriBERT model. A custom dataset of authentic fraudulent and legitimate messages was compiled, preprocessed, and tokenized using the DziriBERT tokenizer. The model was trained and evaluated with HuggingFace’s Trainer API, using accuracy and weighted F1-score as performance indicators. Experimental results from 5-fold cross-validation demonstrate that the fine-tuned DziriBERT model achieves exceptional performance with a mean accuracy of 99.0% ± 1.2% and weighted F1-score of 98.8% ± 1.3%, significantly outperforming AraBERT (95.24% accuracy) on the same task. This study highlights the effectiveness of fine-tuned transformer-based models for fraudulent message detection in Arabic and dialect, and lays the foundation for future work on larger, more diverse datasets to support real-world cybersecurity applications.

title: High Altitude Electromagnetic Pulse (HEMP) Coupling and Analysis of a Dipole Antenna
authors: Rakesh Kichouliya, Dipanjan Gope
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Electromagnetic Interference and Compatibility (INCEMIC)
abstract: High Altitude Electromagnetic Pulse (HEMP) coupling analysis plays a critical role in the design of protective circuits against HEMP effects. Traditionally, such studies require the use of an HEMP simulator, which serves as the test system for final compliance evaluation. However, these simulators are highly expensive and not readily accessible, posing a significant challenge for conducting HEMP coupling analysis. In this work, a low level, amplitude based frequency domain transfer function approach readily available in a typical electromagnetic compatibility (EMC) laboratory is presented to compute the HEMP induced voltage in a dipole antenna. The computed results are validated through full wave simulations using Altair’s FEKO software. Furthermore, waveform norms representing various effects in electronic systems for failure mode analysis are also evaluated.

title: Design and Analysis of a sub Ku-Band Parabolic Reflector Antenna for Satellite Communication
authors: N Kanagaraj, R Saravanakumar, S.G. Susila
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: A sub Ku-band, particularly its upper frequency range (14-18 GHz) plays a vital role in digital satellite communication due to its efficient, high bandwidth and capability to support broadband, broadcast and VSAT applications. This research presents the design and analysis of a parabolic reflector antenna optimized for sub Ku-band operation at 17.5 GHz uplink for the f/D ratio of 0.4. The design incorporates precise reflector geometry and feed design and optimization to achieve high gain, narrow beamwidth and improved radiation efficiency by minimizing side lobe level. The simulation of proposed antenna is carried out using MATLAB to evaluate the antenna’s parameters such as radiation pattern, gain, directivity, return loss and efficiency. The proposed design gives the return loss −60dB at the operating frequency of 17.5 GHz uplink, the gain is 42.13 dBi, directivity 38.85 dB, HPBW 1.33° and efficiency 60%. The feed of the antenna is compact corrugated conical horn with diameter of 58 mm with low side lobes and good cross polarization for VSAT, DTH broadcasting and earth station systems.

title: AI-Driven Sentiment Analysis in News Media: Insights into Public Opinion and Journalism's Evolving Role
authors: Pavan Mishra, Namrata Laxman Jogi, Aastha Saxena, Prem Kumar Sholapurapu, B. Sujatha, Pratlshruti S Singh
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Sentiment analysis remains a fundamental component of contemporary news environments, since tracking underlying public attitudes allows journals to recalibrate their strategies against accelerating information flows. Existing models, however, remain discreetly deficient; they neglect cadence cues, overlook temporal-narrative motifs, and silence dynamics in affective scale. To remediate these vulnerabilities, a two-tiered architecture anchored in complex artificial intelligence is advanced, whereby the second-tier algorithm directly inherits and amplifies tutorship from the first. The first module, Neuro- Helical Sentiment Tensorization (NHST), executes a hierarchical tensor factorization of dense semantic embeddings, extracting isotropic sub-manifolds whose affective delta enlightens a sample of minimally-annotated, dense news corpora. Aggrieved tensors are thus calibrated, denoised, and transformed to serve as precursor variables for the second leg, Chrono-Gradient Harmony Mapping (CGHM), a hybrid matrix of temporal harmonic gradients and spatiotemporal graph embeddings that concurrently realigns semantic flow over emergent network -line explosions. Graphical embeddings and tensors of time-scale and net affect carry parametrically healed norms. Reference signals are harvested at scale from the open-access Global Database of Events, Language, and Tone (GDELT), whose intra-dataset recalibrated sentiment tensors are overlaid against target periodicals to surface public affect intersections moment to moment, permitting cognitive and dialectical shifts to be retrospectively, thereby prospectively subjected to temporal echo and amplitude gauging. The present investigation furnishes a more vivid instance of allowing empirical phenomena to develop on their own terms than is evident in Barthet's earlier work. In this context, “to set” is synonymous with the agronomic act of scattering seeds across cultivated soil in order to germinate a communal expectation. This new analytic pipeline not only achieves higher granular fidelity in sentiment metric computations but simultaneously supplies profound illumination into the mutative capacity of contemporary journalism as a constructor of public judgment.

title: Integrating Multi-Scenario Preprocessing and Data Augmentation with BiLSTM for Robust Agricultural Weather Forecasting
authors: Vivi Nur Wijayaningrum, Vipkas Al Hadid Firdaus, Mamluatul Hani’Ah, Noprianto, Agung Nugroho Pramudhita, Rokhimatul Wakhidah
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Technological Solutions (ICAITech)
abstract: Crop yields are strongly affected by weather factors including temperature, humidity, rainfall, and wind, which play critical roles in plant development, irrigation management, and harvest outcomes. Reliable weather forecasting is thus crucial for enabling data-driven horticultural decisions and minimizing production risks. Conventional prediction techniques often struggle with non-stationary and multivariate time-series data and typically rely on a single preprocessing or feature engineering method. This study proposes a comprehensive framework integrating multiscenario preprocessing, scaling, and data augmentation with Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) modeling to predict daily weather parameters. Preprocessing strategies include interpolation, mean, median, and k-nearest neighbors (KNN) imputation, while scaling methods involve Min-Max and Standard normalization. Data augmentation techniques such as sliding windows, Gaussian noise injections, and seasonal encoding are applied to enhance temporal pattern learning and model generalization. The framework evaluates multiple combinations of imputation, scaling, and augmentation strategies to identify optimal pipelines for each weather parameter. Results show that the best scenario, which combines Median imputation, Min-Max scaling, and Seasonal augmentation with a window size of 7, achieves the lowest RMSE of 0.0833 for temperature and an $\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$ of 0.5151, indicating substantial variance explained. Wind speed also shows robust performance under similar preprocessing, whereas rainfall and relative humidity remain challenging to forecast due to high variability. The findings highlight the importance of systematic preprocessing and augmentation for improving predictive accuracy. This framework provides a robust and adaptive tool for supporting precision agriculture, enabling more informed management decisions amid varying weather conditions.

title: Traffic Model and Simulation Analysis for Machine Type Communication Under Dynamic scenes
authors: Xinggen Qu, Yajing Hu, Hongguang Dai, Qihua Huang, Jinlei Chen, Dashuang Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: Machine type communication (MTC) has become the main force of 5G communication and is the basic technology for the Internet of Things to achieve the "Internet of Everything". The traffic model for MTC is completely different from the traffic model for human-type communication, which not only needs to process a large number of devices, but also needs to consider the correlation between a large number of devices in time and space. In this paper, based on traditional Coupled Markov Modulated Poisson Process (CMMPP) a low-complexity source traffic model for MTC is constructed in the time-varying dynamic scenes of emergencies. The proposed model not only considers the impact of the speed of the emergency on the source traffic model, which meets the actual application scene, but also adopts the piecewise function to calculate the random variable, which reduces the computational complexity and has more application value. Simulation results verify the effectiveness of the proposed model.

title: Using artificial intelligence algorithms to predict Vietnamese student success in English listening and reading exams
authors: Vo Phan Thu Ngan, Thao-Trang Huynh-Cam, Long-Sheng Chen, Leigh Gerrard Dwyer, Tzu-Chuen Lu
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: This study aims to predict and identify key factors influencing student success in English listening and reading exams among non-English major students at a public university in Vietnam’s Mekong Delta region. The analysis employs Naïve Bayes (NB), CART, and Support Vector Machines (SVM) classifiers for predictions and important feature selection. The sample consists of 123 students enrolled in English preparation courses during Semester 2 of the 2021/2022 academic year. The input features included scores for 18 listening and 22 reading practice tests provided in these preparation courses. The output feature was students’ success or unsuccess in the final authentic English listening and reading exams. For listening exams, the NB model outperformed both CART and SVM, achieving an accuracy of 95.2% and an F1 score of 93.2%. Among all input features, scores from practice tests 18 and 5 emerged as the most influential factors in determining whether students passed or failed the listening exams. For reading exams, the NB and SVM models surpassed CART, each recording an accuracy of 93.6% and an F1 score of 93.4%. Similarly, practice tests 18 and 8 were identified as the most significant contributors to students’ success in the reading exam. These findings are expected to assist educational managers and course designers in enhancing exam preparation strategies, ultimately improving student performance through targeted practice content.

title: Lightweight Dangerous Goods Detection Algorithm in X-ray Image Based on Improved YOLOv11
authors: Jiangyu Peng, Zhe Yu, Bin Wang, Yiming Sun
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Current high-precision object recognition algorithms in X-ray security inspection struggle with excessive parameters and computation, limiting deployment on mobile embedded devices. Lightweight models, however, often fail in complex scenarios. To strike a balance, this paper proposes YOLO-Light, an enhanced YOLOv11 detection model with four improvements. First, the backbone is replaced with RepHGNetv2, using depthwise and reparameterized light convolution to lower complexity while boosting speed. Second, a Lightweight Local Attention Convolutional Network (LLACN) is added to the feature pyramid to reduce high-frequency loss and improve downsampling. Third, an Efficient Single Branch Detection Head (ESBDH) employs group convolution and sharing to minimize resource use. Finally, a Contour Detail Enhancement Fusion CSPNetwork (CSP_CDEFN) suppresses noise and alleviates occlusion. YOLO-Light decreases parameters and computation by 30% and 27%, and achieves 88.8%, 69.8%, and 65.6% mAP@0.5 on OPIXray, CLCXray, and PIDray, slightly surpassing YOLOv11n. Experiments confirm higher efficiency and smaller model size than mainstream lightweight detectors.

title: Research on Hybrid Optimization Algorithm for Multispectral Radiation Thermometry of High-Temperature Aerospace Components
authors: Yuyang Feng, Peng Xiao, Hongbing Tai, Yulin Cong
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: As the core high-temperature component of aero-engines, accurate surface temperature monitoring of turbine blades is essential for ensuring engine performance and reliability. With the continuous increase in turbine inlet temperature, traditional contact measurement methods (e.g., thermocouples and thermal paints) suffer from drawbacks such as temperature field disturbance and insufficient dynamic response. Meanwhile, non-contact multispectral radiation thermometry is severely limited by errors introduced from emissivity model assumptions, which constrain its measurement accuracy. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a dual-population hybrid optimization method that combines an Adaptive Differential Evolution (ADE) algorithm with a Fast Gradient Projection (FGP) algorithm for improving temperature and emissivity inversion accuracy and efficiency. Specifically, ADE dynamically adjusts the mutation factor and crossover rate to enhance global search ability and maintain population diversity, thus avoiding local optima, while FGP employs projection gradient descent with an adaptive step-size mechanism to achieve fast convergence within the feasible domain. The cooperative optimization effectively integrates global exploration and local acceleration. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves an average relative temperature error of only 1.1% across six typical emissivity models (decreasing, increasing, W-type, M-type, etc.), outperforming the conventional genetic algorithm (1.92%) and reducing inversion time by 37.5%. These results confirm the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed hybrid optimization method in multispectral temperature measurement, providing a promising approach for accurate thermometry of high-temperature components.

title: Deep Learning Methods of Unstructured Data Integration and Analysis to Optimize Decision Making and Database
authors: Ainomugisha Maxima, Maninti Venkateswarlu, Majid Saleem, S. Naveen Kumar, Tella Prameela, Bala Gangadhara Gutam
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: The integration of unstructured information in a Relational Database Management System (RDBMS). Companies that want to exploit the use of unstructured data in their decisionmaking processes find it a great challenge to exploit them due to the large amounts and forms that such form of data takes. This study presents a novel integration framework combining Optical Character Recognition (OCR) with advanced deep learning models-specifically Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM)-to facilitate the incorporation of unstructured data into Relational Database Management Systems (RDBMS). Unstructured data, due to its diverse formats and volume, poses challenges for traditional RDBMS, which are optimized for structured inputs. To address these limitations, this research develops a classification-driven model capable of automatically extracting and structuring data from scanned documents such as receipts and invoices. The hybrid CRNN-BiLSTM architecture significantly enhances recognition accuracy, increasing performance from 83.2 % to 94.6 %, with corresponding gains in precision, recall, and F1-Score. The model was validated through a rigorous data science methodology encompassing data collection, model training, testing, and evaluation. These results demonstrate the model's effectiveness in transforming unstructured documents into structured formats, enabling improved decision-making and database performance. The study encourages future exploration into additional deep learning enhancements, model scalability, and cross-domain applicability.

title: Interacting with Student Information on Google Sheets Using the RAG Technique
authors: Chacharin Lertyosbordin, Nattawat Panyapakdeewong, Panyakorn Singhadoung
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: This study presents an AI-powered chatbot that enables natural language access to student records stored in Google Sheets. The system integrates Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) using Gemini 1.5 Flash and ChromaDB for semantic embedding, vector-based retrieval, and contextual response generation. A RESTful API, developed using Python Flask, supports integration with external platforms, allowing users to query academic, health, contact, and demographic data. Developed under the Design and Development Research (DDR), Type I model, the prototype was tested with 15 representative queries against a mock dataset of 35 students. Results showed average token usage of $\mathbf{3 1 6. 5}$ for prompts and $\mathbf{3 7. 7}$ for responses, with 14 of 15 answers receiving the highest relevance score. The findings demonstrate that a lightweight, RAG-based chatbot can offer efficient and accurate educational data access, supporting non-technical users in retrieving information without direct spreadsheet interaction.

title: Tri-Objective Self-Supervised Representation Learning for High-Dimensional Tabular Data
authors: Rama Mohana Rao Maganti, D. Varun Prasad, Prasad Devarasetty, RRajaRamesh Merugu, Nageswararao Malisetti, N.Venu Babu
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Self-supervised learning (SSL) has emerged as a powerful paradigm for representation learning without large labeled datasets, but its application to tabular data remains difficult due to heterogeneous feature types, missing values, and the lack of spatial or sequential structure. This paper introduces a tri-objective SSL framework that jointly integrates contrastive, masked reconstruction, and alignment objectives within an encoder-projector-decoder architecture. The proposed method learns robust and transferable tabular representations that remain effective under noise, corruption, and distribution shifts. Extensive experiments on five benchmarks, comprising three UCI datasets (Adult, Breast Cancer, Covertype) YearPredictionMSD and a healthcare dataset, demonstrate consistent gains over tree-based learners (XGBoost, CatBoost) and recent SSL baselines (SCARF, SubTab, SAINT, ReConTab), with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2}-\mathbf{4} \boldsymbol{\%}$</tex> higher accuracy, up to 5% lower RMSE, and over 90% retention of full-supervision accuracy using only 10 % labeled data. These results highlight the potential of multi-objective self-supervision as a practical and scalable solution for real-world tabular applications.

title: The Role of Artificial Intelligence in Science Education: Enhancing Student Engagement and Preparing the Foundations for Future Education through Digital Literacy
authors: Thoriqi Firdaus, Sabar Nurohman
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: Science education is increasingly recognizing the role of Artificial Intelligence (AI) ’s role in teaching and learning. However, students’ preparedness in Indonesia to optimally leverage this technology remains a significant issue. This study analyzes the role of Al through the mediation of digital literacy based on factors influencing student engagement in technology-based learning processes and their readiness to face future educational ecosystems. The quantitative research approach utilises Partial Least Squares Structural Equation Modeling (PLS-SEM). Data were collected via a six-scale questionnaire involving 200 science education students from three universities in Madura Island. The findings reveal that Digital Literacy significantly impacts Future Learning Readiness ($\beta$ =0.389, t = 3.789 p < 0.000), although its effect on Learning is relatively weak ($\beta$ = 0.099, t = 1.118 p > 0.264), Learning Motivation was found to enhance Digital Literacy 0.180, t = 3.126 p < 0.002) and Learning Engagement ($\beta$ = 0.521, 16.821, p < 0), effect on Future Learning Readiness was not significant ($\beta$ = 0.12, t = 1.87 p > 0.062) Self-Regulated Learning significantly influenced Digital Literacy ($\beta$ = 0.236, 12.917, p < 0.004), Future Learning Readiness ($\beta$ = 0.181, t = 2.189 p < 0.029), Learning Engagement ($\beta$ = 0.219, 12.584, p < 0.01). Technology Readiness showed a strong effect on Digital Literacy ($\beta$ = 0.569, t = 8.303 p < 0.000) and Future Learning Readiness ($\beta$ = 0.271, t = 2.762 p < 0.006) but had a minimal impact on Learning Engagement (0.062, 10.800, p > 0.424). These findings provide critical insights into the factors must be considered when designing educational interventions to enhance student engagement and preparedness for future education.</abs>

title: Edge Deployed Speech to Text Models for Real Time Classroom Feedback in Interactive Linguistics Pronunciation Labs
authors: V. R. Yasu Bharathi, Priyadharshini K, K.Siva Madasamy, K. Roshan Goldwin, A. Elangovan, M. Vinoth Kumar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Real-time feedback systems play an important role in promoting linguistic competence and especially the pronunciation in the dynamic learning environment of language. Here, the work will investigate the application of edge-based speech-to-text (STT) models to interactive linguistics pronunciation labs and offer instant, offline feedback with no cloud infrastructure requirement. Using recent developments in low-latency on-device neural models like Whisper.cpp, this framework applies speech recognition and pronunciation analysis on edge devices, which provides privacy in addition to real-time transcription and pronunciation analysis. The presented system combines acoustic modeling with feedback on a phoneme level and applies natural language processing (NLP) to evaluate prosody, tonal and articulation patterns. The edge deployment has been observed to respond faster compared to the cloud-based alternatives, minimize the cost of transmitting the data, and improve the autonomy of the learner. It makes the premise that edge STT solutions have become a radical solution to the latest language pedagogy in an area where bandwidth may be an issue or privacy a concern.

title: Smart Scheduling for Administrative Excellence: A Hybrid AI-Human Approach to Calendar Management
authors: Arisa Jirathachanon, Wanida Kanarkard
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: Executive calendar management in large academic institutions represents a mission-critical administrative function that imposes substantial cognitive load while exhibiting systemic inefficiencies and non-negligible error rates. This paper proposes a novel semi-automated scheduling framework leveraging state-of-the-art generative artificial intelligence to optimize this complex workflow. Grounded in human-centered design principles, our solution adopts a Human-in-the-Loop (HITL) architecture that strategically positions AI as a cognitive augmentation tool while preserving administrative professionals’ decision-making authority. The system design emerges from a comprehensive ethnographic study of current practices at Khon Kaen University, employing formal workflow analysis methodologies. Our mixed-methods evaluation protocol, theoretically anchored in the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM), incorporates a longitudinal four-week deployment study with ten participating executive secretaries. The paper makes three significant contributions to the field of intelligent administrative systems: a systematic identification and characterization of inefficiencies in traditional executive scheduling practices, An innovative HITL interaction paradigm for AI-assisted calendar management, an empirically-validated evaluation framework for assessing such systems in organizational contexts The implemented prototype demonstrates both practical efficacy and theoretical significance, offering a generalizable model for enhancing operational efficiency in complex institutional settings through human-AI collaboration.

title: AI-Assisted Fault Diagnosis in Rotating Machines using Acoustic Signals and Linear-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients
authors: Laraib Imtiaz, Shanzay Amjad, Yumna Aziz, Muhammad Faraz, Syed Zohaib Hassan Naqvi, Adil Usman
publish: 2025 International Conference on Engineering &amp; Computing Technologies (ICECT)
abstract: In rotating machines, accurate and efficient bearing fault detection is essential to ensure the safety, reliability, and maintenance of machinery in industries. Bearing faults in machines can have a catastrophic effect on system performance during operation, leading to significant risk to human life. Therefore, early fault prediction plays a vital role in averting accidents and unexpected failures, minimizing safety hazards and ensuring secure working environment. This study introduces a novel approach for detection of 4 types of machine faults (inner race, outer race, cage and ball) in addition to healthy condition. The process begins by segmenting the acoustic signals into total of 40 segments for each class. Next, we extracted Linear Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (LFCCs) from these segmented signals. To address class imbalance problem in real-world datasets, Adaptive Synthetic Sampling (ADASYN) was applied to generate synthetic samples for minority classes. Then, we classified the faults using these cepstral domain features as input to different classifiers. Among different classifiers, Fine KNN (FKNN) provided the highest accuracy of $99.5 \backslash \%$, demonstrating its effectiveness in identifying various bearing faults.

title: FOSSIL FUME OVERSIGHT: Tracking and Managing Harmful Emissions
authors: J. Loyola Jasmine, P. Khaleed Hussain, B. Anil Kumar, M. Brahma Reddy
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: The present work aims at the pressing need of controlling environmental pollution and protecting human health by offering an overall approach concerning emissions regulation and monitoring from fossil fuels. The procedure submitted to this work would take in real-time sampling from an open weather API designed to a local host server, making use of technology and prevention to allow for continuous monitoring of several pollutants such as carbon dioxide and sulfur dioxide. Easy-to-use interface allows for tracking at particular locations or by means of current location data; the data is used to calculate the air quality index (AQI). A corporate registration system also enables accountability. Automated alarm systems are delivered through email to registered businesses the minute their emissions breach a threshold level. Supplementation with some additional resources increases transparency, such as supplementary documents that contain relevant information regarding environmental issues, social media engagement, interactive mapping, and community participation in doing so, in the attempt of instilling responsible stewardship, building environmental consciousness, and initiating a future that will prove resilient and sustainable.

title: Explaining Student Inattention Detection from Visual Cues: A Comparative Machine Learning Study
authors: Salem Alemaishat, Bassam Kasasbeh
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: The accelerated adoption of online learning during the COVID-19 pandemic has expanded educational access and flexibility, yet it has also intensified difficulties in maintaining student attention. This study presents an AI-driven framework for detecting and explaining inattention in virtual classrooms by leveraging multimodal computer vision features, including face detection, pose estimation, hand tracking, and mobile phone detection. A dataset of 4,000 frame-level observations was used to evaluate three classification models-XGBoost, Random Forest, and Logistic Regression-across Accuracy, Precision, Recall, F1score, and ROC-AUC metrics. XGBoost achieved the highest accuracy (99.49%), followed closely by Random Forest (99.15%), while Logistic Regression provided a strong baseline (95.00%). Model interpretability was addressed using SHAP, permutation importance, and a consensus ranking, which consistently identified forward head orientation (pose_forward) and mobile phone presence as primary indicators of distraction, head rotation angles and phone detection. These findings support earlier studies examining the relationship between engagement (posture and device); by using a model that is both predictive of student engagement and provides transparency into how those predictions are made, the proposed method combines technical credibility with practical knowledge for educators to develop specific methods to keep their students engaged over time in an online environment.

title: Predictive Modeling of Typhoid Fever using Machine Learning
authors: Sobana M, Shalini R, Shrishahari J, Sivakarthika G
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Typhoid fever caused by Salmonella typhi is a major issue. It remains a global health issue, largely because its symptoms are not specific and current diagnostic methods have limitations. These shortcomings lead to frequent misdiagnosis and increase the risk of antimicrobial resistance. This study looks at how supervised by Logistic regression, extreme gradient boosting- XG boosting and random forest which are machine learning models these can create a fast, non-invasive diagnostic tool. This tool will use easily obtainable clinical and laboratory data from the Kaggle platform. Start from careful computational approach, splitting the data 80% for training and 20% for testing were applied. Thorough data preprocessing, feature engineering, and hyperparameter tuning while keeping a separate test set to provide realistic performance estimate are carried out. This shows the best balance of precision when identifying the disease and outperformed in Logistic Regression. This research highlights how Artificial Intelligence in Machine learning (ML) will be an affordable, quick triage tool which is key for improving decision-making in clinical areas, in high-burden areas with limited resources.

title: Digital Learning Module Integrating Local Wisdom and Inquiry-Based Approaches: Enhancing Critical Thinking and Cultural Awareness
authors: Tia Sarawati, Ismail Fikri Natadiwijaya
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: Science education often relies on conventional teaching materials that lack cultural relevance, which can reduce student engagement and critical thinking. A promising solution is the use of digital modules within an Inquiry-Based Learning (IBL) framework, integrated with local wisdom. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a science e-module incorporating the Mega Mendung batik-making tradition in enhancing students’ critical thinking and cultural awareness. The study employed a quasi-experimental design with a pretest-posttest control group, involving 61 eighth-grade students (30 in the experimental group and 31 in the control group) selected through random sampling. Data were collected using critical thinking and cultural awareness tests and analyzed using paired and independent sample t-tests, along with effect size calculations. The results showed a very large effect size for critical thinking (d=3.14) and cultural awareness (d=2.31) in the experimental group. These findings suggest that integrating local cultural heritage into digital science modules within an IBL framework significantly promotes both cognitive and affective development. This approach offers a contextualized and culturally responsive model for 21st-century science education, bridging scientific literacy with cultural identity.

title: A Design of an Efficient Data Analysis for Ear Disorders Detection Using PCA Q-Value Distribution and Shallow Neural Network
authors: G. Ramkumar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Electroencephalography (EEG) is a simple method of monitoring the brain's electrical activities by attaching electrodes on the scalp. So, we come up with the energy-efficient deep embedded medical diagnostic prediction system (EDEDPS) that, first of all, by combining brain wave data and images, is a device to identify the presence of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) and detect inner ear abnormalities. An information fusion technique, which was designed for low-power operation, incorporated brain signals of 17 subjects (8 were autistic) recorded through a simple four-channel system for alpha band filtering. The initial trial employed straightforward computations such as power spectral density and Hjorth, which resulted in about 64% energy saving. ASD was instrumental in categorizing ASD cases, and by using simple math, the performance was enhanced further. We got MRI scans of the inner ear through fixed angles and principal component analysis to build a model for comparing the shapes. The metrics of evaluation are comparing our model with the others, CLEWE, GCMEP, and MSGSE. We relied on the ROC curve of (1.0), CMRR of (10 Hz to 31.6 kHz), noise cancellation of (0.65 μVrms), variable gain of (80 dB near 316 Hz), comparative ROC curve of (1.0), and precision & recall of (1.0) to validate our findings.

title: DeepSeek Models in STEM Education: Capabilities, Applications, and Challenges
authors: Fnu Neha, Deepshikha Bhati
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: The application of artificial intelligence (AI) in STEM education has introduced new capabilities for enhancing structured reasoning, mathematical problem-solving, and programming instruction. General-purpose large language models (LLMs) lack domain-specific precision and pedagogical alignment. This paper explores the applications of DeepSeek models (DeepSeek R1, DeepSeek Math, and DeepSeek Coder) in addressing these limitations by integrating structured logic, stepwise reasoning, and contextualized programming guidance. DeepSeek models support learning by offering adaptive feedback, iterative guidance, and human-like reasoning. This study evaluates their capabilities in improving educational outcomes while addressing key challenges such as overreliance, algorithmic bias, and skill fragmentation. Additionally, it discusses policies for responsible AI integration and explores future directions, including AIdriven personalization, collaborative AI-human instruction, and interdisciplinary applications.

title: Expanding beyond STEM: coding as a crossdisciplinary tool for liberal arts
authors: Margherita Maria Sacco, Alberto Parola
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: The Coding for Liberal Arts research project explored the potential of coding as a cross-disciplinary educational tool, extending its application beyond STEM to liberal arts subjects. By integrating the principles of the scientific method, the project aimed to develop both digital and disciplinary skills in primary school students, fostering critical thinking, creativity, and interdisciplinary learning. Using a mixed-methods approach, it combined qualitative text mining and quantitative analysis, applying coding as both an educational tool and a research method. Preliminary results indicate that students effectively applied coding skills in liberal arts contexts, supporting its potential for enhancing interdisciplinary education.

title: Trade-off Between Global Accuracy and Fairness in Multi-Label Emotion Classification
authors: Yoppy Sazaki, Ahmad Fadhil Yusof, Chan Weng Howe, Ab Razak Che Hussin
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Technological Solutions (ICAITech)
abstract: The rapid expansion of social media platforms has made multi-label emotion classification an essential task for applications such as sentiment analysis, conversational agents, and mental health monitoring. However, the highly imbalanced distribution of emotions in datasets like GoEmotions creates a trade-off between global accuracy and fairness across classes. This paper investigates the comparative performance of Focal Loss and Asymmetric Loss (ASL) when applied to RoBERTaLarge. Theoretical formulations of Binary Cross-Entropy (BCE), Focal Loss, and ASL are presented to explain their optimization mechanisms under imbalance conditions. Empirical experiments on the GoEmotions dataset demonstrate that Focal Loss achieves superior Micro-F1 (0.602), reflecting higher global accuracy, while ASL attains superior Macro-F1 (0.502), emphasizing fairness across rare and minority emotions. These findings highlight that no single loss function is universally optimal, and the choice should align with application requirements global accuracy for large-scale sentiment tasks versus fairness for socially sensitive systems like mental health monitoring. The study further discusses implications for responsible AI and alignment with Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs 3 and 9), while suggesting future directions such as exploring ensemble methods and adaptive loss parameter tuning.

title: Evaluating Human-Curated and AI-Generated Affective Images in the Valence-Arousal Space Using a Multimodal AI Agent
authors: Leandros Stefanopoulos
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: This research introduces a framework for comparative evaluation of human-curated versus AI-generated affective images using a multimodal AI agent. The dataset (N=80 pictures) includes a selection of 40 human-curated images from the Open Affective Standardized Image Set (OASIS), and a set of 40 synthetic images generated specifically for this study. The synthetic dataset was created by prompting the “GPT Image 1” model, a specialized image generation model built on GPT-4o, with the goal to represent four target emotional states—Excitement, Frustration, Boredom, and Relaxation. A custom AI agent was deployed to rate all images along the valence and arousal dimensions of the affective circumplex model. Statistical analyses were performed to compare: (1) human vs agent image ratings for OASIS and (2) the agent’s ratings of the AI-generated image set and OASIS. The findings indicate that the AI agent reliably aligned with the human ratings and that GPT-4o can serve as both a generator and evaluator of affective content, thus supporting scalable, human-free validation pipelines. This approach contributes to the field of affective computing by enabling rapid generation and analysis of emotionevoking stimuli, with potential applications in experimental psychology and mental health.

title: Explainable Attention-Guided Framework for Interpretable Retinoblastoma Diagnosis
authors: D. Ramalakshmi, Hemavarshini G B, Jessica Heizal R, M. Maheswari
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Retinoblastoma is a pediatric eye cancer that is rare and life-threatening, but must be diagnosed correctly and at the correct time to save a child vision and increase survival rates. Older screening techniques are based on manual analysis of RetCam and fundus images which tend to be subjective and liable to variation between different observers. Current deep learning models are high-performing in terms of classification but are black-box models, which cannot be interpreted and identify lesions precisely. This paper addresses these shortcomings by introducing an Rb-AttnX which is based on EfficientNet- B4 feature extraction, Convolutional Block Attention Modules, and hybrid Grad-CAM++ visualizations. The structure uses the dual-task learning to classify and localize lesions simultaneously, which guarantees the accuracy of diagnosis and clinical interpretation. Rb-AttnX was found to perform better than its baseline models with 98.9% accuracy, 99.1% sensitivity, and 99.3% ROC-AUC on multi-source datasets. The system enables ophthalmologists to interpret model predictions and make sound decisions by giving them visual attention maps, which are consistent with expert annotations. This renders Rb-AttnX an applicable instrument in pediatric oncology in the real-world, to assist in the accurate, interpretable, and timely diagnosis of retinoblastoma.

title: Towards Trustworthy Multimodal Large Models in Professional Domains: A Unified Framework for Counterfactual Reasoning, Adaptive Fusion, and Decision Chain Analysis
authors: Ziyao Zhang, Weijie Jin, Juntong Tang, Yitong Ding, Huaiqian Li
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Multimodal large models have achieved significant progress in general domains, yet in high-risk applications across specialised fields such as healthcare, finance, and industry, they still face challenges including insufficient robustness to counterfactual scenarios, poor adaptability of static fusion strategies, and opaque decision-making processes. This paper proposes a unified framework that systematically examines model blind spots by constructing a counterfactual vision-language evaluation benchmark. It designs a dynamic, adaptively weighted fusion mechanism for input-level modal weight allocation and introduces a decision chain evaluation protocol to trace and quantify the logical consistency of specialised decisions.
