Experiments on medical imaging diagnosis and autonomous driving safety tasks demonstrate that this approach significantly enhances model robustness against out-of-distribution and adversarial samples, optimises multimodal fusion efficiency, and generates decision evidence comprehensible to human experts. This work provides systematic support for the evaluation, optimisation, and trustworthy certification of multimodal large models in professional domains.

title: Research on Structured Big Data Processing and Analysis Based on Improved GAN and EKF
authors: Zongfeng Yang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: In the era of big data, structured data has obvious shortcomings in data generation, noise processing, real-time performance, and other aspects. This article proposes an innovative data processing and analysis framework that integrates improved generative adversarial networks (GANs) and extended Kalman filters (EKFs) to address key challenges in structured big data processing. This study first systematically analyzed the characteristics and processing difficulties of structured data, and deeply explored the basic principles of GAN and EKF and their application status in data generation and state estimation. On this basis, an improved fusion model of Conditional Table Generative Adversarial Network (CTGAN) and Adaptive EKF is proposed, which significantly improves the performance of the model in terms of data generation quality, computational efficiency, and state estimation accuracy by introducing dynamic weight adjustment and parallel computing architecture. The experimental results show that the proposed method outperforms traditional methods on multiple real datasets, providing a new technological path for the processing and analysis of structured big data. This study not only provides innovative methodologies for big data processing, but also valuable references for practical applications in related fields.

title: A Provenance Solution for Ethical Generative AI and Fair Attribution
authors: Nilesh Joshi, Omkar R. Barve, Manisha Bharati
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Generative AI (GenAI) threatens to devalue human art by using data without credit or pay. We argue these ethical issues stem from a lack of provenance. We propose a technical “Attribution Framework” using cryptography and smart contracts to trace AI content to its sources, calculate influence, and automate micropayments. This enforced transparency is vital to make GenAI a collaborative, fair tool that supports creators.

title: Advanced Skin Lesion Segmentation for Melanoma Detection Using an Enhanced SegNet Architecture with Regularization Techniques
authors: Dasari Chaithanya, Suresh Kumar Mandala
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Skin cancer, especially melanoma, remains a major contributor to cancer-related mortality, highlighting the importance of precise segmentation for early detection and improved survival outcomes. This study introduces an advanced SegNet-based architecture tailored for skin lesion segmentation, aiming to overcome issues like image variability, noise interference, and overfitting. The model incorporates deeper convolutional layers, employs dropout regularization at varying rates, and adopts a comprehensive evaluation approach using metrics such as Intersection over Union (IoU) and Dice Coefficient to enhance segmentation performance and generalization. The model is tested on the PH2_resized dataset and outperforms traditional models like U-Net and ResNet50, with an IoU of 97.02% and an accuracy of 96.83%. The novelty of this approach lies in the combination of regularization techniques, advanced feature extraction, and comprehensive evaluation metrics, which enhance robustness and performance of the segmentation process. These results demonstrate that a reliable tool for accurate skin lesion segmentation is provided by the proposed model, offering significant potential for improving the efficiency of automated melanoma diagnosis and clinical workflows.

title: Improved Q-learning Algorithm based for Permutation Flow Shop Scheduling Problem
authors: Anran Zhao, Tongming Xu, Bozhao Li, Yang Lu, Huanhu Feng, Kun Jing
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Control and Computing Science (ICICCS)
abstract: As a typical scheduling type for mass customization production, permutation flow shop scheduling (PFS) has been widely applied in modern manufacturing. The superior performance of the PFS method is conducive to improving production efficiency. This study proposes a novel PFS method with makespan as the scheduling objective, which combined Q-learning with a priority dispatching rule (PDR) set. First, the study designs a makespan solution algorithm for PFS strategy. And then, a scheduling strategy solving framework based on Q-learning algorithm is designed. where an action selection method is proposed based on the greedy algorithm. Finally, a series of numerical experiments were conducted to demonstrate the performance of the proposed method, which shows a reduction of 6.49% in the average makespan than a PDR set.

title: Guassian Process-based Interacting Multiple Model Particle Filering for Nonlinear Stochastic System with Adaptive Transition Probability Matrix
authors: Xueqi Yuan, Qing Sun
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Control and Computing Science (ICICCS)
abstract: This paper addresses the state estimation problem for a class of nonlinear stochastic systems that switch among multiple models. The system under consideration has the following characteristics: the dynamic characteristics of each subsystem are unknown and the Markov transition probabilities are imprecise. To achieve precise and low-latency state estimation, the proposed algorithm trains on the pre-prepared offline dataset through Gaussian Process Regression (GPR), thereby obtaining the unknown sub-pattern dynamic model. And combine it with the interacting multiple model particle filtering (IMMPF) and the adaptive transition probability matrix (TPM) to quickly adjust the estimation structure during model switching. The GPR has implemented a fully data-driven framework, enabling it to predict different update patterns of the target. A correction function is added to adaptively adjust the TPM by using variations in model probabilities. It can enhance the probability convergence trend of the correct model to improve the overall accuracy of the estimation. Finally, the overall algorithm is implemented through simulation software and our proposed method is compared with traditional IMMPF. The IMMPF is divided into two cases. In one case, only a ground-truth dynamic system is used to update the statement but the TPM is inaccurate. In the other case, both an adaptive TPM and a ground-truth dynamic system are present. The results show that, even in the absence of a known system dynamic model and precise TPM, this method still achieves quite good estimation performance.

title: A dual-branch collaborative model for long sequence time series forecasting
authors: Zhili Song, Xvanhao Guo
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Time-series analysis has provided a popular solution to real-world problems such as early warning of extreme weather events and long-term energy consumption planning. Traditional time series analysis approaches, such as the Transformer model and its variants, rely on the self-attention mechanism to capture long-range dependency. However, as time series grow in length and complexity, these models often suffer from decreased learning efficiency, trend prediction delays, and the failure to capture trend mutations and local features. To address these challenges, this study constructs a dual-branch forecasting network model, termed DBTF, to extract high-frequency details and abrupt local trend changes that traditional models often overlook. The model also provides stable compensation in scenarios with blurred data boundaries or pronounced noise to alleviate forecast biases. Experiments performed on several datasets that cover domains like energy, transport, and weather forecasting have confirmed the superior performance of our new model in long-sequence time series forecasting over other methods.

title: Hybrid Dual-Signature Scheme using Falcon and SPHINCS+: A Theoretical Study with Preliminary Results
authors: Madhav Mishra, D Saravanan
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: The development of quantum computers becomes a threat to current cryptosystems including RSA and ECDSA, and hence to blockchain and IoT security. This work introduces a Hybrid Dual-Signature Scheme (HDSS) blending Falcon and Sphincs+ signatures with higher quantum resistance against quantum adversaries. We present the theoretical construction of HDSS and provide preliminary experimental indications using small-scale datasets. Full benchmarking, system quantification, and deployment in blockchain/IoT are left as future work.

title: A Prediction Method for Scientific Creativity Based on Writing Behavior Sequence Pattern Analysis*
authors: Baoying Xu, Xuan Yang, Yiqi Liu, Zehui Zhan
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: Scientific creativity is a core competence in cultivating innovative talents, yet its process-based assessment still faces methodological challenges. Existing studies suggest that writing behavior, as a form of information expression and cognitive practice, may partially reflect an individual’s creative thinking traits. This study employed the iBCM framework to model learners’ writing processes, extract sequence-based features, and construct regression models to explore the intrinsic relationship between writing behavior patterns and scientific creativity. The results indicate that iBCM effectively identifies behavioral sequence features that can be used to predict scientific creativity levels. Among the tested models, the stacking model achieved the best predictive performance (MAE =2.84, R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>= 0.735), using ridge regression, XGBoost, and GradientBoosting as base learners and Lasso regression as the meta-learner. Further analysis ranked the importance of writing behavior features and aggregated them by their corresponding scientific creativity dimensions, revealing that the “Elaboration” dimension contributed the most. This study demonstrates the potential of writing behaviors in the assessment of scientific creativity and offers a novel methodological approach for process-oriented evaluation.

title: An Intrusion Detection Algorithm Based on Deep Learning and Extreme Learning Machine for Intelligent Connected Vehicles
authors: Haibo Mao, Yongzhong Li
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: With the rapid development of the Internet of Vehicles and artificial intelligence, intelligent connected vehicles are facing increasingly severe network security challenges. Intelligent connected vehicles have posed significant challenges to existing cybersecurity technologies. Consequently, intrusion detection has emerged as a vital research avenue within the cybersecurity domain. Aiming at the problem that the existing unknown Intelligent connected vehicles network attack detection method is an initial stage and the low-layer selection feature classification leads to low detection accuracy, This paper proposes a novel method that integrates a deep learning autoencoder with an extreme learning machine for enhanced intrusion detection. During training, the autoencoder combines coefficient regularization and reconstruction loss to effectively extract features from high-dimensional data. Subsequently, the extreme learning machine efficiently classifies these extracted features. The algorithm’s performance is validated using a standard industrial control intrusion detection dataset, demonstrating improved detection accuracy and a reduced false alarm rate.

title: RapidGrade: OCR and NLP-based Automated Assessment System
authors: Aniket Mahesh Vyavhare, Vedant Bhagwat Ahire, Mansi SureshSingh Chauhan, Khasim Ilahi Patel, Riddhi R. Mirajkar, Jayashree V. Bagade
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: It is crucial to move towards automated evalution from descriptive answer sheets' manual evaluation to improve transparency, fairness, and efficiency in education. The research here propose an automated evaluation framework namely RapidGrade, RapidGrade combined Optical Character Recognition(OCR) and Natural Language Processing(NLP) to automatically grade handwritten answer sheets. The students answer sheets are transformed to digitized and machine readable text by using deep learning OCR and answers are extracted and matched with given model rubric through model answer sheets and answer rubric controlled answer sheets semantic similarity scoring answer sheets through answer rubric controlled answer scoring through semantic similarity scoring model answer sheets and answer rubric controlled answer sheets semantic similarity scoring extracted rubric controlled semantic similarity scoring. By a cross-portal configuration, grading and analytics are monitored by instructors and students are provided with feedback regarding their answers along with personalized instructions and history of performance. Pilot project scale out tested with large scale handwriting dataset using the system showed evaluation consistency, reduction of time for evaluation, and system compliances. Hence education assessment is made unbiased by the framework, feedback based, and centred around learners.

title: OWT-DNet: A Timely and High-Accuracy End-to-End Offshore Wind Turbine Detection Network Based on Multimodal Remote Sensing Data
authors: Shuai Zhang, Fangxiong Wang, Wubiao Huang, Fei Deng
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: With the rapid development of the offshore wind power industry in recent years, its effects on local social, economic and ecological environments have attracted widespread attention. Therefore, a timely understanding of the development status of offshore wind power, specifically, offshore wind turbines (OWTs) is crucial for the healthy and sustainable development of the offshore wind power industry. However, existing OWT detection methods often struggle to achieve timely, high-precision end-to-end detection of OWTs. To address this, in this study, an OWT detection network (OWT-DNet) based on multimodal remote sensing data is proposed. This network integrates Sentinel-1 synthetic aperture radar (SAR) imagery and Sentinel-2 optical imagery, effectively addressing the insufficient semantic information inherent in single-modal data for OWT detection. Experiments across five global test regions demonstrate that OWT-DNet achieves detection accuracy, recall, and comprehensive evaluation metrics that exceed 99.9%. Furthermore, OWT-DNet demonstrates outstanding detection performance under complex weather conditions. Comparative and ablation experiments validate the network's superior capability in OWT detection tasks. Overall, timely, high-precision end-to-end OWT detection is achieved for the first time on the basis of multimodal remote sensing data. Furthermore, an inaugural multimodal OWT sample dataset is established, laying a solid foundation for future OWT detection research.

title: Styx: An Efficient Workflow Engine for Serverless Platforms
authors: Abhisek Panda, Smruti R. Sarangi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Parallel and Distributed Systems
abstract: Serverless platforms are widely adopted for deploying applications due to their autoscaling capabilities and pay-asyou- go billing models. These platforms execute an application's functions inside ephemeral containers and scale the number of containers based on incoming request rates. To meet service level objectives (SLOs), they often over-provision resources by maintaining warm containers or rapidly spawning new ones during traffic bursts. However, this strategy frequently leads to inefficient resource utilization, especially during periods of low activity. Prior research addresses this issue through intelligent scheduling, lightweight virtualization, and containersharing mechanisms. More recent work aims to improve resource utilization by remodeling the execution of a function within a container to better separate compute and I/O stages. Despite these improvements, existing approaches often introduce delays during execution and induce memory pressure under traffic bursts. In this paper, we present Styx, a novel workflow engine that enhances resource utilization by intelligently decoupling compute and I/O stages. Styx employs a fetch latency predictor that uses real-time system metrics from both the serverless node and the remote storage server to accurately estimate prefetch operations, ensuring input data is available exactly when needed. Furthermore, it offloads the output data upload operation from a container to a host-side data service, thereby efficiently managing provisioned memory. Our approach improves the overall memory allocation by 32.6% when running all the serverless workflows simultaneously when compared to Dataflower + Truffle. Additionally, this method improves the tail latency and the mean latency of a workflow by an average of 26.3% and 21%, respectively.

title: A Generalized Framework for Medium-Frequency Transformer Insulation Design: Case Study on Air Insulation
authors: Bastian Korthauer, Jürgen Biela
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: A key challenge in designing medium-frequency transformers (MFTs) is determining adequate insulation distances, especially as the insulation occupies a substantial fraction of the overall transformer volume. To ensure both efficient thermal management and high gravimetric and volumetric power density, these distances must be carefully optimized to be just sufficient for reliable operation. This paper presents a generalized framework to obtain such distances, suitable for integration into transformer design optimization routines. The framework employs a two-step procedure to compute universal design curves, enabling straightforward selection of the required insulation distance for a given design voltage. Using a foil-wound, air-insulated MFT as a case study and a physics-based model for discharge inception in air, a prototype is designed with a discharge level well below 10 pC at a design voltage of 8.5 kV. Compared to conventional design methods, the proposed approach permits up to six times higher design voltage while maintaining a safety margin exceeding 100% relative to the maximum one-minute withstand voltage.

title: Air Quality Prediction Using Deep Learning Models
authors: Kshirsagar Sopan Bapu, Rais Abdul Hamid Khan
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: The investigation looks at how deep learning models can be used to guess what the air quality will be like. PM2.5, PM10, NOx, SO2, and CO are the five key things that affect air quality control. If we want to keep people healthy and informed, as well as make progress in controlling air pollution, especially in cities, we need to be able to correctly predict the air quality. Traditional machine learning methods can't correctly guess the quality of the air because they can't deal with the complex nonlinearities in environmental data. Different types of deep learning, such as CNNs, RNNs, and LSTMs (Long Short Term Memory networks), can help solve these issues. To make models for predicting air quality, this study looked at past data on air quality, weather, and place. There were factors for both shortterm and long-term air quality in these models. We also used a mix of well-known machine learning models, like CNN-LSTM, to include connections between places and times. Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) helped us add more data because we were having trouble because we didn't have enough of it. Mean Absolute Error (MAE) and Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) were used to check how well the models worked. The Bidirectional Stacked LSTM model worked the best out of all of them. Really good at guessing what the air quality will be like, and it can be used to guess the air quality almost in real time. We thought that models could be better if they had more factors, were kept up to date, and were easier for people making decisions to understand. Some of us think that our research shows that deep learning is a good way to help keep the air clean.

title: Smart Contract Security - A Comprehensive Evaluation of Deep Learning based Mechanisms for Smart Contract Vulnerability Detection
authors: Deepa Mishra, Shraddha Phansalkar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: Widespread adoption of Blockchain Technology has emphasized smart contracts as vital units of digital transactions. In the brief history of smart contracts, significant losses have occurred owing to unexplained vulnerabilities in blockchain-loaded contracts. Smart contract vulnerabilities endanger blockchain technology's viability and confidence. Blockchain-based applications rely on smart contracts to automate and trustlessly execute agreements. Their immutable and self-executing nature leaves them vulnerable to security vulnerabilities, which have caused major financial losses in decentralized platforms. Traditional static and symbolic analysis tools often miss sophisticated or obfuscated vulnerabilities, resulting in insufficient coverage or excessive false positives. These restrictions led the investigation of Deep Learning (DL) algorithms for detecting vulnerabilities in smart contract crucial since they can learn complicated patterns from code representations without manual feature engineering. Deep learning based methods for detecting vulnerabilities in smart contracts are thoroughly evaluated. We rigorously assess state-of-the-art DL models including BiLSTM, BiGRU, CNNLSTM, GCN, and CodeBERT using publicly available dataset. We provide a taxonomy of DL-based detection techniques and standardize performance criteria including accuracy, F1-score, and detection latency. Experimental results show model architecture trade-offs in detection, computational efficiency, and generalization.

title: Automated Detection of Rheumatoid Arthritis in X-Ray Images: An Enhanced and Optimized Deep Learning Framework
authors: Palakala Poojitha, P. Praveen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Rheumatoid arthritis is a progressive autoimmune disease where by the time it is radiographically diagnosed, irreversible bone erosion and joint deformity has often occurred. To overcome the shortcomings of X-ray detection by a human radiologist, we therefore developed a more sophisticated deep learning approach to automatically identify features of rheumatoid arthritis in hand radiographs. Preprocessing consisted of standardizing all 480 images to 512512 pixels, and contrast enhancement, from a total of 4812 images from 1130 patients. A residual network with a channel-spatial attention mechanism was trained with 3300 images, validated with 812 images, and tested with 700 images. The model achieved a sensitivity of 93.41%, specificity of 92.08% and accuracy of 93.02% outperforming a baseline residual network by 5.17%. These results provide a dependable radiographic inference to guide the initial clinical decision.

title: MVHR-OEL: Multi-View 3D Human Reconstruction with Online Evolutive Learning
authors: Ruiyang Jing, JiaXuan Liu, Wen Wang, Filip Paluncic, Liang Song
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: In the field of computer vision, accurate estimation of 3D human poses and shapes plays a vital role in applications such as motion analysis, virtual try-on, and human-computer interaction. While most existing methods rely on monocular RGB images and deep learning regression networks, they often suffer from ambiguities caused by occlusions, self-similasrity, and missing visual cues. Leveraging publicly available multi-view image datasets offers an effective way to mitigate these limitations and improve reconstruction accuracy.In this work, we propose a novel framework for 3D human reconstruction that jointly lever-ages multi-view consistency and iterative refinement of SMPL parameters. Specifically, our method takes images from multiple viewpoints as input, extracts SMPL pose and shape parameters from each view using a CNN-based regressor, and integrates them through a multi-view parameter fusion strategy. To further refine the fused parameters, we introduce an Online Evolutive Learning(OEL) mechanism, which applies a SMPLify-inspired optimization process to iteratively minimize a reprojection-based evaluation loss without requiring ground-truth 3D annotations. This iterative optimization loop progressively enhances structural plausibility and alignment consistency across views. The im-proved parameters are then used to optimize the CNN regressor in an online evolutive manner, forming a feedback loop that continuously improves the model generalization ability.

title: LSTM-Enhanced MAPPO: Synchronous Learning of Policy and Value Functions in MAPPO via LSTM Networks
authors: Li Zhang, Lunbo Li, Yu Zhang, Shuyan Ding
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: In the field of deep learning, Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) is a recurrent neural network architecture specialized in processing sequential data, and its core advantage lies in its ability to effectively capture long-term dependencies in data. Meanwhile, Reinforcement Learning (RL), as an important branch of machine learning, learns optimal decision making strategies through continuous interaction between an intelligent and its environment to maximize long-term returns. Integrating LSTM into a reinforcement learning framework not only enhances the performance of intelligences in complex sequential decision-making tasks, but also significantly improves their decision-making ability in scenarios requiring long-term memory and strategic planning. In this study, based on the MAPPO algorithm, we use LSTM networks to simultaneously learn both strategy and value functions, which not only helps intelligences make more rational decisions, but also can more accurately assess the expected value of future rewards, thus guiding the learning of intelligences. We train and test in a multi-intelligent body environment MPE (multi-agent particle environment), and the final experimental results show that compared with the MAPPO algorithm, the LSTM-MAPPO algorithm improves on the final reward.

title: Forecasting-Aided Safe Reinforcement Learning for Hybrid Solar-Grid EV Charging with Dual-Battery Optimization
authors: Revathi G, Arun SV, Athithya KC, Dharaneesh A
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: The growing popularity of electric vehicles (EVs) has Created a demand for smart and efficient charging systems that can use renewable energy. This paper presents a Forecasting-Aided Reinforcement Learning (FA-RL) hybrid charging framework managing the flow of energy between solar photovoltaic (PV) panels and the grid. The system includes dual battery storage, a solar battery stores excess PV energy, while a grid The battery holds grid energy. This arrangement provides real-time flexibility in power distribution. A Safe Soft Actor-Critic (SAC) Algorithm works together with the Long Short-Term Memory. Forecasting models that can project solar irradiance, grid prices, and electric vehicle charging demands. These forecasts help the RL agent select the most energy-efficient and cost-effective source while maintaining safe operation. A multi-objective reward function aims to reduce charging costs, boost the use of renewable energy, and minimize battery wear through aging-aware optimization. Simulation results using actual solar and pricing data indicate that the proposed system achieves up to 30% greater energy efficiency and 25% longer battery life compared to traditional rule-based and standard RL-based charging systems. This intelligent and adaptable framework provides a sustainable solution for future smart EV charging infrastructures.

title: A Visual Cognition Training System for Children with Autism Based on Gaze Estimation Model
authors: Lu Liu, Jialiang Zhu, Boyao Chen, Shunfeng Chen, Liangxianzhen Cao, Man Zhang, Xiaofeng Lu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: To address the limitations of current rehabilitation training for children with autism, such as constrained application scenarios and insufficient specialized medical resources, this study proposes a visual cognitive training system for children with autism, enabling rehabilitation training without temporal or spatial restrictions. Centering on the four core functional requirements of cognitive rehabilitation for autistic children, the system is designed with eight training programs categorized into four modules: computational ability training, focused ability training, recognition ability training, and memory ability training. The system adopts a gaze estimation model based on Vision Transformer (ViT) and Context Broadcasting. By introducing a context broadcasting mechanism to enhance the global correlation of features, and integrating a mixed-scale guidance module to optimize the extraction accuracy of local eye features, the system effectively improves gaze localization precision in complex training scenarios, providing objective data support for training effect evaluation.The game-based training process enhances children’s initiative in communication. After each training session, an automatic training report is generated to support historical data review; based on actual training progress, pie charts and line graphs are generated to track rehabilitation trends, facilitating clinicians’ analysis and interpretation. This system represents an AI-driven exploration of innovative rehabilitation approaches for autism. It not only meets the usability requirements of both hospital-based and home-based rehabilitation but also eliminates the need for continuous involvement of specialized clinicians, effectively alleviating the shortage of psychiatric medical resources. It serves as a novel AI-based exploration of autism rehabilitation strategies, providing a practical solution to the limitations of traditional rehabilitation models.

title: Deep Learning and Blockchain-Based Multi-Crop Classification Framework for Food Quality Assessment
authors: Femimol R, Nalini Joseph L
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: Quality and traceability of fresh crops in the contemporary agri-food supply chains is an important issue. This study offers the use of deep learning in multi-crop classification and prediction of condition through the integration of blockchain technology to ensure that the monitor of food quality is safe and transparent. The system is able to seamlessly take in image data through the three different datasets and employs the same feature extraction modality Oriented FAST alone Rotated BRIEF (ORB) to come up with highly robust visual descriptors conducted and run using less than 15ms of an image with keypoints identified. A deep learning classifier EfficientNet with Multi-Task Learning Head has been used to detect crop type and its state (fresh, partially spoiled or spoiled) concurrently at the rate of 96.2% overall classification accuracy. The outcomes of all classifications, timestamps and sensor metadata are recorded safely on a dedicated block chain ledger, with verification of log less latency on a private network. Through this hybrid system, real time decisions can be made, and it heightens trust within the supply chain.

title: Design and Development of a Gamified Web Platform to Enhance Design-Based Digital Maker Skills in Thai FabLabs
authors: Monamorn Precharattana, Tinnapob Phengpom, Pongpatai Kitrungloadjanaporn, Soonthareeya Sanium, Nantawachara Jirakittayakorn
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: The Fourth Industrial Revolution has redefined essential competencies for future-ready learners, emphasizing digital literacy, computational thinking, and interdisciplinary problem-solving. In response, Thailand has integrated coding into its national curriculum and established over 150 FabLabs to foster student innovation. However, challenges such as limited engagement, instructional tools, and collaboration persist. This study presents the design and development of a gamified web application to enhance secondary students’ Design-Based Digital Maker Skills. Developed using the ADDIE model, the platform comprises five learning modules—Design Thinking, Digital Fabrication, Computational Thinking, 21st Century Learning, and FabLab Management—and features video content, gamified elements, and a self-assessment tool. Expert validation ensured content accuracy and pedagogical quality. Effectiveness was evaluated through pre- and post-tests within Thailand’s FabLab network, demonstrating the platform’s potential to deliver scalable, engaging, and skill-based learning experiences.

title: Speed enhancement in EMC design optimization using MultiFidelity modeling
authors: Bibhu Prasad Nayak, Joydeep Pal, Sayantan Dhar, Kaushik Patra, Anand Upadhyay
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Electromagnetic Interference and Compatibility (INCEMIC)
abstract: Electromagnetic compatibility (EMC) simulation is essential for optimizing products to meet EMC testing requirements. However, for complex products such as electronic control units (ECUs), simulation times can extend from several hours to days, diminishing the advantages of simulation. A significant bottleneck arises from dielectric formulation when using the Method of Moments (MoM) for electromagnetic solvers. This study addresses the challenge of lengthy simulation times by employing multi-fidelity modeling. We propose a low-fidelity model that conducts simulations without dielectric materials to generate data sets, while a high-fidelity model incorporates dielectric effects. This dual approach enables a substantial reduction in simulation time, achieving speed improvements of 5 to 10 times, thereby enhancing the efficiency of the EMC simulation process. We demonstrate the effectiveness of this approach through a patch antenna simulation, showcasing its practical application and benefits in real-world scenarios.

title: Pruned but Accurate: Lightweight AlexNet for On-Device Skin Lesion Diagnosis
authors: Yasser A. Amer, Hassan I. Saleh, Omar A. Nasr
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Telecommunications and Artificial Intelligence (IC-FTAI)
abstract: Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) hold great promise for accurate and timely medical diagnostics; however, their computational complexity limits deployment on resourceconstrained edge devices. To enable efficient on-device inference, we present a magnitude-based pruning strategy for AlexNet, applied to melanoma classification using the PAD-UFES-20 dataset. We conduct a detailed layer-wise analysis to evaluate the trade-offs between pruning levels, accuracy, and resource efficiency. Our results indicate that pruning fully connected layers significantly reduces memory usage, while pruning convolutional layers improves inference speed. The optimized model achieves 91 % pruning, with accuracy decreasing marginally from 99.16 % to 97.48 %. These findings demonstrate the feasibility of deploying compressed DNNs for real-time, edge-based medical diagnostics without compromising diagnostic precision.

title: Sparse Bayesian Learning for Decentralized 2D Smoke Source Localization
authors: Dmitriy Shutin, Victor Scott Prieto Ruiz, Patrick Hinsen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: The increasing frequency and severity of forest fires, driven by climate change and human activity, necessitate accurate and efficient modeling of such events. This paper proposes a method leveraging prior knowledge in the form of a stationary, inhomogeneous advection-diffusion Partial Differential Equation (PDE), combined with decentralized, over-thenetwork sparse Bayesian learning (SBL), to enable a multiagent system to localize smoke sources and reconstruct spatial smoke concentration based on collected smoke concentration samples. The approach employs Green’s functions for solving the PDE and nonlinear optimization for grid-less estimation of sources based on cooperatively acquired data. A novel iterative initialization strategy is introduced to enhance convergence and promote sparsity in source localization. Simulations validate the method’s effectiveness.

title: A Blockchain Based Counterfeit Product Identification System
authors: Shreyas S, Asmita Poojari
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: One of the main problems facing players in the present retail business is product counterfeiting. Products that are Counterfeit products are low-quality copies of authentic goods. Currently, because counterfeit goods can fit in with the market, it is difficult to tell them apart. Some unaffiliated parties attempt to take advantage of a legitimate business by creating inferior replicas in order to increase their revenue. The market is impacted by counterfeiting, as are the company's reputation, revenue, and earnings. To stop and deal with product counterfeiting, a variety of techniques have been used, including machine learning, artificial intelligence, RFID (Radio-Frequency Identification) tags, QR code-based approaches, etc. However, each of them has drawbacks of its own. For example, QR codes can be used to convert authentic products into counterfeit ones, and artificial intelligence and machine learning require a significant amount of processing power to operate. There isn't a workable solution for this problem as of now. We are experimenting with a method in this project by using Blockchain technology. Blockchain technology notifies the user about the product's legitimacy and can be used to distinguish between real and phony goods. With the use of QR codes, we intend to retain product supply chain data at every level of a product's transaction with a new party. With its many benefits, including its decentralized nature and lack of a single point of failure, blockchain technology is a useful tool for preventing counterfeiting. Blocks of immutable information are used to store it. Ethereum was chosen because it allows smart contracts, which are required for automated product verification. Furthermore, it is widely used, and it is accompanied by powerful developer tools such as Hardhat, MetaMask, and Ethers.js, which facilitate development and integration. Furthermore, Ethereum ensures immutability, decentralization, and transparency, all of which are crucial in counterfeit detection.

title: FPGA-Optimized VHDL Implementation of an ITU-T G. 707 STM-1 Multiplexer/Demultiplexer With Comparative Performance Analysis
authors: Alaa Elshafey, Hatem Zakaria, Abdelhady Mhmoud
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Telecommunications and Artificial Intelligence (IC-FTAI)
abstract: The growing demand for high-capacity and reliable backbone networks has reinforced the importance of Synchronous Digital Hierarchy (SDH) as a standardized and robust transport technology. While STM-1 framer/deframer designs have been studied, most implementations either focus on partial subsystems or lack benchmarking against FPGA platforms and ITU-T standards. This paper presents a complete VHDL-based implementation of an STM-1 multiplexer and demultiplexer fully compliant with ITU-T G.707. The design introduces a hierarchical coding methodology to improve portability across FPGA/ASIC platforms and integrates faultresilient synchronization to enhance reliability. Functional verification is performed using a pseudo-random binary sequence (PRBS) testbench, enabling end-to-end bit error monitoring across regenerator, multiplex, and path layers. The architecture was synthesized on an Xilinx Artix-7 FPGA, achieving the ITU-T line rate of 155.52 Mbps while utilizing only 25.03% LUTs and 16.48% FFs. Comparative benchmarking against state-of-the-art designs demonstrates superior logic efficiency, competitive throughput, and robust error detection. Although FPGA-based power estimation was higher than ASIC counterparts, this is attributed to prototyping artifacts and can be mitigated through low-power design techniques in future hardware migrations.

title: Integrating Deep Learning and Predictive Modeling for Smart Agriculture: Disease Detection and Yield Estimation
authors: K. Vignesh, B. Baranitharan, K. Ram Charan, D.Sammerah D. Sammerah, U. Sravanthi, L. V. Nishanth
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Crop diseases and erratic weather patterns pose serious problems for modern agriculture, lowering yield and compromising food security. In order to improve precision farming, this paper proposes a clever web-based system that combines deep learning and machine learning. In order to predict the best crop types and yields, hybrid crop prediction uses Decision Tree and Random Forest Classifiers, which use soil and environmental parameters. While a Label Encoder guarantees efficient preprocessing of categorical data, a Convolutional Neural Network is utilized for disease detection through leaf image analysis. The suggested system helps farmers make timely decisions, lowers crop losses, and promotes sustainable, data-driven agricultural practices by giving them real-time insights into plant health and productivity.

title: Advancing Pediatric Speech Disorder Treatments using LLM
authors: Srishti Vashishtha, Deepika Varshney, Kirti Sharma, Vedika Gupta, Manya Gupta
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: Children with specific language impairment (SLI) experience persistent communication challenges that affect their development. Early detection is vital for effective intervention. This study applies large language model (LLM) architectures to automatically classify speech from children with and without SLI using the Speech Database of Typical and SLI Children (1,574 samples). Audio features were extracted via Hugging Face’s AutoFeatureExtractor with Whisper and Wav2Vec2 as backbone models, then fine-tuned using AutoModelForAudioClassification. was conducted using accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score, which showed that Whisper achieved perfect classification (1.0 across all metrics), outperforming Wav2Vec2 (accuracy = 0.9556). The findings highlight Whisper’s strong capability to capture fine-grained acoustic and linguistic patterns associated with SLI, demonstrating its potential for early screening and clinical deployment.

title: Security-Oriented Design for IRS-Assisted MISO Systems Based on ISCSO-MRT Joint Optimization
authors: Chuanzhen Zhang, Hongyuan Gao
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: Based on the secure communication problem in Intelligent Reflecting Surface (IRS)-assisted Multiple-Input Single-Output (MISO) systems, this paper proposes a joint optimization scheme for beamforming vectors and RIS phase-shift matrices. First, the beamforming vector at the base station is designed based on the Maximum Ratio Transmission (MRT) precoding scheme. Subsequently, the reflection coefficient matrix of the RIS is optimized using an Improved Sand Cat Swarm Optimization (ISCSO) algorithm to maximize the system’s secrecy rate. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm outperforms both the standard Sand Cat Swarm Optimization (SCSO) and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) algorithms in terms of achievable secrecy rate and convergence efficiency.

title: Comparative Evaluation of RegNet Architectures for Multi-Task Skin Cancer Detection
authors: Alfiya Banu Mohammed Arif, Ashmitha D Kotian, Apoorva Bhatt B R, Gagan Sherigar, Soumya J Bhat
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Skin Cancer can be very dangerous type of disease that can become life-threatening if ignored. When skin cancer is not found early, it can quickly spread to different areas of the body. Because of this Detecting skin cancer early is important because it helps prevent serious complications and saves lives. In this work, we created a deep-learning based system that identifies skin lesions and determines whether they are cancerous or non-cancerous. To check if a skin lesion is cancerous or non-cancerous, we utilized the HAM10000 dataset. We use the RegNetY-400MF and RegNetY-8GF deep learning models in conjunction with multi-task learning to achieve this. Following testing, the accuracy of RegNetY-400MF was 82.20%, while that of RegNetY-8GF was 81.77%. This method helps sort skin lesions correctly and lets people spot problems early so they can visit a doctor on time.

title: Computer Vision-Powered Hand Gesture Interface for STEM Applications
authors: Prathamesh. S. Rampogu, Priyanka. B. Sabale, Raviteja. S. Peddnity
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Gesture recognition has progressed from basic vision techniques to advanced multimodal AI systems, enabling real-time use in education, accessibility, and industry. The paper covers four areas: classic and modern pipelines; AI tools for users with impairments; gesture-based math learning and HCI; and AR/MR remote collaboration. Lightweight models paired with strong inference achieve good accuracy and speed for practical use. Applications include reducing cognitive load in learning, enabling hands-free control, and improving industrial training and remote assistance. Challenges remain in handling occlusion, cultural differences, multi-user scenarios, privacy, and real-world benchmarking. A proposed deployment blueprint uses on-device tracking, adaptive personalization, privacy-focused analytics, and AR overlays, with future work focusing on standard datasets, inclusive design, and adding haptics with multimodal AI.

title: Real-Time Vehicle Trajectory and State Prediction using Advanced Recurrent Networks in a SUMO Simulated Environment
authors: Marni Jacinth Raj, E. BijolinEdwin, M.Roshni Thanka
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: The real-time accurate prediction of the vehicle state and trajectory for autonomous vehicles and Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS) has been addressed in this study. The work extensively compares three Recurrent Neural Network (RNN) variants: the initial Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), the state-of-the-art Bidirectional LSTM (BiLSTM), and the resourceeffective Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU). Such time-series mobility data of very high quality have been obtained from Levin/OBD sensor and NGSIM trajectory datasets for the training in algorithms. The dataset, using RobustScaler with a look-back window of 20 time steps, is pre-processed to make it robust against outliers. The performance is evaluated based on manoeuvre class quality (F1 Score) categorically and prediction error (MAE) continuously. The top-performing model is implemented in a custom SUMO simulation, where an ego_car moves within dynamic traffic close to a signalized intersection, showing direct relevance for predictive control within real-world settings.

title: Implementation and Analysis of a 3MW Grid-linked PV System
authors: Kayyam Saikumar, Prem Kumar, T Thamizhselvan
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Environment Friendly Energies and Applications (EFEA)
abstract: This paper presents the modeling and performance evaluation of a 3 MW grid-connected photovoltaic (PV) system designed and simulated in MATLAB/Simulink. The system employs a two-stage conversion process consisting of a DC–DC boost converter controlled by a Perturb and Observe (P&O) MPPT algorithm and a DC–AC voltage source inverter (VSI) regulated through a dq0-based vector control scheme. The control architecture ensures dynamic stability, unity power factor, and low harmonic distortion while maintaining synchronization with a 400 V, 50 Hz grid. Simulation results demonstrate that the system delivers a rated power of 3.036 MW under standard irradiance and 1.54 MW under partial irradiance, with the MPPT achieving 99.6% tracking efficiency in both conditions. The total harmonic distortion (THD) of grid current remains below 1%, confirming compliance with IEEE 519 standards. The proposed configuration offers a reliable and efficient approach for large-scale PV integration with robust operation under variable solar conditions.

title: Multi-Cloud Federated Learning Architecture with Homomorphic Encryption and Differential Privacy for Secure Cyber-Attack Detection
authors: D. Raghunath Kumar Babu, Sharabu Rakesh, Boya Narasimhulu, Chenna Madan Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: The continuous growth of extensive network infrastructures and cloud computing platforms has resulted in a quick rise in both the number and complexity of cyber-attacks. With data that comes from many sources increasing at an exponential rate, conventional centralized Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) run into difficulties surrounding communication latency, privacy leakage, and scalability issues inherent in big data. This work presents a Multi-Cloud Federated Learning Architecture with Homomorphic Encryption (HE) and Differential Privacy (DP) for secure and adaptive cyber-attack detection. In the proposed architecture, each cloud node performs local training independently using the Improved Recursive Feature Elimination (IRFE) technique for effective feature selection and an ensemble Deep Belief Network-Recurrent Neural Network (DBN-RNN) for effective intrusion classification. Encrypted model parameters are simply accumulated at a global server using an adaptive synchronization strategy which minimizes communication delay while status of convergence is preserved. The experiments on three benchmark datasets, namely_CSE-CIC-IDS2018, UNSW-NB15, and TON IoT, validated that the proposed framework has 98.2% accuracy, 0.985 F1-score, and 93% decreased privacy leakage when compared to the conventional centralized deep learning-based IDSs. The incorporation of HE and DP improves the confidentiality of shared model parameters, while ensuring strong robustness against adversarial inference. Therefore, this framework presents a scalable, high secure, privacy ticketed, and high-performance model for the detection of cyber-attacks in multi-cloud environments.

title: Research on Standing Balance Ability of Human Under an Impulse Based on Multistage Inverted Pendulum
authors: Xue Gong, Zhongqu Xie, Liangli Wang
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotic Systems and Applications (ICRSA)
abstract: When subjected to an external impact, humans utilize joints such as the ankle and hip to restore balance. This paper investigates the roles of individual joints in resisting impacts and the overall anti-disturbance capability of the human body through multiple balancing strategies. We first describe the PD controllers. Subsequently, various simplified multistage inverted pendulum models are established, and corresponding balancing strategy controllers are designed. Genetic Algorithm (GA) is utilized to optimize the controller parameters. Simulation results demonstrate that: (1) The balance ability would be stronger with more joint involved; (2) The knee joint enhances resistance to sustained external forces by lowering the center of mass; (3) The shoulder joint significantly shortens balance adjustment time by 4-50%. These findings provide insights for improving the balance control of bipedal robots under external disturbances.

title: Personalized Online Bus Ticket Booking Using Machine Learning and Reinforcement Learning
authors: M.Suresh Kumar, S. Namaslvayam, Afrin Munawra S
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: The online bus ticket booking systems have contributed to the modern transport system and have been something that cannot be overlooked, but most of the existing systems fail to meet the complex requirements of customers, such as the ability to vary the fare, the ability to select the seats, as well as the service quality. To overcome such constraints, this paper presents an AI-based customer preference analysis framework that incorporates dynamically scored preference scoring, hybrid recommendation modeling, and real-time transportation simulation. The system relies on machine learning and reinforcement learning algorithms to process booking history, behavioral attributes, and user feedback, and perform adaptive personalization. Experimental analysis shows high performance: the preference scoring model scored above 92% in a variety of booking situations, and the real-time simulation layer claimed a booking efficiency ratio of 0.94, seat utilization of 85% and revenue increase of 21.4%. Also, customer satisfaction rose to 90.3% relative to baseline systems. These findings confirm that the offered AI-based solution can significantly improve personalization, the efficiency of operations, and decision-making in online bus ticket booking systems.

title: NutriScan: Explainable AI Framework for Real-Time Nutrition Analysis Using Hybrid Databases and QR Code Scanner Integration
authors: Vivek Shitole, Srushti Shinde, Shlok Shinde, Nidhi Shirsath, Isha Yadav, Manasi Ghamande
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: The continuous rise in dietary choices play critical role in person's health addressing the need for intelligent app designed to help users make better dietary decisions. Our application, NutriScan provides a solid solution which integrates basic information from the Open Food Facts API and unique NutriScan database with facts from verified sources for selected products to ensure accuracy and reliability. The application allows users to scan the QR codes of packaged food products to fetch list of ingredients and health-related information. A dynamic web link is generated with each QR scan thus redirecting to our customized web page which represents visuals and insights of nutritional information of the scanned product. The application also includes alternative food remedies, daily food recommendations, calorie tracking to support the overall nutrient requirements. The hybrid approach of our system includes our own database, NutriScan Random Forest Model and QR code Scanner. The NutriScan RF Model achieves 80 percent accuracy and provides valuable insights into the suitability of products for diabetics as well. Overall, by combining the verified database system, intelligent data extraction and valuable nutrient insights provide real-time approach to dietary consciousness and human living.

title: Racing Line Optimization with Fuel Efficiency Using Reinforcement Learning
authors: E Praveen Kumar, Deepika D
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Conventional racing line optimization focuses on decreasing lap time without considering the energy expenditure, diminishing its impact on autonomous vehicles. This article presents a reinforcement learning approach with a modified Soft Actor-Critic algorithm and reward structure to simultaneously minimize lap time and fuel use while abiding to track limits. The agent is motivated towards energy-efficient driving while being penalized for violating track boundary and speeding. Results from experiments in a physics-based simulator depict smoother trajectories and evident fuel savings without drastically increasing lap time. Our results contribute to sustainable performance in autonomous racing.

title: Improving DDoS Detection Accuracy in IoT Networks Using Machine and Deep Learning Strategies - A Survey
authors: Jyotsna A Nanajkar, Sudhir B Lande, Shailendrakumar M Mukane
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: The rapid proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) based appliances has amplified vulnerability to Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks, threatening availability and reliability. In this paper, we present a literature review of machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) methods for DDoS Detection in IoT network. A structured search protocol was employed to identify and filter relevant works. The reviewed studies are categorized by algorithm type, IoT network layer, dataset, and evaluation metric. Results indicate strong reported accuracies on datasets such as BoT-IoT and CICDDoS2019; however, critical gaps remain, including dataset imbalance, lack of reproducibility, limited reporting of system-level metrics, and under-explored adversarial robustness. To address these limitations, we propose an evaluation framework integrating both classification (Precision, Recall, F1, ROC-AUC) and system-level measures (latency, memory, energy efficiency). The review concludes by highlighting proposed research priorities, including lightweight edge-compatible models, federated privacy-preserving learning, adaptive detection under concept drift, and robustness against adversarial manipulation

title: PSO-EHO: A Cooperative Clustering Routing Algorithm in WSN
authors: Kaixiang Zhang, Mei Wu
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotic Systems and Applications (ICRSA)
abstract: Wireless sensor networks(WSN) are widely used in various fields, and the battery energy of WSN nodes is limited, which limits the lifetime of WSN. Therefore, it is important to reduce node's energy consumption and prolong the lifetime of WSN. Therefore, this paper proposes a clustering routing algorithm (PSO-EHO), which take advantages of PSO algorithm with EHO algorithm in cluster head's selection. It strengthens the ability of global optimization and local development, improves the accuracy of cluster head (CH) selection, avoids the PSO algorithm falling into local optimums, and prevents the slow convergence speed of EHO algorithm. In the routing phase, our algorithm designs an optimal relay strategy, which is triggered when the residual energy of nodes was low or the distance between the cluster head and the base station exceeded the threshold. This strategy constructs the graph structure and considers the residual energy of nodes and other factors, to calculate the weight of edges. The data transmission path between the node and the base station was selected according to the principle of weight minimization. The simulation results show that compared with LEACH, PSO_Kmeans and ICSSA, our algorithm significantly prolongs the network lifetime, reduces the network energy consumption.

title: Cardiovascular Disease Prediction with Deep Learning
authors: Berin Prabu A V, Srinitya G
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Cardiovascular Disease (CVD) is viewed as a significant cause of mortality in the global community and the way to avoid serious complications is early detection. Today, due to the invention of artificial intelligence, artificial intelligence has been integrated with medical imaging and biosignals to predict diseases reliably. The proposed project will create a multimodal deep learning model that will integrate retinal fundus imaging and electrocardiogram (ECG) data to identify the risk of cardiovascular disease. The aim of the current study was to obtain the structural and vascular characteristics of cardiovascular risk by deriving the image characteristics through a high-resolution version of the fundus image with the convolutional neural network (CNN). At the same time, the ECG signals are analyzed with the help of a 1D convolutional neural network (CNN) based on long short-term memory (LSTM) network blocks to locate the spatial and morphological alterations which are connected to the cardiac abnormality. Results of both modalities are normalized into certain probability scores and weighted averaging technique makes one prediction. The model does not only give a binary present/absent CVD, but it also gives scores that can be interpreted individually to each modality to improve the level of transparency. Performance is evaluated with the help of accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and ROC-AUC to ensure that it is appropriately evaluated on a range of levels. Using the option of visualizing various ophthalmic imaging and cardiac signal analysis, the current paper will prove that a scalable and efficient solution to non-invasive screening of cardiovascular diseases can be utilized to assist clinicians in their diagnosis and intervention on time.

title: Research on Facial Expression EMG Recognition Based on Gold Disk Electrodes and Machine Learning
authors: Jiawei Liu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Facial expression recognition is crucial for human-computer interaction and affective computing. However, vision-based methods are often unstable due to lighting, occlusion, and individual differences. This study proposes a robust non-visual approach using surface electromyography (SEMG) with gold disk electrodes for signal acquisition. SEMG signals from key facial muscles are processed and classified using machine learning algorithms (LDA, SVM, MLP) for seven basic expressions. Experimental results from 10 subjects show an average recognition accuracy of 92.6%, with LDA achieving the best performance. This confirms the feasibility of SEMG-based expression recognition and provides a new direction for wearable Human-computer interaction (HCI) systems.

title: A Hybrid Knowledge Graph Completion Model Combining Entity Descriptions and Graph Topology for Electrical Safety Applications
authors: Xiaoming Wang, Yulong Bai, Wenguang Zhao, Bo Peng
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Knowledge graph completion (KGC) plays a pivotal role in addressing data incompleteness and inconsistency in domain-specific knowledge representations, particularly in safety-critical fields such as electrical power systems. This paper presents a novel hybrid model, termed EntityFusion-KGC (Entity Description Fusion–Knowledge Graph Completion), which integrates both textual semantic information and graph structural features to enhance KGC performance within the context of electrical safety applications. The proposed architecture encompasses four core components. First, an improved BERT-based encoding mechanism is developed to extract domain-specific semantic representations from unstructured entity descriptions. Second, graph topology is modeled using the TransE algorithm to capture latent relational features among entities. Third, a weighted fusion module, incorporating a graph attention network (GAT), adaptively aggregates semantic and structural embeddings by assigning dynamic importance weights. This fusion mechanism facilitates effective multi-source representation learning. Finally, the ENTITYFUSION-KGC model is empirically evaluated on a domain-curated electrical safety knowledge graph through comprehensive link prediction and entity classification experiments. Experimental results indicate that the model outperforms several benchmark methods in terms of Mean Reciprocal Rank (MRR) and Hits@K metrics. The integration of enriched textual semantics and attention-guided structural features demonstrates a significant improvement in reasoning accuracy and robustness. The proposed model contributes a scalable and interpretable solution to enhance knowledge completion in electrical safety domains, with potential applicability in broader safety-critical knowledge systems.

title: Federated Learning in Embedded and Edge Systems: Architectures, Algorithms, and Applications
authors: Vasuki Shankar, Dhruv Dhankher, Sameeksha Dadmi, Rahul Biliyar, H Sinchana
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: Federated learning represents a paradigm shift in distributed model training, particularly relevant for embedded and edge computing environments where privacy preservation, latency minimization, and resource efficiency remain paramount. This survey synthesizes research developments from 2019 through 2025, examining peer-reviewed literature across architectural frameworks, hardware deployment scenarios, and algorithmic optimization techniques. This study establishes a comprehensive taxonomy encompassing five distinct architectural paradigms-namely client-server, peer-to-peer, hierarchical, hybrid, and split learning configurations-while systematically evaluating their respective trade-offs regarding scalability, computational efficiency, and operational robustness under resource constraints. The analysis reveals that communication and computation optimization approaches yield substantial resource reductions, though maintaining accuracy under nonIID data distributions remains challenging. Privacy and security frameworks demonstrate theoretical soundness yet impose computational burdens that constrain practical implementation on battery-operated devices. Domain-specific applications exhibit varying maturity trajectories, with healthcare and smart city deployments advancing while autonomous vehicle integration faces regulatory and certification barriers. Persistent gaps are identified in standardized evaluation frameworks, longitudinal stability assessment, and seamless integration with legacy edge infrastructure.

title: Lightweight LLMs in Mental Healthcare: Systematic Review of Federated Learning, Compression, and Privacy Enhancement
authors: Poonam Hadke, Sonali Patil
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: Use of mental health and language models involve computational inefficiency, privacy violation, and personalization standards. Our systematic search includes the men addressed issues through a privacy-protecting, lightweight language. models evaluation placing particular focus on federated learning, compression schemes, and personalization techniques. As per PRISMA guidelines, systematically we reviewed 89 Academic articles after January 2019 through September 2025. Our findings prove that privacy-preserving schemes would attain 9095 % precision and reduce the communication cost by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$60-80 \%$</tex>. Also, many compression schemes attain model size compression by 5-10x with minimal precision loss. Importantly, federated personalization techniques attained a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${1 5}-{2 5} \%$</tex> improvement in user specific task. We also show that federated learning coupled with lightweight models offers a promising solution to privacyenhancing mental healthcare solutions. A lot remains to be conducted in terms of research, e.g., standardized evaluation metrics by necessity, better privacy guarantees, and clinical validation. This review captures accrued knowledge and provides a research road map with future implications by pointing out how the considered technologies hold promise in transforming mental health support.

title: Blockchain-Enabled Intellectual Property Management: A Comprehensive Framework for Digital Rights Protection
authors: Sourav Narvekar, Sonali Patil, Prastuti Motghare, Tejashreeraje Panaskar, Rohit Pawar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: The digital transformation of intellectual property (IP) ecosystems has created pressing challenges in establishing provenance, preventing infringement, and managing rights in distributed environments. Blockchain technology emerges as a disruptive solution with its decentralized architecture, cryptographic security, and immutable audit trails. This paper presents a comprehensive examination of blockchain applications in intellectual property management, analyzing 17 distinct use cases across eight industry verticals. We develop a novel taxonomy of blockchain-based IP systems, comparing six architectural paradigms and their suitability for different IP classes. The study evaluates twelve commercial and governmental implementations, identifying key success factors and limitations. Through detailed analysis of three consensus mechanisms and four smart contract frameworks, we establish technical guidelines for system designers. The paper further examines seven critical challenges including legal recognition, scalability constraints, and interoperability barriers, proposing a roadmap for future research. Our findings demonstrate that hybrid blockchain architectures with off-chain storage and on-chain verification currently offer the most viable solution for enterprise-scale IP management. The research contributes a validated framework for assessing blockchain implementations in IP ecosystems, supported by case studies from patent offices, creative industries, and manufacturing sectors.

title: An AI-Driven Ensemble Framework for Personalized Career Coaching and Job Readiness
authors: Chandra Naik, Tangevva R Gadad, R Varshitha, K Yoghana B, B Srushti N
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Computing, Semiconductor, Mechatronics, Intelligent Systems and Communications (COSMIC)
abstract: Navigating the new job market is quite stressful for students or early-career professionals who usually have lesser access to more personalized guidance and a real-time perspective of the industry. Even though career counseling services exist, and so do online tools, those services and tools usually fail to go deep into providing profoundly personalized, scalable, and adaptable support that talks to one’s strengths, interests, and changing market trends. As roles are getting increasingly dynamic, there comes the need for intelligent systems that help aspirants to connect with career opportunities of significance. In light of such needs, we are attempting to develop an AI Career Coach which integrates advanced ML and NLP models to provide full end-to-end career support. The system would comprise of four modules: job recommendations, resume generator, mock interviews, and industry insights. Each of these modules will leverage state-of-the-art technologies such as Google Gemini for multimodal generative reasoning; BERT for understanding the context behind user profiles, job descriptions, etc.; RAG for pulling relevant interview content and market data; To help the user feel prepared and confident, this platform incorporates automation for the essential career services and then combines them with insightful feedback and ideas for enhancement.By way of example, the personalized career pathway comes to ought to change, evolving with each user’s development and changes in the industry through AI technologies within a modular and user-dependent setting. And regularly picking up feedback and restyling in both content and form along with the suggestions, they essentially guarantee absolute currency and relevance of the recommendations. Such a system can tend to a total makeover on how people actually design, pursue, and work now in their day-to-day disturbances of professional-being.

title: Cognitive Robotics for Assisting Surgeons in Precision Medical Procedures
authors: Priyanka Gupta, Gaurav Tamrakar, Preeti Pandey, Anupa Sinha, Anushree Saha, Priyanka Singh
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Cognitive robotics is also changing the surgical practice that provides accuracy, safety, and teamwork between the surgeon and robot. Shared autonomy with haptic feedback is one of the most promising approaches in this area, with the robotic systems handling the fine motor actions with the surgeon enforcing high-level control. This strategy reduces human errors since it corrects tremors, scaling motions and ensures tool paths are kept in preset safe zones. Haptic feedback can also be integrated to enable surgeons to sense the presence of delicate force interactions with tissue and make better decisions during delicate procedures such as suture or dissection. One of the prominent ones is da Vinci Surgical System that is a combination of high-tech teleoperation, force-sensing, and motion control with real-time imaging. Shared autonomy through the combination of surgeon expertise and robot accuracy guarantees repeatability of performance in complex surgeries with the added benefit of decreased fatigue and increased patient outcomes. This synergy is a leading step to safer, more efficient and intelligent robotic-assisted surgeryt.

title: Optimal Active Power Dispatch for Bipolar VSCMTDC System during Converter Trip
authors: Ayaka Nakamura, Mikimasa Iwata, Yasunobu Yokomizu, Naoto Kodama, Takuto Ohsawa
publish: 2025 IEEE PES 17th Asia-Pacific Power and Energy Engineering Conference (APPEEC)
abstract: This paper investigates optimal power redistribution in a bipolar voltage source converter based multi-terminal DC (VSC-MTDC) system under a converter trip. A mathematical optimization framework is developed to minimize both operational costs and frequency deviations in the interconnected AC grids. The model incorporates multiple types of balancing resources, including contract-based reserves, market-based reserves, and local converter adjustments, each with distinct cost and capacity limits. Converter trip events are modeled using redistribution coefficients $\omega _{ter,i}^m$, and power assurance coefficients ω<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ass,i</inf> , enabling flexible allocation of surplus or deficit power among remaining converter stations. All monetary values in this study are expressed in JPY. Simulation results demonstrate that, for representative operating points, the total adjustment cost can be reduced from 21.166 million JPY at a frequency-minimization case to 18.438 million JPY at a cost-minimization case, while maintaining AC frequency deviations. Specifically, the frequency-minimization case reduces the maximum frequency deviation from 14.9545 Hz to 8.9500 Hz. These results indicate that the method provides a reliable and economically efficient approach for MTDC system.

title: ML Driven Alert Correlation Approaches For Attack Detection
authors: Yassmine Habi, Nasreddine Abdelli, M-Tahar Kechadi, Abdelkamel Tari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Innovative Applications (AIIA)
abstract: Alert correlation is critical for synthesizing related security events from intrusion detection systems (IDS) and security monitoring solutions to reveal complex attack scenarios, such as Multi-Stage Attacks and Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs). These modern threats utilize stealthy, dispersed actions that readily evade single-point detection, making effective correlation essential. Traditional correlation approaches, relying on rule-based or knowledge-driven systems, suffer from inherent limitations in adaptability, flexibility, and scalability against the rapidly evolving threat landscape. Machine Learning (ML) offers a powerful alternative, providing adaptive, data-driven solutions capable of learning novel attack patterns without the need for extensive, explicit expert rules. This paper provides review of the state-of-the-art ML-based alert correlation approaches. We critically analyse the methodologies based on their input encoding and features, underlying model architectures, use of key benchmark datasets, and established evaluation strategies. Finally, we identify emerging trends and highlight significant open issues to guide future research in developing next-generation alert correlation systems.

title: PaiNN-LS-Elec: Machine Learning Force Field Integrating Linear Attention and Electronegativity Correction
authors: Pengwei Tao, Lin Lin, Mengzhi Han
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: In the field of molecular dynamics simulation of machine learning force field, most of the existing methods focus on the study of neutral singlet structure particles and short-range interactions, while the study of non neutral singlet structure particles and long-range interactions still faces many challenges. Therefore, a new linear-sigmoid attention is proposed and introduced into the PaiNN(Polarizable Atom Interaction Neural Network) model to deal with the non neutral singlet structure particles and correct the long-range interaction force. Moreover, the linear attention takes into account both computational efficiency and feature diversity. In addition, from the point of view of physical chemistry, this paper also enhanced the expression ability of atomic local charge in the model, that is, the electronegativity of atoms was introduced as a priori knowledge to modulate the expression of atomic local charge, so as to further improve the expression ability of the model. The experimental results show that on the carbene and Ag3 datasets, the accuracy of the new linear attention is similar to that of softmax attention with high computational complexity, and the electronegativity correction further improves the performance of the model; On the carbon chain and Ag clusters datasets, compared with the existing machine learning force field, the proposed machine learning force field combining linear attention and electronegativity correction reduces the root mean square error (RMSE) of force by 6.27% and 64.2%, respectively.

title: A Hybrid Deep Learning Framework for Real-Time Anomaly Detection and Source Classification of Conducted EMI in Electric Vehicle Inverters
authors: Rohit Nalwade, Priyanka Jain
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Electromagnetic Interference and Compatibility (INCEMIC)
abstract: The rapid adoption of wide-bandgap (WBG) semiconductors in electric vehicle (EV) inverters has introduced significant electromagnetic compatibility (EMC) challenges. Conventional EMC qualification relies on a reactive, iterative test-fail-fix cycle, where diagnosing the root cause of an electromagnetic interference (EMI) failure is a primary bottleneck.
