This paper proposes a novel Hybrid Diagnostic Framework (HDF) that leverages deep learning to transform this process. The HDF integrates a 1D Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and a Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) with an attention mechanism to perform real-time anomaly detection and multi-class root-cause classification of conducted EMI. Using a high-fidelity “Digital Twin of Failure” approach, a synthetic dataset was generated for a SiC-based inverter under normal operation and six distinct, physically-grounded fault modes, including critical thermo-mechanical and semiconductor degradation effects. The trained HDF, enhanced with an attention mechanism for inherent explainability, demonstrated a macro-averaged F1-Score of 0.98 on an unseen test set. The framework provides not only a direct, actionable link between an observed EMI failure and its physical source but also offers a pathway to model transparency through Explainable AI (XAI). This work further proposes a concrete strategy to bridge the sim-to-real gap, significantly accelerating the automotive EMC debugging and qualification process.

title: Automating Corneal Diagnosis for Keratoconus Detection using Deep Learning
authors: R. Sandhiya, K. Sruthi, K. Vasumathi, K.T. Yukesshwaran, S.S. Raja Ganesh, G. Sundaravadivel
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: The recognition of keratoconus is emerging as a focus of interest in contemporary Ophthalmology, which is important because a timely identification of the disease can prevent severe vision loss and intervene in the disease process, long before it reaches an advanced stage of risk to vision. This study assesses the role of artificial intelligence, namely modern deep learning algorithms, in the development of systems for automated clinician-based classification of corneal disease based on topography images. After precisely labelling a corpus of corneal topography scans, a number of processing techniques, normalization, and augmentation are employed to improve the quality of the topography scans and therefore enhance the efficacy and robustness of the deep learning models. Novel Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) architectures are evaluated, that recognized subtle changes in the shape and curvature of the cornea, which traditional diagnostic techniques may not recognize. The importance of preparation steps which are supported by data preparation, preprocessing and feature extraction phases to identify clinically-relevant features/patterns in the corneal maps, is emphasized. A process for selecting and tuning high performing models: ResNet, EfficientNet and Dense Net, models which can be used on many other medical imaging classification and diagnostic tasks, has been outlined. Validation methods against frameworks with full training and testing of the models have also been provided.

title: Secure and Efficient AI Architectures for Real-Time Video Forensics
authors: Wael Badawy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Telecommunications and Artificial Intelligence (IC-FTAI)
abstract: Real-time video manipulation detection and content authentication have emerged as critical challenges in the era of AI-generated media. The proliferation of deepfakes, adversarial attacks, and synthetic video content threatens information integrity and digital trust. In this paper, we propose VIDSEC-Net, a novel hybrid AI framework that integrates transformer-based vision encoders, adversarially trained classifiers, and spatiotemporal consistency models to detect manipulations in compressed, streamed, and archived video data. Unlike existing solutions, VIDSEC-Net is optimized for edge deployment and supports zero-trust environments through embedded cryptographic watermark validation and federated update mechanisms. We begin by formulating the mathematical problem of video tampering as a dynamic multivariate anomaly detection task across temporal frames and motion vectors. Our architecture leverages hierarchical attention across frame sequences, coupled with frequency-domain residual analysis, enabling high-precision detection even under post-processing or compression. The system is validated on multiple benchmark datasets (FaceForensics++, DeepfakeTIMIT, DFDC, and YouTube-Forensics) and demonstrates state-of-the-art performance in accuracy, F1-score, and adversarial robustness. In addition to performance metrics, we analyze VID-SEC-Net's real-time throughput on edge platforms (NVIDIA Jetson, Apple M1, Intel Movidius) and benchmark against transformer-lite and CNN baselines. Ethical implications, including potential misuse and dataset bias, are discussed, and we propose a set of deployment guidelines for privacy-preserving and trustworthy media verification. Our contributions offer a secure, scalable, and explainable AI-based solution for video forensics, setting the foundation for future research in trustaware media processing.

title: Integrating Mobile and IoT Solutions for Public Safety: A Review with an Emergency Button Framework
authors: Deepika Kamath, Gayatri Baligar, A Gajendra, H Manjula, Raghavendra Karjagi
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: Guaranteeing public safety has emerged as an escalating issue due to the rising frequency of harassment and crime occurrences in communities. To tackle this issue, scientists have investigated numerous mobile apps, wearable gadgets, and IoT-driven systems aimed at providing swift and dependable emergency assistance. Leveraging these insights, this project suggests a comprehensive emergency button system for public safety that merges live communication, location data, and cloud integration. The system can make hands-free SOS calls, produce geofencing alerts, capture audio and video evidence, and alert nearby trusted contacts. Extra protections comprise battery and signal backup systems, secure one-to-one communication, chatbot help, safety tools, and a simulated calling option for subtle intervention. This comprehensive strategy enhances response time in emergencies while also equipping individuals with preventive and proactive security tactics in daily situations.

title: Generative AI for Automating Product Descriptions and Marketing Materials
authors: Karthick K K, Valliappan Raju, K K Ramachandran, Suchi Dubey, Zahran Al-Salti, Arul Kumar Natarajan
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Online shopping is also being coexed, for example CAD rules and marketing text could be developed automatically at a new unparalleled degree of efficiency and customization using Generative Artificial Intelligence (AI). Using advanced natural language generating (NLG) models like GPT 4 T5 & fine-tuned large language models (LLM), it enables companies to generate context-aware brand aligned search engine optimized and purpose and need-based content for their multi-faceted audiences. Each of these systems make use of deep learning, prompt engineering and reinforcement learning with human feedback (RLHF) to maximize the accuracy, finitude and engagement of the model while minimizing the human time and time to market. As well as text generation this kind of automated demand generation process also renders product images, commercials and clickable marketing elements at the same time based on the natural language and visual information. Thus shifting the paradigm from physical economics using analogue long tail analogy to the digital economy, the research explores “next generation generative AI, technologies, and deployment strategies, of components in the conversational marketing processes or conversations”.

title: Blockchain Consensus: Intrinsic Work Feedback for Enhanced Latency
authors: Priyanka Muppuri
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: This paper proposes a fresh adjustment to blockchain fork choice rules based on an intrinsic work feedback which substantially improves confirmation latency. This protocol provides that one chain, instead of being simply the longest chain, is selected as the chain with the greatest cumulative “intrinsic work” of blocks. Safer block production rates are achieved with feedback, with the time length to confirm a transaction also significantly reduced. We show through extensive simulations and formal security proofs that our design provides a performance improvement via a strengthened consensus feedback loop.

title: Engineering of a High-Precision Job Matching Engine using Dual Encoders and Graph-based Neural Models
authors: M. Bagya Lakshmi, G. Vinoth Rajkumar, S. Naveen, U. Sakthivelu, S. Pravin, S. R.Sahanaz Begam
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: This study presents the engineering, deployment, and evaluation of a high-precision job-matching engine built using advanced deep learning architectures, including dual encoders and graph-based neural models. The system addresses the increasing complexity of modern recruitment workflows, where unstructured resume data, heterogeneous job descriptions, and rapidly evolving skill requirements demand scalable, intelligent processing strategies. The implemented framework integrates a DualEncoder-XLM-HR module for high-fidelity semantic embedding, a UMTC-X2 multi-task classifier for structured attribute extraction, and a GraphSAGE-HR skill-graph network for contextual skill inference. These components are orchestrated within an optimized microservice pipeline that supports low-latency inference and real-time recommendation generation. The ranking layer, powered by RankGPT-JR, leverages reinforced preference learning to provide highly personalized job recommendations aligned with user capabilities and career pathways. The system’s engineering design emphasizes modularity, vectorized retrieval efficiency, and robust representation learning, enabling it to operate effectively at scale. Evaluation against large anonymized recruitment datasets demonstrated substantial improvements in matching accuracy, ranking precision, and skill-gap detection when compared to conventional keyword-based or rules-driven systems. By enhancing alignment between candidate profiles and organizational requirements, the platform supports broader socio-economic objectives such as promoting Decent work and fostering Innovation in employment-matching technologies.

title: Artificial Intelligence Assisted Enhanced Thermal and Electrical Performance of Epoxy–GO–MgO Nanocomposites via Hybrid Filler Integration
authors: Lurdhumary Jl, Venkateswaran N
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Multifunctional epoxy nanocomposites that are more thermal and electrical conductive have led to the investigation of hybrid filler systems. In this paper, an artificial intelligence (AI)-aided design and optimization methodology of epoxy composites reinforced with a hybrid blend of graphene oxide (GO) and magnesium oxide (MgO) nanoparticles has been introduced. Surface-functionalized hybrid fillers were incorporated into a bisphenol-A epoxy resin through a controlled dispersion test based on mechanical stirring and ultrasonication. It was found that the ratio of a GO:MgO of 1.5:0.5 and a total filler content of 2wt% yielded the best results in terms of giving significant changes in thermal and electrical properties. Thermal conductivity was 1.25 W/m K, which was 78% better than plain epoxy, and still a high-volume resistivity of 8.5 x 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">s</sup>0·cm upheld great insulation abilities. The ANN and SVM AI models have been trained using experimental data when the filler ratio, sonication time, and curing temperature are used as inputs. The most successful AI model (GA-ANN) had R2=0.971, and MAPE= 2.7, which confirmed the precision in its predictions and the application in the real-time formulation tuning. The paper shows how material science and data-driven modelling can successfully meet in intelligent material design. The proposed hybrid composite can be used in other areas such as electronics packaging, energy systems and sophisticated thermal interface materials. Future research and development will involve expanding this type of AI-driven method to other polymer-based matrices and the study of the future of self-healing, dynamic composites based on next-generation smart materials.

title: Multi- Task Lesion Segmentation and Classification with Explainable AI and Uncertainty Estimation for Trustworthy Diabetic Retinopathy Screening
authors: G.J. Maniram, S. Nithishkumar, A.S. Hepsi Ajibah
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: This paper aims to promote collective health through occupational therapy by addressing the challenge of early detection and clinical interpretability in diabetic retinopathy (DR). The proposed framework employs a Multi-Task Learning (MTL) model built on a convolutional neural network (CNN) to simultaneously predict disease severity and generate lesion segmentation from retinal fundus photographs. To enhance transparency, Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) is integrated through Gradient-weighted Class Activation Mapping (Grad-CAM), highlights the image regions which is most influential in the model's decisions. Furthermore, Monte Carlo (MC) Dropout is applied during inference to estimate prediction uncertainty and provide confidence scores along with classifications. High-confidence predictions can be adopted directly by ophthalmologists, while low-confidence cases are flagged for further review, supporting safer clinical decision-making. By jointly performing classification, segmentation, and uncertainty estimation, the system improves diagnostic accuracy, minimizes misclassification, and produces interpretable lesion maps with confidence-aware outputs. Experiments on benchmark datasets-APTOS 2019 for severity grading and IDRiD for lesion segmentation-show that the proposed method consistently outperforms single-task approaches. The combined use of XAI and uncertainty estimation delivers trustworthy and clinically relevant results, offering clear advantages over traditional DR detection methods and demonstrating strong potential for tele-ophthalmology screening programs.

title: StructureID: Implicit User Authentication by Sensing Structure-borne Sound on Smart Device
authors: Huijie Chen, Juan Fang, Xiaobin Xu, Shuopeng Li, Youqi Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: User authentication on mobile smart devices is essential for safeguarding personal privacy. However, existing methods based on facial recognition and fingerprint biometrics are susceptible to impersonation attacks, while those relying on PIN codes or unlock patterns are vulnerable to theft or observation. To address these issues, this paper proposes StructureID, an implicit authentication approach that leverages users’ grip posture biometrics through active acoustic sensing on smart devices. By applying a series of signal processing techniques and deep learning models, StructureID effectively eliminates interference from direct airborne signals and multipath noise. It then extracts distinctive acoustic features from structure-borne signals within the device to enable secure user authentication. Experimental results demonstrate that StructureID achieves an authentication accuracy of nearly 90% and maintains a false acceptance rate below 8%.

title: Deep Learning-based Assistive Healthcare System with Context-Aware Personalization for Visually Impaired Patients: A Clinical Validation Study
authors: J Preetha, K Rajchandar, S Darshwana R, S Hareini
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: Healthcare accessibility for visually impaired individuals remains a critical challenge in medication management and telemedicine. This research presents a validated AI-enhanced telemedicine system integrating computer vision based medicine recognition using enhanced Inception-v4 achieving $97.5 \%$ controlled and $94.2 \%$ diverse-condition accuracy, natural language processing through transformerbased models with $92 \%$ intent recognition, and context-sensitive adaptation employing reinforcement learning for personalized behavior. Clinical validation with 45 visually impaired participants demonstrated $96 \%$ medicine identification accuracy, $\mathbf{9 2 \%}$ task completion rate, 78-second average task time i/e., 57% reduction versus manual methods, $42 \%$ medication adherence improvement, and 4.6 out of 5 user satisfaction rating. The system integrates electronic health records, pharmacy databases, and emergency services, achieving $99.2 \%$ uptime and $32 \%$ faster emergency response.

title: Measuring Canopy Geometric Structure for Crop Yield Estimation Using PCA-Driven Machine Learning Models with Hyperspectral Images
authors: K Sudharshan, Ahmad al-qerem, P Yakaiah, K M Rayudu, V Revathi, A Shanthipriya
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: The Canopy Geometric Structure for Crop Yield Estimation Using PCA-Driven Machine Learning Models with Hyperspectral Images (CGCPMH) utilizes UAV-mounted hyperspectral imagery for estimating plant biomass and evaluating vegetation. The approach involves a preprocessing pipeline that improves image quality and segmentation through CIELAB color space transformation. Principal Component Analysis (PCA) facilitates data dimensionality reduction, enabling extraction of key spectral features relevant to soil moisture. Precision canopy monitoring is accomplished through voxel-based 3D modeling. This methodology supports decision-making in precision agriculture, providing a framework for sustainable practices in Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs). The following specifications spike weight and plant height analysis, gain weight analysis, error estimation, RMSE, and MAE calculations.

title: Cyberattack Detection in DC Microgrids Using Logical Monitoring Framework
authors: Bandar Mahlawi, Muhyaddin Rawa, Mousa Marzband, Tawfiq Aljohani
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Environment Friendly Energies and Applications (EFEA)
abstract: This paper presents a cybersecurity-oriented detection framework for DC microgrids integrated with electric vehicle (EV) charging networks. A logical monitoring model is developed in MATLAB/Simulink to identify and isolate cyber-induced anomalies such as False Data Injection (FDI), Denial-Of-Service (DoS) attacks, and PWM-signal manipulation. The methodology integrates mathematical modeling, rule-based detection, and logical operators to enhance resilience and reliability in distributed control units. Simulation results validate the proposed framework’s ability to detect attacks with minimal latency while maintaining system stability and safe voltage operation under various cyberattack scenarios. The proposed framework offers a scalable and adaptive approach for securing future EV-integrated DC microgrids. The findings validate the efficacy of the detection system as a dependable and lightweight real-time cybersecurity solution, achieving less than 10 ms response time, over 98% detection accuracy, and zero false-positive activations.

title: Viberehab: Advanced Vibration Therapy Glove for Stroke Recovery with IoT Integration
authors: Sanjana Devi V S, Surya M, Rithuparna K S, Sukesh S A
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Recovery from a stroke can depend on regular and purposeful exercises to regain use of the hand and wrist. The traditional methods of rehabilitating these patients have the limitations of providing no real-time feedback to adjust and lack personalization, both of which may influence patient interest in participating and overall recovery. While wearing the glove, patients will perform exercises while receiving vibrational feedback in real-time which simulates therapeutic hand movements to support motor recovery. At the same time, sensors embedded in the glove collect details of hand movement, which are sent to the IoT platform. The combination of the adaptive vibration therapy and the ability to visualize and collect real-time data in the IoT platform is an advancement in stroke rehabilitation in that it promotes personalized therapy, maintains motivation to perform exercises, and allows for the ability to practice regularly. Thus, this integrated approach provides a more data-driven and interactive system to rehabilitate incapacitated patients who have had a stroke, optimized recovery speed and optimizing results.

title: Zero-Trust Dynamic Encryption Framework for Secure Cloud Storage and Multi-Branch Blockchain File Sharing
authors: Patan Feridoz Khan, Manellore Sahitheepragna Reddy, Kandula Poojitha, Kuraparthi Phaneendra Reddy, Poluka Venkata Niranjan, K.Amala
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: In cloud environments, where data encryption is fixed and the keys are centrally managed, the security and limited data sharing are still major issues due to the statistical attack and key compromise vulnerability. In this paper, we present a multi-branch blockchain framework with dynamic AES keying and ECC-based encryption to achieve decentralized and tamper-resistant and fine-grained data protection in the cloud. Each file is given a unique key of AES based on a hash of the file and the most recent block in the blockchain, making the keys non-reusable and very unpredictable. These keys are strongly packed into the blockchain blocks and encrypted to ECC to ensure that they are not accessed in an unauthorized way during storage and transmission. It is also suggested that a multi-branch blockchain mechanism can facilitate the mechanism of verifiable and revocable file sharing between users without altering the main chain. The experimental efficiency proves a high cryptographic security: the proposed dynamic keys can reach a high sensitivity of 59.04, which is higher than previous dynamic AES methods (51.46) and the established benchmark systems (42.5%). Encrypted images can be analyzed using the histogram to determine that the pixel distributions are uniform, which implies that they are more resistant to statistical attacks. Also, values of ciphertext entropy are close to the theoretical 8 bits/byte, which assures excellent randomness and resistance to brute-force and data-analysis attacks. The findings confirm that the offered architecture creates a significant positive effect on the level of confidentiality, integrity, and safe collaboration in the cloud computing environment.

title: Research on Cooperative Operation Algorithm for Electric Shovels and Trailing Cable Reel Vehicles in Open-Pit Mines
authors: Changpeng Ji, Longxue Yu, Wei Dai, Wenxin Ji
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: The cooperative operation efficiency of electric shovels and electric shovel trailing cable reel vehicles in open-pit mines directly affects mining productivity and safe production. To address the challenges faced by traditional path planning, such as difficulty in meeting long-span target tracking in complex environments, small obstacle detection, and cable tension constraints, a perception system and a hierarchical cooperative path optimization algorithm based on the modeling strategy of "equipment-application scenario dynamic fusion entity" are proposed. Through multi-sensor fusion, long-distance dynamic recognition of electric shovels, accurate obstacle detection in complex backgrounds, and rapid calculation of spatial positions are realized. A hierarchical architecture including global path planning, local dynamic obstacle avoidance, and multi-machine conflict resolution is constructed. Combined with adaptive cable tension constraints and a dynamic obstacle prediction model, conflict-free cooperative operations are achieved. Simulation experiments show that the algorithm effectively improves operation efficiency and safety in typical mining scenarios, and the standard deviation of cable tension fluctuation is reduced by 40%.

title: Three-Layer Hierarchical Control Architecture for Coordinated Multi-ESS Management in Microgrids
authors: Vansh Suri, Manan Sethi, Neelu Nagpal, Ravi Sharma, Sheersh Kumar Garg, Rahul Garg
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Environment Friendly Energies and Applications (EFEA)
abstract: Managing heterogeneous Energy Storage Systems (ESS) units with different characteristics require coordinated control which the existing control mechanisms fail to provide. Modern power grids require simultaneous optimization at different time scales – day ahead planning, real-time adjustments, and fast regulation. This paper proposes a novel three layer hierarchical coordinated control architecture with three control layers working at different timescales - (i) Tertiary layer: Mixed Integer Linear Programming (MILP) based layer for day-ahead planning, (ii) Secondary Layer: Alternating Direction Method of Multipliers (ADMM) based Distributive Model Predictive Control (DMPC) for real-time coordination, and (iii) Primary Layer: PI control with droop mechanisms for rapid local regulation. This framework was tested for a microgrid with four heterogenous ESS units and demonstrated exceptional performance. A net revenue of $4273.78 was obtained through energy arbitrage along with zero tracking error. Frequency regulation was within 0.071 Hz and there was no voltage deviation, henceforth assuring the robustness and grid stability. The core control execution time was just 1.64 seconds, giving a testimony of computational efficiency. The proposed framework, therefore, provides an efficient solution for coordinated ESS management under uncertainity while maintaining superior grid stability and power quality.

title: Blockchain-Enabled Market Integration: Transforming Agricultural Sales and Supply Chain Transparency
authors: Nayani Venkata Santhosh Rohan, Sushant Malik
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: The agricultural input industry faces challenges because it lacks proper demand management, along with poor transparency and inventory management, which can also be referred to as the mismatch between the marketing and sales functions. This research aims to identify blockchain technologies that can address existing issues related to supply chain transparency and inventory management. This study employs a problem-driven architectural analysis to enhance our understanding of blockchain technology and its innovation process. Multiple barriers were identified in this research, including reluctant stakeholder participation and expensive implementation costs. This work outlines a transformative method based on reputable blockchain engineering, which utilises tracking systems with RFID and NFC components, smart contracts and data assessment capabilities to advance automated procedure streams. The main barrier to blockchain technology adoption for the agricultural input sector stems from a need for solutions that meet stakeholder requirements, according to recent evidence. Similar to past research, this investigation aims to sustain agriculture through the deployment of advanced technology, benefiting decisionmakers in industries and government departments.

title: Multiclass Brain Tumor Classification using Optimization Enabled Deep Learning
authors: S.P Aynun Jarria, A. Boyed Wesley
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: The rapid increase in brain tumor cases has made it essential for researchers to develop automated methods for their detection and diagnosis. Given the diverse nature of each tumor, multi brain tumor image classification has emerged as a current research endeavor. Even though numerous classification methods have been developed in recent years, these methods rely on time-consuming and error-prone manual segmentation and feature extraction prior to classification. An automated approach for multiclass tumor classification is required in order to correctly extract features, identify and classify the tumor. This research proposes an optimization enabled deep learning for the brain tumor classification. Here, the Magnetic Resonance Image (MRI) input is preprocessed utilizing anisotropic filtering. The image, which is preprocessed, is then passed to the brain tumor segmentation process that relies on the 3DU-Net. Then, features including tumor size, mean, variance, etc., are extracted and then utilized in the brain tumor classification phase. In this phase, two level classification, such as 1<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">st</sup> stage and 2<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">nd</sup> stage classification, is used. In the 1<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">st</sup> stage classification, Deep Convolution Neural Network (DCNN) is employed to classify the tumors into normal or abnormal and the network is fine-tuned using Hybrid Fruit Bee Optimization (HFBO). Consequently, tumor types are categorized at the 2nd stage using Le-Net, which is trained by the introduced Sewing training optimization algorithm (STBO). Furthermore, the proposed STBO-based Le-Net has achieved superior results with accuracy of 0.945, TPR of 0.938 and TNR of 0.955.

title: AI-Enabled Multimodal Detection and UAV Deployment of Self-Deploying Anti-Bird Spikes for Overhead Transmission Towers
authors: Zheng Zhilong, Liu Jianfeng, Huang Chongbin, Li Yufeng, Li Yuqi, Chen Zeming, Chen Zhaohao
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Smart Grid and Clean Energy Technologies (ICSGCE)
abstract: Bird-induced faults compromise transmission-line reliability and impose substantial maintenance costs. This paper presents an integrated mitigation approach that couples a magnet-hinged, tiltable self-deploying anti-bird spike with a Transformer-enhanced multimodal recognition framework and a vision-guided UAV installation protocol. The recognition pipeline fuses RGB imagery with hyperspectral and LiDAR-derived features to detect hazardous bird species, compute tower-level risk, and classify cross-arm geometries for hardware selection. In a pilot evaluation using 800 labeled images and field mock-ups, the multimodal detector achieved an F1 score of approximately 0.91 for species detection and 95.2% accuracy for cross-arm classification. UAV installation trials yielded an autonomous installation success rate exceeding 90% and an average installation time of 4.3 minutes per tower. Results indicate the proposed system is feasible for targeted, scalable bird-fault mitigation; future work will address IoT-enabled monitoring, further multimodal robustness, and coordinated UAV deployment.

title: IoT-Enabled Smart Grid Energy Distribution using Adaptive Load Forecasting Algorithms
authors: Joshua Daniel, Karpagam M, Veera Inba Priya Darshini K, Jenifer Sangeetha S, S.Prema, Divya K
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: The emerging issues in power systems demand the use of very effective and reliable allocation of force. The introduction of renewables adds variability on the energy input and output. Old methods of load-forecasting can be obsolete, excessively projecting the ability of the system and output. This consumes power and increases the cost of operation. In this paper, a connected load controller framework in a distributed energy resource micro grid is presented. In harsh conditions, there is attention to the minimization of the load and energy input-output at the cross-SVW microgrids. Developed power-prediction models optimize the model of microgrid control of the closed-loop structure. The model relies on real-time power data streams, preconfigured control, and planned feedback of the IoT data controllers. It seeks to implement and optimize cross-standard smart-grid case studies in the Southeast Asian region and microgrids with smart are nervous installed. The results of the case-study are positive showing that there is a strong synthesis in the case of traditional forecasting based on MAPE and RMSE. Adaptive system optimizes the distributed resources among related microgrids, both integrated and meshed, and it is proving to be realistic in smart-grid application in real life through adaptive forecasting. It facilitates energy distribution in a sustainable and resilient environment through the Internet of Things.

title: IoT-Based Smart Monitoring System for Supervision of Unused Drug Donations: Enhancing Public Health Safety
authors: Pushpa Joshi, Kunvar Chokshi, Claudio Paya Santos, Juan Carlos Fernandez-Rodriguez, S. Muralidhar, C. Sivakumar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: In this paper, the author introduces an IoTBased Smart Monitoring System to oversee unused drug donations, which is designed to improve the health safety of the population. The system uses a Hybrid Edge-Cloud Computing Architecture that comprises of AWS IoT Core, AWS Lambda, Amazon S3, and Raspberry Pi to provide effective real-time monitoring of the drug conditions, such as temperature and humidity. The edge computing block is responsible to process data locally in Raspberry Pi devices with minimum latency and immediate reaction to anomalies. Information is then sent to the cloud to be analyzed and stored long term. The system provides real-time notifications, thriving analytics, and scalable infrastructure to manage big data. Compared to traditional manual monitoring, cloud-only and edgeonly approaches, the performance is shown to be better in accuracy, speed and scalability. By avoiding drug wastage, providing a secure storage system, and enhancing resource allocation, this solution offers an efficient and universal system to handle drug credits that have gone unused and improve the health security of the population.

title: A Hierarchical Multiscale Attention framework for Robust Chest X-Ray Abnormality Detection
authors: P Pradeepan, S Gladston Raj, Juby George, M R Neethunath
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: Accurate and interpretable detection of abnormalities in chest X-rays is crucial for early diagnosis and treatment planning. A significant challenge faced by many AI models is the difficulty in concurrently analyzing broad contextual patterns and fine-grained pathological details. This study proposes a framework that enhances the Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) backbone using a hierarchical attention strategy designed to capture pathologies of varying scales. The proposed approach integrates parallel multiscale attention modules for comprehensive feature analysis with a final spatial attention layer to localize abnormalities precisely. The proposed approach is evaluated on two public datasets, which achieve accuracies of 96.47% and 96.84% for pediatric pneumonia and multiclass abnormality classification, respectively. These findings indicate a significant improvement over the existing methods and demonstrate that the hierarchical strategy is a powerful step towards building a more robust and reliable AI for radiological diagnosis.

title: Enhanced Bi-LSTM-based Multimodal Snap Detection for Media Playback Control
authors: Priyadharshan K, Gethsia P, Sujitha Juliet
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: The hands-free Media Playback Control is applicable in the Snap Detection system. The paper proposes a multimodal solution that has visual and audio snap detection. The simplest solution relies on an Enhanced BiLSTM model, that is conditioned to MFCC and Melspectrograms to provide high-confidence audio snap classification. A Mediapipe pipeline is a snapping gestures detector in live video streams to aid in visual detection. The media processes and monitors gestures in real time and therefore, there is never a time where the conversion of snap gestures into media commands can be made impossible e.g. play/pause, rewind and fast-forward. This multimodal acquires power in the diverse environment through audio based detection giving a play/ pause control and visual based detection which gives directional media navigation. It is constructed on top of an audio-video processing system with an OpenCV interface. It executes system media keys through the assistance of PyAutoGui that enables it to be easily integrated with most of the media players. The system provides an interactive non contact control system which is natural and thus fits well in regards to accessibility enhancement, presentation control and entertainment. The Enhanced BiLSTM comprises a temporal Conv1D pre-net, a 2-way LSTM (two layers), and a slim additive attention head, and generalized with layer normalization and dropout. The general system is very assured and controllable real-time, demonstrating its reliability as well as a potential chance of hands-free and intuitive interaction in diverse user conditions.

title: VLSI Architecture for High-Speed Soft-Decision Decoding Using ORBGRAND
authors: S. Palanivel Rajan, M. Paramaiyappan
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Soft-decision decoding plays a crucial role in achieving near-capacity error correction performance for modern communication standards such as 5G and 6G. However, existing soft-decision decoders often suffer from high complexity, large area overhead, and limited throughput, making them less suitable for high-speed applications. This paper proposes a high-throughput VLSI architecture for soft-decision decoding based on the Ordered Reliability Bits Guessing Random Additive Noise Decoding (ORBGRAND) algorithm. The novelty of the proposed approach lies in its pipelined and parallelized noise-guessing engine, lightweight reliability sorting mechanism, and optimized memory hierarchy, which collectively minimize latency and improve energy efficiency. The overall methodology involves algorithmic optimization, architecture design in HDL, simulation under AWGN channels, FPGA synthesis, and benchmarking against existing GRAND-based decoders. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed architecture achieves multi -Gbps throughput, lower decoding latency, and superior error-correction performance with reduced area and power consumption. These results highlight its potential as an efficient solution for next-generation high-speed communication systems.

title: Experimental Evaluation of Deploying SASE JEM Authentication and Deep Fool Techniques for Robust Generative AI Chatbot Protection
authors: K. Sundara Velrani, Krithika S, Maria Jansi M
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Generative AI chatbots are used in more and more fields, but until the technology can be secured and trusted, it remains sensitive to unauthorized access and adversarial prompts. This paper will use experimental approaches to improve the safety of chatbots by testing a new model, the SACD, that combines the use of SASE JEM authentication and the DeepFool adversarial defense. The framework will block errant or malicious users, and subsequently identify and counter opposing inputs, such that only harmless prompts are passed through the chatbot. The SACD framework performed well with using the LLM Jailbreak + Safety Data on Kaggle as the program provided a high-level of robustness, scoring 98% and decreasing the number of unsafe outputs and attack success rates significantly. These findings affirm the fact that the suggested structure offers a stable, multi -layered defense system, which integrates access-level protection with the model-level adversarial protection and therefore offers secure, trustworthy, and resilient chatbot interactions.

title: MTRAG: Multi-Target Referring and Grounding via Hybrid Semantic-Spatial Integration_supp1-3663039.pdf
authors: Hongjue Li
publish: N/A
abstract: Fine-grained visual referring and grounding are critical for enhancing scene understanding and enabling various real-world vision-language applications. Although recent studies have extended multimodal large language models (MLLMs) to these tasks, they still face significant challenges in fine-grained multi-target scenarios. To address this, we propose MTRAG, a pixel-level multi-target referring and grounding framework that leverages semantic-spatial collaboration. Specifically, we introduce a Channel Extension Mechanism (CEM) that enables a global image encoder to extract global semantics and multi-region representations while retaining background context, without extra region feature extractors. Moreover, we introduce a grounding branch for pixel-level grounding and design a Hybrid Adapter (HA) to fuse semantic features from the MLLM branch with spatial information from the grounding branch, thereby enhancing the semantic-spatial alignment. For training, we meticulously curate MTRAG-D, a dataset comprising single-and multi-target referring and grounding samples derived from existing datasets and newly synthesized free-form multi-target referring instruction-following data. We also present MTR-Bench, a benchmark for systematic evaluation of multi-target referring. Extensive experiments across five core task, including single- and multi-target referring and grounding as well as image-level captioning, show that MTRAG consistently outperforms strong baselines on both multi- and single-target tasks, while maintaining competitive image-level understanding. The code is available at https://github.com/deng-ai-lab/MTRAG.

title: Overview of Thermal Modeling and Monitoring for SiC Multi-Chip Power Modules
authors: LINKE ZHOU, DI WANG, SAMANTHA JONES-JACKSON, CHANG LIU, MOHAMED ABDALMAGID, ALI EMADI
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Power Electronics
abstract: Silicon carbide (SiC) multi-chip power modules (MCPMs) have emerged as critical components in high-power and high-reliability power electronics due to their superior integration capability and performance potential. However, the inherent structural complexity and intense thermal coupling effects pose significant challenges in thermal modeling and monitoring. This paper provides a comprehensive review of recent advances in thermal modeling and monitoring methods tailored specifically for SiC MCPMs. Thermal modeling approaches are thoroughly analyzed, highlighting their respective advantages and limitations in terms of computational efficiency, accuracy, and applicability. Additionally, various direct and indirect thermal monitoring techniques are discussed, examining their practical implementations, strengths, and constraints. To address existing challenges in thermal modeling and monitoring of SiC MCPMs, future research directions are identified. Challenges and opportunities in thermal modeling and monitoring have been specifically analyzed and discussed for SiC MCPMs with advanced packaging technologies. This review not only summarizes the state-of-the-art methodologies but also identifies potential research pathways to enhance the accuracy and robustness of thermal modeling and monitoring for SiC MCPMs. Beyond thermal modeling and monitoring, this paper also serves as a valuable reference for advancing SiC MCPM research in thermal management, packaging design, and lifetime assessment.

title: Generative Model-Aided Continual Learning for CSI Feedback in FDD mMIMO-OFDM Systems
authors: Guijun Liu, Yuwen Cao, Tomoaki Ohtsuki, Jiguang He, Shahid Mumtaz
publish: IEEE Signal Processing Letters
abstract: Deep autoencoder (DAE) frameworks have demonstrated their effectiveness in reducing channel state information (CSI) feedback overhead in massive multiple-input multiple-output (mMIMO) orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM) systems. However, existing CSI feedback models struggle to adapt to dynamic environments caused by user mobility, requiring retraining when encountering new CSI distributions. Moreover, returning to previously encountered environments often leads to performance degradation due to catastrophic forgetting. Continual learning involves enabling models to incorporate new information while maintaining performance on previously learned tasks. To address these challenges, we propose a generative adversarial network (GAN)-based learning approach for CSI feedback. By using a GAN generator as a memory unit, our method preserves knowledge from past environments and ensures consistently high performance across diverse scenarios without forgetting. Simulation results show that the proposed approach enhances the generalization capability of the DAE framework while maintaining low memory overhead. Furthermore, it can be seamlessly integrated with other advanced CSI feedback models, highlighting its robustness and adaptability.

title: ReparoV2: QoE-aware Live Video Streaming under Low-Bandwidth Networks
authors: Fulin Wang, Qing Li, Wanxin Shi, Qian Yu, Gareth Tyson, Yong Jiang, Jianhui Lv, Zhenhui Yuan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Live video streaming has grown significantly, especially on networks with limited bandwidth. Traditional video streaming methods, which drop less important frames, often struggle with high latency. We propose ReparoV2, a novel approach designed specifically for live streaming environments. On the client side, ReparoV2 selectively omits video frames at the source, which substantially reduces bandwidth usage without significantly degrading the QoE. ReparoV2 implements a real time Video Frame Discarding (VFD) algorithm, which categorizes even-indexed frames into three types: preserving, recovering using neural networks and substituting with the previous frame, which is corresponding to the high, medium and low degree of difference between two adjacent frames. Additionally, to gain a better QoE, ReparoV2 integrates an adaptive bitrate strategy and introduces multiple discrete low-frame-rate encoding modes, balancing video quality and bandwidth reduction when the network bandwidth is limited. On the server side, ReparoV2 uses a Video Frame Interpolation Deep Neural Network (VFI-DNN) and frame-copying to reconstruct dropped frames, ensuring a smooth viewing experience. It updates the VFD model based on received video chunks and sends the updated model back to the client. ReparoV2 outperforms conventional Dynamic Adaptive Streaming over HTTP (DASH), achieving higher Structural Similarity Index Measure (SSIM) (+0.024), lower bandwidth usage (-23.19%), and improved QoE (+26.66%) on 25fps videos under 0.974Mbps average bandwidth.

title:
Interannual Divergence of PM
                    <sub>2.5</sub>
                    and O
                    <sub>3</sub>
                    Pollution in East-Central China Revealed by Seamless 24-Hour Retrievals (2017-2023)
authors: Yuqing Su, Ying Yang, Yi Zhang, Jianhua Yin, Feiyue Mao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Despite recent improvements, particulate matter (PM2.5) concentrations remain excessive, and concurrent worsening of surface ozone (O3) pollution has further amplified dual-pollutant risks. This trend underscores the urgent need for more accurate, continuous, and integrated air quality monitoring. To address this challenge, we proposed GeoFusion-RT, a novel high-resolution, all-hour retrieval framework for PM2.5 and O3, to generate seamless 24-hour pollutant concentration fields over East-Central China from 2017 to 2023. Model evaluations show strong predictive performance, with cross-validated coefficients of determination (R²) of 0.92 for PM2.5 and 0.94 for O3, and root mean squared errors (RMSEs) of 8.59 μg/m³ and 10.94 μg/m³, respectively. Independent site-based validation further confirms robust generalizability (PM2.5: R² = 0.86; O3: R² = 0.89), demonstrating high accuracy across diurnal, seasonal, and interannual timescales. Trend analysis reveals a reduction of over 10 μg/m³ in annual PM2.5 concentrations from 2017 to 2020, with particularly sharp declines in regions such as Beijing–Tianjin–Hebei and the Yangtze River Delta. However, this progress stagnated or slightly reversed after the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020, possibly reflecting the saturation of earlier interventions or diminishing policy effectiveness. In contrast, O3 showed limited decline prior to 2020 but has risen sharply since, with an annual increase of approximately +1.5 μg·m-3yr⁻¹ by 2023, highlighting a decoupled trend between the two pollutants. These findings emphasize the urgency for coordinated precursor controls, targeting both NOx and VOCs, to prevent worsening O3 pollution under PM2.5-only reduction pathways in the post-COVID era.

title: Two-Stage Expert Offloading for Domain-Aware MoE Inference
authors: Hangyeol Kim, Honguk Woo, Younghwan Kim
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) architectures, while computationally efficient, suffer from a critical memory–latency bottleneck. The need to store all experts in GPU memory or to incur high I/O latency when offloading them to CPU severely hinders their practical deployment. To address this, we propose ADEPT (Adaptive Domain-aware Expert Prefetching Technique), a framework designed to optimize expert management during LLM inference under memory-constrained GPU environments. ADEPT employs a two-stage strategy. First, during the prefill phase, it analyzes the input’s semantic domain to selectively preload only relevant experts, minimizing peak memory usage. Second, during token-by-token decoding, a locality-aware mechanism predicts and preemptively loads upcoming experts into the GPU cache, effectively hiding I/O latency. Evaluated across diverse domains, ADEPT demonstrates significant efficiency gains in two key aspects: (1) in terms of latency, simulation results show a 50% reduction in I/O wait time, while real-world validation confirms a 3.45× speedup over standard offloading baselines by mitigating system overheads and (2) in terms of memory, it yields a 33% decrease in peak usage compared to a full-loading approach. Our findings demonstrate that this principled approach significantly improves the practical deployability of MoE models on cost-effective hardware, making them a more viable option for latency-sensitive applications.

title: Data-Driven Magnetic Core Loss Modeling with Multiple Variables Crossing Materials
authors: Zengrui Yi, Hua Meng, Zhengchun Zhou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: The generalized modeling of core loss aims to predict the power loss of magnetic components, which is crucial in fields such as electronic industry design. However, the influence relationships of operating condition variables are complex. Empirical models, such as the Steinmetz Equation, cannot fully characterise such nonlinear relationships, because the used priori equation has insufficient variables and their coefficients are all fixed. Although deep learning alleviates this issue, most existing methods still only consider limited variables and are not applicable to cross-material modeling. Therefore, we combine the prior knowledge of empirical models and the powerful fitting ability of deep learning, and propose a Deep Self-Representation (DSR) module that can either function as an independent model or be integrated into existing empirical formulas. Specifically, the integrated model can dynamically adjust the coefficients according to the input variables, resulting in better accuracy and generalization. In addition, based on the log-linear property provided by Steinmetz, we propose a flexible approach that can conveniently add more variables. To evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed method, we conducted a series of comparative and simulation experiments on the open-source dataset MagNet. The experimental results show that DSR, used alone as the core loss model, outperforms baseline methods in accuracy, with 0.875% and 1.229% errors in single-material and multi-material cases, respectively. Furthermore, the integrated model has even lower errors of 0.657% and 1.01% and better robustness. Moreover, our model can perform training and prediction on an inexpensive GPUor CPU, providing an efficient solution. We release our code online: https://github.com/.

title: Smart Agriculture System for Soil Analysis and Crop Suggestion using AI Techniques
authors: M. Rama Krishnan, Cynthia Sherin, S. Vasanthi, R. Robert, R. Saravanakumar, S. Jeya Lakshmi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: This research aims to enhance agricultural productivity by accurately identifying soil types and recommending suitable crops based on parameters such as soil pH, moisture level, temperature, and nutrient content. Traditional farmers generally depend on personal experience and visual judgment, which may lead to incorrect decisions and lower yields. The proposed system addresses these limitations by using a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) for soil image classification and an Artificial Neural Network (ANN) for optimal crop recommendations. The dataset contains soil samples and environmental parameters collected from multiple regions. The models are trained and evaluated with labeled data to ensure high accuracy and strong generalization capability. The CNN achieves a soil classification accuracy of over 97.58%, while the ANN delivers precise and dependable crop suggestions. These intelligent techniques help farmers make data-driven decisions, reduce losses, and improve productivity. The integration of artificial intelligence (AI) and deep learning (DL) demonstrates a promising and sustainable solution for modern precision agriculture.

title: A New Sorting Algorithm under the Assumption of Partially Ordered Input
authors: Aviral Srivastava, Mitakshu, Amardeep Singh
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: This paper presents an entirely new algorithm for adaptive sorting called PartialSortOpt, designed specifically for the input that is partially ordered. We theorized formal structures of various kinds of partial orderings, including k-sortedness, presorted blocks, and showed how PartialSortOpt utilizes them for optimal or near-optimal performance. Direct comparison with legacy algorithms, including QuickSort, MergeSort, and Time sort, demonstrates that PartialOptSort cuts down computation time and memory in abundance in underlying order scenarios. Even within the parameter of worst-case scenarios the algorithm performs reasonably, and in an even greater measure within the best and average cases that correspond with practical datasets.

title: A Relative Analysis of Enhanced Machine Learning Algorithm SVM & Decision Tree to Predict Smart Grid Stability
authors: V. Dharani, Srinivasa Varma, Sandeep Dwarkanath Pande, Soumitra Das, Sk Hasane Ahammad, Krunal Pawar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: The demand for electricity has been rapidly increasing nowadays. So, it is necessary to distribute power to consumers efficiently. Smart grids (SG) can reduce the losses in the distribution of power. To achieve accuracy, artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning(ML) techniques are implemented widely. There is an evident need of analysing and comparing different algorithms and choose the most suitable one to relate for SGs. Several enhanced algorithms such as Random Forest (RF), Support Vector Machine (SVM), Naïve Baye's (NB), K-Nearest Neighbours (KNN), Logistic Regression (LR), Decision Tree (DT), Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD) classifier, and Gradient Boosting (GB) are used for predicting the stability of SGs. In the proposed paper, a correlative exploration between DT and SVM has been focused formed on evaluation grades like precision and accuracy.

title: Deconstructing AI Detection Tools: Accuracy Limits, Bias, and Human Consequences
authors: Sushil Kumar Patra, Abhishek Gargya, Vansh Rana, Sushant Mahajan, Preeti Khera
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: This is the first study to systematically evaluate AIcontent detectors using dual-direction adversarial edits across multiple genres while simultaneously addressing the ethical gray zone of human-AI collaboration. Nevertheless, there is a critical research gap, as the current literature fails to cover the Gray Zone of the human-AI collaborative authorship and does not have dual-sided adversarial appraisal methods. This study addresses the question raised in the current literature Should the text be considered AI-generated if the AI is used for minor edits. Our two-way evaluation simultaneously evaluates AI-to-human and human-to-AI adversarial changes, applying targeted and strategic changes in order to make human text look like it was produced by AI and the reverse as well with existing commercial AIDetectors as a representative system. The outcomes demonstrate how challenging it is to spot instances of collaborative authorship because even minor typographical adjustments or paraphrases reveal serious flaws in the detection techniques currently in use. Additional algorithmic constraints can be seen in the systemic variation in performance between content types as further shown by genre-specific analysis. The study shows that authorship problems continue even after grammar and style corrections, suggesting that the binary classification method is not effective to capture the complexity of modern human–AI collaboration. Apart from technical criticisms, we also draw focus on practical consequences like academic sanctions for valid work and concerns brought up by institutional policies. It is confirmed by statistical validation that these are systematic limitations rather than problems with implementation. The findings indicate that binary classification is inadequate and that detection tools ought to be reconceptualized as interpretive instruments requiring spectrumbased classifications and human oversight.

title: Explainable Machine Learning Framework for Heart Disease Prediction Using SHAP-Based Feature Optimization
authors: Manikandan A, Vaishak T, Mohammed Sham Saleem
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Cardiovascular diseases, particularly heart disease, remain the leading cause of global mortality. The combination of Machine Learning (ML) techniques into healthcare diagnostics offerings a hopeful solution for timely and precise disease prediction. This study recommends a complete ML framework for heart disease classification using two real world clinical datasets. The methodology includes data preprocessing, multi-model evaluation including SVM, Logistic Regression (LR), Decision Tree (DT), Random Forest (RF), and K-Nearest Neighbours (KNN) and overfitting detection over practical threshold analysis. Highlighting recall as a critical performance metric, the framework prioritizes minimizing false negatives, which is crucial in life threatening conditions. The novelty of this work lies in the integration of Shapely Additive explanations (SHAP) for post-model feature importance analysis and optimization, enhancing model interpretability and efficiency. Models showing high recall and no signs of overfitting undergo SHAP-based feature refinement evaluation metrics can significantly improve clinical trust and deployment readiness of AI models for heart disease prediction.

title: Intelligent Framework for Open Source Software License Verification and Compliance
authors: Mansi Bhonsle, Suresh Kapare, Rekha Sugandhi, Rajneeshkaur Sachdeo
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Modern digital ecosystems rely heavily on Open Source Software (OSS), but maintaining license compliance is still a major and unsolved problem. Current approaches rely on either manual audits, which are expensive, sluggish, and prone to error, or automatic scanners, which frequently fail with dual or bespoke licenses. Businesses, entrepreneurs, and academic institutions are exposed to serious legal, financial, and reputational concerns as a result of this divide. This project suggests a multi-layered OSS License Verification Framework that incorporates human-in-the-loop learning, logical reasoning, evidence-based validation, provenance tracking, and cryptographic assurance in order to overcome these constraints. To establish technical ground truth, the system starts with SBOM and SPDX provenance data, builds an attestation graph, and uses binary inference and differential tracing. License requirements are represented as vectors of obligations, assessed using a constraint solver and validated using zero-knowledge proofs (zk-proofs) to give auditors reliable proof of compliance. A human oracle ensures adaptation to changing license ecosystems by resolving ambiguities and continuously enhancing the knowledge base. The suggested framework seeks to provide an end-to-end, intelligent, and auditable solution for OSS licensing compliance by fusing automation with verifiability and adaptability. The results will help a variety of stakeholders, such as businesses looking to reduce risk, startups seeking quicker innovation, and academic institutions using OSS responsibly, all of which will contribute to a more secure and reliable opensource ecosystem.

title: A Robust Defense Mechanism Design for Side-Channel Attacks Cover Cloud E-Health Environments
authors: C. Lakshminatha Reddy, K. Malathi
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Cloud-based e-Health systems have transformed modern healthcare by offering scalable access to electronic health records (EHR), medical imaging, and remote diagnostics. These systems are however becoming more susceptible to side-channel attacks, which are based on micro architectural leakages including cache timing, memory access patterns and electromagnetic emanations. Conventional cryptographic protection and access control systems do not have the capacity to ward off these covert data exfiltration channels. This research proposes an effective multi-layered defense system that is specifically designed to curb the threats posed by side-channels in cloud-based healthcare systems. The proposed system will combine dynamic runtime obfuscation, deep learning-based anomaly detection and blockchain-based audit trails with federated learning of adaptive response to threats. A hybrid LSTM-CNN autoencoder is used to make predictions on normal system behavior using side-channel telemetry allowing the identification of subtle deviations with a high sensitivity. Obfuscation mechanisms like cache flushing, noise inj ection and randomized scheduling are activated when they are identified, to tamper with attack vectors on-the-fly. Lightweight blockchain records all security events in a way that enables forensic traceability, and federated learning ascertains that defense models are developed without centralizing the sensitive data. The framework proves to be effective in an experimental setting of simulated e-health cloud environment. The system proposed has a detection accuracy of 97.66, which is higher than base formulations of CNN, LSTM, and classical classifiers. The design is operationally efficient and has low overhead resources. These results lay the groundwork of proving the feasibility of AI-based, privacy-sensitive security architectures in the future e-health ecosystems. The framework has a potential in its implementation in telemedicine, PACS, and real-time applications of clinical-monitoring with the help of IoT.

title: TAGGATMA: An AI-Powered E-Learning Platform for Informal and Personalized Vocational Training of Talibés in West Africa
authors: Birahim Babou, Khalifa Sylla, Samuel Ouya
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: TAGGATMA is a digital learning platform based on artificial intelligence, designed to promote the professional integration of talibés in West Africa. It combines an intuitive mobile environment with open source technologies (Moodle, BigBlueButton) and generative AI models such as ChatGPT, to offer a personalized pathway for learners from informal education. TAGGATMA integrates an intelligent tutoring system, pedagogical recommendations based on learning data, and realtime tracking. This project is part of a wider dynamic of inclusive digital transformation, directly linked to our doctoral research. Initial deployments are showing a positive impact on the engagement and skills development of young beneficiaries. This contribution is aligned with the Smart Learning Environment, Personalized Teaching and Artificial Intelligence in Education themes.

title: Eco Build AI: An Intelligent MCDM–TOPSIS based Sustainability Assessment Platform for Construction Projects
authors: P. Senthilraja, R. Madhumithra, O. Obu Sharvadharshini
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Eco Build AI is an intelligent sustainability assessment platform designed to evaluate the environmental performance of construction projects and provide actionable recommendations for improvement. The system has incorporated a Multi-Criteria Decision Making (MCDM) model that employs the TOPSIS (Technique for Order Preference by Similarity to Ideal Solution) method for the purpose of measuring sustainability along nine major criteria, which are: emissions embodied and operational, material reuse, renewable energy use, waste reduction, urban sustainability, energy efficiency, and carbon footprint share. A synthetic dataset of 100,000 projects, combined with policy-driven carbon reduction data, is used to train the model and generate thresholds for Low, Medium, and High sustainability classifications. The platform offers an interactive Stream-lit based dashboard where users can input project parameters, receive real-time TOPSIS scores and classifications, visualize carbon and energy metrics, and explore AI-generated recommendations for enhancing sustainability.

title: Recommendation System with Negative Correlation Learning and Re-ranking Mechanism
authors: Ran Zhang, Yating Li, Jie Wang, Haifeng Yang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Social media platforms enhance user engagement and platform activity by providing precise recommendations based on users' historical browsing behavior to meet their immediate needs. However, this approach lacks the expansion of interest diversity, leading to the echo chamber effect where users struggle to access new, potentially interesting content. To address the balance between accuracy and diversity in recommendation systems, we propose the NC2R algorithm (Negative Correlation Re-ranking Recommendation System). This algorithm optimizes the Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) model with a negative correlation mechanism, encouraging the model to focus on dissimilar items, thereby enhancing recommendation diversity. Additionally, a re-ranking mechanism is applied to prioritize recommending items that are less similar to users' historical preferences, further boosting recommendation diversity. Furthermore, local sensitive hashing and the Mamba algorithm are employed to accelerate the computation of item similarities and dissimilarities, ensuring efficiency on large-scale datasets. Experimental results demonstrate that NC2R significantly improves recommendation diversity while maintaining high accuracy across multiple real-world datasets.

title: A Robust Space Object Tracking Algorithm Fusing Motion Estimation and Re-detection
authors: Fujun Huang, Yifei Yao, Tao Lei, Bo Cheng, Yi Cui, Haiyang Zhang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Accurate and reliable tracking of on-orbit spacecraft is very important for the safety of space assets. However, space-based observation often faces challenges such as complex backgrounds, changing target poses, and long periods of occlusion. These conditions can cause traditional algorithms to fail because of model contamination. To solve these problems, this study presents a robust tracking algorithm that combines motion estimation with a re-detection mechanism. The process starts with target detection, using a dynamic frame differencing algorithm that mixes adaptive background registration with temporal voting. In the tracking phase, based on the hand-crafted feature version of Efficient Convolution Operators (ECO-HC) tracker, we use a dual-metric online evaluation method. This method is based on Peak to Sidelobe Ratio (PSR) and feature similarity, and it is closely integrated with a Kalman Filter.When the tracking confidence is high, the tracking model is updated and the filter is corrected. When the confidence is low, we stop updating the model to avoid contamination. Instead, the target’s trajectory is determined by the filter’s predictions. If the target is lost for a long time, the re-detection module starts automatically.To test how well the algorithm works, we created the "Space Object Tracking Dataset". Experimental results show that our algorithm is much better than baseline methods in both precision (82.6%) and success rate (72.9%). It has strong robustness, especially when there is total occlusion of the target. Besides, the algorithm can achieve real-time tracking speeds (65.6 FPS) on both our own dataset and the public UAV123 dataset. This proves that it exhibits significant potential for practical application in space missions.

title: Numerical Calculation of Convective Heat Transfer in the Boundary Layer of Tunnel Fire Smoke Based on FDM
authors: Zhequn Zhu, Weifeng Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: The convective heat transfer from hot smoke in tunnel fires poses a significant threat to the structural integrity of tunnel linings and internal components, representing a major concern for thermal safety in underground spaces. To address this issue, a finite difference method (FDM)-based algorithm is designed to accurately resolve the temperature gradient within the smoke boundary layer adjacent to tunnel walls during fires in this paper, thereby enabling precise analysis of convective heat transfer intensity. The challenges associated with conventional computational fluid dynamics (CFD) methods are circumvented effectively in this approach, such as mesh generation difficulties and high computational costs when resolving thin boundary layers. The proposed FDM algorithm couples and solves the Navier-Stokes equations and the energy conservation equation within the boundary layer. A novel wall function is introduced, which incorporates an additional wall cell influenced by both the near-wall fluid temperature matrix and the internal solid wall temperature matrix. This formulation allows for a more accurate prediction of the wall temperature gradient. Comparative validation against results from the Fire Dynamics Simulator (FDS) demonstrates that the proposed algorithm achieves high accuracy in predicting temperature gradients while significantly reducing computational cost. The feasibility of the FDM approach is confirmed as an effective supplementary tool for addressing small-scale boundary layer problems by these findings.

title: Quantum Simplicial Attention Convolutional Neural Network Integrated with Brown Bear Optimization for Autonomous Navigation Systems
authors: Sujay Gejji, Rashmi S, Thanuj Kumar M, Daxa Vekariya, Natrayan L, S.SriRagavi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Autonomous vehicle navigation requires finely calibrated environmental awareness, resilient onboard deliberation, and continual, near-instantaneous adaptation to evolving roadway behaviours. Current deep learning frameworks achieve strong scores on perception benchmarks, yet their propensity to overlook nonlinear spatial–temporal couplings—coupled with mandated low-latency constraints—remains a fundamental safety liability in actual driving contexts. To mitigate this gap, the present work introduces a hybrid architecture that overlays a Quantum Simplicial Classical Attention Convolutional Network (QSCACN2Net) with a Brown Bear Optimization Algorithm (BBOA), thereby achieving dual improvements in navigational efficacy and reliability. The QSCACN2Net component leverages quantum-classical hybrid propagation and simplicial attention blocks to isolate multidimensional environmental couplings. By combining sub-millisecond feature resolution with coherent ingestion of panoramic vehicular and atmospheric context, the architecture assimilates relevant information across disparate magnitudes of environmental structure. Simultaneously, the BBOA mimics seasonal hibernation metabolic patterns to design hyperparameter search; this biologically inspired mechanism secures accelerated convergence and pronounced robustness with minimal expansion of the hyperparameter search space. Validate the proposed architecture on the benchmarking KITTI dataset, reporting statistically relevant improvements in absolute error, quantifiable reductions in mean pixel perturbation measurements, and tightened end-to-end latency regimes that exceed existing state-of-the-art solutions. Combinatorial analysis of the experimental results substantiates scalable deployment, illustrating that the architecture satisfies the stringent maintainability, safety, and resource operability criteria demanded by future production-grade autonomous driving frameworks.

title: Comparative Review of Deep Learning and Machine Learning Models for Lumbar Spondylolisthesis Diagnosis
authors: Aman Kumar Singh, Manish Kumar Singh, Nikita
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Lumbar Spondylolisthesis is a very common and prevalent spinal disorder in which one of the interior vertebral slips over another adjacent vertebra. It is a progressive and chronic disorder and early diagnosis can be used to avoid surgical treatment. This paper examines a systematic review of 21 research studies, covering AI methods developed for diagnosis of lumbar spondylolisthesis. The aspects highlighted in the review include methodology, size of data, algorithms employed, and the accuracy attained. The study talks about the application of computer-assisted systems and ML or DL based models especially CNNs in doing detection, classification and measurement tasks. The review also highlights key challenges, including the lack of large public datasets, reliance on private institutional data and limited focus on measurement and grading. Finally, future research should explore hybrid systems that integrate all AI tasks to provide a complete diagnostic pipeline for clinical use.

title: SkinScanNet Deep Learning Framework for Early Detection of Skin Cancer from Dermoscopic Images
authors: Kathlin P, Golden Nancy R, Christina Magneta S, Shane Jude Kiso L
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: SkinScanNet is a deep learning network, which was trained on earlier detection of a skin cancer on the basis of dermoscopic images. These three objectives of this paper are: (i) developing a strong deep learning-based DenseNet201 architecture to identify dermoscopic images by six clinically significant among them, (ii) determining the diagnostic accuracy and reliability of the framework with regard to benign and malignant disease, and (iii) developing a usable web-based screening tool to be applied in clinical practice. The sample size was 10,015 dermoscopic images which were balanced between 6 types of lesions and include: Actinic Keratosis (ACK), Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC), Melanoma (MEL), Nevus (NEV), Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC) and Seborrheic Keratosis (SEK). The model offered the overall accuracy of 94.86, macro averaged F1score of 93.42, and area under ROC curve (AUC) of 0.974. It had a sensitivity of 95.7-class wise with Melanoma and 94.2-class wise with Basal Cell Carcinoma. The findings showed that SkinScanNet can be regarded as a clinical decision-support system to identify the malignant lesions of the skin in their initial stages since the results of the classification are reliable and dependable.

title: Signal Integrity Optimization of LPDDR5X Memory Interface Operating at 9.6 Gbps
authors: Kumar Vijender, P K Seema, Kumar Sanjay, Mutnury Bhyrav, Manjunath Shivappa, Nisarg Modi, Chun-Lin Liao
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Electromagnetic Interference and Compatibility (INCEMIC)
abstract: The increasing demand for high-performance computing, machine learning systems, and mobile applications have driven the need for faster and more efficient memory technologies. To meet this demand from industry, LPDDR5X has become the dominant low-power DRAM interface, enabling data rates up to 9600 MT/s and beyond. While LPDDR5X delivers significant improvements in bandwidth and power efficiency, its high signaling speed and reduced voltage margins impose severe challenges to signal integrity (SI). In this paper, SI challenges related to operating on an LPDDR5X channel are discussed. Various channel variables are used to demonstrate numerous challenges. The scenarios covered in this paper include the impact of breakout length, via coupling, via backdrill, the impact of trace length, and the impact from the connector or socket.

title: Graph Neural Network-Based Prediction of Drug Side Effects via Gene Expression and Pathway Interaction Modeling
authors: R. Shebal Pricilla Chrysolite, M. Sushmethaa, V. Muthulakshmi
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Anticipating harmful effects of drugs, or side effects, continues to be a huge problem in pharmacology; at the same time, developing computational models mostly through either chemical structure alone or static embedding which limit the biological interpretability of such models.
