We have developed a multi-component, pathway-aware graph neural network (GNN) framework combining graph convolution nodes (GCN), graph attention networks (GAT), and a multi- layer perceptron (MLP) for predicting side effects from drugs. Drug-gene expression profiles can be mapped to curated biological pathway graphs (i.e., Reactome) which illustrates the propagation of gene perturbation through regulatory circuitry to generate initial dynamic, context-aware representations of drugs. For multi-label classification, the predictive module predicts the likelihood probabilities of side effects emerging. By predicting with real biological pathways, we surpassed structure-based only methods, and provided biological insights into how drugs may be toxic.

title: Leveraging Time-Series Foundational Model for Student Dropout Prediction: A Comparative Study
authors: Niccolò Ciucci Colli, Guido M. D’Amely Di Melendugno, Stefano Faralli, Damiano Distante
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: Online courses, ranging from fully online degrees to Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs), have expanded access to higher education but continue to suffer from extreme dropout rates. Accurate and timely prediction of disengagement is crucial for enabling targeted interventions, yet most existing student dropout prediction (SDP) systems rely on domain-specific models trained on individual course datasets, with limited generalisability across platforms and content types. This paper investigates whether UniTS, a domainagnostic Transformer for time-series data, can be effectively transferred to the task of dropout prediction in sparse, imbalanced educational logs. UniTS was originally designed to handle diverse time-series problems through a unified architecture and dynamic attention mechanisms, without taskspecific engineering. We evaluate multiple adaptation strategies, from supervised training from scratch, to full fine-tuning, to prompt-tuning, and inference-only. Three public datasets of markedly different scale, semantic richness, and class imbalance are considered: XuetangX, KDDCup15, and Unitelma. Results show that a five-epoch fine-tuning of the supervised UniTS checkpoint achieves a mean AUC of 0.944 and F1 of 0.753, outperforming both classical machine learning baselines (e.g., Logistic Regression, Random Forest) and deep sequence models (e.g., GRU-AE) across all datasets. Prompt-tuning retains much of the predictive power while reducing computational cost, highlighting the model’s flexibility for resource-constrained deployments. These findings demonstrate that temporal representations learned in unrelated domains can transfer effectively to educational settings, offering a reusable, high-performance foundation model for dropout prediction.

title: Topology-Dependent Transient Behavior and Resonance in Offshore Wind Farms: An EMT and Impedance-Based Study
authors: Priya Singh, Ramesh Rayudu, Praveen Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE PES 17th Asia-Pacific Power and Energy Engineering Conference (APPEEC)
abstract: The collector topology of offshore wind farms plays a decisive role in determining power evacuation efficiency, transient stability, and resonance susceptibility. This paper presents a comparative study of three representative topologies—Radial, DSR, and SG-Star for a 200 MW offshore wind farm composed of forty 5 MW turbines connected via 33 kV submarine cables. Time- and frequency-domain simulations were carried out to evaluate post-fault dynamics, fault ride-through performance, and resonance behavior of offshore wind farm collector topologies. The results show that under a three-phase fault at the terminal node, both radial and SG-star topologies disconnect the affected feeder, leading to similar power losses. In contrast, DSR sustains higher post-fault power through its dual evacuation paths. Dynamic analysis reveals that the SG-star provides faster recovery and stronger damping, while DSR enables smoother reactive current redistribution and reduced converter stress; radial exhibits weaker damping and higher oscillatory distortion. Frequency sweep and R–X analyses confirm that radial is most resonance-prone, with impedance peaks exceeding 3.64 kΩ in the 0.8–2.0 kHz band, DSR redistributes resonance energy but retains a sharp peak at 3.40 kΩ, and SG-star provides the lowest impedance amplification, 1.28 kΩ with compact resonance loops, although with vulnerability to low-frequency mode (0.47 kHz). Overall, the results highlight topology-dependent trade-offs, DSR offers resilience and reliability for medium-to-large projects, and SG-star topologies achieve superior damping for compact layouts, though requiring mitigation of low-frequency harmonics.

title: A Diversified Information Recommendation Algorithm Based on Information Cocoon Theory and Transformer
authors: Zihao Hong
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: In the information era, numerous social media platforms have developed their information recommendation algorithm to deeply shape user’ platform usage habits. While manifestly enhancing users’ stickiness towards the platform, they also exploit "information cocoon" theory, providing users with only single-interest, single-dimension, and single-perspective content. This leads to the radicalization and divergence in social values, exacerbating the "echo chamber" effect. In this paper, we adopt Transformer to optimize the existing information recommendation mechanism, With the focus on the comprehensive weights of information, we have improved the self-attention and cross-attention mechanism, thereby significantly increasing the information entropy. We also use a loss function to greatly guarantee that such optimization can still allow expected user stickiness. Through experiement, While effectively ensuring the information accuracy, our method aims to maximize the information diversity.

title: Neuro-Optimization Approach for Precision Agriculture: Remote Sensing-based Crop Disease Detection using Mycorrhized Tree Optimized Global Dense Spiking Neural Network
authors: Santhosh B J, Rajesh Kumar S, Madhu B. K, Vipul Vekariya, Natrayan L, M.SivaramKrishnan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Detecting crop diseases early is critical for ensuring food security and maximizing agricultural productivity. Crop Disease Detection (CDD) uses remote sensing for precision agriculture. Traditional methods are often time-consuming, labor-intensive, and prone to human error. To overcome these problems, this study suggests a Multilayer Global Dense Spiking Neural Network with Mycorrhized Tree Optimization Algorithm (MGDSN3Nets+MTOA) framework for Precision Agriculture and Remote Sensing in detecting crop diseases. The input data, sourced from the Beyond Visible Spectrum: AI for Agriculture 2024 dataset, is first preprocessed using the BitonicX Filtering (BXF) technique. Following preprocessing, feature extraction is performed through the Second-Order Synchroextracting Transform combined with Empirical Wavelet Transform (SSTC-EWT). The Crop Disease Detection is performed using Multilayer Global Dense Spiking Neural Network (MGDSN3Nets) architecture, which is further optimized using the Mycorrhized Tree Optimization Algorithm (MTOA). The proposed MGDSN3Nets+MTOA framework demonstrates outstanding performance, achieving 99.9% accuracy and a 99.8% specificity when evaluated on the Beyond Visible Spectrum: AI for Agriculture 2024 dataset. The entire model is implemented using the Python programming language and significantly enhances CDD capabilities using advanced remote sensing techniques. By integrating efficient preprocessing, robust feature extraction, precise detection, and effective optimization, the proposed method outperforms traditional diagnostic approaches in terms of accuracy, reliability, and computational efficiency within the domain of precision agriculture.

title: A Comprehensive Review of Innovative Approaches to Cyber Defense using Artificial Intelligence
authors: Havinash P H, M Rajeswari, D Brindha
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Securing computing devices and networks from cyber criminals is the main task of cybersecurity professionals. As the number and types of attacks increase, the task has become more challenging. The rate of cybercrime is directly proportional to the growth of technology. Internet, Cloud, Smart phone, Big Data, Internet of Things and Artificial Intelligence, contribute towards this exponential growth of cyber assaults. The tools of a cybersecurity professional also have to be sharpened to solve the issues related to this new generation cyber threat. Conventional tools can prevent already known attacks, but are not very successful in the case of unknown or innovative attacks. New tools integrated with emerging technologies have been proposed to solve this problem. Developments in Artificial Intelligence have attracted various domains towards it. Security professionals and researchers have also begun to use AI to sharpen their weapons. Research on AI for Cyber defense has succeeded in setting up a systematic approach to develop machine learning models that can predict attacks. However, a question arises about the efficiency and practical implementation of such models. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of advanced AI approaches utilized within the field of cybersecurity. It also highlights emerging directions for research in this domain and explores the existing challenges in improving these techniques to strengthen the robustness of cybersecurity systems.

title: An Analysis of Routing Protocols for FANETs: From AODV and OLSR to a Cluster-Aware Enhancement
authors: Safa Ferrah, Ibtihel Baddari, Abdelhak Mesbah, Amine Nouasri
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Innovative Applications (AIIA)
abstract: Flying Ad Hoc Networks (FANETs) have recently become a critical paradigm to support autonomous Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) cooperation in various applications. However, their high mobility and dynamic topology pose persistent challenges for reliable routing. This paper presents a structured classification of routing protocols based on their primary design objectives, emphasizing the emerging role of AI in adaptive decision-making. Within this framework, we conduct a comparative performance analysis of AODV, OLSR, and an enhanced hybrid OLSR+K-means protocol implemented in ns-3. The hybrid maintains OLSR’s proactive nature while improving stability through local features. Each protocol was tested under identical UAV network settings to ensure fair comparison and consistency. Simulations show about 23% lower delay, smoother jitter, and stable throughput with negligible overhead. These findings indicate that simple unsupervised clustering can provide a practical foundation for future intelligent and adaptive FANET routing protocols.

title: Criminal Operandi Prediction System (COPS): A Full-Stack AI Framework for Scalable Crime Intelligence
authors: Mary Joseph, Samuel N R, Nithishwar T
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Criminal investigations often involve sifting through large amounts of structured and unstructured data, such as case files, criminal profiles, accomplice connections, and behavioral patterns. Analyzing these records manually takes a lot of time, is prone to mistakes, and can be inefficient, especially in places with limited digital resources. To tackle these issues, we introduce COPS (Criminal Operandi Prediction System), a web application powered by AI. It allows law enforcement personnel to retrieve and analyze criminal data using just one input in natural lan- guage. COPS can extract important details like suspect names, 10- cations, crime descriptions, and partner information. It connects them to existing records through fuzzy matching and semantic analysis. The system shows relevant criminal history, methods of operation, relationships, and predicts likely behaviors based on past data. It is built with modern technologies, including React for the frontend, FastAPI and Python for backend logic, and MongoDB for flexible data storage. Designed to be deployed on- premise, COPS ensures complete data privacy while remaining usable without an internet connection. This paper discusses the architecture, workflow, and implementation of COPS, showing how it can speed up investigations, improve decision-making, and boost public safety through smart crime analysis.

title: Adaptive Energy Management in VANET based Smart Cities through Deep Q Learning
authors: M Angel Shalini, S Saranya, A Anuradha, S. Viji, E. Anitha, G. Prathap
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: Energy aware communication in Vehicular Ad Hoc Networks (VANETs) is essential to enhance the smart city’s sustainability. Conventional routing and resource allocation methods are not able to deal with highly dynamic and resource constrained characteristics of vehicular networks. This work proposes a reinforcement learning based Double Deep Q Networks (DDQN) with Prioritized Experience Replay (PER) approach for sustainable energy management in VANETs. The proposed system treats each vehicle as an independent agent that learns to optimally take various actions, such as tuning transmission power, choosing energy efficient routes, and offloading content to roadside units, according to the observed network state including battery levels, vehicle locations, and channel conditions. The structure is comprised of state encoder, DDQN+PER agent for stable and prioritized training and action executor. Simulation results for multiple traffic densities reveal the substantial performance advantages over traditional schemes like AODV, standard DQN, and greedy heuristics. The DDQN+PER model reduces the average energy consumption by 23.5%, enhances the packet delivery ratio by 14.2%, and decreases the communication delay by 17.8%. These results support the effectiveness of the proposed approach to facilitate adaptive and energy aware communication strategies, and its promising perspective to contribute to the establishment of smart sustainable vehicular networks in the smart cities of the future.

title: Enhancing Law Enforcement with a Blockchain-Based Biometric System for Secure and Efficient Suspect Identification
authors: E. Leelavathi, K. Anuratha, Manoj Kumar D, Akash S, Balaji J
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: In contemporary law enforcement, tracking and identifying the efficiency of criminals is significant. The absence of a streamlined system to link forensic evidence, such as fingerprints and criminal records, hampers investigative efforts. Current methods are unorganized and make it difficult to find relevant information quickly. This project aims to address these issues by developing a comprehensive system that seamlessly integrates forensic data to provide accurate information on individuals with criminal records. The system is built using a React Native front-end for a cross-platform mobile application, whereas the back-end, developed with Node.js and Express.js, ensures fast and reliable data processing. MongoDB is used for dynamic storage, and blockchain technology (Ethereum) guarantees data integrity by preventing tampering. Forensic analysis is enhanced using machine learning algorithms (CNNs and random forest) for fingerprint recognition and anomaly detection. The system also employs secure authentication mechanisms, such as JWT and OAuth 2.0, to ensure authorized access. Developing a system to provide information about criminals using forensic data such as fingerprints and other physical evidence. In addition, the project can contribute to the advancement of forensic technologies, ensuring that evidence is processed and analyzed efficiently and securely.

title: Design and Implementation of a Secure Online Test Environment Using Real-Time User Verification
authors: Vishakha Shinde, Pratham Mewada, Jainish Kotadia, Shivam Patel
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: With the recent surge in online education, students around the world have gained unprecedented access to learning opportunities. However, this shift has also made it harder to keep remote exams fair and secure. Old-fashioned proctoring methods just don't work as well in a virtual setting, and as more assessments move online, there's a real need for security solutions that are both reliable and easy for students to use. That's why we created SecuCode-a system designed to help maintain academic honesty during online exams without adding unnecessary stress or complexity for students. SecuCode starts with a simple PIN login, making it easy for students to get started while still confirming their identity. Once the exam begins, the system uses real-time facial recognition to make sure the same person stays present throughout the test. What really makes SecuCode different is its strike-based monitoring approach: if a student's face disappears from the camera too many times, the exam is automatically submitted. This way, the system discourages cheating but also understands that honest mistakes can happen. Our goal with SecuCode is to create a secure, respectful online exam experience that supports both students and educators as online learning continues to grow.

title: From Reflection to Action: Conceptual Design of a Critical Systems Heuristics Implementation Framework for Energy Transition Planning
authors: Alireza Maheri
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Environment Friendly Energies and Applications (EFEA)
abstract: Energy transition projects often rely on optimisation tools that prioritise technical and economic performance while overlooking ethical, social, and epistemic dimensions. This paper introduces the Critical Systems Heuristics Implementation Framework (CSHIF), designed to embed reflection, participation, and legitimacy within digital planning environments. The framework maps the 12 boundary questions of Critical Systems Heuristics to corresponding CSHIF functions and seven design principles that guide inclusivity, traceability, transparency, accountability, and reflexivity. It is structured around four integrated modules, namely, Stakeholder Identification, Governance Framework, Performance Indicator, and Model Bridge. Working in conjunction with conventional design, optimisation, and decision-support systems, the CSHIF provides a participatory layer that links stakeholder values, governance structures, and analytical models, enabling transparent, legitimate, and adaptive approaches to energy transition planning processes.

title: BNN-FourierNet: A Bayesian Spectral Framework for Community Detection and Uncertainty-Aware Optimization in Green Energy Systems
authors: Daozheng Qu, Yanfei Ma
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: The rapid growth of renewable and distributed energy resources has transformed traditional power systems into dynamic, networked ecosystems that demand intelligent modeling, adaptive control, and uncertainty-aware optimization. This paper presents BNN-FourierNet, a Bayesian spectral framework that integrates Bayesian Neural Networks (BNNs) with Fourier-based graph community detection for resilient and interpretable green energy management. In BNN-FourierNet, node-level temporal profiles of prosumers, storage units, and loads are transformed into spectral representations through Fourier decomposition, capturing both structural and frequency-domain correlations. A spectral community detection module then identifies self-sufficient energy clusters using an energy-aware modularity criterion, while the Bayesian neural layer quantifies epistemic and aleatoric uncertainties in load and generation forecasting within each detected community. The inferred uncertainty distributions guide a downstream optimization engine for demand scheduling and renewable integration, achieving energy balance with minimal transmission losses.

title: From Play to Proficiency: Investigating the Effectiveness of Digital Game-Based Learning in Junior High School Vocabulary Development
authors: Miranti, Lusi Nurhayati, Iswan Maujud, La Ode Ilan
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: Vocabulary plays an important role in language acquisition, yet it is often a significant challenge for learners of English as a foreign language, especially when traditional methods do not successfully engage students or support long-term retention. To address these challenges, this study explores the potential of Digital Game-Based Learning (DGBL) as an innovative approach to enhance vocabulary development among junior high school students in an EFL context in Indonesia. Using a pre-experimental, one-group pretest-posttest design, the study was conducted with 27 eighth-grade students at SMP Negeri 13 Yogyakarta. The participants underwent a series of DGBL sessions over four class meetings, where vocabulary games such as Kahoot, Baamboozle, and Wordwall were integrated into the teaching. Pre-test and post-test scores were analyzed using SPSS to measure the impact of the intervention. The results showed a marked improvement in students’ vocabulary acquisition, with the mean score increasing from 68.6 to 87.7 and a significant decrease in score variation. T-tests confirmed that the difference between pre- and post-test results was statistically significant, underscoring the effectiveness of DGBL. The findings suggest that incorporating digital games into vocabulary instruction not only increases student engagement but also yields measurable academic gains. This study contributes empirical evidence to the growing body of research on technology-enhanced language learning and provides practical insights for educators seeking to foster more interactive and effective vocabulary instruction in EFL classrooms.

title: Comparative Analysis of Battery Charging and Storage System for EV Charging System
authors: Kumaran K, Lingeswaran V, Premkumar R, Rajesh Kumar E, Sathish Kumar D
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Electric vehicles' (EVs') explosive rise emphasizes how urgently dependable energy storage and effective charging solutions are needed. When combined with renewable energy sources like solar power, traditional charging methods can encounter issues including lengthy charging periods, shorter battery lifespans, and uneven performance. In order to assess the effectiveness, dependability, and sustainability of various battery technologies and charging techniques, this project compares them. Alongside charging methods including solarassisted maximum power point tracking (MPPT) and constant current/constant voltage, lithium-ion, lithium iron phosphate (LFP), and lead-acid batteries are examined. The study focuses on important factors such energy losses, storage capacity, charging efficiency, and adaptability to the integration of renewable energy. Performance insights from simulation and experimental assessments help determine the best battery type and charging technique for practical EV applications. The findings are intended to aid in the creation of sustainable and reasonably priced EV charging infrastructure.

title: DriveMind: A Machine Learning Algorithm for Driver Safety Score Prediction
authors: A.Elakya, D.Gunapriya, Mahalakshmi P, Ananthalakshmi C, Haarish Santhan G
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Two of the leading causes of road traffic accidents in the entire world include driver fatigue and reckless driving. The present paper is regarding one such machine learning model DriveMind that predicts a continuous driver safety score through behavioral and telemetry data. The model is developed in a Python on Google Colab and utilizes Random Forest approach, which was opted due to its ability to cope with non-linear relationships. A dataset of 5,000 driving behavior samples with a variety of driving-related variables is used for training. Strong predictive accuracy is demonstrated by the model's performance as measured by important regression metrics, like the MAE, R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, and RMSE. In order to provide real-time driver monitoring and improved road safety, this work constitutes the DriveMind system's basic algorithmic development stage and offers a solid basis for future integration with Internet of Things (IoT)-based platforms.

title: Social Sentiment Insights Using Natural Language Processing
authors: Jatin Rawal, Devansh Raheja, Shivansh Raheja, Payal Thakur
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: In the age of unparalleled social media connectivity, this research demonstrates the transformative role of Natural Language Processing (NLP) in addressing social disparities through sentiment analysis. The increasing reliance on digital interactions necessitates a comprehensive understanding of the nuanced sentiments embedded in textual data across various platforms. This paper presents a novel framework that synergistically integrates multidisciplinary insights from social sciences with advanced NLP techniques, coupled with an intersectional analytical lens, to unveil, interpret, and mitigate inequalities. Our rigorous methodology involves systematic data collection, advanced preprocessing, and a hybrid sentiment analysis model designed to capture complex linguistic nuances. The empirical results not only reveal a profound impact on identifying disparities in socio-economic, cultural, and demographic dimensions but also highlight the ability of NLP to uncover hidden biases in language usage. These findings contribute significantly to the evolving discourse on the role of NLP in advancing social justice agendas, offering valuable, actionable insights for developing targeted interventions and policies in sectors such as healthcare, education, and public policy. Despite the promise of NLP, ethical considerations are paramount, and our system design explicitly incorporates bias mitigation strategies.

title: The Dynamic Resource Management in LoRa Agricultural Networks
authors: Jingjie Mu, Zhaoran Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: With the development of technology, smart information processing and antomatical control is widely applied in agricultural field. LoRa supports information transmission with low power and low costs. A dynamic channel scheduling algorithm is employed to enhance data transmission efficiency and network stability alongside an adaptive spreading factor selection strategy. Simulation results show that the method enables low-power data transmission across multiple green-link zones and improves overall intelligent management.

title: Memory Dropout GRU Architecture for Efficient and Generalizable Sequence Learning
authors: Shravan Kumar, B T Jeevith, K L Asthik, Rathishchandra Ramachandra Gatti, N Sri Haripriya Rai
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Computing, Semiconductor, Mechatronics, Intelligent Systems and Communications (COSMIC)
abstract: This study proposes an innovative recurrent neural network model employing the Memory-Dropout Gated Recurrent Unit (MD-GRU), which is aimed at enhancing the sequential data ML classification performance. The MD-GRU introduces two key modifications to the standard GRU: (1) dropout applied directly within the memory update pathway to mitigate overfitting, and (2) a learnable activation function to increase model adaptability. The MD-GRU model was evaluated on the UCI Human Activity Recognition (UCI-HAR) dataset and it is observed that this model achieves a remarkable classification accuracy of 95.08% for 50 epochs compared to the conventional GRU, with minimal additional computational cost. These results demonstrate that the proposed modifications improve generalization while maintaining efficiency, positioning MD-GRU as a promising approach for time-series analysis tasks.

title: NeuroFed-ResBiLSTM: A Federated, Neuromorphic-aware ResNet-BiLSTM Hybrid for Occlusion-Robust Edge Vehicle Detection
authors: T Sivaprakash, R Sarala
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: In edge computing contexts, precise and effective vehicle identification is essential for the development of autonomous driving and intelligent transportation systems. However, the strict processing limitations of edge devices, data privacy issues, and optical occlusions continue to pose a hurdle to this endeavour. In this research, NeuroFed- ResBiLSTM is presented as a novel system that addresses these issues by combining the fundamentals of neural computing, Federated Learning (FL), and a hybrid deep learning architecture. The suggested methodology improves occlusion resistance by using a Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) framework to model temporal interactions and contextual details after a ResNet-powered encoder extracts strong spatial features from graphic information. Data privacy is maintained at dispersed edge nodes through the use of a centralised learning framework in the decentralised training procedure. Additionally, neuromorphic awareness is integrated by refining the model for energy-efficient deployment on neuromorphic hardware and event-based visual processing. NeuroFedResBiLSTM outperforms a number of centralised and federated baselines, achieving a mean Average Precision (mAP) of 89.7% under strong occlusion conditions, according to extensive assessments on the KAIST and BDD100K datasets. Importantly, this methodology sets a new standard for robust, economical, and privacy-preserving vehicle perception at the edge by reducing energy usage by $4.7 \times$ and data traffic by $3.8 \times$ when compared to the conventional federated learning approaches.

title: ChatGPT as an Early-Stage Design Tool in Architectural Education: Pedagogical Uses, Constraints, and Implications
authors: John Paul P. Miranda, Jeffrey L. Pineda, Joanafel M. Mateo, Mark Anthony A. Castro, Alvin E. Camacho, Aileen P. De Leon, Charlie K. Padilla, Daryl Jay D. Pangilinan
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: This study examines how ChatGPT supports students during the preliminary and design development stages in architectural education. It focuses on the tool’s ability to help generate spatial layouts, suggest materials, and describe interior elements. ChatGPT helps students begin their design ideas and provides coherent text-based descriptions. However, it does not show clear spatial reasoning, follow specific design rules, or respond well to revisions. These issues limit its use in creating complete and acceptable design solutions. The study stresses the importance of reviewing AI-generated content carefully and using the tool only as a support under the guidance of instructors. Based on actual use in design tasks, the study presents several teaching suggestions for using AI in architecture classes. The results show that while ChatGPT can support early design thinking, it cannot take the place of professional judgment and formal design validation in architectural training.

title: Forecasting NVIDIA Stock Prices Using LSTM and Random Forest: A Comparative Study with XAI-Based KernelSHAP Interpretation
authors: Zhafira Oktaviani, Nughthoh Arfawi Kurdhi, Zailan Siri, Elayaraja Aruchunan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Technological Solutions (ICAITech)
abstract: A fundamental objective in the field of computational finance is the precise forecasting of market behavior, which provides considerable benefits for investors and financial analysts. The primary focus is forecasting the stock price of NVIDIA (NVDA), a key player in the technology sector. We develop and compare two machine learning approaches: Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), a deep learning model adept at capturing temporal dependencies in time-series data, and Random Forest, a robust ensemble learning method. Historical daily stock data, including Open, High, Low, Close (OHLC), and Volume, were used for training and testing the models. Performance was quantitatively evaluated using standard metrics such as Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), Mean Absolute Error (MAE), and the coefficient of determination. An Explainable AI (XAI) framework, specifically Kernel SHapley Additive exPlanations (KernelSHAP), is employed to provide transparency and interpretability to these “black box” models. The SHAP analysis revealed the key features influencing the forecasts of both models. By integrating high-performance forecasting with robust explainability, this research provides a more transparent, reliable, and actionable framework for financial analysts and investors.

title: Machine Learning for Loan Default Mitigation with Six Sigma
authors: Aadit Mali, Mayuresh Argulwar, Riddhi Mirajkar, Manisha Mali, Anushka Pardeshi, Swapnil Chaudhari
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: Financial institutions face serious difficulties as a result of the growing number of personal loan defaults, which affects economic stability, operational effectiveness, and profitability. Inaccurate risk analysis normally results from the traditional credit scoring approaches' ongoing inability to properly capture advanced borrower behaviour. This paper presents an integrated approach to improve forecast accuracy and reliability in assessing personal loan defaults through the combination of innovative Machine Learning (ML) algorithms with the Six Sigma DMAIC process. To reduce class imbalance, an extensive preprocessing of a dataset of more than 838,000 loan requests was performed, involving feature engineering, resampling, and careful data cleaning. Through model testing of various classification models, XGBoost emerged to outperform all the rest by attaining an accuracy rate of 88.19 %. An ensemble model of Random Forest, Logistic Regression, and XGBoost was constructed to further improve predictive performance, attaining equivalent levels of performance for defaulters and non-defaulters. Six Sigma measures such as Defects Per Million Opportunities (DPMO) and Sigma Level registered impressive process improvements from 2.5 to 3.96 and down to 7,000, respectively. In addition to enabling improved decision-making speed and accuracy, the proposed approach guarantees process stability, transparency, and flexibility through real-time monitoring and retraining. The proposed hybrid approach encourages risk mitigation, operational excellence, and enhanced customer confidence in financial lending operations by providing an extendable and highly reliable framework.

title: Comparative Assessment of Classical and Deep Learning Approaches for Bone Marrow Disease Detection
authors: S. Ramkumar, L. Charu Leela, G. Dharani, P. Kaviya, T. S. KavyaSree, S. Dhanasekar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Background: Early and proper discovery of bone. marrow disease is important because it enhances the survival of patients. determines effective treatment plans. Purpose: To plan effectively. do a comparison between Logistic Regression and ResNet50 to compare bone marrow accuracy, interpretability, computational cost, and clinical practicality. Methods Microscopic cell. pictures were gathered and categorized as being healthy or abnormal. In the case of Logistic Regression the features that will be used are to be crafted, as the shape of the nucleus, size, texture and color were extracted. ResNet50 on the contrary was directly trained. to acquire hierarchical feature representations on raw images. automatically. Findings: Logistic Regression found made interpret able predictions based on probability, but was restricted in recreating cellular variations. ResNet50 demonstrated and better quality and strength in detecting weak morpho- logical differences, though having greater computational requirements. In conclusion, Logistic Regression is simple and provides ease. interpretability, and ResNet50 offers predictive advanced. performance. ResNet50 is superior in terms of the cost of computation. fits actual clinical detection systems.

title: Autonomous Miniature Vehicle with Integrated Camera and Edge Computing for Military Surveillance and Reconnaissance
authors: J.Jeril Singh, N.A. Ashok, S. Ferdin, S.Samuel Aldeo, Vinayagam K
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: This paper introduced a self-contained miniature military surveillance and reconnaissance vehicle system that incorporated neuromorphic event-camera sensing, spiking edge inference, RF -assisted visual-inertial-magnetic SLAM, opportunistic LPI/LPD offloading, few-shot federated meta-learning and on-device differential privacy, physics-informed spectrum-transfer GANs for defeating camouflage, and bio-inspired micro-gimbal stabilization with adaptive micro-saccades. A zero-summation event-driven perception attained an average of 96.24% accuracy in the negative encounters of ten events that are at the verge of 1.60ms mean latency, 1.30 W power and 1.32% of the false alarms; at daytime, scanning kept a maximum of 98.6% and that at the starlight was 94.1 %. RF -assisted SLAM improved the average drift by 2.96% or to 1.54% with 1-2.4o heading error. The opportunistic offloading of the bursty and low-signature links produced an average 1.84% increase in accuracy (to 3.2%) on the challenging vignettes at an incremental offloaded subset latency of 57. 9ms. Federated few-shot adaptation increased both top-1 accuracy (90.1 up to 96.4) and new-class F1 (46.6 up to 94.3) and reduced expected calibration error (4.7 down to 1.3). The GAN-spectrum-transfer achieved a mean accuracy of 96.29% on dichotomous camouflage varieties, the highest being a result of 98.1 % on ghillie suits. Acute stability of the stack was maintained through fast performances of aggressive maneuvers that facilitated performance of strong perception-navigation coupling in microsecond time scales. Analysis demonstrated that combining neuromorphic sparseness with privacy-preserving adaptability and low-likelihood radiations furnished a low-signature system primarily able to discover its target reliably and navigate within bounds of drift in GPS-denied, nondescript visual, and electro-magnetically-contested environments

title: Optimal Trajectory Tracking Control for Uncertain Unmanned Surface Vehicle via Adaptive Critic Learning
authors: Huichao Wang, Pengda Liu, Jun Gou, Yunfei Mu, Huiyan Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Control and Computing Science (ICICCS)
abstract: In this paper, an optimal trajectory tracking control approach combining particle swarm optimization neural network and adaptive critic learning is proposed for unmanned surface vehicles with uncertainties and disturbances. The control law of the proposed method consists of feedforward control input and optimal feedback control input. Firstly, the feedforward controller is derived by using the sliding mode control based on saturation function to deal with the uncertain nonlinear dynamics and disturbances in the unmanned surface vehicle system. Subsequently, the optimal feedback control strategy is constructed using the critic-only adaptive dynamic programming, which reduces the computational complexity. To approximately solve the Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equation, the critic learning network based on particle swarm optimization algorithm is constructed to approximate the optimal value function. Finally, the simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Fault Detection and Isolation in Smart Grids Using IoT and Edge Computing
authors: K. Senthilkumar, P. Dass
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: The dynamic nature of smart grids requires more advanced maintenance techniques in addition to traditional reactive and time-based preventive techniques, which are frequently to blame for inefficient resource use, unnecessary downtime, and delayed problem discovery. Existing platforms are not particularly dependable these lack real-time analytical and forecasting capabilities. A predictive maintenance framework built on the Internet of Things (IoT) and Machine Learning (ML) is provided as a solution to the preceding issues. The proposed system uses a combination of real-time sensor data, aLong Short-Term Memory (LSTM)network for Remaining Useful Life (RUL) prediction, Isolation Forest for anomaly detection, and Random Forest for fault categorization. In these ways, it facilitates condition-based maintenance, intelligent decision-making, and early fault detection. Compared with existing systems, detective accuracy, precision, and recall improved to 92.6%, 90.8%, and 91.2%, respectively, with ephemeral recordings. When the average downtime was lowered from 6 hours to just 1.9 hours, it demonstrated that smart grid maintenance was more responsive, efficient, and reliable.

title: A Computer Vision Approach for Real-Time Tomato Mosaic Virus Disease Diagnosis
authors: Ajatray Swagat Bhuyan, Shaurya Vir Singh Pathania, Sanjeev Kumar, Suryakanta, Mohit Singh Bisht, Sneh Garg
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Tomato Mosaic Virus (ToMV) which is caused by the Tobamovirus pathogen severely impacts the plant health and also leads to the significant yield losses. The disease initially appears as the light and dark green mosaic patterns and leaf curling and the blister-like deformations on the leaves. In the advanced stages the infected plants exhibit the stunted growth, the fruit discoloration and the malformation reducing both the quality and the marketability. ToMV spreads rapidly through the mechanical transmission, the contaminated tools and even the seeds making it highly persistent in the agricultural environments. The farmers manage the ToMV through the resistant cultivars and strict sanitation practices for removal of infected plants to prevent spread. Since there is no chemical cure for viral infections, prevention through vector control (e.g., managing aphids) and the use of virus-free seeds are critical strategies. This study proposes a deep learning-based classifier to automatically distinguish between healthy tomato leaves and those infected with Tomato Mosaic Virus. Input images undergo preprocessing to enhance contrast and highlight key disease features. A fine-tuned GoogLeNet architecture is trained on an augmented dataset and effectively identifies disease markers such as mosaic patterning, leaf distortion, and chlorotic spots. The model achieves a classification accuracy of 100%, demonstrating its potential for early virus detection. The results highlight the viability of deep learning in precision agriculture, providing farmers with a tool for timely intervention and improved crop monitoring. Future work includes deploying this model in mobile and drone-based systems for real-time field diagnostics and integrating it with IoT-based farm management tools for automated disease surveillance.

title: Black-Mirror Light-Probe Cow Model For Specular Highlight Removal To Improve Holstein Cattle Identification
authors: Manu Ramesh, Amy R. Reibman
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: Computer-vision methods for identifying Holstein cattle based on their appearance depend on the correct distinction of the black and white regions on their coats. Bright specular highlights on black regions of cows could be registered as white regions, confusing the identification algorithm and leading to misidentifications. As a solution, we develop a per-pixel specular highlight removal method designed to handle non-uniform lighting from multiple illuminants on a per-scene basis. It is fast as it does not compute image statistics or use neural-network inference. It first segments and tracks a black, mirror-like object - a fully black cow - in a video of the scene, and then uses it as a light probe to map the scene illumination at the pixel level. This illumination map is then used to remove specular highlights on black regions of cows appearing at other times in the scene. Following this, we binarize the cow-pixels using a low threshold to separate the white regions from the black ones. When coupled with an available cattle recognition system, our method outperforms both the traditional and the recent deep-learning color-constancy methods, in improving recognition performance. Our method improves the performance of this cattle recognition system by almost 7%.

title: DeepExplain-CB: Explainable AI for MultiDimensional Cyberbullying Detection
authors: R Dhesigan, K Guna, C Kabilan, R Saranya
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: The intensive development of social media has increased the cases of cyber bullying, hate speech, and offensive material, posing a great challenge to the safety and welfare of the online community. Conventional automated detection systems are usually very accurate but are black boxes where there is little information on how they made their decisions. Such is the absence of transparency, which kills trust and accountability in content moderation. To overcome this shortcoming, DeepExplain-CB, which is an explainable AI model that aims to detect multi-dimensional cyberbullying has been presented in this research. DeepExplain-CB uses a BERTbased model to predict hate, offensive or neutral social media posts, and produces an interpretable explanation that identifies important linguistic features and contextual features that can drive that particular prediction. The framework is trained using a human annotated dataset which uses target groups as well as natural language rationale to make it both interpretable and inclusive. Through a combination of deep learning and explainable AI methods, DeepExplain-CB not only can keep the pace in detection performance, but also provides moderators, policymakers and researchers with the capability to interpret the logic behind model responses. The experiments conducted with real-world social media data show that the proposed method has a high degree of accuracy and produces humanreadable explanations, which allow conducting content moderation in a responsible and ethical manner. DeepExplainCB can be used as a starting point of further studies on creating reliable cyberbullying detection models, and underline the need to be transparent about AI-assisted social media analytics usage.

title: The Role of Parenting in Mitigating Problematic Social Media Use Among Adolescents: Insights and Interventions
authors: Parveen Shonak, Sumit Kushwaha
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Problematic social media use (PSMU) in adolescents has become a cause of increasing concern due to its possible negative impacts on the mental state, social interactions, and school performance. Parenting is the issue explored in this paper to discuss how parenting can reduce the risks linked to PSMU. Authoritative, authoritarian, permissive, and neglectful parenting styles are analyzed on the basis of their effects on the social media users of adolescents. The most effective among all forms of parenting in the prevention of PSMU is authoritative parenting that implies balanced incorporation of warmth and structure, and the authoritarian, permissive, and neglectful parenting styles affect high risks of problematic use. As well, the parental mediation techniques used are restricted mediation, active mediation, and co-viewing based on their effectiveness in regulating the social media consumption of adolescents. The result shows that active mediation characterized by unrestricted communication and direction has a significant negative impact on PSMU, whereas restrictive and co-viewing techniques lead to different results depending on whether they are carried out. The paper will conclude by emphasizing the need to adopt a holistic interdisciplinary approach that will involve positive parenting practices alongside digital literacy and emotional regulation educational programs. Parents can be key figures in reducing the risk of PSMU and developing more healthy digital habits because they can create a positive environment in the family and provide teenagers with the resources necessary to use media responsibly. The paper will be relevant to the academic knowledge of parenting as a determinant of social media consumption and formulate new interventions to mitigate the adverse impact of digital addiction among adolescents.

title: State Prediction and Fault Early Warning of Power Equipment Based on Variational Inference and Generative Models
authors: Yuping Yan, Jiaxin Lin, Yongjiao Yang, Ruiqi Li, Yuetian Huang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Power System and Energy Internet (PoSEI)
abstract: Safe operation of power equipment is essential, yet traditional threshold or statistical methods struggle under complex conditions with scarce fault data. This paper proposes a variational inference and generative model-based framework for state prediction and fault early warning, integrating VAE-GAN, SeqVAE, and CVAE-GAN, along with detection mechanisms based on reconstruction error, latent distribution deviation, prediction residuals, and multi-modal fusion. Extensive experiments conducted on wind turbine SCADA data, power grid PMU data, and nuclear plant operational data demonstrate that the proposed method significantly outperforms PCA, CNN, and standard VAE baselines in terms of AUC, F1-score, and Recall. Specifically, in early gearbox fault detection of wind turbines, the method achieved a Recall of 0.92 with up to 48 hours lead time; in grid short-circuit event detection, it provided warnings 3–5 seconds in advance; and in nuclear cooling pump anomaly detection, it achieved a Recall of 0.95. These results highlight the framework’s high accuracy, robustness, and strong early warning capability.

title: Research on Infrared Image Fault Detection Method for Composite Insulators Based on YOLOv8
authors: Hui Shi, Xiao Yang, Yanda Wang, Yongzhe Guo, Yun Xu, Wei Huang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Power System and Energy Internet (PoSEI)
abstract: Composite insulators play an essential role in power transmission lines by providing both insulation and mechanical support. However, surface defects such as contamination and cracks can lead to serious failures. To address the challenges of low resolution and high noise interference in infrared images, this paper proposes an improved YOLOv8-based algorithm that enhances feature extraction through dynamic convolution and a pyramid attention module (PAM). Experimental results show that the improved model achieves a mean average precision (mAP) of 95.84% on the composite insulator defect dataset, representing a 5.58% improvement over the original YOLOv8. The proposed method significantly improves the detection performance of small targets and low-contrast defects in complex scenes, providing an efficient solution for the intelligent inspection of power transmission lines.

title: Computer Vision-Driven Pavement Defect Detection Framework for Road Maintenance
authors: E. Afreen Banu, Shivani Hemraj Patil, Vandana Soni, PrithiKanaga Paul, D. Pavan Kumar, Shree Ram Malani
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: This paper presents a Computer Vision Based Pavement Defect Detection System, which aims at improving the efficiency and accuracy of a road maintenance system. The framework uses Multi-Scale Retinex using color restoration to fix illumination variations and enhance feature visibility when using different environmental conditions. The features that are extracted by a fused CNN - Vision Transformer system are sharpened with the help of mRMR (minimumRedundancy -Maximum-Relevance) to remove redundant data and save the most important features. A multi-task head Graph Convolutional Network is then used to predict pavement defects and assess its level of severity in relation to spatial correlations. PyTorch and PyTorch Geometric versions of the model were implemented and had an accuracy of 96.8 % and real-time inference of 27 FPS, which is efficient and scalable. The suggested framework offers a powerful, understandable, and efficient solution to intelligent road surface surveillance and prediction of maintenance decisions..

title: VeriFIR: An Assistant for Legal Complaint Analysis and BNS Section Recommendation
authors: Preeti Bailke, Renuka Deshpande, Akash Gadekar, Rutvik Gaikwad, Vipul Gejage, Sarthak Ghavate
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: The accuracy of First Information Reports (FIRs) is crucial to ensuring effective investigation and fair judicial outcomes in the Indian legal system. However, due to the absence of legal experts at police stations and the complexity of evolving legal frameworks, FIRs are often drafted with incorrect or missing legal sections. This challenge is further amplified by the recent introduction of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS), which replaces the Indian Penal Code (IPC) and remains largely unexplored in computational legal research. This study presents VeriFIR, an AI-powered legal assistant that automates the identification of relevant legal sections from the BNS based on natural language complaint inputs. The system supports multilingual inputs, applies translation and NLP techniques for preprocessing, and leverages fine-tuned transformer models such as MiniLM and LegalBERT to compute semantic embeddings. These embeddings are then compared against vectorized BNS section representations using cosine similarity, returning a ranked list of the most contextually appropriate legal provisions. Experimental results demonstrate the system’s ability to retrieve semantically aligned legal sections with high relevance and interpretability. VeriFIR offers a scalable, modular solution for enhancing the quality and consistency of FIR drafting, with potential applications across diverse Indian law enforcement contexts.

title: An Improved Brain Tumors Detection in MRI Images using Deep Learning Approach
authors: Prathika M, Dr.J. Praveenchandar, D. Linett Sophia
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: One of the most serious neurological conditions is brain tumors, and early and precise identification is essential to increasing patient survival. Although magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) offers comprehensive structural information, radiologists must manually interpret the results, which takes time and can be subjective. An enhanced multi-task deep learning system for brain tumor analysis is presented in this research. It uses a single architecture to conduct both tumor segmentation and multi-class subtype classification (glioma, meningioma, pituitary, and no-tumor). By integrating an EfficientNet-B0 encoder with a U-Net-based segmentation decoder and a classification head, the suggested model allows the network to concentrate on tumor-relevant regions while preserving interpretability through Grad-CAM visuals. To improve generalization and lessen overfitting, extensive preprocessing was used, including normalization, scaling, and data augmentation. According to experimental results, the model outperforms traditional single-task methods with a 96.2% classification accuracy and a Dice similarity coefficient of 0.91. The study demonstrates the potential of multi-task deep learning frameworks as trustworthy decision-support tools for radiologists, enabling quicker and more accurate MRI-based brain tumor identification in clinical situations.

title: IoT-Driven Smart Refrigerator Monitoring System with Predictive Spoilage Detection Using AI and Automated Alert Mechanism
authors: Yamuna S, Arthisree S, Hanisha, Bharathi Priya M, Anbarasi S
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: The explosion of Internet of Things (IoT) solutions in the smart home applications has transformed home appliance device management and made it energy-conserving, smart, and people-concentrated. Among the latter, the phenomenon of smart refrigerators as solutions to the problem of food preservation and lowering waste is gaining momentum in this regard. The paper proposes an IoT -based smart refrigerator monitoring framework that is integrated with a predictive spoilage alarm solution based on Artificial Intelligence (AI) and an alarm generation feature. The system is integrated with environmental sensors that monitor the temperature, humidity, and gases (ethylene and ammonia) and a door activity sensor, thus capturing real-time storage conditions. The use of RFID and computer vision (YOLOv5) provides complete merchandise tracking with packaged and unpackaged food items. A combination of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and Long short-term memory (LSTM) networks was constructed as a hybrid AI model and fed on multimodal datasets to make accurate predictions regarding spoilage. Overall, the proposed model resulted in a spoilage prediction accuracy of 92.9%, expiry detection accuracy of 95.0% and an energy optimization savings average of 22.9%. Local inference with low-latency and low power via ESP32-CAM, and cloud synchronization enabled enhanced analytics and long-term storage of data. The automated alert system combined with smartphone apps and smart speakers reduced the average user response time to less than 15 minutes, and that resulted in corrective measures in more than 80% of the cases. These findings indicate the possibility of using IoT -enabled AI systems to minimize food waste, improve the efficiency of households, and achieve sustainability. In addition to adding value in domestic food management, the system also creates a platform that can be used on a larger scale and industrial level of monitoring the cold-chain processes.

title: Swarm Intelligence-Augmented Federated Anomaly Detection in Decentralized Smart Grid Security
authors: Sudhakar Tiwari, Sandeep Dommari
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: In this paper, A hybrid intelligent swarm intelligence-federated learning is proposed for the decentralized smart grid anomaly detection. The approach directly applies the federated learning into the communication-efficient aggregation and therefore achieves the adaptively learned aggregation weights which contribute to accelerate the convergence rate and enhancing the performance on detection. Smart grid nodes train local models independently on non-IID, noisy data, with swarm algorithms providing guidance for global model updates according to client contribution quality. The scheme is capable of detecting standard cyberattacks, e.g., false data injection, denial-of-service attacks, and is also scalable over hundreds of clients, even with node dropouts and limited communication. Numerical results suggest faster convergence, fewer communication rounds and better anomaly detection performance than FedAvg. Visualisation of feature embedding using t-SNE2 (Maaten & Hinton, 2008) shows good separation between the benign and anomalous data. We show that swarmenhanced federated learning is a scalable, privacy-preserving and energy-efficient method for resilient smart grid security, which represents a huge leap in biological inspired cyber security for critical infrastructure networks.

title: Structural Design and Mechanical Analysis of a Six-Degree-of-Freedom Electrically Driven Underwater Manipulator
authors: Yining Wang, Xiong Deng, Yang Mou, Gang Zhang, Jiyin Cao, Xinming Xiong, Linfeng Li, Yanyang Wu
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotic Systems and Applications (ICRSA)
abstract: Underwater manipulators are among the core tools for small marine operation robots. However, existing products often suffer from insufficient degrees of freedom and low load-to-weight ratios, which limit their operational flexibility underwater and directly impact the stability and endurance of their host platforms. This paper presents the design and development of a novel six-degree-of-freedom electrically driven underwater manipulator that maximizes weight reduction while optimizing structural compactness, without compromising operational load capacity and workspace requirements. To validate the structural integrity and load-bearing performance, static and dynamic simulations were conducted under critical working conditions. Results demonstrate that the designed electrically driven underwater manipulator-with a 5 kg payload capacity, 36 kg self-weight, 70 mm maximum gripping dimension, 300 m operating depth, and joint motion ranges meeting target workspace requirements-employs reasonable structural parameters. This advancement provides a groundbreaking tool for small underwater robots to perform complex tasks.

title: Sentiscope: Toxicity-Based Comment Analysis Using NLP and Hybrid Deep Learning Models
authors: J. Dafni Rose, JB Paul Ibzhan, M B Meganth
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: The growth of harmful user-generated content necessitates automated moderation systems that can grasp linguistic subtlety. This paper introduces Sentiscope, a system for detecting online toxicity that addresses the critical distinction between overt, keyword-based abuse and covert, context-dependent insults. We propose a hybrid deep learning architecture that synergizes two powerful models: a BERT model, which reads entire sentences at once to understand a word's meaning from its full context, and an LSTM network, which processes text sequentially to track the flow of a sentence. This combined approach is engineered to capture the intricate dance of semantics and syntax that defines toxic communication. Through rigorous evaluation on a multi-label toxicity benchmark, our hybrid model markedly outperforms traditional machine learning baselines. Crucially, our analysis uncovers a significant performance gap: the model confidently identifies explicit threats but falters when faced with subtle insults that depend on sarcasm and subtext. This finding crystallizes a primary challenge in automated content moderation.

title: Digisign-A Smart Digital Signage System for Real-Time Event and Circular Display Management
authors: I. Gugan, Lavanya Laxmi M V, Saranya S, Priya Dharshini P, Nithya Shree, Harshini A
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Traditional paper-based noticeboards normally disrupt the effective communication of educational institutions as it is labor intensive, error prone and unfriendly to the environment. To conquer these challenges the proposed work includes a web-based administrative dashboard to schedule, assign priority and broadcast notices on the different devices on a real time basis. An upcoming Qr-enabled attendance monitor will provide new-level accuracy and security during the process of authenticating the participants at the event, and the dynamic scheduling of the content will allow institutions to make changes to the displays with urgency and significance. DIGISIGN offers offline caching to enable smooth displays even when the network is down, real time socket communication to deliver real- time updates and enable the drag and drop management of the content by non-technical administrators. The proposed work enhances student engagement through interactive rich content, is not demanding a lot a paper and is therefore more sustainable. Extensive testing was used to demonstrate the performance, synchronization and security of the system with different devices. Scalable to any large organization, DIGISIGN is not restricted to universities only but can be applied in corporate campuses, in buildings that are used by people and even in smart cities. It is a smart, dynamic and sustainable communication infrastructure in the future with AI-guided content recommendation, mobile app support and live streaming.

title: Detection, Analysis and Real Time Monitoring of Pollution Levels in Coal Mining and Quarrying Industry
authors: Chandini Sunil, Rajesh Kannan Megalingam, Aruna Devi
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: The mining process can cause environmental pollution in all its stages and has serious consequences for the health of people working at such sites as well as people that live in their vicinity. In this paper an IoT based solution for online detection, analysis and monitoring of pollution in those industries is developed in real time. The proposed system integrates sensors for weather monitoring (DHT11), water quality monitoring (pH sensor) and air quality assessment (MQ4 gas and flame sensor). ESP8266 NodeMCU is responsible for processing the sensor data and transferring real-time values to the mobile application through Firebase live data via Wi-Fi. It enables related stakeholders to act accordingly by taking necessary actions so they can get into risk mitigation mode quickly. It is of course different from conventional systems that require some sampling (often during the turnaround time and lead to exponential late responses), this is a preventative system that supports environmental safety and compliance.

title: Solar Power Tower Plants Considering Meteorological Dynamics - Safety and Reliability Optimization
authors: Hayder Al-Sarraf, Ahmed Alhusseny, Ramon Zamora
publish: 2025 IEEE PES 17th Asia-Pacific Power and Energy Engineering Conference (APPEEC)
abstract: Concentrating solar power plants (CSP) utilize sophisticated technologies to convert solar thermal power into electricity. Particularly, solar power tower plants (SPT) are very promising due to the high concentration ratio and the ability to deliver heat transfer fluid (HTF) at high temperatures. However, solar irradiance fluctuates during the daytime due to various atmospheric effects. That directly affects the thermal performance of the solar receiver, as well as the electric power produced and dispatched to the grid. Additionally, fluctuations in solar irradiance can lead to overheating issues in solar receiver tubes. To address the latter issue, this research proposes a solution by introducing a temperature control valve (TCV) that balances the steam flow distribution across superheater panels based on their respective tube wall temperatures. To guarantee operational safety and reliability, a series of optimization processes has been conducted to identify the optimal circulation factors (CF) between each opposing pair of superheater panels. The results show that the optimum circulation factors from the south to north panels, and between the east and west panels, are 0.25 and 0.1375, respectively. Such an approach contributes not only to decreasing the tube wall temperature below the maximum allowable limit but also slightly improves energy consumption and conservation. Hence, the optimized operation offers a reduction in the net power required to meet the turbine inlet conditions by 0.7731% and in the makeup ratio by 0.782%. Furthermore, the optimization approach ensures that the electricity production remains unchanged compared to the production without optimization, while improving the thermal efficiency of the solar receivers.

title: SkiDi-X: A Multistage Explainable AI System for Smart Skin Disease Diagnosis and Guidance Reality
authors: Budamcharla Venkata Naveen, Malathi Janapati, Finny Novel Balagam, Balabomma Sai Dinesh
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Skin diseases affect millions worldwide, where early and accurate diagnosis is essential for effective treatment. Limited access to dermatologists, particularly in remote areas, often delays proper medical care. This paper presents SkiDi-X, an advanced AI-powered skin disease detection chatbot that integrates ensemble deep learning, explainable AI, and conversational intelligence into a unified diagnostic system. The approach employs a fallback-based ensemble mechanism combining EfficientNetB0, DenseNet121, and ResNet50, ensuring reliable predictions even when model confidence is low. Trained on the HAM10000 and ISIC 2019 datasets, the models achieved accuracies of 89% (EfficientNet), 89% (DenseNet), and 88% (ResNet), demonstrating stable and high-quality performance. To promote transparency, Grad-CAM visualization highlights the key lesion regions influencing decisions, while a Dialogflow-powered chatbot delivers interactive explanations, possible causes, and suggested actions. By merging automated image analysis with human-like interaction, SkiDi-X provides an interpretable, accessible, and user-friendly platform that enhances the reach and impact of teledermatology in early skin disease assessment.

title: AFCEN: Adaptive Fusion and Contrastive Enhancement Network for Multimodal Aspect-Based Sentiment Analysis
authors: Lujuan Deng, Ruixue Wang, Zhenhua Lu, Yun Zhu, Zuhe Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: Multimodal Aspect-Based Sentiment Analysis (MABSA) aims to identify sentiment polarity toward specific aspects by integrating textual and visual information. However, existing methods suffer from insufficient cross-modal interaction and difficulties in aligning heterogeneous features. To address these challenges, we propose an Adaptive Fusion and Contrastive Enhancement Network (AFCEN). The framework integrates a Cross-modal Gated Attention Fusion (CGAF) module to capture fine-grained dependencies between aspect terms and multimodal sentiment cues, and a Graph-aware Heterogeneous Contrastive Module (GHCM) to enhance feature discrimination through graph-based semantic fusion and contrastive learning. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model achieves superior overall performance on two benchmark datasets.

title: Automated Software Flaw Estimation and Detection using Deep Learning
authors: C. Karthikeyan, V. Karthi, K. Vinoth, V. Adhithya, M. Ponkarthikeyan, D. Yogeshwaran
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: This research develops an automated system for deep learning-based estimation and detection of software flaws that enhance reliability and minimize vulnerabilities. It compares LSTM (Group 1) with Random Forest Regression (Group 2), where LSTM achieved 73.5 % accuracy with 45 samples, while RF attained 94.4 % accuracy with 56 samples. The dataset contains diverse software projects with annotated flaws. RF outperformed LSTM in terms of accuracy (91.40 %-94.40 % vs. <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$73.50 \%-78.30 \%$</tex>) and training time (315-330s vs. 400-430s) at a significance value of 0.000. The model proposed uses convolution layers for feature extraction purposes and fully connected layers for classification. RF also proves more effective in detecting flaws; it reduces its deployment risks and surpasses LSTM in terms of accuracy, efficiency, and adaptability. Thus, it has taken the position of the benchmark method in the real world.

title: Bunker Wall Crack Monitoring Technology for Coal Storage Inspection Robots
authors: Aijun Guo, Bin Wang, Xingyu Wu, Xuan Chen
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotic Systems and Applications (ICRSA)
abstract: As the core facility of coal mine production systems, coal bunkers play vital roles in coal transfer and buffer storage operations. Underground raw coal bunkers in particular serve as critical hubs for transporting coal from mining faces to surface facilities. During operation, the high-speed impact of coal chunks and hard materials like gangue against bunker walls creates significant safety hazards. The intense collision and friction not only risks structural integrity but also induces concrete wall damage including cracks and spalling, accelerating fatigue degradation and deformation instability of the bunker structure. To overcome the safety limitations and real-time deficiencies of traditional manual inspections, coal bunker inspection robots have developed an intelligent monitoring system integrating 3D point cloud modeling with thermal analysis: Equipped with high-precision LiDAR and infrared thermal imaging, the system enables millimeter-level crack detection through 3D reconstruction while identifying stress concentration zones via temperature field variations. This dual-mode data fusion technology significantly improves detection rates and positioning accuracy for hidden defects, providing an intelligent structural health monitoring solution that ensures inherent safety and continuous efficient operation of coal storage systems.

title: Investigation on Satellite-Image for Classification Using Intelligent Soft Computing Techniques- an Environment Approach
authors: Akanksha Sharma, Shakti Raj Chopra, Suhas Gajanan Sapate, Prashant Basavaraj Bhagawati, Keerti Raju Kanada
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: Satellite imagery has become a vital data source for a wide range of Earth observation applications, including land cover classification, disaster monitoring, and agricultural assessment. Satellite data is a useful tool for comprehending and controlling both natural and man-made ecosystems because of its capacity to collect comprehensive, large-scale photographs of the Earth's surface throughout time. Raw images collected from different sensors of satellites often contain distortion and inconsistency due to various factors, including atmospheric disruption, absorption, scene illumination, satellite orbit motion and geometrical distribution. An effective preprocessing technique is required to remove distortions from satellite images and enhance image quality, ensuring accurate analysis. This study proposes a comprehensive preprocessing algorithm aimed at enhancing the quality of satellite imagery databases by integrating data augmentation techniques and Kernel Principal Component Analysis (KPCA). The augmentation phase improves dataset diversity and model robustness by applying geometric adjustments like rotation, flipping, and scaling. KPCA is then used to reduce nonlinear dimensionality, keeping crucial spatial-spectral information while minimizing noise and redundancy. The combined technique improves model generality and efficiency, making it an effective strategy for satellite-based image analysis. This study also underlines the importance of secure IoT-based sensor networks in providing accurate real-time landslide monitoring.

title: ML2++: A Model-Driven Blended Framework for Automated Machine Learning, Time Series Forecasting, and Data Visualization in IoT Applications
authors: Zahra Mardani Korani, Thimoty Smet, Moharram Challenger, Armin Moin, Joao Carlos Ferreira, Alberto Rodrigues da Silva, Gonçalo Vitorino Jesus
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE 28th International Conference on Model Driven Engineering Languages and Systems Companion (MODELS-C)
abstract: Intelligent Internet of Things applications must seamlessly combine established software engineering practices with various machine learning (ML) and time series forecasting techniques. However, most pipelines today rely on handwritten code, which is error-prone and imposes a steep barrier for domain specialists. Domain-specific modeling languages (DSMLs), the backbone of model-driven engineering (MDE), address this complexity by allowing developers to describe systems at a high level, while tooling generates the executable code. To this end, we introduce the ML2 family of DSML frameworks. ML2 converts concise Textula models into complete Python pipelines for classification and regression ML models, autogenerating every preprocessing, training, and prediction script. Building on that foundation, ML2+ adds declarative, end-to-end support for time series forecasting: users can select any statistical (e.g., ARIMA or ETS), machine learning (e.g., SVR or XGBoost), deep learning (e.g., LSTM or Transformer), or hybrid (e.g., Prophet) algorithms and specify key settings, such as lag length or seasonality, without writing a single line of code. In addition, ML2++ enhances both textual and graphical workflows by providing an improved Textula editor alongside Sirius Web, an IDE drag-and-drop graphical modeling environment, and realtime dashboards; ML2++ automatically generates all relevant plots, including loss curves, autocorrelation functions, and forecast versus actual charts during preprocessing, training, and prediction for both ML models and time series forecasters. We validated the framework on two real-world cases, river flow forecasting and server crash prediction, showing faster development, fewer errors, and interpretable results compared to hand-coded workflows.

title: JFRFFNet: A Data–Model Co-Driven Graph Signal Denoising Model with Partial Prior Information
authors: Ziqi Yan, Zhichao Zhang
publish: IEEE Signal Processing Letters
abstract: Wiener filtering in the joint time–vertex fractional Fourier transform (JFRFT) domain has shown high effectiveness in denoising time-varying graph signals. Traditional filtering model uses grid search to determine the transform order pair and compute filter coefficients, while the learnable one employs gradient descent strategy to optimize them, both requiring complete prior information of graph signals. To overcome this shortcoming, this letter proposes a data–model co-driven denoising approach, termed neural network aided joint time-vertex fractional Fourier filtering (JFRFFNet), which embeds the JFRFT domain filtering model into the neural network and updates the transform order pair and filter coefficients through data-driven approach. This design enables effective denoising using only partial prior information. Experiments demonstrate that JFRFFNet achieves significant improvements in output signal-to-noise ratio compared with some state-of-the-arts.
