title: Deep Reinforcement Learning-based Cooperative Searching of Multi-AUV in Continuous Space with Uncertain Regions
authors: Zhao Wang, Wenjie Li, Jian Gao, Yimin Chen
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Cooperative searching for unknown targets is a significant challenge for multiple autonomous underwater vehicles (multi-AUV) in uncertain regions. While many existing studies discretize the searching space into small grids to accelerate planning, continuous space-based algorithms generate more adaptive searching strategies in dynamic environments. However, the complexity of the underwater environment and the need for multi-AUV coordination lead to inaccurate spatial modeling and exponential growth in computation time. To address these issues, this paper proposes a multi-agent continuous soft actor-critic (MACSAC) algorithm for underwater cooperative searching, employing a multi-agent deep reinforcement learning (MADRL) framework based on the soft actor-critic (SAC) algorithm. The multi-sensor cooperative detection model uses a probabilistic target representation based on Gaussian distributions, with Bayesian updating dynamically guiding the searching process. A dynamic dual-agent switching mechanism, which incorporates the MADRL framework, is designed with detection agents and detection-free agents. Moreover, the SAC algorithm is improved for continuous space to enhance cooperative searching efficiency. Simulations are conducted with four AUVs searching for an unknown target region in the underwater environment containing static obstacles. Results show that the proposed method produces smoother paths than discrete grid-based MADRL, and compared to existing continuous MADRL algorithms, reduces the average search steps by 50.70% and the sailing distance by 41.36%. These findings indicate that MACSAC enables efficient, collision-free path planning for multi-AUV systems operating in continuous, uncertain underwater environments.

title: Continual Learning with Memorized Dynamic Visual Description for Remote Sensing Scene Classification
authors: Rui Peng, Wenzhi Zhao, Liqiang Zhang, Kun Jia, Qiao Wang, Fengcheng Ji
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: The continual updating of data renders the design of model architectures time-consuming and energy-intensive when tackling diverse tasks, and it quite commonly confronts weak generalization performance, even leveraging fine-tuning or transfer learning. Furthermore, the model tends to be well adapted for the current task, whereas suffering performance degradation on previous tasks, namely, the catastrophic forgetting problem, whereas suffering performance degradation on previous tasks. Hence, there is an urgent demand to maintain models to learn new knowledge and alleviate knowledge forgetting, specifically, balancing the plasticity as well as the stability of the model during the continual learning process. To address the aforementioned challenges, we propose a dynamic visual description and playback mechanism that leverages deep feature clustering and memory across diverse tasks. The former extracts stable, invariant features by clustering typical visual characteristics of scenes, accounting for spatial patterns, seasonal variations, and lighting conditions, thereby enhancing the model’s comprehension of continuously evolving remote sensing scenes. The latter selectively memorizes features from specific samples to preserve historical model knowledge. This approach significantly strengthens the model’s capabilities, deepening its understanding of scene imagery while mitigating the forgetting of historical knowledge. We generate several sequence tasks on AID, RSI, NWPU, SEASONET and different scaled merged datasets to simulate the continual learning process across different resolution, seasonal variations and illumination change. Compared to the classical continual learning methods, we demonstrate the superior performance of our model in dealing with continually updated remote sensing data.

title: EViMNet: An Efficient Visual Model for Radar-Based Human Activity Recognition
authors: Liyuan Lin, Guanhua Qiao, Jingpeng Yan, Leguang Wang, Xiaoyu Li, Chaofan Wang, Rui Wang, Weibin Zhou, Yuan Zhou
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: In recent years, Radar-based human action recognition has recently gained attention due to its high precision and robustness, making it well-suited for Internet of Things (IoT) applications. However, radar spectrograms often contain noise and redundant information, while conventional classification models exhibit limitations in capturing complex nonlinear patterns, which hinders recognition performance. To address these challenges, we propose EViMNet, an efficient vision-based model for robust Radar-based human behavior recognition. EViMNet integrates two core components. The first is a Stem Filtering Block (SFB) that applies Gaussian filtering to enhance target features and suppress source noise. The second is an improved Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) architecture, where traditional linear layers are replaced by Kolmogorov–Arnold Networks (KANs). These KANs utilize B-spline basis functions to enable flexible nonlinear modeling and increase sensitivity to subtle signal variations. Experimental results show that EViMNet achieves 95.20% accuracy on the Glasgow dataset. For generalization evaluation, it further attains 99.18% cross-validation accuracy on the Doppler Gesture dataset and achieves the best cross-dataset performance when trained on Glasgow and tested on the corresponding actions in CI4R-MIX77. These results verify the strong generalization and practical applicability of the proposed model in IoT scenarios.

title: Deep Learning-Aided Time-Discrete Bioprinting for Single-Cell Encapsulation in Microgel With Composable Stiffness Gradients_supp1-3656633.docx
authors: Huaping Wang
publish: N/A
abstract: Single-cell microgels, engineered to replicate complex 3-D in vivo niches, have shown tremendous potential for advancing biomedical research. Studies have demonstrated that microgels recapitulating tissues’ stiffness facilitate the observation of cellular behavior in vitro. However, encapsulating single cells in microgels with composable stiffness gradients to understand cellular responses at microscale interfaces remains challenging. Here, we propose a versatile fabrication method that integrates an enhanced vision model with time-discrete bioprinting to encapsulate single cells in microgels featuring composable stiffness. An enhanced deep learning algorithm was developed to localize single cells in microscopic images, integrating traditional image processing algorithms for improved precision. By combining single-cell positioning data with a time-discrete array based on a digital micromirror device, dynamic digital masks can be generated to control each micromirror in real time. Using these masks, MDA-MB-231 cells were encapsulated in Gelatin methacrylate microgels with tunable stiffness ranging from 1.42 to 11.42 kPa. Experimental results indicated that when the microgel stiffness gradient exceeded 2 kPa, MDA-MB-231 cells exhibited a significant response, extending toward the softer regions of the microgels. These findings illustrate that our approach provides a valuable biofabrication strategy for investigating single-cell behaviors in microgels, showing great potential for applications in 3-D single-cell research.

title: Assessment of Wind Turbine Integration for Microgrids at Naval Installations
authors: Alex Lim, Karen Flack, Hyatt Moore
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This study evaluates the technical and economic viability of integrating wind turbines into naval microgrids at six geographically diverse bases. Eight turbine models from 7 kW to 2MWare analyzed using hub height wind speed distributions from NASA MERRA-2 and manufacturer power curves. Annual capacity factors are computed and used to derive turbine equivalent counts, integer procurement counts, and capital costs required to sustain a 1 MW average load. Results show pronounced site effects. High resource locations such as Souda Bay and Guam achieve capacity factor values around 0.5 for mid and utility scale machines, whereas low resource sites such as San Diego seldom exceed 0.2. Where siting allows, utility-scale machines minimize unit counts and often total cost. In some contexts, mid-scale designs yield the lowest procurement cost because integer counts remain modest. Small wind requires hundreds to thousands of units at weak sites, which drives prohibitive first costs and added balance of system complexity, and it is generally noncompetitive except under severe height or airspace constraints. The modeling framework links hub height wind distributions to performance data and explicitly accounts for integer procurement effects, and the method is transferable for preliminary wind integration decisions in naval and civilian microgrids. Estimates reflect simplified power curve representations and exclude balance of system and O&M costs.

title: Optimal Operation of AC/DC Hybrid Distribution Network with PET Considering Electricity Pricebased Demand Response
authors: Yaobin Sun
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: The effective operation of AC/DC hybrid distribution networks (HDNs) is paramount to maximising the efficiency, reliability and economic benefits of modern electricity grids. This paper presents a totally new approach of combining demand response (DR) based on electric pricing and power electronic transformers (PET) to optimize the performance of the hybrid network. A new Graph Neural Network (GNN) framework is presented that identifies the complexity of topological interdependencies and the dynamic interactions of the hybrid grid and provides an accurate representation of both power flow and voltage stability. The proposed framework optimizes the operating parameters of the hybrid grid including power dispatch, PET control strategies, and DR scheduling to minimize operational costs and maintain grid stability. The execution of PET optimization produces a remarkable improvement in voltage stability whereby voltage levels increased from an unstable region of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.90-0.94$</tex> p.u. (without PET), to a stable region of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.96-0.99$</tex> p.u. (with PET), representing an average voltage increase of 6.8%. Moreover, the electricity price-based demand response approach is highly efficient in saving operation costs, reducing the cost from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${\unicode{x0024}} 1200 / \text{MWh}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\unicode{x0024} 1200 / \text{MWh}\unicode{x0024} 950 / \text{MWh}$</tex>, corresponding to a 20.8% increase. Comparative evaluations with conventional optimization techniques show that the proposed GNN-based framework provides faster convergence speed, reduced energy expenditure, and enhanced voltage regulation. Simulation outputs on a benchmark AC/DC HDN demonstrate the applicability of our solution to real-time demand variability management and achieving optimal grid operation under changing electricity prices. Our research demonstrates the promise of combining artificial intelligence with advanced control methods for efficient and cost-saving management of contemporary hybrid distribution networks.

title: NeuroScan: Automated Brain Tumor Classification Using AI-Powered Vision
authors: V. Kavitha, Shandeep G
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Proper and timely classification of brain tumors is essential in the planning of treatments given to patients and prognosis. The traditional Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) algorithms are effective at localizing spatial spatial features and they are unlikely to learn global contextual features with and they need large datasets and can be readily overfitted on small medical imaging data. ViT models require large datasets, and will overfit to small medically relevant datasets. To overcome these disadvantages, we introduce NeuroScan that is a hybrid deep learning model that integrates CNNs with ViTs to automatically identify brain tumors based on MRI images. Such mechanisms of the framework include an Attention-Enhanced U-Net that is used to effectively segment tumors, two-stream feature extraction that learns local and global features, and a new Cross-Modal Fusion Layer (CMFL) that fuses multi-scale embeddings in an adaptive way. The merged representation is classified with the help of fully connected ensemble layer, and the visual interpretability of the merged representation is provided with the help of Grad-CAM and attention maps. Comprehensive analysis of BraTS 2021, Figshare Brain MRI and Kaggle datasets shows that NeuroScan has an accuracy of 99.2%, sensitivity of 98.7 percent, and specificity of 99.0 %, which is higher than state-of-the-art approaches without clinical explanation. NeuroScan thereby offers a viable, interpretable and clinically acceptable automated neuroimaging analysis solution.

title: GlowBuddy- A Tokenized Reward, Health and Wellness Application using Blockchain
authors: Shwetha AN, Ankitha Suraksha V, Darshan P D, Jeevitha S, Kasukurthi Yojith Prasad
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: A blockchain-powered application called GlowBuddy offers a structure of encouragement for inspirational and healthy lifestyle adoption. By combining fitness tracking, everyday challenges, and protected digital rewards, it provides a consistent and pleasant wellness platform. GlowBuddy collaborates with Apple Health or Google Fit to track everyday tasks like food, sleep, steps, and hydration. People gain HealthCoins, which are based on the ERC-20 blockchain tokens, by finishing these activities. The earned tokens can be used for actual benefits like gym memberships or health checkups in the app’s marketplace. In addition to providing goal-based eating guidance, mindfulness assistance, and emotional check-ins, a personalized diet planner and an AI-powered mental health chatbot also improve user well-being. GlowBuddy has a scoreboard to promote healthy competition and an additional digital wallet for token management. Medical history and wellness data are stored in a clear and safe manner to blockchain-backed health records. Admin dashboards enable reward monitoring, while smart contracts handle token issuance and redemption. Anti-cheat mechanisms use dependable APIs to verify the legitimacy of the data. GlowBuddy is a scalable, user-centric, anticipatory healthcare system with hands-on applications and startup potential that associates health technology, blockchain, and gamification.

title: Evaluating Fidelity in Explainable AI: A Comparative Study of SHAP, LIME, EBM, and Counterfactuals for Diabetes Prediction
authors: Sana Arora, Shachi Singhal, Vanshika Singhal, Yashika Jindal, Khyati Ahlawat
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: A comparative study for evaluating the explanations generated by various XAI approaches including SHAP, LIME, EBM and Counterfactual explanations has been presented in the paper “Evaluating Fidelity in Explainable AI: A Comparative Study of SHAP, LIME, EBM, and Counterfactuals for Diabetes Prediction”. Diabetes is a chronic condition and it ranks among top ten causes of disease- related deaths in India. Although, Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning have been applied to detect patterns but they remain as black-box models, making it difficult to analyze the trustworthiness and interpretability of these models. In order to address this issue, we have conducted fidelity with permutations-based testing on Explainable AI (XAI) techniques for diabetes prediction. This Study involves four algorithms SHAP, LIME, EBM and Counterfactual Explanations that were implemented on three different datasets, including two balanced and one highly imbalanced data distribution. Furthermore, their results were analyzed using fidelity as the primary metric. Results revealed that EBM outperformed others on imbalanced data, while SHAP and EBM achieved the highest fidelity overall. Furthermore, LIME generated decently accurate explanations but was sensitive to dataset complexity, while CFEs offered specific insights based on patient-specific data. Additionally, evaluation using accuracy, area under the curve (AUC), computational cost in terms of training time, and interpretability showed that SHAP and LIME performed well on balanced datasets, CFEs showed results by generating explanations I contrast to the exiting class, and EBM balanced predictive accuracy with interpretability, although with longer training time. These findings propose that using fidelity on XAI algorithms supports informed decision making to improve global health outcomes.

title: AI-Driven Learning Behavior Analysis for Adaptive Content Delivery and Enhanced Productivity
authors: Sampath. K, Murugan Kandaswamy, V. Ramu, Kabirdoss Devi, S. Venkatesan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: The modern importance of adaptive learning platforms continues to grow because most platforms currently fail to achieve both dynamic behavior analysis and real-time personalization. An artificial intelligence system that evaluates learner conduct through a two-part approach where reinforcement learning works with decision tree classifier methods. The system tracks live student interactions to modify information distribution according to the current patterns of learner participation. The analysis relied on behavioral data from OpenEd, which included a diverse set of interactions for both training and assessment purposes. The use of the proposed model led to accuracy enhancements, reaching 96.3%, along with improvements in content relevance to 89.5% and increased learner retention to 41.7%, surpassing the existing systems from 2022 to 2024. The implemented TensorFlow and Python for its simulation runs through a cloud-based education simulation environment. The model demonstrates better delivery adaptability and learner involvement than basic regulationbased systems. It demonstrates that educational platforms containing AI behavior modeling show the potential to upgrade learning effectiveness together with real-time productivity improvements in instructional settings.

title: Outage Analysis of Underlay Cognitive Radio Air-Ground Communications Under Outdated CSI
authors: Mostafa M. Aniter, Mahmoud Abdelaziz, Tamer Mekkawy, Tamer Rakia
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Telecommunications and Artificial Intelligence (IC-FTAI)
abstract: This paper studies cognitive radio (CR) for aeronautical air-ground communications of the underlay mode, where secondary users (SUs) share spectrum with primary users (PUs) while controlling interference. Recognizing the rapid channel variations inherent to aircraft mobility, the analysis models outdated channel state information (CSI) and adopts Nakagami-m fading to capture line-of-sight and scattering effects typical of aeronautical links. The work formulates SU operation subject to simultaneous constraints on peak interference at the PU and reliability at the SU receiver, and derives closed-form expressions for the SU outage probability. The impact of CSI and fading severity on performance is characterized analytically and corroborated by Monte Carlo simulations, showing close agreement between theory and experiment. The results provide tractable performance benchmarks and design guidance for interference-aware SU power control in rapidly time-varying aeronautical environments, and clarify the conditions under which coexistence between primary and secondary systems remains feasible without compromising PU protection.

title: Data-Driven LMS Analytics for Enhancing Student Performance in EdTech Platforms
authors: Pavithra C R, Hari Haran C, Hari Shanker R, Nithish Kumar M, Nivetha I
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: The progress towards sophisticated and efficient systems has accelerated the development of advanced computational structures in order to circumvent the problems of scalability, flexibility, adaptability, and real-time decision-making systems. Conventional methods suffer from low efficiency, expensive calculations and limited dynamic accuracy. To tackle these downsides, optimized deep learning and adaptive algorithms are presented here, aiming at an improved performance in different evaluation metrics. The methodology is applied as a hybrid pipeline of pre-processing, feature extraction and training in order to experiment with benchmark datasets. Experimental evaluation shows that there was significant improvement in details accuracy from 91.8% to 96.8%, details precision from 90.6% to 95.7%, details recall from 91.9% to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 6. 2 \%}$</tex>, details <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{F 1}$</tex>-score from 91.4% to 96, and increased details reliability and stability compared with the previous works. Furthermore, a comparison of previous methods revealed that some continuous improvements were made, thereby demonstrating the power of the model. A scalable, efficient and high-performance solution, it would have a really good prospect of real-world application in the critical use case where reliability of intelligent decisions needs to be ensured.

title: A Survey on Task Scheduling in Cloud Computing: Techniques, Simulation Tools, and Applications
authors: Rajani Bandaru, Tarana Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: Task scheduling plays a pivotal role in optimizing the performance, efficiency, and reliability of cloud computing environments, where dynamic workloads and heterogeneous resources demand intelligent decision-making. Despite extensive research, the rapid evolution of scheduling algorithms, simulation tools, and application domains presents a challenge in understanding current trends, gaps, and technological advancements. This systematic literature review aims to comprehensively analyze existing task scheduling techniques in cloud computing, evaluate widely used simulation platforms, and explore domain-specific applications to provide a consolidated understanding of the state-of-the-art methods. Following PRISMA guidelines, relevant studies published between 2010 and 2025 are collected from major scientific databases, filtered through rigorous inclusion-exclusion criteria, and analyzed using thematic, comparative, and quantitative synthesis. The results reveal a clear progression from heuristic and metaheuristic algorithms to AI-driven and hybrid scheduling models, alongside increased adoption of simulation tools such as CloudSim, iFogSim, and WorkflowSim for performance validation. Moreover, the review highlights how scheduling strategies are increasingly tailored for diverse applications including scientific workflows, big data processing, edge-fog ecosystems, and energy-aware cloud services. The findings provide critical insights into emerging trends, existing limitations, and future research opportunities, offering valuable guidance for researchers and practitioners striving to enhance task scheduling efficiency in next-generation cloud systems.

title: Application of One-Time Authorization Dynamic Token Authentication Technology in Boundary Security Devices
authors: Dongxi Lu, Yaoxin Pan, Lumin Xu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: This paper proposes a dynamic token authentication technology based on Hash-based Message Authentication Code (HMAC) and Unix timestamps, aiming to improve the authentication efficiency and security of boundary security devices. By combining the HMAC algorithm with timestamps, dynamic tokens with uniqueness and timeliness are generated, effectively preventing replay and brute-force attacks. In high- concurrency environments, the forward validation cache mechanism introduced in this paper significantly optimizes authentication performance, reduces computational load, and improves authentication speed. Experimental results show that the system achieved a 100% success rate in 30,000 authentication requests, with an average authentication delay of 1.8 milliseconds and 99% of requests having delays below 3 milliseconds. Additionally, under stress testing, the system can run stably for 72 hours with memory usage ranging from 14.5MB to 15MB, and CPU utilization remains within a reasonable range. Compared to traditional static password and SMS-based authentication schemes, dynamic token authentication offers significant advantages in resistance to brute-force attacks, authentication delay, and reliability, particularly in high-concurrency environments. Through formal security verification, the proposed solution effectively defends against replay attacks and ensures the security of key storage. The experimental results validate the efficiency and application prospects of this authentication technology in modern boundary defense.

title: Wavelet-Based Deep Neural Network with Attention for Interpretable Epileptic Seizure Prediction Using EEG Spectrograms
authors: Abhishek S. Rao, Ramaprasad Poojary, Shravya A Prabhu, Shravya S Shetty, Diya M Shetty, H. Nagesh Shenoy
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Computing, Semiconductor, Mechatronics, Intelligent Systems and Communications (COSMIC)
abstract: Epileptic seizures arise from abnormal electrical discharges in the brain and significantly impact patient safety and independence. Accurate and timely prediction of seizures is vital for enabling preventive care and improving quality of life. This study proposes a hybrid deep learning model for reliable seizure prediction using electroencephalogram (EEG) spectrogram data. Continuous wavelet transformation (CWT) was applied to raw EEG signals to generate spectrograms that capture both frequency and temporal characteristics. Wavelet transformation was preferred over the short-time Fourier transform (STFT) because of its superior ability to represent non-stationary EEG variations, providing improved temporal resolution during seizure onset. Although EEG signals contain spatial information, a convolutional neural network (CNN) was employed to extract localized spatial–frequency features from wavelet spectrograms, enhancing sensitivity to subtle regional variations. These spatial features were processed by a bidirectional long short-term memory (BiLSTM) network with an attention mechanism to model temporal dependencies and emphasize seizure-relevant patterns. The hybrid model integrates a three-layer CNN with batch normalization and max pooling, followed by a two-layer BiLSTM with an attention block to enhance interpretability. The framework was trained and evaluated on the CHB-MIT Scalp EEG database using 10-fold GroupKFold cross-validation to ensure subject-level independence. Comparative analysis with baseline CNN, LSTM, and STFT-based models demonstrated superior performance, achieving an average accuracy of 85% and an ROC-AUC above 0.90. The use of explainable artificial intelligence techniques further improved model transparency and trust, establishing a foundation for real-time seizure forecasting and future integration into wearable EEG monitoring systems.

title: Public Policy generation: Enhancing AI Literacy in High School students
authors: José Guillermo Guzmán Segura
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: This study assessed the impact of an AI literacy educational innovation. Drawing from the AI literacy frameworks outlines in references [1–2], nineteen Global Politics students developed a public policy to promote holistic national development through a project-based learning approach. This project utilized OpenAI’s ChatGPT, Microsoft Excel, and Python programming language to enhance students’ critical thinking and AI competencies. Results indicated a 33% improvement in students’ analytical skills and a 27% improvement in their explanatory skills. Students reported increased confidence in AI usage. However, they encountered challenges with traditional computational tools. This study addressed a significant gap in secondary-level AI pedagogy by demonstrating how interdisciplinary, tech-savvy projects can enhance AI literacy and critical thinking among students.

title: Empowering Digital Rights: Real-Time Detection of Piracy Channels on Telegram Using Machine Learning and Network Analysis
authors: Gaurav Dhanwate, Archana Jadhav, Indrajit Lavate, Samarth Bawage, Rushikesh Aghavane, Dipali Patil
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: Although Telegram is a secure messaging service, it has also been misused for distributing illegal content, including web series, movies, and other copyrighted materials. The platform's security and scalability make it challenging to detect and eliminate piracy routes effectively. This study explores current methods for identifying pirated Telegram channels. Additionally, we propose an approach that utilizes network analysis, machine learning, and natural language processing (NLP) to detect and categorize piracy related content. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method, achieving up to 92 % accuracy in detecting piracy channels. The objective of this study is to develop a system that can identify, report, and block pirated channels on Telegram and similar services.

title: Optimal Battery Management Model for Profit-Oriented Grid-Connected Solar-Powered Smart Farms
authors: Nahin Ar Rabbani, Wooi-Nee Tan, It Ee Lee, Gwo Chin Chung, Tiong Hoo Lim, Phon Sovatna, Long Touch, Khanthanou Luangxaysaxana, Phutsavanh Thongphanh
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Smart Grid and Clean Energy Technologies (ICSGCE)
abstract: The increasing integration of renewable energy systems with agricultural infrastructure creates significant opportunities for sustainable and additional income beyond traditional agricultural harvests. This research proposes a mixed-integer linear programming model for grid-connected, solar-powered smart farms, with the aim of maximizing net profit through optimal management of battery energy storage system (BESS) and the sale of surplus energy to the grid as an extra revenue stream. Simulations are conducted over a one-week period using Time-of-Use (ToU) tariffs, considering various weather conditions such as sunny, cloudy, and rainy days. The results show that generating profit is feasible on sunny and cloudy days, while losses are incurred during rainy days. This study demonstrates the viability of enabling farmers to invest in renewable energy technologies by showcasing a cost-effective energy management strategy that optimizes energy usage, reduces reliance on grid electricity, and lowers operational costs, thereby empowering them to adopt sustainable practices that not only support environmental goals but also enhance long-term economic benefits.

title: PPO-Based Joint Voltage Control Strategy for Power System with Photovoltaic Farms
authors: Chunyan Li, Tong Su, Yali Qing, Qiuyan Xiang
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Smart Grid and Clean Energy Technologies (ICSGCE)
abstract: With the increasing integration of photovoltaic (PV) farms, the variability of PV generation leads to dynamic operational modes in the power system, posing significant challenges to conventional voltage–reactive power control strategies. To address this issue, a voltage regulation approach based on the proximal policy optimization (PPO) algorithm is proposed. By utilizing historical active power outputs from PV farms, along with system voltage data, a reinforcement learning agent is trained to learn an optimal control policy for reactive power regulation and voltage optimization. Then, the reactive power optimization model in the PV farm is introduced to address the voltage issue caused by variability of PV generation. Subsequently, a two-stage voltage control strategy based on PPO for power system with PV is introduced. The effectiveness of the proposed method is validated through simulations on a modified WSCC 9-bus system, demonstrating its capability to control the voltage.

title: An Analysis of Electromagnetic Wave Propagation in Cables and Cable Joints at 433 and 915 MHz
authors: Guangqi Lu, Xuan Wang, Donghai Zhao, Bodong Chen, Kang Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Measurement Control and Instrumentation (MCAI)
abstract: Cross-linked polyethylene (XLPE) high-voltage cables are widely used in distribution networks, but structural defects in intermediate joints make them prone to partial-discharge and temperature-rise failures, accounting for over 80% of faults in cables rated at ≤10 kV. To address the high cost and installation complexity of conventional temperature-monitoring techniques, passive wireless schemes combining surface acoustic wave (SAW) sensors with radio-frequency identification (RFID) offer clear advantages; however, electromagnetic-wave propagation in the cable’s multilayer shielding and composite dielectrics remains insufficiently characterized. In this study, we developed a high-fidelity finite-element model of a YJ-series 64 kV cable and its intermediate joint and analyzed RFID-band wave propagation systematically. The results showed that, in the presence of a joint, abrupt material and geometric transitions introduced impedance mismatches that caused strong reflections/refractions and superposition, severely distorting the waveform. When the operating frequency exceeded the cable’s cutoff (735.1 MHz), higher-order modes—TM and TE, in addition to TEM—were excited, further aggravating signal distortion; consequently, compared with 433 MHz, waves at 915 MHz exhibited markedly more severe waveform distortion within the cable and at the joint.

title: Optimized Orientation and Beamforming for Intelligent Omni-Surface: Meta-Heuristic Approach
authors: Sarah Hassan, Karim Banawan, Ahmed F. Tayel, El-Sayed A. Youssef
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Telecommunications and Artificial Intelligence (IC-FTAI)
abstract: We consider a downlink multi-user non-line-of-sight communication setting, which is supported by an intelligent omni-surface (IOS) with adjustable orientation. IOS can serve users on both sides of the surface by independently controlling the reflecting and transmitting phase shifts of the IOS elements. We study a unified framework for maximizing the sum spectral efficiency of the system. In this framework, we optimize the azimuth and elevation angles of the IOS, the reflection and transmission coefficients of the IOS, and the base station beamforming. To that end, we propose a novel meta-heuristic approach to optimizing the orientation angles of the IOS using a particle swarm algorithm. Furthermore, we employ WMMSE and alternating optimization to adjust the hybrid beamforming and energy-splitting factor. Our numerical results show significant gains over conventional MIMO and IRS-assisted networks. The results show a gain of 2.5 b/s/Hz over the IOS-based system with a fixed orientation.

title: Smart Electronic Based Rodent Repellent System for Automobiles
authors: Ajith. B. Singh, Arjun M, Bramanayagam S, Kamaleshwaran Y
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Rodent infestations in vehicles cause severe electrical damage and high repair costs, posing both economic and safety challenges. This article presents a smart, IoT-enabled rodent detection and deterrent system designed for automobiles, integrating ESP32-CAM for real-time image capture, a YOLOv8 deep learning model for object recognition, and a NodeMCU microcontroller for intelligent control. The system detects rodent activity through camera and infrared sensors and activates ultrasonic sound (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$40-70 \text{kHz}$</tex>), flashing LEDs, and vibration deterrents only upon detection, ensuring safe and energy-efficient operation. Experimental evaluation demonstrated an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{8 5 - 9 2 \%}$</tex> detection accuracy, 94% deterrent success rate, and a response time below 0.9 seconds, with power consumption maintained under <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{5 0 0 ~ m A} ( \approx \text{6 ~ W} )$</tex>. IoT-based data logging recorded over 350 detection events, revealing increased rodent activity during night-time hours. The proposed eco-friendly approach reduces chemical dependency, lowers vehicle maintenance costs by nearly 40 %, and extends component lifespan by up to 35 %. By effectively combining Internet of Things and Python-based intelligent automation, the system offers a reliable, low-power, and non-lethal solution for rodent prevention in vehicles, marking a significant step toward smarter, safer, and more sustainable automotive pest management.

title: A Robust Video Watermarking Algorithm Based on GANs Integrating Spatio-Temporal Features and an Attention Mechanism
authors: Hanyu Zhang, Ke Niu, Jun Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Control and Computing Science (ICICCS)
abstract: A multi-task generative-adversarial-network (GAN) video watermarking scheme that synergizes spatio-temporal feature learning with an attention-driven embedding strategy is proposed. A five-level progressive 3-D convolutional backbone first extracts attack-resistant spatio-temporal representations; a multi-scale pyramidal attention module then performs content-aware watermark allocation, while an edge-frame consistency loss eliminates the quality degradation that conventionally appears at the first and last frames. A cosine-annealing adversarial-training scheduler smoothly shifts the optimization focus from fidelity to robustness. Evaluated on UCF-101, the method keeps the watermarked videos at 38.44 dB PSNR and 0.9831 SSIM on average, while the extracted watermark achieves 0.9882 NC under clean conditions and 0.9801 NC after H.264 compression (CRF 28). The results verify state-of-the-art robustness and invisibility for practical video copyright protection and content tracing.

title: A User-Defined Angle-of-Attack Oscillation Control System for Wind-Tunnel Testing of Aerofoils
authors: Nicolas Ciavatta, Xiang Shen, Xu Deng
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Environment Friendly Energies and Applications (EFEA)
abstract: This paper presents a versatile Angle-of-Attack Oscillation Control System (AoA-OCS) developed for wind-tunnel testing of wind-turbine aerofoils under unsteady inflow conditions. The system replaces conventional crank mechanisms with user-defined LabVIEW signal functions driving a stepper-motor-actuated rig, enabling full 360° rotation, oscillation amplitudes up to 180°, and frequencies up to 16 Hz in constant-speed and sinusoidal modes. Dual encoders at the motor and output shafts provide independent verification of imposed motion. System performance is assessed using three sinusoidal case studies representing steady, quasi-steady and unsteady regimes, with measured trajectories closely matching theoretical functions and mean absolute errors of order 0.1°, confirming high-precision tracking across a range of reduced frequencies. Additional functions, including ramp-up motion and incremental angle steps, support both static and dynamic measurements. The system therefore provides an accurate and adaptable platform for experimental studies of unsteady aerodynamics, dynamic stall and aeroelastic behaviour in wind-turbine aerofoil research.

title: A Reinforcement Learning Approach for Adaptive Energy Management
authors: Udit Mamodiya, Indra Kishor, Mohamed M. Awad
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Telecommunications and Artificial Intelligence (IC-FTAI)
abstract: The world is seeking clean and sustainable energy, and there is a growing interest in more sophisticated, data-driven methods for generating renewable energy. Traditional methods for forecasting and controlling renewable energy systems face challenges due to the nonlinear, stochastic, and rapidly changing characteristics of the renewable energy resources (solar, wind, and bioenergy). This research suggests a Hybrid AI Model for optimized energy generation and prediction developed by integrating ML, DL, and RL in a closed-loop configured cyclic process. The developed framework employs CNN-LSTM for the energy output spatiotemporal prediction, boosted regression tree for short-term forecasting, and reinforcement learning for adaptive decision making in dynamic and uncertain environments. hybridization of these three models will help in forecasting renewable power generation with accuracy and flexibility concerning the decision variables. In one proposed experiment on solar-wind hybrid datasets, the accuracy of the forecasting models based on one hybrid dataset significantly improved with borderline controllable limits of RMSE 0.172, MAPE <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3.84 \%, R^{2} 0.963$</tex> compared to classic single models. Forecasting under different climatic conditions demonstrated the hybrid model's under-performance in many instances. The proposed Hybrid AI Model focuses on skid and integrate the intelligent control the the variables, predominantly the underutilized variables of renewable energy. This will increase the robustness of the smart grid. The models designed also help in fulfilling the new standards set in the Sustainable Development Goals.

title: A method of measuring the roll of cooperative target by vision-based methods based on laser tracking
authors: Qifan Qiu, Doudou Gao, Zhi Cheng, Yixuan Han, Dengfeng Dong, Weihu Zhou
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Measurement Control and Instrumentation (MCAI)
abstract: Currently, the measurement of roll of laser tracking cooperative target using vision-based methods often necessitates the presence of multiple feature points on the target, distributed according to specific rules. However, this requirement undermines the inherent characteristic of laser tracking which is to consistently track a single point. In order to simplify the target structure by leveraging this characteristic, this paper investigates a visual measurement method for determining the roll of a cooperative target based on laser tracking. Firstly, this paper describes the characteristics of visual target detection for laser-tracked cooperative targets using active infrared detection and analyses the principles behind visual measurements based on distributed feature points in laser-tracked cooperative targets. Secondly, this paper constructs a measurement model for determining the roll of a cooperative target using active infrared detection and features, and establishes a corresponding measurement system. Finally, experiments are conducted and accuracy is analysed. The result demonstrates that this proposed method only requires a simple structure and achieves an error better than ±0.08° when only one active infrared feature point is present, thereby meeting medium- to high-precision application requirements.

title: IoT-Based EV Charging Infrastructure Safety System with Ground Fault Detection & Smart Transformer-Pole Health Monitoring
authors: R.S. Thirumurugan, M. Vanathi, M. Rishikesh, V. Yogeshkannan, V. Anand Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: After Visiting Several Charging Stations and Conducting Extensive on-Site Investigations, We Discovered Serious Safety Deficiencies in the Electric Vehicle Charging Infrastructure. Traditional Safety Systems Protect Each Charger with Ground Fault Circuit Interrupters and Overload Protection. However, Our Investigation Showed that Electrical System Components, Including Transformers and Distribution Poles, Were Subjected to Significant Stress Without Proper Monitoring. at One Large Charging Facility, We Observed Transformer Temperatures that Fluctuated By More than 15°c During Peak Hours. Additionally, a Structural Assessment of 12 Utility Poles Showed that Four of Them Exhibited Unstable Slopes of More than 2 Degrees. After a Transformer Failure Caused a Six-Hour Local Power Outage, We Discovered Harmful Blind Spots Created By Currently Independently Managed Monitoring Techniques (such as Charging Protection, Transformer Health Checks, and Structural inspections). Our Research Project Addresses This Fragmentation By Developing An Integrated Internet of Things Monitoring Platform that Simultaneously Tracks Ground Faults, Transformer Thermal Conditions, and Pole Stability. Using Laboratory Testing with esp32 Microcontrollers and Calibrated Sensors, We Built a Prototype that Processes Real-Time Data from zmct103c Current Transformers, ds18b20 Temperature Probes, and mpu6050 Accelerometers. Our System Communicates Through Cloud Platforms, Providing Instant Alerts and Automated Fault Responses. Laboratory Validation Demonstrated Ground Fault Detection Within 143 Milliseconds and Temperature Monitoring Accuracy of±0.4°c Across Our Test Range. This Unified Approach Proved Particularly Valuable During Discussions with Utility Engineers, Who Confirmed Similar Infrastructure Challenges Across Expanding Ev Networks. Our Economic Analysis Shows Potential Maintenance Cost Reductions of Approximately $280,000-420,000 Annually Per Monitored Station, Making the System Especially Relevant for Rapidly Growing Electric Mobility Sectors Where Aging Infrastructure Faces Unprecedented Loading Demands.

title: Emotion-Aware Narrative Modeling for Robust Fake-News Classification
authors: Ahmed Alsharmani, Najeeb Saiyed, Nivedita Mishra
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: This paper addresses fake news detection based on text feature as well as emotion feature. Our sample is 79,617 articles of English news, including trusted sources (Reuters, The New York Times, The Washington Post) and misinformation and propaganda of the right-wing extremist websites. Once the text has been cleaned we use TF-IDF and train Logistic Regression, Support Vector Machine (SVM) and Multinomial Naive Bayes. The accuracy of SVM is highest with 95.66 percent, followed by the Logistic regression and Naive Bayes has the least performance. In order to go beyond word frequency we construct emotion aware pipeline wherein DistilRoBERTa is used to label sentence level emotions (joy, fear, anger, sadness) and we extract features such as dominant emotion, longest streak and emotion transitions that are then modeled with a Logistic Regression, a random forest and an LM over emotion sequences. Though these emotion-driven models do not outperform the TF-IDF + SVM baseline, they reveal typical emotional indicators of fake news and can aid fact-checkers and sites in clearing their doubts.

title: Anomaly Detection in VANET Using Machine Learning-Based Data Analytics
authors: Suganthi Evangeline C, Sandhya S, Shrivarsha S, Sri Sivaranjani VR, Roshini M, Nivethitha T
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Anomaly detection in Vehicular Ad Hoc Networks (VANETs) using machine learning-based data analytics is critical for safeguarding intelligent transportation systems from cyber threats and network irregularities. This study reviews and synthesizes state-of-the-art approaches, highlighting the application of supervised algorithms (Random Forest, SVM, Logistic Regression), advanced deep learning models (CNN, GRU), and hybrid techniques that combine traditional and neural methods for both known and novel attack detection. Key findings indicate that ensemble and boosting algorithms (XGBoost, CatBoost, AdaBoost), coupled with robust feature engineering and data balancing, deliver superior detection accuracy often achieving F1-scores above 96% and real-time classification performance. Benchmarking on realistic datasets generated via SUMO simulators, with features such as protocol type, mean delay, and flow duration, underscores the importance of data realism and scalability. Despite significant progress, challenges remain regarding model transferability, real-world validation, and privacy-preserving learning. Overall, machine learning-based analytics are central to developing scalable, reliable, and interpretable anomaly detection solutions for next-generation VANET environments

title: A Lightweight Android Malware Classification Framework for Imbalanced Data
authors: Jian Wang, Hong Jian Wu, Ya Yin Lin, Yi Yu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: The rapid proliferation of Android malware poses a serious threat to the platform’s ecosystem. Machine-learning–based classification is an effective defense, yet real-world datasets are typically imbalanced, which severely degrades a model’s ability to recognize minority classes. We propose a method combining random oversampling with LightGBM to address this challenge. At the data level, we balance the training set via oversampling; at the model level, we employ LightGBM with L1/L2 regularization for robust optimization. Evaluated with comprehensive metrics, our approach achieves 99.23% accuracy and 98.6% macro-F1 score, with Banking malware recall improving by 14.1% due to oversampling. The confusion matrix reveals that most errors occur between behaviorally similar classes, indicating the limitations of frequency-based features. Our work demonstrates that a lightweight approach can effectively handle class imbalance while providing practical Android malware detection.

title: The Utilization of Attention U-Net Architecture to Enhance YOLOv8 Detection of Transventricular Objects in Fetal Head Ultrasound Images
authors: Yadi Utama, E Erwin, Samsuryadi Samsuryadi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Technological Solutions (ICAITech)
abstract: Ultrasonography (USG) is a widely used imaging modality in obstetrics for visualizing fetal head structures and identifying critical anatomical landmarks. In this study, we examine the effect of segmentation-assisted annotation on object detection performance by comparing YOLOv8 trained with and without Attention U-Net-assisted labeling, as well as Faster R-CNN, under identical training parameters and dataset splits. Experimental results show that YOLOv8 trained without segmentation assistance achieves a mean Average Precision (mAP) of $\mathbf{9 2. 3 \%}$ on the training set and $\mathbf{8 1. 2 \%}$ on the testing set, with an F1-Score of 98%. Incorporating Attention U-Net-assisted annotation improves generalization, yielding $93.2 \% \mathrm{mAP}$ on training and $89.8 \%$ on testing, with the same F1-Score of $98 \%$. In contrast, Faster R-CNN achieves a slightly higher training mAP ($92.8 \%$) but a significantly lower testing mAP ($76.8 \%$), indicating weaker generalization. These findings demonstrate that YOLOv8, when combined with Attention U-Net-assisted labeling, provides a more robust and generalizable solution for object detection in transventricular fetal head ultrasound images. This work presents a hybrid Attention U-Net + YOLOv8 framework that enhances detection accuracy and reliability in ultrasound imaging scenarios.

title: Stabilization-Triggered Reinforcement Relearning Control for Virtually Coupled Train Sets
authors: Wenxiao Si, Shigen Gao, Krishna Busawon, Xuewu Dai, Bohua Deng
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Environment Friendly Energies and Applications (EFEA)
abstract: A stabilization-triggered reinforcement relearning control (STRR) framework is proposed for virtual coupling train operation systems. A dual performance monitor mechanism with enforced boundary constraints and minimum dwell-time conditions is integrated to ensure approximation optimal and safe operation. Distinct from prior approaches, the monitoring mechanism directs the system to stabilized optimal mode with suspended actor-critic (AC) updates, restarting learning only if necessary. A coefficient-enhanced Gaussian learning rate is developed for AC weight updates, ensuring persistent excitation of tracking error signals without performance degradation. The framework is validated using operational data from the Beijing South to Jinan West railway station, where reinforcement relearning under stabilization-triggered conditions is successfully demonstrated. Rigorous validation is performed through error-convergence analysis and computational resource savings quantification.

title: SRR-Loaded Metamaterial UWB Antenna for Selective Dual-Band Rejection
authors: A. S. I. Amar, Y. M. Madany
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Telecommunications and Artificial Intelligence (IC-FTAI)
abstract: This study presents the design and analysis of an ultrawideband (UWB) antenna incorporating dual band-notched characteristics, intended for modern wireless communication applications. The antenna features a microstrip-fed semicircular monopole configuration, integrated with a metamaterial-inspired split-ring resonator (SRR) slot etched into the radiating patch, and a semicircular ground plane on the backside. In its basic form-without the SRR-the antenna supports wideband operation across 3 to 1 2 GHz, effectively encompassing the entire UWB range defined by the FCC (3. 1 - 1 0. 6 GHz). The introduction of the SRR slot enables the antenna to generate two distinct bandnotches at 3.3 GHz and 5.6 GHz, effectively mitigating potential interference from co-existing systems such as WLAN, C-band, and WiMAX. Comprehensive performance evaluations, including reflection coefficient analysis, radiation pattern measurements, and assessments of gain and efficiency, confirm the antenna's capability to deliver the desired behavior with satisfactory performance across the UWB frequency range.

title: Analysis of Anchor and Fairlead Forces on Offshore Floating Wind Platforms
authors: Majid Aleyaasin, Mallum Dauda, Vahid Vaziri, Marcin Kapitaniak
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Environment Friendly Energies and Applications (EFEA)
abstract: This paper investigates anchor and fairlead loads under various environmental conditions for both spar and semi-submersible floating wind turbine types. As expected, it is shown that the anchor and fairlead loads for the 15 MW semi-submersible type are higher than for the 5 MW spar type. However, the difference is substantial, and therefore the loads are not proportional to the output power of the turbine. It can be concluded that spar-type floating platforms are more suitable than semi-submersible ones because they experience lower forces on their anchors and fairleads.

title: Adopting AI-Automated Feedback in Academic Writing: Insights from English Majors Using Grammarly
authors: Toan Bao Nguyen, Ngoc Nhu Nguyen, Tien My Cat Le, Duy Thuy Huynh, Vy Khanh Le
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: This study contributes to the field of Artificial Intelligence in Education by investigating the adoption of AIbased automated writing feedback in academic writing (AWF), using Grammarly as a representative case. Employing an explanatory sequential mixed-methods design, it collected data from 126 students at a private university in the Mekong Delta. Guided by the Unified Theory of Acceptance and Use of Technology (UTAUT), the study examined how Performance Expectancy, Effort Expectancy, Social Influence, and Facilitating Conditions influenced students’ behavioral intention to use AWF. Findings revealed high adoption levels, with Facilitating Conditions as the strongest predictor—highlighting the importance of institutional support in AI adoption. Qualitative insights further uncovered students’ perceived benefits, challenges, and suggestions for future use. The study contributes theoretical and practical implications for integrating AWF into academic writing instruction, emphasizing its potential to enhance student autonomy, writing accuracy, and confidence.

title: A Blockchain-Based Framework for Secure Management of Government and Law Enforcement Records
authors: Himanshu S Shetty, Pratheek G Shetty, M Imaad Iqbal, Shifali Florine Lobo, Mustafa Basthikodi
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Computing, Semiconductor, Mechatronics, Intelligent Systems and Communications (COSMIC)
abstract: The integrity, security, and accessibility of government and law enforcement records are fundamental to public trust. Yet, traditional centralized databases remain vulnerable to data manipulation, cyberattacks, and systemic inefficiencies that can compromise sensitive legal documents and undermine judicial processes. Blockchain technology offers a paradigm shift toward decentralized trust and cryptographic assurance. This paper presents a robust framework designed using Hyperledger Fabric to secure government legal records and enhance law enforcement procedures. We focus on the practical application of a permissioned blockchain, which is better suited for government use than public, cryptocurrency-based models. The architecture integrates smart contracts to automate legal documentation workflows and employs a hybrid on-chain/off-chain storage model to ensure scalability. Our results demonstrate a functionally complete, tamper-proof system that improves efficiency and provides a fully auditable trail for all record interactions. This work validates the feasibility of blockchain as a foundational technology for next-generation digital governance.

title: Three-Level Diagnostic Process for Early Bearing Failure Based on EES-Modified GFD
authors: Quanbo Luo, Chongye Qin, Luyang Jiang, Manman Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Measurement Control and Instrumentation (MCAI)
abstract: Train bearings, as core components of the bogie system, directly impact the safety and reliability of rail transit systems. Existing fault diagnosis methods typically rely on high-performance computing platforms, making real-time analysis and deployment challenging in resource-constrained edge environments. To address this, this paper proposes a lightweight diagnostic framework based on a three-tier threshold determination. By sequentially executing time-domain feature prescreening, Fast Spectral Correlation (Fast_SC), and Generalized fractal dimension (GFD) quantification assessment at the edge, it enables hierarchical classification of fault types and severity levels. This system demonstrates the capability to rapidly complete initial data processing and fault diagnosis within edge computing environments, significantly reducing reliance on cloud-based transmission and computation.

title: IoT-based Real-Time Energy Routing Algorithm in The Energy Internet
authors: Dina Emad, Diaa-Eldin A. Mansour, Tanemasa Asano, Sobhy M. AbdelKader
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Environment Friendly Energies and Applications (EFEA)
abstract: Modern smart grids leverage Internet of Things technologies to revolutionize power distribution through intelligent network connectivity across generation units, energy storage facilities, and transmission infrastructure. These complex interconnected systems require sophisticated routing mechanisms to orchestrate optimal power flow control and ensure seamless energy delivery across heterogeneous network topologies. However, conventional path-finding mechanisms exhibit limitations such as excessive processing demands, suboptimal load distribution, and inflexible response capabilities, leading to elevated power losses and degraded performance. This work introduces a dual-phase adaptive routing framework that employs predictive scheduling algorithms for initial path determination, coupled with dynamic IoT-driven reconfiguration for responsive energy management. The proposed approach utilizes distributed edge computing nodes and impedance-based network analysis to achieve superior power flow optimization with reduced transmission losses. Experimental validation using cloud-based monitoring platforms confirms that adaptive routing mechanisms minimize supply-demand misalignments, strengthen grid stability, and enhance operational efficiency, highlighting IoT's transformative impact on contemporary energy infrastructure.

title: Real-Time Public Transport Tracking for Small Cities: An IoT and AI-based Approach
authors: Bharath B, Yashaswini B. V, Sudharsan V, Nur Alom Talukdar, G. Santhosh, Aniruddha Deka
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: In lesser Indian cities, rigid timings and inadequate communication about public transport usually force people to use their own cars. A new cost-efficient tracking system based on IoT and AI, utilizing GPS, infrared, and weight sensors plus LSTM and XGBoost models for bus arrival predictions and passenger flow monitoring in real-time has been introduced in this research. During the six-month experiment in Surat, Lucknow, and Coimbatore the results were quite encouraging. The forecasting system for buses was accurate with an average of just 1.4 minutes error. It also achieved 94% accuracy in passenger counting and the hardware was functioning 98.7% of the time. The tracking system that was put in place not only improved or made it more efficient but also cut down waiting times by 35%, raised on-time rate from 68% to 84%, reduced delays during peak hours by 42%, and eliminated 67% of passenger complaints, all with an initial investment of around INR 12,500 per bus and a payback period of only eight months. Besides, the passengers’ happiness rating went up from 3.2 to 4.1 out of 5 and there was a 23% increase in bus ridership. All these results show that a chip, equipped with sensors, powered by AI system could remarkably improve the level of service in poor-resource areas. However, it should still be emphasized that growing this system to more extensive areas and making it work that way for a long time would be very hard.

title: Freedrape: Free-Form Garment Transfer Via Pose-Aware Bidirectional Warping
authors: Chiao-Yin Hsu, Ming-Sui Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: Virtual Try-On (VTON) technology has transformed online fashion by enabling users to preview outfits digitally. Traditional VTON systems rely on frontal, in-shop images, limiting their adaptability across poses. This work explores a VTON variant called apparel transfer, which allows garments to be transferred directly from one person to another. The proposed FreeDrape synthesizes realistic try-on results without requiring ground-truth supervision. FreeDrape leverages pose-aware bidirectional warping and appearance flow estimation to model how clothing deforms across varied human poses. Additional modules for shape adjustment and pattern restoration further improve realism. These components help preserve fine clothing details and structural consistency. Experimental results demonstrate that FreeDrape outperforms existing approaches, particularly in retaining intricate textures and adapting to diverse body poses, making it a robust solution for free-form garment transfer in real-world applications.

title: The k-index: a fairer assessment of research quality and its societal and environmental impact
authors: Krishna Busawon, Vimi Neeroo Lockmun-Bissessur
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Environment Friendly Energies and Applications (EFEA)
abstract: There is a growing necessity for establishing a fair and reliable research evaluation metric given that these assessments directly influence academic promotions and the allocation of research funds towards the most deserving projects with a significant societal and environmental impact. Currently, the h-index is the most widely used metric by academic institutions to evaluate the academic performance of researchers. It is claimed that the h-index is designed to quantify both the quantity and the quality of a scholar's publications by measuring the number of papers that have received enough citations. Such a claim is not true as it favours quantity over quality. In effect, the h-index is defined as follows: a researcher has an index of h if h of their papers has at least h citations each, and the rest of their papers have fewer than h citations. This means that if a researcher has only one paper with 1 million citations, then his h-index will still be equal to 1. On the other hand, if a researcher aspires to achieve an h-index of 100, then he/she must publish at least 100 papers. To address this issue, we propose a new fairer metric called the k-index to evaluate the academic performance of researchers. The k-index is defined as the sum of the h-index and the q-index; whereby the q-index is a term that is proportional to the total number of citations, accounting for the quality and impact of the publications. We highlight authors who have made highly influential contributions in renewable energy, often through a few seminal works, but may not have the long, continuous publication record that builds a high h-index. We show that their corresponding k-indexes reflect their academic records in a much fairer way.

title: Hybrid Intrusion Detection Framework for IoT Applications Enhancing Cybersecurity with AI-Driven Threat Mitigation
authors: S. Madhan, S. BrinthaRajakumari
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: With the rapid expansion of IoT devices exponentially coming along with cybersecurity risks that keep on changing, new innovative solutions have to be established. The hybrid intrusion detection system, which was proposed by this paper, helps in enhancing security within Internet of Things (IoT). The proposed framework applies both signature-based and anomaly-based approaches to AI -driven threat mitigation and incorporates machine learning in monitoring network traffic, suspicious activities, and the reaction in response to real-time dangers. The system detects known and zero-day threats with low false positive rates by integrating the strengths of conventional detection approaches with powerful artificial intelligence. To protect IoT ecosystems, a reinforcement learning agent optimizes methods in real time to ensure an adaptable and efficient reaction to threats. The framework's scalability, low latency, and excellent detection accuracy across varied IoT installations are shown experimentally using benchmark datasets. A key requirement in today's digital ecosystems is the security of IoT networks against growing cyber-attacks. This hybrid approach offers a robust, adaptive, and efficient solution to this problem.

title: Smart Solar Tracking System
authors: Sarika Sawant, Saloni Abin, Vaidehi Sakalkar, Arjun Salunke, Sakshi Thorat, Aditya Salunkhe, Saksham Chouhan
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: With the increasing demand for clean and renewable energy, we have been investigating ways of improving the efficiency of solar power. One of the main shortcomings of most traditional solar panels is that they remain stuck in the same position, hence fail to take full advantage of the sun's movement throughout the day. In this project, we designed a smart solar tracking system that automatically follows the sun from sunrise to sunset, allowing the panels to catch more sunlight and generate more power. Our system uses simple sensors and a microcontroller to determine the position of the sun and adjusts the panel angle in real time, sidewise and up and down. We also implemented an intelligent feature that enables users to monitor how the system is performing from anywhere in the world using the internet. During the test run, this setup generated approximately 25-35% more energy when compared to regular fixed panels. It's a relatively inexpensive solution that can be highly beneficial for homes, businesses, and other standalone off- grid areas to make full use of their installed solar facilities.

title: Adaptive Business Continuity Planning Using Self-Organizing Maps and Scenario-Based Generative AI Models
authors: Ranjitha. P. K, Narinder Kumar Bhasin, Anita Gorkhe, Vijayalakshmi Srinivas, Sajiv G, M. Karthik
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: In an increasingly unpredictable and data-driven business landscape, ensuring seamless continuity during disruptions has become vital. Traditional Business Continuity Planning (BCP) methods are often static, expert-dependent, and incapable of responding to real-time changes in risk environments. These limitations lead to delayed scenario updates, poor scalability, and limited interpretability. To overcome these challenges, this study introduces an Adaptive BCP framework that combines Self-Organizing Maps (SOM) for pattern recognition with Scenario-Based Generative AI (GAI) for dynamic scenario generation. The core aim is to enable automated detection of anomalous risk clusters and generate realistic continuity responses based on real-time data. A multi-agent system feeds live data—news feeds, logs, and alerts—into the model, enabling adaptive retraining and scenario regeneration. The proposed SOM-GAI-BCP model achieves superior performance with a clustering accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{9 5. 6 \%}$</tex>, scenario relevance of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{8 9. 2 \%}$</tex>, and update latency under 3 seconds, supported by high interpretability through U-Matrix visualizations and expert review. Tools such as Python, TensorFlow, and Matplotlib are employed for implementation and evaluation. This hybrid, cognitive computing approach ensures timely, intelligent decision-making and paves the way for next-generation business continuity solutions that are scalable, interpretable, and aligned with modern risk dynamics.

title: Inverse Estimation of Thermophysical Properties in Semitransparent Materials via Particle Filter and Photothermal Radiometry
authors: Hao Sun, Baohai Gao, Shuangcheng Sun, Hong Qi
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: The characterization of photothermal properties in semi-transparent media is pivotal for advancing cutting-edge technologies; however, it is hindered by the complexity of internal photothermal processes. Conventional photothermal radiometry techniques often oversimplify internal radiation transport, resulting in substantial inaccuracies in media representation. To address this limitation, a coupled radiation-conduction modulated thermal wave model was developed in this work. Its integration with the Bayesian particle filter algorithm enabled high-precision robust simultaneous inversion of multiple critical thermophysical parameters, expanding the application boundaries of photothermal detection technology.

title: Blockchain-Enabled Customer Data Privacy for Trust-Centric Digital Marketing: A Framework for Transparency and Consent Management
authors: Pritibala Sudhakar Ingle, Rahul Diliprao Tamhane
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: Digital marketing has become a core strategy in captivating consumers through personalized content, which is done by the collection and analysis of personal user data. This personalization motivates marketing effectiveness but at the same time it has also raised concerns over privacy, data misuse, and consumer autonomy. The General Data Protection (GDPR) and the California Consumer Privacy Act(CCPA) an existing privacy regulations have attempted to reinforce consumer rights, still they often fall short in delivering real-time transparency and granular consent management. Through this paper a block chain-enabled architecture is proposed which integrates decentralized identity management and smart contracts to create a consent-driven, transparent data-sharing model. This proposed model empowers a granular control to users over their personal data by enabling them to explicitly grant or deny access to all marketing platforms. The approach of immutability of blockchain and the decentralization of Interplanetary File System (IPFS) addresses user privacy, trust and compliance requirements. System's functionality is demonstrated by implementing a prototype using Ethereum and MetaMask which results as an improvement in data control, transparency and regulatory alignment.

title: Research on Bird Detection Algorithm in Farmland Based on Convolutional Neural Network
authors: Huanhuan Peng, Jiang Xiong
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Constrained by complex environmental factors, traditional bird detection methods suffer from insufficient accuracy, which limits the response efficiency and practical effectiveness of bird control systems. To address this, this study proposes an enhanced bird detection method based on the YOLOv11 model. The innovation lies in embedding a Hybrid Dilated Residual Attention Block (HDRAB) attention module into the backbone network, which significantly improves feature representation capabilities through integrated residual connections, void convolution, and attention mechanisms. Additionally, an A-Down down-sampling module replaces conventional convolution operations in the backbone and neck layers, effectively reducing parameter size and computational complexity while optimizing feature extraction. Experimental results demonstrate that the improved YOLOv11-HA model achieves a 4.34% improvement in mAP50 compared to the baseline YOLOv11, with parameter volume decreasing from 2.68×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sup> to 2.23×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sup> (a 16.79% reduction) and computational cost dropping from 6.8 GFLOPs to 6.1 GFLOPs (also reduced by 16.79%). This model not only enhances detection accuracy but also demonstrates lightweight advantages, providing reliable technical support for the development of intelligent bird-repelling devices.

title: AI Fiesta - A Platform that Compares LLM Models
authors: Elizabeth Rani G, Mannam Ganesh Babu, Dhusinthan V, Ruban Srijith A
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: The fast development of Artificial Intelligence (AI) has resulted in the creation of many different models with different levels of performance, complexity, and the scope of application. The choice of the most appropriate model also continues to be a problem because of the unintegrated evaluation techniques and a scarcity of comparison tools. To overcome this, we offer AI Fiesta, a model comparison platform, which aims to offer an interactive dashboard that facilitates a systematic analysis. The platform encompasses the combination of various AI models through a single interface with the visualization of performance, ranking based on metrics, and comparative insights. To guarantee the consistency of data processing, deep learning (DL) algorithm was used to provide data persistence, which would make the storage, retrieval, and dynamic update of experimental outcomes effective. The integration helps in a smooth interaction and durability of the platform. Through both transparent benchmarking and continuous data management, AI Fiesta will enable researchers and practitioners to make faster and better-informed model choice, which will eventually lead to the better deployment strategies in the real world.

title: Research on Absolute Distance Measurement Technology
authors: Zhizhong Zhu, Dengfeng Dong, Weihu Zhou
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Measurement Control and Instrumentation (MCAI)
abstract: The precise acquisition of distance data critically depends on Absolute Distance Measurement (ADM) technology. This paper comprehensively examines frequency-modulated continuous wave (FMCW), pulsed laser ranging, and ultrasonic ranging technologies, evaluating their application value across automotive manufacturing, aerospace, and industrial automation. FMCW technology demonstrates superior ranging accuracy and resolution through frequency difference analysis despite its susceptibility to multipath interference; pulsed laser ranging achieves long-distance precision via optical pulse transmission while facing ambient light limitations; ultrasonic technology offers cost-effective short-range solutions though constrained by environmental factors. Current challenges include signal processing complexity in FMCW systems, environmental sensitivity of pulsed laser ranging measurements, and resolution limitations in ultrasonic methods. This paper summarizes the research results of the past few years, points out the problems existing in the current technology, and puts forward suggestions for future research directions, providing an important reference for research in related fields.

title: Optimizing Rice Quality through Image Processing And Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Chandra Singh Nitte, K.V.S.S.S.S. Sairam, Ks Akhilesh
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Computing, Semiconductor, Mechatronics, Intelligent Systems and Communications (COSMIC)
abstract: Image-based analysis is crucial for enhancing the efficiency and accuracy of rice grain evaluation, utilizing computer vision and image processing techniques. This methodology involves capturing rice grain images and applying various techniques to classify and assess their quality. This concept utilizes OpenCV to implement a real-time system, processing images from a camera to provide insights into grain size, shape, and quality. Classification is based on size, determined through contour analysis and area calculation, with contour detection, filtering, and ellipse fitting identifying rice grains. A novel approach detects broken grains by analyzing sharp edges within contours, improving rice quality assessment. The code offers visual representations of the process, displaying original images and various processing stages.
