This approach provides a practical solution for real-time rice evaluation, contributing to streamlining quality control processes in agriculture and food industries. By combining contour analysis, ellipse fitting, and innovative edge detection techniques, the system achieves accurate classification and quality assessment, holding significant potential for enhancing production and distribution practices.

title: Design and Simulation of a Smart Public Distribution System with Stock Monitoring and Lighting Optimization
authors: Sanchana L, Hariprasath S, Deepak Prabhu C, Mohamed Zeeyath S S, Sreekanth R
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: The paper suggests a Digitally Enhanced Smart Ration Shop Model that will help streamline the process of wide distribution as well as make it more transparent and comfortable to the user. The system is also integrated with online inventory display screens revealing customer real time inventory status and avoids cases of confusion and congestion. DIALux simulation assists in optimizing lighting, fan systems etc in such a way that comfort is brought to people in a queue. A program created specially does the computations of the most optimal lighting and fan setups based on the room size and the specifications are fixed. It also has a well-developed system of tracking entry-exit of the stock that will help in management of the stock. The smart ration shop model is a concept of modernization and it deals with the transformation of basic services of the State in a dignified and convenient way, which is inherently in its essence designed in a modular way.

title: Edge-AI Medical Imaging Framework Using Residual Neural Networks for Enhanced Diagnostic Precision
authors: R. Vani, K Sanjai, V.T Saravanakumar, P Sri Azhagan, S M Surya Varsa
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: The need to have real-time, accurate, and low-resource medical imaging diagnostic systems has necessitated the inclusion of deep learning and edge computing. The new Edge-AI framework that is proposed in this paper ensures the low-latency inference on resource-constrained edge devices and enhances the accuracy of diagnostic through the exploitation of optimized Residual Neural Networks (ResNet). Compared to the majority of cloud-based solutions, the proposed structure has a light version of ResNet that can be trained with adaptive feature pruning and quantization aware. This capability allows for efficient deployment without a loss in diagnostic accuracy. Furthermore, the framework has a cross-layer residual attention mechanism to protect clinically relevant fine-grained features that are often lost during compressed architectures. Adaptive balancing of computation between central nodes and edge devices would be adopted through a distributed inference pipeline, allowing to save bandwidth and preserve privacy of patient data. Benchmark testing of medical imaging Experimental comparison shows that its energy efficiency improves by many times, reduces inference time by orders of magnitude, and its diagnostic accuracy exceeds the state-of-theart methods. This article sheds light on how edge-resilient ResNet models have the potential to make medical diagnosis intimate to real-time, scalable, privacy-sensitive, and correct.

title: PLM-Net: Physics and Large-Model Guided Network for Single Image Dehazing
authors: Zhoufeng Yin, Tongwei Lu, Tao Lu, Jiaming Wang
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotic Systems and Applications (ICRSA)
abstract: Current dehazing networks often decouple physical modeling from deep feature learning, resulting in limited interpretability and existing dehazing methods tend to ignore the multi-scale characteristics of images, due to the dependence on limited training data and shallow priors. To address these issues, we propose PLM-Net: Physics and Large-Model Guided Network for Single Image Dehazing, a novel framework that unifies generative semantic knowledge and physical constraints in a synergistic dual-path design. The Multimodal Diffusion Feature Adapter (MDFA) injects semantic priors from Stable Diffusion into the dehazing pipeline in a scale-aware manner, enhancing the network's understanding of haze distribution and scene structure. Simultaneously, the Multi-scale Physics-Driven Block (MPB) embeds the physical dehazing process into the network via differentiable transmission and atmospheric light estimation, improving interpretability and performance. Extensive experiments on synthetic and real-world benchmarks demonstrate that PLM-Net achieves state-of-the-art results while maintaining clear physical meaning in its predictions.

title: Single-Snapshot Direction Finding Method Based on Quantum Artificial Hummingbird Algorithm
authors: Xitao Sun, Yidu Zhang, Lulu Wu, Joshua Lee, Hongyuan Gao
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: Direction of Arrival (DOA) estimation, also known as spatial spectrum estimation, is the focus of this paper. The study aims to investigate DOA estimation under impulsive noise and small snapshot conditions. Traditional MUSIC algorithms typically require a large number of snapshots and high signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) to achieve accurate direction finding. Although the maximum likelihood algorithm can handle coherent sources under low SNR and strong impulsive noise conditions, it still suffers from high computational complexity, excessive computational load, and poor convergence. Therefore, this paper proposes a single-snapshot direction-finding method based on a quantum artificial hummingbird mechanism, specifically the quantum artificial hummingbird algorithm under a uniform linear array, where the low-order moments are replaced with a cosine kernel function. This method can improve both the accuracy of direction finding and the robustness of DOA estimation.

title: Project Synapse: Building the Neural Network of Your Enterprise
authors: Hemant Arvind Mandge, Somen Sarangi, Manisha Dash
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: In an era where business agility is paramount, the ability of an enterprise to process information and react to market changes is dictated by the nervous system that connects its digital assets. However, traditional application integration methodologies are slow, brittle, and expensive, acting as a systemic bottleneck rather than an intelligent facilitator. This paper introduces Project Synapse, a self-service, low-code integration platform designed from the ground up to function as the neural network of the enterprise. The architecture is explicitly bio-inspired, comprising a central management service, the Nucleus (analogous to the cell body), and a high-performance, distributed execution engine, the Axon (the signal transmission pathway). By abstracting profound technical complexity behind a simple user interface and leveraging a powerful embedded rule engine for synaptic logic, the platform empowers non-technical product owners to forge new connections between applications dynamically. This paradigm shift transforms integration from a complex, multi-month coding endeavor into a simple, rapid configuration exercise, enabling the business to operate at the speed of thought.

title: A Design and Development of Enhanced Solid Biofuel Classification and Optimized Grid Management Using ML Approaches
authors: T Sreenivasa Murthy, OdehMahmoud, T Chaitanya, A Kiran Kumar Reddy, B Rajalakshmi, Ramya M
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: To enhance the performance of dual-fuel engines by classification and predictive analytics for energy systems, we developed the ESBCOG model. It utilizes biogas from an anaerobic digester and a B20 blend of biodiesel overall as fuels, employing a variable compression ratio engine for detailed experimental data collection. Data processing involved cleaning and min-max normalization to improve accuracy. Optimization of resource allocation used integer programming, while a hybrid MSA-CBLSTM model effectively classified biofuels by accurately capturing sequential dependencies. Logistic regression was employed for estimating binary probabilities, along with Gradient Boosting and Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) for higher accuracy and reduced overfitting risk. Accuracy, precision, recall, F-score, MCC, training and validation accuracy, and the loss of ESBCOG are the parameters used to evaluate the model's performance.

title: Integrating Hybrid Cryptography with Role-Based Access Management in Multi-Tier Cloud File Encryption
authors: K.Sundara Velrani, Lokeshvaran N, Jerome Richard D
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Cloud computing has the advantage of storage which is scaled with the disadvantage of data confidentiality, secure handling of key and fine-grained access control. In an attempt to resolve the above challenges, the research paper presents a hybrid cryptographic framework between the AES and RSA schemes combined with the Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) in ensuring safe multi-tier cloud storage. AES is used to efficiently encrypt files whereas RSA is used to secure AES session keys. RBAC correlates user roles (Admin, Manager, Staff, Guest) with file sensitivity levels (Public, Restricted, Confidential, Highly Sensitive), and allows the implementation of access control with accuracy. Forensic preparedness is achieved through wholesome logging and auditing. The system was developed in python and tested on a Kaggle-based cloud data. Findings indicate that the framework encrypts and decrypts data at very high rates, access controls at 99 % accuracy and high resistance to brute force and unauthorized access, better than AES-only and RSA-only frameworks. This validates the idea that hybrid cryptography and RBAC are effective in ensuring the scalability in terms of security, efficiency, and usability in the multi-tenant cloud settings.

title: IoT based Hybrid EV Charger with Mobile Monitoring
authors: Mr.S.MariaAntony, Balavishva N, Hamsaanand A V, Madhan N M
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: This project presents a hybrid EV charger that reliably charges EVs using both grid and solar power. Based on the amount of sunlight detected by an LDR sensor, the system automatically alternates between power sources. For effective voltage control, an ESP32 microcontroller uses DC–DC converters to manage the charging process. User convenience is increased by a mobile application that allows live monitoring of charging parameters, such as battery voltage ,current ,ampere, power and status. This design offers a cost-effective solution for the expanding electric vehicle market while supporting eco-friendly transportation initiatives by combining renewable energy with smart monitoring to ensure energy efficiency, sustainability, and scalability.

title: Transformer Acoustic Fingerprint Fault Diagnosis Method Based on Adaptive Wavelet Denoising of Fault-Sensitive Frequency Bands and XGBoost
authors: Lusheng Hou, Taian Shi, Hui Chang, Hejia Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Measurement Control and Instrumentation (MCAI)
abstract: This paper addresses the challenges of noise interference and feature extraction difficulties in transformer acoustic fingerprint fault diagnosis by proposing an intelligent diagnostic method that integrates fault-sensitive frequency band adaptive wavelet denoising with XGBoost. The method identifies key sensitive frequency bands by analyzing the acoustic spectral characteristics of different fault types and implements a differentiated threshold strategy, effectively suppressing noise while preserving acoustical features relevant to diagnosis. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves 99.79% accuracy in diagnosing 10 types of transformer faults, showing significant improvement over traditional methods while maintaining good computational efficiency. This approach provides a reliable acoustic fingerprint diagnostic technique for transformer condition monitoring.

title: Optimizing Construction Safety: Multimodal Prompts For Automated Image Descriptions In Daily Construction Reports
authors: Chuan-Yu Chang, Abida Khanum, Sheng-Gui Su, Ming-Hsiu Tsai, Hui-Huang Hsu, Wei-Ting Chen, Hsiang-Wei Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: We explore the potential of Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) that combine the strengths of GPT, LLaMA, and VLMs to handle multimodal inputs such as text, image, and more in various natural language understanding tasks. Despite advances, managing and analyzing images from construction sites remains a significant challenge in construction projects. Daily site monitoring ensures safety, maintains quality, and meets regulatory requirements. Traditionally, this process relies on-site managers manually capturing photos and writing daily reports, a time-consuming and labor-intensive task. To address this challenge, we proposed CSMMP-Dr (Construction Safety Multimodal Monitoring with Prompts for Daily Reporting), a novel multimodal framework designed to automatically generate comprehensive daily safety reports from construction site images. Using the capabilities of large multimodal models, CSMMP-Dr combines image understanding with textual generation to detect and describe safety conditions on construction sites. The framework uses real-world data from CECI Engineering Consultants, Inc., Taiwan. CSMMP-Dr processes input images through a dual-branch architecture: one for scene understanding using a multimodal SafeSceneView module and another for deep visual feature extraction via a Vision Transformer. Retrieved contextual information from a visual-textual database enhances the prompt and produces textual summaries and annotated images. Experimental results demonstrate that CSMMP-Dr significantly reduces reporting workload and improves clarity in safety monitoring, offering a practical solution for construction site management. We processed 1,409 images, achieving an average inference time of 12 seconds per task.

title: Multi-Task Learning for Fine-Grained Emotion and Sentiment Classification: A Comparative Study of Recurrent and Transformer Architectures
authors: Aleena Saji, Vignesh Rajkumar, Sujitha Juliet
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: Emotion and sentiment classification are critical components of affective computing. This study presents a rigorous comparative analysis of three established deep learning mod-els-Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU), Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), and the Transformer-based BERT-applied to a multitask classification problem combining six fine-grained emotions and binary sentiment. Experiments are conducted on a focused subset of the GoEmotions dataset. The methodology includes essential techniques such as synonym-based data augmentation to expand the training set and weighted random sampling to mitigate class imbalance. To enhance rigor, ablation studies on data augmentation and statistical significance tests on performance differences are included. The results demonstrate that the Transformer model significantly surpasses the RNN baselines, achieving a macro-averaged emotion F1-score of 0.729 and a sentiment $\mathbf{F 1}$-score of 0.943. An in-depth confusion analysis is provided, showing that while the Transformer excels, subtle semantic distinctions, particularly between admiration and approval, remain a primary source of misclassification. This work affirms the superiority of attention-based architectures for complex, fine- grained multi-task NLP, provides empirical evidence on the impact of preprocessing techniques, and establishes a foundation for future improvements in multi-label and hierarchical emotion modeling.

title: Optimization Model for Microgrid Considering Time-of-Use Electricity Pricing
authors: Yishu Sun, Leping Li, Dexuan Li, Yubin Guo, Minsheng Yang, Zhi Yang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Power System and Energy Internet (PoSEI)
abstract: This paper addresses the economic operation optimization issue of microgrids under the time-of-use electricity pricing environment and proposes a microgrid optimization model that comprehensively considers the time-of-use electricity pricing mechanism, energy storage system configuration, and multi-park loads. By constructing an objective function with the goal of minimizing the total system cost, it covers the cost of purchasing electricity from the main grid, the operating cost of distributed generation, and the average annual cost of energy storage systems, and introduces multiple constraints such as power balance, energy storage charging and discharging, and equipment capacity. The model is solved by using a genetic algorithm with an improved mutation operator to dynamically adjust the mutation rate and enhance the global optimization ability. The case study analysis, based on typical daily data, compared the optimization results under the scenarios of fixed electricity prices and time-of-use electricity prices, verifying the effectiveness of the proposed model in reducing the total system cost, optimizing energy storage configuration, and enhancing operational economy. The research provides theoretical support and practical reference for the collaborative dispatching and resource allocation of microgrids under the time-of-use electricity price mechanism.

title: AI-Enhanced Agent-Based Simulation for Urban Mobility Policy Evaluation: Driving Restriction Zones in the Paris Region
authors: Tatiana Seregina, Tarek Chouaki, Nicolas Coulombel, Sebastian Hörl
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Innovative Applications (AIIA)
abstract: Driving restriction policies are increasingly used to curb congestion and pollution, yet their impacts are difficult to assess at scale. Agent-based transport simulations like MATSim offer detailed insights but are computationally intensive, limiting scenario exploration. This study investigates the use of artificial intelligence (AI) as a surrogate modeling approach to accelerate such analyses. Diverse Driving Restriction Zone (DRZ) scenarios were simulated in the Paris region to capture mobility and environmental impacts, and multiple machine learning models were trained on the MATSim outputs. Initial results show that while methods such as KNN, Gradient Boosted Trees, and multi-output Neural Networks struggle with high errors, separating models by policy outcome - especially at the regional level - improves accuracy, with Neural Networks and Linear Regression achieving RMSEs below 2%. Overall, aggregated, region-wide impacts appear more predictable than localized effects. These findings highlight both the potential and the current limitations of AI-enhanced simulation frameworks, paving the way toward scalable, data-driven tools for urban mobility policy design.

title: Privacy-Preserving Medical Image Classification Using Homomorphic Encryption
authors: Rakhi Bharadwaj, Priyanshi Patle, Bhagyesh Pawar, Nikita Pawar, Kunal Pehere
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: The sensitive sector like medical care are growing rapidly, it is critical to maintain data confidentiality and integrity when using artificial intelligence (AI) in computing. Convolutional neural networks (CNNs), a piece of deep learning model, have shown impressive results in applications like image classification. However, there are significant risks associated with exposing raw data to central servers when using traditional centralized model training techniques. In highly regulated spaces such as healthcare, this model of computation is no longer an option due to data privacy issues and legislation such as GDPR and HIPAA. To overcome this vulnerability, we propose an end-to-end image classification system computed in an encrypted environment based on Homomorphic Encryption. It helps in computation on encrypted data without decrypting it, hence maintaining privacy even at inference and training phases. The implementation relies on the Cheon-Kim-Kim-Song (CKKS) encryption scheme implemented by the TenSEAL library, enabling approximate arithmetic on real numbers. A ResNet18 deep learning model pretrained on ImageN et and fine-tuned on a chest X-ray dataset is used as the base classifier. The model is adapted to run on encrypted feature vectors, allowing inference in an encrypted environment. Chest X-ray images from four classes-COVID-19, pneumonia, tuberculosis, and normal-make up the dataset used. This experiment demonstrates that homomorphically encrypted image classification is feasible with negligible performance and latency trade-offs. The model's classification accuracy is about 88%, and data confidentiality is 100% guaranteed. The deployment of secure AI models to privacy-critical applications, where data leakage can be catastrophic, like AI-aided radiology, smart diagnostics, and remote health care, is made possible by this work.

title: Harnessing Large Language Models for Personalized Education: Opportunities, Challenges, and Implications for SDG 4
authors: Ronel Francisco Ramos, Juan Paulo Hilario Magcuyao, Alfredo Lucion Calimbo, Roman Madrid De Angel
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: The rapid advancement of large language models (LLMs) such as ChatGPT, Claude, and Gemini presents new opportunities for personalized education. These AI systems are capable of tailoring learning experiences, providing instant feedback, and supporting self-paced study. However, questions remain regarding their pedagogical effectiveness, ethical implications, and alignment with educational goals. This study explores the opportunities and challenges of integrating LLMs into personalized learning environments in higher education. Using a mixed-method approach that combines experimental use of LLM-based tutoring with surveys and interviews of students and educators, the research evaluates their impact on engagement, learning outcomes, and inclusivity. Findings are expected to contribute to the discourse on AI in education while supporting the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goal 4 (Quality Education), particularly in promoting inclusive and equitable access to learning opportunities through emerging technologies

title: Stacked Deep Convolutional Neural Networks for Accurate Colorectal Cancer Classification from Endoscopic Images
authors: Faiza Bella, Abdelouahab Moussaoui, Ali Berrichi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Innovative Applications (AIIA)
abstract: Accurate classification of colorectal cancer (CRC) and related intestinal tract diseases from endoscopic images is critical for assisting pathologists and improving diagnostic efficiency. This paper presents a stacking ensemble framework that combines five deep convolutional neural networks (CNNs): VGG19, ResNet101, EfficientNet-B0, DenseNet121, and MobileNetV3. Each network was fine-tuned using transfer learning on the CRCCD_V1 dataset, with 3-fold cross-validation employed To strengthen both generalizability and robustness of the approach. Meta-features were generated by concatenating the softmax output probabilities of the base models, which were then used to train three meta-classifiers: Logistic Regression, Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost), and Random Forest(RF). Experimental results demonstrate that the stacking ensembles consistently outperform individual CNNs. Among the base models, MobileNetV3 achieved the highest standalone accuracy of 96.00%, whereas the XGBoost-based ensemble achieved the best overall performance with 96.46% accuracy, 96.51% precision, 96.45% F1-score, and a mean AUC value 0.9976. These outcomes emphasize the effectiveness of ensemble learning for automated CRC image classification and its potential to enhance clinical decision support.

title: AskDB: AI-Assisted Natural Language Interface for Database Querying and Visualization
authors: Swati Shilaskar, Prapti Dongaonkar, Pruthavik Gavali, Suhani Gunje
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: The growing reliance on data-driven insights in sectors around the world has created an ongoing problem. Many non-technical users struggle to effectively query and analyze databases with the complexities of Structured Query Language (SQL), limiting their ability to properly access data and significantly slowing down the decision-making process. This system proposed AskDB, an intelligent neural text-to-SQL system that enables users to use natural language queries as input in order to interact with a database. The system automatically translates user queries into valid SQL and executes them against the connected database, returning results to the user in tabular form and easily interpreted graphical visualization. AskDB's use of large language model (LLM) optimizes the translation of the user's input into SQL commands while contextually comprehending the intent of the query to create more accurate translations. The frontend was developed in React to create a responsive, user-friendly experience, while the backend was developed in Python and SQL to JS the command, process the query, and connect and run the query against the selected database. AskDB also utilizes schemadriven query correction and prompt-engineering optimization to better support each end user with more accurate outputs. Experiments represent AskDB achieves an [exact-match] accuracy of 93% - still slightly less than T5 based systems worth between 73-84% accuracy while completing each task successfully. The Proposed framework brigde gap between human language and database querying.

title: A Brief Study on Point Cloud Optimization Algorithm Based on Graph Convolutional Network
authors: Jinchao Guo, Ruchao Liao, Jiangbo Feng, Haopeng Li, Zhenbing Zhao, Bing Li, Yuting Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: To address issues of information loss and computational complexity in point cloud data processing, this paper introduces a point cloud optimization algorithm based on Graph Convolutional Network (GCN), which allows for direct processing of raw point clouds. The algorithm creates an adjacency matrix using the k-Nearest Neighbors (k-NN) method to maintain local connectivity. It also integrates the Self-Attention mechanism and the Direct Attentional Graph Network (DAGN) to model long-range dependencies, thus improving robustness against sparse and noisy point clouds. The method primarily focuses on point cloud classification and segmentation tasks, with performance evaluated through accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. Experimental results show that the proposed optimization algorithm delivers excellent performance on multiple publicly available datasets. Compared to traditional methods, it demonstrates greater adaptability and robustness, confirming the effectiveness and practicality of graph convolution structures in point cloud processing.

title: An XGBoost Machine Learning Model to Detect Fraudulent Transactions in Real-Time Applications
authors: K. Maharajan, M. Siva Santhosh Kumar Reddy, G. Raja Sekhar Reddy, K. Ashok Kumar, B. Naresh
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Financial fraud has been complicated in the digital era. This has resulted in a dramatic loss of revenue and also security challenges. Conventional detection of fraud systems are typically unable to keep up with emerging fraud patterns due to their preset rule base. This paper implements the Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) machine learning classification algorithm which is effective, scalable and suits the detection of imbalanced data to generate a real-time fraud detection machine. The proposed approach involves tuning of the hyper parameters, feature engineering and painstaking handling of the data used. It addresses the balancing of the data on transactions through such methods as cost-sensitive learning and SMOTE. Tested on actual financial data, the system attains high performance with such metrics as precision, recall, F1- score, and AUC-ROC. In the digital economy, financial frauds are huge concerns. Cybercriminals are adopting ever sophisticated methods to capitalise on the vulnerabilities in systems of online financial systems. The velocity and multidimensionality of the present-day financial transactions indicate that the conventional fraud detection strategies, which tend to be inert and rule-intensive are no longer effective. Such systems lack real-time fraud prevention capability because they have very high false positive rates, cannot easily scale up, and have long reaction times. To guarantee effective antifraud detection and fraud resilience to evolving cyberthreats, adaptive learning and explainability of the model has additionally been integrated into a real-time monitoring system.

title: MerkleDoc: A Privacy-Preserving Blockchain-Based Document Verification System
authors: Akshat Patil, Arya Manve, Aarya Lomte, Anshuman Dalmia, Ayush Gupta, Sunil Sangave
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: MerkleDoc is a hybrid, privacy-preserving document verification system that anchors cryptographic fingerprints of documents on a public blockchain while keeping document contents off-chain. The system divides documents into page-level SHA-256 hashes, constructs a Merkle tree, and stores only the Merkle root on-chain together with an EIP-712 issuer signature that cryptographically binds issuance to an owner's address. Verifiers can confirm the authenticity and ownership of any page using a compact Merkle inclusion proof without accessing the full document or a centralized backend. We describe the system design, security assumptions, smart-contract interface, and implementation choices, and we evaluate latency, gas consumption, and scalability on an Ethereum testnet. The code and evaluation scripts are available at: https://github.com/pieakshat/merkleAuthenticate.git.

title: Multi-Objective Improved Differential Evolution Algorithm Based Smart Home Energy Management System Considering Energy Storage System, Photovoltaic, Electric Vehicle
authors: Sreekanth R, Ramesh Babu M, Malini A, Joshika P
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: In contemporary smart grids, effective energy management is necessary to meet the balance between electricity consumption, cost, and sustainability. Traditional home energy systems are not adaptable and intelligent enough to manage the dynamic nature of renewables and variable pricing. To overcome these difficulties, the present system presents a Multi- Objective Improved Differential Evolution (MO-IDE) algorithm-based Smart Home Energy Management System (SHEMS) with photovoltaic (PV) generation, energy storage systems (ESS), and electric vehicles (EVs). The system maximizes power distribution by reducing energy cost, minimizing the peak-to-average ratio, and maximizing the usage of renewable energy. The MO-IDE algorithm utilizes adaptive mutation and control parameters for quicker convergence and optimization accuracy, and decision-tree-based scheduling ensures real-time execution with efficient load shifting, ESS management, and EV coordination. The goal is to maximize energy efficiency, cost savings, and grid stability through smart decision-making. The innovation is in the integration of state-of- the-art optimization with scheduling based on machine learning, which gives a robust, scalable, and sustainable solution for the next-generation smart home.

title: Domain Translation of a Soft Robotic Arm using Conditional Cycle Generative Adversarial Network
authors: Nilay Kushawaha, Carlo Alessi, Lorenzo Fruzzetti, Egidio Falotico
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotic Systems and Applications (ICRSA)
abstract: Deep learning provides a powerful method for modeling the dynamics of soft robots, offering advantages over traditional analytical approaches that require precise knowledge of the robot's structure, material properties, and other physical characteristics. Given the inherent complexity and non-linearity of these systems, extracting such details can be challenging. The mappings learned in one domain cannot be directly transferred to another domain with different physical properties. This challenge is particularly relevant for soft robots, as their materials gradually degrade over time. In this paper, we introduce a domain translation framework based on a conditional cycle generative adversarial network (CCGAN) to enable knowledge transfer from a source domain to a target domain. Specifically, we employ a dynamic learning approach to adapt a pose controller trained in a standard simulation environment to a domain with tenfold increased viscosity. Our model learns from input pressure signals conditioned on corresponding end-effector positions and orientations in both domains. We evaluate our approach through trajectory-tracking experiments across five distinct shapes and further assess its robustness under noise perturbations and periodicity tests. The results demonstrate that CCGAN-GP effectively facilitates cross-domain skill transfer, paving the way for more adaptable and generalizable soft robotic controllers.

title: Build-A-Volcap: Automated Synthetic Validation of Real-World Volumetric Capture Quality
authors: Antonella Rech, Giulia Martinelli, Nicola Garau, Nicola Conci, Francesco De Natale
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: Volumetric capture techniques have significantly advanced in recent years, enabling detailed 3D reconstructions of dynamic real-world scenes. However, predicting their performance prior to real-world deployment remains challenging, often leading to costly experimental setups and uncertain outcomes. In this paper, we present Build-A-Volcap, an automated synthetic validation environment designed to predict the quality of real-world volumetric capture systems. Our solution constructs comprehensive synthetic datasets and environments that faithfully simulate practical capture conditions. This enables rigorous testing and benchmarking of volumetric methods such as photogrammetry, NeRF, Gaussian Splatting and Radiant Foam without the need for physical setups. Through extensive experiments, we demonstrate how Build-A-Volcap effectively identifies methodological strengths and limitations, significantly reducing the synthetic-to-real gap. Our pipeline enables researchers and companies to optimize and validate their volumetric capture setups virtually, ensuring robust performance upon real-world deployment. More information and code release on our project page: https: //mmlab-cv.github.io/Build-A-Volcap/.

title: Convergence of Iterative Learning Control for Stochastic Generalized Systems
authors: Zhaoqiang Ge
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Control and Computing Science (ICICCS)
abstract: Convergence of iterative learning control (ILC) algorithm for stochastic generalized systems is studied in the sense of integral solution in separable Hilbert spaces. It is proved with stochastic equation theory and GE-semigroup theory that the convergence of input error and tracking error is bounded in the mean square sense, respectively.

title: Educational Application of RAG-based LLMs
authors: Azlaan Khan, Sakshi Chandekar, Atharva Baikar, Akanksha Kanade, Sandeep Kadam, Veena Kadam
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: The integration of Large Language Models in the education field has highlighted issues like spreading of misinformation or wrong data, misalignment with curriculum or syllabus, and lack of personalized learning experiences. So, this research proposes a web-based intelligent tutoring system which combines concepts of fine-tuned Large Language Models and Retrieval Augmented Generation. This will help provide precise, personalized and curriculum-aligned assistance in studying. The proposed system will be able to process documents of different formats and then, transform and store them into a vector database for proper and semantic retrieval, and will cite or refer verified course materials in it’s responses using parameter-efficient fine-tuning. This ensures that system is reliable and adaptable with smooth conversations. Initial testing and analysis show improvements in accuracy, relevance and student satisfaction as compared to conventional Large Language Models. It will also be secured using OAuth, JSON Web Tokens, or other login security methods. The proposed system provides a cost-effective and scalable basis or template for creating domain-specific Artificial Intelligence tutoring systems, which align with objectives of education.

title: The Art Of Ai: how a Multimodal Model Reveals the Secrets of Human Creativity in Paintings
authors: Zhehan Zhang, Meihua Qian, Li Luo, Ripon Kumar Saha
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: Assessing artistic creativity has long been a challenge. Traditional tests are widely used but often require time-consuming manual scoring. Thus, researchers are exploring a new way, such as machine learning (ML), to automate the assessment. Recent research on visual artistic creativity assessment has demonstrated that ML methods are effective but constrained by their reliance on visual data alone. This study integrates textual descriptions alongside visual data for a more holistic assessment of paintings’ creativity, which is more sophisticated to measure than simple sketches. The multimodal model was fine-tuned and leveraged both visual and textual inputs. It achieved approximately 95.3% accuracy in predicting the painting creativity scores, demonstrating a strong positive correlation (Pearson r = 0.96) with expert ratings. The study allows a text-image evaluation of paintings’ creativity to better align with human interpretations.

title: Location-Information-Based Beamforming for Multi-IRS-Aided Systems
authors: Xueyan Cao, Xiaolong Wu, Shubin Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: This paper proposes a location-aware beamforming scheme for IRS-assisted OFDM systems that eliminates the need for cascaded channel estimation. The method uses a two-phase protocol—location-based passive beam training and rate-maximizing beam optimization—to reduce overhead while maintaining near-optimal performance. Simulations demonstrate significant overhead reduction and improved rate compared to DFT-based methods, particularly under short coherence times or large IRS arrays.

title: A Genetic Algorithm based on Edge Assembly Crossover for Slide Stainer scheduling Standard
authors: Jiake Wu, Hongjie Zheng, Xiang Fu, Fangyan Dong, Kewei Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: The automatic pathological slide staining machine is the core equipment of the modern pathological diagnosis system. This equipment significantly reduces the labor costs of hospitals and laboratories in tissue slide staining through standardized processes. To build an efficient and stable staining system, this paper will focus on the site layout optimization problem of the pathological slide staining machine and aim to enhance the intelligence level of the staining system. The research first establishes a mathematical model based on the temporal sensitivity characteristics of the pathological slide staining process, defines an optimization function with the goal of minimizing the total staining time, and quantifies the risk of staining time fluctuations by introducing a fuzzy membership function. Around the non-waiting scheduling characteristic of pathological slide staining, the non-waiting constraint model is further designed in collaboration with the EAX genetic algorithm. Experiments show that this method can effectively handle complex constraints and improve scheduling efficiency.

title: Data Transformer - AI Driven Multimodal Fusion Network for Cardiovascular Risk Prediction using Multimodal Data
authors: Irin Sherly S, Mohanaprakash T A, Sindhu T, Nalini Subramanian, Dhribitri Bora, Cinthuja K
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) remains a global health burden, necessitating early and accurate prediction frameworks. This research proposes a novel transformer-based multimodal deep learning architecture that integrates heterogeneous data sources—ECG signals, clinical parameters, demographic attributes, and lifestyle habits (e.g., smoking, alcohol consumption, and dietary behavior)—to enhance prediction accuracy. Unlike traditional CNN-LSTM or ensemble models, the proposed framework employs a Vision Transformer (ViT) for ECG signal analysis, BERT-like encoder blocks for textual and tabular clinical data, and a self-attention-based fusion module to capture cross-modal interactions. The fusion network efficiently combines the temporal dynamics of ECG with structured lifestyle and clinical features. Experimental results on publicly available datasets show the proposed model achieves an accuracy of 94.6%, precision of 93.8%, recall of 92.7%, F1-score of 93.2%, and AUC-ROC of 95.1%, outperforming CNN-LSTM and Random Forest baselines. This approach demonstrates the power of transformer architectures in modeling multimodal biomedical data and offers a reliable, scalable solution for intelligent cardiovascular health assessment and prevention.

title: 2D Multiphysics Transient Modelling of a Molten Carbonate Electrolyser Under Step-Change Current Inputs
authors: Durand Brunel Zozime Tsiatsipy, Jonathan Deseure, Jean-Jacques Kadjo, Dominique Grondin, Krishna Busawon
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Environment Friendly Energies and Applications (EFEA)
abstract: Molten Carbonate Electrolysis Cell (MCEC) is considered an innovative solution to produce low-carbon hydrogen (H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>) and synthesis gas (H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>+CO) through solar photovoltaic power sources. In order to investigate the possibility of using a MCEC directly coupled to solar electric power, it is crucial to study the MCEC’s transient behaviour. In this context, this study proposes the development of a dynamic and multiphysics 2D model of a MCEC single cell. Step-change current profiles were applied to analyse the system’s dynamic responses in terms of charge, mass, and heat transfer. Simulation results revealed that electrical voltage reacts quickly to sudden changes, with a response time of only a few milliseconds (0.4-0.6 s). Mass transfer responds more slowly than charge transfer, with gas molar fractions requiring around 1 s to reach a new steady state. In the MCEC, heat transfer, particularly temperature, is the slowest dynamic phenomenon, taking approximately 1.5 hours to reach a new steady state. These results highlight that temperature, identified as the most critical dynamic parameter of the cell, requires an adapted control strategy when coupled with a highly fluctuating electrical power supply to ensure efficient MCEC operation and optimal hydrogen/syngas production.

title: Machine Learning for Big Data Analytics: Challenges, Trends, and Future Research Directions
authors: Alamelu R, Ranjithkumar G, Chandru K, Priya R V, Aparna P, M.G.Dinesh
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: The rapid expansion of Big Data has revolutionized how organizations and societies create, store, and use information, but it has brought opportunities and challenges to effective intelligent data-driven decision-making. The capacity of Machine Learning (ML) to learn patterns, make predictions, and automate processes has turned it into an important key to unlocking the full potential of Big Data. This survey gives an in-depth overview of the overlap between ML and Big Data, including fundamental concepts, technology ecosystems, and a wide range of applications across the areas of healthcare, finance, smart cities, and governance. It also looks at some of the main issues like data heterogeneity, scalability, interpretability, security and privacy issues that restrict large-scale adoption. The research identifies some of the recent developments in the field such as deep learning, federated learning and edge intelligence which are transforming Big Data analytics. In addition, the paper outlines new research frontiers like sustainable and energy-efficient ML, hybrid models of heterogeneous data, human-in-the-loop systems, and cross-disciplinary applications to solve social issues such as climate change and disease epidemiology. Through a synthesis of previous work, this survey highlights the paradigm-shifting potential of ML in deriving actionable intelligence out of Big Data and describes future directions in developing scalable, secure, interpretable, and socially responsible analytics systems.

title: An Algorithm for Performance Evaluation of Prediction Models
authors: Rashi Jaiswal
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: The prediction models are used to predict the future data through the computation of historical data by learning the pattern. The objective of this paper is to determine which prediction model is how much strong, average, or weak in relation to the temporal dataset. Various researchers have measured the performance evaluation only for the small size of data. This paper proposed an algorithm for performance evaluation of prediction models (PEPM) based on performance scores for the different sizes of data. It provides the categorization of prediction models based on the mean performance score evaluation over the different sizes of temporal datasets. An illustration of the proposed algorithm has been done experimentally. The results obtained from experiments show that the performance of the prediction models is directly proportional to the size of the data.

title: SLIM: A Simplified LLVM IR Abstraction for Pointer Analysis
authors: Aditi Raste, Swati Jaiswal, Uday Khedker
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Pointer analysis is a static code analysis technique that derives points-to information of the pointers used in a program. This information can be used to enhance the precision and reasoning capability of LLMs when dealing with program semantics, to detect bugs in the program, identify security vulnerabilities, program verification, etc. LLVM (Low-Level Virtual Machine) is a widely used compiler framework that has gained significant popularity in industry as well as in academia for the ease of adding passes to it due to its well-designed IR. However, it is observed that program analysts when performing pointer analysis often encounter significant challenges in understanding the LLVM IR because (a) it employs a low-level, load-storebased memory abstraction instead of the higher-level, namebased abstraction used in three-address code (b) and includes numerous low-level details within its instructions. Hence, there exists a pressing demand, particularly for pointer analysis for an abstraction layer over the LLVM IR that will extract only the relevant information from the IR while ignoring the rest. To address this, we present SLIM (Simplified LLVM IR Modelling), an open-source tool engineered as a high-level abstraction over LLVM IR. SLIM employs a name-based memory abstraction and conceals low-level details, producing a clean intermediate representation that is ideal for pointer analysis. We observe that (a) With SLIM there is a reduction in the instruction count for performing pointer analysis as compared to LLVM IR by an average reduction of 52% on the programs analyzed from SPEC CPU 2017 benchmark suite. (b) SLIM provides an easy framework for implementing an analysis as per the scaffolded study conducted at IIT Bombay and VNIT, Nagpur.

title: OncoMouth: Deep Learning-Based Efficient Oral Cancer Detection
authors: Atharva Maslekar, Atharva Joshi, Atharva Suryavanshi, Yash Pawar, Snehal Rathi, Gauri Ghule
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: In the world of medicine, oral cancer is still a big problem with an estimated 475,000 new cases every year, sharply decreasing survival rates of individuals diagnosed with the disease at its advanced stage. The research compared various deep learning architectures for histopathological image classification into Normal and Oral Squamous Cell Carcinoma (OSCC). The dataset, downloaded from a publicly owned Kaggle repository, was split into 75 % training, 15 % validation, and 15 % test sets, with the latter two sets maintaining a balanced representation between OSCC and normal cases. Here are the models considered along with their accuracies on the test set: Basic CNN: 84.34%; ResNet50: 93.20%; DenseNet121: 84.72%; EfficientNetB3: 94.74%; EfficientNetB3 with FineTuning & Data Augmentation: 97.18%; MobileNetV2 with Fine-Tuning & Data Augmentation: 89.70%; and the proposed custom InceptionResNetV2(90%) variants with data normalization and augmentation. EfficientNetB3 set the record, with ResNet50 and the fine-tuned EfficientNetB3 keeping close behind. This supports the conclusion that the advanced architectures using transfer learning, fine-tuning, and augmentation fare better than those baseline CNNs in oral cancer recognition.

title: SCR Argo Farms: Integrating Emerging Technologies for Transparent and Intelligent Dairy Operations
authors: Shiwangi, Krishtina, Shivani, Deepa, Kavita Sharma, SRN Reddy
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: Milk is a widely consumed staple across the globe, often distributed through intermediaries such as Amul. In the conventional dairy supply chain, the involvement of multiple intermediaries significantly reduces the profits of milk producers, primarily due to limited transparency between producers and consumers. To address these limitations, a web-based dairy management system has been designed and developed for SCR Argo Farms, located in Andhra Pradesh, India. The system aims to connect milk consumers directly with producers, effectively eliminating middlemen. Developed using the MERN (MongoDB, Express, React, Node.js) stack, the platform offers a streamlined interface for transactions, user management, and order tracking. It also incorporates secure two-step authentication and a welldefined user role hierarchy to ensure data privacy and controlled access for both administrators and end-users. This study further discusses the system's design, architecture, and long-term vision for enabling a technology-driven, consumer-connected dairy ecosystem for SCR Argo Farms.

title: Next-Generation Turf Booking and Sports Management Using Modern Web Technologies
authors: Aryan Chugera, Atif Dadhiwale, Ronit Dahiwal, Sumit Dahiwal, Daksh Dharmani, Karan Daliya, Vishnu Sonwane
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Recreational sports in India are gaining popularity with the rise of turf facilities, but the digital tools supporting them are still limited in scope. Current applications emphasize reservations while neglecting challenges such as player coordination, analytics for turf owners, and event management. This paper introduces a cloud-based sports platform built on the MERN stack that integrates booking, player matchmaking, live engagement, and performance dashboards into a single system. By serving players, turf owners, and organizers alike, the platform seeks to streamline operations, enhance user experience, and strengthen community-level sports participation.

title: Understanding of Statistical Descriptors and Accelerated Calculation Methods through CNN
authors: Liyuan Wang, Xiangyun Ge, Richard Johnston, Chenfeng Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: In the field of materials science, statistical descriptors are essential for characterizing and understanding the microstructural properties of materials. However, traditional methods for calculating these descriptors usually rely on numerical simulations or analytical calculations, which are complex and time-consuming, limiting their practicality in large-scale applications. In this study, a new method based on convolutional neural networks (CNNs) is proposed to accelerate the calculation of statistical descriptors. We designed a CNN model that takes a two-dimensional binarized material microstructure image as input and predicts the key points of its two-point correlation function and pore size distribution. Experimental results on Fontainebleau sandstone(FS) materials show that the prediction accuracy of the CNN model is almost the same as that calculated by traditional methods, and the calculation speed is increased by 20 times. Therefore, this study provides an effective way to quickly and accurately calculate the statistical descriptors of material microstructure, which has important theoretical significance and practical application value.

title: FAIRM-WSN: A Fault-Aware Intelligent Routing and Maintenance Framework for Enhanced Wireless Sensor Network Performance
authors: Sulakshana Guduri, Govardhan Reddy Kamatam
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Wireless sensor networks (WSNs) are essential in the scope of Internet of Things (IoT) mainly environmental monitoring, industrial automation, and smart city projects. However, in practice, large-scale WSNs have a series of problems such as node failure, energy imbalance and environment uncertain. Hotspot and traffic congestion affects the network lifetime and reliability in case of static sink-based data collection. To address these, in this paper we present FAIRM-WSN an intelligent and comprehensive solution to the problem of fault-tolerance, energy efficiency, and data collection performance. The system contains three main parts: fault detection, clustering-based data collection and adaptive mobile sink path planning. For fault detection, a hybrid scheme is employed including the Principal Component Analysis (PCA) dimension reduction for data feature extraction and Deep Neural Network (DNN) whose parameters are fine-tuned by Grasshopper Optimization Algorithm (GOA) for high accuracy component localization when one fails. As a result, the healthy nodes are collected by DBSCAN to obtain energy and fault-conscious visiting points for the mobile sink. An agent based on Deep Q-Network (DQN) adaptively changes the trajectory of the sink according to network status. Experimental results on UNC WSN benchmark dataset show that FAIRM-WSN obtains the fault detection accuracy at about 99.72%, and energy saving of 22.3%, as well as better data delivery than some state-of-the-art algorithms. The results demonstrate the capabilities of FAIRM-WSN as a powerful and scalable approach for intelligent, fault-tolerant and energy-efficient WSN management over real world IoT systems.

title: Learning to Predict Constraints: Hybrid Neural-MPC Control Architectures for Real-Time Vehicle Path Tracking
authors: Ákos M. Bokor, Szilárd Aradi, Tamás Bécsi, László Palkovics, Ádám Szabó
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Vehicular Technology
abstract: This paper proposes hybrid Neural Network-based Model Predictive Control (NN-MPC) architectures for real-time autonomous vehicle path tracking. To compensate for their individual drawbacks, we integrate supervised learning directly into the optimization process to accelerate solver convergence. Specifically, Multilayer perceptrons are trained to learn a constraint-correction term added to the closedform unconstrained MPC solution, and to provide learning-assisted warm starts for an active-set QP solver by predicting the Lagrange multiplier vector and the active-constraint pattern. The first solution avoids online quadratic programming (QP) and achieves an approximately two orders of magnitude reduction in computation time, at the cost of approximate constraint enforcement in highly transient conditions, whereas the latter two solutions retain the original constrained optimization problem. The learning components are trained on a simplified design model and evaluated in the high-fidelity CarMaker environment to assess robustness under unmodeled dynamics and modeling errors. In CarMaker validation, the classificationbased warm start reduces the number of QP iterations by approximately 30% and computation time by 23% relative to a classical shift-initialization warm start, supporting more predictable real-time operation in representative driving scenarios.

title: Distributed Coverage Control for Air-Ground Robot Systems with Heterogeneous Sensing Capabilities
authors: Hang Zhang, Ronghao Zheng, Senlin Zhang, Meiqin Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: In multi-robot coverage control, ground robots aim to cover and monitor a domain optimally. However, when covering an extensive domain like a densely forested potential fire site, the sensing capabilities of ground robots are limited, resulting in poor coverage. Leveraging the aerial robots’ ability to expand sensing ranges through high-altitude flight, this paper proposes a fully distributed, air-ground coverage control scheme to address this challenge. First, aerial robots provide a low-resolution coverage of the domain. Then, they use coarse but broad sensing information to guide ground robots, with short-range but high-resolution sensing, to achieve a high-resolution coverage. Simultaneously, each aerial robot dynamically adjusts its cell size to match its load, enhancing the coverage performance. The convergence of the control scheme is proved and its performance is evaluated through simulations and experiments.

title: AHLLNS: An Automated Algorithm for Multi-Objective Heterogeneous Agricultural Robot Operation Scheduling Problems
authors: Hengwei Guo, Quanke Pan, Hongyan Sang, Zhonghua Miao, Wei Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Advances in multi-robot technology have accelerated the development of smart agriculture, enabling tasks to be executed collaboratively with higher efficiency. In heterogeneous agricultural robots collaborative operation scheduling, fuzzy time window and matching constraints significantly increase the problem complexity. This paper proposes a multi-objective heterogeneous agricultural robot operation scheduling model with fuzzy service time window and matching constraints (MHROS_FT&M), aiming to optimize the total operation cost and service level. Given the NP-hard property of MHROS_FT&M, the hierarchical learning large neighborhood search algorithm (HLLNS) is developed. HLLNS incorporates the hierarchical reinforcement learning to enhance adaptability, a dynamic programming-based approach to improve service levels, and a sub-problem collaboration and mutation strategy to escape local optimum. By employing automated algorithm design technique to optimize 12 key parameters, the automated HLLNS (AHLLNS) is realized. In practical smart-farming scenarios, AHLLNS supports the joint scheduling of heterogeneous robots such as spraying drones, weeding robots, and seeding drones under uncertain service times, and explicitly balances operation cost against farmer satisfaction. The obtained schedules reduce unnecessary travel and resource consumption while keeping service times within acceptable ranges for farmers. Through automatic parameter tuning and the use of problem-specific operators, AHLLNS effectively addresses fuzzy time windows and matching constraints, achieving better performance across different problem scales. Experimental comparisons with Gurobi and state-of-the-art algorithms demonstrate AHLLNS superior computational efficiency and solution quality, validating its effectiveness for MHROS_FT&M.

title: Large Improvements of Uniformity and Sensitivity from Reshaped Detection Coil for a Magnetometer_supp1-3662621.docx
authors: Chengliang Zhang
publish: N/A
abstract: The vibrating sample magnetometer is one of the most popular choices for measuring magnetic moment. The detection coil array determines the performance of a vibrating sample magnetometer to a great extent. In the past decades, researches have been striving to finely adjust the dimensions and spatial location of the circular coils to obtain a uniform zone of sensitivity. Here, we found that reshaping the traditional circular coils can be a simple but quite effective solution. Two noncircular coil designs: semicircular and oblong coils were proposed based on the distribution of magnetic flux density variation induced by the vibrating sample on the electromagnet pole plane via finite element analysis. Compared with the conventional circular coils, the proposed semicircular/oblong coils exhibited larger uniform zone by about 18%/20% and significantly enhanced sensitivity by about 47%/49% at the center of the coil array, respectively, under the limited circular area on the pole plane. Furthermore, by appropriately enlarging the semicircular and oblong coils while maintaining the distance between the left and right coil pairs unchanged, a uniform zone expansion of about 53%/35% and a sensitivity increase of about 9%/11% over the circular coils were obtained. The simultaneous improvement in both the uniform zone and sensitivity via detection coil reshaping is advantageous for enhancing the repeatability and accuracy of the vibrating sample magnetometer.

title: Distributed and Autonomous Group Management Supporting Group Fusion for UAVs
authors: Fengqun Wang, Manting Gan, Hong Zhong, Qingyang Zhang, Jie Cui, Debiao He
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: With increasingly complex tasks, cooperation among multiple unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) groups has become more significant. However, in complex operational environments, UAVs may operate outside the communication coverage of the trusted authority (TA), making continuous online TA services unavailable. Under such circumstances, most existing group management methods have difficulty achieving group fusion and cannot flexibly update post-fusion member certificates. Therefore, we propose an autonomous UAV group management scheme based on mobile proactive secret sharing. First, the scheme achieves autonomous group fusion by updating the subsecrets of UAVs. Second, without the participation of a TA, the scheme supports the dynamic self-updating of certificates, ensuring secure communication in the new group and continuous availability of certificates. Security proofs and analyses show that the proposed scheme is secure under the random oracle model and can resist several common attacks. The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed scheme outperforms related schemes in computational performance and is suitable for secure and efficient UAV group management scenarios.

title: Optimizing Local-Global Fused Feature Space with Category-Center-Aware Supervised Contrastive Learning for Urban 3D Mesh Segmentation
authors: Guangyao Zhou, Guangyun Zhang, Rongting Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Semantic urban 3D meshes have widely applied in the fields of photogrammetry and remote sensing. Acquiring discriminative feature representations to improve semantic segmentation accuracy in urban 3D meshes remains a significant challenge. To address this issue, a novel framework for urban 3D mesh semantic segmentation is proposed in this paper, which comprises three key innovations: (1) an adaptive local edge feature extractor designed to capture fine-grained geometric details across diverse local structures; (2) a local-global fusion module that synergistically combines these local features with global contextual representations extracted via transformer networks; and (3) a supervised category-center-aware contrastive learning strategy that addresses class imbalance and improves the discriminability of feature representations. Ablation studies validate the individual contributions of each component. Evaluated on three benchmark datasets, namely SUM, seMet, and Wuhan, our framework achieves state-of-the-art performance, consistently surpassing existing methods across all three datasets. The code is available at https://github.com/NJTechZhang/Category-Center-Aware-Contrastive-Learning-Mesh.git.

title: Tidal Flat Elevation Inversion Model Based on Moisture-sensitive Features (TFEIM-MSF)
authors: Jianbo Xiao, Qizhi Zhuang, Li Ye, Shanlin Gao, Liang Cheng, Manchun Li, Chunpeng Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Tidal flats, located between the highest and lowest tidal levels, have topography that directly determines habitat patterns and plays a critical role in ecological security and sustainable management. Existing satellite remote sensing–based elevation inversion methods primarily include the waterline method and the inundation frequency method. However, both approaches exhibit limitations in accuracy and in capturing fine-scale tidal flat topographic features. Additionally, single-temporal optical imagery–based sediment moisture content (SMC) models, while physically capable of representing elevation differences, are highly susceptible to slope effects and residual water interference, which hampers their large-scale applicability. To address these challenges, this study proposes a novel tidal flat elevation inversion method (TFEIM-MSF) based on optical imagery and inundation frequency information. The method constructs pixel-scale cumulative moisture-sensitive features to enhance spectral information utilization. Combined with inundation frequency features, a deep learning network is designed to fuse detailed and trend information at the output stage, using ICESat-2 LiDAR elevation data as control points to achieve high-precision tidal flat elevation inversion. Experimental results from three typical tidal flat regions in England show that TFEIM-MSF maintains high accuracy under complex environmental conditions, achieving RMSE values of 0.30–0.33 m and R² values of 0.91–0.95, demonstrating consistent improvements over the existing Tide2Topo method. This method overcomes the limitations of information utilization and fitting capability inherent in inundation frequency and waterline-based approaches, offering an efficient and low-cost technical solution for global tidal flat elevation monitoring.

title: On the Convergence Club Nature of Competitiveness and Efficiency across Firms by Technological Complexity and Size_supp1-3664073.docx
authors: Madjid Tavana
publish: N/A
abstract: Digitalization strategies emerge through interactions among producers, consumers, and institutions across value chains, leading to gains in productivity, the introduction of new patents, and innovations in products and processes. Dynamic Capabilities theory extends the static resource-based view of the firm by incorporating learning and innovation in evolving environments. Its collaborative extension has recently been introduced to analyze the behavior of corporate dynamics within evolving ecosystems shaped by Information and Communication Technologies and firms' digitalization strategies. However, empirical evaluations of how digital value chains influence firm level productivity and innovation remain limited, relying on static efficiency evaluation frameworks. We apply a dynamic Slacks-Based Data Envelopment Analysis model to a panel of 1,369 Spanish manufacturing firms progressing through the emergence and consolidation phases of digitalization that have characterized the early decades of the twenty-first century. We examine how efficiency and competitiveness evolve, finding that larger firms and those in more complex technological sectors show more varied behavior but lower inefficiency. The findings offer implications for theory, best practices, and digitalization policies. The robustness of our analysis has been validated by demonstrating substantial differences between the patterns obtained under the standard static and our dynamic evaluation environments.

title: Waveform Design for MIMO Covert Sensing and Communications
authors: Qiao Shi, Meiding Liu, Yi Zhou, Zhengchun Zhou, Pingzhi Fan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: In this paper, we consider a multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) integrated sensing and communications (ISAC) system, aiming at simultaneously communicating with multiple users and sensing targets that serve as adversarial observers, under multiple signal-dependent interference sources. A novel concept of covert sensing, preventing adversarial observers from detecting our sensing action or sensing intentions, is proposed, and a new metric named covert sensing distance (CSD) is established to evaluate the corresponding performance. Specifically, we develop a two-stage scheme. The first stage is to minimize the multi-user interference (MUI) while designing an omnidirectional transmit beampattern by constraining the CSD, to guarantee both reliable communications and covert sensing. Leveraging receiver design flexibility, the second stage formulates a trade-off optimization problem by maximizing the sensing signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR) and imposing a similarity constraint to obtain a directional receive beampattern to improve the sensing performance. To solve the formulated nonconvex problem, we propose an efficient alternating optimization algorithm aided by the gradient-projection framework. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed scheme is validated by simulation results.

title: Diffusion-Based Dynamic Contract for Federated AI Agent Construction in Mobile Metaverses
authors: Jinbo Wen, Jiawen Kang, Yang Zhang, Yue Zhong, Dusit Niyato, Jie Xu, Jianhang Tang, Chau Yuen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Services Computing
abstract: Mobile metaverses are envisioned as a transformative digital ecosystem that delivers immersive, intelligent, and ubiquitous services through mobile devices. Driven by Large Language Models (LLMs) and Vision-Language Models (VLMs), Artificial Intelligence (AI) agents hold the potential to empower the creation, maintenance, and evolution of mobile metaverses, enabling seamless human-machine interaction and dynamic service adaptation. Currently, AI agents are primarily built upon cloud-based LLMs and VLMs. However, several challenges hinder their efficient deployment, including high service latency and a risk of sensitive data leakage during perception and processing. In this paper, we develop an edge-cloud collaboration-based federated AI agent construction framework in mobile metaverses. Specifically, Edge Servers (ESs), as agent infrastructures, first create agent modules in a distributed manner. The cloud server then integrates these modules into AI agents and deploys them at the edge, thereby enabling low-latency AI agent services for users. Considering that ESs may exhibit dynamic levels of willingness to participate in federated AI agent construction, we design a two-period dynamic contract model to continuously incentivize ESs to participate in agent module creation, effectively addressing the dynamic information asymmetry between the cloud server and ESs. Furthermore, we propose an Enhanced Diffusion Model-based Soft Actor-Critic (EDMSAC) algorithm to effectively generate optimal dynamic contracts. In the algorithm, we apply dynamic structured pruning to DM-based actor networks to enhance denoising efficiency and policy learning performance. Simulation results demonstrate that the EDMSAC algorithm outperforms the DMSAC algorithm by up to 23% in optimal dynamic contract generation.

title: A Switching Event-Triggered Communication Method for DC-DC Converters
authors: Hao Li, Zhiwen Huang, Dawei Xiang
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: Stable and effective communication is a fundamental prerequisite for power electronic converters (PECs) to facilitate critical functions such as condition monitoring, fault detection, and power flow management. Existing switching frequency modulation methods employ switching ripples as data carriers. Their demodulation relies on a spectral analysis of the ripple signal, which suffers from limited spectral resolution. This limitation thus constrains the achievable data rate and increases system disturbances. To address this limitation, this paper proposes a novel switching event-triggered communication method that leverages high-frequency (HF) switching oscillations as data carriers. Based on an analysis of the causal relationship between power device switching actions and HF switching oscillations, a HF oscillation current sensor and a signal processing circuit were designed to extract the switching oscillation current and convert it into discrete switching events. Theoretical and experimental investigations demonstrate that the proposed method achieves a demodulation period of just two switching cycles and a switching frequency resolution of 0.2%, while maintaining robust performance under dynamic operating conditions.

title: Shielding Effectiveness of Naval Waveguide-Below-Cutoff Ventilation Arrays: Full-Wave Simulation and Experimental Validation
authors: Che-Min Cheng, Shun-Feng Tsai, Yu-Chuan Hwang
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This study investigates the electromagnetic shielding effectiveness (SE) of ventilation structures based on the waveguide-below-cutoff principle using a combined full-wave numerical and full-scale experimental approach. Although waveguide-below-cutoff ventilation designs are widely adopted for electromagnetic pulse (EMP) protection, existing standards, such as MIL-STD-188-125, prescribe conservative waveguide length guidelines that are often impractical for space- and weight-constrained naval platforms. Full-wave simulations were conducted using the Method of Moments accelerated by the Multilevel Fast Multipole Method (MoM–MLFMM), and broadband experimental measurements were performed in accordance with MIL-STD-188-125. The shielding performance was characterized using transmission coefficient (S21) measurements over a frequency range of 10 kHz–1 GHz using loop, biconical, and log-periodic antennas. The test specimens consisted of full-scale 20 × 30 waveguide-below-cutoff ventilation arrays with 50×50mmsquare apertures and waveguide depths of 140 mm, 175 mm, and 210 mm. The close agreement between the simulations and measurements validates the full-wave modeling framework and enables quantitative evaluation of the shielding performance for electrically large configurations. For all tested cases, the measured SE exceeded 80 dB across the entire frequency band, satisfying the MIL-STD-188-125 requirement. The results further demonstrate that compliant shielding performance can be achieved with waveguide depths that are approximately two to three times the aperture diagonal, with an enhanced attenuation observed at higher frequencies. These findings provide full-scale experimental evidence that the conservative waveguide length guideline in MIL-STD-188-125 can be satisfied with a substantially reduced waveguide depth, thereby establishing experimentally validated design flexibility for compact EMP-compliant naval ventilation structures.

title: Development of a Real-Time Vehicle Silencer Gas Detection and Monitoring System Using IoT and Machine Learning for Environmental Protection
authors: T. Karthika, K.A.Mahesh Kumar, Vishal Geethan S, Prithiv. I, S. Pradeepan
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Automobile emission gases are a common source of air pollution in cities and there is need to have an efficient real-time scalable car emission monitoring solution that helps in environmental protection. This paper develops a hybrid IoT/ML model to identify and characterize harmful gases released by car silencers. The system air quality sensors will be a MQ-series and NDIR sensors installed at the silencer to extract the content of carbon monoxide (CO), nitrogen oxides (NOx), hydrocarbons (HC) and carbon dioxide (CO2). To decrease noise and normalize the signal, preprocessing is conducted through Butterworth low-pass filters and Z-score normalization. An ESP32 microcontroller records and transmits data via MQTT data over Wi-Fi/LoRa to a cloud server. A Random Forest classifier is trained with supervised learning to classify emission level into the Safe, Warning, and Critical zones. Further, a dynamic Emission Severity Score (ESS) is generated on weighted gas concentrations to allow higher interpretability and alerting. Test results on 100 vehicles showed a classification accuracy of 92.3%, and a low transmission latency of data in real-time of less than 250 milliseconds with stable dashboard data display. Flexibility of the model was determined using iterative steps of retraining the model, increasing the F1-score to 90.8%. The analytics dashboard uses a web-based application, which provides real-time heatmaps of the emissions, historical comparisons, regulatory alerts. The proposed system proves to be quite effective in assessing environmental risk, quick decision-making, and scalability to smart cities and regulatory networks. The incorporation of real-time IoT sensing and adaptive machine learning makes it a scalable and sustainable methodology in the modern control of emissions. Future development includes integrating a mobile application and blockchain based data integrity to meet regulatory requirements.

title: Task-Oriented Adaptive Wireless Communication Optimization Based on Reinforcement Learning
authors: Xun Zhang, Hongyu Luo, Jie Tang, Ning Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: An adaptive beamforming optimization strategy is proposed for target users in varying channel environments by combining a pre-trained performance table with reinforcement learning. Four beamforming models are integrated, enabling environment-aware selection of the optimal model and strategy.
