A pre-constructed reward table quantifies model performance under different states, while the Q-learning algorithm updates the selection policy online. This approach leverages individual model strengths and supports real-time adaptation under security constraints. Simulations show that it ensures high signal quality for the intended user, effectively suppresses unintended users’ reception, and significantly reduces computation time, demonstrating strong potential for practical deployment.

title: Design of IGBT Life Prediction Method Based on Particle Filter Algorithm
authors: Yu Zhang, Yang Wen, Tadiwa Elisha Nyamasvisva
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Control and Computing Science (ICICCS)
abstract: This project uses the publicly available IGBT accelerated aging experimental dataset from NASA to predict the health status and remaining life of IGBT based on the particle filter algorithm. The research framework of this project is as follows: First, the change trend of the collector-emitter saturation voltage VCE is selected as the parameter for evaluating the health status of IGBT. Secondly, the NASA data is fitted into a common curve using the curve fitter in MATLAB, and the state equation and observation equation are constructed. Finally, the prediction is made through the particle filter algorithm, and the error accuracy is calculated. The quantitative results show that the prediction error, measured by RMSE, decreases from 7.8 to 1.4 groups as the amount of prior data increases from 150 to 240 groups. The optimal performance is achieved with 200 particles and 240 groups of prior data, beyond which the error increases due to overfitting and the inherent limitations of the particle filter algorithm.

title: Power System State Classification Based on Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks
authors: Xingzhi Liu, Yan Zeng, Wenbo Yao, Juan Tian
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: With the widespread integration of distributed photovoltaics and diversified loads in low-voltage distribution transformer areas, their operational states have become increasingly complex. Traditional methods face challenges in both accuracy and interpretability when identifying typical operational scenarios. To achieve precise perception of the operational state in distribution transformer areas, this paper proposes a hybrid deep learning model that integrates Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Gated Recurrent Units (GRU), and Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks (KAN). This model first utilizes CNN to extract local spatial features from load data, then employs GRU to capture temporal dependencies, and finally introduces a KAN layer to achieve fine-grained mapping and decision-making for complex high-order nonlinear relationships among features. The unique learnable activation function structure of the KAN network enhances the model's fitting capability while potentially offering advantages in interpretability. Experiments based on three months of real active power data from a distribution transformer area show that the proposed model achieves an accuracy of 97% on the test set, significantly outperforming other comparative methods.

title: Big Data, Cloud Computing, and Internet-Enabled Infrastructures for Sustainable Development
authors: Anusha S, J. A. Adlin Layola, P. Ruba Sudha, Sharmila Bhargavi Vijayan, Yuvasri B, M Ezhilvendan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Sustainability has become a major global concern and this necessitates the need to develop novel methods to handle the environmental, social, and economic resources in an effective manner. The combination of Big Data, cloud computing and the infrastructures enabled by the Internet provides the unprecedented opportunities to facilitate the process of sustainable development due to the real time monitoring, data-based decision making, and intelligent resource optimization. Big Data analytics and cloud computing allow the extraction of actionable insights out of very large and heterogeneous datasets that have been gathered through IoT devices and sensors and, at the same time, offer scalable, flexible, and power-efficient platforms to process and store the data. Internet-connected infrastructures such as edge and fog computing support low latency, real time control of systems that are critical to environmental management, smart cities and industrial processes. New technologies like analytics powered by AI, blockchain to manage resources in a transparent way, green cloud computing, and digital twins will also increase the efficiency, robustness, and responsibility of sustainable systems. Nonetheless, bumps on the road, including excessive energy usage, interoperability, data privacy, and adoption limitations in developing nations, still exist, however, research and innovation are ongoing to create intelligent, adaptive, and equitable solutions. This survey provides a broad picture of the principles, usage, upcoming trends, challenges, and future study directions, and states the revolutionary potential of these technologies in realizing the sustainable development objectives.

title: Hybrid CNN-RF Framework for Accurate Lemon Leaf Disease Classification
authors: Khushdeep Kaur, Manani Bhasin, Mansi Pathak, Sakshi Garg, Rushil Garg, Anil Kumar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: The research suggests the use of a deep-learning model for diagnosis besides achieving high ratings for diseases on all categories, accuracy, precision, recall, and F1 scores are kept high for each class: Alternaria leaf spot (97.09), Anthracnose (97.16), Citrus canker (97.26), Citrus leaf spot (97.25), Greasy spot (96.95), Powdery (96.84), and Zinc deficiency (97.25). Every class had a good amount of data in the dataset, where the number of samples ranged from about 1,425 (Powdery) to 1,645 (Citrus canker), with each class having nearly equal representation (about 13-15%). Besides, the classes also ensured a minimum of 99% overall accuracy; thus, as a result, the model is guaranteed to be reliable in the detection of diseases. These outcomes are the main reasons that the suggested CNN-based method is the most accurate one for the identification of citrus leaf diseases. The fascinating are these extremely high-performance metrics, which will make the practical application of this solution in the real world, especially early detection and treatment in agriculture, really easy and far-reaching. This model, with good classification performance and balanced dataset coverage, will allow farmers and agronomists to not only monitor the health of lemon crops but also prevent the loss of the crops indirectly via accurate disease monitoring and timely intervention.

title: Web-based application for 3D printing visualization of mathematical surfaces in education
authors: Pongsakorn Kaewcholkram, Nathaphon Boonnam, Rattanasak Hama
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: We developed this platform by integrating the web graphics technology with WebGL via the Three.js library to understand surfaces in 3 dimension space, which is a significant challenge in 3D analytic geometry. Users can enter surface equations, adjust parameters, rotate, zoom, and interactively explore 3D models in a browser without the need to install additional software. A key feature is the direct export of surface models to the STL format for immediate 3D printing, allowing students to interact with abstract mathematical concepts physically. Performance evaluation demonstrated an average rendering frame rate of 55-60 FPS for standard surfaces, with STL export completed in less than 2 seconds. Classroom trials with 36 Grade 11 students reported high satisfaction (mean score: 4.46/5; 89.20 % positive), highlighting the tool’s ease of use, interactivity, and pedagogical value. The results suggest that the proposed platform offers an accessible, efficient, and cost-effective solution for enhancing conceptual understanding and engagement in mathematics education.

title: Nonlinear Control-Oriented Modelling and Real-Time Simulation of a DAB Resonant Converter for Data Centre Applications
authors: Aphrodis Nduwamungu, Tek Tjing Lie, Nirmal Kumar C. Nair, Ioannis Lestas
publish: 2025 IEEE PES 17th Asia-Pacific Power and Energy Engineering Conference (APPEEC)
abstract: The increasing adoption of DC microgrids (MGs) in data centres demands high-efficiency, reduce electromagnetic interference (EMI), stable power conversion systems, stable operation with wide voltage range and load variation. The Dual Active Bridge (DAB) resonant converter is a promising solution due to its high-power density and bidirectional power flow capability. However, ensuring robust stability and dynamic performance under varying load conditions remains a challenge, especially in the presence of data centres as load. This paper proposes a Super Twisting Sliding Mode Control Observer (STSMO) approach to enhance the regulation performance and robustness of a DAB resonant converter while reducing chattering and voltage regulation. The proposed control strategy is validated through MATLAB/Simulink with a Software-in-the-Loop (SIL) experiments, demonstrating its effectiveness in maintaining stable operation, fast transient response, and improved voltage regulation. The results confirm that the proposed STSMO based DAB resonant converter achieves enhanced stability, even when supplying data centres, making it a viable solution for next-generation data centres and power flow in DC MGs

title: Dynamic Command Structure Adjustment Method Based on Online Simulation and Hierarchical Modeling
authors: Riyong Mao, Yaoqin Zhu, Haonan Ding
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: To address the issues in unmanned swarm operations where static adjustment of command structures struggles to adapt to dynamic battlefields and lacks multi-dimensional integrated analysis, this paper proposes a dynamic command structure adjustment method based on online simulation and hierarchical modeling.First, a macro-micro hierarchical command structure model is constructed. It decouples macro command coordination relationships from micro functional interaction relationships, and clarifies the definitions and correlations of four types of unmanned combat units (including command units and detection units) as well as five types of functional modules (including perception and command-control modules).Second, a closed-loop training framework driven by online simulation is built. Relying on full-process combat simulation to generate training data, a comprehensive reward function integrating command structure effectiveness and operational task performance is designed.Finally, the effectiveness of this method is verified through comparative experiments and ablation experiments, providing effective support for the dynamic optimization of command structures in unmanned swarm operations.

title: Cloud-based XGBoost Framework: Enhancing Scalability and Performance in Machine Learning
authors: R. Aswanandini
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: In this big data world, large amount of information is generated regularly leading to major challenges like security and processing. Because of its unparalleled flexibility and scalability, cloud computing has become a crucial component due to the advancement of technology in recent years. Using machine learning techniques is a potential solution for solving these issues. In the constantly evolving world of cloud computing, protecting data and systems from illegal activity and unauthorized access is necessary. But these developments also bring with them serious security risks. A prominent benchmark in the intrusion detection space is the KDDCUP99 dataset. The goal in using XGBoost on this dataset proved to find patterns that could identify security risks. The utilisation of Amazon cloud capabilities and other cloud resources are used to trigger the model scalability and performance. The complexity of the dataset could be handled well due to this integration, which also XGBoost model a stable environment whereby to train and test. The XGBoost model showed outstanding efficiency and effectiveness when identifying significant security risks. Its incredible 99.17% accuracy rate illustrates its capacity to classify between beneficial and malicious behaviour in cloud environment. The model potential as a dependable tool for intrusion detection in cloud computing systems is highlighted by its high accuracy rate.

title: Plug-And-Play Diffusion Models For Image Compressive Sensing With Data Consistency Projection
authors: Xiaodong Wang, Ping Wang, Zhangyuan Li, Xin Yuan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: We explore the connection between Plug-and-Play (PnP) methods and Denoising Diffusion Implicit Models (DDIM) for solving ill-posed inverse problems, with a focus on single-pixel imaging. We begin by identifying key distinctions between PnP and diffusion models—particularly in their denoising mechanisms and sampling procedures. By decoupling the diffusion process into three interpretable stages: denoising, data consistency enforcement, and sampling, we provide a unified framework that integrates learned priors with physical forward models in a principled manner. Building upon this insight, we propose a hybrid data-consistency module that linearly combines multiple PnP-style fidelity terms. This hybrid correction is applied directly to the denoised estimate, improving measurement consistency without disrupting the diffusion sampling trajectory. Experimental results on single-pixel imaging tasks demonstrate that our method achieves better reconstruction quality.

title: A Software Compensation Scheme for Sampling Clock Mismatch Error in Heterodyne Laser Interferometers
authors: Zhipeng Sheng, Bing Dai
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Measurement Control and Instrumentation (MCAI)
abstract: This paper resolves the challenge of frequency-mismatch-induced drift in heterodyne interferometers through a real-time software compensation technique. Theoretical modeling establishes that independent AOM and sampling clocks generate significant fictitious displacement drift, fundamentally limiting measurement accuracy. Our method leverages the AOM drive signal as a phase reference to directly estimate and suppress drift components. Experimental validation with piezoelectric standards demonstrates near-complete drift elimination and reveals the dominant influence of sampling clock instability. The solution maintains sub-nanometer accuracy under thermal variations, enables substantial yield improvement in semiconductor manufacturing, and dramatically reduces implementation costs compared to hardware-based approaches. This establishes computational compensation as a new paradigm for precision metrology.

title: Weighted Confidence Scoring for Context-Aware Emotion Recognition using Fine-Tuned DeBERTa
authors: Sumitra A. Jakhete, Nilima Kulkarni
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: Human Emotion Recognition in Conversations (ERC) is critical for applications such as empathetic virtual assistants, mental health monitoring, and human-computer interaction. Conventional transformer-based models rely on raw SoftMax confidence scores, which are often miscalibrated, biased toward majority classes, and insensitive to dialogue context. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a finetuned DeBERTa model with a Weighted Confidence Scoring (WCS) framework. The WCS mechanism incorporates classbased weighting and contextual information from preceding dialogue turns to improve both predictive reliability and interpretability. Experiments on benchmark datasets (IEMOCAP, MELD, DailyDialog) show that WCS-DeBERTa consistently outperforms baseline models, achieving higher Macro-F1 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(+3.7 \%)$</tex>, Balanced Accuracy <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(+4.1 \%)$</tex>, and improved calibration (ECE, Brier Score). Minority emotions such as fear and disgust also exhibit significant gains in precision and recall, as validated by per-class metrics and Precision-Recall curves. These results confirm WCS-DeBERTa as a robust framework for reliable and context-aware ERC, with strong applicability in empathetic AI systems.

title: Intelligent Real Time Fault Diagnosis Framework for Cyber Physical Electronic Systems Using Adaptive Learning Techniques
authors: Eswararao Boddepalli, Al-Hussein Maysir Majid, Nurilla Mahamatov, D. Jyothi Preshiya, N.V. Phani Sai Kumar, P. Nagaraj
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: The growing sophistication of cyber-physical electronic systems demands intelligent real-time fault diagnosis with the ability to cope with dynamic settings at low latency and high reliability. Traditional methods like deep learning and symbolic reasoning are limited by lack of interpretability, flexibility, or addressing uncertainty in time-varying signals. To address these issues, this study introduces an adaptive learningbased fault diagnosis architecture named AR-FDNet (Adaptive Reinforcement-Fuzzy Diagnosis Network) that combines deep frequency-domain feature extraction and reinforcement-based classification. The model learns in real-time from changing fault patterns dynamically, supporting correct classification even in noisy and complex operational conditions. Experiments on the Electrical System Fault Diagnosis Dataset verify the efficacy of the framework, with 95% recall, 97% accuracy, F1-score 95% and 96 % precision. The proposed approach brings enhanced generalization and fast responsiveness, which makes it extremely suitable for real-world industrial process control applications, smart grids, electric vehicle applications, and embedded safety-critical systems where continuous monitoring and adaptive diagnosis are critical.

title: Traffic Flow Prediction with Spatio-Temporal Graph Convolutional Networks Based on Edge Computing
authors: Jiaqiang Chen, Zhixin Qi, Zejiao Dong, Hongzhi Wang, Kai Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: Traffic prediction is a critical problem in Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS) and is of great significance to management authorities, road users, and intelligent vehicles. However, most existing approaches rely on centralized computing, which struggles to address the challenges posed by massive traffic data. Edge computing provides a promising solution to this issue. In this paper, we propose a Spatio-Temporal Graph Temporal Convolutional Network for traffic forecasting under the Edge Computing paradigm (STGTCN-EC). To adapt to edge environments, we first partition the large-scale traffic network into multiple subgraphs by jointly considering computational load balance and communication cost. This decomposition transforms the global forecasting problem into distributed tasks executed on edge computing units. Then, the model employs a gated temporal convolutional network (Gated TCN) to capture temporal dependencies and integrates a graph convolutional network (GCN) to extract spatial topological features, enabling accurate traffic flow prediction. Experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate that the proposed model improves both prediction accuracy and training efficiency in traffic forecasting.

title: Advancements and Challenges in 3D Mesh Data Hiding: A Survey of Traditional and ML Techniques
authors: Amit Verma, Bhogeswar Borah
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: The exponential rise of digital devices and widespread internet access has unleashed an unprecedented wave of multimedia content creation and distribution, heightening the critical need for robust digital asset protection. Robust information hiding strategies, such as watermarking and steganography, play a vital role in safeguarding data security and intellectual property in this dynamic landscape. This paper presents a comprehensive review of cutting-edge approaches in 3D multimedia communication, including spatial and transform domain methods, reversible and irreversible schemes, and hybrid security models. By synthesizing current advances, we highlight existing strengths and expose important limitations, such as the challenge of balancing embedding capacity and imperceptibility, the need for resilience against emerging threats like deepfake manipulation, and adaptability to diverse formats and real-time transmission. Our analysis not only clarifies where today's systems excel but also reveals promising directions for future research using machine learning techniques that encourage innovation in secure, reliable, and scalable 3D media communication to meet the demands of modern digital environments.

title: A Parallel Dual Straight-Tube VTD with DSP-Based Digital Driving System: Design for Online Cement Slurry Density Measurement
authors: Junzheng Tian, Lin Hou, Chao Wang, Ping Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Measurement Control and Instrumentation (MCAI)
abstract: To meet the requirements of density monitoring under harsh cementing operation conditions, a parallel dual straight-tube Vibrating Tube Densimeter (VTD) with a matched DSP-based digital driving system is proposed. The parallel dual straight-tube adopts a "splitter-parallel-combiner" flow channel design, which minimizes flow resistance to avoid solid deposition and bubble stagnation, while suppressing environmental common-mode interference through symmetric anti-phase vibration. The DSP-based digital driving system integrates three key signal processing algorithms: adaptive lattice notch filter for fundamental frequency extraction, zero-crossing detection combined with autocorrelation analysis for amplitude calculation, and Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) for drive-sensor phase difference estimation. A dual closed-loop control strategy, consisting of adaptive PI amplitude control with parameter switching and phase difference compensation control, is implemented to ensure stable resonance. Experimental verification under ambient temperature and pressure using six media shows that the system achieves rapid resonant frequency locking, stable phase difference control, and precise amplitude regulation. The calibrated quadratic density-frequency model realizes high-precision density inversion with an absolute error ≤±0.002 g/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>. This design effectively meets the requirements of online cement slurry density monitoring in well cementing operations, providing a reliable technical solution for complex engineering scenarios.

title: DeepLSTMDefense: A Recurrent Learning Framework for DDoS Detection using Network Traffic Sequences
authors: Sandeep Kumar, Anand Kumar, C.Kamatchi, Rajalakshmi G, C.Jayabalan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks are still making networks less available, so detection needs to be able to tell the difference between real flash-crowds and fake ones with very precise timing. This paper introduces DeepLSTMDefense, a recurrent sequence-classification pipeline. Network flows are grouped into time-ordered sequences, normalized, and windowed to keep temporal dependencies. Then, stacked Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) layers are used to model traffic dynamics more accurately than static feature learners. We trained and tested the system using CICDDoS2019 and custom Portmap traces. Compared to classical baselines (Naïve Bayes, Support Vector Machine, Random Forest), consistent gains were made: on CICDDoS2019, the accuracy was 97.9%, the precision was 98.1%, the recall was 97.8%, and the false-alarm rate was 4.3%. This cut the overall error rate from 7.517% to 2.103% (≈72.0% relative reduction). When there was only a small amount of Portmap traffic, the error rate dropped by 39.69%, showing that it works with more than one dataset. These findings were validated by an AUC exceeding 0.98 and by confusion matrices demonstrating elevated sensitivity and specificity across various attack vectors. By framing DDoS detection as sequence classification, it became possible to establish earlier and more dependable trigger points for mitigation without compromising generalization. The stacked-LSTM design was put to use for practical, almost real-time defense.

title: Closing the Modality Gap: Integrating LLMs With Lidar For 3D Object Detection and Object-Level Understanding
authors: Youngchae Chee, Taeheon Kim, Youngjoon Yu, Hyun Wook Park, Yong Man Ro
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs), which integrate multiple modalities such as vision and language by leveraging Large Language Models (LLMs), have demonstrated remarkable progress in multimodal understanding. However, the incorporation of LiDAR—a key modality for spatial and geometric comprehension—into multimodal LLMs (MLLMs) remains underdeveloped. In this work, we devise a novel framework that enhances MLLMs with object-level LiDAR comprehension by jointly aligning both scene-level and region-of-interest (ROI) LiDAR features with natural language. Our method includes three components: scene-level LiDAR compression, ROI-based extraction of object-level features, and multimodal alignment with language. To support accurate object-level understanding, we propose two complementary tasks: LiDAR-to-Class (predicting object classes from LiDAR features) and Class-to-LiDAR (identifying LiDAR objects from natural language descriptions). Leveraging the large-scale NuScenes dataset with over one million annotated objects, our model achieves strong performance, including 95% accuracy on the Class-to-LiDAR task. Leveraging LiDAR data, this work advances precise object-level semantic understanding in 3D environments and underscores the potential of MLLMs in safety-critical and interactive scenarios such as autonomous driving and robotics.

title: Transient Frequency Stabilizing Mechanism of Renewable-dominated Power System and its Application in Droop Control
authors: Mengjun Wang, Xiao Wang, Tiezhu Wang, Shicong Ma, Yuefeng Wang, Shiyi Ma, Yiguo Zhang, Jianbo Guo
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Power System and Energy Internet (PoSEI)
abstract: The transient stability of renewable-dominated power systems, containing a high proportion of power electronic interfaced generation (PEIG) units, is known to be threatened during large disturbances. In this study, we analyze the transient frequency stabilizing mechanism of such power systems and propose an improved frequency regulation method based on this analysis. Firstly, the stabilizing conditions are proposed, which consist of two parts: one is the PEIG frequency regulation power capability condition (FRPCC), and the other is the PEIG control method condition (CMC). It addresses the identification problem of PEIG reserve capacity and control method boundary, ensuring system transient frequency stability. The stabilizing conditions of the unconstrained PEIG droop control are studied, and an improvement based on a saturation link is proposed accordingly. Finally, we verify the theoretical results of this study through simulations.

title: Design and Implementation of a LightGBM-based Poaching Hotspot Prediction Framework for Optimized Ranger Patrol Scheduling
authors: K. Karthick, S. Selvin Rajesh Kumar, J. Relin Francis Raj, M. Prem Nazeer, N. Kalpana, X. Arogya Presskila
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Illegal poaching continues to threaten global biodiversity conservation and disrupt ecological balance in forest ecosystems. Conventional monitoring methods are often limited by lack of automation, slow response, and inadequate coverage of remote areas. This research presents an engineering-based predictive framework that applies advanced machine learning and spatial analytics to strengthen environmental protection strategies. By combining artificial intelligence with geospatial data, the framework aims to improve decision making for forest authorities through accurate identification of potential risk zones and efficient deployment of patrol resources. The proposed approach demonstrates how technological innovation can transform traditional conservation practices into intelligent surveillance systems capable of addressing complex environmental challenges. From an engineering perspective, the integration of predictive modeling, data processing, and optimization principles represents a significant advancement in sustainable forest management. The system supports proactive interventions that align with broader goals of climate action by enhancing adaptability to environmental risks and promoting resilience in forest ecosystems. This work highlights the growing role of data-driven engineering solutions in addressing conservation and security challenges. It establishes a pathway for applying emerging technologies to strengthen ecological governance, ensuring that forest resources and wildlife are managed sustainably and protected against illegal exploitation.

title: Context-Aware Ensemble for Stock Market Prediction using Sentiment and Volatility Signals
authors: Nitu Saha, Amit Majumder
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: It is a widely acknowledged fact that stock markets are a significant source of volatility and unpredictability, driven by a combination of financial data and public sentiment influenced by global affairs. Conventional forecasting models often struggle to find a line between short-term market momentum and long-term fundamental trends. This research introduces a context-aware stacking ensemble that addresses this challenge by assigning specialized deep learning models for each task: a stacked LSTM with an Attention Layer for short-term prediction and a streamlined unidirectional GRU for long-term trend analysis. The framework is strengthened by a diverse feature set including price history, volatility metrics (VIX, HV), technical indicators (RSI, MACD), and FinBERT-derived sentiment analysis from global news derived from The New York Times News Headlines. A meta-learner then intelligently weighs the predictions of these models against real-time market volatility to produce a unified, highly accurate forecast. On the S&P 500 dataset, the ensemble sets a new benchmark with an $R^{2}$ of 0.9875 and an RMSE of 0.00478, which, upon inverse-scaling, turns out to be ${\$}$66.11 USD. These results confirm that after models are specialized for different temporal dynamics and guided by a context aware meta-learner, it becomes a highly effective strategy for robust stock market prediction.

title: Emulating Pain Perception Using a Cation Migration-Induced Threshold Switching Ag/TaOx/Pt Memristor
authors: Aryan S Nair, Srikant Kumar Mohanty
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Our work demonstrates an artificial nociceptor made from a two terminal Ag/TaOx/Pt memristive device, fab-ricated to emulate the phenomena of biological pain perception. Our device functions based on volatile threshold switching mechanism, which is caused by field driven migration and dissolution of Ag cations within a sub-stoichiometric TaOx matrix. This threshold switching allows for the successful hardware emulation of some key nociceptive functions: a stimulus incited threshold response, temporal relaxation till a resting state, and sensiti-zation phenomena (hyperalgesia and allodynia). Our fabricated device exhibits exceptional performance characteristics, including compact structure, stable endurance, and high energy efficiency, helped by low operating voltages and leakage currents in the range of picoamperes. The flexible relaxation dynamics and stable switching behavior show its potential as a key inclusion in advanced neuromorphic tactile sensing systems, intelligent robotic e-skin, and modern prosthetics with sensory feedback.

title: Architecting an AI System for Automated, Human-Like Lead Engagement on WhatsApp
authors: Ajinkya Bhujbal, Nilesh Joshi, Manisha Bharti
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: This paper introduces an AI-Powered Lead Management System designed to automate real estate lead engagement on WhatsApp. The system combines a real-time CRM dashboard with a human-like conversational agent. Using a hybrid Python and AutoHotkey architecture, it automates the pipeline from lead detection to personalized follow-up. A key innovation is its stealthy operation and ability to mimic a specific agent's communication style using local AI and templates, ensuring rapid, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$24 / 7$</tex> responses to boost conversion rates without needing special API access.

title: Design of Error-Tolerant VLSI Adders and Multipliers for High-Performance Approximate Computing
authors: Srihari Velpuri, Eswararao Boddepalli, Shamim Ahmad Khan, Shukur Ramadan Hama Sharif, Mallula Praveen Kumar, S. Gayathri
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Modern digital computing systems depend upon high-performance and low-energy arithmetic units. This work presents the ETAM Framework, a new model of parameterized approximate adders and multipliers with built-in error-compensation circuits in an attempt to guarantee constrained accuracy. This is geared towards reducing area, delay and power consumed and the high degree of computational accuracy. The framework makes segmented carry adders, truncated partial array multipliers and are optimized to be carried out in digital CMOS VLSI. In the cases of adders and multipliers, where the values of MRE are 0.14 and 0.58 respectively, the experimental results are that the proposed compensated units have MAE of 1.1 and 7.5. At the application level Image processing, digital signal processing and machine learning Image processing Digital signal processing and machine learning Application-level analyses reveal that performance is not significantly degraded. The paper verifies that the ETAM Framework offers a systematic and efficient approach to high-speed energy efficient as well as error-tolerant arithmetic operations in VLSI systems to guarantee predictable and dependable computation.

title: Advanced Neuro-Fuzzy Decision-Making for Gold Price Prediction Using Sentiment Cues
authors: Malathi J, Paulraj Jayasimman I
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: The gold price prediction model is a crucial role of financial asset to the price is highly sensitive approach to geopolitical events, economic indicators and investor sentiment. The traditional model forecasting approach captures the non -linearity and uncertainty associated with sentiment cues driven data. We present model approach to the novel framework that integrates data from the sentiment analysis with an Advanced Neural Fuzzy Inference System (ANFIS) for accuracy gold price prediction model. Financial news and social media posts are processed to extract sentiment scores and using combined with historical gold price prediction data model. The ANFIS model and neuro fuzzy decision-making model leverages the learning approach of neural networks and the reasonable power of fuzzy logic model to handle imprecision and uncertainty in to the input space. The experimental results demonstrates that the proposed system approach the higher predictive data accuracy compared to the machine learning models and conventional statistical. The result highlights finding the potential of the prediction model of sentiment-aware neuro- fuzzy systems in financial forecasting model approach, valuable insights offering for policymakers, traders and investors.

title: Impact of Lesion Masking on Skin Cancer Detection Using Deep Learning: A Comparative Study of CNN, Xception, and EfficientNetB0
authors: Saloni Shahane, Daksh Agarwal, Archit Gupta, Yashwant Ingle, Parikshit Mahalle
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Skin cancer, particularly malignant melanoma, is rising globally. Despite advances in imaging, dermatoscopic diagnosis remains challenging because many lesions appear visually similar and background details can introduce additional noise and confusion. This study looked at whether using lesion masks to isolate the area of the lesion could improve classification by deep learning. We tested three models: a custom CNN, Xception, and EfficientNetB0 on the HAM10000 dataset, which has <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{1 0, 0 1 5}$</tex> dermatoscopic images from ISIC 2018. We compared the masked and unmasked versions of each image. EfficientNetB0 showed the best improvement, with accuracy rising from 68.43 percent to 78.02 percent and macro-F1 increasing from 0.48 to 0.73. In contrast, the custom CNN and Xception, which already had high accuracy (98.58 percent and 97.61 percent), saw small drops in performance after applying masks. Their macro-F1 scores remained nearly unchanged (custom CNN: 0.98 to 0.98; Xception: 0.98 to 0.97). This effect is likely due to the removal of background information that would have otherwise been useful. Statistical analysis showed no significant difference between automated masks and manually refined ones. Overall, automated lesion masking can enhance diagnostic performance in mid-range deep learning models and may support computer-aided skin cancer detection, particularly for clinicians with less experience.

title: Enhancing Handwritten Answer Sheet Evaluation Through Large Language Models and Multi-Agent Reasoning
authors: Sujit Sarkar, R Jayadevan, Neha Sharma, Mrityunjoy Pandey
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Accurate and timely evaluation of handwritten exam answer sheets remains a major challenge in educational institutions, especially for large-scale assessments. Manual grading is time-consuming, prone to inconsistencies, and often leads to delayed feedback for students. Although OCR-based grading systems exist, their accuracy is often insufficient for realworld deployment due to handwritten script variability. Recent advances in artificial intelligence, particularly large language models (LLMs), offer promising solutions to this problem. This paper presents an automated grading system that combines image preprocessing, advanced OCR, and LLM-based evaluation. Gemini Flash Thinking is employed for OCR, achieving up to 98% character-level accuracy on a benchmark of 100 answer scripts. Each extracted answer block is mapped to its respective question using a likelihood-based merge sort prompt augmented with semantic entailment scoring. This ensures contextual accuracy in matching even for incomplete or misaligned responses. Following mapping, a multi-agentic evaluation strategy is introduced using simulated professor agents for collaborative grading. These agents assess content relevance, coverage, and structure, while providing constructive feedback and rubricbased scoring. The proposed pipeline significantly reduces human intervention while maintaining grading consistency and fairness. It offers a scalable, explainable, and institution-ready solution for automated subjective answer evaluation.

title: Hybrid CNN-LSTM Architecture for Early Detection of Ransomware Attacks in Enterprise Network
authors: V. Mahilnan, K Surya, S Thamaraiselvan, S Vasanth Raj, R Vicknesh
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: Enterprises face an existential threat from ransomware that encrypts important data with no warning; therefore, early and automated detection tools are required. Zero-day versions have a high possibility of success compared to conventional signaturebased and computational approaches, which generate many false negatives. Although these methods use deep learning techniques to achieve good detection results, the existing algorithms are not trained to handle ransomware, which leads to more false positives because of enterprise and sporadic contexts. The proposed system provides a hybrid supervised machine learning architecture that combines incremental updates, Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks with attention for temporal behavior modeling, and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) for spatial feature extraction to close these inefficiencies. With an accuracy of 99.75%, an F1 score of 99.51%, an F2 score of 99.61%, an FPR of 0.17%, and a mean time to detect (MTTD) of 4.8 seconds, the results show significant improvements and provide a strong early-warning framework for businesses’ security operations.

title: TinyML based monitoring and diagnosis system to enable the European battery digital passport
authors: Emanuele Ogliari, Marco Mussetta, Marco Carratù, Vincenzo Paciello, Antonio Pietrosanto, Emilio Pafumi, Luigi Ferrigno, Filippo Milano
publish: 2025 IEEE PES 17th Asia-Pacific Power and Energy Engineering Conference (APPEEC)
abstract: The European Union mandates comprehensive battery digital passports for EV and industrial batteries above 2 kWh capacity starting February 2027. This paper presents a TinyML-based monitoring system that enables real-time battery parameters estimation to support digital passport requirements using voltage (V), current (I), and temperature (T) measurements. Two neural network architectures were evaluated: an Artificial Neural Network (ANN) with 6.5K parameters and a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) with 24.5K parameters. Both models were quantized to 8-bit precision and deployed on an STM32F413ZHT6 microcontroller with ESP32-WROOM-32E for cloud connectivity. Experimental validation was performed using a case study of State of Charge estimation for a 20 Ah Lithium Iron Phosphate battery. The ANN model achieved superior performance with a Mean Absolute Error below 5.3% and a Root Mean Square Error below 6.7%, while consuming only 6.36 kB of flash memory and 0.35 kB of scratch memory. The quantized models showed minimal accuracy degradation compared to full-precision versions. The proposed system provides a cost-effective solution for continuous battery monitoring, supporting regulatory compliance while enabling predictive diagnostics and enhanced safety management throughout the battery lifecycle.

title: Design of a Multi-Degree-of-Freedom Assembly Robot in a Strong Magnetic Environment
authors: Wenyuan Cun, Honghai Qiao, Yangling Xu, Xufan Jiang, Jianfeng Yao, Zhuang Fu
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotic Systems and Applications (ICRSA)
abstract: This paper proposes a multi-degree-of-freedom assembly robot that can adapt to strong magnetic environments. It is mainly composed of a position adjustment module, a posture adjustment module, and an end feed module. Through demand analysis, structural design, and material selection, the design of a multi-degree-of-freedom assembly robot in a strong magnetic environment is completed. The multi-degree-of-freedom assembly robot has strong magnetic compatibility, workspace compatibility, and good positioning accuracy. The feasibility and reliability of the device are verified through calibration and repeatability experiments.

title: Design and Implementation of a Three-Dimensional Precision Motion Stage Control System Based on Qt Framework
authors: Liangcheng Tao, Rongguo Fu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Control and Computing Science (ICICCS)
abstract: To meet the requirements for precision and convenience in Gaussian film scanning within coating machines, this paper aims to design and implement a three-dimensional precision motion stage control system based on the QT framework and C++ language, with preconfigured scanning protocols. The main content includes the design of the overall system architecture, implementation of the core motion control module, data acquisition functionality, and the development of a user-friendly human-machine interface. During the software development process, methods such as Qt signal-slot mechanisms, multi-threaded communication, and object-oriented design were employed. Through a series of tests and practical applications, the system has been proven to achieve the expected design objectives in terms of positioning accuracy, stability, and usability.

title: Automated Urine Color Analysis using MTCNN for Rapid and Non-Invasive UTI Detection
authors: G. M. Sathyaseelan, Vineetha Varghese, Raja Mohamed N, N. Kavith, D. Vikram, S. P. Santhoshkumar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: One of the most common diseases, urinary tract infections (UTIs) are typically detected by laboratory urine analysis. This work introduces an automated UTI detection system that uses Multi-Task Cascaded Convolutional Neural Networks (MTCNN) for analyzing the urine color images provided by the users. The severity of the infection is classified into three categories, namely, normal, mild and severe according to color intensity and visual characteristics. Preprocessing methods including color correction and histogram normalization were employed to ensure that the data are normalized. The MTCNN framework is able to extract texture, hue and spatial features efficiently with the help of its multi-stage cascaded design and outperforms traditional color-threshold and rule-based classification methods in accuracy and stability. Experimental results show that MTCNN can learn the correlation between urine color characteristics and the level of infection well. The proposed approach provides a fast, cheap and non-invasive diagnostic solution for remote monitoring of patients and mobile health applications. Future work has the purpose of improving clinical reliability by combining multimodal parameters such as odor, pH, and chemical indicators in order to advance intelligent and accessible healthcare diagnostics through deep learning-based color images analysis.

title: GAN-based Framework for Robust Network Intrusion Detection
authors: S Rajeshwaran, R Manoj, S Poovarasan, K RamSidharth, Laxmi Raja
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: As the number of internet-enabled tools grows exponentially, contemporary networks are experiencing more advanced cyber threats, such as unauthorized access, data breaches, and the so-called zero-day attacks. The problem with the traditional Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) and its use of signature-based or conventional machine learning methods is that they tend to miss unknown or rare intrusions because of the imbalanced datasets and because the network traffic is dynamic. A new IDS architecture based on Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) and the ability to detect it, has been suggested in this research. GAN model produces realistically synthesized intrusion traffic which complements the existing datasets and solves the problem of class imbalance. The discriminator, which is trained together with the generator is an efficient anomaly-detecting model since it is trained to be aware of the underlying distributions of typical network behavior and to identify malicious activity. Experimental analyses on popular benchmark datasets, such as NSL-KDD and CICIDS2017, show that the proposed GAN-based IDS shows a markedly better level of detection accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score than the traditional models. The findings are that the system is especially efficient in recognizing unprecedented attacks and resisting against changing network environments. This study presents the opportunity of adversarial learning as a data augmentation approach as well as a solid machine to detect anomalies, which opens the door to smarter, adaptive, and resilient IDS solutions. The given approach is useful in the practical application of network administrators and cybersecurity specialists trying to enhance the security against the new threats in the modern network settings.

title: Analyzing Factors Influencing Students’ Intention to Use AI Chatbots for Learning: The Role of Task-Technology Fit and Perceived Usefulness
authors: Edward Gabriel Nathanael, Shalomita Sharon Prasetyo, Adele B L Mailangkay
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Technological Solutions (ICAITech)
abstract: This research assesses aspects that determine students’ aim to apply AI chatbots in higher learning, by focusing on task-technology fit and perceived usefulness within Technology Acceptance Model. Along with the integration of AI into digital learning transformation, knowing aspects that its application critically affects the enhancement of learning experiences. By using quantitative approach, with a survey of 209 higher education students in Indonesia that experienced in using AI chatbots, this research evaluates five main variables: technology characteristics, task-technology fit, perceived usefulness, expectation confirmation, and intention to use. SEM (Structured Equation Modeling) analysis shows that technology characteristics significantly influence task-technology fit, followed by positive impact over perceived usefulness as well as intention to use. Expectation confirmation also boosts perceived usefulness, meanwhile perceived usefulness along with task-technology fit directly strengthen students’ intention to use. Unexpectedly, task-technology fit appears as strongest predictor of intention to use, indicating the importance of aligning between chatbot capabilities with academic tasks. This finding suggests that educators and developers must prioritize in optimizing AI chatbots functional alignment with learning environment, also ensuring that educative values are implemented to encourage adoption. This study gives practical insight for higher education institutions who want to integrate AI chatbots effectively in learning environment

title: Optimal Design of Rural Off-Grid Power Systems in Japan with Green hydrogen Production and Sales
authors: Takuto Ohsawa
publish: 2025 IEEE PES 17th Asia-Pacific Power and Energy Engineering Conference (APPEEC)
abstract: This paper proposes an optimal design method for a 100% renewables-based off-grid power system in rural Japan that considers the production and external sale of green hydrogen. While prior work has largely treated hydrogen as seasonal storage, the economics of selling surplus hydrogen under realistic logistics constraints remain underexplored. We develop a mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) model that co-optimizes the capacities of photovoltaic panels, wind turbines, batteries, and hydrogen equipment (electrolyzer, fuel cell, and storage tank). A key contribution is the inclusion of periodic sales constraints to represent vehicle-based transport of hydrogen. A case study of a rural town in Hokkaido, Japan, shows that allowing green hydrogen sales substantially reduces the levelized cost of energy (LCOE) relative to self-consumption-only designs. Sensitivity analyses indicate that viability is maintained even at low selling prices; notably, selling surplus hydrogen at a zero price remains beneficial because it reduces the required storage capacity. Moreover, cost-saving effects persist with infrequent sales (e.g., once every 2 weeks). These findings offer practical guidance for policymakers and communities seeking to improve the economics of energy-independent, carbon-neutral off-grid systems.

title: Cardiovascular Abnormalities Prediction using CNN and EfficientNetB3 model
authors: Shokhista Mamajonova, Ozodbek Eshqobilov, Zamira Atamur Atova, Niginabonu Khajiqurbonova, Mukhlisa Mustafayeva, B.Venkataramanaiah
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: In recent days cardiovascular diseases are more dangerous and to be monitored early for human’s health monitoring. Cardiovascular Diseases (CVD) causes many million deaths throughout the world. An Irregular pattern variation in ECG signals, like too quickly or too slowly, is known as arrhythmia. The main aim of historical research in ECG classification is identifying arrhythmia. Electrocardiogram (ECG) gives information about heart activity of the person. ECG signal has P,Q,R,S,T,U sample points that shows heart activity of the person. Machine learning and deep learning algorithms recently used for various medical health disorders prediction. This research proposes a model that predicts heart diseases using machine learning and deep learning. Impulsive cardiac Death (ISD) is known as unexpected cardiovascular disease-related deaths with dates and times which are not predicted early.The proposed research uses efficient Net-B3 and Convolutional neural network(CNN) for prediction of Cardiovascular disease prediction.This research compares CNN and EfficientNet-B3 model to predict heart diseases and EfficientNet-B3 model produces highest accuracy 95% when compared to basic CNN.

title: Object Detection for Total Station using Deep Learning
authors: Iman Morsi, Ahmed El-Meligy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Telecommunications and Artificial Intelligence (IC-FTAI)
abstract: Artificial intelligence is reshaping a wide range of industries, and geodetic instrumentation is no exception. While Deep Learning (DL) has become the gold standard in image-based photogrammetry, enhancing automation and analysis of more complex visual data, its full potential remains under de-velopment in surveying applications. This study focuses on ob-ject detection for Image Assisted Total Stations (IATS), first re-viewing classical detection and measurement techniques and their limitations. It then discusses the implementation of deep learning with an IATS to overcome these drawbacks. In the study presented, a dataset of 390 images of circular retroreflective prisms was collected from multiple sources, including a smartphone camera attached to a total station's eyepiece. The YOLOv8n (You Only Look Once version 8 nano) model was trained on the dataset. The overall precision is 0.995, the recall is 1.0, and the F1-score is 0.995. This experiment was a success-ful demonstration of how image-based object detection using a total station can be employed to automatically identify surveying targets such as circular prisms, bridging the gap between optical instrumentation and modern computer vision techniques.

title: Hybrid AI-Driven Predictive Analytics Framework for Real-Time Patient Monitoring and Adaptive Early Warning Systems in Smart Hospitals
authors: Arivukarasi M
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Modern healthcare has been completely transformed by the quick development of artificial intelligence (AI) and the Internet of Medical Things (IoMT), which have made it possible for automated, intelligent, and continuous patient monitoring. This study suggests a Hybrid AI-Driven Predictive Analytics Framework that combines deep learning and machine learning models for adaptive early warning system (EWS) production and real-time patient monitoring in smart hospitals. IoMT-enabled wearables and bedside sensors are used to gather multimodal physiological data, including blood pressure, temperature, oxygen saturation, heart rate, and ECG signals. The hybrid AI approach uses Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks for temporal sequence prediction and machine learning methods for trend-based anomaly detection to find early indicators of patient decline. Reducing false alarms and increasing diagnostic accuracy, an adaptive alert mechanism constantly modifies threshold values according to clinical risk categories and patient-specific health profiles. Computational efficiency is increased through cloud-edge integration, which guarantees scalability and low-latency analytics across hospital networks. According to experimental data, the framework outperforms conventional EWS techniques in terms of accuracy, precision, and sensitivity. By improving clinical decision-making, speeding up reaction times, and fortifying the digital infrastructure of smart hospitals, this research helps create proactive, intelligent, and patient centred healthcare systems.

title: AI-based Adaptive Overcurrent Protection for Load-side Relays in Offshore DC Microgrids
authors: Avy Sheina, Ramon Zamora, Amanullah Maung Than Oo, Kosala Gunawardane
publish: 2025 IEEE PES 17th Asia-Pacific Power and Energy Engineering Conference (APPEEC)
abstract: The integration of renewable energy sources (RES) such as solar, wind, wave, and tidal power through microgrids is gaining interest globally, particularly for offshore applications. In these circumstances, DC microgrids are preferred over AC counterparts due to their suitability for islanded operation and their ability to simplify the integration of RES and energy storage systems (ESS). DC systems also mitigate common AC challenges such as frequency deviations, harmonic distortion, and voltage imbalance. Despite these advantages, DC microgrids face significant protection challenges, primarily due to the absence of natural zero-crossing, rapid fault current rise, and limited availability of standardized DC protection devices and schemes. To address the need for more responsive protection mechanisms that can accommodate varying RES, ESS, and load conditions, this paper proposes an adaptive overcurrent protection approach based on artificial intelligence (AI). The adaptive scheme employs an Adaptive Neuro-Fuzzy Inference System (ANFIS), trained on data from diverse operating scenarios including normal loading, fault events, and renewable intermittency. The model enables real-time adjustment of relay settings on the load side, ensuring accurate fault detection and improving system reliability. A DC microgrid protection model is developed in MATLAB/Simulink, in which current measurements obtained under different operating conditions are used for training and validation. The ANFIS-based method achieved 99.41% prediction accuracy over 1.35 million samples, and the Opal-RT real-time simulation confirmed its effectiveness with circuit breaker tripping times of 130 milliseconds for overcurrent faults and 20 milliseconds for short-circuit faults.

title: DeepSeaEdge: Federated Intelligence and Edge Learning for Autonomous Underwater IoT Systems
authors: M. Aarthi Elaveini, Kanishk Balaji. K. S, Nakshathra. G. A, Harshavardhan. S, Sai Jayanth. M, Sabareesh. S
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Underwater Internet of Things (UIoT) is now able to provide intelligent ocean monitoring, surveillance and find resources, but the challenge of communication latency, energy limitation and data heterogeneity still pose significant challenges. The current paper describes DeepSeaEdge, a federated intelligence/ edge learning platform that can support autonomous underwater IoT networks. DeepSeaEdge refers to the distributed learning of edge nodes that allow jointly updating models, and central data aggregation is not necessary, which contributes to privacy and efficiency. The design once again makes use of the adaptive acoustic-optical hybrid communication to best utilize connectivity as well as energy expenditure in dynamic underwater environments. Experimental assessments show that DeepSeaEdge can be used as a promising architecture in the next generation of autonomous underwater intelligence as it can improve inference accuracy, reduce latency, and have power efficiency in comparison to traditional centralized learning models.

title: Multidimensional Indicators Construction and Optimization for Solar-Driven Polygeneration Systems
authors: Yanbo Wang, Shanmei Dong, Lei Pan, Nianci Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE PES 17th Asia-Pacific Power and Energy Engineering Conference (APPEEC)
abstract: This paper establishes a comprehensive evaluation index system for solar-driven combined cooling, heating, and power (CCHP) systems from three dimensions: energy efficiency, economy, and system scale. Multi-objective optimization studies are conducted for two typical coupling configurations: series and parallel. A thermodynamic system model is developed, and the Manta Ray Foraging Optimization (MRFO) algorithm is employed to perform a multi-objective collaborative optimization of four distinct coupling schemes. The results show that the series scheme 1, in which the heating and cooling systems sequentially utilize the condensation waste heat of the power generation system, outperforms the other schemes in terms of comprehensive solar energy utilization, initial investment cost, and payback period, demonstrating effective energy cascade utilization. This work provides a theoretical basis and a practical reference for the optimal selection and multi-objective optimization design of coupling schemes in solar CCHP systems.

title: The Application of Artificial Intelligence Technology in Early Childhood Numeracy: Systematic Literature Review
authors: Vena Yuliana, Rita Mariyana, Nur Faizah Romadona, Mubiar Agustin
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: Numeracy Artificial Intelligence (AI) offers personalized, adaptive, and interactive approaches to early childhood numeracy learning. Numeracy which encompasses understanding numbers, patterns, shapes, and problem-solving skills represents a critical aspect of children’s cognitive development. This study systematically reviews the application of AI in numeracy learning through 10 relevant articles published between 2020 and 2025. The findings reveal that AI implemented through mobile applications, educational robots, and gamification effectively enhances children’s interest, comprehension, and engagement, while also supporting early detection of learning difficulties and the development of computational thinking. These results underscore the potential of AI in fostering early numeracy and advancing the stages of mathematics learning for young children.

title: An Ensemble Machine Learning Framework for Intelligent Farm Input Optimization using Multi-Source Agricultural Data
authors: Nallagondla Jyothi, S. Jamalaiah
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: This work describes an ensemble machine learning framework aimed at optimizing farm inputs such as irrigation water, fertilizer, and pesticides, by integrating diverse agricultural data sources. The framework synthesizes soil, weather, crops, and satellite index data within a decision support system that learns spatial and temporal patterns that impact crop yield and resource use. Multiple base learners (Random Forest, Gradient Boosted Trees, and LSTM-based temporal predictors) are integrated into a stacked meta-learner for improved robustness, generalization, and interpretability. Experimentation with multi-regional open-source datasets shows that the proposed ensemble model offers significant improvement against other single model baselines. The system achieved a prediction accuracy of 94.6%, an RMSE of 0.32, and a MAPE of 4.7% for water and fertilizer recommendations, advancing by 12% over the closest competitor model. The SHAP-based Explainable AI module provides decision logic clarification by tracing important agronomic factors including soil nitrogen and variability in rainfall impacts. Findings confirm that the ensemble model provides a software-based precision agriculture and farm resource management decision support system that is efficient, sustainable and readily scaled.

title: Optimization-Driven IC Architectures for Beamforming Efficiency in Massive MIMO Systems
authors: Jiachen Xi
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Next-gen wireless networks depend on massive MIMO systems, which are highly spectral efficient and have high capacity, but efficient beamforming is a difficult problem due to IC-level trade-offs between performance, power and scalability. This paper suggests an optimization-based approach to IC-based hybrid beamforming in massive MIMO systems, including a low-power hardware model and an intelligent control algorithm to optimize the beamforming weights in an adaptive way. To achieve high performance beam steering with setting limits of quantization and phase resolution we employ Improved Particle Swarm Optimization (IPSO) algorithm. The IPSO algorithm search dynamically within the solution space of optimal combinations of analog and digital beamforming weights to reduce beamforming error subject to IC-level constraints like phase-shifter granularity and discrete multi-level digital processing. The recommended structure will include a hybrid beamforming engine, which has quantized, phase control, reconfigurability baseband processing modules, and a lightweight optimization controller embedded in the digital signal path. The proposed work suggests a novel architecture and algorithmic co-design strategy of future wireless systems to enable the support of realistic and opportune beamforming within dense and dynamic communication scenarios.

title: A Novel Wireless Covert Pulse Waveform Signal by Using Artificial Noise
authors: Ming Shen, Xun Zhang, Yongqiang Wan, Jie Tang, Ning Wang, Yao Ge
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: This paper proposes a new anti-detection sorting method based on artificial noise for wireless covert pulse waveform signal transmission. Before transmitting the signal, by making full use of the directional characteristics of the channel, the artificial noise designed by the directional characteristics of the channel is cleverly superimposed on the wireless covert pulse waveform to be transmitting, and the superimposed artificial noise does not have any perturbation to the wireless covert pulse waveform transmitted by the own party to achieve the concealment of the wireless covert pulse waveform. Finally, by controlling the power ration of the artificial noise and the wireless covert pulse waveform signal of the own party, the detection probability of the wireless covert pulse waveform signal by the third party receiver can be effectively reduced; by designing and optimising the parameters of the time-domain artificial noise and the random overlap of the wireless covert pulse waveform signal, the reconnaissance receiver can be perturbed to form the correct pulse descriptor word PDW, so as to achieve the effect of interfering with radar binning at the lowest cost-effectiveness ratio. Experimental results show that the proposed technique can effectively improve the anti-detection and anti-sorting capabilities of wireless covert pulse waveform signal.

title: YOLOv9 Meets CBAM: A Real-Time Smart Traffic Signal System for Emergency Response Optimization
authors: Rohit Shitole, Aryan Shivatare, Jayant Shelke, Omraje Shendage, Vijay Rathod, Sujal Sune, Dattatray Takale
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: Delays in emergency vehicle (EV) movement within congested cities present a critical safety challenge. Current systems, which rely on single-mode visual or acoustic detection, are unreliable under poor visibility or high ambient noise. To address this, we propose a novel smart traffic solution that fuses visual and auditory data for robust, real-time EV recognition. The primary novelty of our work is the optimized integration of a YOLOv9 object detector with a CBAM-enhanced ResNet18 audio classifier, fused at the decision level. This architecture is specifically designed to suppress background clutter and acoustic interference, a significant challenge where prior intelligent transport systems have struggled. Our model achieved a mean Average Precision (mAP@0.5) of over 99% for visual detection and near-perfect scores (Precision: 0.994, Recall: 0.991, F1-Score: 0.992) for audio classification, operating at real-time speeds of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 33$</tex> FPS. Comparative results demonstrate superior recall and precision over unimodal approaches. This system reduces emergency response delays by dynamically controlling traffic signals, thereby enhancing intersection safety and contributing to a smarter urban traffic network.

title: Machine Learning vs. Agentic AI: Benchmarking RNA-Seq Disease Prediction with Candidate Biomarker Identification
authors: Abhisek Bakshi, Souvik Sengupta, Abhijit Dasgupta
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Accurate prediction of the disease state and identification of candidate biomarkers from high-dimensional RNA sequence (RNA-seq) data is a major challenge in precision medicine. Conventional Machine Learning (ML) pipelines for transcriptomic analysis typically involve sequential steps of preprocessing, feature selection, hyperparameter tuning, and evaluation. These pipelines often rely on either manual trial-and-error or exhaustive grid searches, which are time-consuming and may overlook the optimal configurations. In this study, we benchmarked a standard ML workflow against an agentic AI framework for RNA-seq based disease prediction and candidate biomarker identification. The ML baseline includes classifiers such as Support Vector Machine, Logistic Regression, and Random Forest optimized via conventional grid search. In contrast, agentic AI workflow employs Large Language Model (LLM) agents to autonomously orchestrate a cascade of downstream steps- preprocessing, class balancing, model selection, parameter optimization, and feature interpretation. Across multiple experimental setups, the agentic approach achieved a consistent 2–5% improvement in predictive accuracy, with notable gains in precision and recall even under class imbalance. A novel algorithm is proposed to identify candidate biomarkers by systematically ranking the top-contributing RNA features and then cross-referencing them with two public biomarker repositories. Our findings demonstrate that agentic AI not only improves model's prediction performance but also streamlines RNA-centric transcriptomic analysis, offering adaptability and actionable insights for RNA-based biomarker studies.

title: Research on a Fusion Algorithm for Boundary Violation Detection in Power Transmission and Transformation Construction Scenarios Based on Attention-Gated Recurrent Units
authors: Xiaomin Dai, Zhenjun Du, Jin Liu, Yu Xia, Xiaoguang Cheng, Yibin Wang, Feng Chen, Jiawen Yan, Xiongfei He
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Control and Computing Science (ICICCS)
abstract: Traditional multi-sensor fusion methods face challenges in perimeter intrusion detection under complex environmental conditions (rain, smog, nighttime), exhibiting high false alarm rates and limited robustness. This primarily stems from fixed weighting strategies that fail to dynamically assess sensor reliability. This study proposes an Attention-GRU multimodal fusion algorithm to enhance environmental adaptability and decision accuracy in transmission and transformation substation construction scenarios. The method integrates millimeter-wave radar and infrared thermal imaging through a collaborative perception architecture, employing parallel convolutional neural networks and gated recurrent unit modules to extract deep spatio-temporal dynamic features. The core innovation lies in introducing an attention mechanism to perform real-time reliability assessment and adaptive weighting of multimodal feature streams under varying environmental interference conditions. Experimental validation using a 110kV substation dataset demonstrates that the proposed algorithm achieves an F1 score of 98.2%, a false alarm rate of 1.3%, and a Mean Time Between False Alarms (MTBFA) of 76.8 hours, significantly outperforming Kalman fusion and single-sensor baselines. The proposed environment-aware attention-weighted temporal fusion paradigm provides an effective technical solution for high-reliability perimeter security.

title: High-Accuracy Classification of Pancreatic Cancer Subtypes Using Feature Selection and Optimized Machine Learning on High-Throughput Gene Expression Data
authors: Prajakta Gunjal, Tejas Mankeshwar, Girija Chiddarwar, Bhushan Anokar
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PC) is one of the deadliest cancers. It has a poor prognosis, with overall five-year survival rates between 2 % and 10 %. To address diagnostic challenges, new molecular classification based on gene expression is becoming important. A machine learning pipeline is created to classify four important PC molecular subtypes: Progenitor, ADEX, Squamous, and Immunogenic. The pipeline used high-throughput gene expression data from 150 matched samples. After reducing dimensions with L1 Regularization (LASSO), identification of molecular signature of 89 highly predictive genes has been conducted. Comparison of four different classification models: Random Forest (RF), XGBoost, Support Vector Machine (SVM), and Logistic Regression (LR) is presented in the research. Model has been optimized through all parameters using GridSearchCV with cross-validation. The comparison showed that ensemble methods performed better than traditional models. The XGBoost Classifier had the highest predictive power. The result is better as compared to the tuned Random Forest model and the Support Vector Machine model, both using the same 89-gene feature set.

title: Assessing the Emotional Impact of Fake News on Social Media: An Ensemble Approach to Sentiment Analysis
authors: Deepika Kumar, Ritanjali Panigrahi
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: The progress of Web 2.0 has radically transformed how we interact in the present day. Although it has enhanced connectedness and interpersonal communication, it has its disadvantages including sharing of fake information and the effects of the same on mental health. With the current influence of social media in our lives, it is important to thoughtfully weigh the benefits that it has brought to us against the potential harm that it can cause. This research undertaking attempts to examine the sentiment aroused by fake news shared in leading global social media sites like Twitter (X). A hard voting ensemble classifier was used, and it was able to classify tweets into phony and authentic with a remarkable 94.21% accuracy rate. Moreover, sentiment analysis with the same classifier resulted in an accuracy rate of 84.11%. The psychological implications of sharing misinformation with the general population were then examined using these models. The research also considers the significant correlation between fake news and emotions and depicts that misleading information is directly associated with negative mental health conditions. This establishes a strong relationship between the false news and attitudes. The results of the proposed approach were compared to the traditional machine learning algorithms. A larger multilingual dataset could justifiably be considered an improvement of the future study to test false tweets and real-time human emotions. As generative AI and large language models (LLMs) that can create highly realistic and misleading content, such as deepfakes; grow more popular, the issue of emotional reactions to false information has gained even greater significance.

title: A Computationally Enhanced STL-WD-Informer Framework for Short-Term Electricity Load Forecasting
authors: Cong Wu, Chengyi Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: Accurate short-term electricity load forecasting is a critical computational task for optimizing power system dispatch and energy management algorithms. To address the inherent computational challenges posed by the nonlinearity, non-stationarity, and high-frequency noise in load time series, this paper proposes an integrated computational framework: the STL-WD-Informer model. The framework employs a multi-stage algorithmic pipeline: Firstly, Seasonal-Trend decomposition using Loess (STL) decomposes the raw load sequence into computationally distinct components, effectively decoupling multi-scale temporal features through non-parametric smoothing. Secondly, Wavelet Threshold Denoising is algorithmically applied to the residual component, utilizing discrete wavelet transforms and adaptive thresholding to suppress high-frequency noise interference. Finally, an enhanced Informer architecture is developed for sequence prediction. Significantly, the model integrates the Convolutional Block Attention Module (CBAM) within its encoder-decoder structure. CBAM leverages both channel and spatial attention to dynamically focus on salient spatio-temporal patterns, significantly enhancing the model's ability to capture complex, high-dimensional load dynamics. Experimental results on electricity load datasets demonstrate that the proposed method significantly reduces prediction error compared to baseline models and exhibits more stable forecasting performance, validating its efficacy as a robust computational solution.

title: Smart Diagnostics of Sugarcane Nutrient Deficiency: Integrating UAV, RGB Imaging, and AI Models
authors: Pradip P Ghorpade, Pankaj Dashore
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Micronutrient deficiencies in nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), potassium (K), and sulfur (S) critically affect sugarcane growth, yield, and quality. Traditional diagnostic approaches, though accurate, are limited by cost, labor, and spatial scalability, which restrict timely intervention. Recent advances in remote sensing, UAV multispectral imaging, RGB phenotyping, and machine/deep learning (ML/DL) provide real-time and non-invasive alternatives for nutrient deficiency detection. This paper presents an integrated review and synthesis of thirty recent studies (2017–2025) covering UAV and satellite-based sensing, RGB image analysis, machine learning pipelines, convolutional neural networks, transfer learning, and multimodal sensor fusion.
