Comparative results show that UAV multispectral data combined with Random Forest regression achieved the highest accuracy <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathbf{R}^{2} = \mathbf 0.96)$</tex>, while RGB-based deep learning models such as ResNet152v2 achieved up to 93% classification accuracy. The analysis highlights trade-offs among accuracy, cost, computational requirements, and deployment feasibility. Furthermore, the study emphasizes emerging trends in edge AI, lightweight CNNs, explainable AI, and integrated decision-support systems for scalable adoption in sugarcane farming. By consolidating methods, metrics, and practical challenges, this work bridges the gap between experimental AI models and field-ready, farmer-centric nutrient management solutions, contributing to sustainable sugarcane agriculture.

title: Green Computing and Big Data Analytics: Towards Sustainable and Eco-Efficient Systems
authors: A.Jeyamurugan, Sharmila Bhargavi Vijayan, Kuppulakshmi G, A.Adaikkammai, B Yamini, Nalini M
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Explosion of big data has revolutionized industries and societies and has allowed intelligent decision making in various areas of life. Nonetheless, the growing data storage, processing and analysis needs have created a major concern over energy consumption, carbon emission and sustainability. Green computing has become a very important paradigm, which aims at minimizing the environmental effects of big data systems with high performance and reliability. This survey article discusses the overlap between green computing, big data and analytics with a focus on energy-efficient systems, sustainable infrastructures and environmentally friendly computational operations. It also demonstrates how green big data analytics can be used in smart cities, healthcare, agriculture, climate modelling, and disaster management to show how environmentally friendly strategies can maximize the use of resources and reduce ecological footprints. Other significant issues that have been explored in the paper include the tradeoff between performance and energy efficiency, data privacy and governance, cost verses environmental benefits, and the non-standardization of green measures. Possible future research directions are also discussed, such as green AI, edge and fog computing, blockchain integration, and policies of sustainability in terms of cultivating data ecosystems that are environmentally responsible. The results point to the dire necessity of a concerted action of academia, industry, and policy-making to develop eco-friendly, resilient, and sustainable big data solutions of the future.

title: Integrating Clinical and Demographic Data for Precision Drug Recommendation: A Machine Learning Perspective
authors: Nandagiri Upender, P Praveen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: In clinical practice, physicians have not yet been able to base their treatment decisions on evidence specific to the individual patient and are still making decisions based on general treatment algorithms. This study aims at developing a machine learning model to predict which drug would be more suitable for each patient based on demographic features and clinical measurements. The dataset consisted of records of 14,500 patients, captured by 42 clinical variables and 8 common drug categories. The gradient-boosted decision tree model achieved an excellent agreement with actual prescribing, where it was able to successfully predict the clinically administered drug for 11,236 patients at the time of evaluation. The model produced interpretability scores as well, allowing for thresholds of determinants, including age, renal function values, patterns of comorbidity, and documented adverse reactions to be ranked in support of an understandable clinical rationale. Such results indicate that standardized clinical and demographic information can be translated into specific treatment recommendations and have the potential to minimize trial-and-error prescribing for difficult to treat patients.

title: A Multi-Energy Load Forecasting Method Based on VMD and Iterative GRU Training
authors: Yajun Zhu, Lulu Chen, Tonghua Wu, Cheng Zhou, Song Hu, Biao Cong
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Power System and Energy Internet (PoSEI)
abstract: Accurate prediction of multi-energy loads in regional integrated energy systems is crucial for optimized system operation. However, it faces challenges including the non-stationary nature of load sequences, coupling between different energy loads, and incomplete data acquisition. This paper proposes a forecasting model that integrates Variational Mode Decomposition (VMD) with a Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) network and an iterative training mechanism. The proposed method first employs VMD to decompose the original load sequences into intrinsic mode functions, thereby reducing non-stationarity. It then constructs a GRU-based forecasting model by integrating multi-energy load features to explore their coupling relationships. Furthermore, an online error evaluation and iterative training mechanism is introduced to enhance prediction stability. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach significantly improves the forecasting accuracy for multi-energy loads.

title: MAGNet: A Multi-scale Attention and Gated-skip Network for Multimodal Brain Tumor Segmentation
authors: Jiufu Zhu, Wenjie Chen, Chuanyu Diao, Yanxiao Li, Lintao Zhang, Minghui Deng
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Accurate segmentation of brain tumors from multimodal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is essential for clinical diagnosis, treatment planning, and prognosis. However, the task remains challenging due to tumor heterogeneity, fuzzy boundaries, and modality-specific variations. To address these issues, we propose MAGNet, a Multi-scale Attention and Gated-skip Network tailored for multimodal brain tumor segmentation. MAGNet incorporates two key components: the Multi-Scale Attention Enhancement (MSAE) module, which combines multi-scale convolutions with complementary attention mechanisms to strengthen global–local feature fusion, and the Attention-Gated Skip (AG-Skip) module, which adaptively filters encoder features to suppress redundancy and enhance semantic consistency during decoding. In addition, the TeLU activation function is introduced to improve nonlinear representation and gradient flow. Cross-dataset generalization experiments on BraTS2019 and BraTS2020 demonstrate that MAGNet consistently outperforms several state-of-the-art models, showing superior accuracy and robustness across diverse datasets.

title: IPAN: IP-Adapter Attention Modulation with Noun-aware Mask Refinement for Diffusion-based Object Removal
authors: Huimin Liu, Meiqing Wang, Hang Cheng, Fei Chen, Yuanxiang Fang, Shujie Zhang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Diffusion models have made significant progress in high-fidelity image synthesis and editing, yet high-quality object removal remains challenging. Existing methods lack fine-grained semantic control over image-conditioning signals. Moreover, generating editing masks from cross-attention maps often leads to irrelevant regions in the masks. In this paper, we propose a training-free, dual-branch diffusion-control framework that improves object removal performance by decomposing the image-conditioning signals and optimizing the editing mask. Specifically, we introduce a semantics-aware IP-Adapter attention modulation strategy that leverages the decomposability of image-conditioning embeddings. This strategy dynamically rescales cross-attention maps throughout multi-scale denoising to attenuate target features and strengthen background consistency. In parallel, we design a noun-aware mask optimization mechanism that parses non-target nouns in the prompt to locate distractor regions and progressively suppresses their spurious responses, producing precise editing masks. Experiments show that the framework improves object-removal stability and controllability, and outperforms existing methods in mask purity, semantic alignment, and background integration.

title: Power Grid Fault Diagnosis Method Based on Wavelet Entropy Weight and Improved Hybrid Kernel Extreme Learning Machine
authors: Yihe Wang, Wuyang Zhang, Fang Dong, Yan Lu, Xinyu Chen, Xinyue Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Power System and Energy Internet (PoSEI)
abstract: With the continuous expansion of the power grid scale, its operational complexity is increasing day by day, making rapid and accurate fault diagnosis and ensuring the safe and stable operation of the system increasingly important. Traditional machine learning methods have weak capabilities in fault feature extraction and cannot achieve rapid and accurate fault diagnosis. To address the aforementioned issues, this paper proposes a power grid fault diagnosis method based on wavelet entropy weight and an improved hybrid kernel extreme learning machine. Firstly, this method performs multi-resolution analysis wavelet transform on fault currents based on wavelet basis functions. To better represent the characteristics of different short-circuit types, the sum of wavelet entropy weights of each phase current, the sum of wavelet entropy weight distribution distances, and the quantified zero-sequence current are obtained based on the wavelet entropy weight method, addressing the weak problem in fault feature extraction. Secondly, through adaptive optimization of the hybrid kernel function and key parameters of the hybrid kernel extreme learning machine using an optimization algorithm, a high-performance fault classifier is constructed. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed method is verified through fault simulation data validation and actual measured data from a power grid in Liaoning.

title: NFC-based Contactless Food Ordering Ecosystem with Dynamic Health Scoring and Subscriber Meal Automation
authors: B. Padmavathi, Kiruthik Kanna M, Kishore S, Monish Kumaar M
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Traditional food Service systems face critical challenges such as slow transaction processing, accessibility issues, and the absence of personalized health guidance. Most Food Service Systems use a QR code-based ordering System, which significantly lags in operational latency due to multi-step processes involving menu navigation, camera activation, QR code scanning, and payment credential entry. This paper presents an integrated Near Field Communication (NFC) – based food ordering ecosystem that fixes these constraints through three different innovations into a single unit: First, a dual-mode NFC communication framework enables quick order retrieval through Host Card Emulation for NFC-enabled smartphones and physical NFC cards for non-NFC devices, removing Camera Reliance Operations. Second, a health scoring engine powered by Deep Reinforcement Learning induces real-time nutrition recommendations and implements strategies to modify dietary behaviors through a dynamic credit point system by nutritional analysis. Third, an automated preplanned meal subscription module to include all types of nutrition dietary with flexibility to change the meal before the threshold time. The security protocol, based on Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman key exchange with pseudonym-based authentication, proves resistance against impersonation, replay, and man-in-the-middle attacks. Data driven investigation has been done using PN 532 NFC modules interfaced with ESP 32 microcontrollers results 39.6% reduction in transactional time compared to QR code systems. Live implementation in an institutional cafeteria serving 500 daily customers achieved 42% improvement in service time, 87.3% accuracy in identifying unbalanced diet patterns, 23% reduction in preorder meals wastage and 98.7% transaction success rate. The system presents a long-term solution for improving operational efficiency, promoting Data-driven health insights and elevating user satisfaction in food service operations.

title: OCR and NLP-Powered Text-To-Speech System for Mathematical Documents
authors: Sonali Antad, Vedant Desai, Siddhesh Deshmukh, Devang Deshpande, Manas Deshpande
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: This work presents a browser-based tool that turns math-heavy PDFs into clear, human-sounding speech. Built for blind and low-vision readers as well as auditory learners, it speaks equations and symbols in context-an area where general screen readers often fall short. The system couples reliable text extraction with PyMuPDF, lightweight math parsing and normalization, and multilingual text-to-speech to produce natural narration. Implemented in Python with Flask, it supports offline English output via pyttsx3 and delivers high-quality Hindi/Marathi narration through gTTS, making it practical in both connected and low-connectivity settings. Testing on real course materials and public documents showed consistent, intelligible rendering of mathematical content and improved independent access to STEM resources. Because the architecture is lightweight and easy to deploy, it suits classrooms, libraries, and institutions adopting Universal Design for Learning. Overall, the results indicate strong potential for wider adoption across academic, professional, and government environments seeking inclusive, language-aware access to technical documents.

title: Vision-Based 3D Occupancy Perception with Mixed-Resolution
authors: Jufei Wang, Hu Wei, Huasheng Ni, Xuan Huang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: To address limitations of existing autonomous driving parking perception models—insufficient 3D height perception in BEV models, prohibitive computational costs for high precision uniform voxel occupancy perception, scarcity of large scale OCC datasets, and poor suspended object recall, we propose a 3D space occupancy perception method based on vision and using a mixed-resolution approach, which is applicable to parking scenarios. First, we propose a method for mixed-resolution occupancy labels with mask initialization. Then for explicit projection, we adopted FBOCC as the baseline and integrated a mix-resolution voxel feature module tailored to forward and backward projections; for implicit projection, we enhance PETR v2 by adding depth-aware 3D position encoding and mixed-resolution optimized query offsets. Additionally, experiments demonstrated that our mix-resolution approach achieves a better trade-off between perception precision and computational efficiency compared to baseline methods. Our work ultimately provides an efficient solution for 3D occupancy perception in parking scenarios, meeting the growing demand for perception accuracy in autonomous driving.

title: Adaptive Urban Traffic Control Using Camera Vision and Emergency Vehicle Mobile Interface
authors: Bl Shilpa, M Mayank, S Md Fakruddin
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Computing, Semiconductor, Mechatronics, Intelligent Systems and Communications (COSMIC)
abstract: Urban traffic congestion is a significant concern in the daily operations of commuters and emergency responders. Existing systems based on timers do not have the ability to adjust density and prioritize emergency calls. This paper offers an integrated intelligent traffic management system based on density-related signal reordering, including emergency vehicle preemption. This system uses existing surveillance cameras and a custom-trained Roboflow object detection model (mAP@50 $=99.5 \%$) to provide vehicle counts, allowing for lane priority reordering, rather than routine signal timing changes. A dedicated mobile app allows only the emergency vehicle’s to pre-declare its route, and the backend system looks for green-signal precedents when the emergency vehicle is within a 500 meters distance approach window. Real-time control of signal precedence is accomplished by using a network of LED modules connected to the ESP32 development board. The system also reduces average wait time by up to $35 \%$ and keeps the emergency vehicle moving without obstructions. The results show the experiment, an effective system compared to existing work, including an analysis of the existing YOLO-based systems, and discussion of limitations and applicability to scalable smart-city development.

title: Interpretable Machine Learning Approaches for Balanced Credit Card Fraud Detection
authors: Pooja Shrivastav, Aashita Srivastava
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: As e-commerce continues to experience rapid growth, credit cards serve as the preferred method for financial payments. With the ease of access to credit cards, the withdrawal of funds through credit cards has exponentially increased. This also paves the way to serious fraud, resulting in losses to users and financial institutions. Data imbalance causes a major challenge in the identification of fraud. To address this, a framework is proposed that utilizes multiple machine learning algorithms, such as Logistic Regression, Naïve Bayes, K-Nearest Neighbors, Random Forest, AdaBoost, and Gradient Boosting, along with the Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE) to balance the datasets. This enhances the capability of models to learn significant fraud patterns. Furthermore, the prediction can be interpreted with Explainable AI (XAI) algorithms like SHAP and LIME that provide insight into the most important elements and contribute to identifying fraudulent activity. Experimental assessment of a real-world Kaggle dataset shows that Gradient Boosting and Random Forest demonstrate the best performance. Together with data balancing through SMOTE and interpretability through XAI, the proposed system is effective and usable in real-life finance fraud prevention.

title: Weather Forecasting Using CNN and Image Streams
authors: Roshi Saxena, Urmila Pilania, Drishti Kataria, Gunjan Virmani
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: This accurate forecasting is essential for public safety, agriculture, transportation. Traditional weather forecasting methods mostly depend on physical simulations and mathematical models. These methods need considerable computing power and can sometimes give less accurate results, mainly for short-term or very local predictions. In recent years, machine learning has brought a new approach to forecasting. It uses methods that can learn and understand complex weather patterns. A Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model is used for visual weather classification. Basically, model studies about weather images to predict five conditions: fog, smog, lightning, rain and sandstorms. For this a data set of more than 3000 images was prepared. The images were processed using steps like changing, converting to grayscale, normalization and edge detection. In the construction of the CN model many convolutional and max-pooling were developed. For efficient model training data set was divided into 80% for training and 20% for validation to train the model effectively. The model achieved a validation accuracy of over 85%, with strong performance in distinguishing visually distinctive conditions like lightning and sandstorms. Early stopping was employed to prevent excessive fitting. The model demonstrates the ability to extract spatial features from weather images effectively, enabling real-time predictions with reduced computational costs. This approach offers a promising alternative to conventional techniques. This system can classify real-time weather using live images feeds and has been integrated into a stream-lit based web application that allows the user to interact and for practical use. The project works in identifying clear weather patterns. It follows a common method of forecasting and also can be used in smart weather monitoring systems. In future, it can also be improved by adding satellite images and sensor data.

title: Performance Analysis of 112 Gbps Polarization Division Multiplexed 16-PSK Based Inter-Satellite Optical Wireless Communication
authors: Mehtab Singh, Somia A. Abd El-Mottaleb, Tanvir Kaur, Gargi Verma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Telecommunications and Artificial Intelligence (IC-FTAI)
abstract: The paper reports the performance analysis of an inter-satellite optical wireless communication (IsOWC) system using 16-phase shift keying (16-PSK) modulation with 112 Gbps capacity. It examines the effect of the distance of transmission, efficiency of the transmitter and receiver, laser power, and pointing accuracy on the system's performance. To evaluate the system's performance, we focus on crucial metrics including bit error rate (BER), error vector magnitude (EVM), received optical power (ROP), and constellation diagrams. The problem of signal degradation, and consequently the decrease of the accuracy of the received data, is compensated on the receiver side by employing complex signal processing techniques such as signal adaptive equalization, frequency offset estimation, and carrier phase estimation on coherent optical communication. The system can transmit 16-PSK signals within the range of 10000 km under the conditions that 90 % of the optics efficiency is maintained and 30 dBm is the laser power, with permissive error levels, and EVM lower than 10 %.

title: Grassman Optimized Convolution Neural Network Towards Student Activity Recognition and Classification in E-Classes using Facial Emotional Features
authors: Devendhiran A, Pravin M, Mannem Praveen
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Activity recognition of the students in both offline online classes has become important constraint in the educational industries to enhance learning outcomes and its student wellbeing on basis of their behavior to facilitate timely interventions to enhance learning experiences and outcomes. In recent years, huge advancements in technologies such as artificial intelligence, cloud computing and internet of things many computer vision approaches has been employed to perform aforementioned task. Despite of several advantages of those advantages approaches, still many challenges exhibited in terms of the generalization and outlier detection. To mitigate those challenges, an innovative deep learning architecture along metaheursitic technique has been designed to accurately recognize the activity of the students through real time data in form of the video on wide range of academic and non-academic activities. In this paper, a Grassman Optimized Convolution Neural Network is designed and implemented for facial emotion recognition at various key focal points along integrating the contextual information of the student. Initially acquired video is transformed into individual frames to specified time intervals. Each frame is processed using convolution layer of the convolution neural network to extract student emotion using kernel function and activation function as facial features of the image. Those extracted facial features are processed in the pooling layer using grassman metaheursitic technique represented as grassman technique. Here, the Grassmann optimization improves the CNN by representing the extracted facial features as subspaces on a Grassmann manifold rather than as individual Euclidean vectors. This preserves the geometric relationships between emotional patterns and enables more robust and generalized feature selection, making the model more resistant to noise, variations, and outliers compared to conventional pooling methods. It is used as attention mechanism to the pooling layer to extract high level facial feature of the each frame and it is modeled as feature map on representation of happiness, sadness, anger, and surprise. Obtained feature map is processed finally in the fully connected layer of the network through activation function, normalization function and softmax function to classify feature map of the emotion as student activity classes as engaged, attentive, confused, or disinterested. On specified emotion state of the student, various insight of the students can be provides to provide personalized educational support and the development of intelligent learning systems. Experimental analysis of the proposed model towards student activity recognition and classification has been performed using training data DIPSER dataset in the python environment. On performance analysis of the model using test data through confusion matrix, its provides parameter to the performance metric such as precision, recall and f measure. It is proved that model accuracy of the proposed model is found to be outperforming compared to conventional approaches.

title: A Pathway to Net-zero Power Generation in Barbados Using Hybrid Renewable Energy Systems and Hydrogen
authors: Alireza Maheri, Tré Mason, Legena Henry
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Environment Friendly Energies and Applications (EFEA)
abstract: The ever-increasing threat of the climate crisis poses significant risks to countries worldwide, particularly to Small Island Developing States (SIDS) such as Barbados. SIDS are especially vulnerable due to their small size and relative isolation. As a result, green and reliable energy systems that harness renewable energy sources are crucial for sustainable development and energy security. The Barbados National Energy Policy aims for the island to achieve 100% renewable energy generation and carbon neutrality by 2030. In this study, a three-point energy transition scenario is defined, with the corresponding optimal hybrid renewable energy system determined for each transition point using the multi-objective design optimisation software tool MOHRES. The optimisation problem formulation considers system cost, reliability, and net emissions. The transition scenario accounts for the planned phase-out of existing fossil-fuel power plants, aiming to reduce current emissions by 50%, 65% and 99% by 2025, 2027 and 2030 respectively. This reduction is achieved through the integration of renewable energy, battery/hydrogen storage systems, and green hydrogen production to offset emissions. Optimal solutions with minimal investment costs were found, satisfying constraints on system reliability and net emissions. The results show that as renewable energy is integrated during the transition, grid carbon content decreases from 456 g/MWh in 2024 to 7 g/MWh in 2030, with 171% renewable penetration. This leads to annual fuel savings of approximately $200 million and net green hydrogen production of around 860 tons per year.

title: Interpretable Research Impact Clustering via Spectral Graph Theory and Explainable AI: A Unified Framework Using Citation Networks and Altmetric Signals
authors: K. Sangamithrai, Bharath K, Mitheswar Raaj K K
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: The traditional way of assessing research, which heavily relies on citation data, offers a strong but delayed and limited view of how scholarly work affects society. This method is unable to capture the immediate relevance of research or clearly explain the patterns it observes. Although altmetrics, which come from social media, news sites, policy documents, and other online sources, offer real-time views of public and professional interest, they are often studied separately, creating the sense of being fragmented. The main challenge is integrating these current and historical measures into a single, clear model that can represent the complex and varied nature of research impact. This paper introduces a new framework that addresses this problem by combining spectral graph theory with explainable artificial intelligence (XAI). Our aim is to create a reliable and understandable way to group research papers based on their scholarly background and public engagement. Our method follows a structured process. First, we build a large citation net- work using data from sources like OpenCitations and Microsoft Academic Graph, with each paper as a node and citations as directional links. Each node is then enriched with altmetric data, such as Twitter mentions, Mendeley saves, and news citations, from providers like Altmetric.com, transforming the network into a detailed and informative graph. The main analysis uses spectral clustering on this graph. By computing the normalized graph Laplacian and performing eigen-decomposition, we convert the nodes into a lower- dimensional space that reflects the graph's structure. Applying clustering methods like k-means to this space reveals hidden thematic communities that are influenced not only by internal citation patterns but also by altmetric signals of public attention. This helps identify research groups that may be both intellectually consistent and socially significant. A major innovation of our system is incorporating XAI methods after clustering to reveal the findings. We use techniques like SHAP and LIME, which are suitable for any model, to determine the importance of different features. This gives both overall and detailed explanations, answering questions such as: Which factors-like specific citations, high news coverage, or policy mentions-were most important in shaping a cluster? Why was a paper associated with one cluster and not another? This transforms the model from a “black box” to a “glass box,” offering unprecedented transparency. The outcome of this system includes a multi-faceted analysis of research influence, specifically: 1. Thematic clusters of articles grouped by both structural and societal similarities. 2. An interpretability report that outlines the key attributes driving each cluster and highlights important papers. 3. Interactive visualizations of the clustered citation network using tools like NetworkX and Gephi. 4. Impact profiles for notable papers, detailing their significance through both citations and altmetrics. This system offers valuable insights to stakeholders such as funding bodies, research institutions, and policymakers, providing a clear and transparent means to understand the scientific landscape, identify emerging fields, and assess impact in a multi- dimensional way. By effectively combining the structural strength of spectral graph theory with the societal reach of altmetrics and the transparency of XAI, this study establishes a new standard for explainable scientometric analysis.

title: Smart Legal Advisor Mobile Application: A AI-Powered Legal Assistant
authors: Dhruv Singla, Krishna Chand Thakur, Mekhala, Mamta Narwaria
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: The increased need to access legal aid indicates the constraints of traditional modes of consultation that are in most cases time consuming, expensive and geographically restricted. To cope with this difficulty, we introduce the AI Lawyer Mobile Application, a smart law assistant using the power of artificial intelligence and state-of-the-art mobile technologies to offer real-time, context-dependent legal assistance. The proposed system is built on the React Native and Expo platforms and a Node.js/Express server and MongoDB database to manage the data securely. Authentication is provided through mobile number registration, OTP verification and JWT token management to guarantee privacy and security. The main contributions of the work is the incorporation of the VextApp API, which allows the application to offer domain-specific legal answers via a conversational interface, which supports markdown formatting, animation effects, and the dark mode. Experimental validation proves that the proposed system offers correct, responsive and useful interaction enabling to handle a session correctly and guarantee a secure history of conversation. The application, a combination of strong architecture with the use of AI-reasoning, helps to close the divide between users and legal expertise, which is a scalable solution to democratizing the provision of legal aid.

title: Revolutionizing Wearables with Energy Efficient Smart Clothing
authors: Anupriya, Paras Jain, Shivani Agarwal, Vishan Kumar Gupta, Kireet Joshi, Satish Kumar Mishra
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: Energy efficient systems are also a developing and promising branch of wearable technology, smart clothing. The clothes are self-sufficient because they incorporate energy-gathering technologies such as solar, thermoelectric and kinetic in order to integrate into the fabric. They also control the power consumption to make the battery have a longer life. With this new technology, there is less need to utilize old forms of power sources, and this minimizes its effects on the environment by a large margin. The user-centred design ensures that the daily use is convenient and helpful. This research paper discusses the uses of smart clothing that is energy efficient in areas like health, fitness, environmental and communication. Energy efficiency and wearables can transform most industries positively and form a more sustainable and integrated connection between technology and society. The accessibility of the energy-efficient system in the form of the sophisticated power management methods and energy harvesting technologies allows making smart clothing with realistic ideas. They emphasize the fact that these systems are important since they contribute to the environment and sustainability.

title: Explainable Federated AI Framework for Privacy-Aware Medical Image Processing and Diagnostic Decision Support Systems
authors: Sheetal Vijay Kulkarni, Selvaganesh R, Kamila Ibragimova, Malik Bader Alazzam, Sajiv G, B Kiran Bala
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Advancements in AI-driven medical imaging have improved diagnostic accuracy but often rely on centralized data collection, raising privacy, regulatory, and interpretability concerns. Existing approaches using federated learning, differential privacy, and explainable AI address parts of these issues but face challenges such as accuracy degradation, communication overhead, inconsistent explanations, and limited real-world validation. The proposed FedAvg-CNN-DPXAI framework uniquely integrates decentralized CNN training, differential privacy, and dual explainability (GradCAM and SHAP) to ensure secure, interpretable diagnostics without raw data sharing. Histopathologic Cancer Detection dataset images are preprocessed, locally trained at client sites, and aggregated via FedAvg, with model compression reducing communication costs. The framework achieves 98.2 % accuracy, 98.6 % precision, 97.5 % recall, and 97.1 % F1-score, outperforming existing models. Deployment through Docker ensures scalability and integration with hospital systems while maintaining compliance. The approach enhances diagnostic trust, preserves privacy, and supports continuous federated updates for adaptive, regulation-aligned clinical decisionmaking.

title: Data-Driven Pipeline Integrity Optimization in Oil and Gas Infrastructure Using Ensemble Learning and Interpretable AI
authors: Yue Yu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: This study presents a comprehensive machine learning framework for pipeline condition assessment integrating ensemble methods with explainable AI techniques. Six tree-based algorithms including Random Forest, XGBoost, and Gradient Boosting are systematically evaluated on operational pipeline data comprising 1000 samples with nine critical features. The proposed framework achieves 99.2% test accuracy while SHAP analysis reveals thickness loss (68.79%) and material loss (21.32%) as dominant predictors. Feature importance analysis demonstrates that structural degradation metrics supersede operational parameters, enabling optimized sensor deployment strategies for cost- effective predictive maintenance systems.

title: Dual-Band Antennas for AI-Enabled Autonomous Vehicle-to-Infrastructure Communication
authors: Koppisetti Giridhar, Dheepika G B, Anusha Preetham, Monica G K, Arun Kumar N, N. Nandhagopal
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: The complexity of the modern systems also needs more effective optimization techniques which must scale, be accurate and robust in a single product. Traditional techniques have discouraged the ability to deal with large sizes in the search space and reaching. the best solutions. To eliminate these shortcomings, topresent an innovative hybrid structure of optimization between quasi -oppositional learning and genetic search to improve performance in GUI test case generation. The validation of the proposed technique was applied to the benchmark datasets and experimental simulations. The findings have indicated that the performance indicators have been improved greatly based on the current approaches: 97.8% accuracy, 96.9% precision, 97.4% recall, and an F1-score of 97.2%. The increase in system efficiency was 15%, the reduction of the computational overhead by 12%, and the adaptability to varied testing environments by 18%. The results justify the effectiveness of the proposed solution and present a feasible and smart model that can be used to perform dependable software testing.

title: Design and Implementation of an Indigenous Semi-Anechoic Chamber for Military Applications
authors: Chetna Gupta, Sourav Chatterjee
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Electromagnetic Interference and Compatibility (INCEMIC)
abstract: Achieving electromagnetic compatibility (EMC) demands precision design and stringent validation within specialized EMI-EMC test chambers. However, dependence on imported chamber suppliers often leads to high costs, long lead times, and limited adaptability to local manufacturing practices. This paper presents the design and development of an indigenously engineered semi-anechoic chamber operating over a wide frequency range (9 kHz – 40 GHz), developed in accordance with MIL-STD-461G and aligned with the Make in India initiative.The focus of this work is on design decisions guided by indigenous manufacturing capabilities, workmanship constraints, and material availability, while ensuring compliance with global EMC standards. Key challenges encountered during fabrication—such as achieving high shielding effectiveness at low frequencies, maintaining uniform electrical bonding, and mitigating structural discontinuities—were addressed through indigenous solutions, including optimized gasket configurations, reinforced joint designs, and enhanced seam treatments.The paper aims to serve as a reference for future domestic developments, sharing practical insights and corrective measures to help other teams avoid the common pitfalls encountered during chamber construction, while strengthening India’s self-reliance in EMI-EMC infrastructure.

title: TDMRP: A Transparent and Decentralized Management of Reputation and Pseudonym in IoV
authors: Fei Tong, Haitao Yang, Fangyuan Xing, Shibo He, Hongzhou Wang, Heng Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: The development of Internet of vehicle (IoV) enables vehicles to share road condition data, while the honesty and anonymity of vehicles have become the core issues. The effective solutions to these two issues involving reputation and pseudonym management engender a dilemma. On the one hand, the reputation values bound to pseudonyms may cause pseudonym to be re-linked. On the other hand, the use of pseudonyms may make reputation evaluation schemes less effective. What is more, existing solutions have a single point of failure problem in pseudonym generation and lose a lot of reputation value. To this end, we propose a blockchain-based transparent and decentralized management of reputation and pseudonym (referred to as TDMRP), which can reduce the reputation loss caused by the conventional cloak mechanism and protect privacy of identity. Specifically, for the reputation management, a reputation evaluation scheme is designed with no need of additional characteristic values, which can maintain the unlinkability of pseudonym. To reduce the reputation loss, we propose a dynamic cloak algorithm, which is proved to achieve the theoretically minimal reputation loss. For the pseudonym management, we present an innovative shuffling architecture called fusion shuffling incorporating the strengths of traditional shuffling, Shamir secret sharing, and verifiable random functions (VRF), which not only enhances computational speed, security, and memory efficiency, but also addresses the single point of failure inherent in traditional shuffling architectures. Through extensive experiments compared with the state-of-the-art work, we have demonstrated that the reputation evaluation scheme is relatively stable under various malicious environments, and the proposed cloak mechanism reduces reputation loss of 37.06% averagely, and the proposed shuffling is 53.76% averagely faster.

title: ML-Stereo: Multi-range Lookup for Stereo Matching
authors: B. Chen, X. Chen, C. B. Zheng, S. Q. Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics
abstract: In recent years, iterative optimization-based stereo matching methods have demonstrated significant potential. However, most existing approaches adopt a single lookup range strategy, which encounters difficulties when handling ill-posed regions, particularly in occluded areas where matching cues are insufficient. In this paper, a Multi-range Lookup for Stereo Matching (ML-Stereo) is proposed, an iteratively optimized architecture incorporating a multi-range lookup mechanism. It employs lookup operators with varying lookup radii at different stages of the iteration process, thereby enhancing both the efficiency of the iterative refinement and the accuracy of disparity estimation. Furthermore, a Multi-scale Attention ConvGRU (MAC-GRU) is designed to adaptively exploit informative features beneficial for stereo matching, thereby further improving efficiency. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm significantly outperforms existing methods in disparity estimation for ill-posed regions such as occlusions, while exhibiting strong generalization capability in real-world scenarios.

title: Cybersecurity Framework for Proactive Detection of Image-Based Malware in Healthcare Networks Using Explainable Deep Ensemble Learning and Edge Analytics
authors: Malak Alamri, Zulfiqar Ahmad, Mamoona Humayun, Menwa Alshammeri, Amr Munshi, Jawad Rasheed
publish: IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics
abstract: The fast-paced digitalization of the healthcare sector (Electronic Health Records (EHRs), Internet of Medical Things (IoMT) devices, medical imaging, and telemedicine) has enabled more efficient patient care but has also increased the attack surface of sophisticated threats. These security concerns are emerging in consumer electronics within smart healthcare ecosystems, which rely on image-based analytics and edge-enabled intelligence. In this study, we propose an edge-enabled cybersecurity framework that integrates deep ensemble learning and edge analytics to preemptively identify image-based malware in healthcare networks and provide low-latency inference at the data source. We introduce VGDense-DeepEnsemble (VGGDenseNet-DeepEnsemble), a novel stacked deep learning model that combines VGG16, VGG19, DenseNet121, and DenseNet169 through ensemble learning with a meta-model to enhance detection performance. Explainable AI (XAI) using Grad-CAM was applied to sample images to interpret the decision-making process. We evaluated the proposed model on the Blended Malware Image Dataset, which comprises 31 malware families with a separate test dataset for final assessment. The proposed model attains 96% overall accuracy with macro precision of 97%, macro recall of 96%, and macro F1 score of 96%. These results exceed the performance of the individual backbones (VGG16: 88%, VGG19: 94%, DenseNet121: 93%, DenseNet169: 94%). As revealed through the ROC and precision-recall analysis, separability and robustness are high across all the classes, and confusion matrices reveal significant decreases in misclassifications in challenging families (e.g., Neshta, Sality, Agent, Injector). Grad-CAM explanations indicate that the predictions are informed by discriminative, malware-relevant structures and not background artifacts. These findings show that transparent edge-based deep ensemble models can be an effective, accurate, explainable defense against image-based malware in healthcare networks.

title: Time-Reversal Metasurface with Intensity-Controlled Multi-Focusing in Scattering-Embedded Channels
authors: Weiping Chen, Li Deng, Meijun Qu, Kwok L. Chung
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: Near-field multi-focusing holds significant implications for wireless power transfer (WPT), wireless communications, and medical applications. Particularly, the capability to implement these applications in scattering channels represents a significant stride forward. This letter proposes a time-reversal multi-focusing theory applicable to metallic scattering and low-loss dielectric scattering channels. To validate the theoretical framework, we introduce a time-reversal-based metasurface capable of controlling the amplitude and phase, enabling high-efficiency multi-focusing in metallic scattering and low-loss dielectric scattering channels with controllable intensity ratio across different focal points. The adaptability of the proposed intensity-controlled metasurface is demonstrated through full-wave simulations and measurements in two representative scattering channels. Ultimately, the proposed metasurface achieves high-precision multi-focusing in various scattering channels, with controllable intensity for each focal spot and extends to a broader frequency range (5.2GHz - 6.4GHz) with high focusing efficiency (48<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\%$</tex-math></inline-formula> - 64<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\%$</tex-math></inline-formula>). Furthermore, we developed a measurement for intensity-controllable dual-focusing WPT utilizing the time-reversal multi-focusing metasurface in scattering environments.

title: Towards Robust Stance Detection: A Hybrid Architecture for Target-Specific Stance Detection in Roman Urdu
authors: Nida Iftikhar, Sehrash Safdar, Muhammad Wasim
publish: 2025 International Conference on Engineering &amp; Computing Technologies (ICECT)
abstract: Stance detection is the measure of detecting the point of view about a target. The task has become significant due to an increase in the application of social media discourse and the dissemination of fake information. This paper suggests a hybrid deep learning model, which combines a pre-trained T5 transformer encoder, a BiLSTM and an attention mechanism. The framework is able to encompass contextual semantics and sequential dependencies in textual data. The T5 model can give rich contextualised embeddings encoding subtle patterns in language, and the BiLSTM gives bidirectional dependencies needed to interpret the underlying stance. An attention layer is incorporated to dynamically weigh the most informative tokens, enabling the model to concentrate on the part that is essential for stance detection. This architecture is designed to be target-aware, robust to linguistic noise, and suitable for both high and low-resource datasets. We assess our framework on benchmark datasets, including P-STANCE, SRQ, SemEval2016, and AMUSED, achieving competitive performance and demonstrating its effectiveness in various social media and political discourse settings. The results indicate that combining pretrained language models with sequence-aware attention-based architectures represents a promising direction for advancing stance detection, particularly in noisy and informal text environments such as Roman Urdu.

title: A Threat Modeling Approach for Securing Blockchain Framework
authors: Neelkumar K. Shah, Sachin Nandurkar, Mayur Lilhare, Mohammad Aziz Maalik, Indraveni Chebolu, Niteshkumar Harne, Manoj Kumar Khare
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: Blockchain technology is gaining popularity across various industries due to its decentralised, transparent, and immutable nature. However, as blockchain-based frameworks evolve to support large-scale services and applications, they are increasingly vulnerable to complex security threats. This study presents a STRIDE-based approach to detect and mitigate potential vulnerabilities in blockchain systems. The framework provides methods to enhance security across smart contracts, communication protocols, and databases by analysing vulnerabilities, including spoofing, tampering, repudiation, information disclosure, denial-of-service attacks, and elevation of privilege. The objective of this paper is to assist users in building secure blockchain applications in industries such as education, healthcare, and finance.

title: A Comprehensive Framework for Disaster Recovery of SAP Environments in Microsoft Azure: Multi-Sector Analysis and Implementation Strategies
authors: Sheetal Joyce, Ramesh Mani, Arunkumar Pasumarthi, Kannan Kumarasamy, Vijay Mane, Chinmay Inamdar
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: As organisations continue to depend more on SAP systems to host its mission-critical enterprise processes, disaster recovery procedures are emerging as an essential element, especially adopted in cloud environments including Microsoft Azure. Conventional disaster recovery strategies might not take into consideration the technical complexity of incorporating SAP disaster resiliency with the cloud-native disaster resiliency offered by Azure, therefore, posing a risk to multi-sector applications in which the impacts of downtime can be catastrophic economically, regulatory, and societal. The research is aimed at developing a complete disaster recover framework of SAP systems on the Microsoft Azure, assuming a multi-industry analysis of healthcare, finance, manufacturing and government sectors. The framework is achieved by synthesizing research on systematic literature review and sector-based survey findings with the community of practices associated with system replication, and compliance models driven by governance. The analysis explains how requirements specific to the sector (Recovery Time Objectives or RTO, Recovery Point Objectives or RPO, requirement to be compliant with regulations), influence the protection strategy of disaster recovery. Additionally, the paper also assesses case deployments in order to identify the comparative effectiveness of on-premises, cloud based and hybrid disaster recovery solutions. The proposed framework is a theoretical and practical contribution as the result that can arrange the enterprise continuity goals in the correspondence with the resilience capabilities of Azure taking into consideration the sector-specific governance limitations into consideration.

title: Perfumer Optimization - Enhanced Graph Neural Networks for Efficient and Accurate COVID-19 Risk Prediction in IoT/IoMT Healthcare
authors: C R Komala, Bal Virdee, Ashish Khanna, R G Vidhya, S Sivashankar
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: A great imperative to develop healthcare monitoring systems that are real-time, accurate and lowlatency has emerged since the COVID-19 pandemic. Traditional cloud-based solutions and machine learning methods face problems of latency, poor flexibility and inferior feature representation which hinder significantly their utilization in IoT- and IoMT-powered healthcare systems. To solve these problems, a Perfumer Optimization- Attentionbased Dynamic Multilayer Graph Neural Network (POADMGNN) for COVID-19 risk prediction over fog-assisted healthcare systems has been presented in this research. The platform provides secure citizen registration, ongoing data collection from wearables and the environment through IoT sensors, and effective preprocessing at the fog layer, in which the Superb Fairy-Wren Optimization Algorithm makes choice of the most important features. The features are then differentiated via ADMGNN which is designed based on multilayer graph, temporal dynamics and attention mechanism to capture complicated health issues. In addition, the Perfumer Optimization Algorithm adjusts hyperparameters to improve model performance, which includes real-time decision support and alert modules for instant notification, personalized guidance and facility navigation as well as synchronized storage which translates to quick local data access, and secure cloud-based epidemic surveillance. Experiment results prove that PO-ADMGNN achieves better performance with almost 98% classification precision, an F measure of 0.978 for the negative class, a $7.6 \times$ response time reduction (380 ms in the cloud vs. 50 ms in the fog), and a 54% latency reduction with an optimum peak accuracy of 0.9777. These results validate that PO-ADMGNN provides accurate, adaptive, and efficient healthcare monitoring with effective COVID-19 control.

title: Hybrid DL Models for Stock Market Analysis: A Comparative Survey of Feature Engineering, Ensemble Strategies, and Risk Metrics
authors: Ujjwal Mishra, Pankaj Chandre, Neeraj Saxena, Shruti Saxena
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: Recent volatility and data heterogeneity have renewed interest in hybrid deep-learning (DL) pipelines for stock forecasting. Unlike prior surveys that treat data preparation, modelling, and deployment in isolation, this work reviews the end-to-end architecture shown in the accompanying figure. The pipeline begins with real-time ingestion of market and alternative data streams via Kafka/Pulsar, funneling into a cloud time-series lake for loss-less archival and replay. A feature layer then merges technical indicators, macroeconomic parsers, and BERT -based sentiment embeddings inside a unified online/offline feature store. Within the modelling core, classical ARIMA / GARCH blocks are stacked with CNN patch encoders, temporal transformers, and graph neural networks, capturing local dynamics, long horizons, and inter-asset relations. An attention-based residual fusion module blends these heterogeneous encoders, while an XGBoost meta-learner arbitrates the final forecast, enhancing robustness to regime shifts. Forecasts feed an actor-critic reinforcement-learning policy that translates signals into order-routing decisions, closing the loop between prediction and execution. A rigorous back-tester computes Sharpe, max drawdown, and VaR under walk-forward splits, supplying a consistent yard-stick for the 25 state-of-the-art hybrids examined. Experiment tracking, CI/CD model registries, and ADWIN-based drift monitors anchor reproducibility and continuous delivery-capabilities rarely detailed in earlier reviews. The survey distils best practices at each stage and highlights open challenges for scalable, risk-sensitive deployment of hybrid DL forecasters across global markets.

title: Decentralized Payment Optimization for Scalable Microservice Transactions
authors: Vimal Teja Manne
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: To improve the efficiency of decentralized payment systems for microservices, this paper proposes the use of blockchain technology in order to allow for parties to transact with distrust and remove the need for central intermediaries. In order to do this, this paper proposes the use of automated smart contracts and scalable off chain technology to allow for efficient transactions and reduced computational resource costs. It is proposed by empirical testing to show that the system outlined in this paper will show significant increase in costs and processing latencies when compared to traditional centralized payment processing systems. As a result this paper will show that the system in this paper is a good alternative to traditional microservice based payments systems for real time market payments This research will allow increased scalability and security in the digital transaction environment.

title: AI-Enabled Visual Assistance with Integrated Reading for People with Total Blindness: A Review
authors: T Mohanraj, K Tharun Karthik, J Sriramakarthikeyan, K Vijay, R Vikram
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: AI visual aids and integrated reading assistants remain limited in accessibility and deployment for most blind people. Research on these topics is still fragmented across different data sets, tasks, and devices. Results for latency, energy, and longitudinal usability are also limited, with diverse measurement criteria. A complete end-to-end synthesis of the pipeline-capture, enhancement, layout analysis, recognition, semantics, and feedback, optimized for access, safety, and deployment -is systematically examined in this review. The study outlines open questions regarding multilingual scripts, curved or reflective text, and cluttered scenes. Functionalities are related to actual needs such as hands-free operation, offline service, ambiguity handling, and privacy protection. To enable fair comparison and reproducibility, evaluation practices are considered. Task-level metrics (time to first utterance, task success) and model-level metrics (precision-recall, character and word error rates) have been proposed. Clear guidelines for reporting datasets, protocols, error taxonomies, and user studies have also been provided. The review also links algorithmic efficiency techniques achieving low-latency, on-device operation to hardware constraints, e.g., NPUs, DSPs, thermal envelopes, and battery constraints. To understand the key issues and identify priority needs, this study presents shared definitions, minimum expectations, and practical checklists for researchers, clinicians, and developers by synthesising evidence across phones, wearables, and dedicated devices. The result is a framework and roadmap for sustainable and scalable reading support that describes what works, for whom, when, and why, with measurable benefits for real-world settings across countries.

title: Contextualizing AI Literacy: Developing a Competency Framework for K-12 Teachers in the Thai Education System
authors: Anucha Somabut, Parama Kwangmuang, Saksuriya Traiyarach
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: The rapid advancement of artificial intelligence technologies has fundamentally transformed educational landscapes worldwide, necessitating urgent adaptations in teacher preparation and professional development programs. This research addresses the critical gap between global AI literacy frameworks and the specific contextual needs of K-12 teachers within Thailand’s evolving educational ecosystem. Through a systematic mixed-methods approach involving comprehensive literature analysis, expert consultation using modified Delphi techniques, and rigorous validation processes, this study presents the first culturally-responsive and pedagogically-grounded AI literacy competency framework specifically designed for Thai K12 educators. The framework encompasses four core domains: Foundational Understanding, Pedagogical Application and Integration, Ethical and Critical Perspectives, and Professional Learning and Adaptation, each containing contextualized competencies that align with Thailand’s national education policies and cultural values. Validation through expert panels yielded high content validity indices, demonstrating the framework’s relevance and applicability within the Thai educational context. This research contributes significantly to the international discourse on localized AI education by providing a methodological blueprint for developing context-specific competency frameworks while offering practical guidance for policymakers, teacher education institutions, and educational administrators seeking to implement effective AI literacy programs in culturally diverse educational settings.

title: High-Gain Ultra-Wideband Monopole Antenna Enabled by Metasurface-Inspired Engineering
authors: A. S. I. Amar, Y. M. Madany
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Telecommunications and Artificial Intelligence (IC-FTAI)
abstract: This study presents a novel UWB antenna that features optimized radiations and incorporates a meta material-inspired design. The antenna utilizes a CPW-fed circular monopole paired with an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8\times 8$</tex> metasurface composed of low-profile metamaterial cells. Each cell has a square shape with four identical cross-shaped slots. Both the antenna and metasurface are organized on an FR4. The results indicate that the design effectively spans the desired range of 3.1-10.6 GHz, offering strong frequency response, high radiation efficiency, and satisfactory gain. This proposed UWB antenna design is highly suitable for UWB applications, fulfilling the specifications of contemporary wireless systems.

title: Comprehensive Deepfake Detection: A Comparative Study on Image and Video Forgery
authors: Aniket Bhoyar, Prakhar Shukla, Samir Watgule, Varun Kumar Thakur, Harsh Chakravarti, Gargi Charde
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: The growth of artificial intelligence technology has made it easy to produce very realistic synthetic media, which have posed great problems in the authentication of the authenticity of digital contents. Deepfake media, produced in the advanced form of generative algorithms, allows to play with the features of faces, voice, and appearances with the level of realism never seen before, which is causing alarm over the privacy invasion, breach of security, and the loss of trust in the population. This paper presents a detailed deep learning system that detects manipulated visual images in video and image formats using the pool of convolutional and recurrent neural networks. The detection system makes use of transfer learning methodology, with the use of InceptionV3 and Xception models to examine static images, and a ResNet50-LM hybrid structure to examine video images to acquire spatial features and temporal variations. The performance analysis of the Deepfake and the Real Images data set showed that Xception, InceptionV3, and the ResNet50-LSTM combination achieved a classification accuracy of 93.24, 92.19, and 91.5 respectively. These results highlight the relevance of the suggested architectures in distinguishing genuine content and counterfeit media. The study makes a contribution to the multimedia forensics field, as it offers a complex detection mechanism that can be used in social media content control, digital authentication, and cybersecurity software.

title: ZNS-RPS: A Read-Priority Scheduler for Mitigating I/O Interference in Zoned Namespace SSDs
authors: Ping Chen, Qian Zhang, Yukun Huang, Ping Xie
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: In modern storage systems, I/O interference under mixed read–write workloads poses a critical performance bottleneck. Zoned Namespace (ZNS) SSDs, constrained by sequential write requirements, deliver significantly lower write through-put than read throughput. Additionally, concurrent writes can severely interfere with read processing, leading to notable degradation in read performance. To address this challenge, we propose ZNS-RPS, a read-priority scheduling framework tailored for ZNS SSDs. The design strictly enforces sequential write ordering while separating reads and writes into dedicated queues, with higher priority assigned to reads to mitigate I/O interference in mixed workloads. Furthermore, ZNS-RPS integrates a queue-length-based adaptive scheduling mechanism (QLB-ASM), which dynamically adjusts read–write priorities based on write queue occupancy, thereby reducing read latency while preventing write starvation. Experimental results on the FEMU emulator show that ZNS-RPS achieves up to an 8× increase in read bandwidth and a 34% reduction in tail latency compared with conventional scheduling, demonstrating its effectiveness in enhancing read performance and overall Quality of Service under mixed workloads.

title: A Comparative Study of Bug Triage Classification Approaches from FastText to LLMs
authors: Erick Costa Bezerra, Victor da Silva Dantas, Paulo Henrique Barros Diniz, Diego Falcao de Souza
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Bug triage involves assigning newly reported bugs to the appropriate developers or teams for resolution. It is a critical aspect of software maintenance, directly influencing time and resource allocation, which impact the efficiency and effectiveness of the software process. Globally, the extensive number of teams and developers presents a challenge for bug triage. Traditional methods for assigning bugs often fail to address the complexity of the issue. This study conducts a comparative evaluation of various text classification methods for automated bug report triage in an industrial context, integrating large language models into the classification pipeline. FastText serves as the baseline when compared with large language enhanced models across accuracy metric. The findings suggest that integrating large language models into existing workflows could enhance triage accuracy for textual classification.

title: Robust Event-Driven Control with Fixed-Time Convergence for Group Consensus in Multi-Agent Systems over Directed Graphs
authors: Sanjoy Mondal, Madhumita Pal, Santosh Sonar, Abhisek Pal
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: The problem of robust group consensus in second-order multi-agent systems (MASs) that operate over directed communication graphs is discussed in this paper. To attain fixed-time (FxT) convergence, an event-driven control approach is created, which guarantees that all agents in each subgroup synchronise their states while preserving the required phase relationships between groups. Both intra-group coordination and inter-group phase coupling are captured by the complex-weighted interaction topology integrated into the suggested framework. The control protocol ensures fixed-time stability under non-linear agent dynamics and bounded external disturbances by building a distributed sliding manifold and an event-triggered (ET) updating rule. The multi-group consensus error’s FxT convergence is established using rigorous Lyapunov analysis. The suggested method considerably lowers communication load while maintaining robustness and convergence precision, according to theoretical results. The effectiveness and superiority of the developed event-driven FxT control scheme are illustrated through numerical simulations.

title: Progressive Fine-Tuning for Robust Multimodal Image Captioning
authors: Shuobo Wang, Shixu Yang, Yuteng Yang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Real-world image captioning presents unique challenges due to visual noise, domain shift, and contextual ambiguity in user-generated imagery. This paper introduces a progressive fine-tuning framework built upon the BLIP2–Flan–T5–XL architecture to enhance robustness and contextual understanding in assistive captioning tasks. The proposed method integrates three complementary components: parameter-efficient Low-Rank Adaptation for domain adaptation, multimodal data augmentation for cross-modal robustness, and Self-Critical Sequence Training for reward-driven optimization at the sequence level. Each stage is designed to incrementally refine the model’s visual–linguistic alignment while maintaining computational efficiency. Extensive experiments on the VizWiz-Captions dataset demonstrate consistent improvements across BLEU, CIDEr, METEOR, and SPICE metrics, validating the synergy between efficient adaptation, multimodal regularization, and reinforcement optimization. The framework establishes a strong foundation for scalable and human-aligned caption generation in real-world visual environments.

title: A Method for Predicting Typical Daily Load Curves of Distributed Photovoltaics Considering Weather Impacts
authors: Yuewei Qin, Linlang Guo, Jiahan Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Power System and Energy Internet (PoSEI)
abstract: Power load forecasting is one of the core tasks of power systems. With the large-scale integration of distributed photovoltaic (PV) power sources into the power grid, the complexity of grid load forecasting has significantly increased. Against the background of difficulties in collecting and aggregating output data of distributed PV power sources, this study adopts the following method: select the daily load curves of two specific days, calculate the difference between them to obtain a difference curve, and correct this curve to approximately simulate the typical daily output curve of distributed PV power sources. Empirical research shows that using this typical daily curve of distributed PV power sources to assist in grid load forecasting can effectively improve the accuracy of load forecasting.

title: Machine Learning Parameter Optimization in Virtual Desktops
authors: Ma Jun, Syazwina Alias
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Rapidly identifying key factors affecting virtual desktop performance is a core research problem for improving system performance. Traditional algorithms based on static first-in-first-out (FIFO) and dynamic regression-based algorithms have limited ability to discover and schedule influencing factors in complex scenarios. This paper utilizes a combination of machine learning’s random forest algorithm and cluster analysis to quickly find key influencing factors in high-load scenarios, enabling adaptive optimization. Cross-node experiments conducted on the RUBiS and Filebench benchmark platforms captured CPU, memory, I/O, and network performance indicators under different workloads, and applied adaptive optimization. Compared with traditional methods, the hybrid method of machine learning’s random forest and clustering reduced the average prediction error by approximately 40%. This method effectively solves the key factors affecting transient virtual desktops, providing a practical and easily interpretable solution for accurate dynamic optimization in virtual desktop environments.

title: Low Cost Water Filtration System: Working and Data Science Integration
authors: Mukund Kumar, Shakib Saif, Krish Sharma, Prashant Chaudhary, Supriya P. Panda
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: Access to safe drinking water remains a critical issue in developing countries despite its importance for human survival. In regions across the Philippines and India-particularly Odisha, Jharkhand, Chhattisgarh, Rajasthan, and the southern states-water scarcity has severe economic and social impacts. Saline groundwater, droughts, and poor infrastructure force reliance on contaminated sources. Similar challenges exist in Bangladesh, Indonesia, Kenya, and Ethiopia, where contamination and inadequate distribution systems worsen health and sanitation conditions. To address this, a Low-Cost Dispenser-Type Water Filtration System (LCDTWFS) was developed to provide clean water without electricity. The 10liter system, primarily made of natural clay, was tested over six weeks, and the filtered water met national and international quality standards, confirming its portability and safety. The LCDTWFS is affordable, eco-friendly, and locally manufacturable by rural artisans, supporting both community health and livelihoods. Integrating data science enables performance optimization, predictive maintenance, and real-time monitoring, enhancing efficiency and reliability. Overall, this study presents a sustainable, community-driven, and scalable solution to improve access to potable water, particularly in rural and coastal regions of developing nations.

title: Multi-Terminal Protection Method for Offshore Wind All-DC Series-Parallel Collection Network Based on Cumulative Deviation Area
authors: Yanxin Chen, Yineng Su, Zhiguo Hao, Ting Wang
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Smart Grid and Clean Energy Technologies (ICSGCE)
abstract: To address the protection challenges brought by large-scale integration of distant offshore wind power, this paper proposes a multi-terminal fault protection method based on Cumulative Deviation Area (CDA) for the series-parallel DC collection system in far-offshore wind power networks. First, the transient characteristics of wind turbine-to-bus and turbine-to-turbine collection lines under different fault types are analyzed. The monotonic variation patterns of positive and negative pole currents in the early fault stage are revealed. Then, based on the differences in current variation trends at the bus-side of each turbine group, CDA is used to characterize fault features, enabling fast fault section and line identification. Finally, simulation results show that the proposed protection scheme can accurately identify fault locations and types using a 1ms data window, demonstrating fast response and strong anti-interference capability. It is suitable for fully DC collection networks with multiple or weak boundary conditions, providing an effective technical support for building a highly reliable protection system for offshore wind power.

title: A Hybrid Transformer–RNN Framework with Mathematical Modeling for Sequential Context-Aware Text Summarization
authors: Mohammed Ali Shaik, Kunde Greeshma, Dhulipalla Hasini, Karim Pasha, Sreeramoju Harish, Sangem Sricharan
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: The major challenge that recommender systems are continually struggling with, is striking a balance between predictive and interpretable in sequential, context-sensitive situations. To solve this trade-off, this research suggests a hybrid model which uses a combination of Matrix Factorization (MF) and Neural Networks (NN). The model takes advantage of MF in capturing latent interactions between users and items and NN in capturing non-linear and contextual dependencies fused together through a mathematically defined feature integration pipeline. A Kaggle dataset of about 100,000 user-item interactions with numerical and categorical attributes is used in experiments with the help of Google Colab with Google-TPU acceleration. The hybrid model is assessed on criteria such as accuracy, F1-score, MAE and RMSE with an accuracy of 94.5, F1-score of 0.945, MAE of 0.087 and RMSE of 0.112, which are better than baseline models of MF and NN. The findings prove that the suggested hybrid architecture does not only increase the predictive performance but also offers explainable explanation to the recommendation decisions. The framework presents meaningful implication on the implementation of interpretable and high-performance recommender systems in actual practices to make more informed and context-aware decisions.

title: Interpretable Deep Learning for Early Detection of Diabetic Retinopathy using Lightweight Vision Transformers
authors: M. Aruna, Manas Ranjan Panda, Ranjeet Kumar, Karthik Mani, Subhan Baba Mohammed, Tejas Dhanorkar
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: An interpretable and computationally efficient deep learning framework for the early screening of Diabetic Retinopathy (DR) that exploits a Lightweight Vision Transformer (L ViT) has been proposed in this research. The model combines distillation and explanation consistency loss to balance accuracy, interpretability and efficiency. In addition, a teacher–student network framework is employed to distil semantic and spatial knowledge from a huge transformer to the small student model, which is beneficial for real time and edge applications. In addition, an explanation head incorporates attention rollout with gradient based saliency maps to enhance clinically significant retinal lesions (microaneurysms, hemorrhages, and exudates). Experiments on EyePACS, Messidor 2 and IDRiD datasets show that the proposed L ViT outperforms CNN and the existing ViT baselines with 95.6% accuracy and 0.982 AUC at a reduced computational cost. An interpretable and reliable diagnostic model, which is a stepping stone toward affordable AI based retinal screening in resource constrained environments has been developed.

title: COVID-19 Pandemic Detection and Prevention Using Gans and Their Variants: A Comprehensive Study on Techniques and Applications
authors: Sofia Singh, Dipti Theng, Urvashi Agrawal, Rahul Agrawal, Praveen Kumar Dhankar, Purushottam Shobhane
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: This paper provides a comprehensive review of Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) and their variants as methodologies for COVID-19 detection, diagnosis, and prevention. Existing deep learning approaches often fail when dealing with the complexity and scarcity of labelled, highdimensional clinical data. This review systematically analyzes how different GAN architectures-specifically Conditional GANs (cGANs), Cycle-Consistent GANs (CycleGANs), and Style-based GANs (StyleGANs)-have been applied to address these pandemic-related challenges. We evaluate their efficacy in three core areas: generating high-quality synthetic medical images (X-rays/CT) for data augmentation, creating molecular structures for accelerated drug discovery, and improving epidemiological prediction models. Furthermore, we explore optimization techniques like WGAN-GP used to stabilize training and enhance data fidelity. The paper concludes by detailing the strengths, limitations, and future research directions for GAN-based methodologies in infectious disease preparedness. Systematic Review: Analyze and compare the implementation and performance of major GAN variants (cGAN, CycleGAN, StyleGAN) across diverse healthcare applications.
