Problem-Solution Mapping: Detail how GANs directly solve critical data challenges, including scarcity, imbalance, and privacy in clinical and epidemiological datasets. Performance Benchmark: Review and synthesize reported performance metrics (e.g., FID, PSNR, diagnostic accuracy) to establish a benchmark for GAN-based COVID-19 solutions.

title: Automatic Examination of Fundus Images for Disease Detection: An Analysis with ResNet Model
authors: Gnanajeyaraman Rajaram
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Eye diseases are common particularly in aged individuals and the timely diagnosis and management is necessary to maintain the eye health. Untreated eye illness will lead to various health complications and hence, it is necessary for appropriate diagnosis with medical imaging methods. Fundus-imaging (FI) is a common approach in eye disease analysis and this work implemented a deeplearning (DL) scheme for detecting the normal and abnormal eye condition from FI-data. This work proposed ResNet-model based scheme and its performance is analysed with conventional-feature (CF) and fusedfeatures (FF) based classification with SoftMax. Various phrases in this scheme includes; FI-data collection and modifying its dimension, image enhancement based on CLAHE and extraction of deep-features with ResNetmodels, implementing SoftMax classification and identification of best model for generating FF, and classification and verification with 3 -fold cross validation. In this work 1000 FI-data is considered for the examination and ff-based detection achieved an accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>95 \%$</tex>.

title: A Secure and Transparent Cold Chain Shipment Monitoring System Leveraging IoT and Blockchain
authors: Abishek S, Anirudh B Varma, Arnav Purohit, Sidarth M, Rolant Gini J
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: The integrity of temperature-sensitive goods during transportation remains a critical challenge in modern cold-chain management. Variations in temperature and humidity can compromise product quality, particularly in pharmaceuticals, vaccines, and perishable goods. This paper presents a secure and transparent cold chain monitoring system that integrates Internet of Things (IoT) and blockchain technologies. The proposed system employs a master–slave network architecture, where Arduino-based slave nodes collect environmental data and a Raspberry Pi-based master node aggregates and transmits it to the blockchain server via GSM communication. Hyperledger Fabric is used to ensure secure, immutable, and auditable record keeping, while a web-based interface allows warehouses and logistics providers to initiate, monitor, and approve shipments collaboratively. Implementation results indicate enhanced reliability and transparency in monitoring cold chain shipping conditions. Data sampling occurs every 5 seconds at the slave nodes, with an average data rate of 21 bps between master and slave. Experimental results show a blockchain upload latency of 2.394 seconds for a 1000-byte payload, approximately 50 times faster than Filecoin, supporting high-frequency, synchronous data updates, significantly reducing the risk of data congestion. This solution addresses the need for reliable and transparent documentation of environmental conditions during transport in the industry.

title: Electricity Distribution Resilience Improvement to Severe Events through Energy Storage
authors: Shaila Arif, Eric Sauvage, Kevin I-Kai Wang, Nirmal-Kumar C. Nair
publish: 2025 IEEE PES 17th Asia-Pacific Power and Energy Engineering Conference (APPEEC)
abstract: In order to increase the resilience of the power system and avoid cascading effects in the aftermath of severe events, it is necessary to plan network operations through multiple separate islanded network configurations like microgrids (MGs), each operating independently. However, the implementation of a MG in purposeful islanding comes with its requirements and may give rise to additional concerns that must be addressed. This study employs N-2 contingency analysis to identify the vulnerable lines to be severed for partitioning and to determine the most effective approach for isolating the power system. To mitigate the challenges of islanding and post-islanded difficulties, a battery energy storage system (BESS) is utilized. The IEEE 43 bus distribution network serves as a test system. The results indicate that N-2 analysis not only provides insight into the lines that should be severed for islanding but also identifies potential buses for BESS installation.

title: Real-Time Flood Monitoring and Resource Allocation Using AI-Driven UAVs in Disaster-Prone Areas
authors: Ravi Kumar. M, ParimalkumarMukeshbhai Chaudhary, Madhura Raghava Reddy, G Madhumathi, Sneh Gangwar, Deepthi Rani S S
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: In flood-prone areas of India, traditional disaster management approaches that rely on human surveys, satellite images, and ground assessments to provide decision makers with basic real-time information frequently lag and need a lot of resources. Delays in evaluating the damage, identifying survivors, and allocating resources lead to an increase in the death toll and a decline in effectiveness. To address these issues, suggest a drone-based artificial intelligence (AI) system that combines AI-powered computer vision with unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) for quick flood assessment, survivor location, and resource allocation optimization. For instance, the proposed system reduces the amount of obtaining data to 5 minutes, damage assessment to 10 minutes, survivor recognition to 8 minutes, and resource allocation to 6 minutes, allowing for extensive analysis. By managing resources for disaster response, which will ultimately help save lives and resources, and by analyzing images of the disaster with greater accuracy (95% for damage assessment, 92% for survivor recognition), the proposed system speeds up, improves, and reduces the cost of decision-making.

title: TransStar-DehazeNet: A Global-Local Hybrid Network with Multi-Input Star Fusion for Image Dehazing
authors: Ziqiang Huang, Wei Liu, Miao Qi, Hangyu Nie
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotic Systems and Applications (ICRSA)
abstract: Image dehazing is a critical task for enhancing the robustness and perceptual quality of vision systems, particularly in applications such as intelligent maritime navigation and autonomous driving. Existing single-image dehazing methods often struggle to achieve a satisfactory balance between global context modeling and local detail restoration. CNN-based approaches are inherently limited by their local receptive fields, whereas pure Transformer models are computationally expensive and insufficiently sensitive to fine-grained features. To address these challenges, we propose TransStar, a novel network architecture that integrates global-local information modeling with a multi-input degradation-aware mechanism. At the heart of TransStar is the TransXBlock, which adaptively models global context and local details in parallel, enabling a balanced representation of global semantics and local textures. Furthermore, the use of multi-scale downsampled degraded images as auxiliary inputs allows the model to better handle non-uniform haze and varying degrees of blur. In addition, the Star operation is employed to perform high-dimensional nonlinear feature mapping, enhancing the model's ability to capture richer detail information with minimal computational overhead. Extensive experiments on both synthetic and real-world hazy images demonstrate that TransStar consistently outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods in both quantitative metrics and visual quality.

title: GPU-Accelerated Deep 3D CNNs for Modeling Memory-Related Brain Activity Using Multi-Voxel Pattern Analysis on fMRI Data
authors: Shubham Kumar Singh, Dharanya T, Aarthi N, Nagadevi S
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Understanding how the human brain encodes and retrieves information is a central challenge in cognitive neuroscience. This study presents a high-performance computational framework for classifying memory-related brain activity using functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) data and deep learning techniques. We utilized the publicly available ds000228 dataset, which includes 4D fMRI recordings of subjects engaged in movie-watching tasks known to stimulate cognitive processing. Multi-Voxel Pattern Analysis (MVPA) was applied using NiftiMasker to extract time-resolved voxel activity patterns, providing input features for classification. A custom 3D Convolutional Neural Network (3D-CNN) was developed to process spatial brain volumes per timepoint, enabling subjectwise classification based on observed neural activity. The model architecture includes five convolutional layers, batch normalization, adaptive pooling, and a fully connected softmax output layer. Performance was benchmarked on both CPU (ARM 10-core) and GPU (Tesla P100), demonstrating a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 33 \times$</tex> speedup on GPU with classification accuracy exceeding 99.9% within 10 epochs. This work highlights the feasibility of GPUaccelerated deep learning for analyzing high-dimensional neuroimaging data and provides a scalable pipeline for cognitive state decoding. The proposed approach holds promise for applications in brain-computer interfaces, memory disorder diagnostics, and large-scale neuroinformatics benchmarking.

title: Multi-Level Wavelet Shrinkage Network for Magnetic Anomaly Detection
authors: Lili Zeng, Zhihang Zhang, Lijun Miao, Jianhua Yang, Dapeng Han, Youxing Liao, Dengwei Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Measurement Control and Instrumentation (MCAI)
abstract: This article proposes a multi-level wavelet shrinkage network to enhance the detection performance of magnetic anomaly signals under high-noise conditions. The foundational architecture employs a multi-level wavelet network, integrating the time-frequency analysis capabilities of wavelet transform with the feature extraction strengths of neural networks. Furthermore, we introduce an adaptive soft-thresholding shrinkage module (ASTSM), which innovatively combines the convolutional block attention module (CBAM) with soft-thresholding denoising theory to eliminate insignificant features and enhance network robustness against noise. Experimental results show that the detection performance of the proposed network has better detection performance than some existing methods at low signal-to-noise ratios.

title: Hybrid VGG19-ResNet50 Network for Brain Tumor Classification using Feature Fusion and Imbalance-Aware Learning
authors: SivaKumar Depuru, Suvarna Yashaswini, Dudekula Pedda Madarsa, R Neeradh Kumar Reddy, P C Jaswanth, K. Amala
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: The precise brain tumors classification in the area of medical imaging is a task of great concern because of the variability of the descriptions of the subtypes of tumors and the imbalance of the classes of tumors describing datasets. In this research paper, the authors propose a new hybrid network that combines the potential of two effective deep convolutional networks, which are VGG19 and ResNet500, based on a sophisticated integration of features. Any of the proposed architectures combine the hierarchical capabilities of feature extractions of the VGG19 and the residual learning process of ResNet50 to deliver a more discriminative and generalized description of tumor features. Further, to boost the clinical reliability of the classifier, apply medicine techniques, mitigate the problem of class imbalances by implementing focal loss and the methods of artificial analyzing based on synthetic data augmentation by the SMOTE and GAN methods. Wide-ranging testing on benchmark medical imaging datasets attests to massive boosts in both accuracy of classification, a sensitivity, and an F1-score, especially in classes of minorities of tumors. The findings indicate that the hybrid VGG19-ResNet50 architecture and novel fusion and imbalance-aware learning have the potential to provide the robust and clinically feasible method of tumor classification in real-life diagnostic conditions.

title: Development of a Predictive Maintenance System for Stand-Alone Photovoltaic Systems in Indonesia’s Seismic Monitoring Stations Using Simulated Data and Machine Learning
authors: Agha Muhammad Ahya, Ramon Zamora, Avy Sheina
publish: 2025 IEEE PES 17th Asia-Pacific Power and Energy Engineering Conference (APPEEC)
abstract: Indonesia's seismic monitoring stations mostly depend on stand-alone photovoltaic (SAPV) systems for power sources, as they are situated in rural locations and far from the grid. However, the reliability of these stations is often compromised due to power interruptions caused by the degradation of solar panels and batteries. This research proposes the development of a predictive maintenance system using machine learning models to forecast the remaining useful life (RUL) of solar panels and the State of Health (SoH) of batteries. MATLAB/Simulink created synthetic datasets simulating PV degradation at a rate of 1.6% annually and battery discharge behavior over a range of SoH values. Three machine learning algorithms, namely, Random Forest, XGBoost, and LightGBM, were trained and assessed. With R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> values of 0.9612 for PV RUL and 0.9662 for battery SoH, Random Forest consistently exceeded the other algorithms. The study shows that, given simulated data, machine learning models can efficiently learn degradation patterns, therefore providing a workable alternative in situations when actual operating data is limited. Combining simulation-based data with data-driven modeling presents an alternative way to improve system reliability and enable proactive maintenance plans in distant infrastructure applications.

title: Human-Robot Interaction-Integrated Code Review Interface for Collaborative Development
authors: Sharmila Zope, Aashish A. Gadgil, Avishek Bhattacharjee, T. Manjula, Lakshmi Narasimhan Srinivasagopalan, L. Karthick
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Human-Robot Interaction (HRI) has become a potent paradigm to enhance collaborative software development environments through the incorporation of intelligent support systems. This study presents a HumanRobot Interaction-Integrated Code Review Interface that is aimed at improving team-based development processes. The system uses Natural Language Processing (NLP) as the main tool to process developer feedback and suggestions, and uses PyTorch as the tool to implement deep learning-based models to analyze semantic code. The interface enables a robotic assistant to give contextsensitive review comments, point out possible problems, and support interactive conversations between developers. The proposed system will promote better accuracy, efficiency, and inclusivity in the code review processes by integrating automation with human insights. The experimental findings show that there are considerable enhancements in error detection and knowledge sharing, which highlights the potential of HRI-based solutions in contemporary software engineering.

title: Machine Learning-Driven System for Kannada-to-English Text Translation
authors: Sachhidanand Sidramappa, Mallamma V. Reddy, Shilpa K
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: In this paper, the author introduces a Machine Learning-based Kannada-to-English Text Translation System that uses the state-of-the-art multilingual Transformer architecture called IndicTrans2. PEFT (Kannada-English translation with PEFT) fine-tunes the system to minimize the computational expenses and achieve high accuracy. One technique is to use backtranslation to produce artificial parallel data, which overcomes the problem of scarce resources in lowresource languages such as Kannada. The workflow is given a morphology-aware post-editor that tackles the morphological problems specific to Kannada to increase grammatical correctness and fluency. The system is written in the Hugging Face ecosystem, where Transformers, Datasets, PEFT, and Evaluate on PyTorch help to make it easy to develop, train, and evaluate. The findings demonstrate that the quality of these translations was significantly improved over those of the current approaches, offering a viable solution to the real-time Kannada-to-English machine translation problems, and that it could be used in multilingual settings or in digital content accessibility.

title: Low-Cost Mini Automated Guided Vehicle (AGV) with AI-Powered Multicolor Line Tracking and Slot Detection for Industrial Automation
authors: Praveen. E, Darshan Prabhukumar, S. Revathy, S. Abishek, A. Saleth Kavin
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Automated guided vehicles (AGVs) are an essential part of the modern industrial automation process and help move in autonomously navigated material transportation. Nevertheless, commercial AGV systems are too expensive and not very flexible, even when considering small and middle-sized enterprises. This research paper designs a cost-effective, mini miniaturized AGV with artificial intelligence (AI)-based multicolor line tracking and real-time slot detection to fill the affordability-performance gap. The robot uses an ESP32 microcontroller, L298N motor driver, ultrasonic and IR sensors and OV7670 vision modules installed on a lightweight 3D-printed chassis. The bottom point camera reads the multicolored routes with the OpenCV program using the HSV segmentation, which makes it applicable to adjust to various industrial paths. The optimal values of slot occupancy are computed as the prediction output of a lightweight model YOLOv5 processed through TensorRT, providing the average success detection of 94.9% and F1-scores of 95.0. Line tracking precision was 1.49 cm-average deviation across paths of many colors, and obstacle avoidance was 100% hit-rate at less than 2.3% distance estimation error. Inference speed with quantized weights was decreased to the ~75ms range, allowing FPS of 13+ on Raspberry Pi hardware. Power tests run time of more than 2.4 hours under full load. The proposed AGV architecture shows high accuracy, speed of inference, and adaptability in different environments at a low cost design footprint. This allows providing a simple, scalable approach to decentralized automation, typically in small factories, educational labs and warehouses. Future research will focus on collaboration between swarms of vehicles, dynamic path-re-routing, and integration with IIoT -based fleet orchestration and predictive maintenance analytics.

title: Artificial Neural Network-Based Prediction of Total Project Cost of Residential Dwellings in Quezon City, Philippines Utilizing Engineering Building Parameters and Site Location Using Python
authors: Robert Kristoper R. Gina, Dante L. Silva
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: This study develops an Artificial Neural Network (ANN)-based prediction model to estimate the total project cost (TPC) of residential dwellings in Quezon City, the largest local government unit in Metro Manila characterized by rapid residential growth and increasing land values. Recognizing the limitations of traditional cost estimation methods that often overlook indirect costs such as land acquisition, the model integrates both engineering building parameters and locational attributes using actual project data from 2016 to 2025. Categorical inputs include district location and type of finishes, while numerical variables encompass building dimensions, soil bearing capacity, and distances to essential amenities. The ANN model was built and trained using Python, employing Min-Max Normalization, a hyperbolic tangent activation function, and RMSPROP optimizer. Model performance was evaluated using MAE and MSE metrics and applied for forecasting to support early-stage planning and risk mitigation. The model addresses the persistent challenge of underestimations in project feasibility by offering a more comprehensive and localized approach to cost prediction. Though effective, the model does not account for sudden economic shifts or policy changes, which may influence future construction costs. This research offers significant value to stakeholders, including developers, engineers, government agencies, and researchers, by enhancing cost accuracy, transparency, and planning reliability in the residential construction sector of Quezon City.

title: A Real-Time Integrated Cafeteria Management System for Enhanced Operational Efficiency
authors: Ayush Nagras, Vaibhav Tajane, Govind Suryawanshi, Vedant Tarate, Shilpa Rudrawar, Rashmi Mahajan
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Conventional cafeteria and mess management systems in institutional settings are often plagued by inefficiencies such as long queues, food wastage, lack of real- time information, and manual operational processes. This paper presents the design and implementation of a comprehensive, web-based Cafeteria Operations Management System that integrates real-time data to address these challenges. The proposed system features modules for pre- booking of meals and seats, dynamic menu management, live occupancy tracking, an automated feedback mechanism, AIdriven demand forecasting, and a hardware-based waiter call system. Built on a full-stack architecture utilizing Node.js, Express.js, MongoDB, and WebSockets, the system ensures seamless data synchronization and a responsive user experience. The implementation demonstrates significant potential to reduce waiting times, optimize inventory, minimize food waste, and improve overall user satisfaction, presenting a modernized solution for institutional cafeteria management.

title: MindSync: An Intelligent Journaling Tool for Mental Well-being and Productivity Analysis
authors: P M Srinivas, Prashantha, Aditya Bhagwat, Dhanush Naik, Kumar Marathe
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Computing, Semiconductor, Mechatronics, Intelligent Systems and Communications (COSMIC)
abstract: MindSync stands out as a smart journaling platform. It uses Natural Language Processing to help boost mental well-being in everyday ways. Our approach relies on advanced machine learning models that dig into daily journal entries. These models handle emotion detection for things like stress or anxiety. They also cover sentiment analysis and productivity checks all in one go. The system provides feedback that feels personal. It includes easy visualizations drawn from behavioral trends we spot. The results demonstrate solid model performance from the models along with good usability overall. This makes MindSync a useful tool in digital mental health. It connects emotional insights directly to productivity patterns.

title: Offline Signature Verification with Auto Encoder CNN Hybrid Feature Extraction for Improved Fake Signature Detection
authors: T Harinadh, G Srinivasa Rao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Signature verification is also one of the most popular forms of biometric authentication, particularly when there is offline authentication, e.g. cheques, forms, letters and official documents. Accurate verification is essential since the signature of each person is unique, and this can help stop fraud. Nonetheless, the loss of human verification is usually susceptible to mistakes and irregularity. A hybrid solution to the offline signature verification through Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) that integrates with Autoencoder-based data augmentation to enhance the detection of fake signatures is presented in this paper. A Writer-Dependent model is applied in which random distortions are produced on authentic signatures with the help of an autoencoder to produce counterfeit signatures. The CNN classifier is then trained using them. The paper describes the pre-processing procedures applied to the signature images, and gives experimental results under different conditions of varying the number of training samples. In the Persian signature dataset, the model was trained on 22 genuine images per user and its average test accuracy was 83%. At the lower reduction in the number of real training samples (9), accuracy was decreased by 9.4 percent, which indicates that the amount of training data does affect verification performance.

title: Machine Learning Based Identification of Key Features for Misarticulation Quantification
authors: Anushri Pratik Ghadge, S.P. Mahajan
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Speech Sound Disorder (SSD) affects the quality of communication. Misarticulation refers to the production of correct speech sounds. In individuals with motor speech disorder, precise assessment of misarticulation is critical for early diagnosis and effective intervention. Traditional evaluation methods depend heavily on subjective auditoryperceptual judgement, which lacks consistency and scalability. In this paper, a data-driven approach to identify and classify the most influential acoustic features for the quantification of misarticulation using the UASpeech Dysarthric Speech Database is discussed. A complete set of audio features including Mel-frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCCs), spectral and prosodic features was extracted from the speech samples. Machine learning models such as LightGBM, KNearest Neighbor (KNN), Decision Tree (DT) and Random Forest Classifier (RF) were employed to predict misarticulation severity with the help of classification metrics such as Precision, Recall, F1-Score and Unweighted Average Recall (UAR). SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanation) values were used for model interpretation and feature ranking, enabling transparent identification of the most influential features. Experimental results reveal the MFCC-13 among the top ranked features contributing significantly to the quantification of misarticulation. The proposed framework enhances the objectivity of speech disorder assessment and provides interpretable insights into the acoustic correlates of misarticulated speech, supporting the development of clinical tools for automatic evaluation of speech disorder.

title: DDoS Protection System for Cloud: Architecture and Tool
authors: Poornima P, Divya R, Shwetha B, Sharmasth Vali Y
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: A Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attack is a coordinated attempt to exhaust computing or network resources by overwhelming a target with massive amounts of malicious traffic. Such attacks have become a major threat cloud computing, where scalability and resource sharing expose services to large-scale disruptions. DDoS incidents can severely degrade performance, limit availability, and cause significant economic and operational losses for cloud providers and users. Traditional defense mechanisms, including filtering and anomaly-based detection, struggle to address the dynamic and high-volume nature of cloud traffic, often resulting in delayed detection or high false positive rates. To address these challenges, this work proposes an architecture and tool for DDoS protection in cloud environments. The system simulates botnet-driven traffic to create realistic attack scenarios and employs machine learning models to detect anomalies and mitigate attacks in real time. The proposed framework integrates traffic monitoring, classification, and automated response modules, ensuring improved resilience and reduced downtime during large-scale attacks. Experimental evaluation demonstrates that the approach can detect high-volume DDoS activity with improved accuracy and minimal false positives. This study contributes a practical and scalable framework that combines attack simulation and adaptive defense mechanisms to enhance the security of cloud infrastructures.

title: YOLOv8-Driven Multi-Task Vision Framework for Obstacle Avoidance and Path Guidance in Smart Glasses
authors: V. Saroja, A. Muthukumaravel
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: The paper proposes a deep reinforcement learning-based method of real-time analysis and optimization of athlete motion patterns across gymnastics and athletic field activities. The presented architecture combines various streams of sensory data, like a camera, IMU, and GPS allowing them to detect obstacles, plan the path, and present AR path navigation on top of it. Having harnessed an appropriately optimized YOLOv8 backbone, the framework balances the levels of high accuracy in detection and a low level of computational latency that renders the framework suited to implementation on an edge-based wearable platform. Pose estimation and path acing modules are used to achieve precise tracking of the movement with an augmented reality (AR) overlay used to give users feedback on how to correct the movement in time. The suggested system shows an experimental outcome of detection accuracy of 96.4 % and an average response of feedback latency of 210 ms which makes its performance close to instant analysis of the performance. Ablation studies indicate the relevant and proliferative roles of the path guidance and AR components cases in enhancing accuracy and speed of reaction. The framework will provide an effective, flexible solution for the monitoring of the performances, coaching assistance, and injury prevention in competitive sport and fill the gap between the success of data-driven knowledge and the training on the field.

title: Multimodal Monocular 3D Object Localization for Human-Robot Interaction
authors: Ari Wahl, Dorian Gawlinski, David Przewozny, Paul Chojecki, Felix Bieβmann, Sebastian Bosse
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: Pre-trained general-purpose Vision-Language Models (VLM) hold the potential to enhance intuitive human-machine interactions due to their rich world knowledge and 2D object detection capabilities [1]. However, VLMs for 3D coordinates detection tasks are rare. In this work, we investigate interactive abilities of VLMs by returning 3D object positions given a monocular RGB image from a wrist-mounted camera, natural language input, and robot states. We collected and curated a heterogeneous dataset of more than 100,000 images and finetuned a VLM using QLoRA with a custom regression head. By implementing conditional routing, our model maintains its ability to process general visual queries while adding specialized 3D position estimation capabilities. Our results demonstrate robust predictive performance with a median MAE of 13 mm on the test set and a five-fold improvement over a simpler baseline without finetuning. In about 25% of the cases, predictions are within a range considered acceptable for the robot to interact with objects.

title: Dyslexia Screening System for Children Using Parental Questionnaire and Eye Tracking with WebGazer and Kolmogorov-Arnold Network
authors: Mukund Dhenge, Yashasvi Yede, Lucky Nimbarte, Dewanshu Katre, Sampada Wazalwar
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Dyslexia is a prevalent learning disorder that impairs reading fluency and comprehension, often remaining undetected during the critical years of a child's education. Early screening is essential to initiate timely support and reduce long-term academic difficulties, yet conventional diagnostic approaches are costly, language-specific, and dependent on expert evaluation. This paper presents a full-stack web-based dyslexia screening system designed for children aged 8-12 years. The platform provides two independent assessments- a parental screener test comprising ten diagnostic questions and a child eye-tracking test that uses WebGazer.js with a standard webcam to capture fixation patterns, regression frequency, and reading speed. Each test produces its own outcome, while an integrated dashboard consolidates the findings by displaying the detected indicators, the number of completed tests, and the average confidence of dyslexia risk. The backend employs a Kolmogorov-Arnold Network (KAN) model to analyze eye-tracking metrics, with performance validated against the publicly available Zenodo eye-tracking dataset. The system further offers automated report generation and doctor recommendations based on location to guide next steps. By combining accessibility, scalability, and interpretability, the proposed system provides a practical tool for early dyslexia screening in both school and home environments.

title: LAP-IIoT: A Latency-Aware Prediction Approach for Enhancing Industrial IoT Performance
authors: Ramya Gopalakrishnan, Abinaya Gopalakrishnan, Preethiya T, Anousouya Devi M
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: The Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) demands real -time and dynamic data processing to support and enhance predictive maintenance and process automation. Maintaining very low latency in such critical situations becomes significant and challenging because of dynamic network environment and imbalance load. To address this, this work proposes a Latency Aware Prediction for IIoT (LAP - IIoT) a framework that leverages Long - Term Short Memory (LSTM), a Machine Learning (ML) model to predict network latency to optimize the performances of the network as well as fog-edge task offloading in real- time scenarios. The proposed methodology LAP -IIoT leverages real-time network parameters to predict network latency. The obtained results demonstrate that this ML-driven approach effectively identifies 'warning' and 'failure' states. By anticipating both performance deprivation and identification of states, this proposed model allows for intelligent fog- edge task offloading in IIoT systems.

title: Virtual Reality-Based Learning Systems in Vocational Education and Training: A Systematic and Bibliometric Review Toward Future-Oriented Learning Environments
authors: Roudlotus Sholikhah, Mochamad Bruri Triyono, Sukarno, Sudiyono
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: The accelerating digital transformation of education highlights the need for smart and immersive technologies to prepare vocational learners for Industry 4.0. Virtual Reality (VR) has gained recognition as a powerful tool in Vocational Education and Training (VET); however, existing research remains fragmented on how VR-based learning systems are conceptualized and developed to support future-oriented learning environments. This study aims to systematically examine the trends, patterns, and thematic focuses of VR-based learning systems in VET, as well as how these systems are evolving towards an intelligent and adaptive learning framework. A Systematic Literature Review (SLR) and bibliometric analysis were conducted on 43 peerreviewed articles published between 2020 and 2024, retrieved from the Scopus and Web of Science databases. The review followed the PRISMA protocol and used the PICOS framework for inclusion criteria. VOSviewer and Bibliometric supported data analysis. The results identified three main research themes: simulation-based technical training, virtual laboratories, and learner-centered immersive environments. The recent shift towards intelligent VR systems-integrating AI adaptability, realtime feedback, biometric sensing, and personalized pathways demonstrates its alignment with the needs of the future workforce. In conclusion, VR in VET is evolving into an adaptive and intelligent infrastructure for competency-based learning, making it future-ready. In the future, research is expected to include the implementation of VR in project-based pedagogy and incorporate interdisciplinary innovations to lead to sustainable and scalable integration.

title: A Parallel Convolutional Neural Network Approach for Classifying Malang Batik Motifs with Image Augmentation Techniques
authors: Mamluatul Hani’Ah, Rendy Septian Pradana, Muhammad Afif Hendrawan, Vivi Nur Wijayaningrum, Vit Zuraida, Moch. Zawaruddin Abdullah, Mungki Astiningrum
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Technological Solutions (ICAITech)
abstract: Batik, a traditional textile art recognized by UNESCO as an Intangible Cultural Heritage, holds profound cultural and aesthetic values across Indonesia. To support cultural preservation through digital recognition, this study proposes a classification approach for Malang batik motifs using a parallel Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) architecture. A dataset of 622 images across 31 motif classes was collected directly from three Malang batik production centers and enriched using various augmentation techniques to overcome data scarcity. The proposed model employs two parallel convolutional branches with different kernel sizes to capture multi-scale visual features, followed by concatenation, global average pooling, and fully connected layers for final classification. Model training was performed using a $\mathbf{5}$-fold cross-validation scheme with the Adam optimizer and ELU activation function. The proposed parallel CNN architecture was designed to extract richer and more diverse feature representations, improving classification accuracy compared to conventional sequential CNN models. Experimental results demonstrated that augmentation significantly influenced performance, where geometric transformations such as rotation achieved stable accuracy above 90%. The highest performance was obtained using a combination of all augmentations, achieving 99.59% accuracy, 99.60% precision, 99.50% recall, and 99.50% F-measure. However, this improvement came with higher computational costs, as runtime and memory consumption were substantially increased compared to simpler augmentation strategies. These findings highlight a clear trade-off between accuracy and computational efficiency. Overall, the proposed method demonstrates the potential of parallel CNNs and augmentation in enhancing batik motif recognition.

title: Determinants of Extended Reality (XR) Adoption in Architecture and Urban Design Education
authors: Kholoud Mahrous, Israa M. ElMagraby, Menna Shouman, Elhassan Elsabry
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Telecommunications and Artificial Intelligence (IC-FTAI)
abstract: Extended Reality (XR) encompassing virtual, augmented, and mixed reality holds significant promise for transforming architectural and urban design education by enabling immersive visualization, real-time feedback, and collaborative, student-centered learning. However, adoption within higher education lags behind industry. This study looks at the factors that affect XR adoption at Nile University through a UTAUT based survey that targeted second to fifth years students. Comparisons of students with XR experience and those without show significant, medium-to-large differences in Experience, Performance Expectancy, Effort Expectancy, Social Influence, and Facilitating Conditions. Those with prior exposure reported greater perceived usefulness, ease of use, social support, and resource readiness. Five main barriers were identified through qualitative analysis: limited training and awareness, infrastructure limitations, high costs, and challenges in curriculum integration. This paper suggests targeted pilots, faculty training, shared XR labs, and structured curriculum modules to support a broader adoption of XR in design programs.

title: Enhancing IoT Healthcare Security Through Machine Learning and Game-Theoretic Anomaly Detection
authors: K Thinakaran
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) has transformed healthcare with wearable devices, data collection and analytics as well the continuous monitoring of patients. However, when applied to IoT-based healthcare systems, such advancements can be dangerous, especially in devices with limited power capacity. In order to make the system more stable and better at detecting threats, this project aims to build a healthcare IoT platform that is secure and uses deep learning and machine learning. The initial layer of the suggested two-layer security system provides the sink and source nodes with two-way mutual authentication. Layer 2 contains a lightweight intrusion detection system (G-IDS) that can detect both RPL and conventional network threats using a game-theoretic methodology. This approach compares itself to state-of-the-art ML and DL models like CNN, LSTM, and hybrid DNNs by combining data collection with modeling of IoT architecture. Results from experiments show that the proposed G-IDS achieves better performance than IDS models based on deep learning. These models usually achieve 92.4% accuracy, 96.8% detection accuracy, 94.3% precision, 95.6% recall, and an F1-score of 0.95. There is a 21% reduction in energy consumption and a 3.2% decrease in the false-positive rate when compared to conventional ML algorithms. The proposed approach also successfully detects attacks that are unique to RPL, such as Rank, Version Number, and Hello Flood. Based on its guarantees of robust protection, low computing cost, and high detection accuracy, the study concludes that the two-layer IoT healthcare security framework is ideal for healthcare IoT environments with limited resources and for fostering safe digital healthcare transition.

title: Unveiling Sentiments in Movie Reviews: A Comparative Study of Computational Approaches for Sentiment Analysis
authors: Rupesh Sai Ram Kotha, Raghu Ram Sai Lingutla, Sarin Kumar Sathunuri, Mohana Gopala Krishna Reddy Nalamalapu, M. Srinivas
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Computing, Semiconductor, Mechatronics, Intelligent Systems and Communications (COSMIC)
abstract: In today’s digital age, where opinions are readily shared and accessible, understanding public sentiment through movie reviews has become increasingly important. Three computational methods-Machine Learning (ML), Deep Learning (DL), and Probabilistic Graphical Models (PGMs)-have been the primary basis for this research, which focuses on sentiment classification. For this research, we consider both traditional ML algorithms and a hybrid deep learning approach with Bayesian Networks (BNs) due to their explanatory power. With the IMDb dataset, the DL model achieved the best performance of 88%, closely followed by the traditional ML methods at 87%. The PGM model, however, considerably lagged at $\mathbf{5 2} \boldsymbol{\%}$ accuracy. These findings illustrate an existing performance-interpretability tradeoff which contributes to model selection for real-world applications in SA.

title: Intrusion Detection Systems for Unmanned Aerial Vehicles: A Comparative Analysis of Machine Learning Approaches
authors: Neha Rani, Mayank Dave, Amisha Yadav, Ishpreet Kaur, Piryanka Chahar
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial vehicles (UAVs) are increasingly being used in various fields like agriculture, military, construction surveys and other surveillance purposes, etc. Due to increasing dependency, UAVs have become more prone to various types of cyber attacks. This increasing dependence on UAVs has significantly increased the probability of cyber attacks. Although ML algorithms have enabled the development of intrusion detection systems (IDSs), modren IDSs do not work effectively to identify an attack. Several different ML techniques are studied in this work to compare the IDS detection capabilities of different models on the basis of which the probability of an attack is determined. Different ML/ DL based IDSs are analyzed that are trained to detect cyber attacks using seven models by using a publicly available dataset that includes different types of cyber and physical features related to UAVs. Models are developed for both binary and multiclass classification to identify attacks, and performance of different models are compared to find accuracy of detecting an attack. The work done in this paper will help in studying and determining the best model for predicting attacks on a UAV system based on different cyber and physical features.

title: Crypto-Agile Zero-Trust Access for Multi-Cloud via SDN, with PQC-QKD Key Orchestration
authors: Venkatesh H, Sashikanth Reddy Avula
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: Cloud infrastructures moving toward post-quantum cryptography present both opportunities and risks since safe workload interoperability is made more difficult by disparate providers' uneven key management. In this study, a crypto-agile zero-trust access architecture for multi-cloud environments is presented, utilizing software-defined networking (SDN) to coordinate quantum key distribution (QKD) and post-quantum cryptography (PQC) for session security. The architecture incorporates a policy-driven controller that uses programmable data planes for micro-segmentation and continuous verification to dynamically choose ML-KEM or QKD-derived keys for each transaction. The system includes automated failover between PQC and QKD to guarantee resilience, preserving secure connectivity in the event of link failure or resource exhaustion. QKD-PQC failover under adversarial stress, flow-level path enforcement via P4, and TLS 1.3 handshakes with PQC are all demonstrated using a simulation prototype. The results demonstrate that SDN-based orchestration can maintain performance and uphold zero-trust principles, while also highlighting the viability of quantifying PQC overhead in real-time cloud scenarios. This establishes the framework as a workable route to multi-cloud security that is quantum robust.

title: Integrating AI in Social Cognitive Theory-Based Character Modeling: A Comparative Study of Behavioral Influence in Hans Christian Andersen's Fairy Tales and Disney Cartoons
authors: P. Vijayalakshmi, R. Rajakumari
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: This study presents an innovative AI -assisted framework that integrates Bandura's Social Cognitive Theory (SCT) to analyze and compare character modeling and behavioral influence in Hans Christian Andersen's fairy tales and their Disney animated adaptations. By leveraging Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques, particularly BERT -based sentiment analysis, alongside computer vision-based visual feature recognition and SCT behavioral scoring, the study quantifies key psychological constructs such as attention, retention, reproduction, and motivation. Ten iconic stories from Andersen's canon-including The Little Mermaid and The Ugly Duckling-are examined alongside corresponding Disney animations. SCT -based influence scores were computed for each character, yielding a higher average score for Disney protagonists (mean score: 0.81) compared to their Andersen counterparts (mean score: 0.66), suggesting enhanced character modeling through animation. Sentiment analysis also revealed a 78.3% net positivity in Disney narratives compared to 52.4% in the original texts. Structural similarity analysis yielded an average narrative similarity index of 0.78 across the corpus. AI-driven K-means clustering of child audience responses further validated the dominance of prosocial traits like empathy, independence, and bravery among viewers influenced by high-scoring Disney characters. Overall, the model demonstrated a comparative accuracy of 94.61 % in classifying characters' SCT influence levels and behavioral impact. This study not only bridges literary analysis with AI but also sets a methodological precedent for evaluating moral education tools in children's media using quantitative behavioral science frameworks.

title: Multi Objective Reinforcement Tuning for Responsible Generative AI in Automated Financial Advisory Systems
authors: Vishakha D Bhandarkar, Musa Dima Genemo, Iskandar Muda, Rekha Murugan, G. Sreeram, N Dharani
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: Generative AI in a financial context poses risks to the areas of regulatory compliance, accuracy in the content being delivered, and appropriateness in terms of emotion. This research proposes ReFiGen, a framework that can be used to create compliant financial content that is compliant with the regulatory framework and the sentiment of the users. Following domain-specific fine-tuning, ReFiGen blends sentiment alignment with reinforcement learning to optimize on compliance. It demonstrates better performance than baseline models with a high data accuracy rate of 98.35 percent and can generate a fluent output that is emotionally congruent, and regulation-minded. The results of experiments indicate that ReFiGen is both clear and coherent and exactly follows financial guidelines. This practice affirms that the combination of unstructured compliance modeling and affective control is a successful aspect of LLMs. ReFiGen is one of the milestones on the journey of trustworthy and ethically aligned AI in the financial advisory market.

title: Transcending Image Generation Paradigms: Fusion of Transformer-Based Latent Diffusion and Semantic Clip Embeddings
authors: Sasi Vardhan Reddy Mandapati, Venkata Mani Nikhil Reddy Mandapati
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Computing, Semiconductor, Mechatronics, Intelligent Systems and Communications (COSMIC)
abstract: The synthesis of images from textual descriptions is a complex task at the intersection of language understanding and visual creativity. This paper presents the Lexico-Visual Synergy Diffuser - A Hierarchical Transformer Framework for Contextual Image Synthesis (LVSD-HTFCIS), a novel framework that melds CLIP-driven semantic embeddings with a hierarchical transformer-based latent diffusion process. Our model adeptly translates intricate text prompts into visually coherent outputs, evidenced by an exemplary FID score of 13.21. By employing Swin transformers, squeeze-and-excitation and multi-scale feature fusion mechanisms, LVSD-HTFCIS adeptly emphasizes relevant visual features, resulting in high-resolution images that faithfully reflect the input semantics. This advancement heralds a new era in generative modeling, with implications for creative AI applications in content generation and beyond.

title: Diamond NV Center-Based Quantum Sensors for Electromagnetic and Thermometric Applications
authors: Anjali Rana, Pallavi Gupta, Manisha Rajoriya, Surendra Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Quantum sensors are advanced devices that utilize the principles of quantum mechanics to achieve highly precise and sensitive measurements of various physical quantities, such as magnetic fields, temperature, acceleration, gravitational forces, and more. They exploit unique quantum phenomena like superposition, entanglement, and quantum coherence to detect minute changes in their environment, surpassing the capabilities of classical sensors. This review aims to provide an analysis of recent developments in NV center-based quantum sensing technologies and its utility in key innovations across electromagnetic and thermometric applications, materials and device engineering, algorithmic advancements, and biomedical integrations. Summarizing the findings across these domains, the review emphasizes how NV centers are leading the way to robust, high-resolution sensing platforms applicable from electrical engineering to cellular biology.

title: Campus Seeker- Sustainable Admission Insights
authors: Ganesh C, Naveen K S, Logeshwaran V, Siddarthan S, Rakesh M, Samraat M
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Students find it difficult to estimate admissions based on cutoff grades during the Tamil Nadu Engineering Admissions (TNEA) process, which frequently leads to stress and less-than-ideal decisions. In order to address this, Sustainable Admission Insights has created a web application that uses machine learning to generate precise admission predictions. The tool reduces anxiety by providing students with individualized predictions based on past data analysis, which helps them make well-informed decisions. This tool supports fair access to education, which is consistent with SDG 4. To guarantee prediction accuracy, it is developed through data collection, preprocessing, model training, and validation. Students enter their cutoff scores and get real-time projections using an intuitive interface. Feedback and empathy mapping guarantee that the design satisfies the needs of the students. The project's goal is to make the TNEA experience more equitable and transparent.

title: A Composite Sentiment Index for Technology Adoption & Investment
authors: James C. Brailean
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: This paper presents the Karmel Capital Sentiment Score (KCSS), a composite index designed to quantify sentiment in enterprise technology adoption. The KCSS integrates five components-Executive Optimism, ROI Success, Media Sentiment, Investment Confidence, and Organizational Readiness-into a 0-100 scale. The paper defines the mathematical formulation of the score, details its normalization and weighting, and validates it through regression and principal component analysis. Applications across enterprise projects indicate that the KCSS correlates with future success metrics, providing a structured tool for monitoring and forecasting technology-adoption outcomes.

title: Real-Time Adaptive Traffic Signal Control Using FPGA and a Machine Learning
authors: Abhiram A, Rethenya M, Vaishnav Raj M, Anantha Krishnan M, Geethu R S
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Urban traffic congestion continues to be a major concern, contributing to wasted time, excess fuel consumption, and environmental pollution. These challenges are often amplified by traditional fixed-time traffic signal systems that lack the ability to adapt to real-time traffic variations. This paper presents a realtime adaptive traffic signal controller implemented on an FPGA using Verilog. The system employs a deterministic, rule-based algorithm to dynamically tune green light durations based on live traffic density obtained from lane-based sensors. Each lane is monitored by three sensors that classify traffic as low, moderate, or high, enabling the FPGA to allocate green times accordingly. Leveraging the parallel processing capabilities and low latency of FPGAs, the proposed system ensures rapid decision-making, reduced vehicle idle time, and enhanced traffic throughput. The design is lightweight, scalable, hardware-efficient, and suitable for modern intelligent transportation systems. In addition to improving traffic flow, the system contributes to lower fuel wastage and reduced emissions by minimizing unnecessary idling.

title: Real-Time Cascaded Pipeline for Drone Detection and Behavior Anomaly Analysis: YOLOv8 Benchmark and ConvLSTM Approach
authors: Thatipamula Palgun, Upasna Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: The proliferation of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) necessitates advanced surveillance systems that can not only detect their presence but also analyze their behavior. Most existing works focus on object detection, which is insufficient for identifying malicious intent. Furthermore, a comprehensive benchmark for the latest object detectors on specialized UAV datasets is notably absent. To address these gaps, we propose a novel cascaded pipeline for real-time drone behavior anomaly detection. First, we establish a rigorous benchmark evaluating YOLOv7 and YOLOv8 variants on the visible-spectrum subset of the Anti-UAV 300 dataset. Our results demonstrate that YOLOv8m provides an optimal trade-off between high accuracy (68.7% mAP50-95) and real-time performance (132 FPS). Second, we use this optimal detector to power a cascaded analysis pipeline that employs a spatio-temporal ConvLSTM Autoencoder to learn normal drone motion from motion-saliency maps. By analyzing reconstruction error, our system effectively distinguishes normal flight from anomalous behaviors, achieving an AUROC of 0.944. This work provides two key contributions: a valuable benchmark for the research community and a complete, effective framework for advancing drone surveillance to nuanced behavior analysis.

title: Bring-Your-Own-Agent: Extending Copilot Across Enterprise and Healthcare Platforms
authors: Sunil Kumar Gingade Krishnamurthy
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: As AI gets integrated into healthcare and enterprise platforms' interoperable frameworks, safe data and compliance become a major challenge. To complement AI agents like Copilot in heterogeneous systems such as Electronic Health Records (EHRs), enterprise resource planning (ERP) systems, and Internet of Medical Things (IoMT) devices, the Bring-Your-Own-Agent (BYOA) framework is proposed. The BYOA framework uses AI to solve the problems impacting agent orchestration. It includes real-time data, automatic work processes and compliant data governance. The modular design and standard APIs of this system allow non-communicating objects to communicate. The standard API ensures all data remains safe and secure 100 % of the time. It also has built-in compliance features for HIPAA and GDPR that protect sensitive data from collection to deletion. According to a paper that sets out a conceptual framework and applies real tests and case studies, expanding Copilot functionality can significantly improve operational efficiency, decision-making and resource usage in enterprises and healthcare. The BYOA foundation will enable industries to do effective AI agent integrations and improve security and compliance. In other words, it can help realize the construction of an integrated and intelligent system.

title: An NLP - Based Customized and Optimized Offline PDF Summarizer Using Multi - Threading Approach
authors: Zafirah Inamdar, Zahrah Qureshi, Shrinidhi Zangar, Pruthvi Gangapure, Amogh Toshniwal, Tanishq Chavan, Parikshit Mahalle, Vaishali Rajput
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: In response to the increasing amount of digital textual information, there is growing need of smart applications to assist users in reading long documents in bitesized summaries. In this paper, a lightweight desktop application named Summarize Smart will be presented, written in Python and Tkinter-based interface. The application was created with ease of use, whereby, the user can drag and drop PDF files to summarize them. The system uses the basic extractive methods that are informed by the existing trends of hybrid summarization to produce compact and efficient results. In contrast to such cloud-based alternatives, SummarizeSmart is entirely offline and ensures the privacy of user data and is not required to have an internet. This article demonstrates the architecture of the system, the user-friendly design model, and its applicability in academic, professional and educational settings.

title: A Multi-Objective Nonlinear Programming Approach for Reliability-Aware Routing in Rescue Mesh Networks
authors: Yufeng Fan, Qingbo Ma, Ao Xing, Cen Chang
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: The operational efficacy of micro-sized search-and-rescue robots in post-disaster environments, such as collapsed buildings, is critically dependent on robust and efficient communication. Traditional Mobile Ad-hoc Network (MANET) routing protocols often falter in these challenging scenarios due to dynamic topologies, severe signal attenuation, and stringent energy constraints, primarily because they treat network reliability as a passive constraint rather than an integral optimization variable. This paper introduces a novel multi-objective nonlinear programming model for mesh network routing that deeply couples reliability dynamics with routing decisions. We model the network as a time-varying graph where link and node reliabilities are not static parameters but dynamic state variables co-evolving with traffic load, interference, and energy consumption. Our framework simultaneously optimizes four conflicting objectives: reliability-weighted delay, load balancing, network survivability, and energy efficiency. The model's core innovation lies in its bidirectional feedback mechanism: routing decisions directly influence reliability degradation rates, while instantaneous reliability values actively reshape network performance metrics and constraints. A detailed case study of a building collapse scenario demonstrates that our model achieves a superior trade-off. This work provides a rigorous mathematical foundation for deploying resilient robotic networks in life-critical missions.

title: A Novel Synthetic Dataset for JavaScript Malware Detection
authors: Hind Ikni, Alaa Eddine Belfedhal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Innovative Applications (AIIA)
abstract: The development of efficient AI-based methods for malware detection is significantly limited by the lack of high-quality datasets, as real-world scripts are often imbalanced and may include sensitive information. This scarcity of curated data poses major challenges for cybersecurity researchers, particularly regarding reproducibility and ethical compliance. In this paper, we introduce a novel synthetic dataset of JavaScript snippets that are programmatically labeled and balanced. Fine-tuning a CodeBERT-based classifier on the generated samples shows promising performance when evaluated on real-world scripts.

title: EFashion: Discriminative-Tuned Outfit Generation with Selective History Modeling
authors: Angang Zhang, Junyan Li, Zhongjian Chen, Fang Deng
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Outfit recommendation seeks to propose fashion items that align with user preferences and historical shopping patterns. Traditional methods are constrained by existing inventories, whereas generative approaches create novel items to offer diverse outfit combinations. To address the limitations in historical information utilization, this paper approximates the variational autoencoder’s latent space as a Gaussian mixture model, enabling unsupervised discovery of latent styles from user interactions. Additionally, a multi-condition discriminative loss is designed to enhance style consistency between existing items and generation targets. Experimental results on iFashion and Polyvore datasets demonstrate competitive performance across multiple metrics.

title: TCA-Net for Thangka Colorization with Multi-Axial Attention Fusion and Adaptive Graph Channel Recalibration
authors: Zhen Wang, Xinyang Zhang, Yunbo Yang, Yutong Wang, Mengyuan Zhang, Nianyi Wang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: In the task of automatic Thangka image colorization, traditional methods often struggle to balance artistic color fidelity with semantic structural consistency. To address this challenge, we propose a novel Thangka image colorization framework based on a multi-branch attention fusion mechanism (TCA-Net). Specifically, three directional attention branches (channel-height, channel-width, and channel-spatial) are introduced to capture semantic correlations across different feature dimensions. In addition, we design an Adaptive Graph Channel Recalibration (AGCR) module to enhance the flexibility of attention representation and improve inter-channel dependency modeling. Furthermore, we introduce a Strip-Based Contextual Line-Aware Attention (SCLA) mechanism, which significantly strengthens the model’s capability to perceive contextual information and enables global feature integration across spatial dimensions. By integrating multi-directional attention to guide the learning of color distributions, the proposed method achieves superior performance in terms of detail preservation and semantic coherence. Extensive experiments conducted on both the Thangka dataset and public benchmarks demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing methods in color realism, edge fidelity, and cross-style generalization. This work provides a promising solution for the digital restoration of Thangka murals.

title: MASF-FB: Multi-Attention Spatio-Frequency Fusion for Epileptic Seizure Prediction
authors: Abhishek Batra, Kapil Goyal, Vian Gandhi, Hima Deepthi Vankayalapati, Kapil Rathor
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: This approach tackles the challenge of seizure prediction with the help of a personalized deep learning model for each patient via the use of CHB-MIT EEG dataset. The key innovation in our approach is a novel dual-branch architecture, MASF-FB, which at the same time analyzes EEG signals from two perspectives. A Transformer is leveraged by spatiotemporal branch to capture evolving temporal dynamics and spatial dependencies of brain activity, while the power of brain waves is quantified by frequency branch to extract spectral cues linked to seizure onset. An enriched latent vector is formed by fusing representations from both branches which emerges minutes before seizure. So our approach aims to provide patient-specific seizure forecasts, empowering individuals with timely warning for betterment of safety and quality of life.

title: Deep Learning Performance Comparision for Plant Dieases on Mobile Devices
authors: Kolage Vaibhav Ashok, Meshram Vidula Vishal
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: EfficientNet B3, GoogLeNet, DenseNet, VGG16, in the Plant disease classification trial, are identified to be observed based on the aspects of accuracy, efficiency and using resource. We discover how each of the models is able to learn by training on a varied dataset of plant types and diseases by training them over several epochs on accuracy, precision, recall, and latency. In addition, CPU and RAM usage and temperature, and Total Design Power (TDP) are checked. Findings indicate EfficientNet B3 proves to be more effective in run time and accuracy in resource limited settings, next GoogLeNet, then DenseNet, and finally VGG16. Its findings stress that both performance and resource efficiency must be co-examined during the selection of models to be applied in agricultural practices to help with crop disease management. Keywords-- deep learning, the classification of plant disease, EfficientNet B3, GoogLeNet, DenseNet, VGG16, accuracy.

title: Bipedal Robot Running Gait Design Based on Phase Information
authors: YiChao Yang, QingDu Li, WenCong Gan, ZhiYuan Liang, YouShuang Ding, Ge Gao
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotic Systems and Applications (ICRSA)
abstract: Humanoid robots possess an anthropomorphic structure that makes them particularly suitable for performing diverse tasks in human-centered environments. However, this biomimetic design presents significant challenges in motion controller development, especially when operating in complex real-world conditions. Existing humanoid robots typically employ either model-based control or model-free reinforcement learning (RL) for locomotion on simple terrains. In this work, we focus on reference state generation for bipedal running, proposing an end-to-end RL framework for human-like motion control. Our approach successfully achieves zero-shot sim-to-real transfer of learned running skills, enabling physical robots to maintain stable running at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 ~\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> on both flat and uneven terrain. This demonstrates the strong robustness and generalization capability of our reference state generator.

title: Reconstructing 3D Flame Temperature Fields via Light Field Compression, Denoising and Feature Extraction
authors: Qingran Wang, Pengfei Gao, Yatao Ren, Hong Qi
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: Accurate 3D temperature reconstruction is vital for combustion diagnostics under noisy conditions. This study develops a light field imaging framework incorporating a radiative transfer model and a Light Field Compression and Noise Reduction (LFCNR) method based on low-rank approximation and eigenvalue decomposition. The LFCNR algorithm separates signal and noise subspaces and applies Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) for structural compression, reducing computational complexity. Comparative results show that the customized 1D denoising with SVD truncation achieves superior accuracy (ARE = 2.8770%, NRMSE = 0.0408, SSIM = 0.9288), outperforming wavelet thresholding method (ARE = 2.9920%, NRMSE = 0.0429, SSIM = 0.9230). The framework ensures robust, high-resolution temperature reconstruction in complex combustion fields.

title: A Comprehensive Analysis of Efficient Statement Methods for Internet of Things (IoT) Applications
authors: S. Afshia Nasrin, S.Somu, A.Lavanya, E. Divya, J. Sowmiya, S. Karunya
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: A revision of wireless machineries for IOT requests in period of control ingesting consumes continued pre-scented in this rag. The revision emphases on the position of by low control wireless methods and units in IOT requests by familiarizing a relative amid different squat control wireless communication methods such as ZigBee, Little Control Wi-Fi, 6-LowPAN, LPWA, their components to marmalade control and desire the lifetime for the IOT system instruments. The method of the revision is in period of procedure rummage-sale and the specific component that attain that procedure. The applicant procedures are confidential rendering to the variety of connectivity among sensor bulges. For small varieties connectivity the contender etiquettes are ZigBee, 6-LoWPAN and little control Wi-Fi. For extended connectivity the applicant is LoRa-WAN protocol.
