title: Research on a Hybrid Point Cloud Denoising Method for Mining Tunnels Based on Multi-Feature Fusion and Adaptive Segmentation
authors: Guo Yin, Daqing Wang, Weibin Guo, Zhijian Tu, Yongming Liu, Lifu Gao
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Precise 3D point cloud information from mining tunnels plays a vital role in tasks like surroundings awareness, 3D modeling, and structural change detection in smart mining systems. Yet, the harsh subsurface setting often results in point clouds contaminated by noise at various scales due to LiDAR scanning. Conventional denoising techniques relying on a single method frequently fail to eliminate noise adequately while safeguarding essential surface details on tunnel walls. To overcome this challenge, we introduce an integrated denoising strategy for mining tunnel point clouds that leverages feature integration and dynamic partitioning. This approach begins by combining surface properties (such as surface normals and bending measures) with tunnel layout knowledge (like the main tunnel orientation) to conduct flexible area division, categorizing the point cloud into smooth surface zones, rounded detail zones, and areas with intense noise. Subsequently, customized adaptive denoising tactics are employed based on each zone's traits: a bending-adjusted adaptive outlier detector for smooth zones, a normal-integrated dual-sided filter with flexible weighting for rounded zones to maintain specifics, and an enhanced grouping-based technique for noise-heavy zones. Tests using actual tunnel point cloud samples show that our strategy successfully identifies and clears diverse noise forms. Relative to standard techniques, it delivers better noise reduction and improved retention of tunnel layout details, offering reliable data for advanced tunnel alignment and simulation.

title: Secure Data Governance in JavaScript-Driven Web Systems using Blockchain-based Hybrid Federated Learning
authors: Ravindra Putchakayala, Rohit Yallavula, B. Jegajothi
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: Contemporary JavaScript-based web applications generate huge volumes of interactivity and connectedness data that is very sensitive and vulnerable to tight privacy and governance policies. To establish secure and responsible data management in such distributed environments, the approach requires a combination of decentralized control, privacy safeguards and effective collaborative learning. In this research, a hybrid federated learning/blockchain architecture, PSOAdam Federated Blockchain Governance (PA-FedGov) is proposed and aimed at meeting verifiable and privacyprotecting data governance. The new hybrid optimization approach is a combination of Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) algorithm of adaptive global aggregation and the Adam optimizer of local model optimization which leads to faster convergence and better generalization on non-independent and identically distributed data sources. To achieve immutable, auditable and transparent governance mechanisms, smart contracts are used by the blockchain layer to store model provenance, different privacy budgets, and compliance metadata. To conduct experimental evaluations, the system utilized Benchmark datasets such as FEMNIST to identify user specific handwritings, CICIDS 2017 to detect intrusion in web systems and the Edge-IIoTset to analyze and govern edges, and IoT. These datasets are used in the publicly available CSV or JSON formats. The findings show that the suggested PAFedGov model is more accurate and more stable by up to 12 percent when compared to the conventional federated learning approaches like FedAvg and FedProx, with the same set of differential privacy restrictions. The architecture that ensures traceability and decentralized policy enforcement is blockchain based, and it provides a scalable and reliable foundation of safe data control within federated and privacy-sensitive JavaScript web environments.

title: Demand Forecasting with Machine Learning: A Data-Driven Strategy for Market Prediction
authors: Shravan Dhage, Dhananjay Chitale, Shreenand Bandre, Priya Shelke, Pallavi Rege, Anuja Mate
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: The application of demand forecasting is vital to the retail industry because proper forecasting of its sales will ensure it maintains the appropriate level of inventory. This reduces shortage losses and enhances efficiency in the supply chain. However, manual forecasting cannot withstand the dynamics of customer demand, seasonal fluctuations, and changes in the store and therefore inaccurate. To this purpose, the project presents demand forecasting system based on machine learning. It uses past sales information to forecast the sales in each item by each store every day. The model preprocesses time-series data and derives helpful time predictors and uses a Random Forest Regressor to learn intricate and non linear buying characteristics. These experiments demonstrate that the system is giving quality predictions and identifying trends and seasonality, and also makes decisions based on data. The solution allows retailers to plan inventory more efficiently and to make operations efficient.

title: Machine Learning Based Prediction of Biomaterial Hardness for Medical Devices
authors: Neha Meriya Binu, Rahul Krishnan Pathinarupothi
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Medical-grade biomaterials need to be accurately characterized for their mechanical properties, with hardness being a prominent selection criterion for clinical applications. Well-established methods, such as Vickers and Brinell hardness tests, while common, are generally time-consuming and dependent on expert equipment, posing problems during initial material screening. This paper presents a machine learning approach to predict hardness based on a small number of readily available material properties, such as tensile strength, elongation at break, and density. The dataset comprises 25 biocompatible materials with six features selected from MatWeb. Linear Regression, Ridge Regression, Random Forest, Gradient boosting, and XG-Boost models were implemented, incorporating feature reduction through Principal Component Analysis (PCA). This enables a fast, data-driven prediction of Vickers and Brinell hardness, with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex> values of 0.82 and 0.83, respectively. Furthermore, once the value of one of these types of hardness, Brinell or Vickers, is available or predicted, the value of the other can be deduced with great accuracy. In particular, Vickers hardness was predicted from Brinell hardness and density by using Ridge Regression with an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex> value of 0.96.

title: Development of Integrated Shipboard Microgrid for Simultaneous Realization of Emission Reduction and Carbon Neutrality
authors: Sachio Kubota
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Environment Friendly Energies and Applications (EFEA)
abstract: This paper presents a shipboard microgrid architecture aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions, mitigating environmental pollution, and improving energy efficiency. Despite global decarbonization efforts, maritime transport remains heavily reliant on diesel and other oil-based fuels, and these fuels are expected to continue being used for diesel engines even as alternatives such as hydrogen, ammonia, and liquefied natural gas (LNG) are gradually introduced. Conventional shipboard power systems often operate at low generator load factors, resulting in poor fuel efficiency and significant emissions of nitrogen oxides (NOx), sulfur oxides (SOx), and particulate matter (PM). The proposed microgrid integrates multiple energy sources with advanced control strategies to optimize power flow, enhance generation efficiency, and enable effective exhaust gas treatment. By providing stable onboard power while reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) and pollutant emissions, the system supports practical implementation of cleaner fuels and contributes to carbon-neutral, sustainable maritime operations.

title: UniDiff-TTS: Aligner-Free Diffusion Speech Synthesis with Duration Guidance
authors: Yangming Chen, Yutao Qi, Wenbin Chen
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Diffusion models have recently attracted considerable attention in speech synthesis tasks due to their remarkable capabilities in generating high-fidelity speech. However, existing diffusion-based text-to-speech (TTS) methods typically rely on external aligners, involve complex structures, exhibit slow inference speeds, and struggle to maintain stable performance in multi-speaker scenarios. To address these limitations, this paper proposes UniDiff-TTS, an aligner-free unified diffusion-based speech synthesis framework. UniDiff-TTS integrates the efficient parallel generation architecture of FastSpeech with the high-quality generative capabilities of Latent Diffusion Models (LDMs). Specifically, during training, UniDiff-TTS utilizes duration-guided conditional representations from FastSpeech to assist the LDM in iteratively reconstructing mel-spectrograms in latent space. During inference, high-quality speech can be generated using only a few diffusion sampling steps. Experimental results on four datasets covering both single- and multi-speaker speech synthesis tasks in Chinese and English demonstrate that UniDiff-TTS significantly outperforms existing approaches, including Tacotron 2, FastSpeech 2, and Grad-TTS, in terms of Mean Opinion Score (MOS), Mel Cepstral Distortion (MCD), and Real-Time Factor (RTF). Particularly, UniDiff-TTS maintains superior performance in multi-speaker settings and under low-step inference conditions. Additional ablation studies and analyses of diffusion steps validate the effectiveness of each component and demonstrate the practical deployment potential of the system. Overall, UniDiff-TTS provides a viable approach for developing unified TTS systems that simultaneously achieve high fidelity and low inference latency.

title: AI-Driven Feedback Through SpeakTalk: Supporting EFL Speaking Skill Development in Higher Education
authors: Siska Wati Dewi Purba, John Jackson Yang, Muhammad Irfan Luthfi, Wiputra Cendana, Michael Recard
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: This study investigated the use of SpeakTalk, an AIbased application, that has automated evaluation characteristics in recognizing and enhancing EFL speaking ability of Indonesian students in higher education. Three activities, namely reading and speaking, sentence completion, and simple conversation were completed by students using the app. The students’ performance was graded automatically based on the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR) B2 scale, using indicators like Accuracy, Fluency, Correctness, Word Error Rate (WER), and Final Score. The results show that the beginner level students made the most of their gains by the structured support, while the advanced students were almost native-like in their fluency. Additionally, the results point out to the opportunities presented by AI-generated, customized feedback and task differentiation that can help students stay on top of their EFL development in speaking and can inform the strategies for teaching future learners about the implementation of the various features of intelligent language learning environments.

title: A Deformable Shape Design for Radar Stealth Satellite
authors: Qingbiao Zheng, Yuanwen Cai, Xiaohui Feng, Youjian Liang, Huilong Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: In order to reduce the detectability and improve the survivability of satellites, a deformable radar stealth shape was proposed. Initially, a preliminary scheme was obtained by using the multi-edge design method, based on the research of the existing stealth satellite configurations, stealth aircraft, ships, tanks and other configurations. Subsequently, the deformation design and layout optimization of the preliminary scheme were carried out to obtain a deformable radar stealth satellite configuration that could achieve stealth function without attitude maneuver. Finally, the radar cross section (RCS) of satellite under stealth and normal operation were calculated by electromagnetic simulation with detection radar waves covering different frequency bands and incident angles. The effectiveness of satellite stealth shape design was verified by simulation results.

title: Traffic and Social Aware Content Caching in Vehicular Social Networks using Taylor Flamingo Shark Optimization
authors: Vedha Vinodha Doraiswamy, Malathy Subramaniam
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Vehicular Social Networks (VSNs) face great challenges in achieving efficient caching of content due to the extremely dynamic mobility of vehicles, time-varying traffic conditions, and dynamic social interactions. The challenges cause elevated latency and a low Quality of Experience (QoE). To address the challenges, a work proposes a Traffic- and Social-Aware Content Caching framework optimized with the novel Taylor Flamingo Shark Optimization (TFSO) algorithm. The framework utilizes predicted mobility of vehicles and social relationship-driven content popularity modeling to efficiently direct cache placement at the Road Side Units (RSUs) and in the vehicles. In addition, a hierarchical cooperative caching policy allows RSUs to cache popular, long-term content globally while allowing the vehicles to store locally popular, short-term content for socially related groups, thus decreasing the redundancy and enhancing the coverage in the network. The multi-objective optimization aims at improving the cache hit ratio, reducing delivery latency, and improving QoE at the same time. The simulation outcomes show that the TFSO-directed framework outperforms the existing caching techniques, and it describes an adaptive efficient, and socially aware approach for content delivery in highly dynamic vehicular networks.

title: Design and Development of an IoT and Web-Integrated Respiratory Disease Prediction System using Machine Learning
authors: N. Bhuvaneswary, Bestha Nagendra Babu, Nandaluru Pavithra, Karnati Indu Reddy
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Respiratory disorders continue to rank high in terms of morbidity and mortality globally and need fast and non-invasive diagnosis. This research presents a low-cost breath analysis system consisting of gas sensors, machine learning algorithms, and a web-based monitoring dashboard. The suggested hardware configuration uses MQ-series gas sensors (MQ-135 for CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> and NH<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>, MQ-3 for ethanol, and MQ-7 for CO) in combination with IR-based patient identification for real-time sampling of the exhaled breath. The sensor readings are analyzed by a pre-trained machine learning algorithm for the prediction of possible respiratory disorders. The system also integrates a secure web dashboard for the registration and tracking of patients. In addition to disease predictions, the dashboard allows preventive Ayurvedic treatment for patients without serious conditions and finds hospitals nearest the patient in need of medical assistance. Experimental outcomes prove the correctness of the readings from the hardware and the forecasting accuracy of the ML algorithm. The prototype developed showcases the possibility of cheap, transportable, and smart healthcare solutions for the early diagnosis of diseases and patient support.

title: Autonomous Sensor Networks: Future of WSNs with Neural Network Implementations
authors: James Deva Koresh Hezekiah, J. Vijitha Ananthi, P. Kanaga Priya, Palanichamy Naveen
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) are widely preferred in various applications from environmental monitoring to healthcare and industrial automation due to its minimum peripheral requirements and simplified architecture. However, extending lifetime has become a significant challenge in WSNs due to its limited energy resources, non-efficient processing and communication strategies. The traditional network lifetime improvement methods are highly affected with environmental factors, hardware limitations and lack of intelligence. The advancements of Machine Learning (ML) and Deep Learning (DL) addresses these issues with an innovative solution by handling the transmission data in an intelligent way. The efficient resource management and adaptive network protocols of ML and DL approaches are moving further WSNs to a greater improvement. This paper examines the impact of ML and DL approaches on improving the lifetime of wireless sensor networks. It explores the performances of various neural networks implemented to optimize the data aggregation, transmission and node operations of WSNs. The findings suggests the possibility of making autonomous sensor networks using ML and DL models, especially in complex and dynamic environments.

authors: Swati Bhosale, S. B. Patil, Swati Anil Patil

title: Learning Compact Semantic Information and Reliable Pseudo-labels for Incomplete Multi-View Multi-Label Classification
authors: Yadong Liu, Chengliang Liu, Jie Wen, Li Shen, Bob Zhang, Yong Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Multi-view data encompasses various data types, including multi-feature, multi-sequence, and multi-modal data. Multi-view multi-label classification aims to leverage the rich semantic information contained in multiple views to achieve enhanced multi-label classification performance. In practical applications, the absence of views and labels poses a significant challenge to multi-view multi-label classification tasks. Premised on the assumption that shared semantic information across multiple views is sufficient to support the downstream task, we propose CTRL, a novel incomplete multi-view multi-label classification framework to address the multi-view learning challenge on the data with partially missing views and missing labels in this paper. The core mechanism of CTRL lies in learning a high-purity, lowredundancy condensed representation that adequately captures the essential information of the original data. Specifically, we design a new objective loss to enhance the semantic information of shared cross-view within the joint representation learning process while simultaneously suppressing intra-view redundant information that is irrelevant to the downstream task. This enables CTRL to extract task-relevant representations even when views are incomplete. Furthermore, we employ the Beta Evidential Neural Network to model the label distribution. This network is then integrated with Dempster-Shafer theory, enabling our model to perform label-level classification uncertainty estimation. This also allows us to use the estimated uncertainty and belief mass to create high-reliability pseudo-labels, resulting in further gains in model performance. Experimental results on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate the superior performance of our proposed model in terms of accuracy, robustness, and reliability.

title: OnUVS: An Online Motion Transfer Framework with Content-Texture Decoupling for High-Fidelity Ultrasound Video Synthesis
authors: Han Zhou, Rusi Chen, Xin Yang, Ao Chang, Junxuan Yu, Yuhao Huang, Ruobing Huang, Xinrui Zhou, Luping Zhou, Jiamin Liang, Haoran Dou, Yongsong Zhou, Lian Liu, Mengyun Qiao, Deng-Ping Fan, Hongkui Yu, Dong Ni, Zhongshan Gou
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Ultrasound (US) imaging plays a crucial role in diagnosing heart and pelvic diseases, where sonographers tend to evaluate dynamic motion and structure. However, the scarcity of US videos for rare cases limits training opportunities for novice sonographers and deep learning models, hindering detection rates and clinical di agnostic applications. US video synthesis is a promising solution to this issue. Nevertheless, accurately imitating the intricate motion of the anatomy while preserving image f idelity presents a significant challenge. In this work, we propose OnUVS, a novel online feature-decoupling frame work for high-fidelity US video synthesis. First, to simulate realistic motion, we incorporate keypoints into anatomical learning through a weakly supervised training approach, which enhances motion representation and minimizes the need for fully annotated data. Second, we implement a dual decoder generator that effectively balances content and textural features of generated frames, significantly enhancing the image fidelity of US videos. Third, a multi-scale discriminator further refines the sharpness and fine details, ensuring high-fidelity video synthesis. Fourth, an online learning strategy is designed to smooth coherence between frames by constraining the keypoint trajectories during inference. Validation on echocardiographic and pelvic floor US datasets demonstrates that OnUVS outperforms existing methods, achieving a 22.08% improvement in motion consistency (FVD) and 25.04% in image fidelity (FID). To facilitate reproducibility, we publicly release the code of OnUVSat: https://github.com/LucyChen159/OnUVS.

title: Super-Twisting Sliding Mode Control for ANPC-Driven Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor with Midpoint Voltage Balancing Strategy
authors: Zibo Sun, Yuanchun Zhou, Sun-Pil Kim, Guangxu Zhou, Feel-Soon Kang
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: The control system for permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM) driven by active neutral-point clamped (ANPC) three-level inverters faces challenges such as slow response of conventional PI controllers, significant chattering and insufficient disturbance rejection in traditional sliding mode control (SMC), and neutral-point (NP) voltage imbalance in the three-level inverter. To address these issues, this paper proposes a composite control strategy integrating second-order fast super-twisting sliding mode control (FSTA-SMC), a novel sliding mode disturbance observer (SMDO), and an improved zero-sequence voltage injection method. The speed loop employs the fast super-twisting algorithm, while the current loop utilizes the super-twisting algorithm, thereby preventing the issue of fast response in individual loops while overall system dynamics remain sluggish. Furthermore, a novel sliding mode disturbance observer is designed by formulating its sliding gain as a function of the disturbance estimation error. This enables precise observation of internal parameter variations and external load disturbances, which are then fed into the sliding mode controller via a feedforward compensation mechanism to enhance system robustness. Additionally, to mitigate the neutral-point voltage deviation, an improved zero-sequence voltage injection method is proposed, characterized by its computational simplicity and ease of engineering implementation. Simulation and experimental results demonstrate that the proposed control strategy achieves superior performance in enhancing dynamic response speed, improving robustness, and suppressing chattering, while also effectively balancing the neutral-point voltage and improving the overall performance of the drive system.

title: Online Distribution-Based Clustering Algorithm for Condition Monitoring in Rotating Machines
authors: A. Tavares, C. Veiga, A. Cavalini, C. Nataraj, A. Abbasi, V Steffen, M. Cunha
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Continuous monitoring of industrial rotating machines is essential for ensuring health, reliability, and safety, while minimizing costs from unplanned downtime. Traditional systems require domain experts to configure parameters for each machine, limiting adaptability. Machine learning techniques offer alternatives, with supervised approaches demanding labeled datasets that are rarely available due to the extensive effort required from specialists. This study presents an algorithm for unsupervised condition monitoring based on an online distribution-driven clustering approach. The algorithm autonomously learns machine behavior, detecting new operating conditions in real time while recognizing previously observed states. Input data consist of signals from proximity and accelerometer sensors mounted on the rotor shaft. These signals are processed using time- and frequency-domain feature extraction methods combined with an autoencoder neural network. Validation was performed with four datasets: synthetically generated signals, real measurements from a rotating machine at the Federal University of Uberlandia, and benchmark datasets from Case Western Reserve University (CWRU) and Hanoi University of Science and Technology (HUST) bearing dataset. Evaluation metrics, including accuracy and F1 score, consistently reached values close to 0.96 across most tests. These results confirm the algorithm’s ability to reliably detect and classify machine condition variations in real time. Furthermore, results obtained with benchmark datasets were compared to supervised learning studies, showing comparable or superior performance. This demonstrates the proposed method’s robustness and practicality in industrial applications, where labeled data are scarce and real-time adaptability is critical. Overall, the algorithm provides an effective solution for unsupervised monitoring of rotating machinery, reducing reliance on expert intervention while maintaining high detection accuracy.

title: Multi-Criteria Evaluation of Large Language Models (LLMs): Balancing Performance and Security
authors: Daniel Mendonça Colares, Plácido Rogério Pinheiro, Raimir Holanda Filho
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Because of its functionality and practicality, Large Language Models (LLMs) have been widely discussed, with a large number of benchmarking being done to evaluate them, especially their efficiency. But despite their numerous applications and the significant benefits they offer, LLMs have proven to be extremely susceptible to attacks of various natures due to their, often unknown, large number of vulnerabilities, characteristics often ignored by benchmarking. Given that, this paper aims to develop a multi-criteria method to assist stakeholders in selecting the most suitable Large Language Model taking into account based on both its efficiency in carrying out tasks of various natures, such as math and reasoning, and its capability to resist a large range of security vulnerabilities, such as prompt injection and jailbreaking. This study utilized the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) along with tools developed to evaluate the capabilities of LLMs in multi-interaction dialogues and LLM vulnerability scanner applied in open source models. The analysis showed that an more efficient model does not mean that it is safer. In addition, it reveals an efficient method for analyzing both model performance and security issues.

title: Multi-Physics Modeling, Analysis, and Validation of Immersion-Cooled Five-Level ANPC Inverters for Electric Propulsion
authors: Reza Ilka, Benjamin Luckett, Majid T. Fard, JiangBiao He
publish: IEEE Transactions on Transportation Electrification
abstract: In the emerging transportation electrification applications, there is an increasing demand on concurrently pursuing high reliability, high energy efficiency, and high power density of power converters. Conventional cooling technologies, such as using bulky heatsinks or cold plates, have constrained further performance improvements of power converters. Based on an innovative immersion cooling technique, this paper presents a high-fidelity, multi-physics modeling and experimental validation framework for a 100-kW, five-level active neutral point clamped (5L-ANPC) power inverter, making it the first comprehensive study on this topic. The study begins by examining the electrical performance of the 5L-ANPC inverter, followed by the computation of semiconductor losses to be used as heat sources in subsequent thermal simulations. Afterwards, the immersion-cooled inverter is modeled and analyzed by conducting high-fidelity computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations. Various operating conditions and thermal design factors for the immersion-cooled 5L-ANPC inverter are considered, and the related impacts are investigated to characterize the thermal performance of the inverter. The results demonstrate significantly reduced semiconductor junction temperatures and more uniform heat distribution compared to conventional air cooling. The findings highlight the advantages of immersion cooling in thermal management, leading to higher output power and higher reliability. Finally, prototypes of air-cooled and immersion-cooled inverters are developed with intensive testing to compare the thermal performance. The multi-physics simulation results showing the superior performance of immersion cooling are also verified in the experiments.

title: Large Language Model-Based Gray Wolf Optimization for Near-Field ISAC Networks
authors: Zhen Chen, Kezhi Wang, Jianqing Li, Xiu Yin Zhang, Kai-Kit Wong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: The advent of extremely large antenna arrays and high-frequency signaling is expected to enable next-generation integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) networks to predominantly operate in the near-field region. Due to the dual influence of distance and angle on wave propagation characteristics in the near-field region, accurately modeling these characteristics remains a critical challenge. Motivated by the potential of large language models (LLMs) in angle prediction and distance estimation, an LLM-enhanced multi-objective optimization problem (MOOP) is developed to accurately capture the dependence of the channel on both the angular position and distance. The formulated LLM-enhanced MOOP framework is decomposed into a series of sub-problems, which can balance spectral efficiency for communication and localization accuracy for sensing. To overcome the computational and energy challenges associated with LLMs, a gray wolf optimization (GWO)-based algorithm is integrated as black-box search operator with LLM-specific prompt engineering to solve these sub-problems. Numerical results demonstrate that the proposed LLM-GWO scheme achieves an trade-off between communication and sensing performance, outperforming baseline approaches in terms of both Pareto front quality and convergence.

title: Fixed-Time Performance Fault-Tolerant Control for Cluster Synchronization of Spatiotemporal Networks with Sign-Based Coupling
authors: Tingting Shi, Cheng Hu, Juan Yu, Shiping Wen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: The practically fixed-time leaderless cluster synchronization is addressed for uncertain spatiotemporal networks (USTNs) with coopetition interactions, actuator faults and external disturbances. Firstly, by introducing sign-based coupling, a class of USTN is formulated to capture the dynamics of coopetition interactions among different clusters, which provides a more accurate representation compared to dynamical networks with unsigned coupling. Secondly, a practical fixed-time (PFT) convergence theorem is developed for a general partial differential system, which relaxes the constraints on the derivative of the Lyapunov function and provides a less conservative method for estimating the settling time. Subsequently, a distributed fault-tolerant control algorithm is designed to drive the cluster synchronization error to an adjustable attraction region in a fixed time. By exploring specific properties of the intra-cluster Laplacian matrix and proposing a new inter-degree balanced condition, several flexible synchronization criteria are derived and a quantitative relationship among control parameters, the settling time and the size of the attraction region is presented. Finally, the effectiveness of the developed controllers and criteria is validated through a coupled reaction-diffusion neural network.

title: Patterned Assembly of Multi-biological Robots with Global Input
authors: Gang Huang, Yuchen Chen, Yang Wu, Songlin Zhuang, Mingsi Tong, Huijun Gao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Robotics
abstract: Engineered assembloids fabricated from tissue spheroids hold immense promise for developmental biology, disease modeling, and regenerative medicine. However, fabricating heterogeneous assembloids with precise spatial patterning remains a critical bottleneck, often reliant on manual pipetting that lacks scalability and reproducibility. While magnetic microrobotics, which transforms spheroids into controllable robots, offers a non-invasive alternative, it faces a fundamental challenge: the global input of magnetic actuation. A single command moves all robots simultaneously, leading to coupled motion and frequent assembly failures. Here, we present a collaborative control framework that overcomes this limitation by leveraging local constraints and a novel motion decoupling strategy. We reformulate the high-dimensional, coupled multi-robot planning problem into a low-dimensional aggregate space, effectively transforming the assembly task into a dynamic sequential decision problem. This framework, coupled with a graph-based dynamic path optimization algorithm, enables deterministic, collision-free assembly. Experimental validation demonstrates a 78.57% higher success rate and a 33.20% higher assembly efficiency compared to conventional strategies. This work establishes a foundational engineering principle for assembloid fabrication, transitioning the process from a qualitative experiments to a controllable and programmable engineering discipline, thereby unlocking the potential for deterministic construction of complex biological structures.

title: Research on the Safety of Rearward Launch Separation of Semi-Recessed Wing-Mounted Missiles
authors: Liang Quan, Yi Jiang
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: In this study, a backward launch method for missiles placed on semi-recessed wings is proposed to reduce the interference effects during the missile-aircraft separation process. The feasibility of this launch strategy and the safety of missile-aircraft separation were verified using an unsteady computational fluid dynamics (CFD) modeling method. Using six-DOF rigid body dynamics equations and unstructured dynamic mesh technology, a numerical simulation of the rearward launch process of missiles mounted on semi-recessed wings was carried out. The separation flow field and missile trajectory parameters were obtained at different times. The results show that during the first separation phase, the missile has low aerodynamic interference from the carrier aircraft, its attitude changes minimally, and the missile may separate from the carrier aircraft rapidly, safely, and stably.

title: An Intelligent Identification Model for Structured Data Security Labeling
authors: Jian Bai, Junqiao Wang, Yunbiao Xu, Hongwei Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: Data right confirmation and traceability are pivotal for secure data element sharing in trusted data spaces, with structured data’s traceability posing unique challenges. This research introduces a novel structured data security identification model via a multi-faceted approach. For numerical data, clustering statistics construct a distribution baseline to enable identification extraction by analyzing patterns and multi-dimensional statistical features, effectively capturing numerical data’s cluster characteristics and inter-dimensional correlations. For character data, an intelligent classification algorithm based on a cross-industry feature thesaurus trains a deep learning classification model to predict semantic categories by analyzing lexical semantics, syntactic structures, and contextual dependencies. A Bloom filter-based algorithm generates compact data fingerprints via probabilistic hashing for ownership declaration and rapid traceability, ensuring efficient similarity matching with minimal storage overhead, scalable performance, and high-speed query capabilities. Theoretical analysis and experimental validation on diverse real-world datasets demonstrate the model consistently achieves millisecond-level identification extraction, sub-second traceability for 500,000 identifiers, and state-of-the-art recognition accuracy. These results validate its capability to support robust right confirmation systems in trusted data spaces, addressing critical needs in real-time access control, sensitive data leakage prevention, and post-incident forensics across dynamic network environments. By integrating statistical modeling, semantic analysis, and probabilistic data structures, the framework offers scalable solutions for ensuring data integrity and accountability in modern data ecosystems.

title: Using Artificial Intelligence Algorithms to Determine Important Features for Academic Achievement of High-school Minority Students
authors: Thao-Trang Huynh-Cam, Hai-Duy Le, Long-Sheng Chen, Tzu-Chuen Lu, Dang-Khoa Le-Huynh
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: Student academic achievement have attracted nonstop attention from theories and practices worldwide. Yet, student academic achievement of high-school students in remote areas, especially minority students have been less concerned. Therefore, this paper aimed to predict and determine important factors for student academic achievement in a Vietnamese remote high school using Decision Tree (DT), Random Forests (RF), and Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) classifiers with recursive feature elimination (RFE) methods. Real samples comprised 445 Grade 10 students in Soc Trang including 270 Vietnamese (Kinh) students and 175 minority students (Chinese (Hoa) and Khmer). The input factors included students’ grade point average scores. The results showed that DT and RF using the RFE feature selection method were better with accuracy and $F 1$ result of 100%. The academic achievement of Khmer high-school students was mostly affected by Mathematics grades in the first semester; of Chinese (Hoa) students was highly influenced by Mathematics and English grades; and of Vietnamese (Kinh) was mostly impacted by English grades in the first semester. The research outcomes of this study hopefully help school leaders foster academic achievement of highschool minority students for maximining university entrance rates and minimizing dropout rates.

title: Machine Learning-Based Weekly Evapotranspiration Prediction and Monitoring in Rice Fields Using MODIS in Thailand
authors: Viphada Boonlerd, Woranut Chansury, Panu Nueangjumnong, Chompunut Chayawat, Duangrat Satakhun, Pakorn Petchprayoon, Onpreeya Siripaet
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotic Systems and Applications (ICRSA)
abstract: Accurate estimation of evapotranspiration (ET) is essential for optimizing irrigation in rice fields, particularly under increasing climate variability. This study presents a machine learning-based approach for predicting weekly ET using MODIS satellite data and ground-truth eddy covariance (EC) measurements collected from a rice field in Roi Et province, Thailand. MODIS vegetation and surface indices were used as inputs to six machine learning models, including Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, and Linear Regression. The EC system, which captures ET every second, was aggregated to match the 8-day MODIS ET product for validation. Results show that the Random Forest model achieved the highest accuracy during the 2020 rice-growing season <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathrm{R}^{2}=0.915$</tex>, RMSE = 2.98 mm/week), while performance dropped in 2021 and in the combined dataset due to the absence of data between cropping periods. Feature importance analysis revealed that NDVI was most influential in 2020, LST in 2021, and EVI in the combined model-indicating seasonal variability in key predictors. The findings demonstrate the robustness of ensemble models for capturing ET dynamics and emphasize the need for seasonal-aware modeling approaches. This study highlights the potential of MODIS-based machine learning models as cost-effective, scalable tools for improving water resource management and supporting sustainable rice production in Thailand.

title: Intelligent IoT: Leveraging Data Analysis, Computer Vision, and Machine Learning for Smart Systems
authors: Srikanth Lakumarapu, R. Saranya, S.Deepa, Prithya M, S.Gayathri, M.G.Dinesh
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: High growth rate of Internet of Things (IoT) devices has led to the generation of high-volume, heterogeneous data that demand the use of advanced techniques of intelligent processing and decision-making. This survey investigates the application of data analysis, computer vision(CV), and machine learning(ML) in IoT systems, what they are applied to and how they have impacted different spheres. Data analysis techniques, including statistical, predictive and real-time stream processing, can be used to provide IoT systems with actionable insights, anomaly detection and predictive maintenance. Computer vision allows the gadgets to perceive and interpret visual information, and this capability allows their application in intelligent surveillance, industrial safety, medical, and self-driving. IoT systems can be made more flexible, predictive, and able to make decisions on their own by using machine learning techniques such as supervised and unsupervised learning, deep learning, reinforcement learning, and online learning. The survey also examines integration methodologies such as edge, cloud and hybrid computing, sensor fusion, and multimodal data processing that enhances real time intelligence and efficiency in operations. What is more, it addresses the most important concerns, namely data heterogeneity, resource limitation, security, and scalability and suggests the research areas of the future, namely explainable AI, TinyML, federated learning, multimodal AI, and 5G/6G integration.

title: Comprehensive Analysis of Mitigation Strategies for Denial-of-Service Attacks on Smart Contracts
authors: Purnima Ahirao, Yogita Borse, Deepti Patole, Shreshtha Agarwal, Mehek Abhyankar, Kaustubh Nair
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: The Denial-of-service (DoS) attacks pose a significant risk in smart contracts. They often arise from unexpected failures in external calls. This papers thoroughly examines DoS vulnerabilities in smart contracts and looks at effective ways to reduce these risks. The authors explore contract scenarios that are vulnerable to refund-failure DoS attacks. In these cases, bad actors can disrupt contract operations. The experiments show that some methods completely defend against these attacks, but they might some with a cost and hamper overall user experience. Other methods find a middle ground, improving security and usability by improving DoS and re-entrancy risks without interfering with single interaction flows. The research provides a solid evaluation for DoS mitigation strategies and offers practical advice for developing secure smart contracts.

title: Dual-Cross Transformer based on the Frequency Domain for Hyperspectral Image Super-resolution
authors: Abdolraheem Khader, Ali Ahmed, Liang Xiao
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: High spatial-spectral hyperspectral images are in high demand across multiple fields and can be acquired by fusing the complementary features of low-resolution hyperspectral and high-resolution multispectral images. Although considerable learning-based approaches have been devised for this task, the complexity and the need to exploit vital features still leave room for improvement. Therefore, we devised a Cross Transformer based on an attention mechanism in the Frequency domain to improve computational efficiency. Furthermore, the proposed technique is further improved by introducing an effective Feed-forward Network in the Frequency Domain. The presented network is validated via various experiments employing two widely used datasets, Columbia computer vision laboratory (CAVE) and Imperial Computer Vision & Learning Lab (iCVL).

title: FVCap: Fact-Verified Image Captioning Model
authors: Kai Zhou, Xiangya Zhu, Yong Yang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Image captioning aims to generate semantically accurate and linguistically fluent descriptions from images. Despite progress with vision–language pre-trained models (VLMs) and large language models (LLMs), existing methods still suffer from visual hallucination—producing entities or attributes inconsistent with image content. To address this, we propose FVCap, a fact-checking-driven model that employs a multistage "generate–verify–rewrite" mechanism to enhance factual consistency and semantic accuracy. The Fact Verification Module (FVM) integrates textual parsing, YOLO-World–based entity verification, and VQA-based attribute checking to impose multimodal factual constraints from entity to attribute levels. This hierarchical verification mitigates hallucination and improves reliability. Experiments on MSCOCO and Flickr30k show that FVCap surpasses state-of-the-art methods across multiple metrics, demonstrating strong robustness, generalization, and interpretability for trustworthy caption generation.

title: Conversational Web3: Enabling Human-Like Interactions with the Solana Blockchain via Hey SOL
authors: R.S Gokulnath, N Shri Bharani Priya, A Vijay, G Balaji, D Saranya
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: Web3 technologies are an exciting new frontier in digital asset ownership and decentralized systems, but certain factors, namely the complexity of blockchain interfaces, may preclude mass adoption. This research introduces Hey SOL, a conversational interface that facilitates interaction with the Solana blockchain by allowing its users to conduct Web3 capabilities using simple prompts and chat commands. Hey SOL integrates directly with the Solana blockchain with the Model Context Protocol (MCP), providing a relatively secure and reliable interaction while eliminating much of the technical burden on users. Overall, extensive testing shows that conversational interfaces like Hey SOL can improve usability and facilitate a better user experience than the traditional blockchain applications.

title: Dual-Axis Sun Tracking Solar Panel
authors: Ashiwini Navghane, Gajanan Ghuge, Prajwal Survase, Shravani Supekar, Samir Sukey, Sammyag Solanki
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: The world henceforth will be dependent on natural resources for energy generation. Solar energy plays a vital role and is leading amongst all of them. Solar energy is one of the crucial types of energy for enhancing the performance of renewable energy systems. This paper explores the design, development, and implementation of a dual-axis sun-tracking solar panel system. It maximises the output of solar energy by adjusting the panel according to the trajectory of the sun throughout the day. It is constituted of basic elements like LDR sensors, Arduino UNO, and servo motors for the movement of the panel. The panel is designed to move horizontally from east to west and in a vertical direction, north and south. This helps the system receive maximum solar energy, giving maximum output. Compared to a typical fixed solar panel, the proposed system has 40-50% more output energy. It is an overall costeffective, reliable, and expandable solar system.

title: XAI Powered Social Network Analysis for Improved Friend Recommendation and False News Detection
authors: Sangamithrai K, Ravi Prasad G, Rahul L, Anbarasu S
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Social networking websites possess a profound im- pact on peer relationships and information exchange between users of information. This project has a dual purpose, delivering an XAI-inspired system that is intended to perform two basic tasks, namely friend suggestion based on social graph analysis and disinformation discovery within online content. To enable the recommendation of acquaintances, the system uses advanced graph-oriented method algorithms like Graph Attention Networks (GAT), Graph Convolutional Networks (GCN), and Node2Vec from the domain of machine learning, each trained on actual Facebook network data. These models help uncover potential connections by examining the structural properties of the social network. The project component related to detection of disinformation uses Natural Language Processing (NLP) meth- ods, particularly transformer-based models such as BERT, to ascertain social media content credibility from annotated Twitter datasets. For transparency while making decisions, techniques from explainable artificial intelligence (XAI), like SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations), are employed. Furthermore, LIME (Lo- cal Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanations) is utilized, allowing human-understandable and interpretable visual explanations insights into the behavior of the models. To find the functioning of the models, metrics such as accuracy, recall, F1-score and precision are used. Comparative graphical analysis shows the most efficient frameworks for a number of tasks. The whole solution is built in a single notebook environment, encouraging constant improvement and clarity. Such blending of intelligibility in social networking Analytics adds authenticity, accountability, and trustworthiness to the digital interaction system.

title: Hierarchical Scheduling and Resource Optimization in NOMA-Enhanced Smart Grid Edge Networks
authors: Wenxiong Mo, Jiantao Zheng, Junhao Li, Kunxiang Lin, Yifan Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: The increasing penetration of distributed renewable energy and the growing demand for intelligent grid management have brought significant challenges in achieving low latency, high reliability, and energy-efficient task processing in modern power systems. Multi-unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) edge computing systems, especially those enhanced by non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA), provide new opportunities for supporting smart grid applications such as real-time fault detection, line inspection, emergency restoration, and wide-area monitoring. In this paper, we study the hierarchical scheduling and joint optimization of UAV trajectory, task offloading, transmit power, and onboard computing resources in NOMA-enabled UAV-assisted smart grid networks. The problem is formulated as a high-dimensional mixed-integer nonconvex optimization, and we propose a reinforcement learning framework that leverages the asynchronous advantage actor–critic algorithm with a hybrid action representation combining discrete and continuous variables. The framework adopts constraint-aware reward shaping to ensure compliance with energy, latency, and UAV mobility requirements while effectively balancing system cost and computational performance. Simulation results show that the proposed method achieves notable gains in latency reduction, energy savings, and resource efficiency, making it a compelling solution for next-generation smart grid infrastructures.

title: Development of an Interactive AI Mentor: A Full-Body Digital Human for Real-Time Conversational Learning
authors: Arnav Atkare, Aniket Bhoyar, Om Akre, Om Bhosle, Tanmay Tembhurne, Sanket Bhanuse
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: The convergence of natural language processing, speech technologies, and 3D rendering enables the creation of digital humans that feel interactive [1]. This work presents an AI Avatar Mentor, a full-body digital tutor that engages learners in real time with knowledge-aware responses expressed through synchronized speech, gaze, and gestures. The architecture integrates low-latency audio, Gemini for reasoning, ElevenLabs for speech, and Ready Player Me/Blender for avatar rendering. Beyond question answering, the system supports dynamic multi-subject explanations, adapts instructional style, and incorporates interactive 3D models via the Sketchfab API to simplify complex concepts. Grounded in Cognitive Load Theory, the design aims to reduce mental effort and enhance understanding. Evaluation using knowledge gain, NASA-TLX, SUS, and UES shows improved learner retention and satisfaction over text-only baselines while maintaining sub-2 s median latency. Design trade-offs, ethical aspects, and scalability considerations are also discussed [5].

title: Enhanced Hybrid Deep Learning Model for Cybersecurity Threat Detection Using CNN-Bi-LSTM and Feature Optimization
authors: Rajendran Satheeskumar, Namburi Teja, Kopparapu Siva Hemanth Kumar, Jalukuri Gopi, Vipparla Chetan, Yalla Jeevan Nagendra Kumar, Dodda Venkata Reddy
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: During the age of high-speed digital advancement, cyber threats increase not merely in numbers but also in complexity, threatening contemporary networks significantly. This article presents an optimized hybrid deep learning approach that combines CNN, Bi-LSTM, and PCA to improve intrusion detection. Unlike previous methods based on computationally intensive algorithms like IPSO or ATFDNN, the new method focuses on effective feature selection and real-time responsiveness without sacrificing detection capability. PCA is used to compress feature dimensions, enhancing computational speed, while the CNN and Bi-LSTM layers collaboratively learn many features of network traffic. The model is trained on CICIDS2017 dataset, simulating realistic traffic scenarios. Experiment results reveal an extremely high detection accuracy of 98.2%, which surpasses most of the current models in terms of classification performance as well as false alarm rates reduction. The work introduces a scalable and practical IDS framework well-applicable to real-world dynamic cyber security environments like industrial IoT, smart cities, and critical infrastructure networks.

title: Blockchain Inspired Key Lineage Framework for Secure Linux Image Builds
authors: Niranjan UV, Dirk Herrendorfer
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Ensuring the authenticity and origin of Linux image builds has become essential for keeping today's software supply chains secure. Securing keys which are part of Linux image during the build process is crucial for protecting sensitive data and ensuring compliance with privacy standards such as the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). Traditional build systems protect individual keys but provide no cryptographic continuity or auditability between them. This paper presents a new and secure block chain inspired system that employs encrypted key management alongside secure build environments where the keys used in the build process and the keys inserted to the Linux image are cryptographically linked to its predecessor. To minimize the risk of key leakage, key rotation and environment isolation are implemented to enforce strict access controls. The resulting chained key lineage embedded to the Linux image can be verified for authenticity and provenance without relying on external trust anchors. The proposed approach enhances trust; accountability and compliance in software build lifecycle providing a robust foundation for maintaining the keys.

title: IoT-Enabled Street Light System with Adaptive Brightness and Fault Detection for Smart Cities
authors: K Sasirekha, Ganesan V, Gayathri M, Gokulnath. R
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: The proposed study will present a scalable design of Internet of Things architecture, which is energy efficient and will run under smart city framework-controlled street light management. The proposed Sources intelligence operations are sensor-controlled. The proposed Sources intelligence sensor-controlled operations initiative, which is powered by LoRa, handles Cloud analytics to greatly increase the standards of energy conservation and operational intelligence. The system developed reduces the amount of power used to 660 W/hr and exceeds the traditional systems which consume 780 W/hr of power. The reliability of the system in the transmission of data is good because it has been able to transmit 98.5 percent of all packets during real-time operation. The design facilitates automatic fault detection and translucent deployment and adjustable brightness using ambient and movement related data. The outcomes of experiments with the new one make the experts of the industry believe - it leaves its predecessors, through increased energy efficiency and speed and through the accuracy with which it conducts the processes of communication. The solution is involved in the creation of a sustainable urban infrastructure that addresses the needs of smart cities and aims at sustainable development.

title: Evaluating Cyber Risk Insurance Frameworks: Bridging Cybersecurity Threats with Financial Risk Strategies Through Actuarial Modeling and Adaptive Resilience
authors: Hemant Nagesh Dusane, Mandar Karyakarte
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: Cyber risk has emerged as a major financial and operational issue, with organizations getting increasingly vulnerable to cyber threats as a result of the rapid digitalization of organizations. Cyber insurance that was once considered an additional protection has taken a new look as a key risk management mechanism. Nevertheless, the process of converting intricate and dynamic cyber threats into the numbers that can be assessed and calculated in monetary terms is still a challenge to insurers and businesses. This paper examines 10 major academic and industry models to assess the effectiveness of the existing cyber insurance models in assessing, pricing, and mitigating the cyber risks. The main limitations, as discovered, are the unavailability of standardized data on incidents, limitations of traditional actuarial techniques, and the inadequacy of integrating technical, human, and organizational factors. Possible solutions to dynamic risk quantification involve the emerging approaches adaptive underwriting (SECURE), Bayesian risk modeling, and machinelearned predictions.[21] The results indicate that there should be open data reporting, standard loss measures and interdisciplinary models between cybersecurity and finance. The paper concludes with realistic suggestions on how to increase the accuracy of underwriting, claims management, and compliance towards a robust and futureproof cyber insurance ecosystem.

title: Hybrid Neural Network-Based Virtual Weighing for Wheat Proportioning
authors: Mingen Jia, Guan Wang, Ruonan Li, Yongqiang Yuan
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: As a core metering device, the wheat proportioner enables precise control of wheat blending ratios. However, existing proportioners often fail to meet industrial accuracy requirements. Mainstream approaches suffer from high costs, limited precision, and vulnerability to environmental disturbances. To address this limitation, we propose a hybrid neural network-based virtual weighing framework. It leverages latent operational patterns in equipment data to achieve high-precision discharge weight estimation. The framework integrates three collaborative modules. The 1D Convolutional Neural Network (1D-CNN) handles transient event detection. The Backpropagation Neural Network (BPNN) performs global nonlinear regression. The Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) compensates for device state drift. By relying solely on readily available signals (e.g., motor current, voltage) from existing Programmable Logic Controller (PLC) systems, the framework achieves high-precision online estimation of discharge weight for target wheat proportioners without requiring internal metering units or auxiliary sensors. Experimental validation in a real-world production environment demonstrated that the estimation error was reduced to one-tenth that of volumetric proportioners, achieving accuracy comparable to gravimetric systems while incurring negligible additional hardware costs.

title: RFID based Smart Shopping Cart
authors: R. Gowrishankar, Darsini K, Shelsia Sharon K, Sruthika P
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: This work has developed an RFID-based Smart Shopping Cart to improve the overall retail shopping experience. Most traditional billing systems have relied on barcode scanning and physical checkouts to find the total cost of a customer's items. These traditional methods of manual processing will often slow down the process at checkout and are prone to human error. The presented system integrates RFID technology with an ESP32-based microcontroller to automatically detect items and their prices, continuously updated onto an LCD display, with total charges calculated instantly. There is a 'cancel' option that allows a customer to remove an item they wish to not purchase throughout the checkout process. In addition, there is also a QR-based payment method for fast, cashless payments. Experimental results indicated the proposed system reduced checkout time by almost 70% compared to the traditional checkout methods. The proposed system enhances billing accuracy, reduces human effort, and is overall a promising practical approach towards establishing advanced smart, automated shopping experiences.

title: A Prediction Model for Dissolved Gases in Transformer Oil Based on ASVMD-GRU-GCN
authors: Chenlei Hu, Qingwei Gao, De Zhu, Liangliang Hu, Zheng Xia, Changsheng Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Measurement Control and Instrumentation (MCAI)
abstract: Accurate prediction of dissolved gas concentrations in transformer oil is crucial for maintenance, yet existing methods often overlook correlations between gas components. This paper proposes a novel model combining Successive Variational Mode Decomposition with a Gated Recurrent Unit-Graph Convolutional Network. The method optimizes Successive Variational Mode Decomposition parameters via minimum envelope entropy for noise reduction, while the hybrid network captures both temporal patterns and inter-gas relationships. Experimental results demonstrate significantly superior prediction accuracy over benchmarks, providing an effective tool for intelligent transformer operation and maintenance.

title: Blockchain-Supported Adaptive Hash Verification for Resilient Healthcare Data Integrity
authors: R. Gayathri, Inderpreet Kaur, Pooja Nayak S, Sunil Dhankhar, GB Renuka, T. Karthikeyan
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: To preserve the validity and integrity of patient information, electronic health records (EHRs) in dangerous contexts require advanced fraud detection and authentication methods. This is significant to protect malicious alterations from organized clinical fields of data. By including deep hash fingerprinting, blockchain-supported provenance management, and semantic-preserving transformer embeddings, the adaptive Adaptive Anomaly-Driven Hash Verification (AADHV) architecture ensures document integrity from the beginning to the end. The system was simulated using databases that were formatted based on Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources (FHIR). It was subjected to insertions and deletions, as well as field-level modifications. The AADHV performed better than baseline machine learning-based cryptography and verification models with a temporal consistency index of 96.82% and area under the curve (AUC) of 0.985. Cryptographic traceability of versions of documents over time was guaranteed through the combination of version-aware hash signatures with contextual embeddings. This facilitated drift detection at the granular level and field-level localization of anomalies. The experiments demonstrated low verification latency with inference times kept at an average of 210 ms per document. The results also reflected the fact that the system was more robust to structured adversarial manipulation.

title: Low-Profile Monopole Antenna Design with Bandwidth Optimization for UWB Communications
authors: A. S. I. Amar, Y. M. Madany
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Telecommunications and Artificial Intelligence (IC-FTAI)
abstract: This study presents the design and analysis of an ultrawideband (UWB) antenna tailored for modern wireless communication applications. The proposed antenna employs a microstrip-fed semicircular monopole configuration featuring a modified stepped microstrip feedline and a semicircular ground plane on the reverse side. By evolving from a basic antenna structure with a rectangular radiating patch, feedline and ground, the design achieves a significantly enhanced impedance bandwidth ranging from 2.5 to 14.5 GHz-effectively covering the entire UWB spectrum as defined by the FCC (3.1-10.6 GHz). Comprehensive performance evaluations, including reflection coefficient analysis, radiation patternd, and assessments of gain and efficiency, validate the antenna's effectiveness across the targeted frequency band. Additionally, a four-element MIMO configuration is explored, demonstrating favorable results in terms of isolation, diversity gain, and overall system performance, making it well-suited for UWB applications.

title: A Hybrid Framework for Personalized Learning Path Optimization Integrating Learner Preference and Blended Modality Exposure
authors: Bhavani M, Jaeyalakshmi M, Maheswari R J, Kishore K
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: This study outlines the development of personalized VARK based learning path for every learners. Traditional "one-size-fits-all" approach fails to consider each learners preference and this leads to poor educational outcome. This paper proposes Lurniq, a platform that creates custom learning path for every learners. The platform begins with a demographic categorization (young, middle school, university, adult) to deliver age appropriate content and a "cold start" mechanism that introduces learners to material from all four VARK styles (Visual, Auditory, Read/Write, Kinesthetic). While learners navigate the instructional system, their behavioral data (such as how engaged they were and what they created with the learning material) are collected. This behavioral data, combined with a questionnaire, is used to drive the hybrid AI model that utilizes and combines a deep neural network and a tree based ensemble into a model that can accurately predict the learner’s preferred VARK style. The final prediction created through a weighted average of both approaches serves as the instructional system’s way to modify the learner’s pathway dynamically, from a broad multi-feature engaging approach to a personalized pathway weighted toward the learner’s preferred VARK style.

title: Emotion Segregation and Analysis of Social Media Comments using Artificial Intelligence
authors: Nirzar Kulkarni, Kireet Joshi, Vishwanath Narayan Revankar, Patik Patel, Harshal Patil, Mahesh Kumar A S
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Emotions are a huge part of the human experience, and one of the ways they are described is as a complex combination of reactions that sometimes are combined with or confused with mood or feelings. We live in a participatory digital era, where global access to the internet and mobile devices is now ubiquitous. The rise of social networks has resulted in a flood of digital data, transforming online content such as blogs, opinions, tweets, and posts into important assets for governments and organizations looking for strategic insights. Businesses must process and analyze these opinions to obtain valuable business insights. Recognizing the emotional content of human-generated text or speech is a significant difficulty in the field of human-machine interaction. This article calls for an Artificial Intelligence (AI) method for automatically detecting human emotions. The comparison analysis reveals the Bi-LSTM model's excellent performance in a multi-classification task such as seven emotions, with the most fantastic accuracy of 97.81%.

title: Real-Time Household Electricity Consumption Prediction and Energy Management with the Help of Machine Learning Models Combination
authors: Raghavi S, Fathima Rania M, Haripriya V
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Household electricity consumption forecasting has become a critical part of modern energy management systems for efficient use of the available resources, demand side management and cost reduction. We present a machine learning based system to forecast the household's hourly energy consumption and trigger an alarm signal if this consumption exceeds a threshold. The data set is hourly with usage profiles, temperature, relative humidity, occupancy and temporal features, which have been preprocessed in such way that they model short term fluctuations as well as long term consumption tendency. Our predictive models are heterogeneous and they include Linear Regression to predict the trend of the baseline, Logistic Regression to classify whether the threshold was reached and Long Short Term Memory (LSTM) networks to organize sequential dependencies in time-series data. Lastly, ensemble method is a combination of all of these to make them more accurate and predictive. It predicts the usage of the next hour and also counts the total import on a daily basis according to the thresholds set and sends alarms and automated emails if the thresholds were exceeded. The experimental results suggest that the proposed LSTM model has better performances in terms of accuracy in the temporal dynamics, and the proposed ensemble model provides a higher level of reliability in using the concurrent advantage of the individual models. The framework proposed in households allows to monitor the consumption in real time, alert on abnormal consumption and to propose actions to reduce wastage. The proposed methodology, which includes automatic alert system, contributes to sustainability in energy practice and contributes to the management of the energy efficiency in the demand side in smart houses using the predictive analytics.

title: Integrating Blood Flow Guidance into Seq2Seq Models for Direct Transformation of Ultrasound Scans to Contrast-Enhanced Images
authors: Jinglin Yuan, Yuxuan Yang, Jing Jie
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: There has been a lot of buzz around using blood flow data for AI medical image processing in the last several years. The employment of cutting-edge imaging methods in conjunction with artificial intelligence algorithms to study and understand vascular diseases and blood flow has been the subj ect of a great deal of research two hundred sixty-six A full pipeline for individualized simulation of blood flow inside the liver parenchyma, techniques to improve blood flow imaging performance using XDoppler imaging, and ultrafast frame rate volumetric imaging technology utilizing Row Column Addressing (RCA) transducers are all part of these investigations in These techniques notably enhance sensitivity and contrast-to-noise ratio (CNR) by integrating blood spatial decorrelation statistics with restricted spatial overlap 171 of point spread functions (PSF). Effective methods for researching complicated blood flow phenomena are individualized blood flow simulations, which apply a complete process that includes medical picture segmentation, organ volume reconstruction, numerical simulation of blood diffusion, and more. In future clinical applications, these improvements show how blood flow information may be used in artificial intelligence medical imaging processing to provide more accurate and individualized diagnostic and treatment options.

title: Secure Session Initialization via Quantum and Post-Quantum Key Generation
authors: Md Thouhedul Alam Tonoy, Md Mahbub Gazi, Mannu Baveja, Partha Chanda, Mohammad Yasir Bin Taleb Abrar, Md Fazle Rabbi Moon, Hirok Agarwala
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: When quantum computers become practical the traditional cryptographic systems will need replacement because they cannot protect against quantum attacks. We present QUBE-Crypto as our innovative hybrid cryptographic solution made of multiple protection methods which blend Quantum Key Distribution with post-quantum digital signatures and blockchain technology plus pseudorandom quantum state security challenges. QUBE-Crypto offers QUBE-AUTH as a protocol to secure quantum identity verification and communication processes. The system verifies authentications unbreakably through quantum behaviors and protects communication with Dilithium-5 digital signatures plus blockchain time stamps. QUBE-Crypto offers simple hardware setups and matches the 5 G and 6 G networks which makes it workable across different internet-of-things devices plus lets users send private messages safely and set up digital services without a central authority.

title: Unmasking Backdoors: Generative Anomaly Detection for VLM Poison Samples and Trigger Characterization
authors: Pooja Bandal, Anshul Verma
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: Multimodal Vision-Language Models are increasingly deployed in critical applications, yet remain vulnerable to back-door attacks—maliciously crafted training data that embeds hidden triggers to elicit adversarial outputs. Addressing this threat, we propose a hybrid anomaly detection and generative framework for identifying poisoned samples and characterizing trigger severity in VLMs. Leveraging CLIP and BLIP for rich multimodal feature extraction, we apply Isolation Forests with an elbow-method-optimized contamination threshold for initial anomaly screening. Clean samples guide the training of a RUNet-based generator, which reconstructs “clean” versions of suspected poisoned images. A frozen surrogate discriminator, modeled on the Isolation Forest decision boundary, guides adversarial refinement. The extracted poison—obtained by subtracting clean reconstructions from originals—is analyzed using a Gaussian Mixture Model to classify trigger severity into weak, moderate, or strong. Experiments on the ICIP 2025 challenge dataset demonstrate the robustness of our approach in both poison detection and severity classification.

title: Assessment of UHF Blade Antenna Response to High-Altitude Electromagnetic Pulse (HEMP) in Aerospace Platforms
authors: Venkata Ramana Botsa, Sravani Kurmapu, Mahesh Gopal
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Electromagnetic Interference and Compatibility (INCEMIC)
abstract: This paper presents the EM modeling, simulation and susceptibility analysis to High-altitude Electromagnetic Pulse (HEMP) of Ultra-High Frequency (UHF) blade antennas networks that are integrated into contemporary aircraft. Two key applications namely Navigation/Communication systems and Emergency Locator Transmitters (ELTs) are analyzed. Using CST EM Studio Suite, antenna designs were optimized for performance metrics such as S-parameters/VSWR and gain. HEMP coupling simulations reveal significant differences in induced voltages and currents between the two antenna applications, with ELT systems exhibiting higher susceptibility. The analysis underscores the necessity of comprehensive electromagnetic pulse hardening for mission-critical avionics.

title: EMC design modifications to solve failure of an industrial product due to EFT - A case study
authors: G. Mahesh, S. Dineshmoorthy, Sanjay Baisakhiya
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Electromagnetic Interference and Compatibility (INCEMIC)
abstract: Electronic product designers faces problems to qualify their products in EMI Environment because of miniaturization and compactness in size of products. This increases the complexity of design to comply the product towards the EMI disturbances such as Electrical Fast Transient (EFT). This paper presents a case study of EFT phenomenon with a repeated field failure in an industrial electronic product and compliance solution to the problem. The circuit level design modifications and transient suppression techniques implemented to enhance the immunity of product for Electrical Fast Transient test is also presented.

title: Unified Framework for Multi-Method Image Forgery Detection
authors: S. Giridharan, M. Senthil Kumar, M. Niddeshkumar, R. Naveenkumar, S. Vigneshwaran, K. Madhesh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: Image editing technologies have created extensive difficulties for digital forensics because of their ability to easily modify digital images. Strong precise techniques need to be developed to validate digital content in order to detect image forgery. The contents of this paper involve a review of multimethod image forgery detection systems that combine RGB and LAB colour space transformations with PRNU and DCT analysis and Patch Match Block matching and pixel-level anomaly detection algorithms. This paper evaluates current methods with regards to their capabilities, limitations and suitability for application in media authentication procedures and forensic examinations.

title: A Comprehensive Review on Dataset Pruning for Medical Imaging
authors: Abdellah Sedda, Djamel Gaceb, Fayçal Touazi, Tayeb Benzenati
