publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Innovative Applications (AIIA)
abstract: Dataset pruning has emerged as a critical data-centric approach to optimize deep learning training by identifying and retaining the most informative samples while reducing computational burden. This review presents a recent analysis of dataset pruning techniques applied to medical imaging published during the period from 2018 to 2025. The approaches presented have been divided into four distinct taxonomic categories: instance-based selection, coreset-based methods, difficulty-based pruning, and uncertainty-guided techniques. Our analysis reveals that dataset pruning can achieve 40-80% data reduction while maintaining diagnostic accuracy within 2-5% of full dataset performance. Key find- ings demonstrate computational savings of 50-75% in training time, improved model generalization, and enhanced handling of class imbalance. The review identifies emerging trends including foundation model integration, privacy-preserving approaches, and federated learning applications, while highlighting critical challenges in clinical validation and standardized evaluation frameworks.

title: A Hybrid AI-Blockchain Framework for Predicting Satisfaction and Loyalty in Organic Food Markets
authors: T. Ramesh Kumar, P. Sowmia, Dhanush P
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: This requirement of the organic food products has made it necessary to ensure the determinants of customer satisfaction are better known in terms of the perception of health, affordability, authenticity, and trust. An AI-based system that combines sentiment models, clustering models, Markov Chain loyalty estimation, and blockchain-based trust verification. A very large consumer dataset (structured and unstructured) was utilized, and both MATLAB Simulink and the AnyLogic simulation were implemented to model the dynamic demand-supply interactions. The results of the experiment show that the proposed system proved to be rather effective in satisfaction prediction and loyalty estimation, with a maximum accuracy of 94.7%, FI-score 93.1%, AUC 95.6%, and customer retention 89.8% as compared to the traditional approaches. Consumer confidence was also improved, with blockchain, with 94.2% authentication. The findings support the premise that AI-based sentiment analysis enabled by predictive and trust-checking algorithms could be transformed into a solution concept and an efficient way of boosting satisfaction and loyalty to organic food markets in the long term.

title: Interlaboratory Comparison of Conducted Emissions Using Low-Cost LED Bulb Artifact
authors: Rakesh Roshan, Raj Kishor, M Jaleel Akhtar
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Electromagnetic Interference and Compatibility (INCEMIC)
abstract: Interlaboratory comparisons (ILCs) are critical for ensuring consistency and reliability in electromagnetic compatibility (EMC) testing. This study presents conducted emission (CE) measurements across four laboratories using the LISN method as per CISPR 15. A set of six commercially available 9W LED bulbs—four from reputed brands and two from local manufacturers—were analyzed. Results showed that compliant brands met emission limits, while one local bulb exceeded the threshold significantly. This non-compliant bulb, though cost-effective, was selected as the test artifact for the ILC. Despite minor emission instability, all labs achieved acceptable z-scores (|z| ≤ 2). confirming the viability of using low-cost artifacts with proper statistical evaluation.

title: Federated Multi-Task Learning Using Server-Side Normalized Loss-Based Weighting Method
authors: Truptee Upadhye, Preethi Nanjundan
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Federated multi-task learning is an approach where multiple clients collaboratively train related but distinct models on their local data without sharing it, thereby preserving privacy while leveraging collective knowledge. However, participating clients can have very different data distributions, sizes and quality, leading to statistical heterogeneity. This heterogeneity is a major challenge in federated learning, as noisy or inconsistent updates from some clients can slow down convergence or degrade the global model's performance. MOCHA is a seminal federated multi-task learning framework that explicitly models task relationships and optimizes clientspecific models, while addressing system challenges like communication costs, fault tolerance and client dropouts. In this work, we enhance MOCHA with a server-side normalized lossbased weighting technique that focuses on the quality of client updates. Each client in the federated multi-task setup computes its local training loss, which is sent to the server during communication rounds. The server normalizes these losses across clients and assigns adaptive aggregation weights, giving more influence to clients with lower normalized losses and down-weighting noisy or unreliable clients. This design simplifies client-side implementation because all weighting is performed at the server. Experiments on heterogeneous MNIST and CIFAR-10 tasks show that the proposed method achieves a slightly higher final-round average test accuracy (0.5108 vs. 0.5065), reduces average training loss by approximately 2.6 % (from 1.1148 to 1.0858), and improves fairness by lowering the standard deviation of client accuracies by about 5 % (from 0.3631 to 0.3450) compared to baseline MOCHA. These results indicate that server-side normalized loss-based weighting improves training stability, convergence behavior and crossclient fairness in federated multi-task learning under nonconvex optimization.

title: AI-Powered Candidate Matching System for Skill-Based Recruitment in HR
authors: Karthick K K, K K Ramachandran, Nornajihah Nadia Hasbullah, Suchi Dubey, Arul Kumar Natarajan, Baba Gnanakumar P
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: This paper introduces the Vision TransformersBased Weld Imperfection Detection Framework to ensure an efficient quality control process in the industrial welding. The proposed system combines Multi-Scale Retinex (MSR) with Color Restoration to preprocess images better to detect the welds irregularities in the different lighting conditions, and mRMR (Minimum Redundancy Maximum Relevance) is utilized to select the set of features that will best identify the defects. The main classification engine makes use of Vision Transformer (ViT) with Multi-Task Head that allows classifying both the defects and severity of welds at the same time. The model is trained on PyTorch and PyTorch Geometric (PyG) to provide scalability and efficiency in the training process. Experimental outputs show performance increase as accuracy and precision reaches 92 % and 88 % respectively with low inference time, among other factors, which makes it applicable in the industrial setting in real time. The solution offers a powerful and scalable automated weld defect detection and quality control in manufacturing.

title: Transformer Fault Detection System based on Vibration Pattern using Xgboost Algorithm
authors: G Sophia Jasmine, R Divyashree, R Harinitha, K Sarvesh
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: Stable operation of power transformers plays a very important role in making the electrical networks stable regardless of the fact that faults in the future cannot be easily detected. Power transformers suffer from numerous repeated faults like short circuits in windings, loosening of the core, overheat, breakdown of insulation, and no oil, which can significantly shorten the lifetime and operation of the transformer. The earlier faults are detected, the longer the fault-free operation and the better the maintenance can be guaranteed. A fault diagnosing system for transformers, that combines machine learning and vibration signal processing from multiple sensors is presented in this research. Vibration signal collected using an MPU6050 sensor and signal processing methods is conditioned finally to feature extraction for fault detection since faults are assumed to create quantifiable changes in vibrations. Additional information is obtained through the monitoring of voltage, current, temperature, and oil level sensor. The sensor data is classified into classes by the XGBoost algorithm, selected partly due to being multi-input, high-accuracy diagnosis algorithm for fault detection. This process detects normal functioning and fault conditions and produce predictive alerts.

title: A-Based Topological Search for Trajectory Completion in Sparse Spatiotemporal Data
authors: Peiru Wang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: AIS data underpins trajectory clustering, short-term prediction, behavioral analysis, and maritime surveillance, but signal obstruction, interruptions, and drift often create gaps that degrade downstream reliability. We propose an A*-based trajectory interpolation method that builds a quadtree grid topology from historical tracks, assigns edge weights by transition frequency and heading change, and uses a grid-coordinate heuristic to accelerate search and adaptively complete missing segments. Using AIS from Shanghai’s Wusongkou, we compare against cubic splines, Dijkstra, and BiLSTM/GRU. Across reconstruction error, path consistency, and efficiency, our method achieves lower error and higher consistency in most scenarios while outperforming other graph searches, making it practical for large-scale automated repair.

title: Research on Standardization and Detection Methods for Communication of IoT Devices in Substations
authors: Yuedan Deng, Jiaxiang Ou, Peilin He, Shang Yang, Nan Wang, Zhenghao Gao
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: With the large-scale deployment of power IoT devices, traditional testing methods face challenges such as low efficiency and limited resources in device communication performance verification, batch simulation, and data consistency detection. This article proposes the design of an MQTT protocol device testing module based on OpenXML to achieve batch automatic testing and evaluation of device communication performance; A standardized detection device for communication of IoT devices in substations is studied, and a Docker containerized simulation method for IoT standard sensors in substations is proposed to effectively simulate a large number of devices and solve the problem of resource constraints; Research batch testing techniques for standardized MQTT protocol, evaluate the communication performance and reliability of the tested sensors in the substation IoT; Research and validate serialization detection strategies to improve the standardized detection efficiency of IoT device communication in substations, while ensuring compatibility and consistency verification of data between devices, and enhancing detection efficiency.

title: PASIVI: A Methodological Proposal to Promote Student Disposition and Engagement in Clinical Simulation Environments
authors: Araceli Hambleton-Fuentes, Jesus Alfonso Beltran-Sanchez
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: When learning experiences in a virtual environment are designed to establish a specific challenge, assign a role to the participant, apply critical thinking to problem solving, and provide clear instructions for execution, these experiences become meaningful for learning. This study presents a methodological proposal for educational innovation that utilizes a Virtual Simulated Patient (PASIVI) enriched with the Body Interact simulator. A quantitative study with a quasiexperimental design with descriptive scope was carried out. The study encompasses two measurement points, designated as the pre and post-test, along with the implementation of PASIVI. Nineteen university students collaborated with the project. Before the intervention with PASIVI, students reported mediumhigh levels of disposition toward simulation, subjective norm, and engagement; after the intervention, the reported levels were higher. Although no statistically significant differences were found in most variables, differences were found in the dimensions of confidence (disposition) and academic (engagement). Likewise, it was found that disposition, engagement, and subjective norm are highly correlated and statistically significant. The findings indicate that PASIVI has had an impact on students’ confidence and academic commitment. Efforts are still needed on the part of faculty to systematize educational practices for learning clinical skills. The use of virtual patient scenarios offers a wide range of possibilities, but these must always be well designed through instructional designs

title: A Data-Driven Faculty Appraisal Framework Integrating AHP, TOPSIS, and Random Forest for Fair and Transparent Evaluation
authors: N.Srija, Namitha S P, Shalini C, Sujithra G, Varshini S
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Faculty appraisal is an essential element for continuously maintaining quality teaching, research output, and institutional growth. However, conventional evaluation methods are error-prone, erroneous, and subjective. This paper proposes an integrated web-based Faculty Appraisal System developed on the LAMP stack, with Python-powered analytics and visualization, thus enabling a role-based dashboard for students, faculty, HODs, HRM in-charges, principals, IQAC, and HR/COE, allowing multi-tier verification. The faculties submit their self-appraisal in academic mentorship (40%), research development (40%), and contribution activities (20%), and the students give structured feedback. This system adopts AHP to deduce weighted evaluation criteria in a structured method, thus ensuring consistent and structured scoring. Technique for Order Preference by Similarity to Ideal Solution (TOPSIS) ranks faculty by comparing performances with ideal marks and hence guarantees fairness and objectivity. The proposed models have been integrated with Random Forest algorithms so as to enhance predictive accuracy and analyze historical data for classification, clustering, and performance prediction. EDA has been embedded to automate data cleaning, outlier detection, and visualization through bar and pie charts so that the reliability and transparency of data increase. An automated scoring engine assists growth-oriented decisions and incentive distribution, reduces bias, and enables real-time institutional analytics and adaptive policy refinement. Experimental deployment of the proposed system verifies its robustness in fostering a consistent data-driven process for faculty appraisals, which also points toward a roadmap for institutional excellence.

title: Machine Learning-Driven Diagnostic Prediction System for Early Disease Detection
authors: Loveleen Kumar, Veena Dubey, Rashmi Rajendra More, Sandhya Vasant Gharge, Claris Annie John, S Nagakishore Bhavanam
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Conventional modes of diagnosis usually depend on clinical manifestations, imaging, and laboratory tests, which could obstruct the diagnosis of the diseases in their asymptomatic or early stages easily. To cope with this, Machine Learning (ML) provides strong predictive potentials since such types of medical data are often multidimensional and have significant levels of complexity in terms of which patterns have to be learned. The proposed research is a Machine Learning-powered diagnostic prediction system based on algorithms employing genetic information, diagnostic imaging analysis, and patient records, all analyzed to predict the disease at an early stage using algorithms, including but not confined to Random Forest, Support Vector Machines, and deep learning models. Of these, Random Forest algorithm is unique in terms of its consistency, explainability, and maximum achievement in identifying the levels of diseases risk. Trained using labeled datasets and cross-validated to check generalizability, the predictive model is expected to provide useful insights into future application. This ML based tool will help clinicians make informed and timely decisions, which may transform preventive healthcare because it will change disease management in medicine, from reactive to proactive.

title: Signease: Machine Learning Based Sign Language Interpreter
authors: Laiba Parwez, Hina Abrar, Muhammad Ali
publish: 2025 International Conference on Engineering &amp; Computing Technologies (ICECT)
abstract: Sign Ease is a mobile application designed to bridge the communication gap between deaf and hearing individuals by translating sign language gestures into text in real-time. The system utilizes a pre-trained Mobile Net model with TensorFlow to process gestures captured via the device camera, converting them into meaningful text outputs. Hearing users can respond via speech or text, with spoken words being converted into text using Flutter’s speech-to-text library. The application also features a quiz for learning sign language, chat-based Communication, and profile customization to enhance user engagement. Future improvements include expanding the sign language database, adding multilingual support, and improving accuracy across diverse conditions to promote greater accessibility and inclusivity.

title: Billiards Optimized Depthwise Separable Convolutional Neural Network for Fake User Identification Using MERN Stack
authors: V Chandra Prakash, S M Hari Jaswanth, M Gokulnath, G Senthilkumar, L JabaSheela, S. Balaji
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Computing, Semiconductor, Mechatronics, Intelligent Systems and Communications (COSMIC)
abstract: With the ever-growing exponential rise in digital platforms, user registration credibility is a critical challenge to maintain. Fake users created with duplicated or manipulated textual information, such as names, emails, and identification numbers, have the potential to undermine the security and integrity of the platform. The current paper presents a strong fake user identification framework that incorporates the MERN (MongoDB, Express.js, React, and Node.js) stack for full-stack web development and the Billiards Optimized Depthwise Separable Convolutional Neural Network (DS-CNN-BilOA). It begins with a data capture module, where the user inputs structured textual information—such as name, email, telephone, and discretionary government ID—through a React-based front-end. The input from the user is validated and stored securely in MongoDB prior to the conversion to numerical vectors appropriate for deep learning. The vectors are passed through the Depthwise Separable Convolutional Neural Network (DS-CNN) model, which classifies users into learned registration patterns. With its minimized computational complexity in delivering model accuracy, it is the best choice in real-time usage. For further improvement in the detection performance, the Billiards Optimization Algorithm (BilOA) is employed for hyperparameter fine-tuning. Experimental results are presented, which validate that the proposed DS-CNN-BilOA model has superior performance with 99.21% classification accuracy, 98.97% precision, 99.06% recall, and 99.01% F1-score. Concurrently, this framework is an efficient, scalable solution to fake user identification based on the user input of textual data alone—biometric inputs unnecessary—appropriate for secure, responsive MERN-based platforms.

title: Robotic Search Engine Optimization (SEO) Competitor Analysis Tool for In-Depth URL Evaluation
authors: Hui Ying Huan, Alvindar Singh, Peter ChunYu Yau
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotic Systems and Applications (ICRSA)
abstract: In today's highly competitive digital landscape, effective Search Engine Optimisation (SEO) is crucial for improving website visibility and driving traffic. However, many existing SEO tools lack the ability to provides comprehensive competitor analysis and automated recommendations for SEO improvements. This project addresses these gaps by developing a modular and scalable SEO competitor audit platform that integrates technical SEO audits, competitor analysis, and AI-driven actionable recommendations as well as content analysis.

title: Artificial Intelligence-Driven Fraud Detection in Digital Payment Systems: A Hybrid Machine Learning Approach
authors: Pritibala Sudhakar Ingle, Surekha B. Mujumale, Pranjali Pandhare, Namrata Wasatkar, Pravin P. Hujare, Yashraj Sanap
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: The speed as well as the convenience of digital payment systems have improved global trade but along with that, the risk and frequency of financial fraud have increased as well. This work introduces a hybrid artificial intelligence (AI) framework for real-time fraud detection which combines deep learning models like Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks with supervised learning algorithms like Random Forest (RF) and XGBoost. When this model was tested experimentally on a dataset of more than 500,000 anonymized payment transactions, the hybrid model outperforms traditional fraud detection methods with an Area Under the Curve (AUC) of 0.991 and an F1-score of 0.97. These findings demonstrate how this model provides strong fraud mitigation with low latency and how it can be implemented in banking, fintech and e-commerce platforms. This paper includes future integration opportunities with blockchain and federated learning to enhance security as well as privacy.

title: A Deep Reinforcement Learning Enabled Path Optimization Approach for UAV Logistics
authors: Daqian Liu, Weiheng Fu, Bowen Fei, Wenjie Xing, Shijing Du, Yanji Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: In the field of cargo distribution, unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) is widely used due to their flexibility and efficiency. To address the challenges of complex path planning and stringent energy constraints in urban environments, this paper proposes a path optimization method based on deep reinforcement learning (DRL). Firstly, we formulate a path optimization objective function that incorporates energy constraints, including factors such as flight energy consumption. Secondly, by adding gating coefficients to each attention head to capture local features between nodes and employing gated connections to enhance the model’s focus on key features, we construct a path decision-making model that integrates energy constraints. Furthermore, to address the issue of the UAV being unable to complete deliveries due to limited endurance during task execution, we have designed a path optimization strategy based on a network of charging stations to ensure continuous task delivery. Experiments demonstrate that this method effectively solves the UAV path planning problem in the logistics field, significantly improving energy utilization efficiency while maintaining delivery timeliness.

title: Malware Detection using Explainable AI
authors: S. Kanimozhi, Poomathi Raja L, Praveen Kumar A, Priyadharsan N
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: The cybersecurity landscape is increasingly challenged by sophisticated cyber threats, rendering traditional malware detection methods inadequate. Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning have enhanced detection efficacy; however, their inherent opacity poses challenges concerning trust, accountability, and regulatory compliance. Explainable Artificial Intelligence emerges as a solution by providing interpretable insights into AI decision-making processes without sacrificing performance. This study investigates the integration of XAI methodologies into malware detection systems, emphasizing the critical equilibrium between predictive precision and interpretability. We evaluate the applicability of various XAI techniques, such as LIME, SHAP, and Grad-CAM, within the cybersecurity domain. Furthermore, this paper elucidates the existing obstacles in deploying XAI-driven models and proposes future research avenues aimed at constructing robust, transparent, and reliable malware detection systems.

title: Machine Learning Algorithm Execution Model in Serverless Architectures
authors: David Berbegal-Esteve, Francisco J. Mora-Gimeno, Julian Szymanski, Higinio Mora
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Running ML models in serverless environments is challenging due to memory, storage, and runtime limits. This type of limitation mainly affects the use of neural networks, since they usually require more resources than these environments offer by default. In this work, a solution based on the segmentation of the neural network model is proposed, dividing its architecture into different independent functions. This spreads the workload across separate functions, helping to adhere to constraints without losing accuracy or altering model behavior. From a set of experimental tests carried out in Azure Functions, it has been possible to verify that this modular strategy enables stable execution of neural networks, without errors related to resource limitations and with execution times comparable to traditional monolithic architectures. In summary, the results confirm that a Machine Learning model can be adapted to the serverless environment without relying on closed or high-cost solutions.

title: Performance-Driven Scheduling of Independent Tasks in Heterogeneous Computing Systems
authors: CH. Rushikesh, D. Sri Sai, D. Naveen Reddy, R. Karthikeyan, M.A. Jabbar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: Effective task scheduling in high-performance computing is challenging, particularly when distributing independent tasks across heterogeneous processors with varying capacities and execution times. Ensuring balanced load and minimizing makespan are critical. This paper analyzes and implements several heuristic algorithms Min-Min, Max-Min, Suffrage, List Suffrage, Priority-Based (PB), and Tenacious Priority-Based (TPB) to address these challenges. We propose a Modified Tenacious Priority-Based (MTPB) algorithm, benchmark against traditional heuristics using <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$512 \times 16$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1024 \times 32$</tex> datasets. MTPB employs an iterative reassignment strategy with penalty-driven metrics to dynamically optimize task allocations, improving load balance and reducing execution time. Each algorithm considers processor workload, task priorities, and earliest completion times for efficient resource allocation. Experimental evaluation highlights robust scalability and superior makespan performance. Notably, MTPB consistently outperforms other heuristics, establishing itself as an effective solution for optimizing task scheduling in heterogeneous computing environments.

title: A Robotic Grasping Framework for Railway Cargo Based on an Improved YOLOv8 Model
authors: Shiyu Xiong, Han Wu, Yunhan Lin
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotic Systems and Applications (ICRSA)
abstract: Railway cargo transportation plays a pivotal role in the logistics industry, particularly in efficient transportation and warehouse management. However, current cargo grasping systems struggle to accurately identify and localize cargo in complex environments, particularly under high-density stacking or cluttered backgrounds. To address these issues, a robotic grasping framework for railway cargo, YOLOv8-SDA (SoftNMS and Deformable Attention), is proposed in this paper, based on an improved YOLOv8 model and depth map processing. The framework first employs the improved YOLO model to extract cargo features from RGB images, enabling identification and localization. Subsequently, a proposed depth map post-processing algorithm is integrated to denoise detection results, thereby improving localization precision. A dataset comprising 1,700 RGB images of cargo in multiple configurations was developed, featuring varying background complexities (simple, intermediate, and challenging) for robust model assessment. Experimental results demonstrate that the improved YOLOv8 model effectively handles railway cargo grasping tasks under high-density, multi-layered, and complex background conditions. Compared to baseline methods, the proposed framework exhibits stronger robustness and real-time performance, significantly improving recognition accuracy and grasping success rates.

title: Utal-Gnn: Unsupervised Temporal Action Localization Using Graph Neural Networks
authors: Bikash Kumar Badatya, Vipul Baghel, Ravi Hegde
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: Fine-grained action localization in untrimmed sports videos presents a significant challenge due to rapid and subtle motion transitions over short durations. Existing supervised and weakly supervised solutions often rely on extensive annotated datasets and high-capacity models, making them computationally intensive and less adaptable to real-world scenarios. In this work, we introduce a lightweight and unsupervised skeleton-based action localization pipeline that leverages spatio-temporal graph neural representations. Our approach pre-trains an Attention-based Spatio-Temporal Graph Convolutional Network (ASTGCN) on a pose-sequence denoising task with blockwise partitions, enabling it to learn intrinsic motion dynamics without any manual labeling. At inference, we define a novel Action Dynamics Metric (ADM), computed directly from low-dimensional ASTGCN embeddings, which detects motion boundaries by identifying inflection points in its curvature profile. Our method achieves a mean Average Precision (mAP) of 82.66% and average localization latency of 29.09 ms on the DSV Diving dataset, matching state-of-the-art supervised performance while maintaining computational efficiency. Furthermore, it generalizes robustly to unseen, in-the-wild diving footage without retraining, demonstrating its practical applicability for lightweight, real-time action analysis systems in embedded or dynamic environments.

title: Diffusion Based Scalable Semantic Communication Framework For Image Compression And Transmission
authors: Namesh Pannigala Gamage, Thanuj Fernando, Anil Fernando
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: Semantic communication for image transmission enhances efficiency by focusing on meaning rather than pixel accuracy. However, existing methods struggle to preserve semantic integrity due to challenges in identifying key content and contextual relationships. To address this, we propose a scalable semantic communication model that prioritizes object-based semantic extraction and dynamic weighting to enhance image representation. The framework detects and extracts objects within an image, assigning significance through a weight map that emphasizes key elements while de-emphasizing irrelevant details. The system dynamically adjusts weights in a weight map for scalable image transmission, adapting to network infrastructure constraints like bandwidth and latency. This ensures only the most relevant data is sent. The weighted semantic representation feeds into a diffusion-based reconstruction model, regenerating high-fidelity images at low bit rates. Experimental results show this approach significantly improves image representation while minimizing transmission overhead, scaling effectively with network conditions. The ability to adaptively control semantic granularity makes it ideal for real-world applications, paving the way for efficient, context-aware image transmission with improved resource utilization and semantic preservation.

title: Comparing Transformer Models for Indonesian Speech-to-Text: Vanilla and Whisper
authors: Ratna Atika, Suci Dwijayanti, Bhakti Yudho Suprapto
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Technological Solutions (ICAITech)
abstract: This study compares the performance of the Vanilla Transformer and Whisper models in Indonesian Speech-to-Text (STT) tasks using the Mozilla Common Voice dataset. The research method involves data preparation using SentencePiece and Byte Pair Encoding (BPE) techniques, as well as model training with spectrogram features. The Vanilla Transformer employs a standard encoder-decoder architecture, while Whisper enhances its capabilities through multi-task learning and noise resilience. Evaluation was conducted using Word Error Rate (WER) and Character Error Rate (CER) metrics. The results show that Whisper, pretrained on largescale audio data, significantly outperforms the Vanilla Transformer, achieving a WER of 0.1732 and a CER of 0.0545, compared to Vanilla’s WER of 1.0033 and CER of 0.6815. Whisper also demonstrated faster convergence and stronger generalization capabilities, making it a more effective model for Indonesian speech recognition applications. This research contributes to the advancement of speech recognition systems for various applications, including service robots and two-way communication systems.

title: Real-Time Threat Detection and Incident Response Using ML
authors: C. Jesifica Cinthamani, R. Manoharan, S. Srivenkatesh, P. Yogesh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: With the rise in complex and evolving cyber threats, the need for intelligent, responsive, and resilient intrusion detection systems has become paramount. Traditional security infrastructures often fall short in detecting real-time anomalies and responding swiftly to attacks. To address these critical challenges, we propose a Network-based Intrusion Detection System (NIDS) that integrates machine learning algorithms for real-time monitoring and protection of IT infrastructures. Our system is trained using the NF-UQ-NIDSv2 dataset, enabling the detection and classification of multiple threat vectors such as port scans, SSH brute force attempts, file integrity violations, and Denial-of-Service (DoS) attacks. Our approach employs a Random Forest model to perform highaccuracy anomaly detection through continuous analysis of system logs and network traffic. Upon identifying a threat, the system autonomously blocks the malicious IP and generates detailed incident alerts for administrators. In addition to threat detection, the system provides robust defense mechanisms, including file integrity monitoring, real-time alert notifications, and user behavior analysis. This ensures not only rapid response but also comprehensive threat management across different layers of the system. Moreover, we implemented the architecture using Python with a modular structure to support scalability and adaptability across varied network environments. Emphasis is placed on automation and minimal manual intervention, ensuring the system can evolve by learning from newly encountered attack patterns. Through this, we aim to significantly enhance the cybersecurity landscape by providing a dynamic, self-learning, and efficient intrusion detection solution capable of defending against modern cyber threats. The inclusion of simulated scenarios for attacks and defenses-such as port scanning, DoS attacks, and file tampering-demonstrates the practical effectiveness and realworld relevance of our proposed framework.

title: Comparison of Q-Learning and SARSA in Allocating Marketing Budget
authors: Andre Hasudungan Lubis, Erna Budhiarti Nababan, Poltak Sihombing, Romi Fadillah Rahmat
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Technological Solutions (ICAITech)
abstract: Q-learning and SARSA are the most popular Reinforcement Learning (RL) algorithms, which have been used for various purposes. In this study, they were utilized in optimizing budget allocation for multi-channel advertising campaigns. A simulated environment was used to model advertising channels, incorporating key performance indicators such as ROI, clicks, impressions, and engagement scores. The results indicated that Q-learning achieved higher cumulative rewards than SARSA, with approximately $9,647,175$ compared to $9,609,927$. This is demonstrating its superiority in stable environments where maximizing highreward opportunities is a priority. On the other hand, SARSA demonstrated faster convergence than Q-learning, with convergence times about 111.06 seconds, favoring its use in dynamic or risk-averse scenarios. Practical implications highlight that Q-learning is better suited for campaigns in stable conditions with ample computational resources, while SARSA is advantageous for dynamic environments requiring swift decision-makings.

title: MCLF: Smart Contract Vulnerability Detection Based on Multimodal and Contrastive Learning
authors: Feixiao Zhang, Yongli Wang, Dongmei Liu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Security vulnerabilities in smart contracts pose a serious threat to the blockchain ecosystem. Traditional detection methods heavily rely on expert-defined rules, leading to issues such as high false positives, false negatives, and poor scalability. Although recent deep learning-based approaches have shown promise, most focus on a single code modality, which limits their ability to capture the multi-dimensional characteristics of complex vulnerabilities. To address these limitations, this paper proposes MCLF, a novel smart contract vulnerability detection framework based on multimodal feature fusion and contrastive learning. The approach simultaneously extracts a Data Flow Graph and code semantic sequences from smart contracts to capture structural dependencies and contextual semantic information, respectively. A dual-branch Transformer architecture is designed to encode each type of feature, while contrastive learning is applied to optimize vector space alignment and enhance intra-class consistency. A masked language modeling task is further incorporated to improve semantic reasoning through multi-task joint training. Finally, transfer learning is employed to fine-tune the model for downstream vulnerability classification. Experimental results on a public benchmark dataset demonstrate that the proposed method achieves precision, recall, and F1score of 91.90%, 92.53% and 92.21%, respectively, significantly outperforming the most advanced vulnerability detection tools and validating the effectiveness of multimodal feature fusion and the contrastive learning mechanism.

title: Adaptive Cross-Modal Detection via Multi-Scale Fusion and Semantic Alignment
authors: Xiang Yi, Tao Lu, Ziyi Wu
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotic Systems and Applications (ICRSA)
abstract: Recent vision-language models (VLMs) have shown remarkable progress in multi-task learning, yet struggle to generalize under complex real-world conditions involving scale variance, visual clutter, and domain shift. To address these challenges, we propose a unified cross-modal framework that combines a novel Multi-Scale Feature Fusion module and a Dynamic Semantic Alignment mechanism. The former adaptively integrates visual features across spatial resolutions, preserving both local details and global semantics; the latter reweights textual representations based on visual context and task demands. Extensive evaluations on four diverse datasets-ships, balloons, pedestrians, and fireworks-demonstrate our model's superior detection performance and robustness compared to state-of-the-art baselines including DETR, GLIP, and RegionCLIP. These results highlight the model's strong cross-modal generalization and make it a promising solution for real-world visual under-standing tasks.

title: Edge-Assisted and Scalable IoT Gate Automation System Using Hybrid RFID-Facial Biometric Authentication
authors: Aman Raj, Amarjeet Singh Chauhan
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: This proposed work focuses on designing an intelligent, scalable, secure gate automation system based on IoT (Internet of Things) technologies, with hybrid Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) technologies, and facial recognition for validation. It proposes an edge-assisted IoT model that combines low-latency local authentication with remote cloud authentication. This model approaches the new cloud-edge model of IoT in the automation domain. Within the system designed, an RFID gate control system authorizes first-stage entry, followed by facial recognition of users through HD cameras interfaced with edge processing Raspberry Pi devices. Doors are unlocked after successful dual authentication, and all cloud logging enables real-time monitoring of activity and system usage. Streamlining the methodology, the integration of diverse safety sensors, servo motors, cameras, and RFID readers was designed and implemented with an MQTT-based communication system with computer vision algorithms. RFIDs and cloud-based elements formed the edge processing model. Edge processing with RFIDs showed latency under 1 sec in diverse settings. The dual-factors control system offers advanced automation and surpasses human reliance compared to legacy systems, and the system performs multitasking with improved efficiency. The system automation paradigm approaches edge cloud processing model of IoT, offering diverse automation in the RFIDs utilized. The ability for multi-gate deployment, obstruction detection, and real-time alerts demonstrates modularity in design and functionality. This indicates unrestricted growth potential in residential, educational, and industrial contexts. This study lays the groundwork for future smart gate automation by integrating intelligent access control in modern infrastructures.

title: Edge and Fog Computing for IoT: Architectures, Applications, and Emerging Trends
authors: Anusha S, Mercy Theresa M, Shobana R, Sathish Kumar N, Anish T P, M Ezhilvendan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: The rapid expansion of the Internet of Things (IoT) devices has produced a new amount of data that requires efficient, low latency, and scalable computing systems. The demanding needs of real-time and latency-sensitive applications cannot always be satisfied with the traditional cloud-centric architecture, which is why decentralized computing paradigms are required. Edge and fog computing have become complementary to each other and they allow processing of data nearer to the source and reduce latency, optimize bandwidth, improve reliability and privacy. This survey gives an insight into the essential concepts, architectures, and key technologies as well as communication models of edge and fog computing. It examines their uses across multiple fields such as smart cities, industrial IoT, medical care, transportation, as well as agriculture and points out the performance measures that are important to the assessment of such systems. Along with that, the paper explains the key challenges, including scalability, heterogeneity, security, and resource management, and lists the emerging trends, including the combination of AI and machine learning, next-generation networks, blockchain, energy-efficient designs, and federated learning. This survey would synthesize what is currently known about edge and fog computing and point out the directions that future research needs to take in order to help researchers and practitioners harness the power of edge and fog computing technologies to create intelligent, safe, and also sustainable IoT ecosystems.

title: Scalable Machine Learning Solutions for Solar Energy Output Forecasting and PV Performance Improvement
authors: Kiran Raj K M, Karthik K Poojary, Aishwarya R S, Shetty Gaurav Jagadeesha, Navyashree M
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: The need for accurate forecasting and management in solar power systems has been highlighted by the quick expansion of photovoltaic (PV) installations and the global transition to renewable energy. This study examines 15 peer-reviewed publications (2015–2025) that use machine learning (ML) for system-level optimization, MPPT, PV power prediction, and solar irradiance forecasting. The research is divided into four areas: ensemble models for short-term irradiance forecasts, deep learning for power prediction, ML-based tracking controllers, and auxiliary applications such as inverter optimization. ML-driven MPPT demonstrates 5–15 % power increases over conventional techniques, whereas ensemble and hybrid ML models attain intra-day forecast errors of about 10%. Lack of publicly available datasets, processing limitations, and sensor accuracy are among the difficulties. This paper provides guidance for the creation of data-driven, adaptive machine learning frameworks appropriate for a range of solar power applications.

title: An Effective Method for Mitigating Polarization Mode Dispersion in Optical Frequency Transfer
authors: Gaoming Peng, Ziang Qiu, Liang Hu, Guiling Wu, Jianping Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: Optical frequency transfer over optical fiber offers remarkable precision and is an indispensable technology for constructing optical clock networks. However, in long-haul fiber links, polarization mode dispersion (PMD) induced by birefringence is susceptible to environmental perturbations such as temperature fluctuations and mechanical vibrations, potentially degrading the system’s long-term instability. To eliminate this limitation, we innovatively develope a theoretical model characterizing the non-reciprocal delay error introduced by the annoying PMD effect. Concurrently, we demonstrate a PMD suppression technique based on polarization scrambling. Experimental results confirm that polarization scrambling, implemented via data averaging effectively mitigates the system’s temperature dependence. More importantly, this approach significantly improves the long-term instability by half an order of magnitude. Our method paves the way for the practical implementation of large-scale networked optical frequency transfer system.

title: Explainable Deep Learning Model Leveraging ConvNeXtV2 for Multiclass Skin Lesion Classification
authors: Jazila Begum B, Jeya Sherlyne P, Mahatishri J, Sam Varghese George
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Utilization of Deep Learning is becoming increasingly useful for assisting doctors with early detection of skin cancer by differentiating the various skin lesions from images. In our study, we compared four common neural networks. The model we used are ConvNeXtV2, ResNet18, EfficientNet and VGG16. We also used the popular image dataset, HAM10000. Data preprocessing included augmentation to ensure balanced contributions from each lesion type. Each model was trained using the empirical cross-entropy loss function and optimized with AdamW. ConvNeXtV2 yielded the best overall results, with a particular emphasis on melanoma detection. Specifically, ConvNeXtV2 achieved highest accuracyon the HAM10000 dataset Grad-CAM was used to visually explain model predictions, enhancing trust and understanding. The results provide confidence that deep learning will be valuable in the future to help physicians make appropriate and timely decisions for diagnosing skin cancer.

title: Improving Outlier Detection with Robust NIQR Z-Score Evaluation Method
authors: P Sudhakar
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Electromagnetic Interference and Compatibility (INCEMIC)
abstract: This paper emphasizes on Performance evaluation of EMC Laboratories by Robust Method rather than Classical Method in Inter Laboratory Comparison (ILC) of EMC measurements. ILC, mandatory requirement in compliance of International Standard ISO/IEC 17025 as part of Quality Assurance, is normally initiated by individual EMC Lab. A comprehensive analysis of Quasi-peak (QP) mode measurement results obtained by ILC of Conducted Emission (CE) as per CISPR 32 using both Classical Method as well as Robust Method is presented in this paper. ILC is accomplished by utilizing Comparison Noise Emitter (CNE) source (150 kHz – 30 MHz) which is widely used for ILC measurements of EMC Test facility. CE Test results and data with estimated measurement of uncertainty reported from seven NABL (National Accreditation Board for Testing and Calibration Laboratories) accredited EMC Laboratories in India are presented in QP mode over the frequency range of 0.150 MHz – 30 MHz under controlled environment. The reported emission is in the range of 64.60 dBμV to 80.40 dBμV for QP mode measurement. A case study of ILC test results is presented in this paper for emphasizing the use of Z-score calculation by Robust Method in order to ensure more accurate analysis of performance evaluation of EMC Laboratories.

title: Pumped Storage Hydropower Cost and Power Modelling and Power Balance Analysis in Multi-vector Energy Systems
authors: Brian A. Macleod, Alireza Maheri
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Environment Friendly Energies and Applications (EFEA)
abstract: An increase in energy storage capacity is required to complement the growing proportion of energy supplied by intermittent renewables in multi-vector energy systems. This paper presents cost and power modelling for pumped storage hydropower (PSH), as one of the potential storage systems that can be used in multi-vector energy systems. The PSH cost and power modelling are required to evaluate the cost, reliability and emission measures of the overall energy system which includes PSH. For cost modelling, this paper examines the relationship between PSH cost and power metrics, focusing on planned projects in the UK and Australia, revealing some useful insights that can be used for initial screening of potential projects. Comparisons are made with recently constructed PSH plants from around the world. Where published cost data was limited, a simplified cost calculator tool was used to model the cost metrics. The paper also presents power balance analysis equations which are needed for evaluating the reliability and emission of the overall energy system. These equations, implemented in MOHRES, predict, for each simulation time step, the state of charge of the upper and lower reservoirs, the pumps input power in case of excess renewable power and the turbines output power when the storage system is in use for generating electricity.

title: PV Plant Installed Capacity Verification Based on High-Resolution UAV Imagery and YOLO11OBB
authors: Shiran Li, Yingyi Yang, Xian Qu, Zhi Xiong, Jiayang Lai, Minghao Liu, Lin Yi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Power System and Energy Internet (PoSEI)
abstract: Aiming at the low efficiency of manual counting and the interference of dense module arrangement in horizontal target detection during traditional PV plant capacity verification, this paper proposes an integrated verification method combining adaptive sliding window cropping and rotated target detection. First, high-resolution RGB images of the PV plant are acquired using an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV). An adaptive sliding window cropping strategy is adopted to solve the problems of low small-target proportion and excessive GPU memory consumption in high-resolution images. Then, a YOLO11OBB rotated target detection model is used to achieve accurate identification of PV modules, outputting rotated bounding boxes containing module position, angle, and confidence. Finally, the number of modules is counted through post-processing steps such as rotated nonmaximum suppression (NMS) and size filtering, and the total installed capacity of the plant is calculated by combining the rated power of a single module. Experiments were conducted on four typical PV scenarios. The results show that the proposed method achieves an average module counting accuracy of 99.61% and a capacity calculation error less than 0.39%. It can provide reliable data support for PV plant operation and maintenance, power grid dispatching, and subsidy accounting.

title: Cognitive IoT-Driven Antenna Optimization System for Dynamic Wireless Connectivity
authors: N.R. Latha, G. Shyamala, Sonal Borase, N. Gayathri, T. Vandarkuzhali, Ashish Rajesh Polke
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: In this paper, a Cognitive IoT-based Dynamically Wireless Connections Antenna Optimization System is presented based on a Hybrid Deep Learning and Reinforcement Learning (RL) technique. The system uses TensorFlow and TensorFlow Agents to optimize dynamically the antenna configurations that enhance wireless connections in IoT networks. The system is able to adjust to changing conditions by use of deep learning to predict network conditions as well as reinforcement learning to make real-time decisions to improve signal strength, limit interference, and conserve energy. The outcomes indicate that performance is greatly enhanced and the hybrid approach is more efficient than the traditional optimization approaches in scalability, adaptability and consuming less resources. The adoption of TensorFlow supports easy training and deployment of machine learning models to maintain real-time adaptability in antenna setup. The present paper presents the potential of cognitive IoT systems to optimize dynamic wireless networks, which potentially provides a viable answer to the increasing need of an efficient and reliable IoT-driven connectivity in diverse and dynamic scenarios

title: Vehicular Network DDoS Defender: Detecting And Preventing DDos Attacks in Connected Vehicles
authors: Azhar Ali Khan, Faisal Hussain, Abdul Majid Soomro
publish: 2025 International Conference on Engineering &amp; Computing Technologies (ICECT)
abstract: Digital links to vehicle networks have revolutionized how transportation works, making the infrastructure and ride better and safer for passengers. However, these improvements have also increased the danger zone by making connected cars more vulnerable to sophisticated cyberattacks like Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) assaults. This paper presents a vehicular network DDoS defender framework. The key purpose of the proposed framework is to efficiently detect DDoS attacks in a vehicular network and timely protect the ecosystems that can target automobiles. We applied different machine learning techniques using the most up-to-date information and benchmarks for the Internet of Vehicles. We trained and tested five commonly used machine learning (ML) algorithms over CICIoV2024 dataset among which the support vector machine (SVM) classifier outperformed all other ML algorithms with $\mathbf{9 8. 2 \%}$ accuracy, $\mathbf{9 7 \%} \mathbf{F 1}$-score, $\mathbf{9 8 \%}$ AUC ROC and $\mathbf{1. 8 m s}$ inference latency. This experimental results indicates that the proposed framework can accurately locate and react to vehicular network attacks that happen in real life.

title: Experimental Evaluation of Examining the Impact of Artificial Intelligence Enabled Skills and Adaptive Competence on Women IT Professionals Career Growth
authors: S. Grace Prasanna, Geetha K Joshi, Debabrata Baral, Manish Kumar Verma, Shrutikeerti Kaushal, Chikati Srinu
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: The dynamic nature of the digital economy has brought about digital skills and adaptive capabilities as key people in determining a prosperous career especially among female IT practitioners. Current methods usually boil down to using traditional talent-fit algorithms and competency analysis methodologies, which, in many cases, tend to undermine gendered discrepancies in the availability of digital training and the problem of career development patterns. To fill these cracks, this paper presents a two-algorithmic model that combines skill profiling and a dynamic competency development. The first algorithm, DigiBloom Mapper, gathers and parses open-access career path data on the Women in Tech Global Dataset that already exists (WITGD) to build a high-resolution profile of women professionals with respect to digital skills. The former output of this system is directly fed into the second algorithm EvoPath Optimizer that dynamically simulates adaptive competencies; resilience, problem solving and innovation capacity and prescribes individualized career growth pathways. WITGD experimental evaluation shows that two-stage process improves the accuracy of prediction of career advancement potential and creates a more equitable, data-driven process of supporting women in the IT career, compared to baseline models, performing higher in adaptability scoring and the prediction of career mobility.

title: NSOA: User-Centric Interference-Aware Load Balancing in Cloud Computing Environment
authors: C Veena, Sunitha Kamireddy
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: User-centric load balancing has become essential for maintaining service quality in cloud-deployed applications, particularly under high interference conditions that degrade system responsiveness. This study addresses the challenge of interference-aware task distribution by proposing a Natural Selection Optimization Algorithm (NSOA)-based load balancing framework designed to enhance user experience in dynamic cloud environments. The proposed method is implemented and evaluated in the CloudSim simulator using the NASA Ames iPSC/860 workload, enabling realistic assessment of heterogeneous cloud conditions. NSOA continuously evolves optimal task allocation strategies by considering execution time, response time, and throughput as key performance parameters. Experimental results demonstrate that the NSOA-based approach significantly reduces execution and response times while improving overall throughput compared to the existing baseline techniques. These improvements indicate that the algorithm effectively adapts to interference patterns and usercentric performance demands. The study’s findings highlight NSOA as a robust and scalable solution for modern cloud infrastructures, offering meaningful contributions toward efficient, interference-aware resource management and improved Quality of Service (QoS) for end users.

title: Low-Pass Filtering Enabled Design of High-Efficiency Broadband Power Amplifier
authors: M. Boumalkha, A. S. I. Amar, Y. M. Madany, H. J. Basherlou, N.O. Parchin
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Telecommunications and Artificial Intelligence (IC-FTAI)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a high-efficiency broadband power amplifier (PA) that leverages a low-pass filtering-based output matching network to simultaneously achieve wideband performance, harmonic suppression, and efficiency enhancement. The proposed PA employs the CGH40010F GaN HEMT device and operates over the 1.0-3.4 GHz frequency range. A systematic design methodology is followed, integrating stability engineering, loadpull analysis, and distributed-element matching networks. The low-pass filter (LPF)-based output matching network ensures both optimum fundamental impedance matching and strong suppression of the second harmonic. Obtained results demonstrate a broadband drain efficiency ranging from 56% to 70%, a nearly flat saturated output power of 39.3-41.4 dBm, and a stable gain between 8.3-10.4 dB across the band. These results confirm the effectiveness of the LPF-based topology as a practical solution for next-generation broadband wireless communication systems.

title: Computational Intelligence for Electric Vehicles: Transforming Mobility through AI
authors: Sudhir K. Routray, Mahesh K. Jha, M. Pappa, K P Sharmila, Jagrati Gupta, Abhishek Javali
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: The integration of Computational Intelligence (CI) into Electric Vehicles (EVs) is very attractive, driving a shift toward smarter, cleaner, and more efficient transportation systems. This study explores the transformative role of AIpowered techniques such as machine learning, deep learning, and fuzzy logic to enhance EV performances. CI also improves energy management, route optimization, battery health prediction, and autonomous driving capabilities in EVs. By enabling real-time decision-making and adaptive control, CI addresses key challenges in EV ecosystems such as range anxiety, charging infrastructure optimization, and vehicle-togrid integration. AI-driven analytics support predictive maintenance and user behavior analysis, contributing to cost reduction and improved user experience. The work highlights current trends, architectures, and future research directions, emphasizing the need for scalable and secure AI frameworks. Through CI, EVs are not only becoming more intelligent and sustainable but are also laying the groundwork for the next generation of smart, connected, and autonomous transportation networks.

title: Self-Supervised Hyperspectral Learning for Leaf Multi-Trait Prediction with Sparse Labels
authors: Chenye Su, Liangsheng Shi, Lijun Wang, Tinghan Wang, Yujie Wang, Jinmin Li, Leilei He
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Accurate estimation of leaf traits is critical for evaluating ecosystem functions and elucidating vegetation–environment interactions. Hyperspectral remote sensing provides a non-destructive and information-rich means for trait analysis, yet its potential remains constrained by the scarcity of labeled data and the limited generalizability of existing learning methods. To overcome these challenges, we propose the Spectral Joint Embedding Predictive Architecture (S-JEPA), a self-supervised learning framework designed to learn generalizable spectral features by predicting target-region representations from contextual spectral information. Utilizing the largest unlabeled hyperspectral dataset to date, comprising nearly 100,000 samples, S-JEPA enables accurate trait estimation with minimal labeled data. Across six representative leaf traits, S-JEPA achieved an average R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.784, substantially exceeding conventional supervised, transfer-learning, and multi-task learning models, and also surpassing another self-supervised baseline, S-MAE, by a small margin. Furthermore, S-JEPA demonstrate superior robustness especially in data-scarce scenarios, efficiently tackling a longstanding field challenge. The learned spectral features revealed coherent inter-trait associations aligned with known physiological linkages, demonstrating that S-JEPA captures biologically meaningful structures rather than statistical artifacts. This study highlights the efficacy of SSL in extracting generalizable spectral features and establishes a scalable framework for multi-trait estimation and ecosystem monitoring.

title: D2S-RSG-SSD: Dual Double-Sampling with Random Sub-Samples Generation for Self-Supervised Real Image Denoising
authors: Xiao Liu, Xiuya Shi, Yizhong Pan, Shuhang Gu, Wei Liu, Chao Ren
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Recent advances in self-supervised image denoising have highlighted the potential of Blind-Spot Networks (BSNs). However, existing methods suffer from three major limitations: (1) Their effectiveness in real-world scenarios is limited by strong assumptions, such as noise independence, which rarely hold in practice. (2) While sampling-based strategies can partially improve performance, BSNs inherently suffer from information loss caused by centroid masking, and removing the blind spot leads to noise overfitting, both of which hinder denoising performance. (3) Sampling-based methods often introduce checkerboard artifacts, yet existing studies typically overlook the fundamental differences between these artifacts and real noise. To address these issues, we propose a novel self-supervised denoising framework, Dual Double-Sampling with Random Sub-samples Generation (D2S-RSG-SSD). To address Limitation 1, we introduce a sampling-based framework that breaks noise dependence by combining Random Sub-samples Generation (RSG) with a cross-paired loss <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathcal {L}_{RSG}$</tex-math></inline-formula>. RSG generates diverse sub-samples with inherent variance, referred to as sampling differences, which serve as natural perturbations to augment training data and disrupt spatial noise correlations. The proposed loss function ensures full utilization of these sub-samples while stabilizing optimization. To address Limitation 2, we propose a Dual Double-Sampling (D2S) strategy with fixed sampling patterns and a dual-branch architecture. This design reduces reliance on pixel-level information and leverages complementary features to mitigate both noise overfitting and information loss. A key advantage is its compatibility with various advanced denoising networks, lifting the constraint of using BSNs in self-supervised settings. Additionally, we introduce a fixed sub-image sampling strategy to prevent pattern collapse during inference and ensure stability. To address Limitation 3, we explicitly differentiate checkerboard artifacts from real noise and develop a dedicated artifact remover to correct pixel discontinuities caused by sampling-based operations. This design preserves fine image details while reducing over-smoothing. Experiments on benchmark real-noise datasets and self-captured noisy images demonstrate the robustness and generalizability of our framework, achieving better performance over existing methods.

title: Sign-Based Privacy-Preserving and Communication- Efficient Federated Learning in Large-Scale Edge Computing
authors: Chenghao Yang, Zhengchun Zhou, Yihuai Liang, Chunming Tang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: The convergence of edge computing and federated learning (FL) is reshaping the technology ecosystem for the Internet of Vehicles (IoV), yet large-scale deployments face critical challenges in privacy preservation, poisoning attack resistance, and communication efficiency. Existing solutions typically compromise privacy safeguards, computational practicality, or communication efficiency. We propose an edge computing-based FL framework that successfully balances these essential requirements concerning privacy protection, poisoning attack resistance, and communication efficiency by integrating three key innovations. First, gradient sign conversion combined with super-increasing sequence compression achieves lossless dimensionality reduction, enabling communication overhead reduction while preserving homomorphic computation capabilities. Second, a user-side duallayer masking mechanism implements privacy protection before gradient transmission. Third, a poisoning-defense strategy leverages the intrinsic properties of gradient signs to defend poisoning attacks across both IID and non-IID data distributions. Security analysis confirms effective protection against privacy leakage throughout the learning process. Experimental evaluations on MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets under varying poisoning attack intensities demonstrate sustained model accuracy exceeding 90% across all attack scenarios. Compared to existing works, our approach reduces communication overheads up to 94.6%, 55% and 80.3% on the user, aggregator and cloud sides, respectively.

title: Open Hardware for Electrostatic Discharge Testing
authors: Dragan Olcan, Jelena Dinkic, Darko Ninkovic, Anja Kovacevic, Antonije Djordjevic
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Open hardware for electrostatic discharge pre-compliance immunity testing is presented. This system is based on a digitally controlled high-voltage source featuring a custom-designed step-up transformer, a capacitive voltage multiplier, and an innovative printed pulse shaper. The voltage multiplier consists of a cascade arrangement of capacitors and diodes, allowing it to provide a constant output voltage in the range from −15 kV to 15 kV for the pulse shaper in accordance with the IEC 61000-4-2:2025 standard. The high-voltage source is designed for burst outputs, capable of stepping up constant voltages from 5 V to ±15 kV. The novel pulse shaper, printed on FR4 substrate, was designed and optimized using circuit analysis and full-wave electromagnetic solvers to generate standard current pulses for contact electrostatic discharges. Measurements, verified in an accredited electromagnetic compatibility laboratory, indicate that the proposed open-hardware electrostatic-discharge generator produces the required voltages and contact-discharge current pulses within standard tolerances. The design choices prioritize ease of reproducibility, manual assembly, and the use of widely available components. All production files and accompanying microcontroller software are publicly accessible and released under the CERN Open Hardware License to foster innovation, promote collaborative design practices and enable broader access to electrostatic discharge pre-compliance immunity testing.

title: A methodological framework for optimizing palm-based soap formulations using deep neural networks
authors: Freddy Marcillo, Víctor Huilcapi
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This paper proposes a design framework for palm-based soap formulations that predicts key properties, melting point (MP), fatty acid profile, and cost, with high fidelity and direct applicability in industrial plants. The proposed approach enables accurate cost-performance decisions with traceability, optimizing laboratory testing, and operating within feasible windows. The approach integrates synthetic data generation under technological and process constraints, utilizing multilayer perceptron (MLP) neural metamodels for toilet soap and laundry soap. Validation is performed using correlation analysis, residual analysis, response surfaces, and local sensitivity maps. The four models (corresponding to the property and cost networks for each scenario) converge stably, reproduce experimental trends with minimal bias, maintain mean errors below 1%, and generalize well within the scope of the analyzed formulation. The MP response surfaces reveal a high plateau toward higher solid fractions (RBD palm/stearin) and a depression with increasing palm kernel olein. Sensitivity maps confirm that olein governs C12:0 (lauric acid), while palm stearin dominates C16:0/C18:0 (palmitic acid/stearic acid) and increases the MP, with olein exerting a lowering effect on this property. These findings translate into concrete lines of action in formulations, including anchoring operations on plateaus to gain tolerance to variability, applying stricter olein control in laundry soap, and leveraging flat cost gradient zones to arbitrate raw materials without compromising performance. The proposed framework optimizes experimental effort, shortens the design-validation cycle, and provides a robust basis for extending it to other lipid matrices in industrial settings.

title: A Hybrid Deep Learning Approach with Explainable AI for Diabetic Retinopathy Classification
authors: G. Pradeep Reddy, Preethi Deepak Javali, Ramyashree, S Raghavendra, C B Chandrakala, P S Venugopala
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Diabetic Retinopathy is one of the major cause of vision impairment around the world, yet its impact can be significantly reduced through early detection and timely intervention. Previous screening techniques were dependent on manual detection, which consumed a lot of time and often provided inconsistent results. However, the successful developments in the area of Deep Learning have facilitated the automated and large-scale analysis of the retinal image with better performance. Irrespective of such developments, the use of explainable AI in many studies has received limited attention. This work, provides an extensive analysis of several deep learning models like ResNet18, EfficientNetB0, DenseNet121 and MobileNetV2 for multiclass diabetic retinopathy classification, using a unified training framework with SMOTE-based class balancing to address severe data imbalance. In addition to individual models, both hard and soft voting ensemble strategies, as well as a feature-level hybrid architecture combining EfficientNetB0 and DenseNet121, were systematically evaluated. The proposed hybrid model achieved an accuracy of 84.02%, while ensemble learning attained the highest overall accuracy of 85.29%, demonstrating improved robustness and balanced performance across severity levels. Model performance was comprehensively evaluated using accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and class-wise ROC-AUC metrics, with per-class AUC values exceeding 0.90 for multiple severity stages. Particularly, model interpretability is introduced with the help of Gradient-weighted Class Activation Mapping(Grad-CAM), where visualization in the form of heatmaps of clinically relevant retinal regions is offered. To move beyond purely qualitative analysis, a quantitative Grad-CAM concentration score was employed, demonstrating more spatially localized and diagnostically focused attention in individual and hybrid model representations. Hence, the results indicate that incorporating complementary convolutional neural network architectures, together with ensemble learning and quantitative explainability, yields a more robust, interpretable, and clinically relevant diabetic retinopathy screening framework.

title: Efficient Off-Grid Near-Field Cascade Channel Estimation for XL-IRS Systems via Tucker Decomposition
authors: Wenzhou Cao, Yashuai Cao, Tiejun Lv, Mugen Peng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Signal Processing
abstract: Accurate cascaded channel state information is pivotal for unlocking the transformative capabilities of extremely large-scale intelligent reflecting surfaces (XL-IRS) in next-generation wireless networks. However, the expansive aperture of XL-IRSs induces spherical wavefront propagation due to near-field (NF) effects, complicating cascaded channel estimation. Conventional dictionary-based methods suffer from cumulative quantization errors and prohibitive computational complexity, particularly in practical uniform planar array (UPA)-structured array systems. To overcome these issues, we firstly propose a tensor modelization method for NF cascaded channels by exploiting the tensor product among the horizontal and vertical response vectors of the UPA-structured base station (BS) and the incident-reflective array response vector of the IRS. This tensor structure leverages the spatial characteristics of cascade channel, enabling independent estimation of the factor matrices to improve channel estimation efficiency. Meanwhile, to avoid quantization errors, we propose an off-grid cascaded channel estimation framework based on sparse Tucker decomposition. Specifically, we model the received signal as a Tucker tensor, where the sparse core tensor captures path gain-delay terms and three factor dictionary matrices are spanned by the BS array responses and the NF IRS array responses. Then, we formulate a sparse core tensor minimization problem with tri-modal logsum sparsity constraints to tackle the NP-hard challenge. Finally, the estimation method is further accelerated through higher-order singular value decomposition preprocessing, combined with the majorization-minimization strategy and a tailored tensor over-relaxation fast iterative shrinkage-thresholding technique. To evaluate the proposed algorithm, we derive the Cramér-Rao lower bound and conduct the convergence analysis. Simulations demonstrate that the proposed scheme achieves an 13.6 dB improvement in terms of the normalized mean square error compared to benchmark methods with significantly reduced runtime.

title: Facial Image-Based Diagnosis of Autism Spectrum Disorder Using an Ensemble Deep Learning Approach
authors: Siva Shankari B, Velammal B.L, Thenmozhi N, Suhandha Sahana S
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Identifying Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) at an early stage is crucial for ensuring timely intervention and effective management, which can significantly improve the quality of life. Conventional diagnostic methods are time-consuming and lack objectivity, pointing towards the urgent need for automated and non-invasive methods. This study investigates deep-learning facial analysis for ASD classification using four models: EfficientNet B7, ResNet50, Vision Transformer (ViT), and an ensemble model. Each model was trained on the ASD facial image training dataset for key aspects of facial features that influenced the classification with Grad-CAM. The results showed that EfficientNet B7 gave an accuracy of 86%. The ensemble model had the highest recall result, making it the most reliable classifier. The results show the possibility of enhancing ASD diagnosis with deep learning and explainable AI (XAI)

title: AI-Driven Audiobook Production: Advancements, Challenges, And Future Directions
authors: Viraj Walavalkar, Nishant Desale, Yashraj Dhole, Janvi Sawalkar, Pranjal Pandit, Anuradha Yenkikar
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: This work is a detailed study and deployment of an AI-based audiobook production system utilizing Natural Language Processing (NLP) and cutting-edge speech synthesis technology. The system converts PDF-based literary works into emotive, character-based audiobooks through the use of cuttingedge tools like LLaMA 3 for dialogue attribution and ElevenLabs' Text-to-Speech (TTS) APIs for emotional voice rendering. A Flaskbased backend coupled with a React frontend controls the automated pipeline, ranging from text extraction with PyPDF2 to audio compilation with PyDub. An overview of 20 recent research papers showcases the advances in deep learning, emotional speech synthesis, and voice cloning but also outlines challenges in multilingual generalization, emotional subtlety, and ethical control.
