Performance of the system shows enhancements in production efficiency, personalization, and accessibility, in particular cutting down audiobook generation time from days to minutes. Results of evaluation validate improved user engagement with dynamic character voice and smooth narration. Although highlighting the potential of AI to transform audiobook production, the work also covers ethical issues related to voice cloning, deepfakes, and copyright. Future research targets incorporation of adaptive storytelling, emotion-aware synthesis, and human-AI collaborative narration. This project represents a step towards making audiobook production more inclusive, scalable, and engaging through the collaboration of NLP and generative AI.

title: Federated Learning and Blockchain-Enabled IoT Framework for Next-Gen Human Resource and Hybrid Portfolio Management
authors: N.Rajesh Kumar, G. Manikandan, Revati Ramrao Rautrao, Ammupriya A, K.Rajesh Kumar, Raghumandala Devi
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: The convergence of the Internet of Things (IoT) and Human Resource Management (HRM) has transformed workforce analytics, employee engagement, and operational effectiveness. Despite these advancements, issues like data privacy, security, and real-time decision-making continue to be an issue. This paper introduces a novel approach that converges IoT -based HRM with next-generation quality management and hybrid portfolio management through Federated Learning (FL) and Blockchain technology. The envisioned framework utilizes IoT -based intelligent devices for real-time data gathering, FL for decentralized AI model training without privacy loss, and Blockchain for secure, tamper-proof data storage and transparency. By combining these technologies, the system improves workforce management, enhances decision accuracy, and optimizes financial and resource allocation strategies. Experimental results show improved HRM efficiency, minimized security vulnerabilities, and enhanced workforce productivity. The proposed framework is a groundbreaking solution to modern-day HRM problems and does not violate the data protection legislation. This initiative paves the path to a secure, intelligent, and evidence-based HR culture as per emerging business demands.

title: Adaptive Fault Response Technology for Transient Stability of Multi-Inverter Systems Supporting Active Synchronization of Clusters
authors: Xiankui Wen, Mingjun He, Yang Fang, Mu Ren, Yong Wang, Biao Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Control and Computing Science (ICICCS)
abstract: To address the transient instability issues in multi-inverter clusters, an adaptive fault response control technology based on feasible region analysis is proposed. A transient stability region model for inverter clusters is established, and a fast feasible region solving method using support vector machine (SVM) boundary fitting is developed, reducing query time from seconds to milliseconds. A dual-driven active-reactive power coordinated control strategy based on stability margin and fault severity is designed. An improved NSGA-II parameter optimization method under transient stability constraints is proposed. An offline-online collaborative hierarchical control framework is constructed. Simulations of a 20-inverter cluster demonstrate that the proposed method improves stability margin by 37.8%, reduces recovery time by 48.6%, and decreases power imbalance by 65.2% under severe faults. Hardware-in-the-loop tests validate engineering feasibility.

title: Transition of Isolated Communities to Net-zero: Case of El Pinar on El Hierro in the Canary Islands
authors: Imam Abed, Alexander De Leon Castano, Alireza Maheri
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Environment Friendly Energies and Applications (EFEA)
abstract: This paper details the optimisation of a standalone Hybrid Renewable Energy System (HRES) for El Pinar, a small community on El Hierro in the Canary Islands, which is disconnected from the mainland electricity grid. Currently, the island’s electricity generation primarily relies on fossil fuels. Aligned with the energy transition strategy to decarbonise the island by 2040, this study focuses on transforming El Pinar’s energy system to a more sustainable model. The studied energy transition scenario in this paper aims to replace the diesel generation that currently supplies 58% of El Hierro's electricity with a system that leverages the abundant local wind and solar resources. Formulating the energy transition problem at hand and employing the design optimisation software MOHRES, the optimum HRES is obtained. The optimum Wind-PV-Battery solution requires an initial investment of 1.64 m$. It produces electricity 60% cheaper than the current prices and has an annual fuel saving of 16.66 m$, leading to a net present value of 162.40 m$ over the 25-year lifespan of the system.

title: GTOA: Energy-Efficient and Reliable Task Scheduling in Cloud Computing Environments
authors: Santhosh Kumar Medishetti, Manasvi Agrawal, Narayanpet Abhinav, T Sujith Reddy, D Akash, Narmala Vineeth Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: Group Teaching Optimization Algorithm (GTOA) has been introduced in this research as an effective metaheuristic-based approach for task scheduling in cloud computing, aimed at improving system efficiency and reliability. Implemented and evaluated in CloudSim using the IBM Tivoli workload, GTOA was benchmarked against Ant Colony Optimization (ACO), Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), and Whale Optimization Algorithm (WOA). The results demonstrate that GTOA significantly enhances scheduling performance, achieving a $21.4 \%$ reduction in makespan, a $17.8 \%$ decrease in energy consumption, and a $14.6 \%$ reduction in VM failure rate compared to the existing approaches. These improvements highlight the algorithm’s ability to balance exploration and exploitation through group-based adaptive learning, ensuring efficient resource utilization and improved fault tolerance in heterogeneous cloud environments.

title: Proposed Optimized Energy-Efficient Routing in WBANs: A Comparative Analysis of ABC and Hybrid ABC-CSO Methods
authors: Amanpreet Kaur, Prabhdeep Singh
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: WBANs have advanced into efficient opportunities for several healthcare, sports, etc., uses. The examination introduced a method for considering efficient information gathering from individual and predictable networks. Energy consumption (EC) is the main reason in WBANs, especially in implantable sensor nodes (SNs), which are limited in energy and capacity. Several routing method data gathering approaches are discussed to transmit the data from the human body sensor nodes (SN) to the server base station (BS). This research article will define an optimized energy-efficient routing method, and it implements the existing ABC-CSO method to create a crossbreed method for data aggregation in the WBAN. The existing implemented ABC-CSO method has different steps: (i) clustering, (ii) cluster head (Ch) selection, and (iii) data broadcast. It classifies the sensor nodes into clusters and utilizes the ABC approach to select the finest Ch for each cluster. Each node transmits information to its consistent node or channel. Generally, CSO is utilized to encrypt the data packets to the BS. The planned optimized EE routing method reduces EC and handles the energy required by several biosensor nodes. In the future, the experimental outcomes will determine whether the planned optimized EE routing method can manage the WBAN framework while handling the energy and reliability of the network. The implemented existing works simulate a variety of cases to define the superiority of the existing suggested methods, ABCCSO and ABC protocols. The comparison was done with the ABC and ABC -CSO models.

title: A synthesis of methods for accounting for indirect carbon emissions from power systems
authors: Xiaodong Fan, Xin Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Power System and Energy Internet (PoSEI)
abstract: With the gradual maturation of carbon trading markets, the accurate measurement and analysis of indirect carbon emissions form the foundation and prerequisite for achieving a green and low-carbon transformation in power systems. This paper analyzes the sources and characteristics of carbon emissions within power systems, focusing on clarifying the meaning of indirect carbon emissions in power systems and demonstrating the necessity of precise carbon measurement. Building upon this foundation, the paper investigates and synthesizes measurement and analysis methodologies for indirect carbon emissions in power systems. It summarizes existing carbon measurement and analysis approaches proposed in relevant research, comparing different methods based on their principles, advantages, disadvantages, and current application status. Finally, the paper outlines future development directions for carbon emission accounting methods in power systems. The findings can provide valuable references for establishing and refining China's power system carbon emission measurement and analysis framework, thereby supporting the low-carbon transformation of the power sector.

title: Pneumatic Air Leakage Detection and Alert System
authors: A.Sridevi, Kanishka D, Kavya V, Lavanya A
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: In every automation industry, pneumatic systems are essential. Energy loss and decreased efficiency can be caused by even a small air leak or an unanticipated increase in pressure. Additionally, there is needless machine downtime. In light of this, we created a Pneumatic Air Leakage Detection and Alert System to monitor air pressure continuously. The operation is safe and dependable because the system uses a rectifier circuit and a step-down transformer to obtain steady DC power. Together, the sound and pressure sensors keep an eye on the pneumatic line. The information is handled by a microcontroller, and the LCDs display the pneumatic line's current pressure in real time. Through the GSM module, the system will instantly generate an alert message with information about the department name, machine number, and fault status if any abnormal condition—such as high pressure or air leakage—occurs. When leakage is detected, the buzzer will sound. As a result, maintenance staff can react right away to avoid damage to the machine. The general method is easy to use, reasonably priced, and appropriate for industrial applications requiring prompt fault detection and preventive maintenance.

title: Smart Insole Solution to Enhance Comfort and Mobility for Pregnant Women
authors: S. Shanmugapriya, S. Kalimuthukumar, J. Sandhiya, Ramya S, Alagu dharshini M, Mano Ranjan R
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Physiological shifts during pregnancy are linked with edema (fluid build-up), predominantly in the lower limbs, leading to pain in the legs, swelling, and discomfort. While these may be usual events, they tend to be inadequately monitored, which could culminate in maternal anxiety and, if inadequately treated, problems for health. This project offers the possibility of an intelligent surveillance system for the early identification and control of oedema-induced pain in the legs of pregnant women.It utilizes sensors to take measurements of leg circumference, pressure, and temperature to detect unusual swelling patterns in real-time. The information obtained would be processed in a way that would help define the severity of the oedema and give prompt recommendations. The system leverages technology in women's health care to make it comfortable, avoid complications, and facilitate early interventions to result in improved maternal health during pregnancy and also the proposed work aligns with the SDG 3 goal of well-being and good health,contributing to better maternal monitoring and healthcare outcomes.

title: Graph Attention Networks for Authorization in Hadoop
authors: Nadia Battat
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Innovative Applications (AIIA)
abstract: Hadoop is a widely adopted distributed computing framework that enables large-scale parallel processing through MapReduce and relies on the Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS) for scalable and fault-tolerant storage. Despite its effectiveness for big data workloads, securing Hadoop environments remains a critical challenge, particularly with respect to authorization, due to system heterogeneity, unresolved vulnerabilities, and both accidental and malicious user behaviors. Traditional policy-based models, such as RBAC and ABAC, provide structured access control but remain inherently static, lacking adaptability and proactive anomaly detection. Behavior-based approaches can partially mitigate these limitations; however, they often introduce additional complexity into the authorization process. By exploiting the adaptive neighborhood selection and weighting capabilities of Graph Attention Networks (GATs), the authorization process in Hadoop can be enhanced by prioritizing the most influential relationships among users, roles, and resources. This capability enables more accurate detection of unauthorized access while alleviating the limitations of static, policy-driven models. Building on this insight, we propose the Authorization-based Heterogeneous Graph Attention Network (AHGAT), a novel learning-based framework that models the authorization landscape as a heterogeneous graph. Its architecture combines a decision network, which identifies the most relevant neighborhood type, with a representation network that refines node embeddings accordingly. To evaluate the performance of AHGAT, experiments were conducted on a custom Hadoop log dataset. The results demonstrate that AHGAT can outperform conventional graph-based learning models, including GAT and GCN, across multiple metrics such as accuracy, precision, F1-score, and ROC-AUC. Furthermore, we assess its adversarial robustness using the Fast Gradient Sign Method (FGSM). The findings show that AHGAT can maintain stable performance under adversarial attacks.

title: Joint Fragmentation and Crosstalk-aware DRL RMSCA Algorithm for SDM-EONs
authors: Jing Jiang, Yushu Su, Jingchi Cheng, Makoto Tsubokawa
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) is regarded as an effective methos to solve the problems of Routing, Modulation, Spectrum, and Core Allocation (RMSCA) in Space-Division Multiplexing Elastic Optical Networks (SDM-EONs). An excellent design of the reward function can guide the agents of DRL to achieve rapid learning. Therefore, in combination with the SDM-EON scenario characteristic, we propose a Multi-link Fragmentation-aware and Inter-core Crosstalk-aware DRL-based RMSCA Algorithm (MIDRL-RMSCA). In MIDRL-RMSCA, a network fragmentation metric based on multiple links is introduced to measure the distribution of global spectrum resources. Furthermore, for the SDM-EON scenario, the inter-core resource adjacency degree is introduced to achieve space-frequency joint resource perception. Simulation results show that our algorithm outperforms reference algorithms in both blocking rate and spectrum resource utilization. Specifically, it achieves blocking rate reductions of 24.85% and 28.01%, as well as resource utilization improvements of 17.66% and 19.05%, in the NSFNET and Cost- 239 networks, respectively.

title: Impacts on Power Quality by Solar PV Integration in Distribution Networks and Mitigation strategies
authors: Shaila Arif, Huasheng Zhi, Shah Hussain, Nirmal-Kumar C. Nair
publish: 2025 IEEE PES 17th Asia-Pacific Power and Energy Engineering Conference (APPEEC)
abstract: The integration of solar photovoltaic (PV) systems into distribution networks offers significant environmental benefits but also introduces challenges related to power quality, particularly harmonic distortion. Unlike transmission systems, distribution grids operate at lower voltages and exhibit weaker grid strength, making them more vulnerable to harmonic resonance and power quality issues. While most existing studies focus solely on harmonics generated by PV inverters, limited attention has been given to the interaction of PV induced harmonics with other nonlinear loads present in industrial grids. This paper addresses this research gap by conducting a harmonic analysis of PV integration in an industrial distribution network with multiple harmonic sources. Furthermore, mitigation techniques are reviewed, and appropriately designed passive double tuned LCL filters are applied to the network model. Simulation-based case studies are performed to validate the effectiveness of these solutions. The findings provide practical insights for improving power quality and support future planning of large-scale PV integration in New Zealand.

title: Research on Binomial Distribution Experiment Design and Consistency Test Issues
authors: Xiangrong Ding
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: To achieve accurate sample design and precise trial quality evaluation for binomial distribution-type trials, an improved algorithm is proposed from the perspective of mathematical statistics, focusing directly on the study of the distribution of parameter p. This algorithm can be applied to the quality evaluation and experimental design of any sample size test, especially suitable for the experimental design and quality evaluation of small samples. Subsequently, to examine the consistency issue of multiple groups of success-failure trials, an appropriate test statistic was constructed based on the parameter hypothesis testing method for normal populations, fully considering the similarity requirements. The rejection event set was identified, effectively resolving the problem of determining whether two binomial populations originate from the same distribution.

title: EEG-based Neurofeedback Gaming: A Non-Invasive Approach to Improve Sleep in Insomnia
authors: J. Rajeswari, S. Rajesh, C.M. Kalaiselvi, G. Kalpanadevi, R. Kavipriya, M.Saminathan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Millions of people worldwide suffer from insomnia, a sleep disorder that leads to cognitive impairment and decreased quality of life. Brain computer interface (BCI) technology, using electroencephalogram (EEG) signals, provides a non-invasive approach to manage insomnia. This study explores a system where brainwave signals control a neurofeedback-based game designed to assist people in regulating their sleep cycle. EEG data was collected using non-invasive headsets, processed to extract relevant sleep-related brainwave patterns, and mapped to control the interactive gaming environment. The system promotes relaxation and train users to achieve optimal brainwave states that support sleep. Preliminary findings indicate significant improvements in sleep onset latency and sleep quality, with increased alpha and theta wave activity correlating with enhanced relaxation.

title: A Multi-Horizon Machine Learning Model for Sepsis Mortality Prediction in the ICU Based on Early Vital Sign Trends
authors: Irawan Irawan, Rossi Passarella, Jasmir Jasmir, Marrylinteri Istoningtyas
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Technological Solutions (ICAITech)
abstract: Sepsis is a major cause of ICU mortality worldwide, and timely risk stratification is critical for improving outcomes. This study investigates whether models trained on early vital signs and demographics can generalize to external datasets. Using the MIMIC-IV database, we engineered 61 features from seven vital signs and three demographic variables, capturing descriptive statistics and temporal trends within the first 24 hours of ICU admission. We trained four ensemble models (Random Forest, XGBoost, LightGBM, and CatBoost) to predict mortality at 1-day, 7-day, and 30-day horizons. On internal validation, all models showed strong discriminative performance (AUROC $\boldsymbol{\gt } \mathbf{0. 8 0}$ for $\mathbf{3 0}$-day mortality). To assess generalizability, the best model, CatBoost, was externally validated on the multicenter eICU database. The model maintained a stable discriminative ability, achieving a comparable AUROC of 0.7955 for 30 -day mortality, confirming its robustness. However, a drop in classification metrics (F1-Score) was observed, indicating a need for site-specific calibration before clinical deployment. Feature importance analysis highlighted physiological variability (e.g., SpO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> std, SBP min) as key predictors. These findings support developing efficient decision support tools using routinely available bedside data, while underscoring the importance of external validation and calibration.

title: Frequency-Aware Weather Recognition for Transmission Corridors: Spectral Attention with Lightweight Self-Distillation
authors: Yicen Liu, Xiaojiang Liu, Xi Liu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Power-transmission corridors traverse mountainous terrain where fast-changing meteorology (haze, rain, snow, thunderstorms) and cluttered backgrounds degrade visual monitoring, masking early-stage hazards along the line. We study six-way, image-level weather recognition tailored to this setting and propose a spectral-attentive backbone that fuses frequency-domain cues (FFT tokens) with global attention, coupled with lightweight in-network self-distillation for stability and compactness. On a balanced WEATHER dataset we observe stable optimization, discriminative attention focusing on sky/planar regions where meteorological phenomena manifest, and consistent accuracy gains when combining spectral cues with self-distillation. Confusion analysis highlights the expected ambiguity between haze and cloudy, while snow and thunder remain distinctive due to their high-frequency signatures. Ablations show complementary benefits—spectral stems improve frequency selectivity; self-distillation improves calibration—with stronger improvements on deeper backbones, supporting deployment on edge inspection units.

title: Artificial Intelligence for Sustainability: Advancing Environmental, Social, and Economic Goals
authors: C.Thiyagarajan, Tamilselvi B, J.Jayalakshmi, E.Nalina, Kirubhanandan C G, Anita M
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) has become one of the key technologies to facilitate sustainability in environmental, social and economic aspects. AI implemented through machine learning, deep learning and predictive analytics can allow efficient resource management, energy system optimization, waste reduction and mitigation of climate change. In agriculture, precision farming and supply chain optimization are conducted with the use of AI, making the process more productive and less harmful to the environment. Urban planning, transport management, and energy efficiency in smart city projects are based on AI, which enhances the quality of life and social equity. Also, AI contributes to the circular economy and sustainable business practice by optimizing industrial processes and tracking the use of resources. Nevertheless, it also has its drawbacks, as data quality, ethical, technical and regulatory issues, among others are still present and should be considered to allow responsible deployment. New trends, such as Green AI, AI-based IoT, edge computing, and blockchain-based sustainability solutions, provide a positive path toward the development of future studies and practice. The survey gives a broad view of the AI application in sustainability, shows the current constraints, and their research directions, with the major focus on the transformative effect of AI on the sustainability goals of the world and creating resilient, equitable, and resource-efficient systems.

title: Deep learning phase unwrapping method based on convolutional block upsampling network
authors: Yunrui Wang, Xianming Xie, Yifan Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Measurement Control and Instrumentation (MCAI)
abstract: In the processing of InSAR, phase unwrapping is one of the most critical steps. Deep learning neural networks can learn phase unwrapping operations from large-scale phase data, accurately extracting the phase distribution of interferograms, while can balance both phase unwrapping accuracy and efficiency of phase unwrapping to a certain extent. This paper proposes a deep learning phase unwrapping method based on CBUNet. First, the model combines a global attention upsampling mechanism with a salient feature fusion module to effectively bridge the semantic gap between high-level and low-level features, enhancing the fusion capability of hierarchical information. Second, through channel and spatial attention downsampling mechanisms, it adjusts the weights of channels and spatial positions to precisely extract key features. Finally, it employs a channel residual convolution structure to capture dynamic dependencies between channels, strengthening the representational capability of interferogram features. The results demonstrate that the CBUNet can more effectively balance accuracy and efficiency, yielding robust results in phase unwrapping experiments.

title: Multimodal Knowledge Graph Construction and Application in Smart Curriculum
authors: Xiaohua Ke, Jiao Lin, Huiqi Zhu, Xianpeng Lin
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Multimodal knowledge graphs are crucial for advancing intelligent education and adaptive learning systems, as well as for improving educational resources. The complexity of university courses necessitates the fusion of multimodal data to achieve personalized and comprehensive learning experiences. Our goal is to improve student engagement through multimodal knowledge graphs, enabling educators to assess learning behaviors and make effective instructional adjustments, promoting comprehensive talent development.In this paper, we propose a multimodal named entity recognition for textbook illustrations based on explicit and implicit knowledge enhancement. By utilizing techniques such as the ResNet-50 image encoder and visual language models, we first extract image information and global text-image content descriptions from the textbook illustrations. Then, through explicit and implicit knowledge fusion modules, we integrate the local and global information from the illustrations to accomplish multimodal named entity recognition. We conducted experiments on a customized cn-mner dataset, achieving improvements in accuracy, recall, and F1 score compared to current mainstream methods.

title: An Improved YOLOv8-Based Method for Citrus Leaf Disease Recognition in Natural Scenes
authors: Linghui Liu, Weidong Tang, Qiuming Liu, Chao He
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: To address the challenges of citrus leaf disease detection in natural environments, affected by complex backgrounds, lighting changes, and small inter-disease differences, a robust and lightweight detection method, SUW-YOLOv8, is proposed. The model incorporates a SimAM-C2F module to enhance finegrained disease representation and small target detection, while the SPPF-UniRepLK structure expands the receptive field and improves context aggregation. The Wise-IoU loss function is used to simultaneously optimize classification and localization accuracy. Experiments on the citrus leaf disease dataset show that SUW-YOLOv8 significantly outperforms YOLOv8n, with precision increasing by 4.1%, recall by 2.5%, and mAP@0.5 by 2.4%. The overall parameter count increases slightly, maintaining high efficiency and deployment-friendliness, making it a promising solution for intelligent disease detection and autonomous control in agriculture.

title: A Lightweight Hybrid CNN–Transformer Model for Liver Lesion Detection with Cloud-based Deployment
authors: Ragul K, Subbiah R, Sarika K
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: In recent days, liver cancer causes high mortality rate. It is critical to find early detection of the focal liver cancer among the patients. Traditional models use CNNs and transformers, which give low values in accuracy and efficiency. To improve this, the proposed system came with the solution that uses lightweight CNN-Transformer for liver lesion detection and also, the proposed system planned to deploy it in the cloud services. The model integrates a CNN based local feature extraction with a transformer for global context learning, achieving the balance between accuracy and efficiency. Unlike the heavyweight architecture, this model uses optimized lightweight modules making it suitable for training on the resource-limited devices and deployment in cloud services. To enhance the scalability and accessibility the trained model is deployed on AWS infrastructure, such that it can be accessed through the web API in real-time inference. Experimental evaluation on multi-modal datasets, including CT and ultrasound images, demonstrates superior performance with Accuracy 98.4%, Recall 0.97. Precision 0.983 and F1-Score 0.981. The proposed solution improves both accuracy and computational efficiency compared to previous approaches, while maintaining low parameter complexity and fast inference times. By combining the lightweight architecture workflow with cloud deployment, the proposed system provides an upgradable, and clinically relevant remedy for liver lesion detection.

title: Enhancing Urban Object Re-Identification With Part-Aware Transformers and Semantic-Guided Retrieval
authors: Sevda Imany, Alaa Yasser Mahmoud Abdelhamid
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: Urban object re-identification (ReID) is a challenging problem that involves matching instances of objects such as waste containers, trash bins, and crosswalks across different scenes and viewpoints. In this work, we adapt the Part-Aware Transformer (PAT) which was originally developed for person re-identification, to the domain of urban object ReID. To enhance PAT’s effectiveness in this new setting, we introduce four key improvements: (1) a systematic evaluation of data augmentation strategies to boost model generalization; (2) classification-guided retrieval using both hard and soft strategies to incorporate semantic consistency; and (3) latent feature fusion using a pretrained autoencoder to enrich the model’s representational power and (4) using super resolution images. Experiments are conducted on two urban datasets: a challenge-specific dataset recorded over multiple months and the publicly available UrbAM-ReID dataset. Our method demonstrates competitive performance and provides insights into the contributions of each component in improving reidentification accuracy under real-world conditions.

title: Adaptive control for hybrid stochastic delay systems based on LaSalle’s invariance principle
authors: Xianqi Bu, Yunhao Liu, Yuyuan Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Control and Computing Science (ICICCS)
abstract: This study mainly focuses on the adaptive regulation for hybrid stochastic systems with time delays and nonlinear uncertainties. Firstly, by devising suitable adaptive laws, unknown parameters related to system nonlinearities and stochastic perturbations are dynamically estimated. Subsequently, a state-feedback based adaptive control scheme is designed. Employing the LaSalle’s invariance principle, a sufficient condition is derived to ensure that the resulting closed-loop system attains almost sure asymptotic stability. Finally, a simulation example is provided to verify the applicability and practical validity of the established theoretical result.

title: Custom VLSI Framework for Real-Time Video Background Adaptation
authors: Veerabhadraswamy K M, D V Manjunatha
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Real-time background subtraction is essential in video usage such as video surveillance, object tracking, and intelligent vision systems. However, while many implementations are software-based and can deliver on the performance, most implementations struggle to provide the required energy efficiency in moving video scenarios. In this work, demonstrated an example of a custom VLSI framework for real-time background adaptation that achieves performance throughputs, latency, and extensibility using minimum hardware resources. The proposed design has a parallelized adaptive background modeling unit with a hardware-compressed update mechanism to accurately perform background modeling on a foreground object in a complex and dynamic environment. However, accounting for illumination variation, motion blur, and background evolution requires a light-weight adaptive thresholding method combined with morphological filtering modules. The framework was developed and implemented on an FPGA, and then synthesized for ASIC purposes, but allows for real-time processing at full-HD resolution, optimally using less memory and performing at lower power levels than existing hardware and software implementations. Evaluation of the method has been performed, through extensive experimentation, with real-time detection demonstrating significantly improved detection accuracy, and resource utilization compared to existing processes, including but not limited to a reduction of latency up to XX% and energy utilized up to YY% in comparison to our conventional designs. This means advancing the use of custom VLSI methods will continue to provide the frameworks required to realize real-time intelligent video analytics, paving the way forward toward uses of intelligent video analytics in surveillance, autonomous analytics, and edge-based vision applications.

title: Improving Multiple Intelligence Learning Style Classification in E-Learning Using Feature Selection - Sequential Floating Forward Selection (SFFS) Technique
authors: Paulus Insap Santosa, Gerzon Jokomen Maulany, Indriana Hidayah
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: Addressing the growing need for personalized and adaptive learning, this study proposes a machine learning-based approach to improve the classification of multiple intelligence learning styles in e-learning. A dataset of 66 students from the Teacher Professional Education Program at Universitas Musamus was collected from interaction logs within the Moodle Learning Management System (LMS). Input features consisted of 22 behavioral attributes representing access frequency and duration, while the output comprised five dominant intelligence types derived from the Multiple Intelligences Inventory. To address data imbalance and feature redundancy, the Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE) and Sequential Floating Forward Selection (SFFS) were applied, respectively. Six classifiers-Support Vector Machine (SVM), Logistic Regression (LogR), Random Forest (RF), Gradient Boosting (GB), K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), and Artificial Neural Network (ANN)-were evaluated using 5-fold cross-validation. SVM achieved the highest performance with an accuracy of 83.33% and $F 1$-score of 82%. Integrating SMOTE and SFFS significantly enhanced classification results, contributing to more accurate and scalable adaptive learning systems grounded in multiple intelligences theory.

title: Design Health Care Monitoring System Using ESP32 Controller Based on Cloud Computing
authors: Murtadha Khafief, Laith A. Abdul-Rahaim, Ali Qasim Almousawi, K. G. Kharade
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: The goal of this project is to deploy an Internet of Things-based smart healthcare system that monitors vital physiological data, such as blood oxygen levels, temperature, and heart rate. The system makes use of an ESP32 server for data processing and communication, as well as an ESP32 development kit for a wireless, wearable sensor. It eliminates the need for in-person visits by enabling clinicians to remotely monitor numerous patients. In order to provide real-time monitoring from any place, the gathered patient data is sent to a Firebase-based cloud server for storage. It is also accessible and viewable via a web interface. Through a mobile application, the technology also alerts physicians to any anomalous situations. Through the recording and analysis of critical health parameters, the smart healthcare system provides efficient medical services and enables physicians to accurately and conveniently monitor patients. The initiative also draws attention to the difficulties in implementing IoT health monitoring systems in the real world. To ensure ongoing patient care, sensor data is sent to the cloud for analysis, storage, and remote access by medical personnel. Tests of the system's actual use revealed a maximum temperature of 37.68° C and heart rates ranging from 66 to 87 beats per minute.

title: A Logical Robotic Arm Fabrication to Perform Human Tasks and Monitoring Purposes Using Deep Learning Methodology
authors: Y.Ramamohan Reddy, K. Malathi
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: The development of intelligent robotic systems capable of performing human-like tasks with precision, adaptability, and contextual awareness has become a crucial research direction in automation and assistive technology. This work introduces a rational robotic arm platform, which combines a deep learning-based vision, a reinforcement-based decision making, and an impedance-controlled motion control to execute the key human tasks, including pick-and-place, inspection, object observation, and cooperative tasks. High-precision object detection and segmentation (Mask R-CNN), human pose recognition (OpenPose), and collision-free movement (Probabilistic Roadmap (PRM) planning are used in the robotic system. The results of experimental evaluation show that the method has high detection accuracy of 98.4%, pose interpretation accuracy of 98.7, and a total accuracy of the task execution of 98.5, which confirms the strength of the framework and its ability to work in real-time. Safe human-robot interaction is also facilitated by the architecture that includes sensor-based torque, proximity and encoder module feedbacks. The findings depict that the proposed robotic arm is highly successful in the dynamic environments by means of smooth trajectory control, fast decision-making, and dependable performance of the tasks. Such an overall combination of mechanical design, sensor fusion, and deep learning intelligence makes it operational flexible and human-task approximation. The suggested methodology provides a platform of scaled adaptive robotic systems that are applicable to industrial, health care, home-assist, and surveillance.

title: Binary Code Featureless Mutation Approach Based on Encryption and Compression Consistency
authors: Xin Zhang, Junkai Yi, Lingling Tan
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: To address the vulnerability of binary code to reverse engineering and feature-based analysis, a featureless mutation approach based on encryption and compression consistency is proposed. The approach derives dynamic keys from system time and random seeds, employs Logistic-map-driven dynamic S-boxes, and integrates an enhanced SM4 algorithm with multi-round encryption to strengthen resistance against differential attacks. A block-level parallel pipeline is designed to unify encryption and compression, where a hash-accelerated dynamic-window LZ77 combined with Huffman coding improves compression ratio and processing efficiency. A unified header structure ensures consistency in decryption and decompression while preserving executability, and a self-destruction mechanism eliminates residual traces in memory to enhance stealthiness. Experimental results demonstrate that the approach significantly enhances confidentiality and compression performance without compromising executability. Providing a reliable and efficient solution for secure and optimized software protection.

title: AI-Powered Simulation for Optimizing Ambulance Dispatch and Emergency Response
authors: Krishna Karan Ghantasala
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: This paper addresses the Ambulance Location and Redeployment Problem by introducing a computationally explicit reinforcement learning (RL) framework that combines ensemble Deep Q-learning architectures with a discrete-event simulation environment. We identify two gaps in prior work: (1) many classic Operations Research formulations (e.g., p-median, maximum covering) optimize static coverage but do not adapt to temporal demand patterns and nonstationary travel conditions; (2) recent Deep RL implementations for emergency medical services often omit clear algorithmic statements (state/action/reward design), reproducible simulation maps, or systematic baselines.We propose (i) a formal MDP formulation with explicit state, action and reward design, (ii) a Bagging + Noisy Duelling DQN training pipeline with prioritized replay to improve exploration and uncertainty quantification, and (iii) a reproducible simulation configuration and evaluation protocol. Experiments in a 50 km<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> synthetic urban environment (three operational configurations, 30 test runs per model) compare the proposed agents against random, greedy (closest ambulance), and OR baselines (pmedian, MCLP). Evaluation metrics include average response time, percent of calls served within target thresholds, reward convergence, and computational cost.We report consistent reductions in average response time and improved robustness relative to the classical and heuristic baselines. The code, simulation map, and seeds are documented to support reproducibility.

title: Proof of Concept: Low-Cost Pressure Sensors Fabricated with a Modified Microhole Inter-Etch and Sealing (MIS) Process
authors: Tianlong Liang, Yilin Yang, Shijiong Luo, Boxi Chen, Yulong Chen, Wenwei Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Measurement Control and Instrumentation (MCAI)
abstract: Achieving robust hermetic sealing for low-cost, miniaturized MEMS pressure sensors without compromising device performance remains a significant challenge. This paper introduces a novel, low-temperature sealing technology based on a multilayer composite of silicone gel and Parylene C. The method was validated on commercially available MEMS pressure sensors, demonstrating a hermetic time constant exceeding 100 hours. Importantly, the seal preserves the sensor's static linearity and high-fidelity transient response. By decoupling device performance from complex, high-temperature fabrication, this cost-effective process enables the development of high-performance sensors for demanding applications, such as low-power wake-up switches.

title: Visionary Code: An AI-Driven Platform for Blind and Visually Impaired Programmers
authors: Permanki Guthu Rithesh Pakkala, R Akhila Thejaswi, Bellipady Shamantha Rai, Sudheer Shetty, Pv Vasudeva Rao, Shrinidhi Upadhyaya
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Computing, Semiconductor, Mechatronics, Intelligent Systems and Communications (COSMIC)
abstract: Visually impaired and blind students face significant barriers in programming and IT education due to the reliance on visual elements in traditional tools, which limits their ability to engage with coding environments. While Braille remains a vital accessibility tool, the lack of adaptive programming resources further complicates the learning process. To address these challenges, we developed a platform that integrates Natural Language Processing (NLP) technology using the BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers) algorithm to enable automated code verification and real-time error detection. The system is designed to offer audio-based feedback along with theoretical programming concepts, ensuring that visually impaired learners can access and interact with coding environments independently. The platform’s performance was evaluated using Python and HTML error detection. It achieved 92% accuracy and 90% precision for Python code detection and 82% accuracy and 80% precision for HTML code detection. These results demonstrate the platform’s reliability and its potential to enhance programming accessibility. By combining NLP-based code analysis with audio-assisted learning, the platform empowers visually impaired students to navigate programming concepts confidently and participate fully in IT education. Furthermore, the platform’s adaptability allows it to support various programming languages, offering flexibility for students to explore diverse coding environments. The integration of realtime error detection and corrective feedback ensures that learners can efficiently progress through their coding exercises with minimal external assistance.

title: Real-Time Stock Trading Simulation using Cloud Computing and Interactive Analytics with AI
authors: G Sunitha, SivaKumar Depuru, V K Nithyanand, Vishwa Veda Meruga, V Lokesh, S Madhumitha
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: This research introduces the AI-Enhanced stock trading simulator platform, that combines cloud computing, machine learning, and interactive analytics to offer a risk-free and educational trading platform. The system runs on the MERN (MongoDB, Express, React, Node.js) stack and simulates a real-life trading experience by data fetching using the Upstox API, and allowing the user to buy/sell using virtual transactions, with live tracking of a portfolio. The Linear Regression-based predictive model is incorporated to complement the analytical insight of the short-term stock trends forecasting, which provides users with interpretable AI-driven advice in the simulation. The site is operated on AWS Amplify with the purposes of constant integration, scalability, and with fault tolerance, whereas MongoDB Atlas is a secure, cloud-hosted data management. Both real and forecasted price patterns are presented in interactive visualizations using Chart.js that enable the use of data to make decisions and learn finance. The performance of the experimental results in terms of low-latency (<120 ms API response), high uptime (99.9%), and accurate short-term trend prediction (~94%) confirm the reliability and responding of the system. The suggested framework presents the interrelation of AI, the cloud-native architecture, and web technologies in the development of the scalable, intelligent, and user-based simulation systems in fintech.

title: Optimal Current Sharing and Voltage Regulation in DC Microgrid Clusters Using a Hybrid ANN–GWO-Based Fixed-Time Consensus Algorithm
authors: Chansereyseth Cheak, Zaid Hamid Al-Tameemi, Tek Tjing Lie
publish: 2025 IEEE PES 17th Asia-Pacific Power and Energy Engineering Conference (APPEEC)
abstract: This paper introduces a novel hybrid Artificial Neural Networks ANN- Grey Wolf Optimizer (GWO) in the secondary control layer of the hierarchical control scheme. The proposed control scheme leverages the predictive power of an ANN is adopted to replace conventional Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) controllers, and the optimisation capability of the GWO is used to optimize the parameters of the fixed time consensus protocol. Conceptually, this hybridization minimizes the voltage deviation across microgrids, balances current sharing, ensures fixed-time convergence, and maintains performance under dynamic conditions. The results demonstrate significant improvements in system performance, exhibiting rapid voltage recovery times ranging from 0.002s to 0.02s, substantially outperforming the conventional PID control method, which requires approximately 0.22 s under faults and 0.14s during load changes. Additionally, current sharing convergence was achieved within 0.001s to 0.03s, in contrast to conventional methods, which necessitated 0.12s and 0.05s for fault and load changes, respectively. The robustness of the proposed control scheme is validated by OPAL-RT.

title: Adaptive Optimal Control for DC-Bus Integration with A Single-Phase Microgrid Under Uncertain System Dynamics
authors: Abdulelah Alshareef, Osamah Aljumah, Sulaiman Alshammari, Frederick Livingston
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Environment Friendly Energies and Applications (EFEA)
abstract: This study presents an adaptive optimal output feedback controller for regulating power transfer from DC bus systems to single-phase microgrids. A key challenge addressed in this work is the uncertainty in system dynamics, which often arises from parameter variations, modeling errors, and external disturbances. To overcome this challenge, the Policy Iteration (PI) algorithm based on Adaptive Dynamic Programming (ADP) theory is employed to design an optimal controller that tracks the microgrid’s reference current without requiring explicit knowledge of system parameters. The PI algorithm derives the optimal control law using measured data alone. Comprehensive simulation studies under diverse operating conditions demonstrate the effectiveness and adaptability of the proposed control strategy.

title: AI-driven Dried Coconut Classification Using Computer Vision
authors: Rajesh Nayak, Anurag R. Rao, Harsharaj, Nayak Akshay Ravindra, Rahul Mendon
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Computing, Semiconductor, Mechatronics, Intelligent Systems and Communications (COSMIC)
abstract: The global dried coconut industry significantly affects agricultural economies, especially in tropical regions. Appropriate grading is necessary to ascertain whether dried coconuts are appropriate for specific uses, such as oil extraction, desiccation, or other by-products. These days, grading is usually done by hand, which leads to mistakes, inefficiencies, and irregularities. Advancements in deep learning and computer vision offer an opportunity to automate and improve the grading process. This work focuses on classifying dried coconuts into three grades (A, B, and C) using deep learning techniques. Traditional manual grading methods are time-consuming, inconsistent, and prone to human error, resulting in inefficiencies and variations in product quality. The system uses Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) to analyze visual features such as texture, color, and shape, ensuring accurate and reliable classification. This approach improves grading efficiency, provides consistent results, and reduces reliance on manual labor, offering a scalable and efficient solution for the coconut processing industry to enhance productivity and quality control.

title: Monitoring and Analysis System for the Growth Environment of Radix Codonopsis Pilosulae Based on DeepSeek-V3 and Internet of Things (IoT) Technology
authors: Hongwei Zhang, Qi Yan, Yutong Zhang, Jiaxin Luo
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Measurement Control and Instrumentation (MCAI)
abstract: The application of Internet of Things (IoT) and AI technologies in the agricultural field is constantly deepening. Radix Codonopsis Pilosulae has a suitable temperature range of 15-25°C and is sensitive to light; therefore, accurate monitoring of environmental parameters and precise analysis of data are crucial for its growth.This paper establishes a multi-sensor fusion monitoring system to assist its cultivation and promote the sustainable development of agriculture.The system uses a variety of sensors to collect environmental data such as temperature, humidity, and light intensity. The data is transmitted to the OneNET Cloud via the STM32 microcontroller and ESP8266 wireless module, and then the Cloud distributes the data to the WeChat Mini Program. This enables data visualization, threshold setting, DeepSeek analysis, and remote early warning. Additionally, the system features low cost and easy deployment. In the future, the sensors, modules, and AI algorithms will be optimized.

title: Automated Analysis of Exam Questions Based On Bloom’s Taxonomy
authors: Lokesh Bootu, Anisha Mahato, Shaurya Kumar Sriwastav, Ramu Miriyala, Divye Bali
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: This research focuses on automating the analysis of exam questions using Bloom’s Taxonomy to improve the quality and fairness of educational assessments. Bloom’s Taxonomy breaks learning objectives into six levels -they are Remembering, Understanding, Applying, Analyzing, Evaluating, and Creating - helping educators design balanced exams that test a full range of skills, from simple recall to critical thinking and creativity. Traditionally, classifying questions into these levels has been a manual and often subjective task. To address this, our approach uses Natural Language Processing (NLP) and Machine Learning, combining the strengths of BERT, a transformed based model known for capturing context and contextual nuances of exam questions for cognitive-level classification. For benchmarking, traditional machine learning algorithms are also implemented for comparison. By integrating these models into an ensemble framework, the system processes the questions through steps such as text cleaning, tokenization and embedding generation before reaching a consensus-based classification. Testing shows that Transformer models clearly outperform traditional approaches, while the ensemble method improves stability. Beyond accuracy, this work can support automated exam paper design, curriculum alignment and adaptive testing that adjusts difficulty while keeping cognitive balance.

title: Resident Issue Reporting System with AI-Powered Predictive Analytics and Blockchain Transparency
authors: Vishal Sharma, Prashant Chaudhary, Ankit Kumar Singh, Parth Kausahik, Naphees Iqbal
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: This article introduces an enhanced Resident Issue Reporting System aimed at streamlining the process of reporting, monitoring, and solving issues related to the community. Utilizing Artificial Intelligence (AI) for complaint classification and prioritization, blockchain for irrevocable tracking, and GPS geotagging for accurate location reporting, the system increases transparency and responsiveness in civic administration. Citizens can safely report issues, add multimedia support, and track real-time updates while authorities receive predictive analytics for proactive planning.

title: Leveraging Post-Quantum Cryptography in Digital Signatures for Enhanced Security in Quantum Computing Threat
authors: Pavan Kurariya, Jahnavi Bodhankar, Santosh K Pandey
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: The emergence of quantum computing introduces unprecedented risks to classical cryptographic schemes, particularly digital signatures that safeguard authentication, confidentiality, and data integrity across digital ecosystems. To address these concerns, this paper investigates the adoption of Post-Quantum Cryptography (PQC) within Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) frameworks, emphasizing its role in strengthening electronic signature (eSign) systems against quantum threats. Traditional PKI implementations rely on algorithms such as RSA and ECC in combination with Hardware Security Modules (HSMs) for secure key management; however, these methods are vulnerable to quantum algorithms like Shor's. We examine how quantum-resistant alternatives-including lattice-based, hash-based, and multivariate polynomial-based schemes standardized by NIST-can be integrated into PKI without compromising interoperability and compliance. A comparative evaluation highlights trade-offs in performance, storage, and computational complexity while demonstrating the feasibility of embedding PQC into existing eSign infrastructures. Our findings underscore the urgency of transitioning towards quantum-safe digital signatures to ensure resilience, regulatory alignment, and long-term trust in national-scale digital services.

title: A Comprehensive Review of Deep Learning and Machine Learning Approaches for Detecting Plant Nutrient Deficiencies and Diseases
authors: Pradip N. Shendage, Shrikant V. Sonekar, Laxman D. Netak
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Crop productivity can be significantly impacted by nutrient deficiencies and plant diseases, resulting in yield reductions and financial losses. Traditional identification methods regularly added labor intensive observation and expert analysis. Its time-consuming consuming and less effective for early detection. The growth of deep learning techniques has provided advanced tools for analyzing plant images to assess plant health using CNN and ensemble methods. This review explores the extensive utilization of deep learning and machine learning models in tracking plant conditions. It categorizes existing research based on the types of model used, pre-processing methods, and practical implementations in agricultural environments. Numerous studies have validated the capability of these methods in accurately diagnosing nutrient imbalances and plant diseases across various crops. Innovations such as transfer learning, feature extraction, and model ensembles have enhanced the precision of predictions. While significant progress has been made, ongoing challenges include environmental variability, limited or imbalanced datasets, and difficulty in interpreting complex model decisions. Nevertheless, integrating deep learning into precision farming holds substantial promise for enabling real-time crop health assessments and advancing sustainable agriculture. This review outlines current limitations and suggests future directions for research to develop more efficient and outcome for crop growth monitoring.

title: Multi Scale Attention Based Hybrid Resnest-Capsnet Deep Learning Model for Diabetics Retinopathy Detection
authors: Kavitha M, Pradeep D
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Diabetic Retinopathy (DR) is a complication of diabetes that threatens vision and requires timely and accurate diagnosis. Traditional deep learning (DL) approaches to DR diagnosis have limitations related to poor generalization, ineffective preprocessing, and high computational costs; therefore, a hybrid deep learning framework called Multi-Scale Attention driven ResNest-CapsNet is proposed to improve the accuracy and efficiency of diabetic retinopathy (DR) diagnosis. Preprocessing was performed, starting from standard approaches such as Contrast Limited Adaptive Histogram Equalization (CLAHE), green channel extraction, median filtering, and Gaussian smoothing, which are recommended for removing artifacts from diabetic retinal images and normalizing illumination. After preprocessing, the features of different scales were extracted using the ResNest architecture, which comprises split-attention blocks, to obtain fine-grained features and multi-resolution features of the retina. These features are extracted from different ResNest layers and combined together by weighted combinations to contextualize the information. The extracted features are sent to the Capsule Network (CapsNet) which maintains the spatial relationship between features, through the use of dynamic routing and squash activation functions. This assists in accurately classifying healthy and every stage of DR, including learning part-to-whole relationships. The model is trained and assessed on benchmark datasets, APTOS 2019 and Kaggle EyePACS, with the following metrics: accuracy, F1-score, AUC, and inference time. The proposed model significantly outperforms the standard CNN-based methods like VGG16, ResNet-50, DenseNet-121 in classification accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Exploring the Role of AI in Transforming Programming Education at Universities: Qualitative and Quantitative Insights
authors: Heng-Wei Chao, Allen Y. Chang
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: As generative AI tools like ChatGPT gain prominence, their role in higher education—particularly in programming instruction—has attracted growing attention. This study explores the practical impact of ChatGPT on introductory programming education in Taiwanese universities. A mixed-methods design was adopted, involving both a quantitative experiment and qualitative survey. First-year computer science students were divided into an AI-assisted group and a traditional group. After a guided reading phase, both groups completed a closed-book test evaluating four learning dimensions: syntax comprehension, logical reasoning, creative design, and error detection. Results show the AI group significantly outperformed the traditional group in syntax, creativity, and debugging, though no notable difference was found in logical reasoning. Survey responses revealed positive perceptions of AI’s usefulness, alongside a growing trend of frequent reliance on such tools. This study concludes that while ChatGPT can enhance learning in specific domains, educators must guide students in responsible usage to avoid overdependence and preserve academic integrity.

title: Dual-Attention Graph Neural Networks for SpatioTemporal Crime Forecasting and Patrol Optimization
authors: Mudit Srivastava, Sanya Raj, Nithyashri J
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: The prediction of urban crime is crucial for proactive law enforcement and the allocation of resources. We introduce an innovative Dual-Attention Graph Neural Network (DA-GNN) designed for spatio-temporal crime forecasting and the optimization of patrol strategies. This model effectively captures spatial relationships through Graph Attention Networks (GATs) and improves upon on temporal patterns via a parallel Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) pathway, our previous research. A dual-attention approach dynamically adjusts the significance of influential neighbors and historical time intervals. To improve precision, we include external covariates such as weather conditions, holidays, and seasonal influences. Additionally, we utilize Quantum-behaved Particle Swarm Optimization (QPSO) to facilitate the automation of hyperparameter tuning. Although the model is trained on a recent subset (January-March 2023) for computational feasibility, it leverages the full 2001-2023 dataset for graph construction, seasonal pattern extraction, and feature enrichment. DA-GNN consistently outperforms classical baselines (ARIMA, random forests), deep learning models (LSTM, CNNLSTM), and prior GNN-based approaches. Finally, the model produces interpretable attention maps and district-level risk visualizations, supporting ethical deployment and data-driven patrol strategy design.

title: Two-Person Action Surveillance via Multi-Modal Feature Optimization and Markov Model
authors: Saleha Kamal, Ahmad Jalal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Engineering &amp; Computing Technologies (ICECT)
abstract: Understanding human interactions and analyzing their impact in real-world settings has gained significant attention in the computer vision community due to its potential applications in various industrial and commercial sectors. With the use of sensors and communication technologies, human movements can be captured to create interactive interfaces that support man-machine collaboration. However, incorporating intelligent computing for enhanced scene comprehension remains a largely underexplored area. In this paper, we propose a novel methodology aimed at enabling machines to better understand human behavior in indoor environments. The objective is to integrate cognitive processes into information technologies, opening new possibilities for intelligent media systems. Our human interaction recognition (HIR) system identifies eight complex interactions from the PKU-MMD dataset: push, pat, handshake, punch, hug, kick, point, and pass object. By designing thermal, Kinetic energy-based features and SIFT algorithms with individual, local and global centroids combined with a Markov model, we evaluate our system’s performance against other state-of-the-art classifiers. Experimental results with mean recognition accuracy of $87.73 \%$ demonstrate that our approach is robust in complex, real-world scenarios, making it suitable for applications in security systems, smart surveillance, violence detection, and child abuse prevention.

title: Unsupervised Video Anomaly Detection Based on Dual-Branch Feature Refinement and Multi-Scale Dilated Dense Integration
authors: Jie Deng, Jianjun Li, Long Liu, Xiaojian Pan
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: Video anomaly detection methods encounter significant challenges in dynamic and complex scenarios, particularly significant interference from irrelevant information and insufficient perception of subtle anomalies caused by the loss of deep feature details. To tackle these issues, this paper proposes a Dual-Branch Feature Refinement Unit (DBFRU), which synergistically optimizes channel and spatial attention mechanisms to enhance the model’s capability for unified perception of channel and spatial semantics, effectively suppressing redundant information interference. Additionally, this paper introduces a Multi-Scale Dilated Dense Block (MDDB), which deepens the fusion of multi-scale contextual information while preserving feature map dimensions, thus improving feature representation and mitigating detail loss. Evaluations on the UCSD Ped2 and CUHK Avenue datasets demonstrate that the proposed framework achieves state-of-the-art performance in terms of frame-level AUC, with outstanding results of 97.9% and 86.8%, respectively, significantly outperforming most existing methods. Ablation studies further confirm that the DBFRU and MDDB modules exhibit complementary effects, working together to enhance the model's performance in localizing fine-grained anomalies.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning-Based Error Correction Method for Secure Data Transmission
authors: P Arthi Devarani, R. Balanriya, Shanmugaraja P, Naveen K N, Raghumandala Devi, JoshuvaArockia Dhanraj
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Since the communications network often adopts advanced communications systems, channel noise, jamming or badwill attacks from the hackers may be very capable of affecting the network; modelling communication channel systems may be very important for soner to correctly transfer data. Therefore, in this paper, an online dynamic adaptation mechanism based on deep reinforcement learning (DRL) and deep reinforcement learning based on deep q-network model (DQN) for an error correction scheme (DRL-ECMS). Therefore, to control the problem, the proposed system simulates the transmission channel into a DRL learning environment, which can be used to learn what does the agent need to do to make a wise transmission channel to mitigate transmission errors, while enhancing data integrity and transmission throughput. Deep learning models are implemented using the next generation cutting edge Pytorch framework, which is the leading development framework for neural architecture design and training model in GPU accelerated environment. Intensive experiments are performed to showcase the breadth of the proposed DRL-based scheme while successfully overcoming the erroneous bit-rates that are beyond any traditional Hamming coding & LDPC code with high tolerance to intrusional attacks & malicious interferences. This project will bring about a paradigm shift in smart self adaptive communications systems while providing reliability and security to the next generation networks.

title: Twinshield: A Dual-Phase System for Detecting and Extracting Backdoors in VLMS
authors: Malavika Nithyanand, Vikalp Srivastava, Shivam Vyas, Tushar Shinde
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: Vision-Language Models (VLMs) are increasingly integral to safety-critical applications, yet their reliance on large, uncurated datasets makes them vulnerable to backdoor poisoning attacks. Detecting such attacks is a formidable challenge, particularly when trigger patterns are unknown and no trusted clean data is available. This paper introduces a robust, two-phase hybrid system for high-fidelity backdoor detection and forensic analysis. The first phase employs an assumption-free screening method that constructs a hybrid feature vector from a deep autoencoder’s reconstruction error and hand-crafted visual features, enabling robust anomaly detection without clean data. In the second phase, samples flagged as anomalous undergo high-confidence verification using a pre-trained Vision-Language Model (VLM). We employ gradient-based saliency analysis, backpropagating from a malicious prompt’s logit score to the input pixels, to generate attribution maps that spatially localize the trigger, providing interpretable, visual evidence of the attack. Our integrated pipeline offers a scalable and effective solution, balancing broad-spectrum detection with rapid, explainable forensic analysis to enhance VLM security.

title: Compressing Quantum Circuits via Learning Hermitian Operators
authors: Pei-Lin Zheng, Fei Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: In the noisy intermediate-scale quantum (NISQ) era, quantum hardware remains insufficient to execute deep quantum circuits. An effective solution lies in leveraging classical computing resources and algorithms to compress quantum circuits into a depth that can be efficiently handled by quantum hardware. Herein, we propose a learning-based approach that employs an autoregressive model to achieve efficient learning of Hermitian operators. Specifically, we decompose the Hermitian operator into a linear combination of Pauli strings and parameterize the combination coefficients via an autoregressive neural network (ARNN). Through training the ARNN on a randomly sampled dataset, we enable it to learn such Hermitian operators. Numerical experiments validate that our method can approximate the target Hermitian operator with high precision, thereby facilitating efficient compression of quantum circuits.

title: Computer Vision-Driven Crop Disease Identification System for Yield Enhancement
authors: Sharmila Zope, Jetlin C P, Priyanka Menon A S, Maya Eapen, H. Mickle Aancy, Shailendra Kumar Bohidar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: The identification of crop diseases at the right time and right place plays a significant role in reducing the losses in yield and in ensuring sustainable agriculture. The paper describes a Crop Disease Identification System based on Computer Vision and driven by the YOLOv8 lightweight variant fine-tuned with transfer learning, executed through Ultralytics YOLOv8 in PyTorch. To improve the effectiveness of the system in actual field conditions, like changing lighting conditions, noisy backgrounds, and overlapping leaves, the system was tested on benchmark and real-world datasets. On-field usability is demonstrated by experimental results including an average Precision of 93.6 percent and realtime inference rates of 38 FPS on a GPU and 22 FPS on an edge device. Quantization and pruning of models were also used to further minimize size by a factor of 40, without much accuracy loss, allowing them to be deployed to mobile and at the edge. The proposed structure provides highly accurate, scalable, and realistic disease detection, which facilitates the implementation of intervention measures that have a direct impact on crop health and yield management.

title: Cryogenic Sensor Performance Testing Methods and Data Analysis
authors: Nanchuan Liu, Tingting Xia, Fei Ding, Dongfei Lu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Measurement Control and Instrumentation (MCAI)
abstract: Cryogenic temperature measurement technology is a fundamental technology in fields such as cryogenic superconductivity, quantum computing, deep space exploration, and cryomedicine. Its accuracy and reliability directly affect the development of cryogenic and related fields. This paper addresses the problems of high cost, long performance testing cycles, and narrow calibration range of existing cryogenic sensors by building an integrated cryogenic sensor calibration platform and a rapid thermal cycling test platform. A comprehensive evaluation of the temperature control accuracy and repeatability of the self-developed sensor was conducted to ensure its high accuracy and repeatability. Preliminary tests show that the sensor calibration platform can cover a wide temperature range of 2.7K ~ 325 K, with temperature fluctuations in the liquid helium range suppressed to within ± 7 mK. Calibration using diode-type and resistive sensors yielded excellent accuracy in the cryogenic region, as reflected in the calibration and fitting results. Thermal cycling tests were conducted using the thermal cycling test platform from 4.2 K to 300 K. The sensor's standard deviation was only 0.003 K, the coefficient of variation was 0.07%, and the temperature change across cycles was less than 0.002 K, demonstrating excellent repeatability. During 40 thermal cycling tests, the temperature curve remained largely consistent with that of the standard sensor, demonstrating excellent stability. The aforementioned testing platform and methods can effectively test the accuracy and repeatability of cryogenic sensors, providing technical support for the development of quantum computing, cryogenic superconductivity and aerospace exploration in the field of cryogenics.

title: An IoT-Enabled Solar-Powered Multi-Crop Thresher with Real-Time Efficiency Monitoring: Design and Development
authors: Kalluri Praveen, Vinod Kumar D. M.
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Conventional threshing systems are mostly crop-specific, fossil fuel-driven, and their costs of operation are very high, which renders their use uneconomical to smallholder farmers. The study shows the design and building construction of a multi crop solar-powered thresher with a smart efficiency monitoring system. This is a system that has used a brushless DC motor of 750W operated by a 1kW solar PV and a 1.5kWh lithium-ion battery bank. Swappable threshing drums and variable concave set-ups would be created to handle crops such as wheat, rice and maize. A monitoring module based on ESP32 stores real-time information such as throughput, drum RPM value, and energy consumption. Field tests revealed that the machine had an average threshing efficiency of 93 percent and cleaning efficiency of 88 percent with an energy requirement of 0.35 Kilowatt per hundred kilograms of the processed crop. The prototype lowered the cost of energy by about 60 percent and CO 2 emissions by 100 percent as compared to a conventional diesel thresher. These findings show the prospect of the system to provide a low cost and environmentally friendly method to decentralized and multi-crop threshing in the farms.

title: Efficient CUDA-Based GNSS Tracking Architecture for High-Rate BeiDou B3I Signals
authors: Tianhao Zhou, Duan Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: This paper proposes a GPU-based single-channel real-time tracking module within a software-defined radio (SDR) system, optimized for BeiDou B3I signals (21.875 MHz sampling rate). To boost GPU computational efficiency, we use coherent integration with constant memory look-up tables, Warp-level reduction, and three-phase correlation to accelerate carrier de-rotation and PRN code correlation. Compared to non-coherent integration, our approach enhances tracking accuracy by preserving phase information. Experiments demonstrate a 9× performance improvement of GPU computation over CPU-based methods, significantly enhancing real-time multi-channel tracking capabilities for high-performance GNSS SDR.

title: An Integrated Agentic AI System for Early Nephropathy Risk Prediction and Prescription Safety
authors: A. Sweety Janish, T. Jemima Jebaseeli
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Diabetes Mellitus currently has more than 537 million global cases, it is expected to rise about 643 million by the year 2030. Of its complications, Diabetic Nephropathy is one of the leading causes of end-stage renal disease, affecting 30–40 percent of diabetic patients and resulting in high mortality and healthcare expenses. An agentic AI-based system for early detection and management of diabetic nephropathy is a predictive modeling with integrated healthcare services. Machine learning algorithms like Logistic Regression, Random Forest, and XGBoost, trained on diabetes and chronic kidney disease data, predict nephropathy risk as Low, Medium, or High based on parameters like age, blood pressure, HbA1c, creatinine, BMI, and cholesterol. Novel aspects include detection of prescription error for dosage and drug interactions, physician recommendations via geolocation services, and integration with pharmacies for ordering and delivery of medicines. The system ensures precise risk prediction, alerts for unusual values, and enhanced patient convenience. With the integration of risk assessment, prescription safety, and healthcare integration, the framework presents an agentic AI methodology that actively supports patients and has the potential to limit late-stage nephropathy development and enhance healthcare support systems

title: PlantHealthNet: An Efficient CNN Model for Disease Diagnosis and Pesticide Recommendation
authors: Kampelly Shilpa, Marriboyana Sudhakar
