title: High-Frequency Seismic Data Reconstruction with Physical and Structure-Guided Constraints
authors: Yang Gao, Xuewen Shi, Dongjun Zhang, Zhiwen Zhou, Min Su, Jing Su
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Reconstructing high-frequency seismic data is essential for detailed subsurface imaging and accurate reservoir characterization, particularly when dealing with complex geological formations. Traditional machine learning approaches typically depend on large labeled datasets, which are often challenging to acquire and may fail to adequately represent the diverse conditions found in subsurface environments. To overcome these limitations, we propose a novel physcis-guided, self-supervise learning methodology that eliminates the requirement for labeled data. This approach integrates physical constraints to ensure that the reconstructed seismic data retains its fidelity. A significant innovation in our method is the application of structure-guided constraints, enhanced by the use of cosine similarity. This allows for the adaptive calculation and minimization of angle errors, effectively preserving the orientation and continuity of geological features. Comprehensive testing on both synthetic and field datasets has demonstrated the robustness and accuracy of our method, showing its capability to maintain high-frequency details and faithfully reconstruct seismic signals in the presence of complex subsurface structures. The results indicate that this method significantly improves the resolution and reliability of seismic data, providing high-quality inputs that can enhance subsequent interpretation in reservoir management.

title: Incentive-compatible Flexibility Sharing for Enhancing Controllability and Economic Efficiency of Demand Response
authors: Yan Meng, Lei Yan, Linjuehao Mei, Zelong Lu, Guocan Yan, Yuanhao Feng, Mohammad Shahidehpour, Zuyi Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Smart Grid
abstract: To address the economic efficiency and controllability obstacles that significantly impact demand response (DR) performance, this paper proposes an incentive-compatible flexibility sharing strategy that optimally coordinates adjustment flexibility of customers with multi-period coupling constraints. In contrast to existing sharing schemes that set adjustment targets based on manipulable load baselines and share time-decoupled energy, we characterize the deviation between individual post-adjustment load curve and the load directrix (LD) as shared flexibility from a holistic multi-period perspective. LD represents an ideal target curve exogenously determined by the system to guide customer in DR, remaining immune to customer manipulation. A tractable model is established to encapsulate the decision making of optimal economic allocation of flexibility, and the closed-form optimal solution is rigorously derived. It is theoretically proved that flexibility sharing satisfies incentive compatibility. That is, individual decisions align with the guided optimal outcomes, which ensures the perfect tracking of LD. We show that every customer achieves cost reductions and hence has motivation to participate in the sharing. Furthermore, revenue adequacy and fairness are guaranteed. Case studies validate the theoretical outcomes and demonstrate the effectiveness and scalability of the flexibility sharing strategy.

title: Incoherent Distributed Sources Tracking Algorithm for Massive MIMO Systems
authors: Hui Chen, Tianjing Wang, Wenxu Zhang, Feng Lian, Guanghua Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: To address the time-varying direction-of-arrival (DOA) tracking problem of incoherently distributed (ID) signal sources for massive multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) systems, which involves critical challenges of data association ambiguity and measurement uncertainty in dynamic environments, this work proposes a novel tracking algorithm for ID sources using the generalized labeled multi-Bernoulli (GLMB) filter and smoother. The algorithm first models ID sources using a uniform rectangular array (URA), and then estimates the nominal DOA, along with angular spreads, via the beamspace unitary estimating signal parameters via rotational invariance techniques (UESPRIT) algorithm. The above estimates are then used as pseudo-measurements for each time step within the GLMB filter and smoother to improve estimation accuracy. At the same time, for the uncertainty of measurement noise, Cramér-Rao bound (CRB) is used to approximate the covariance of measurement noise in the tracking process.Within the framework of the GLMB smoother, a forward filtering stage is performed to generate the association history as well as the trajectory information using the GLMB filter. Term trajectories and trajectory fragments are removed through the trajectory pruning operation. Next, the backward smoothing is applied to achieve the data association of the ID sources and the estimation of kinematic states. To verify the effectiveness of the proposed approach, Monte Carlo (MC) simulations are performed. The results confirm its superior DOA tracking capability, enhanced estimation accuracy, and high robustness.

title: CroBIM-U: Uncertainty-Driven Referring Remote Sensing Image Segmentation
authors: Yuzhe Sun, Zhe Dong, Haochen Jiang, Yanfeng Gu, Tianzhu Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Referring remote sensing image segmentation aims to localize specific targets described by natural language within complex overhead imagery. However, due to extreme scale variations, dense similar distractors, and intricate boundary structures, the reliability of cross-modal alignment exhibits significant spatial non-uniformity. Existing methods typically employ uniform fusion and refinement strategies across the entire image, which often introduces unnecessary linguistic perturbations in visually clear regions while failing to provide sufficient disambiguation in confused areas. To address this, we propose an uncertainty-guided framework that explicitly leverages a pixel-wise referring uncertainty map as a spatial prior to orchestrate adaptive inference. Specifically, we introduce a plug-and-play Referring Uncertainty Scorer (RUS), which is trained via an online error-consistency supervision strategy to interpretably predict the spatial distribution of referential ambiguity. Building on this prior, we design two plug-and-play modules: 1) Uncertainty-Gated Fusion (UGF), which dynamically modulates language injection strength to enhance constraints in high-uncertainty regions while suppressing noise in low-uncertainty ones; and 2) Uncertainty-Driven Local Refinement (UDLR), which utilizes uncertainty-derived soft masks to focus refinement on error-prone boundaries and fine details. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method functions as a unified, plug-and-play solution that significantly improves robustness and geometric fidelity in complex remote sensing scenes without altering the backbone architecture.

title: Intelligent Network Intrusion Detection Using ML With Hybrid XGBoost and Anomaly Fusion
authors: Sampath Magapu, Praneeth Chindiri, C Phani Bhushan Reddy, V Venkata Kalyan, M.S.S Lakshman Reddy, Siddique Ibrahim Peer Mohamed
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: Early, reliable intrusion detection requires leak-age-free modeling and controllable operating points on standard benchmarks. This paper introduces an Intelligent Network Intrusion Detection System (INIDS) on the official UNSW_NB15 split that removes post hoc label proxies during ETL, learns a supervised XGBoost backbone with imbalance handling, and fuses it with a benign-only anomaly ensemble (PCA reconstruction + Isolation Forest) via a tunable risk $r=\alpha p_{\text {sup }}+(1-\alpha) s_{\text {anom }}$. The core novelty is a two-brains architecture: supervised XGBoost and benign-only anomaly fusion providing complementary evidence and deployment control.The operations layer provides OLAP rollups, mini-batch alerts, and auto-generated HTML/PDF reports. At the tuned operating point, the system attains a test accuracy of 88.68% with Precision $=1.0000$, Recall $=0.8336$, $\mathrm{F} 1=0.9093, \mathrm{ROC}-\mathrm{AUC}=1.0000$, and $\mathrm{PR}-\mathrm{AUC}=1.0000$ on the official split, demonstrating realistic performance under leak-age-free evaluation with integrated practical deployment.

title: Ovarian Cancer Diagnosis: A Data-Driven Machine Learning Approach
authors: Sonam Juneja, Nitesh Singh Bhati, Priya Sharma, Reema Goyal, Isha Arora, Rajesh A
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: Ovarian cancer is a highly fatal gynecological disease due to late-stage diagnosis and non-specific early symptoms. This paper presents a machine learning pipeline using clinical data from 3,000 patients, incorporating imputation, encoding, normalization, SMOTE for class balancing, RFE for feature selection and five classifiers. Among them, the Random Forest classifier achieved the highest overall accuracy at 88.94%. This indicates that almost 90% of the model’s predictions came true, indicating that it is highly generalisable across various classes within the ovarian cancer risk spectrum. The findings emphasize the effectiveness of ensemble models and feature engineering in early detection. Models were evaluated using accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, ROC-AUC and confusion matrices with hyperparameter tuning via GridSearchCV and an 80/20 stratified split. The approach addresses class imbalance and improves model interpretability.This work demonstrates the potential of ML pipelines in clinical decision support for ovarian cancer diagnosis.

title: Integrated AI Framework for Detection of Green Foliage Diseases and Sustainable Field Management
authors: S Karthikeyan, M Manoj Kumar, Kishore K, R Roopa Chandrika
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: Agricultural productivity is often threatened by foliage diseases that weaken plant health and reduce yield quality. Manual inspection remains the standard practice for disease identification, yet it requires expert knowledge, consumes significant time, and is not readily available in rural farming contexts. Advanced artificial intelligence methods such as deep convolutional networks have shown promise in agricultural diagnostics, but many of these solutions are computationally intensive and unsuitable for low-resource environments. To bridge this gap, an integrated lightweight framework for guava leaf disease prediction and sustainable management has been developed. The system employs a compressed convolutional neural network combined with a probabilistic assessment module to enhance reliability while maintaining efficiency. The Guava Leaf Disease Dataset (GLDD) was utilized, with a curated subset of 2,500 images across four categories: anthracnose, healthy, insect bite, and scorch. Images are standardized through preprocessing techniques, including resizing, normalization, and augmentation, to strengthen model generalization. Experimental results indicate consistent classification performance above 85% accuracy, with each prediction generated in under three seconds on a standard laptop. Beyond detection, the framework provides actionable recommendations promoting eco-friendly treatments and reduced chemical reliance. These findings highlight the framework’s practical value as a low-cost, accessible, and sustainable solution for both academic research and community-level agricultural applications.

title: Smart Diagnosis: Classifying Lung Nodules with Deep Learning
authors: M. Akshaya, D. Hemanth Kumar, Raju Muntha, M. Sai Kiran, MD. Sameer, P. Manilatha
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Lung cancer is among the top causes of death in the world and the timely detection of the lung nodules is key in enhancing patient outcomes. The paper introduces a computer-aided innovative technique of detecting the classification of lung nodules through a deep learning model in the form of a convolutional neural network. The technique examines CT scan image and classifies them into four broad classes of lung tissue images. The system has been created to enhance reliability of automated diagnosis improvement and facilitation of clinical decision making by detecting pertinent visual patterns related to various subtypes of lung cancer. The method also applies the visualization methods to offer the interpretability and showcase significant areas that impact on the classification decisions. The suggested system has a high potential of helping radiologists with making early diagnosis evaluation and improving the consistency of the medical images evaluation.

title: AI-Driven Customer Satisfaction Analysis towards Blue Dart Courier Services
authors: R. Maheswari, I. Smaila, Aakash M U
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Courier and logistics industries are majorly dependent on customers' satisfaction to measure the quality of services. Dependability, punctuality, and customer support directly influence customer loyalty. This study employs artificial intelligence as a substitute for traditional survey-based methodology in measuring customer satisfaction with Blue Dart Courier Services in Coimbatore City. To determine sentiment, uncover recurring service issues, and unearth drivers of satisfaction, this applied machine learning and natural language processing (NLP) to analyze consumer sentiment that was collected from online reviews, social media posts, and organized survey responses. While it is simultaneously recognizing key drivers such as delivery on time, package care, communications effectiveness, and cost of the service, the proposed method classifies consumer feedback as positive, negative, and neutral. The findings are valuable feedback regarding what they do well and how they can improve, which can assist Blue Dart in revising their service plans. If courier services need to enhance customer happiness and become more competitive, they could adopt this replicable and scalable approach offered by this AI-powered system. The proposed work metrics has performed 92.4% on accuracy.

title: PoachingTracker: Secure Incident Logging and Tracking with Blockchain Technology
authors: Padma J, Lokhande Om Arun, Pratham Jethwani, Prikshit
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: Wildlife poaching, a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${\$ 2 0}$</tex> billion illegal trade, threatens global biodiversity, driving species extinction and disrupting ecosystems. Traditional incident logging systems, reliant on centralized databases or paper records, suffer from data tampering, opacity, and poor inter-agency collaboration, undermining conservation and law enforcement efforts. This work proposes Poaching Tracker, a blockchain-based system leveraging Ethereum smart contracts to securely and transparently record poaching incidents. The Poaching Records smart contract, implemented in Solidity, immutably stores detailed incident data-species, GPS coordinates, health status, poaching method, and motivation-while enforcing access control via MetaMask authentication. A React.js frontend provides an intuitive interface for authorized users to log and query incidents, validated through usability testing with conservation personnel. Testing with a synthetic dataset simulating diverse poaching scenarios demonstrates reliable logging at an average cost of 305,008 gas units and data retrieval times of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 - 1 5}$</tex> seconds on Ethereum's main net. Compared to centralized systems, Poaching Tracker enhances data integrity, transparency, and stakeholder trust, supporting legal evidence and policy-making. Aligning with Sustainable Development Goal 15 (Life on Land), Poaching Tracker offers a scalable, tamper-proof framework for wildlife conservation, with potential applications to illegal logging and habitat protection, paving the way for decentralized environmental data management.

title: Ethical Concerns over AI Learning in Higher Education: A Survey of Curriculum Coverage
authors: Jamiur Rahaman, Abdulsalam K. Alhazmi, Akram M. Zeki, Nasr Alsakkaf
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: AI has revolutionized all sectors, and the educational sector is no exception. AI in education is gradually reshaping the entire spectrum for students and educators. Given its capacity, it has a far-reaching impact on both students and educators. This inclusion and adoption have also brought multifaceted challenges for the institutions and the people responsible for planning, designing, and implementing AI in higher education. The ethical use of AI mediums introduced in higher education is a significant concern. These systems may risk creating vulnerabilities in students’ data usage and the unethical use of AI to perform their daily tasks. Privacy concerns linked to data usage, have also been raised by the people adopting these AI systems in higher education. A limited number of studies have been conducted to evaluate the impact of ethical issues in AI integration in education. This study used a descriptive survey to obtain feedback from educators. The findings of the study reveal the ethical concerns of the students and teachers related to the ethics of AI in higher education. This research contributes to preparing stakeholders with the correct skill set to use AI technologies ethically. The paper focuses on these ethical concerns of the students, educators, and policymakers. It also diverts the attention of the educators and policymakers towards fulfilling their institutional obligations to address these growing ethical concerns through effective policymaking, governance, and institutional reforms, through which AI can be ethically implemented and practiced in higher education.

title: A Comprehensive Deep Learning Framework for Enhanced Recognition and Analysis Using Trimmed Gait Energy Images
authors: Lade. Gunakar Rao, Thikka Shirisha, G. Sumalatha, Bhargav Somisetty, P. Ramana
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: Human gait offers a novel optimisation framework for human gait biometrics, employing the most up-to-date techniques in state-of-the-art-based methods, utilising Trimmed Gait Energy Images and deep learning techniques. The TGEI is attained by smoothing of GEIs as well as decreasing the redundancy of the time features and conserving the motion facts. Such a method also creates recognition accuracy with the help of deep neural networks, thereby addressing such conditions as occlusion, change in walking velocity and viewpoints. The framework would involve a pre-processing pipeline for the generation of TGEIs with a CNN deployed that specialises in feature extraction and classification. The trial tests conducted on benchmark gait databases have been found to be better in recognition, efficiency in computation, and robustness as compared to the conventional GEI-based techniques. This article indicates that feature refinement and deep learning are relevant to the future of the gait biometrics sector to advance into scalable and reliable solutions that may be applied in practice.

title: Comparative Study of Hydrogen-Based and Battery-Based Frequency Support in an HVDC Connected AC System
authors: Michael Graeme Gibson, Ryoichi Hara, Hiroyuki Kita, Nobuaki Kawashima
publish: 2025 IEEE PES 17th Asia-Pacific Power and Energy Engineering Conference (APPEEC)
abstract: The displacement of synchronous generators by inverter-based resources (IBRs) fundamentally reduces the physical inertia in alternating current (AC) power systems, posing significant challenges to frequency stability. This issue is particularly critical in networks connected via high voltage direct current (HVDC) systems, which do not inherently contribute to AC-side inertia. This paper presents a rigorous comparative analysis of battery energy storage systems (BESS) and hydrogen storage systems (HSS) in providing primary frequency support to an AC network. Using an AC system model with an embedded VSC-HVDC link developed in PSCAD/EMTDC, distinct operational scenarios are simulated: (1) an ideal grid-forming (GFM) inverter with an infinite DC source, (2) a GFM inverter supported by a BESS, and (3) a GFM inverter supported by an HSS. Each scenario is subjected to an identical, significant step-load disturbance to evaluate key performance indicators, including frequency nadir, Rate of Change of Frequency (RoCoF), and settling time. The results quantify the distinct dynamic characteristics of each technology, highlighting the rapid power-centric response of BESS and the slower, energy-centric capabilities of HSS. The discussion synthesizes these findings, providing data-driven insights into the strategic deployment of these technologies to enhance the resilience and operational security of modern AC power systems.

title: Regional Crop Yield Forecasting Using a Stacked Hybrid Model with Temporal Spatial Feature Fusion
authors: Dm Bhavana Gowda, K.S Arvind, M.N Nachappa
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Computing, Semiconductor, Mechatronics, Intelligent Systems and Communications (COSMIC)
abstract: Accurate and region-specific crop yield forecasting is vital for optimizing resources, guiding decisions, and reducing risks from climate variability. This paper proposes a stacked hybrid learning model that fuses temporal weather patterns and spatial satellite features using LSTM and CNN, alongside Linear Regression and Random Forest, with Gradient Boosting as the meta-learner. A region-specific dataset covering environmental, soil, crop management, and market factors across five seasons was used for evaluation. The model achieved an RMSE of $\mathbf{1 6. 9 2 ~ t} \boldsymbol{/} \mathbf{h a}$, an MAE of $\mathbf{1 3. 1 2 ~ t} \boldsymbol{/} \mathbf{h a}$, and an $\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$ of 0.89, outperforming the baseline approaches as well as recent state-of-the-art methods. These results demonstrate the effectiveness of integrating deep learning with traditional machine-learning techniques in an ensemble framework, providing a scalable and adaptable solution for precision agriculture and long-term food security.

title: GUARDIAN AI: Real-Time Threat Detection and Alerting System
authors: Jeshma S J, Bavesheya P, SudalaiMuthu T
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: In today's world, where security threats are increasingly complex, varied, and unpredictable, traditional surveillance methods that depend mostly on manual oversight fall short of providing timely and effective threat detection. Guardian AI is a surveillance solution powered by artificial intelligence that combines computer vision and deep learning approaches to facilitate automated, real-time identification of facial threats and multi-faceted alerting. The system continuously records live video, isolates facial areas, and matches them against a customized threat database defined by administrators using leading detection and recognition technologies. Upon detecting a potential threat, Guardian AI promptly alerts security personnel via an integrated voice assistant and SMS notification system, ensuring swift situational awareness and reaction. Additionally, the system features a crowdsourced update mechanism for threats, empowering authorized users to add new identities or modify existing entries, thus fostering continuous enhancement of the model and adaptive security intelligence. Experimental assessments indicate that Guardian AI achieves over 93% detection accuracy with minimal delays, validating its effectiveness for real-time implementation. The blend of high precision, scalability, and operational reliability establishes Guardian AI as a strong option for contemporary smart surveillance scenarios, aiding in proactive threat reduction across public, commercial, and institutional security frameworks.

title: A Novel Lightweight MobileGraphNet for Neonatal Hypoxic-Ischemic Encephalopathy Detection using Cranial Ultrasound Images
authors: Kundan Kumar, Saket Kumar Singh, K. Sridhar Patnaik, Rajeev Mishra, Rajeev Kumar Ranjan, M. Rajesh Kumar Rao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Early detection of Neonatal Hypoxic-Ischemic Encephalopathy can avoid long-term neurological disability and improve developmental outcomes. Transcranial ultrasound, due to its safety and portability, is the most widely used modality. However, diagnosis using Transcranial ultrasound has often been limited by inter-observer variability and subtle imaging features. The authors introduce MobileGraphNet, a lightweight deep learning model for automated HIE detection using cranial ultrasound images, which combines the strength of MobileNetV2, Grid Graph Convolution, and Multi-Head Self-Attention. The model captures both local texture and global spatial relationships, enhancing precision and interpretability. The performance of three different experimental settings-training from scratch, transfer learning, and fine-tuning with transfer learning-has been evaluated using a balanced neonatal ultrasound dataset. The optimal model achieved 99.4% test accuracy and an F1-score of 0.994, with a validation loss of approximately 0.03, significantly outperforming the benchmark CNN models. Finally, the optimized model was exported as a TensorFlow Lite (.tflite) file and integrated into an Android mobile application that can classify cranial ultrasound images in real-time and offline. These findings confirm the hypothesis that MobileGraphNet offers an accurate, efficient, and portable solution for early neonatal HIE detection and bridges the gap between research-grade deep learning and bedside clinical diagnosis.

title: Joint Optimization of UAV Trajectory and STAR-RIS Beamforming in NOMA Systems
authors: Haifeng Jia, Guangyu Li, Peng Gao, Jiapei Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: This paper presents a novel framework that integrates STAR-RIS with NOMA to improve system performance. The primary goal is to achieve the maximum of the overall sum rate. To tackle this aim, the original optimization problem is decomposed into three distinct subproblems: the beamforming design for STAR-RIS, the optimization of trajectory, and the power allocation. A penalty-based method is employed in the STAR-RIS beamforming subproblem to enhance beamforming efficiency and overall system performance. These subproblems are iteratively solved to obtain suboptimal solutions. Simulations validate that the proposed framework significantly outperforms traditional methods in terms of sum rate, yielding substantial gains in spectral efficiency and system performance.

title: Two Issues in Modelling Fish Migration
authors: Hidekazu Yoshioka
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Technological Solutions (ICAITech)
abstract: Fish migration is a dynamic phenomenon observed in many surface water bodies on the earth, while its understanding is still insufficient. Particularly, the biological mechanism behind fish migration is not fully understood. Moreover, its observation is often conducted visually and hence manually, raising questions of accuracy and interpretation of the data sampled. We address the two issues, mechanism and observation, of fish migration based on a recently developed mathematical model. The results obtained in this short paper show that fish migration can be characterized through a minimization principle and evaluate the error of its manual observations. The minimization principle we hypothesize is an optimal control problem where the migrating fish population dynamically changes its size and fluctuation. We numerically investigate alternating and intensive observation schemes as case studies, demonstrating that in some realistic conditions the estimate of total fish count is not reliable. We believe that this paper contributes to a deeper understanding of fish migration

title: Hybrid Deep Learning with Explainable AI for Multimodal Fake News Detection
authors: N. Bhuvaneswary, P Siva Kumar, Kunchepu Lokesh, Ponnathi Leela Krishna, Nambula Vinay Babu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: In the present generation, the extended spread of fake news across online platforms is a major threat to democratic processes, public health, and social stability. The existing methods for detecting fake news are purely dependent on text-based features, and all those methods ultimately fail to capture multimodal misinformation given to them, which contains both text and image-based information. To address these types of challenges, this work proposes a hybrid deep learning framework that integrates multimodal feature extraction along with an explainable artificial intelligence (AI Explainability) mechanism for the transparent and accurate classification of news. The Multi-Head Fusion Network (MHFN) acts as the core component of the system and has been designed to effectively integrate text and image embeddings through hybrid embedding techniques, including Word2Vec, TF-IDF, and PCA-based dimensionality reduction, which play key roles in accurate and precise classification. The framework further introduces a live news proof retrieval mechanism that validates news claims against multiple trusted sources through real-time API integration with SerperAPI, thereby enhancing the credibility of the detection process with fresh, comprehensive proofs. The explainability layer provides detailed prediction-based reasoning, which helps end-users understand model decisions. The system demonstrates strong potential for real-time deployment, combining detection accuracy with explainability and a dynamic fact verification process, offering a robust solution to combat multimodal misinformation.

title: Multi-AUV Collaborative Roundup Position Allocation Based on Improved Auction-Particle Swarm Optimisation Algorithm
authors: Guotao Ren, Wenyang Gan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Control and Computing Science (ICICCS)
abstract: Aiming at the position allocation problem of multiple Autonomous Underwater Vehicles (AUVs) cooperatively rounding up moving targets, this paper proposes a hybrid optimization strategy that integrates the auction algorithm and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO). Firstly, an allocation model with AUV energy consumption and sailing distance as the optimisation objectives is established, and the fitness function is constructed using multi-objective optimisation theory. Second, a fast allocation method based on the cumulative auction algorithm is designed to ensure real-time performance. To further improve the overall performance of the allocation scheme, particle swarm algorithm is introduced for global optimisation search. To solve the problem that the PSO algorithm tends to fall into local optimum, an auction-particle swarm hybrid optimisation algorithm is proposed by using the auction algorithm to generate a high-quality initial population. Simulation results show that the proposed hybrid algorithm is better than the standard PSO algorithm and auction algorithm in terms of allocation adaptability and scheme quality, and is able to effectively achieve the collaborative position allocation of multiple AUVs, which verifies its effectiveness and superiority.

title: GeoAI-Platform: A Web-Based Microservice Architecture for Democratizing Geospatial Intelligence
authors: Amine Belaabed, Rayan Atoui, Ayoub Dadda, Tighlit Amir Moncef, Mohammed El Amin Larabi, Meziane Iftene
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Innovative Applications (AIIA)
abstract: The increasing volume of Earth Observation (EO) data presents a transformative opportunity for national development in sectors such as agriculture and urban planning. However, the operational complexity of traditional Geographic Information Systems (GIS) creates a significant bottleneck, restricting access to actionable insights for non-specialist decision-makers. This paper introduces the GeoAI-Platform, a modern, web-based system designed to bridge this gap by democratizing access to geospatial intelligence. We present a scalable microservice architecture grounded in principles of distributed systems and human-computer interaction. The architecture is organized into three distinct layers—Interaction, Orchestration, and Intelligence—which separate the user-facing interface, service coordination, and high-performance computation. The platform enables two core workflows: (1) on-demand AI analysis from user-defined Regions of Interest (ROIs), and (2) dynamic integration of user-provided imagery. As a proof of concept, the architecture was validated by fine-tuning two state-of-the-art foundation models (Prithvi and Satlas), which were combined using a Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) approach for cereal crop detection. The ensemble model achieved a Mean Intersection-over-Union (mIoU) of 95.74%, outperforming the individual models. The system is designed to be extensible, providing a clear pathway for integrating additional large-scale AI models for diverse geospatial tasks.

title: Advancements in Deep Learning Techniques for Automatic Text Assessment
authors: Naman Kalra, Shefali Singhal, Ritika Dhami, Prateek Biswas, Shivani Kuntal
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: Evaluating free-text answers is one of the toughest challenges in education because manual grading is slow, inconstant and difficult to scale. As online learning grows, there is a clear need for fair and reliable AI-based assessment tools. This research introduces a system that uses the DeBERTa-v3-small transformer model to automatically score question-answer (QA) pairs. Instead of assigning fixed categories, our approach predicts continuous scores, making it closer to how humans grade. We trained the model on $40-50$ QA pairs from various subjects, applying careful preprocessing and normalization for accuracy. The results show that our system performs better than traditional methods and even standard BERT-based models, achieving lower error rates. While it works well for factual and structured answers, it struggles with subjective or partially correct responses, indicating to the need for more explainable and fair AI tools. Overall, this work spotlight the promise of transformer-based regression models in making educational assessment more scalable, consistent, and unbiased while also indicating toward future improvements in multilingual, multi-modal, and transparent grading systems.

title: Structure-Guided Semantic Attribute Transfer in Diffusion Models
authors: Dasol Jeong, Donggoo Kang, Hasil Park, Joonki Paik
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: We present a training-free framework for reference-guided style transfer using diffusion models. Our method preserves the structural layout of a source image while injecting semantic attributes—such as facial components in humans or fur texture in animals—from a reference image. To achieve this, we introduce a stage-wise latent injection strategy that dis-entangles the editing process into structure-preserving and attribute-integrating phases. By manipulating the internal attention layers across timesteps, our method enables local-ized and semantically aligned attribute transfer without the need for task-specific fine-tuning or external supervision. Our training-free setting refers specifically to the absence of any task-specific fine-tuning on the pre-trained diffusion model. Additionally, we incorporate null-text inversion to reinforce identity consistency during sampling. Experimental results demonstrate high-quality style transfer with strong structure-attribute separation across varied domains.

title: Pharmaceutical Quality Assurance via Transformer-Based Deep Learning Models Forautomated Tablet Defect Detection
authors: Shivamma D, Shaila S G, George Fernandez I, Navya R, Santhosh Kumar G, Latha Anuj
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Pharmaceutical tablet quality is a key factor in patient safety and regulatory requirements. Conventional visual inspection techniques are subjective, timeconsuming, and error prone. The research suggests a Vision Transformer (ViT)-based deep learning model to automate tablet defect detection with an objective of detecting surface-level defects like cracks, discoloration, scratches, and contamination. The new approach utilizes the self-attention mechanism of ViT to acquire finegrained spatial information and context-aware representation, allowing accurate defect classification. The model is trained on a labeled set of high-resolution tablet images and attains an impressive accuracy of 98 %, surpassing traditional convolutional neural networks (CNNs) in classification performance and generalization. Evaluation metrics such as ROC curves, precision-recall analysis, and F1-score heatmaps confirm the model's robustness. This method provides an expandable, noninvasive, and real-time solution that is appropriate for implementation in contemporary pharmaceutical production lines. The research cites the promise of transformer-based structures in improving quality control systems in Industry 4.0 platforms.

title: High-Fidelity Coffee Plant Detection Using Yolov8 in Precision Agriculture
authors: Tharaniesh P R, Sai Ananya Yeditha, Nishanth P R, Suthir, Nivethitha
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Coffee cultivation requires automated monitoring systems to address the growing demand projected at 166.63 million bags by 2025. This paper presents an enhanced YOLOv8 architecture incorporating Squeeze-and-Excitation attention mechanisms and agricultural-specific loss functions for coffee plant detection. Our methodology introduces novel modifications including multi-scale feature enhancement, adaptive anchor optimization, and domain-specific data augmentation strategies. The proposed system achieves 95.2% mean Average Precision (mAP) on our curated dataset of 5,000 high-resolution coffee plant images, representing a 7.8% improvement over standard YOLOv8. Experimental validation demonstrates robust performance across diverse lighting conditions, plant growth stages, and plantation environments. The integration of attention mechanisms reduces false positives by 23% while maintaining real-time processing capabilities suitable for automated agricultural monitoring systems.

title: Study on powder forming characteristics under the condition of forced feeding-pressing synchronization
authors: Tianhao Feng, Wenzhen Zhong, Ziyun Chen, Guoping Li, Shu Li, Kexin Zhao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Measurement Control and Instrumentation (MCAI)
abstract: To address common challenges in powder forming—such as insufficient compact density, difficult degassing, and low production efficiency—this study introduces a synchronized forced-feeding and compaction process. A self-developed transparent apparatus was used to conduct die-filling and compaction tests on three powders with distinct flow characteristics. Under the single-stage forced-feeding compaction scheme, the effects of filling time and screw pitch on compaction quality were examined, along with the temporal evolution of torque and compaction force. The results indicate that for powders with better flowability, increasing the filling time and reducing the screw pitch both significantly improve compaction quality. In contrast, the influence of screw pitch on compaction quality is less pronounced for powders with poorer flowability.

title: Three-phase Four-wire Photovoltaic Grid Connected Inverter Based on Repetitive Control
authors: Zhong Yongkai, Zhang Zhi, Zhu Anan
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Smart Grid and Clean Energy Technologies (ICSGCE)
abstract: In the control strategy of photovoltaic grid connected inverters, traditional centralized control is difficult to cope with grid imbalance and harmonic interference. This study focuses on three-phase T-type three-level inverters and proposes a grid connected control strategy based on repetitive control of each phase's independent control, achieving independent and precise regulation of the grid connected current of each phase under unbalanced power grid conditions. Finally, the feasibility of the proposed scheme was verified based on MATLAB/Simulink simulation platform, which can stably control the DC bus voltage and maintain strict phase synchronization between the current and voltage of each phase even under unbalanced power grid conditions.

title: Machine Learning-Powered Fault Detection Method for High-Voltage Transmission Lines
authors: B Mallikarjuna, Y.D. Shahakar, Thogai Rani B, Gokul Talele, S. Dhivya, S Arulkumar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Transmission lines Power systems have high-voltage transmission lines which are both very important and undetected faults may cause serious outage, equipment damages, and safety risks. To overcome this obstacle, this paper suggests a fault detection system based on machine learning with the Random Forest (RF) algorithm as the main solution. Random Forest is chosen due to its strength, high classification rate and its capability to deal with the non-linear data trends that are common in the power system fault signals. It uses previously processed wavelet transform on the current and voltage waveforms to utilize data gathered on both current and voltage to extract features effectively. The RF model is then used in order to classify the extracted features to detect fault type and location in real time. The main tool used in this research is MATLAB with Scikit-learn library of Python to develop, simulate and validate the models. The results of the experiments prove the method is highly accurate, with a high detection rate, and high adaptability, making transmission networks much more reliable.

title: Optimization of Signal Processing - Based Dadda Multiplier for Efficient Multiplication in Digital Signal Processing Applications
authors: Hubert Mary. L, Celine Kavida
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: High-performance Digital Signal Processing (DSP) applications, particularly in real-time systems, require efficient multiplication, particularly audio filtering, image processing and communication protocols. The classical multipliers such as the Dadda, Wallace and Booth designs though functionally valid have drawbacks, in terms of limiting dynamic power, delay, and area scalability under DSP-type workloads. This paper is proposing an Optimized Signal Processing-Based Dadda Multiplier (OSPD-M) that integrates signal-path-conscious partial product suppression, adaptively compressed compressor-based reduction trees, operand isolation, and delay-balanced pipelining to maximize speed and energy efficiency. The novelty is in identifying redundant operand patterns dynamically to disabled the unnecessary blocks of computation and using hybrid (3:2, 4:2, 5:2) compressors selectively depending on signal density. The architecture was coded in Verilog and synthesized on 45nm CMOS platform, and tested by embedding into a 64-tap FIR filter to benchmark at application level. Comparative 10 operand width results indicate that OSPD-M has an average delay reduction of 21.9, dynamic power reduction of 23.6 and area reduction of 14.7 over conventional Dadda multipliers. Also, during DSP application testing, the design achieved a fixed-point simulation environment execution accuracy of 98.92% and no loss of functional correctness. All these enhancements make OSPD-M an appropriate candidate in the power-sensitive machine-on-chip (DSP) in embedded and IoT platforms. It is scalable, FPGA/ASIC-friendly, design. The study shows that architectural and signal-aware optimization can make a substantial contribution to energy-delay-area trade-offs that are so critical in the present DSP environment.

title: BreathX: A Multi-Modal AI Framework for Lung Cancer Detection and Tumor Monitoring
authors: Milind Rane, Omkar Shinde, Shrey Rai, Shreyash Mutha, Rohan Shelke
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Lung cancer remains among the major causes of cancer-related deaths in the world, mainly due to the fact that it tends to be diagnosed late and there is limited access to specialty diagnostic facilities. The introduction of artificial intelligence (AI) and deep learning methods has revolutionized the medical diagnostics field, particularly in terms of identifying early illness and patient interaction. This piece of writing presents BreathX, which is a machine learning platform that seeks to enable the detection of lung cancer through MRI scan analysis. The software simultaneously has a chat-based chatbot with the ability to give personalized health advice for the improvement of patient engagement and care. With the aid of innovative deep learning techniques married to an intuitive, easy-to-use interface, BreathX is looking to speed up and make more accurate the diagnosis of lung cancer while providing users with applicable, related information. The product might close gaps in diagnosis access that presently exist and provide proactive health control by means of smart, automated guidance.

title: AI-Powered Blockchain-Backed System for Cross-Media Deepfake and Forgery Detection
authors: Swathi N Pai, Sharanya S Parol, R Riya, Bavith L Suvarna, Mustafa Basthikodi
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Computing, Semiconductor, Mechatronics, Intelligent Systems and Communications (COSMIC)
abstract: The amount of deepfake content generated by advanced deep learning models is rising, posing a threat to cybersecurity and digital authenticity. Deepfakes can now fool both human perception and traditional detection systems by manipulating images, sound, video, and signatures. To tackle this challenge,this paper introduces DeepLock, a unified artificial intelligence-powered framework that can recognize deepfake content in four essential modalities: images, audio, video, and handwritten signatures. The system employs a Convolutional Recurrent Neural Network (CRNN) for audio deepfakes based on Log-Mel spectogram features, a specially built ExceptionNet for image forgery detection, and a ResNet18 model optimized for both video frame analysis and signature verification, using different architectures for each modality. Experimental results on benchmark datasets show how accurate and generalizable DeepLock is, which makes it appropriate for forensic applications, identity verification, and real-time content validation.

title: An IoT-Integrated Image Processing System for Real-Time Skin Tone and Hyperpigmentation Assessment
authors: Vinoth Selvamani, R. Gopiha Shri, B. Amirtha Varshini, G. Devathai
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Skin tone and pigmentation assessment are critical diagnostic parameters in dermatology and cosmetic science. Conventional clinical evaluation relies on manual observation, which is often subjective and inconsistent under varying illumination conditions. Hyperpigmentation, caused by localized melanin overproduction due to ultraviolet exposure, hormonal imbalances, or inflammation, requires continuous monitoring for an early diagnosis. Recent advances in the Internet of Things (IoT) and artificial intelligence (AI) have enabled smart, low-cost systems for real-time skin analysis. This paper presents a low-cost IoT-integrated image processing system employing an ESP32-CAM module for image acquisition, uniform LED illumination for consistent lighting, and a cloud-based server for automated pigmentation evaluation. to perform color normalization, segmentation of region and melanin index computation the image captured is transmitted over Wi-Fi to a python-based server by applying OpenCV algorithms. This system provides 92% of accuracy and latency response is below 1.5s. The results of experiment trails prove the device offers better reproducibility for different skin types and across various illuminations. The potential gateway for tele dermatology is opened by using this system, which also provides cost effective and home-based dermatology monitor.

title: A Review of Grid-Forming Inverter Validation across Distribution, Transmission, and T–D Integrated Networks
authors: Yihe Liu, Nirmal-Kumar C. Nair, Kevin I-Kai Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE PES 17th Asia-Pacific Power and Energy Engineering Conference (APPEEC)
abstract: High renewable penetration has reduced system inertia and challenged grid stability, driving demand for advanced inverter technologies. Grid-forming inverters (GFMs) have emerged as a key solution, offering voltage and frequency regulation, inertia response, fault ride-through, and black-start capability. This paper reviews their principles, distinctions from grid-following (GFL) inverters, control strategies, and validation across distribution, transmission, and integrated transmission–distribution (T–D) networks. Control strategies include droop-based, synchronous-machine-emulation, oscillator-based, and emerging hybrid or AI-driven methods. Validation spans simulations, HIL testing, and large-scale projects such as Hornsdale, Dalrymple BESS, and SuperFACTS. Findings show that GFMs enhance stability, improve transient performance, and enable seamless GFM–GFL transitions. Remaining challenges include T–D interface modelling, cross-scale validation, and market integration, calling for future efforts in model standardisation, broader validation, and stronger TSO–DSO coordination to ensure reliable and economic deployment.

title: Uncovering Key Cognitive Traits for Placement Success: A Multi-Dimensional Data Mining Approach
authors: D V H Venu Kumar, Rapeti Deepthi, Sudhakar Godi, C P Pavan Kumar Hota, Polinati Vinod Babu, V.Priyadarshani
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: The process of placement in institutions of higher learning plays a very important role in determining the employability of graduates. This paper is intended to establish the prevailing cognitive variables across different stages in the placement such as Quantitative Aptitude Test (QAT), Verbal and Non-Verbal Reasoning (VNR), Computer Proficiency Test (CPT), Programming and Coding Test (PCT), English Communication Test (ECT), Technical Round (TR) and the HR Round (HR). It suggests a new model, which is a combination of the Mean Difference-Based Clustering algorithm and Technique for Order Preference by Similarity to Ideal Solution (TOPSIS) to analyze cognitive profiles holistically. This paper analyzes the data of engineering learners, which gathers attributes of multiple intelligences, learning styles, thinking styles, metacognitive awareness, and personality. Once the data has been properly prepared, similarities among students in terms of cognitive abilities and constraints are found through the help of clustering algorithms. This is followed by the ranking of cognitive qualities based on the TOPSIS (Technique order preference by similarity to ideal solution) technique in which the cognitive qualities with the highest influence on the success of placement are emphasized. The comparison shows essential psychological and cognitive traits differentiating successful candidates that can give valuable information to develop a personalized solution. Through the systematic rating of cognitive qualities and the classification of learners according to several dimensions of preparedness, this study offers a structured, data-driven framework to improve placement outcomes. Because the suggested methodology is reproducible and scalable, it may be used in a variety of educational settings and adapts to changing industry demands by matching student cognitive profiles.

title: Assessing Research Quality in Academic Institutions Using Google Scholar Metrics
authors: Gangula Sai Sudha, Neerudi Uday Kumar, Rupavath Anil, Vivek Kulkarni, Ganesh B. Regulwar, B. Swapna
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: Assessment of research quality at academic institutions is critical in enhancing institutional rankings, promoting innovation, and informing evidence-based decision-making. The design and implementation of a web-based platform for the automation of the evaluation of research performance from publicly accessible Google Scholar metrics are presented in this paper. The system responds to the requirement of effective data collection and analysis by pulling out citation-based metrics like total citations, h-index, and i10-index from faculty profiles. These are then classified into quartile levels (Q1-Q4) in relation to journal quality, enabling institutions to assess departmental research productivity in an organized and comparative way. The architecture of the platform combines web scraping methodologies for data harvesting, Python for data processing, and React.js for frontend interaction. Data is displayed through interactive dashboards that present department-wise averages and allow users to drill down into faculty-specific contributions within a quartile. The solution further includes fall-back mechanisms to deal with missing or inconsistent information and uses optimized scraping frequencies to adhere to web access restrictions. The system suggested offers an institutional research analysis with a scalable and visually appealing method. Translating disjointed citation data into actionable visual understandings, the platform allows academic administrators to track research trends, discover high-performing departments, and aid accreditation or strategic planning purposes. The combination of automation and visualization dramatically decreases man hours, increases transparency, and facilitates informed academic governance.

title: Design and Implementation of a Microcontroller Based Real Time Carbon Emission Monitoring System
authors: Snehal Rathi, Vijayshri Khedkar, Yash Satyavijay Baraskar, Shravani Kurkute
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: Methods that are real-time and affordable for monitoring and regulating carbon dioxide emissions of internal combustion engine vehicles are urgently needed as environmental pollution from vehicle emissions is becoming a major concern. A microcontroller AT89C51 (8051) is the core of the conceptual system and the implementation in the paper that is used & record the vehicle speed and the amount of fuel used. Fuel consumption is determined from standard mileage and the distance is calculated from a Hall effect sensor. Then the carbon emission is calculated from the emission factor and displayed in real-time on an LCD. To educate drivers and make them ecofriendly driving practices, a buzzer is provided in the apparatus that gets activated when the emission level crosses the set limit. The system is simulated with Proteus software and its installation is a demonstration of how it can be integrated into cheap, portable emission monitoring devices suitable for old non-OBD cars.

title: Deepfake Identification Strategies for Secure Cyberspace Engagement
authors: Shravanpuri Goswami, Santosh Saha, Happy
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: The emerging threat of deepfake technology allows creation of highly realistic synthetic media with major implications for digital communication security, enabling manipulation for misinformation, identity theft, and fraud. This paper provides a comprehensive and comparative overview of the latest algorithms proposed for detecting deepfakes, categorized into four types: deep-learning based, biological signals, frequency domain, and hybrid algorithms. We evaluate performance on benchmark datasets (FaceForensics++, DFDC, Celeb-DF) using metrics like AUC-ROC, computational complexity, and generalization ability. Deep-learning based methods perform well on individual datasets but degrade with cross-dataset generalization or adversarial examples. Attention-based methods show improved robustness, with DSP-FWA achieving AUC of 0.930 on FaceForensics++. This paper discusses security considerations and suggests a framework for protective structures in digital communication.

title: LightRAG-Enhanced Automated Question Generation System for Multi-Domain Educational Assessments
authors: Denver G. Magtibay, Debashis Guha
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: This paper presents an enhanced Automated Question Generation (AQG) system that integrates the LightRAG framework to improve accuracy, contextual relevance, and adaptability across multiple educational domains. Unlike traditional Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) models, LightRAG incorporates graph-based text indexing and a duallevel retrieval mechanism, enabling more precise and logically structured question generation. The system is deployed via a Streamlit-based graphical user interface, allowing document upload, multi-topic exam generation, and export of questions in a Canvas-compatible DOCX format for seamless Learning Management System (LMS) integration. A total of 240 multiplechoice questions (MCQs), spanning Electronics Engineering and Engineering Sciences, were evaluated by subject matter experts and large language models (LLMs), including ChatGPT, Gemini, and DeepSeek. Results show that the Hybrid LightRAG model outperforms the Naïve LightRAG model in terms of accuracy, diversity, and cognitive alignment. The system consistently achieved 100 % ratings in relevance, grammatical correctness, and Bloom’s Taxonomy alignment across both domains, confirming its effectiveness as a scalable tool for generating high-quality educational assessments.

title: Intelligent Design and Evaluation of Aesthetic Education Courses Empowered by Digital Technology
authors: Shiqi Chen
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: A modern digital platform serves as a current solution for aesthetic education development by employing contemporary technology which eliminates conventional teaching approaches. The system designs interactive learning spaces which link cognitive intelligence methods to emotional learning via augmented reality and virtual reality systems with haptic interaction and gesture-based HCI methods. Technology uses virtual spaces to build better platforms where art students can interact and create new art studios and professional performance platforms which improve artistic participation. Artistic content production occurs through the continual framework adaptation process which gathers student aptitude alongside educational data and preference inputs from students. Deceptively the produced content maintains regular quality standards thanks to the implemented user requirements. The integration of pain exam data with content difficulty attributes lets PSO determine suitable educational methods that guide learning sequences and pacing to produce individual learning plans that keep students informed and attentive to their studies. AI assessment processes linked with the system create immediate feedback through evaluations of creative outputs such as visual works and written comments and performance data. Robotic systems for creative education deliver immediate tutorial programs and practical support which assists dance and sculpture teaching. Through interactive sessions the system delivers custom aesthetic instruction to boost creativity together with conceptual acquisition in digital learning environments.

title: Human-Centric AI Emotion Recognition to Enhance Collaboration in Industry 5.0 Smart Factories
authors: Kala Karuthedath, Rahul K M, Ramalakshmi R D, Dharshini P, Pavithra S, Athira S
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: As Industry 5.0 emerges, human-centric work in collaboration with intelligent machines is a needed aspect of work where emotion recognition will be critical in ensuring productivity, safety, and well-being. To overcome shortcomings of single-modality and high-latency systems, it proposes a multimodal AI-based framework incorporating computation of facial, speech, and physiological modalities in a robust manner and with low-latency real-time emotion recognition. A reinforcement learning-based hybrid CNNBiLSTM model is proposed to code emotional states and dynamically optimize the allocation of humans and robots in tasks. The proposed model has an accuracy of 96.7%, F1-score of 95.4% and a lower real-time latency of 70ms, thus remarkably better reliability than previously suggested methods. Along with emotion-based collaboration, a 14.2% reduction in error was observed, a 92.9% index of worker satisfaction, and a 95.9% index of collaboration, which increased flexibility in smart factories. The results indicate that AI-powered desiring machines based on the recognition of human emotions can turn Industry 5.0 factories into environmentally-aware, resilient, and human-friendly eco-systems.

title: Decentralized Voting System Using Blockchain
authors: Swapnil Shinde, Anand Sharma, Riya Shete, Kalyani Bonde
publish: 2025 IEEE Pune Section International Conference (PuneCon)
abstract: A secure voting system using blockchain leverages decentralized ledger technology to improve the integrity, transparency, and security of the electoral process. Using smart contracts coded in Solidity, the system performs such critical functions as candidate enrollment, voter registration, vote casting, and result aggregation automatically. Each vote is recorded safely on the blockchain, making it almost impossible to tamper with and guaranteeing that each user votes only once. The integration of tools such as HardHat streamlines smart contract testing and deployment, while MetaMask provides secure authentication and transaction signing. The frontend, which is developed using React.js, offers real-time updates and an interactive user interface. Automating vote management and providing public verifiability through blockchain-based voting systems enhances trust, minimizes fraud, and simplifies operations, providing a cost-efficient and future-proofed solution for electoral management.

title: Enhancing Data Privacy in IoT-Enabled Healthcare Systems through Federated Learning and Secure Data Fusion
authors: Ismail Almsallati, Hari Mohan Singh
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: The rapid advancement of IoT capability for healthcare has facilitated the continuous monitoring of patients though it raises significant privacy issues given a centralized model for data handling. In this framework, Hybrid Federated Secure Data Fusion (HF-SDF), integrates federated learning and secure data fusion to decentralize model training and protect patient anonymity. The proposed solution uses the Secure Healthcare IoT Monitoring Dataset with physiological and network metrics from 2,000 patients. Each client is responsible for local training and shaping of features, and an encrypted summary of updates is securely compiled. Limitations included computational overhead and an inability to manage any non-IID data. Both implementation and evaluation and evaluation were undertaken using Python. The performance evaluation indicated a global model accuracy of 96.8% which is substantially better than existing approaches. The HFSDF protects patient privacy through its decentralized nature; it has the potential create a scalable and robust process that is resistant to adversarial threats.

title: Steel Tensile Strength Prediction Using Optimized LightGBM and Bias-Aware Data Preprocessing
authors: Vinora A, Nithin Prasanth N, Ajey Suthan V N G
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: The purpose of the research was to model tensile strength of steel appropriately with an optimized Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LightGBM) model and a bias aware preprocessing pipeline. The dataset contains a strong and significant set of steel style grades, chemical contents and processing parameters. Being an exploratory data analysis it was evident that there were biases due to the variation in measurements themselves and the distribution of the supporting features. The variety of preprocessing strategies and steps developed to counter the biases included outlier detection (Mahalanobis distance), feature normalization, and sampling techniques to balance the distribution of significant features. The LightGBM model was also optimized via hyperparameter tuning for learning rate, max depth, regularization strength and feature fraction ratios. Model accuracy was evaluated on the hold-out test set by R2, RMSE, and MAE. Our best performing model reached <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}2=0.92,\text{RMSE }=15$</tex> MPa, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{MAE }=11$</tex> MPa. The optimized LightGBM model performed better than our benchmark models; Linear regression and Random Forest (R2 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=0.75$</tex> to 0.85). Also utilized Shapley Additive explanations (SHAP) to determine the most significant features, with carbon equivalent, final carbon content, prior austenite grain diameter, and cooling rate being the most significant predictive features. Sensitivity analyses showed that the model was robust, and Also reporting different bias correction methods.

title: Thermal Image Based Breast Cancer Analysis Using Otsu's Thresholding and Deep Transfer Learning
authors: K. Vijayakumar, Kohinoor Pervin, Yashashwini S, J. Sakthi Priya, P. Aadhirai, Blessy. S
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: The disease happening rate in human kind is gradually rising in alarming rate and early detection is and treatment is essential. In women, the breast-cancer (BC) is recognised to be a harsh disease and it will lead to various health complications including the death. The BC can be diagnosed using medical imaging procedures, in which non-invasive approaches are considered for early detection and invasive procedures are considered for confirming the BC and its stage. Manual examination of the BC is a time consuming process and hence, this work proposed a deep-learning (DL) scheme for analysing the benign/malignant BC from the thermal images. The various phases of this technique involve in; data collection from the repository and cropping the breast region from the considered images, Otsu's based image enhancement, deep-features extraction from the images and implementing the SoftMax-classifier based detection and generation of fused-features (FF) using best two model features, and classification and performance verification using 3 -fold cross validation. This research considered 800 images per class and it helps in achieving >95.5% accuracy.

title: Deep Learning-Based Automated Detection and Classification of Ovarian Cancer from Medical Imaging
authors: Rajendran Sivakumar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Ovarian cancer remains one of the most lethal types of gynaecological cancer because it advances asymptomatically and is often identified at an advanced stage. Early and precise identification is a critical to maintain health. Recent advancements in artificial intelligence (AI), especially deep learning (DL), have shown significant potential for enhancing computer-aided diagnosis and medical picture analysis. This study presents a DL-based system for the automated detection and classification of ovarian cancer utilising medical imaging techniques. The extraction of distinguishing features and categorisation of benign and malignant cases with high precision is achieved through the use of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and transfer learning techniques. The proposed approach is evaluated using publicly accessible datasets and clinical datasets, demonstrating superior performance relative to traditional machine learning (ML) methods in accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity. DL models possess the capability to serve as valuable, dependable, and scalable instruments that can aid radiologists in the early detection and classification of ovarian cancer. This will ultimately enhance patient outcomes and facilitate tailored treatment planning. The results underscore the potential of deep learning methods.

title: Smart IoT-ML Ecosystem for Dynamic Pest Surveillance in Food Storage Environments
authors: V V Vidya, G Prapulla, Suhas A Bhyratae, B V Poornima
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Computing, Semiconductor, Mechatronics, Intelligent Systems and Communications (COSMIC)
abstract: Infestations of pests in food storage facilities can compromise food safety by causing contamination, monetary losses, and health risks. Conventional pest management techniques, such manual inspections, are frequently ineffective and do not allow for real-time monitoring. For effective insect identification, we suggest an IoT and machine learning-based architecture that combines cutting-edge hardware elements with real-time picture processing. The system makes use of OpenCV for preprocessing images, YOLOv8 for accurate insect detection, IoT sensors (DHT11, MQ135) for ambient monitoring, and a buzzer for alerts. An ESP32 microcontroller manages data processing, and a MySQL database running on XAMPP stores the data. By providing a 95% detection accuracy and an automated, economical solution, this framework improves food storage safety and operating efficiency.

title: Effective Rank-Based Layer-Wise Low-Rank Approximation for LLMs
authors: Boning Li, Lin Liu, Yanjie Xu, Zongyu Yin, Jiangqi Shao, Yifan Hong
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Post-training compression of large language models (LLMs) is moving from heuristic ratios toward interpretable, layer-wise policies. We propose a unified, training-free low-rank pipeline that (i) uses an information-theoretic effective rank to set the retained rank k per layer, (ii) constructs layer-wise second-order statistics from a WikiText-2 calibration set (256×4096) and applies right-multiplicative whitening to obtain a better-conditioned factorization domain, (iii) performs SVD on the whitened weight WL and maps the approximation back to the original domain via right-multiplying L<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−1</sup>, and (iv) realizes deployment as two linear factors by splitting the truncated diagonal term. On LLaMA-2-7B, we systematically evaluate decompositions of Gate, Up, Down, and their combinations by using perplexity (PPL), and activation-distribution statistics. Under the same effective-rank policy, whitened-domain decomposition is more robust (e.g., PPL 7.45→≈8.02) than direct decomposition in the original domain (PPL up to 8.38); effective rank serves as a practical lower bound for singular-value retention, offering a consistent, transferable truncation starting point across layers; and clear layer heterogeneity emerges that Gate/Up are more amenable to low-rank approximation, whereas Down is more sensitive and benefits from larger k or conservative handling. Rather than pursuing extreme compression, this work validates the compressibility boundary of LLM weights and provides an interpretable truncation policy, forming a clean interface and engineering baseline for composite compression with quantization, pruning, and distillation.

title: GPU-Based Large Planning Model for Mega-Constellations
authors: Peiyun Li, Zhanpeng Xu, Song Xie, Xi Cai, Linghui Yu
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: With the rapid development of large-scale remote sensing constellations, their sizes have experienced explosive growth, posing significant challenges to both the dynamic and variable nature and timeliness requirements of satellite mission planning. Traditional ground-based constellation control methods are becoming less flexible and increasingly costly. However, the emergence of large language models (LLMs) offers a promising solution for autonomous mission planning in large constellations, reflecting a future development trend. These LLMs can intelligently interpret task requirements and perform mission planning through tool invocation. The key to their feasibility lies in the timeliness of planning for large-scale constellations. To address this issue, a mathematical model for mission planning was developed by comprehensively considering factors such as observational benefits, resource consumption, and balanced observation opportunities for targets. A high-efficiency model algorithm based on GPU parallel acceleration was proposed. This method utilizes custom GPU operators for fast parallel computation of large-scale objective functions and incorporates tensorized improvements to evolutionary strategies, adapting them to the GPU parallel computing architecture. Experimental results demonstrate that this approach can converge within hours for large-scale mission planning problems involving millions of observation windows, providing critical support to solve mission planning challenges in mega-constellations.

title: Application of Transmission Line Method in Characterizing the Conductive Materials in Frequency Domain
authors: Rakesh Kichouliya, Saurabh Kichouliya, Sandeep M Satav
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Electromagnetic Interference and Compatibility (INCEMIC)
abstract: Conductive materials such as EMI gaskets and fabrics are widely employed in equipment under test (EUT) to suppress electromagnetic interference (EMI) by ensuring electrical continuity across metallic interfaces. EMI gaskets specifically reduce field leakage at joints. While shielding effectiveness (SE) is the standard metric, it is often assessed without considering integration into the EUT. This study experimentally characterizes EMI gaskets and conductive fabrics up to 1.5 GHz using the transmission line method, focusing on electrical conductivity and surface impedance as key parameters in addition to SE, for high-altitude electromagnetic pulse (HEMP) protection, which involves frequencies up to 1 GHz.

title: Blockchain Based Secure Threat Detection Model for Industrial IoT Applications
authors: Varsha Prafull Patil, Sharada N. Ohatkar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: Securing data in the Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) is critical due to the growing complexity and scale of industrial networks. Integrating Ethereum-based blockchain technology offers a promising solution by leveraging distributed ledgers to enhance the transparency, immutability, and security of IIoT systems. This study aims to enhance threat detection and data protection in IIoT environments through blockchain integration. To achieve this, the proposed approach incorporates Dynamic Threat Landscape (DTL)-based Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) for real-time attack modelling, enabling systems to adapt to evolving threats. However, integrating blockchain with IIoT also presents challenges, including ensuring low latency for real-time processing, scalability to manage large volumes of sensor data, and maintaining robust cybersecurity while preserving data privacy and integrity. Addressing these concerns is essential for the effective deployment of blockchain-enabled threat detection in IIoT networks.
